title: Extradition Ordered for Italian Financier
description: A Federal judge today ordered the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, one-time owner of the MGM studios, to be extradited to France, where he faces charges of fraud, theft and embezzlement.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Suspect Commits Suicide
description: The 1995 BMW convertible Stephen Frierson was driving turned out to be stolen, but the police say they never had a chance to arrest him. Moments after Mr. Frierson, 22, was pulled over on West Market Street late Thursday, he placed a 9-millimeter gun against his right temple and fired, the Newark police said yesterday. Immediately afterward, he was shot by a state trooper, Rory Mitchell, who thought Mr. Frierson might fire at him. That bullet grazed Mr. Frierson's face, the police said. The Essex County Medical Examiner issued a preliminary ruling of suicide.

title: Secretary Brown Insisted on Flight Despite Storm Risk, a Friend Says
description: Only hours before his death in a plane crash on a storm-swept Croatian mountaintop last month, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown called a former business partner and said he had overruled staff members who were worried that it was dangerous to fly into Croatia because of treacherous weather, the former business partner said today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday, listing the Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans that would be the largest if all announced mergers were completed, misidentified the No. 1 plan in some editions. It would be the merger of Pennsylvania Blue Shield and Blue Cross of Western Pennsylvania.

title: Mayor Urges Breakup of Port Authority
description: Continuing his campaign against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed breaking up the authority yesterday, calling on New York State to take over some of its functions and to create a new agency to operate the city's two airports, now run by the authority.

title: Company Briefs
description: ALPHARMA INC., Fort Lee, N.J., which makes generic pharmaceuticals, said it would take an after-tax charge of $9 million, or 40 cents a share, this year to cover the cost of moving production and cutting about 250 jobs.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN AMERICA;In Reactions, Jewish Groups Echo the Split Of the Results
description: Rabbi Avi Weiss, leader of the Coalition for Jewish Concerns and of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale in the Bronx and a hawk on the issue of how to insure Israel's security, said yesterday that he was "absolutely ecstatic" over the results of the Israeli election.

title: Thousands to Rally in Capital on Children's Behalf
description: With both parties claiming the mantle of family values, a rally this weekend to lament the plight of children in America has become an election-year battleground.

title: F.B.I. Calls In Armored Cars Over Standoff
description: Expressing frustration with a two-month-old stalemate in negotiations at the Freemen ranch, the Federal Bureau of Investigation moved armored emergency vehicles into this area today and said they might be needed for rescues at the ranch or if the bureau decided to occupy parts of it.

title: More Overstatement Found For Inflation in Price Index
description: A panel of private economists appointed by Congress to study the Consumer Price Index now says that the index overstates inflation by even more than the one percentage point it initially estimated.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;No Big Deal As Teen-ager Turns Pro
description: THE best college player in the country turned professional this week at the age of 19. He hired the International Management Group. He signed a multimillion-dollar deal with Nike Nation. Yet no one ripped the system for turning out one more degree-less jock, and David Stern would want to know why.

title: Successful Alternatives to Prison
description: This year's budget stalemate in Albany has momentarily pushed some of Gov. George Pataki's more imprudent and costly criminal justice proposals off the table. The New York State Legislature has temporarily shelved a plan to stiffen punishments for first-time violent offenders that could require 9,000 more prison beds and cost $500 million. Mr. Pataki and the Legislature should use the respite to explore creative alternatives that can be more effective and cheaper than prison.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Treasury Securities Tumble On Fears of Higher Rates Prices of Treasury securities tumbled, reflecting fears that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates earlier than expected. A former Fed governor, Lyle Gramley, said he expected the Fed to raise the Federal funds rate by a half percentage point at its July policy meeting.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF ITRON FALL ON EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: The stock of Itron Inc. plunged yesterday after the company, a maker of equipment for utilities, warned that earnings for the next two quarters would be even with first-quarter levels or below them. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Itron lost 32 percent, dropping $16.25, to $34, making it the biggest percentage loser on the exchange. The company, based in Spokane, Wash., is a supplier of data collection and wireless communications products for remote data management by electric, gas and water utilities. Itron attributed the lower forecast for the second and third quarters to higher expenses and cuts in prices for its automatic meter readers, which account for about three-fourths of its revenues.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bailout Plan Is Close In German Fraud Case
description: Klockner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G., a German cement and engineering company on the brink of collapse by a fraud scandal, said yesterday that it was close to completing a bailout plan. The company said the plan had been worked out with creditors, regional authorities and Deutsche Bank, which owns 48 percent of the company. Details were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about documents sought by lawmakers investigating the dismissals of seven White House travel office workers misstated the date of the dismissals. It was May 1993, not February.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUNGARD TO BUY A UNIT OF NATIONAL COMPUTER
description: Sungard Data Systems Inc., a computer services company, has a definitive agreement to buy the Financial Systems business of National Computer Systems Inc. for $95 million in cash, the companies said yesterday. Financial Systems provides software and services for bank asset management. It had revenues of $58.1 million for the year ended Jan. 31. The Minneapolis-based National Computer provides trust accounting and corporate trust systems to banks and other financial institutions. It has about 350 employees. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Sungard rose $1.25, to $37.75, and shares of National Computer rose $1.25, to $24.25.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : New Rules on Hot Tubs
description: Legislators in several states are planning to tighten rules governing hot tubs after a 16-year-old high school student was pinned to the bottom of one during a post-prom party and drowned.

title: Rig Count Drops by 10
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide dropped by 10 this week, to 765, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 677 rigs operating in the United States a year ago. Of the rigs running this week, 472 were exploring for natural gas and 288 for oil; 5 rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: Feedback Feedback
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;France Succeeds In a Privatization
description: The French Government said today that the sale of the insurer A.G.F., the country's first large privatization of 1996, had been a success.

title: Lights! Camera! Action! Jobs and Revenue!
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;NETANYAHU NARROW VICTOR; SETS OUT TO FORM A CABINET AND ASSURE ARAB NEIGHBORS
description: Confirmed as the winner in Israel's leadership race by the narrowest of margins, Benjamin Netanyahu turned today to the task of reassuring anxious Arab neighbors and sifting candidates for a new Cabinet.

title: After Short Stay, Deer Trades Manhattan for Country Life
description: At 3 o'clock in the morning, people see lots of things, including pink elephants.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Delinquents Pay Up
description: Thousands of delinquent tax payments poured into state offices yesterday as New Jersey's 10-week amnesty period neared its deadline at midnight tonight. State officials said that the program had brought in $145 million as of Thursday -- about two-thirds of that in sales, corporate and use taxes and most of the rest in personal income taxes.

title: Talk of Fed Rate Rise Sends Bonds Over 7% for a Time
description: Treasury prices tumbled yesterday after talk of an increase in interest rates coming sooner than expected rattled a market already nervous about a strong economy and inflation.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;$600 Million Casino Planned
description: Plans to expand casino development in Atlantic City's marina district took another big step yesterday when Circus Circus Enterprises of Las Vegas signed a deal to build a $600 million, 2,000-room casino-hotel. The project would be built near a $750 million, 2,000-room casino hotel planned by Mirage Resorts and a $500 million casino hotel planned by Boyd Gaming in conjunction with Mirage, The Associated Press said. The projects all depend on the state's agreeing to build a $300 million road from the Atlantic City Expressway directly to the marina district. Donald J. Trump and Bally Entertainment, which together control 6 of the city's 13 casinos, most of them on the Boardwalk, are lobbying against public financing of a marina road.

title: Mayor Broke Budget Vow On Children, Critics Say
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed his new budget, a document that runs thousands of pages and deals with scores of agencies, he made one clear-cut promise: There would be no reduction in spending to protect the city's most vulnerable children. The Mayor, in fact, made that his central boast when he unveiled his proposal at City Hall last month.

title: Dole Favors 'Instant Check' for Gun Control
description: Saying he knew from personal experience the damage that guns could do, Bob Dole told police officers in this Columbus suburb today that he would control guns in America with an instant check on anyone who wanted to buy one, not with a ban on assault weapons.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Jobless Rate Took Big April Jump
description: Japan's jobless rate made it biggest one-month jump in four decades in April, the Government said yesterday. The increase of three-tenths of a percentage point, to 3.4 percent. was the biggest since 1959. Japan's unemployment rate would be significantly higher if calculated by United States or European methods, falling somewhere between 5 and 8 percent, economists say. Anyone who has worked an hour or more in the last week of a given month is counted as fully employed in Japan. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;NETSTAR TO BE SOLD TO ASCEND COMMUNICATIONS
description: Ascend Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Netstar Inc. for stock worth about $300 million. Both companies make computer networking products. Netstar, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., makes products that combine high-speed switching capabilities with Internet-standard communication. Ascend, based in Alameda, Calif., will exchange 0.35 of a share for each Netstar share. Netstar's operations will remain in Eden Prairie, operating as Ascend's high-speed networking unit. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Netstar fell $2.375, to $22.875. Shares of Ascend rose 75 cents, to $66.875.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SEACOR COMPLETES PURCHASE OF MCCALL ENTERPRISES
description: Seacor Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired McCall Enterprises Inc. and its affiliated companies. Seacor exchanged 1.3 million shares of its common stock, valued at approximately $64.6 million, for all of McCall's outstanding capital stock, including $6.8 million in working capital. McCall, based in Cameron, La., operates utility and crew boats that serve the oil and gas industries in the Gulf of Mexico. Seacor operates a fleet of vessels used in supporting offshore oil and gas exploration and development in the Gulf of Mexico, the North Sea and West Africa.

title: Cigar Arrives As Superstar
description: Cigar, the 6-year-old race horse with the 14-race winning streak, arrived at Suffolk Downs this afternoon with fanfare, a City Council proclamation of welcome and a police escort that met his van on the Massachusetts Turnpike and accompanied him with flashing lights for 85 miles from Sturbridge to the backstretch.

title: S.E.C. Charges Fraud in Case of Tiny Stock That Soared
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Comparator Systems and three of its officials yesterday with fraud in connection with the company's financial statements. The commission also contended that the company had not developed a new fingerprint identification system, as it had said, but had instead stolen a prototype of a system developed by others.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Economic Growth Lags In Quarter in Italy
description: Italy's economic growth slowed in the first quarter, the national statistics agency said yesterday. Gross domestic product rose an inflation-adjusted two-tenths of 1 percent from the fourth quarter of 1995 and 1.2 percent from a year earlier. The economy expanded 3 percent last year.

title: Albania's Reformer Turns Autocrat
description: When an unknown apparatchik with a big medical reputation emerged as a key negotiator in the downfall of Europe's strictest Communist government, Washington believed that it had found its man in the volatile southern Balkans.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Monorail Opens With Spat
description: The train ran on time, but the $350 million Newark International Airport monorail got off to a bumpy start yesterday when Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey snubbed him. Mr. James said he was insulted not to get an invitation to the monorail's opening ceremonies, so he invited himself. Only Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg were asked to speak.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Aiming at the Cutting Edge
description: Once there was the Television Laboratory and series like "Independent Focus." But new and sometimes controversial film and video makers tend to be a thorn in the side of a timid public television. Showcases come and go. "Reel New York," promising material that "reflects the broad ethnic, social and cultural pluralism of the metropolitan area," is the latest effort, a collaboration between Channel 13 and local media arts organizations.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN THE REGION;Arab Leaders Seem Ready To Search for a New Unity
description: Bracing themselves for the return of a Likud Government in Israel, Arab leaders reached out to one another today in contacts that included surprise talks between the Egyptian Foreign Minister and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about Anne d'Harnoncourt, the director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, referred incorrectly to the uniqueness of her position. She is the only woman in the United States who heads an art museum with a budget of more than $25 million, not the only woman in America who heads a museum of any kind with a budget of that size.

title: Croat Is First to Be Convicted By Balkan War Crimes Panel
description: An ethnic Croat who fought for the Bosnian Serb army pleaded guilty today to crimes against humanity for his part in the massacre of thousands of Muslim men at a United Nations-designated "safe area" in Bosnia last July.

title: Journal;Follow That Front
description: So much for cowboys and soldiers and astronauts, those heroes who once symbolized American right and might. The new national hero of choice is a smiling con man who comes on TV every day to spout official-sounding jargon and make outlandish promises about the future -- and is wrong almost every time.

title: Deal Gives Frito-Lay Head Start In Use of P.& G.'s Fat Substitute
description: Frito-Lay Inc. said today that it had signed an agreement with the Procter & Gamble Company that would give Frito-Lay far larger quantities of P.& G.'s new fat substitute, olestra, than competitors would get, for about a year.

title: BASEBALL;Key and Rivera Help Lift Torre's Post-Sierra Mood
description: At least Jimmy Key and Ruben Rivera helped end Joe Torre's day splendidly. After Key returned from rehabilitation to pitch six special innings and Rivera bashed his first career homer to guide the Yankees to a 4-1 victory over the Athletics tonight, not even Ruben Sierra's accusation that the manager has lied to him since the spring could have spoiled Torre's mood.

title: Buchanan Won't Be Pushed to Center
description: On Thursday, Patrick J. Buchanan was supposed to walk among the dead at the Little Bighorn National Monument in Montana, evoking the ghost of George Armstrong Custer at the site of his last stand against the Sioux, 120 years ago.

title: Democrats Are Torn Between 2 Contenders for Manhattan Surrogate
description: During her unsuccessful race for State Attorney General two years ago, Karen S. Burstein was celebrated and supported by virtually every Democratic official in Manhattan. But in the race she is now waging for a position of decidedly lower profile, nothing could be further from the case.

title: Lights! Camera! Action! Jobs and Revenue!
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer;Harry! Louise! You Lied
description: They told us that national health care would deprive us of the right to choose our own doctors.

title: 2 Automotive Parts Makers Agree to Merge
description: Lucas Industries of Britain agreed yesterday to acquire the Varity Corporation of Buffalo for $1.9 billion in stock, in a deal that furthers the consolidation of the worldwide auto parts industry.

title: Serbs Expel Muslims From Part of Bosnia
description: In what the United Nations is calling the worst "ethnic cleansing" since the Balkan war ended, a wave of violence by Serbs has forced at least 100 Muslims to flee a town in northern Bosnia over the last few days. The attacks have exposed the inability of international troops to protect Muslim residents and a basic weakness of the peace plan.

title: Slovakia's Economy Is Doing Well, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Emotional Appeal by Yeltsin

title: Music in Review;ROCK
description: The Dim Side of Love, With Just a Touch of Trash Congo Norvell Brownies

title: A (True) Fish Story
description: Striped bass, abundant when New York City was New Amsterdam and scarce here in the late 1970's and early 1980's, are flourishing again. Throughout the metropolitan area, far up the Hudson and along Atlantic shores, they are being caught in huge numbers. The comeback is one of the great and rare success stories of fish conservation.

title: Campus Turmoil of 60's Reveals Themes Echoed in Unabom Manifesto
description: In June 1967, as the Vietnam War neared the height of its carnage, 43 of the nation's leading mathematicians took to the pages of a professional journal to implore their colleagues to forgo military research.

title: Seles Backs Fernandez
description: It has become a soap opera, but the controversy over the exclusion from the United States Olympic team of Mary Joe Fernandez, the 1992 doubles gold medalist, continues to percolate.

title: Muslims in Sarajevo Take Over Homes of Serbs Who Fled War
description: In a policy that international officials here say is tantamount to ethnic cleansing and violates the Dayton peace agreement, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government has expropriated tens of thousands of homes of city residents who fled during four years of war and is turning them over to Muslim refugees.

title: World News Briefs;American Is Accused Of Embezzlement at U.N.
description: An American citizen holding a high-ranking United Nations position in Geneva has been accused of forgery and embezzling as much as $500,000 from the agency where he works, the Secretary General's spokeswoman said today.

title: Jury in New Jersey Finds Ex-Prosecutor Guilty on 30 Counts
description: A former New Jersey County Prosecutor who fashioned himself as a tough crime fighter and staunch foe of drug dealers was convicted today of 30 Federal charges of fraud and abuse of power and immediately sent to jail.

title: Music in Review;JAZZ
description: An Improviser and Explorer Returns After 10 Years Sam Rivers, saxophonist Knitting Factory

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a campaign appearance in Chicago by Bob Dole, the probable Republican candidate for President, misstated the period in which he was a county prosecutor in Russell, Kan. It was in the 1950's, not the 1940's.

title: Science Hall Heroine
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman of G.O.P. Criticizes 'Union Bosses'
description: The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Haley Barbour, said today that the labor movement had a vested interest in fighting Republican efforts to cut Government spending because 4 out of 10 union members are on civil payrolls.

title: Sinn Fein Runs Strongly in Vote for Ulster Negotiating Teams
description: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, won unusually strong support in an election Thursday for negotiating teams for full-fledged peace talks in Northern Ireland.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN THE WEST BANK;Settlers Rejoice, Arabs Are Uneasy
description: Beaming through his thick beard, Yossi Leibowitz sat in his kitchen here today in the heart of a Jewish settler enclave as the words he had longed to hear came over the radio.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;To the Cabin Of Slaves, A Gutsy Girl Brings Light
description: The narrator of "Nightjohn," a 12-year-old slave girl named Sarny, is the ideal guide into this jewel of a family film. The story she tells promises to be educational in the most leaden, mawkish way: Nightjohn is an escaped slave who voluntarily returned to slavery to teach others how to read, with Sarny as his latest pupil. Yet "Nightjohn" (tonight on the Disney Channel) turns this tale into a gripping, vivid drama. With her brains and independent spirit, Sarny makes it easy for the film's most likely audience -- girls and boys her own age -- to follow her into the alien and brutal world of slavery.

title: His Stricken Neighbors Pray For Victim of Beating on L.I.
description: For the past week, the white two-story house where Shane Daniels lives has been awash with bouquets, Bundt cakes and flowered cards. Every half-hour, the doorbell buzzes, offering up another well-wisher, plate in hand. Former teachers, long-forgotten friends, even the school bus driver who once shuttled the young man to middle school, have called to say, "I'm so sorry. What can I do?"

title: World News Briefs;Saudi Arabia Beheads Four in Bomb Attack
description: Despite threats of reprisals by militant Islamic groups, four Saudi nationals were beheaded in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, today for the bombing of a United States-run military installation there last November.

title: BASEBALL;Dodgers Pound Jones on Fright Night at Shea
description: Another Friday nightmare took place at Shea Stadium last night.

title: WORKFARE RULES CAUSE ENROLLMENT TO FALL, CUNY SAYS
description: New rules introduced by the Giuliani administration that require all welfare recipients to work have led thousands of students and would-be students to drop out of college or not enroll, according to officials at the City University of New York.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: MAN IN THE NEWS;The 'American' Premier: Benjamin Netanyahu
description: A conversation with Israelis about Benjamin Netanyahu inevitably comes around to how "American" he is.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Attacked Near Bar
description: An off-duty Bronx police officer was attacked and robbed of his wallet, neck chain and sneakers near an upper Manhattan bar where he had been drinking early yesterday with four fellow officers, the police said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Casino Clash Not a Crime
description: Whatever occurred during a late-night confrontation between two rival casino executives on May 4, it wasn't a crime, a municipal judge ruled yesterday, dismissing a complaint by Edward M. Tracy that Nicholas L. Ribis had threatened his life. Mr. Ribis, who runs the Trump casino operations in Atlantic City, had denied making any threat and said he merely asked Mr. Tracy to leave a restaurant at the Taj Mahal casino. Mr. Tracy, who now works for another casino company, was Mr. Ribis's predecessor as the chief executive of the Trump casinos. JOE SHARKEY

title: Chrysler Curb Being Proposed In California
description: A California judge proposed yesterday that the Chrysler Corporation be prohibited from shipping new cars to its 300 dealers in the state for 60 days as a punishment after he found that the auto maker had resold 119 cars and trucks that had been returned under the state's "lemon law."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Bank in Japan To Replace Failed One
description: Japanese banks disclosed plans yesterday to set up a new bank to take over the assets of the Taiheiyo Bank, a regional bank that failed in March because of bad loans. The Sakura Bank of Tokyo said that it and other major banks would finance the new bank.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Renee Fleming Thrives On Tully Hall's Intimacy
description: Two sections of stage seats had to be set up at Alice Tully Hall to accommodate the overflow for Thursday night's recital by Renee Fleming. In the last three years this American soprano has deservedly won an ardent following; she is now central to the artistic future of the Metropolitan Opera. But this means there may be few chances to hear her again in a hall so intimate, which will be unfortunate. Ms. Fleming used it to advantage in this remarkable recital.

title: About New York;Little Change Despite Hopes On 139th St.
description: IT'S Sunday afternoon and Grandma's listening to rap again.

title: Police Try to Build Bridge to China
description: Capt. George Duke arrived in China this week with four fellow New York City police officers on a pioneering mission: to team up with local Chinese police to fight the burgeoning criminal networks that operate between New York City and Fujian Province, a rocky and forbidding region on China's southern coast.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Sidney Swensrud, 95, Hands-On Executive Who Expanded Gulf Oil
description: Sidney A. Swensrud, a former president and chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, who led the company on a major expansion in the United States and overseas, died on Wednesday. He was 95 and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: A Justice Dept. Review Is Sought On a Sleeping Pill's Side Effects
description: A Government task force recommended yesterday that the Justice Department assess whether the Upjohn Company committed crimes by failing to report serious side effects caused by the sleeping pill Halcion.

title: Music in Review;JAZZ
description: A 22-Year-Old Trumpeter With a Meditative Streak Nicholas Payton Village Vanguard

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred Seed Deal
description: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. said today that it would acquire 20 percent of the Sunseeds Company, a developer of hybrid vegetables, in exchange for Pioneer's vegetable seeds program. Sunseeds, of Morgan Hill, Calif., was acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company in 1994. Pioneer is based here.

title: Woman Shoots 2 Muggers
description: The last time Dorothy Newton was robbed, the mugger took all her money and then shot her. This time, she did the shooting, telling her attackers, "Take this!"

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Never-Say-Die Panthers Prepare for a Showdown
description: John Vanbiesbrouck tossed the idea around for a moment. At 32, after 13 National Hockey League seasons, the Florida Panthers goalie suddenly found himself only one game from qualifying for his first Stanley Cup finals.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Economy Rose 1.2% in First Quarter
description: France's economy grew strongly in the first quarter, rebounding from a decline late last year caused by a paralyzing public sector strike, according to data issued yesterday. Growth in the first three months rose 1.2 percent after slipping four-tenths of 1 percent in the final 1995 quarter, the French statistics agency said.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;A June Judgment Day For Jazz and Sonics
description: If all else fails, call a pep rally.

title: Dartmouth Rows to Upset
description: More than 1,000 college rowers, men and women, dipped their oars into the Cooper River about 200,000 times today with a single goal: to be good enough to compete in Sunday's championship races. This was the day of repechage races at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's 94th annual regatta, meaning the day of second chances at qualifying for the finals in 11 events.

title: COMPANY NEWS;4,400 HOURLY WORKERS ARE OFFERED BUYOUTS
description: The Raytheon Company has made buyout offers to more than 4,000 hourly employees in Massachusetts, saying that the move would minimize or eliminate layoffs. Robert McWade, a company spokesman, would not say yesterday how many jobs the company hoped to eliminate with its offer. He said the action was taken to cut costs because military spending is continuing to drop. Mr. McWade said the voluntary severance program was offered to about 4,400 production and maintenance workers who are members of Local 1505 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Raytheon has about 73,000 workers around the world.

title: Who Stands for Children?
description: If a true measure of a society is how well it treats its children, then America is in trouble. Far too many of the nation's youngsters are the victims of poverty, violence and substandard education that leave them without the basic skills to earn their way and advance in a complex society. That is why thousands of Americans will gather in Washington today for a rally designed to give voice in this election year to the needs of millions of citizens who cannot vote but who represent the nation's future.

title: A Custody Battle Over Captive Dolphins
description: As might be expected in a savage custody dispute, a battle over captive dolphins has been marked by litigation and sniping, with warring factions all saying they are acting in the best interest of the mammals.

title: Amazing! Incredible! Siamese Sideshows!;(Well, 2 Masters Of the Freak Show On a Single Street)
description: Before television, almost a half century ago, there were well over 100 full-time American sideshows offering everything from yogis reclining on beds of nails to scantily clad women wrapped in giant snakes. Now, not counting the small acts that play county fairs, less than a half dozen remain.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Prosecutor Is Convicted
description: A former Somerset County Prosecutor who fashioned himself as a tough crime fighter was convicted yesterday of 30 Federal charges of fraud and abuse of power. Moments after the verdict, the trial judge, Alfred J. Lechner Jr., accused the former Prosecutor, Nicholas L. Bissell, of lying in testimony in the trial, revoked his $200,000 bond and ordered him jailed until sentencing on Sept. 6. [Page 1.]

title: Oil, Prices and Politics;Volatile Blend Fuels a Labor Battle at Shut Refinery
description: For some 70 years, the huge oil refinery here pumped out gasoline as dependably as the Delaware River, over which it loomed, sent its waters south to the Atlantic.

title: Kmart Vote Disputed
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that a shareholder proposal to force board members to stand for election annually had failed, but the union group that backed the issue disagreed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PEOPLES HERITAGE TO ACQUIRE FAMILY BANCORP
description: Peoples Heritage Financial Group, a banking company, said yesterday that it would acquire Family Bancorp in a stock deal valued at about $113.2 million. Peoples will offer 1.26 of its common shares, worth about $25.60, for each Family share in a tax-free exchange. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Family gained $1.625, to $23.875, while shares of Peoples rose 12.5 cents, to $19.875. Family, with assets of $887 million, has 17 banking offices in the Merrimack Valley area near Haverhill and Lowell, Mass., and six banking offices in southern New Hampshire. Peoples has $4.3 billion in assets and operates Peoples Heritage Bank, with 62 banking centers throughout Maine.

title: Shanghai Journal;For Modern Ills, Too, An Old, Old Medicine
description: On a narrow street in an old section of town, where small two-story homes are so cramped that many French-style balconies are cluttered with drying laundry or boxes of belongings that won't fit inside, the open doorway of one modest-looking house beckons to passers-by.

title: ROCK REVIEW;A Show and CD at Odds
description: For most of their eight-year career, Cincinnati's Afghan Whigs have been plagued by a rudimentary problem: they are everything they want to be on stage -- coming on with all the power of a rock band and the passion of a funk and soul revue -- but in recordings they fall short of their potential.

title: Timothy Leary, Pied Piper Of Psychedelic 60's, Dies at 75
description: Timothy Leary, who effectively introduced many Americans to the psychedelic 1960's with the relentlessly quoted phrase, "turn on, tune in, drop out," died yesterday at his house in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 75.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A Swiss Bank Is Reorganizing Management
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland said today that it would reorganize its management to to become more competitive internationally, marking the first change since Mathis Cabiallavetta took over as chief executive.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REGAL CINEMAS BUYS GEORGIA STATE THEATERS
description: Regal Cinemas Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Georgia State Theaters Inc., a 68-screen, 10-theater chain with headquarters in Atlanta, for $43 million in stock. The purchase will be accounted for as a pooling of interests. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Regal Cinemas rose $1.625, to $46.375. Regal, based in Knoxville, Tenn., operates 139 multiscreen theaters throughout the country with a total of 1,088 screens.

title: April Spending By Consumers Barely Rose
description: Consumer spending barely edged up in April despite a relatively strong increase in personal incomes, the Commerce Department said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;No. 3 Korea Chip Maker Delays Expansion Plan
description: LG Semicon, South Korea's third-largest semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it had put a hold on plans to expand production of 16-megabit memory chips. The company, which had planned to expand monthly production to 10 million chips by the end of the year, will maintain it at eight million chips instead, it said. The decision was announced a day after the Samsung Electronics Company said it would cut monthly output to 12 million chips from a planned 14 million. (AP)

title: MUSIC REVIEW;They Came for Goode, and Stayed for Meell
description: Although the crowd had turned out at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday evening mainly to hear Richard Goode play two Mozart piano concertos with Orpheus, an unheralded second soloist was hardly less impressive.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Rise to Record Highs
description: Record high prices for corn and wheat helped a 12 percent rise in the farm-price index in May from a year earlier, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Is It Real or Is It Megabytes?
description: Art addicts, computer nerds and anybody interested in art and technology took notice a couple of years ago when Bill Gates bought Leonardo da Vinci's Codex Leicester for $30.8 million. Now the American Museum of Natural History has announced that next fall it will exhibit the 72-page manuscript, which contains drawings on topics from hydrodynamics to astronomy, along with interactive computer displays designed to decode Leonardo's mirror writing and scientific ideas.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAXIM PLANS TO ACQUIRE IMAGE INDUSTRIES
description: Maxim Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Image Industries Inc. in a stock swap valued at $90.7 million. Image, based in Armuchee, Ga., makes carpets from recycled plastic. It will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxim, a Kennesaw, Ga., chain of 700 retail floor-covering stores. Image posted revenue of $135.2 million in 1995. Maxim had sales of $99.3 million in the 10 months ended Jan. 31, and $76.1 million in the previous full fiscal year. The company changed its fiscal year-end last year to Jan. 31 from March 31.

title: GOLF;This Time, The Field Is Chasing Sorenstam
description: The defending champion looked every bit the part today at the 51st United States Women's Open.

title: World News Briefs;De Klerk's Party Wins Voting in Cape Town
description: Defying speculation that South Africa's white-led National Party would quickly pass from the national scene, it has romped to victory in local elections in the Cape Town area.

title: A Common-Sense Guide to Rabies: Don't Panic
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Program Long Planned Turns Accidentally Into a Memorial
description: If the New York Philharmonic's concerts had not been planned and announced more than a year ago, a listener attending the subscription series that began on Thursday evening might have concluded that Kurt Masur had chosen his program reactively, as a grandly scaled memorial. Jacob Druckman, who was once the orchestra's composer in residence (and was the father of one of its percussionists, Daniel Druckman), died last week, and three former members of the orchestra died during the season that ends with tonight's concert. A program insert notes that the concerts are dedicated to Mr. Druckman's memory, and Mr. Masur remembered the musicians in brief comments from the stage.

title: 61 Million Shortfall Seen in School Aid Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew joined with the Democratic leadership of the State Assembly today to criticize a school aid plan by Gov. George E. Pataki, saying it would open a $61 million hole in the city's education budget.

title: GOLF;Huston Takes Swing At Golf's 60 Barrier
description: John Huston was walking toward history at the Memorial Tournament today, following his perfect tee shot down the 17th fairway at Muirfield Village. Behind him was the flaming wreckage of the golf course that he had already torched for 10 birdies and an eagle. In front of him, if he could add just one more birdie in the final two holes, was the all-time PGA Tour scoring record of 59.

title: Mortgage Rates Inch Up
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.03 percent this week, up from 8.01 percent last week, according to a national survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest since May 16, when rates averaged 8.08 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.76 percent, up from 5.75 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.54 percent this week, up from 7.51 percent a week earlier. The rates do not include other charges known as points.

title: The Splinter Factor
description: The election of Benjamin Netanyahu, the first Prime Minister of Israel born after the country's independence, marks the culmination of a new political culture in Israel.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Its Power Eroding, C.F.A. Will Disband
description: The College Football Association, its membership and power eroding, unanimously voted today to disband on June 30, 1997, The Fort Worth-Star Telegram reported.

title: 2d Suspect To Surrender, Lawyer Says
description: A 27-year-old college student was to surrender today to the Suffolk County District Attorney's Office in the beating of a black man outside a Westhampton Beach, L.I., nightclub, his lawyer said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Stop Pining for Pitino, And Make Second Choices
description: The tissues were dry wads in a trash can by yesterday. The Nets had wiped their eyes and moved on a day after Rick Pitino's rejection, but they do not appear to be wooing another hot college coach, UMass's John Calipari.

title: Bridge
description: The premier event in the New York calendar is the Reisinger Knockout Teams, which has been played annually since 1930. In the quarterfinals, at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, the scores by captain at the midpoint yesterday were: Jeanne Rahmey of Brooklyn led Richard Schwartz of East Elmhurst, Queens, by 11 imps; Bob Blanchard of Manhattan led Allen Kahn of Manhattan by 20; Adam Wildavsky of Jackson Heights, Queens, led Gerald Sosler of Purchase, N.Y., by 21; and Dorothy Truscott of Riverdale, the Bronx, led Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., by 8.

title: Promote Cancer Treatment, Not Cancer Phobia
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl, 11, Charged in Death of 2 1/2-year-old
description: An 11-year-old girl was charged with murder on Thursday in the apparent beating death of a 2 1/2-year-old at the home of a Baptist deacon.

title: SOCCER;South Korea And Japan Will Share World Cup
description: The fierce competition between Japan and South Korea to host soccer's international championship ended with an uneasy solution yesterday, when the contentious nations were chosen as joint hosts of the 2002 World Cup.

title: World News Briefs;Colombian President Suffers Setback in Trial
description: President Ernesto Samper suffered a possible setback in his impeachment trial, with an announcement in Congress that he should be judged on political grounds as well as criminal complaints.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Continue to Slip On Concern About Iraqi Exports
description: Crude oil prices continued to slip on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as concerns grew that renewed exports from Iraq and surging output from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would create a supply surplus later this year.

title: No Headline
description: I feel all your pain, all the country's pain. However, I am sure it is the pain of a recovering organism."

title: Union Accord Averts Tony Trouble
description: The Tony Awards telecast has been saved.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO BUY ADDINGTON
description: Republic Industries, headed by H. Wayne Huizenga, agreed yesterday to acquire Addington Resources Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $322 million at Thursday's closing stock price. Republic, which provides waste management and electronic security services, will exchange 0.45 of a share for each of Addington's 15.2 million outstanding shares. Shares of both Republic and Addington rose sharply yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Addington stock was up $3.50, or nearly 21 percent, at $20.50 a share, while Republic stock was up $4.8125 at $52. Addington is a waste-management company based in Ashland, Ky. It expects to post revenue of about $65 million to $70 million for its current fiscal year, while Republic has annual revenue of about $346 million.

title: A Writer Who Delights In Layers of Complexity
description: Robert Coover's mysterious new novel, "John's Wife," is a cosmorama of eros and ethos in a small American prairie town. Written in one long chapter, the book is filled with closely guarded secrets. It is easy for the unwary to become lost in Coover country, and the author is not about to provide a map, but during a recent interview he offered a few clues to his method.

title: Yeltsin, in Manifesto, Pledges to Treat Voters' 'Pain'
description: Saying today that he felt the "pain" of the Russian people, President Boris N. Yeltsin made a strong but emotional appeal for the voters' support.

title: Development Trend Evades Poverty Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Start in India
description: The failure of Hindu nationalists to form a government in India has opened the way for a fractious coalition of splinter parties to make the next try. Their nominal leader, H. D. Deve Gowda, is to be sworn in today as Prime Minister. He is a relatively untested politician from the south who faces a formidable challenge in pleasing both the groups in his camp and the leaders of the defeated Congress Party, whose votes he needs to stay in office. Nevertheless, the odds are good that Mr. Gowda will survive, at least for a while. His record suggests that he will continue India's economic reforms and, perhaps more important, preserve its secular traditions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Along an Ethnic Fault Line, Bosnians Fear Hard-Liners
description: A fearful young Muslim couple arrived here this week, fleeing their home to escape what the United Nations is calling the worst "ethnic cleansing" since the Bosnian war ended.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Born of 'Swan Lake' and Peter Martins
description: The New York City Ballet's newest work, "Tchaikovsky Pas de Quatre," is a divertissement in search of a four-act ballet.

title: South Carolina Executes Killer of Policeman
description: A man who killed a rookie police officer in a 1983 drive-by slaying was executed by injection early today, bidding farewell to his lawyer with the words, "I'll see you when I see you."

title: In a Key Vote, Italy's Leader Gains Support of the Far Left
description: Prime Minister Romano Prodi's new center-left Government passed a critical test in the Chamber of Deputies today, winning a vote of confidence with the "conditional" help of 35 hard-line leftist deputies whose support it needs for a majority.

title: Far Away From the Limelight? Someone Tell Bratton
description: The limelight hasn't ended," former Police Comissioner William J. Bratton said yesterday, beaming, before he received an honorary degree from the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan. "I enjoyed it then, and I'm enjoying it now."

title: TENNIS;Pierce Hears the Whistles Before Defeat Brings On the Boos at French
description: Wearing the little black tennis dress that has launched a thousand wolf whistles and raised more than a thousand eyebrows among the sport's fashion police, a quite contrary Mary Pierce, the next-to-last French Open hope of her not-so-native France, was whistled off Center Court today in a hail of derisive jeers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DANKA BUSINESS PURCHASES LESLIE SUPPLY
description: Danka Business Systems P.L.C., a London-based company that distributes, leases and repairs office equipment in the United States, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Leslie Supply Company for $80 million in stock. Danka issued 6.8 million ordinary shares, the equivalent of 1.7 million American depository receipts, to finance the purchase, said Robin Cohen, a company spokeswoman. Leslie Supply is a distributor of Canon photocopiers, fax machines and supplies. It employs 400 people in three offices in the New York area.

title: RJR Nabisco's Tobacco Chief Quits Abruptly
description: James W. Johnston, chief executive of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Company's worldwide tobacco operations, resigned abruptly yesterday, surprising Wall Street because the company's once-struggling tobacco unit had been improving in profitability and market share.

title: Beliefs
description: The New Yorker magazine welcomed the month of marriages by featuring a bride on its June 3 cover. Bustling about her are bridesmaids and a seamstress, cheerfully adjusting the billowing white wedding gown to accommodate a very visible pregnancy.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Wider Curfews Studied
description: In tightly packed northern Hudson County, one town's curfew isn't a big problem for those under 18, who can hop the border into an adjoining town that lacks a curfew. Yesterday, police officials and municipal aides from North Bergen, Weehawken, Union City, Hoboken, Secaucus, West New York and Guttenberg met to begin exploring ways to impose, and enforce, a regional curfew. The towns with curfews now are West New York, at 9 P.M., and Guttenberg, at 11 P.M.

title: Giuliani Visits Relatives As Victim Lies in a Coma
description: Under attack for his low-key response to the arrest of a police detective in a racially charged assault, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met the family of the man beaten in the attack yesterday. And in an apparent effort to deflect criticism of the city's police force as a whole, he quickly moved to honor an officer who helped two mentally retarded teen-agers who got lost at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Safety Panel Urges Evaluation Of How Airlines Handle Cargo
description: The National Transportation Safety Board urgently recommended today that the Federal Aviation Administration evaluate airline procedures to keep "undeclared or unauthorized hazardous materials" out of their cargo holds.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;For CUNY Graduates, Long Trek to a Diploma
description: Commencement ceremonies for the City University of New York's Graduate School and University Center got off to a traffic-stopping start yesterday as participants walked from their building on 43d Street down the block to Town Hall. Counterparts at another CUNY school, John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, found their way to Madison Square Garden for their ceremony.

title: Unabom Manifesto Echoes 60's Tumult
description: A look at the campus turmoil in the late 1960's offers intriguing clues to why Theodore J. Kaczynski rejected society and reveals themes later elaborated in the Unabom manifesto.

title: Institute Offers 'Shrinks' More Than a Retreat
description: To the Editor:

title: STYLE;Going Public
description: First, there was Gucci. Then, Estee Lauder, and now, Saks Fifth Avenue and Donna Karan. The biggest trend in fashion these days is the Initial Public Offering. Designer labels have gone from family businesses to multinational corporations, and already the stock they're issuing has turned out to be more in demand than the clothes the magazines are touting, eclipsing "the return of the bikini" as news. Wall Street is bullish on fashion: in one article after another, financial analysts are quoted, endorsing it as a sound investment.

title: Political Briefing -- The States and the Issues: Third Parties;Perot's Party Is Not Alone
description: If, in fact, Americans are tired of the conventional two-party system and ready for a third way, their options are not confined to Ross Perot's Reform Party. The Natural Law Party, founded in 1992 by some meditators and followers of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, hopes to be on the ballot in all 50 states with a Presidential ticket and some 1,000 state and Federal candidates.

title: Botanists Join Fight To Save Butternut
description: THE United State Forest Service, in search of a few good butternut trees, found instead a couple of retired botanists who want to help the Government save the species from a deadly fungus, which is killing butternut trees nationwide.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SOUTH STREET SEAPORT A Hong Kong Cornucopia, From Noodles to Politics

title: Olympic tickets: how to get the seats that remain
description: ALTHOUGH the situation is obviously in flux, tickets were available in mid-May to every Olympic session of track and field and soccer, as well as most sessions of baseball, field hockey, rowing and yachting, along with limited sessions of basketball and gymnastics. At the same time, Olympic officials released 40,000 tickets to swimming, diving, synchronized swimming, water polo and equestrian events, which had previously been announced as sold out. This reflects in part the large number of tickts available for the Atlanta Games -- 11 million, at an average price of about $40 for sports events, compared to 3.7 million in Barcelona and 6.9 million in Los Angeles. The sold-out sports are archery, cycling, fencing, modern pentathlon and table tennis.

title: FARM LIFE -- A special report.;Directing Bees to Pollinate the Orchard
description: I LIKE to impress on the young people that their food doesn't just all of a sudden appear in the store," said John Halsey, who farms a 60-acre orchard in Bridgehampton, the only self-supporting commercial apple orchard on the South Fork.

title: WEDDINGS;Sara Hazelwood, Raul F. Yanes
description: Sara Messinger Hazelwood and Raul Francisco Yanes, associates at law firms in New York, were married yesterday at the Ozaukee Congregational Church in Grafton, Wis. The Rev. Richard Buchman, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Michael Barrett, a Roman Catholic priest, was a participant.

title: U.S. Getting Public Housing Closer to the Ground
description: Flexing the toe of her sneaker, Sheila Ingram digs through the patchy baldness of the lawn in Oscar E. Miles Village, a new public town-house project in the heart of Newark. Every few minutes she unearths an inch-long broken glass vial with a tapered blue, red or green plastic screw top and displays it triumphantly.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Just a Regular Kid Being Remarkable
description: ALEX MACK IS A 14-YEAR-OLD girl who can morph into a puddle of water, send bright yellow electrical charges across a room and levitate cookies behind her father's back. But the essential Alex qualities are more evident when she says to her mother, "I cannot believe you embarrassed me like that!" Alex had been walking down the street with Scott, a boy she has a crush on, when her mother drove up and humiliated her by ordering her to do the grocery shopping. Some things about adolescence never change, even if you're telekinetic.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Jazz and SuperSonics Are Fighting for the Right to Be Second Best
description: After Seattle and Utah settle their series tonight, a compelling question will remain. Can either the SuperSonics or the Jazz give the Chicago Bulls a serious challenge? Or will the National Basketball Association finals be as one-sided as recent Super Bowls?

title: WEDDINGS;Daniel I. Mines and Liza R. Somers
description: Dr. Liza R. Somers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Laurence Somers of Lafayette Hill, Pa., is to be married today to Dr. Daniel I. Mines, a son of Joan Mines and Dr. Martin Mines, both of Rockville Centre, L.I. Rabbi Marcia Prager is to perform the ceremony at the Glen Foerd Estate in Philadelphia.

title: GARDENING;First Aid for the Ailing Pachysandra
description: THERE is a lot of pachysandra growing in these parts. It is planted under shade trees, beneath shrubs, along paths, at edges of the lawn. It is a groundcover that appears to be enveloping the land.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: FUNDS WATCH;Chasing Those New Issues
description: Entrepreneurs start innovative companies, take them public and became millionaires overnight. And everyone seems eager to get in on the action -- leading to great demand for shares in newly public companies.

title: PERSPECTIVES;Changing the Approach in Low-Income Housing
description: THE 111th Street Oldtimers will be playing their annual stickball game on July 14 on the block between Fifth Avenue and Lenox Avenue in Harlem. They have been doing it for 28 years, but this year there will be a difference.

title: Armenian Genocide Cannot Be Denied;A University's Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Concert to Mark Start of $5.5 Million Restoration;Recharging Battery Park's Seawall and Promenade
description: A free concert on Wednesday at Castle Clinton, with a 12-piece orchestra and Broadway singers, will be part of the ground-breaking ceremony for a $5.5 million restoration of the Battery Park Seawall and Promenade -- which in turn is part of a $25 million restoration of the historic park.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 5/ Do you profit from overseas sweatshops? Finding out if your investments violate your beliefs is nearly impossible. By Ken Brown.

title: The Moderns
description: SISTER BROTHER Gertrude and Leo Stein. By Brenda Wineapple. Illustrated. 514 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $35. IN "The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," Gertrude Stein purloined the voice of her devoted secretary and lover to memorialize herself as the center of avant-garde Paris at the turn of the century. Stein described herself as the pre-eminent proponent of modernism, as well as a cultural revolutionary whose unconventional prose inspired writers like Ernest Hemingway and Sherwood Anderson. Lionized by subsequent generations as the grande dame of the expatriate literati in the Paris of the 1920's, she became a cult figure, an icon whose radical credo and hermetic writing style were the very symbol of modernist experimentation.

title: Vision of Original Developer Should Be Realized
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Corri P. Iser, Jeffrey M. Wolf
description: Corri Paige Iser, a daughter of Eileen Lipman and Stuart Iser, both of New York, is to be married today to Dr. Jeffrey Michael Wolf, the son of Debra Wolf and Dr. Martin Wolf of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Norton Shargel is to officiate at the Water Club in New York.

title: Vision of Original Developer Should Be Realized
description: To the Editor:

title: On Broadway and Off, a Seesaw Season
description: TONIGHT'S TONY AWARDS, TO BE broadcast at 9 on CBS, signal the end of the 1995-96 Broadway theater season, one that seemed to elicit as many opinions as this year's Tony nominations. Recently, the New York Times critics Vincent Canby, Ben Brantley and Margo Jefferson traded impressions about the season on Broadway and beyond. The moderator was Peter Marks, the Times's theater reporter.

title: WEDDINGS;Rebecca Herschler And John A. Hope
description: Rebecca Eleanor Herschler and John Anthony Hope, managers in the college division of John Wiley & Sons, the New York publisher, were married yesterday at the HF Bar Ranch, a dude ranch in Saddlestring, Wyo. The Rev. Patti Welch, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday The Conference Board reports the index of leading indicators for April. In March the index rose two-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Defining Moment For Loft Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: Exit Reasonable Right
description: AT 6 FEET 7 INCHES, ALAN SIMPSON IS probably the tallest member of the Senate, and he has, during 18 years there, been one of the most noticeable and outspoken Senators. But not for long. Like 13 colleagues -- eight Democrats and five Republicans, including Bob Dole -- the Wyoming Republican will leave the Senate this year.

title: Sunday June 2, 1996: PIE IN THE SKY;Disc-o-Mania
description: Depending on your school tie, you could be celebrating the 39th (Princeton or Dartmouth), 44th (Amherst) or 57th (Middlebury) anniversary of the Frisbee fad this year. Or you could be a Yalie, congratulating yourself for 50 years of tossing tins (from the Frisbie Pie Company) to and fro. "A shout of 'frisbie-e-e-e' was a distinctive warning when a pan was veering off toward an unsuspecting group of fellow students," writes a self-proclaimed originator of the game, Sam Carr Polk, Yale Law '47, in an alumni bulletin. Middlebury grads are not swayed; they insist that their Delta Upsilon fraternity brothers made the discovery on a road trip to Nebraska in 1939, while getting a flat fixed. Middlebury has immortalized its claim with a bronze sculpture of a dog catching a flying disc. No, Amherst alums say, it was they who sailed the first tin, in 1952. Still, a 1957 article in this Magazine credited Princeton and Dartmouth.

title: WEDDINGS;Abby Fisher, David Goldstein
description: Abby Lyn Fisher, a daughter of Enid and Alexander Fisher of New York, is to be married today at her parents' house in Bridgewater, Conn., to David Mark Goldstein, a son of Debbie and Fred Goldstein of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Judah Nadich is to perform the ceremony.

title: Whitewater Verdict Didn't Taint the Clintons;No Time for Siblings
description: To the Editor:

title: ART;Young-at-Heart Guide To the Big Questions
description: SHE could almost be Eloise from the Plaza, only grown-up and called Dr. Jodi. Her mischievousness is under control, but not her curiosity. Who is she? A tour guide, of sorts.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS
description: Regarding the memoirs in your issue: I only hope that my own children will have a fonder memory of their childhood.

title: Edison's 'Experiments': 40 Watts and 40 Winks
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends;The Return of the City-State
description: IN antiquity, before the rise of powerful nation-states, there were city-states whose names identified a civilization -- Athens, Edo, Rome and Alexandria among them. Some experts are now suggesting that in the future, cities, and not nations, will once again define who we are and how we live.

title: Long Island Q&A: Diane Romm;Toward a Definition of the Internet's Role in Education
description: DIANE ROMM met the Internet four years ago in a pilot project among Hofstra University, the Nassau School Library System and Nassau Boces. As library chairwoman in the Uniondale school district, overseeing nine libraries, Ms. Romm was trained to use the Internet with five other librarians.

title: Center-Right Party Leads in Czech Vote
description: Early surveys of voters leaving polls today indicated that the governing Civic Democratic Party of the conservative Prime Minister, Vaclav Klaus, had a commanding lead over the opposition Social Democrats in Czech parliamentary elections.

title: WEDDINGS;Jeffrey Zucker and Caryn Nathanson
description: Caryn Stephanie Nathanson, a supervisor at NBC in New York, and Jeffrey Adam Zucker, the executive producer of NBC's "Today" show in New York, were married last evening. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: THEATER;Phoenix Has Answers For Broadway's Woes
description: AMID the glitter of tonight's Tonys, which celebrate 50 years of awards for achievement on Broadway, an accumulation of statistics interlock golden memories with jolting reality.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Will Vent Allow Artist's Return?
description: The tortuous saga of the photographer who says a coffee bar ruined her apartment and her life appears to be edging to a close.

title: WEDDINGS;Rachel A. Charles, Martin M. O'Bryan
description: Rachel Ann Charles, the daughter of Rita A. Charles of Ann Arbor, Mich., and the late Edwin T. Charles, was married yesterday to Dr. Martin Murray O'Bryan, a son of Henry and Joan O'Bryan of Plainfield, N.J. The Rev. Roger Prokop performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Ann Arbor.

title: WEDDINGS;Barbara L. Kaye, Drew M. George
description: Barbara Lynn Kaye, a daughter of Lila Berman of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Steven Kaye of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Drew Michael George, a son of Donnie George of Katonah, N.Y., and Andy George of New Rochelle, N.Y. Cantor Marina Belenky performed the ceremony at Maxine's, a restaurant in Granite Springs, N.Y.

title: BASEBALL;Ordonez's Defensive Artistry Saves Mets
description: It is still too soon, Dallas Green said, to rate how Rey Ordonez compares to the very best defensive shortstops to play baseball.

title: LIVING IN TONGUES
description: Luc Sante's description of how certain words take him back to the moment in childhood when he first learned them is not limited to the multilingual home ("Living in Tongues"). Most of us have "associative" words that carry us back to the past.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: The Power and the Darkness The Life of Josh Gibson in the Shadows of the Game. By Mark Ribowsky. Simon & Schuster, $23.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: WHEREVER THAT GREAT HEART MAY BE Stories. By W. D. Wetherell. University Press of New England, $21.95.

title: From the Y to the Olympics
description: WHEN Lawrence Clay-Bey walked into the old Y Center at the Stowe Village housing project in Hartford's North End four years ago, the veteran boxing trainer Francisco Zayas saw, as he recalled it, "a fat guy with a gut."

title: W.W. Morrison, 59, N.A.A.C.P. Adviser
description: Walter W. Morrison, a former speechwriter and policy adviser at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died on May 17 at Good Samaritan Hospital in Baltimore.

title: The Song Is Ended
description: IRRIVING IN HIS ROOM AT THE BRADFORD Hotel in Boston in the fall of 1966, John Kander, the music half of the songwriting team Kander and Ebb, turned on the radio. He had traveled from New York for the out-of-town tryout of his new musical, which would eventually become famous as "Cabaret." As yet though, no one had seen a single performance; no one had heard the biting, infectious title song as it was meant to be heard: at the climax of a drama set in decadent prewar Germany. Nevertheless, by the time Kander finished unpacking his bags, "Cabaret" -- and several other songs from the remarkably varied score -- had been played on the radio, in versions recorded by pop artists who got hold of the music before the show even opened.

title: WEDDINGS;Naomi E. Hain, Michael B. Smigel
description: Naomi Esther Hain, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Kenneth N. Hain of Lawrence, L.I., was married there on Monday to Michael Benjamin Smigel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcel B. Smigel of Great Neck, L.I. The bride's father performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom, of which he is the rabbi.

title: The Nation;Whitewater Enters Its Season of Danger
description: BURIED in an otherwise mundane letter three weeks ago, Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating the Whitewater affair, dismissed the White House's single most important political defense, and offered a tantalizing new clue about the direction of his secretive inquiry.

title: IN BRIEF;Lawyers and Athletic Leagues Team Up to Prevent Injuries
description: Each year, four children die of Little League-related injuries in the United States, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Half of the deaths are caused by trauma from chest injuries when children are hit by baseballs. Such injuries can be fatal, even though Little League balls have softer cores than the professional variety.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN VALLEY;A Teacher Gets Girls Up And Running
description: It got to the point that Nicky Kram, who teaches science to seventh graders in the gifted and talented program at Booker T. Washington Middle School, was more worried about her students' bodies than their minds. title: Pacific Overtures
description: Middle Son By Deborah Iida. 228 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $18.95. FOR all its modesty, hushed restraint and intentional understatement, Deborah Iida's first novel, "Middle Son," is something of a high-wire act. Set in a community of Japanese-American sugar cane cutters in Hawaii, the book explores a world unknown to most of us, a world with its own customs and its own languages, "the oral and the written." The narrator, Spencer Fujii, speaks pidgin -- the plantation patois -- with his family, but conceptualizes and recounts the events of his childhood and later life in "textbook English." It's a novel by a woman writing from a male point of view, a story of a childhood that is clearly not the writer's own -- two significant acts of bravery in a literary culture that often seems to value experience over imagination.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Popular Science
description: Henry Holt & Company, in its series "Scientific American Focus," has the rather interesting goal of taking areas of science that are likely to be in the news or are generating controversy and making them clear to the average newspaper reader. The first three volumes, all written by science journalists and each costing $22.50, are written in simple, straightforward language and are embellished with numerous photographs and diagrams. MEDICATION OF THE MIND, by Scott Veggeberg, grapples with one of the many deep and difficult problems uncovered by our new understanding that life depends, at bottom, on chemistry. Specialized molecules in the brain, called receptors, seem to govern our moods and general feelings, and drugs like Prozac, which affect molecular chemistry, are the first fruits of this new understanding. But as more and more illnesses are dealt with by manipulating the brain's chemistry, traditional mental health practitioners find themselves fighting a rear-guard action. COSMIC COLLISIONS, by Dana Desonie, takes on the bombardment of the earth by pieces of debris from interplanetary space. Starting with the Big Bang and the formation of the solar system, the book describes the historical process by which humans came to realize that large stones occasionally fall from the sky. My only problem was a sense that Ms. Desonie was trying too hard to make the subject relevant, perhaps underestimating its inherent interest and her own ability to spin a good story. THE LANGUAGE OF ANIMALS, by Stephen Hart, is full of interesting tidbits about the communication inherent in the feather displays of peacocks, the mechanisms for sound production in dolphins, and modern experiments on the language capabilities of chimpanzees. What is missing is a single coherent theme, or at least some direction as to which topics are sidelights and which bear on deep scientific questions. If these books are any indication of what is to come, I look forward to the next volumes with great anticipation. James Trefil

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Starting Over
description: Before he married Eva Wasierski, Tom Riley's life was "so uneventful, so without particulars, it might have been ordered from a catalogue." An energetic and opinionated world traveler, Eva prodded and enlivened this quiet pet-shop owner who had rarely ventured outside his native Chicago. They had planned to go to Egypt to celebrate their 10th wedding anniversary -- but instead Tom finds himself alone, mourning Eva's death in Lago de Luz, the small Mexican town where they spent their honeymoon. "You can't run from sorrow," his sister warns him. To which, with admirable logic, he replies, "I can cry in some warmer place, at least." As the opening chapters of Sandra Scofield's latest novel, A CHANCE TO SEE EGYPT (HarperCollins, $22), make plain, Tom's journey is a metaphor: without Eva, he thinks he cannot cover new ground. But when, shortly into his stay, an incident at the hotel leads him to take up residence elsewhere, we understand that Tom is ready to venture beyond his past. Drawn to the strength of a local woman, he slowly awakens to his love for her beautiful and spirited 18-year-old daughter, aptly named Divina. Ambushed by his emotions, Tom is aware that "he had not so much earned his joy as accepted it." While this May-December romance may seem terribly familiar, Ms. Scofield (whose novel "Beyond Deserving" was a finalist for the National Book Award) gives it her own skillful twist. With its lively cast of characters and its vividly rendered setting, "A Chance to See Egypt" emerges as an absorbing story that allows us to delight in Tom Riley's elation at the unexpected gift of a life renewed. Janet Kaye

She might have picked some innocuous station for the day -- the spin-art booth, or dunk-a-teacher, or even the faulty but popular snow-cone machine -- but no, these are not for her. As a result, this year at the Wild West-themed fair, mothers dressed as cowgirls, swinging lariats, fail to gather an audience, and instead simply mill around the gym unhappily, ropes dragging on the floor. See, Celebrity Mom seems to be saying, as her delicate paintbrush hovers, I am taking everything I have learned during my years in Hollywood and demonstrating it on your children, your Ariels and Zoes and Jasons. After last year's fair, I knew of one mother who did not let her daughter wash her face for days. "We wanted to make something you didn't have to throw away," says Rahul Nair, one of the three who turned peppermint-flavored soybean oil into digestible wax as a school project (and won $5,000 from the Indiana Soybean Development Council in the process).

title: Take My Job, Please
description: True, true, true: Asian factories churn out sneakers cheaper than any made here. Downsizing has created the Incredible Shrinking Work Force. A job that supported four people in 1960 now supports two. But don't forget the bright side: office jokes. Whether batted about the water cooler or zipped from desk to desk by E-mail, they are as bountiful, as funny, as mean-spirited as ever. Send the best jests making the rounds at your job -- nothing unseemly or personally damaging, of course -- to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: At Belmont, Once Again The Future Is Uncertain
description: IN its heyday the Belmont Stakes had no trouble living up to its reputation as the crown jewel of horse racing. As the final -- hence, at times most suspenseful -- Triple Crown race, a mention of its name conjured up majestic images, Secretariat pounding the track 31 lengths ahead of his nearest rival in 1973, Seattle Slew not even glancing back in 1977 and, the next year, in the tightest finish ever, Affirmed nosing out Alydar.

description: WHEN George Fertitta, the president and chief executive of Margeotes, Fertitta & Partners, the Manhattan advertising agency, was wooing his wife 24 years ago, he told her that his middle name was Algonquin, and that the middle names of his siblings were Iroquois, Dakota and Mohawk.

title: Rev. Kenneth Neigh, 87, Dies; Led Church Into Civil Rights
description: The Rev. Kenneth G. Neigh, a national Presbyterian Church official who put the church in the forefront of the civil rights movement and broadened its commitment to social causes during the 1960's, died on Monday at his home at the church's Meadow Lakes retirement home in Hightstown, N.J. He would have been 88 yesterday.

title: WORD & IMAGE;Media Mongrels
description: I ONCE ORDERED A sheriff's badge with a coupon snatched from the back of a cereal box. When Mom didn't yank those boxes off the table, they also enthralled me with offers of magic wands and club kerchiefs. Although my orders were to buy cereals strictly for the taste of the stuff inside, I feigned enthusiasm even for shredded wheat just to savor the prizes pitched on the outside. In short, I grew up expecting content and commerce to work in symbiotic harmony, like the articles and advertisements in a newspaper, or comedies and commercials on television.

title: Atlanta: Scenes Beyond The Mall

Rather than cherishing and building an identity around eccentricity, the city usually defines its personality by the glitzy commercial spine of Peachtree Street beginning downtown, running north to the designer office towers of midtown and culminating in the state-of-the-art malls -- Phipps Plaza and Lenox Square -- that are to Atlanta what Fifth Avenue is to New York.

title: A Regatta With Lots of Tradition
description: SEVERAL thousand people turned out for New London's first Harvard-Yale Regatta, on June 28, 1878. Just-completed bleachers were filled; an observation train followed the race, and spectator boats were everywhere. As the two crews rowed furiously down the Thames River, telegraphers every half mile signaled who was ahead. Race officials raised balloons -- red for Harvard, blue for Yale -- to inform the crowds.

title: After Dark The Other Games Begin
description: GEORGIA has been the cradle of some of America's most influential popular music, from soul to alternative rock to hip-hop: the roll-call includes Little Richard, James Brown, the Allman Brothers, R.E.M. and Arrested Development. As the cultural hub of the New South, Atlanta is a place where down-home Americana rubs shoulders with the latest in communications technology. Many of its homegrown rock bands are close to blues, soul and country roots, while its recording studios have become a center for easygoing, seductive hip-hop and rhythm-and-blues. And with a sizable student population and a thriving middle class, Atlanta provides audiences for obscure local bands as well as national touring acts, in settings ranging from intimate, smoky basement hangouts to grand, scenic amphitheaters.

He says Mrs. Rosasco even called his mother in California and told her her son had AIDS. It was the first his mother had heard of his illness.

title: THE ROOSEVELT BEARS
description: In its centennial issue (April 14), the Magazine repeated the myth that The New York Times never published a comic strip. But it did, in 1906, after Adolph Ochs found his daughter, Iphigene, reading a competitor's comics. He commissioned "The Roosevelt Bears," drawings and verse about two bears who traveled east to see President Theodore Roosevelt. Only two years before, Roosevelt, amused by a cartoon showing him refusing to shoot a bear, had given permission for his name to be used for a new toy, the teddy bear. The toy survives, but Ochs's venture into educational comic strips died after six months because children preferred the colorful "Yellow Kid" and "Katzenjammer Kids." HAROLD FABER Ancram, N.Y.

His shoulders shimmied, his knees rocked, but he was careful not to flash any moves that might be construed as dancing. The sign in red letters above the dee-jay booth at Nation, a nightclub on Avenue A between Third and Fourth Streets, warned, "No Dancing."

title: IN BRIEF: BAEDEKER;Explosives and Torpedoes Left Their Mark on 2 Places
description: MAXIM Howell Township, Monmouth County. While studying at the Wesleyan Seminary in Kent's Hill, Me., Hudson Maxim developed a keen interest in chemistry. He began experimenting with explosives in 1888. In 1890, he built a dynamite and powder factory in the town that would become known as Maxim. There, he invented maximite, an explosive bursting powder that, when placed in torpedoes, resisted the shock of firing and the greater shock of piercing armor plate without bursting. The powder could then be set off by a delayed-action detonating fuse, which also happened to be invented by Maxim.
