title: Little Chappies With Breasts'
description: AN EXPERIMENT IN LOVE By Hilary Mantel. 250 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $23. HILARY MANTEL'S seventh novel, "An Experiment in Love," is only the second to be published in the United States. This is a shame, because Ms. Mantel is an exceptionally good writer. Her book's title, however, is somewhat misleading. "Experiment" suggests clinical detachment; but if experiments are going on, they're more like what Dr. Frankenstein got up to with the body parts: intense, unholy and messy. As for "love," the inaccuracy is that it's singular: there are many kinds of love in this book, almost all contaminated. "Enter the Dragoness" might be a more likely title, for this is a story about emotional kung fu, female style -- except that by the end, although all are wounded or worse, there's no clear winner.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Workers Fired for Selling Masters Badges
description: Three employees at the Augusta National Golf Club were fired and four were suspended for allegedly selling their 1996 Masters tournament series badges. The six men and one woman worked in the housekeeping and locker room/bar departments of the Augusta, Ga., club.

title: A Few Bright Spots for Young People Seeking Summer Jobs
description: At 18, Antoine Joyce is a veteran of New York City's summer jobs market. Having been employed for four summers in the Federal Government's largest employment program for teen-agers, he has been cast off this year to fend for himself.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Reeve Sends Call for a Cure For Spine Injuries
description: JUST days shy of the first anniversary of the devastating horseback-riding accident that left him a quadriplegic, Christopher Reeve spoke at the Burke Rehabilitation Hospital here about his determination that he and others like him who suffer from spinal-cord injuries will rise from their wheelchairs and walk.

title: Ukraine Yields Warheads
description: Ukraine transferred the last of its nuclear warheads to Russia today, President Leonid Kuchma said in a statement. Under an agreement with the United States and Russia signed in 1994, Ukraine was to receive $1 billion for giving up the weapons and Russia was to sell the nuclear components of the warheads to the United States and compensate Ukraine, mostly in the form of fuel for its five nuclear power stations. Ukraine is the second former Soviet republic to disarm, after Kazakstan.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS
description: While the memoir genre may stand accused of narcissism, it has a built-in redemptive escape hatch. A lesson in your fine clutch of excerpts: memoirs are most interesting and moving when they're about the mystery of a parent's character rather than about oneself.

title: The Fresh Air Fund;A City Girl Who Saw the Stars Returns the Favor
description: When Carol Gattuso Hausler was 8 years old, she fearfully boarded a train bound for Port Royal, Pa., leaving her Italian immigrant family and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, behind as she went off to "see America."

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Investing Abroad With a Conscience: It's Not Easy
description: JUST as Kathie Lee Gifford wept on her morning TV show after it became known that a line of clothing sold under her name was made by Honduran children working for pennies a day, Americans who buy mutual funds that invest in foreign markets might be appalled if they knew where their money really was going.

title: May 26-June 1;Sperm of a Different Kind
description: Two staid British journals published articles last week that may be the first harbinger of a very strange world, in which a woman could be inseminated by a man whose sperm had been grown in the testes of a mouse.

title: HORSE RACING;15 Races and Counting: Cigar Breezes to Victory
description: Two months after he won the Dubai World Cup on the Persian Gulf and became racing champion of the planet, the great horse Cigar gave a powerful solo performance today when he outraced five ordinary rivals, won the Massachusetts Handicap by 2 1/4 lengths and extended his winning streak to 15.

title: MUSIC;Westfair Founder Will Bid Choir Farewell
description: NINE years ago, Judith Hahnssen-Schwab set out to establish a choir that would "touch the lives of the people who come before us." Mrs. Hahnssen-Schwab recalled, "Our intent was to make a difference, to inspire spiritual oneness through the arts and to speak to the community with a balance of spirit, beauty, harmony and joy."

title: Men and Their Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM VIEW;Spoofing a Game That's Already Cartoonish
description: WHEN THE LIMOUSINE driver and rabid fan Edwina (Eddie) Franklin is named coach of the New York Knicks as a promotional stunt in the new film "Eddie," the resident star responds with disdain. "Stacy Patton ain't playing for no woman," says the player, who habitually refers to himself in the third person. But Patton does play, and that is the tip-off that this attempt to capture the comic spirit of professional basketball doesn't parody as much as it pales.

title: Shippan Point Opens Its Doors
description: VISITORS to six houses not far from Long Island Sound will be transported for a day when they stroll their waterfront gardens and view their furnishings. The Shippan-by-the-Sea house and garden tour will take place in Stamford for the second year on Friday from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.

title: Curfews Give No Lessons in Geography
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: No Sweep at Tonys

title: POLITICAL STAKES INCREASE IN FIGHT TO SAVE MEDICARE
description: The political war over the future of Medicare, a cannonade of oratory and statistical rotten tomatoes that has already thoroughly spattered both parties, is about to resume. And with near-religious fervor, for this time, control of both Congress and the Presidency could turn on the outcome.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bozell Acquires Garfield-Linn
description: Bozell Worldwide Inc., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, has acquired Garfield-Linn & Company in Chicago and merged it with its Chicago office. Terms were not disclosed.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK An Unraveling Crackdown The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has recently declared war on illegal employment in New York City's garment industry. The agency's raids on garment factories have inspired a stream of news releases heralding the number of factories hit (86) and workers caught (1,228). But the news releases do not describe what immigration officials, economists and workers themselves say happens after the raids. Most of the workers are released the same day and are usually not deported. Some go back to the very factories where they were picked up; others move to other factories or to industries in which there is no crackdown. [Page A1.]

title: Serve the Same Sauce?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trees Fall. Whole Town Hears.;Man's Landscaping Ignites Leaf-Loving Greenwich
description: When Dr. Paul I. Dantzig moved from Utica, N.Y., and bought an $825,000 home here in 1994, he wanted to make a few changes. The house for one. It had to go. So he had it torn down and began work on another.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Two Decades of Dance: A Scrapbook of Favorites
description: Tonight's "Great Performances" presentation keeps asking, What is dance all about? Viewers may also wonder, What is this special about? Well, "Dance in America: A Renaissance Revisited" is a 20th-anniversary souvenir scrapbook, culled from the impressive dance-on-video archive built over the years by WNET and by Jac Venza, executive producer of the series. In short, with budgets tight, this is a relatively cheap way to send a birthday present.

title: Metro Matters;From Welfare To the Top Of Her Class
description: LIKE most people, Kimberli Rothwell has mixed feelings about welfare. She considers it demeaning, and thinks it fosters dependency and is riddled with fraud.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Guilty Plea in Bond Fraud
description: A former Merrill Lynch bond processor could receive five years in prison and a $1.1 million fine at his sentencing on Aug. 26, after he pleaded guilty in Federal court on Friday to embezzling more than $550,000.

title: A Quicker Pace Means No Peace in the Valley
description: Silicon Valley, held in the Internet's thrall, has found a new religion. Its symbols are everywhere -- including the slide that David Hancock recently used to illustrate a sermon to his management team.

title: Summer Village Regrets a Chilling Event
description: Amid all the voices on the sun-splashed streets and sidewalks of this village by the ocean, the most eloquent words today were silent ones.

title: CUNY's Tenure Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Beating Victim Emerges From His Coma, Slowly
description: After a week of worrying and waiting for some sign that Shane Daniels might recover from a severe beating outside a bar in Westhampton Beach, L.I., his family and doctors finally got a promising one yesterday when he opened his eyes and began moving his arms and legs.

title: Rent' and 'Master Class' Win Tonys; No Award for Andrews
description: Broadway took Julie Andrews at her word last night, denying her the Tony Award that she had declared she did not want. In the surprise of the evening, the Tony voters gave the prize for best actress in a musical to Donna Murphy of "The King and I."

title: GOLF;Woods to Stay in College
description: Tiger Woods, the amateur golfing star from Stanford, achieved two goals and delayed another this weekend. First, he won the individual title at the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's championship on Saturday at the Honors Course in Ooltewah, Tenn. Then he was awarded the Jack Nicklaus college player of the year trophy today at Muirfield Village.

title: Editorial Notebook;Mario Pataki?
description: An overdue state budget has become such a matter of course in New York that it is unlikely average citizens have noticed that another all-time record for lateness is about to be set. But George Pataki promised that such things would not happen on his watch, and as the official deadline recedes further and further into the past, the Governor has been looking increasingly frayed around the edges. Last week, under a barrage of questions from reporters about his collapsed budget plans, Mr. Pataki was photographed holding his hand to his forehead in a woebegone gesture of exasperation or exhaustion.

title: Alton Clingan, 27, Writer of Quintets
description: Alton Howe Clingan, a composer whose works have recently been performed in New York City, Boston and Amsterdam, died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 27.

title: Union Rejects McDonnell Pact
description: The union representing 6,700 machinists at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation rejected a contract offer today from McDonnell, the giant aerospace company and military contractor, and indicated that a strike might start on Wednesday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Hit-and-Run Kills Cabby Once Known for Bagels
description: Hector Hernandez, one of the founding partners of H & H Bagels on the Upper West Side, didn't talk much about his role in helping to build up the famous business. In fact, he was loath to mention it.

title: Elliot Lake Journal;Snug Retiree Haven Where Uranium Mine Stood
description: Uranium miners' children used to kick soccer balls and ride two- and three-wheelers around the garden plots where Eileen Porter, 83, and Ingeborg Boone, 57, now tend the fresh plantings of their carrots, beans, peppers, strawberries and rhubarb.

title: Eccentric Editor Is Jailed Over Letter in Paper
description: There was the time Bruce Anderson published a satirical list of 107 people whom he described as potential satanic child molesters in Mendocino County. Or the hullabaloo Mr. Anderson raised when he fabricated an interview in which the area's Congressman called his constituents "know-nothing malcontents" who mainly cared about "where their next joint is coming from."

title: In America;What Unity Looks Like
description: Azim Khamisa is an investment banker. On Saturday he stood at the Lincoln Memorial and told some 200,000 people at the Stand for Children gathering, "I speak to you as an international businessman and a proud but impatient citizen, but foremost as a father. It is 16 months and 11 days since I lost my only son, Tariq. He was 20 years old."

title: Mackinac Island Journal;At a Tourist Resort, Us vs. Them Sentiments
description: For anyone accustomed to the sharp-edged wit of big cities, last week's humor column in the local newspaper of this quaint resort was pretty tame.

title: U.S. May 'Adapt' Policy to New Israeli Leader
description: Responding to questions about American policy in the Middle East after the narrow election victory of Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel, Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher said today that adjustments will be necessary in response to a more conservative leadership in Israel.

title: Algeria-China Nuclear Tie
description: Algeria, which has a Chinese-made nuclear reactor, has signed a draft nuclear cooperation agreement with China, the official Algerian news agency A.P.S. reported today.

title: Edward P. Bullard 4th, Development Organization Leader, 61
description: Edward P. Bullard 4th, the former president of TechnoServe, a non-profit international development organization, died on Thursday in his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 61.

title: James Daniel Blanc, Dancer, 36
description: James Daniel Blanc, a modern dancer who performed with Pilobolus and other troupes, died on May 11 at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 36.

title: Treasury Announces Schedule to Sell Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Vanbiesbrouck Is Old And Always in the Way
description: He had ice packs covering his right knee and left shoulder, and another one bulging from under his T-shirt at the small of his back, each one secured by a bandage and yards of athletic tape. John Vanbiesbrouck, the Florida Panthers' goaltender, looked like he was about to be mummified, but he had actually put the wraps on the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Halls of Treasure but Little Cash at the Hermitage
description: The last two months have been like Christmas in much of Russia. Eager to buy his way back into the good graces of voters before the election on June 16, President Boris N. Yeltsin has been tossing cash in the direction of nearly every worker, factory director and farm collective he can find.

title: Accounts Put Only One Officer at Scene of L.I. Beating
description: A man who was with a New York City police detective accused in the beating of a young black man outside a nightclub here said through his lawyer today that there were no other police officers in their group of four. He has also agreed to testify without immunity before a grand jury.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Lemieux Suspended for 2 Games of Finals
description: The Colorado Avalanche right wing, Claude Lemieux, was suspended today for the first two games of the Stanley Cup finals against the Florida Panthers for his blind-side check on the Detroit Red Wings forward, Kris Draper.

title: Corrections
description: An article Saturday about the beating of a black man outside a Westhampton, L.I., nightclub misspelled the surname of a figure in the case in some editions. His name is Austin Offen, not Offner.

title: Bridge
description: Teams headed by Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., and Bob Blanchard of Manhattan clashed yesterday in the finals of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, played at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street. After 28 deals of a scheduled 56, Becker led by 12 imps.

title: DANCE REVIEW;At the Barre, a Dreamlike Tone, Then Exuberance
description: There was a time when young choreographers, not just young dancers, were regularly introduced at the School of American Ballet's annual spring performances.

title: No Headline
description: The desire to fit the cultural ideal of thinness drives many women to diet severely. In some vulnerable young women, this leads to bingeing and purging, or to self-starvation." Dr. Terence Wilson, a psychologist at Rutgers University. [D2:5.]

title: Abroad at Home;Bosnia Betrayed Again
description: Suppose that at the end of World War II Heinrich Himmler and Adolf Eichmann had remained in control of a large zone of Germany. They were supposed to be removed and tried for war crimes. But the United States and its allies decided to hold all-German elections while the Nazis still ruled the zone, suppressing and murdering opponents.

title: HORSE RACING;'Song' Showing Signs of Ulcers
description: The continuing saga of Unbridled's Song took yet another turn yesterday when his trainer, Jim Ryerson, reported that the colt showed signs of ulcers -- some possibly bleeding -- in a medical checkup.

title: These Days, a Magazine to Satisfy Every Taste Bud
description: Sipping their gourmet coffee, chugging -- but of course savoring -- their boutique beers, spooning in their salsa, the consumers of the trendiest beverages and foods are the targets of a growing wave of magazines and newsletters.

title: SOCCER;Wood's Goal Lifts MetroStars
description: A. J. Wood, a possible member of the United States Olympic soccer team, scored his second goal in two games to give the MetroStars a 1-0 victory over Dallas today in Major League Soccer.

title: Gambling in the Senate
description: Despite intense opposition from the gambling industry, the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee has approved a worthwhile measure to create a national commission to review the social and economic impact of casinos and state-run lotteries. Chances are good that it would win easy approval by the Senate, much as a similar bill unanimously passed the House in March. But there remains a danger that Senate Republican leaders may try to kill the measure quietly by failing to allow time for a vote on the Senate calendar.

title: Albert (Pud) Brown, Jazz Musician, 79
description: Albert (Pud) Brown, a Dixieland jazz clarinetist and saxophone player who created the "Johnson Rag," died of a heart attack on Monday. He was 79.

title: POLITICS: THE MANAGER;Dole Campaign Chief Relying On Determination, and Luck
description: Scott Reed, Bob Dole's campaign manager, sits at his desk at campaign headquarters here in a classic Reed pose, with eight rows of papers strung out neatly before him, arrayed like spokes on a bicycle wheel.

title: Bristol-Myers to Seek A New Obesity Drug
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb and an Australian institute will collaborate on research that could lead to a new obesity drug.

title: POP REVIEW;Songs Eerie and Foreboding By the Light of a Cigarette
description: Tricky disdains the cult of personality. "Maxinquaye" (Island), one of the most innovative albums of 1995, established his reputation as a producer, songwriter and laconic rapper. But Tricky's next project is billed as Nearly God, which was a four-member band when it performed on Wednesday night at the Mercury Lounge. Tricky spent the entire set in darkness, illuminated mostly by his cigarette.

title: BASEBALL;New Go-Go Yankees Take Their Cue From Mr. Torre
description: Gerald Williams spent the entire afternoon annoying the Athletics and being quite successful at it. He ran here, he ran there, he ran everywhere. Terry Steinbach never got a chance to relax because Williams constantly tested his arm, disturbed Oakland's pitchers and breezed around the bases as if it were an afternoon in the park.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Influenced By Weimar And Harlem
description: The more famous artists who fled Nazi Germany were given an enthusiastic embrace in the United States: lecture tours, publishing contracts, do-nothing professorships at major universities. No such welcome awaited Alexander Zemlinsky, an Austrian composer of considerable but not enormous reputation, who arrived in New York to little fanfare in 1938 and died a nonentity four years later. On Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Brooklyn Philharmonic partially atoned for Zemlinsky's neglect by presenting his "Symphonische Gesange," in the company of nothing less than the Beethoven Ninth.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: POLITICS: THE STATE CHAIRMAN;This Time, on Receiving End of Snub
description: The chairman of the Washington Republican Party, who angered backers of Patrick J. Buchanan by barring him from speaking at the state convention this past weekend, has been denied a seat as a delegate to the Republican National Convention in August.

title: In New York City High Schools, Paths to Diploma Grow Longer for Many
description: The percentage of New York City high school students graduating in the traditional four years has reached a five-year low, according to the Board of Education. But with the dropout rate also falling over the same period, there are now more 19-, 20- and 21-year-olds than ever in classrooms.

title: Successes Reported for Curfews, but Doubts Persist
description: Nightly curfews for teen-agers, like those recommended last week by President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, have shown encouraging signs of reducing juvenile crime in several cities across the nation.

title: Robert Pusey Hastings, Co-Founder of Law Firm, 86
description: Robert Pusey Hastings, a co-founder of a prominent international law firm and a civic leader in Los Angeles, died at his home in Pasadena, Calif., on May 23, his 86th birthday.

title: Victor in Israel Calls for Peace With the Arabs
description: Sending conciliatory messages in all directions in his first speech since his election as Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu today issued ringing calls for harmony at home and peace with the Arabs.

title: J. Cuatrecasas, 93, An Expert in Botany
description: Jose Cuatrecasas, a research botanist at the Smithsonian Institution and the National Science Foundation, and an expert on the flora and ecology of South and Central America, died on May 23 in Bethesda, Md. He was 93 and had lived in Washington.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 'Skeletal' Models Cause a Furor A day after the Swiss watch manufacturer Omega said it had suspended its advertising in the British version of Vogue to protest the magazine's use of what Omega called skeletal models in a fashion layout, Omega's chairman overruled the company's marketing manager and said the advertising would continue.

title: A Pyramid Scheme Is Halted by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission said last week that it had halted an illegal pyramid scheme advertised on the Internet that received more than $6 million from thousands of investors.

title: Bitterness and Posturing As Rivalries Resurface In Fight for CableNews
description: The all-news channel that NBC, in partnership with the Microsoft Corporation, plans to start next month has become entangled in a dispute between cable operators and the broadcast network. Several senior cable operators are threatening to balk at NBC's plans to distribute the new all-news channel in place of its current America's Talking channel. NBC is responding in kind, saying that any cable system that refuses to carry the news channel in place of America's Talking will face an immediate lawsuit, and, more ominously, will no longer get any programming from the top-rated broadcast network. That includes the 1996 Olympic Games from Atlanta, which begin only four days after the scheduled start of MSNBC.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Exploring Decisions of Life and Death
description: Making use of afternoon talk-show devices in an up-market way, "Whose Death Is It Anyway?" takes on the subject of when to pull the plug. The studio audience -- mainly relatives of the departed along with a smattering of doctors, nurses, social workers and clergymen -- vent the emotions involved in that ultimate decision and in getting hospitals to carry out a family's wishes. Their sad stories are echoed by three reports by Betty Rollin, an NBC reporter:

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Playing, And Living, By a Father's Rules
description: On the night of Jan. 18, 1984, Steve Kerr, an 18-year-old freshman and a substitute player on the basketball team at the University of Arizona in Tucson, was asleep in his bed in the Babcock dormitory when the ringing of the telephone woke him up. It was about 3 A.M.

title: 6 Shot at Baptism Party in Queens Church
description: Six people were shot, three of them critically injured, last night as gunfire shattered the festive air of a baptismal party at a Greek Orthodox church in Queens, the police said.

description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Both Evil and Revenge Can Smolder for Years
description: THE STATEMENT By Brian Moore 250 pages. A William Abrahams Book/Dutton/Penguin. $22.95.

title: RAID AND RELEASE -- A special report.;A Tattered Crackdown on Illegal Workers
description: Walkie-talkies in hand, Federal immigration agents guard possible lines of escape from the garment factories while another contingent spreads through the rows of sewing machines, handcuffing workers believed to be in the country illegally and leading them to government vans.

title: Technology: DIGITAL COMMERCE;As privacy grows scarcer on the Internet, people finally start to take notice.
description: AFTER many years of heated discussion among the digerati, the debate over the an individual's privacy rights while using the Internet and the World Wide Web has finally moved into the mainstream.

title: Officer Fatally Shoots Man in a Stolen Car
description: A police officer shot and killed a man in the Bronx early Saturday when he moved suddenly while officers were questioning him about the stolen vehicle he was driving, the police said.

title: Martin M. Schaeffer, Theater Critic, 50
description: Martin M. Schaeffer, a theater and cabaret critic for Variety and other publications, died on Wednesday at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 50.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Clinton to Speak at Princeton
description: By tradition, Princeton University does not have outside speakers at its graduation ceremonies, but university officials say that Princeton's 250th anniversary this year calls for an exception. So President Clinton will speak at commencement ceremonies tomorrow.

title: Bill to Ease Prosecution Of Sex Abuse
description: York State legislative leaders have agreed on a bill that would make it easier to prosecute abusive pedophiles and give their victims more time to bring charges against them.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Celestial Seasonings Selects Dailey
description: Celestial Seasonings Inc., the maker and marketer of herbal teas, has selected Dailey & Associates in Los Angeles to handle its account, which had been handled by Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco for nine months. The billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Francois Genoud, Nazi Sympathizer, 81
description: Francois Genoud, a Nazi sympathizer who became a banker for Arab militants and defender of terrorists, committed suicide by poison on Thursday with the help of a Swiss pro-euthanasia group, a family spokesman said. He was 81.

title: Real Peace With Security': Parts of Netanyahu's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Benjamin Netanyahu, Prime Minister-elect of Israel, to his supporters today, as translated from the Hebrew.

description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;Serene Sorenstam Wins Her Second Straight U.S. Open
description: Everything seems easy in Annika Sorenstam's golf game. She hits the fairways with remarkable consistency and is in a tranquil frame of mind when she reaches the green. Even though she knew she was on her way to history this afternoon at the 51st United States Women's Open, Sorenstam's disposition suggested she was taking a casual walk in the park.

title: Sports of The Times;The New, Improved Talcum-Powder Putter
description: IN the long late afternoon shadows of a week ago Saturday at the Kansas City Country Club, Tom Watson was on the putting green under the steady eyes of Stan Thirsk, the club pro who has developed and polished his game since he was 6 years old.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Cool Single People Living in Alaska, but Mooseless
description: With the 1995-96 season officially over, television diddles, as usual, into the summer months. Reruns are mixed with a scattering of new series that are probable rejects or possible winners getting an eager jump on the fall. Fox brings on one of each tonight.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Family Portrait in Word and Movement
description: People fascinate David Dorfman. That became evident on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop in a program that revealed him to be one of our finest young choreographers.

title: Dana and U.S. In Settlement
description: The Dana Corporation said Friday that it had agreed to pay $10.2 million to settle remaining Federal charges that a former subsidiary overcharged the Pentagon for jet-engine parts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUSAN McDOUGAL, who was convicted of fraud last week in the Whitewater investigation along with her former husband, James B. McDougal, and Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas, faces yet another legal battle involving another famous name: ZUBIN MEHTA, the conductor.

title: American Topics : Those Ever-Present Video Cameras:Are They an Invasion of Privacy?
description: A landlord uses a camera hidden in a smoke detector to spy on a tenant. A hospital videotapes its staff to prevent theft, but denies that it is spying on patients as well. And a mother, anxious about her child's welfare, spends $750 to surreptitiously keep an eye on her babysitter.

title: GOLF;Watson Buries Nine Years of Doubts and Despair
description: All the years of frustration, all the three-putts and the missed three-footers and the disappointments of a decade were about to be wiped away by a single stroke of Tom Watson's putter.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Alive, Bloodthirsty and Here
description: Pestilence update: The Asian tiger mosquito, a disease-carrying nuisance that has spread through 30 states, usually by hitching rides on old tires being shipped to dumps, has come through the cold weather alive and well in New Jersey.

title: BOSNIAN ELECTIONS TO GO AHEAD IN '96, CHRISTOPHER SAYS
description: After meeting with the Presidents of Bosnia, Serbia and Croatia and with other officials in charge of carrying out the peace accord for Bosnia, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said tonight that elections would go ahead there this year. He said he expected a date to be set by the end of this month.

title: Patents;Some independent inventors cry foul about an omnibus bill to reshape the patent  system.
description: THE introduction last month of a Congressional bill that consolidates several proposals to reshape the patent system into one piece of legislation has triggered a red alert among the independent inventors who have waged a losing battle against revisions of intellectual property laws.

title: Armored Vehicles Moved Closer to Freemen Ranch
description: Federal agents moved three armored vehicles closer to the Freemen ranch near here today, within the F.B.I.'s roadblocks around the ranch where the anti-Government group has been holed up for 70 days.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Prudential Unit Narrows Its Review
description: Prudential Healthcare in Roseland, N.J., has narrowed the review on its consolidated account to five semifinalists from a list of 18 contenders. The account, with billings estimated at $20 million, had been divided among three agencies: W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore, which continues to handle some direct marketing for Prudential Healthcare; Larkin Meeder Schweidel in Dallas, and Noble Steed Associates in Lutherville, Md.

title: Sports of The Times;The Mets Are Getting Burned at the Hot Corner
description: BEFORE the Dodgers' Ismael Valdes ever threw a pitch in anger against the Mets yesterday, Dallas Green talked about a major difference in his club from this year to last.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Accord on Investigative Bill
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to release a compromise bill today to extend the life of the embattled State Commission of Investigation until 2002 without requiring it to operate under the direction of the state attorney general, The Associated Press said.

title: POLITICS: THE TEACHER;Political Lessons Learned In School of Hard Knocks
description: With a bittersweet laugh trilling back toward 1988, Michael S. Dukakis described the fate that has befallen him: "I teach my mistakes."

description: * UMI, a division of Bell & Howell Corp., Ann Arbor, Mich., to Crispin & Porter Advertising, Miami, to introduce Proquest Direct, a new on-line information service. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

description: THE insuperable power of "family values" in an election year seems to have claimed another victory -- or victim, depending on one's perspective.

description: International A3-9

description: Members of California's Reform Party immersed themselves today in the nitty-gritty aspects of building a third party, attending workshops on everything from organizing precincts to writing a party platform. But none of those sessions delved into the topic that was on the mind of Mark A. Sturdevant and some others all weekend.

title: American Topics : Those Reports of Bagel Injuries Have Only a Crumb of Truth
description: Dan Rodricks, a columnist for The Baltimore Sun, found the reports hard to believe. Are bagel cuts really the most common injury seen in emergency rooms? Or was this a bit of '90s lore so often repeated that it had taken on a life of its own?

description: Mark Clark said it had been two years since he had thrown the ball this well.

description: To the Editor:

title: Communists Exploit Old Fears of Fraud Before Russia Votes
description: Like many Russians, Vladimir I. Zakharov is reluctant to say who will get his vote in this month's presidential election. But he's quick to declare his conviction that the votes will not be counted fairly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Taking his campaign to legalize industrial hemp -- as opposed to marijuana -- to Beattyville, Ky., WOODY HARRELSON, the actor, was arrested Saturday after planting four marijuana seeds while a television crew recorded the staged event.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dole at Polish Festival
description: Greeted by chants of "Every Pole is for Dole," Bob Dole waded into New Jersey politics for the second time in a week yesterday, the A.P. reported. Joined by Governor Whitman and the Republican Senate contender, Dick Zimmer, Mr. Dole worked a crowd of several hundred at the 25th annual Polish ethnic festival at the Garden State Arts Center.

title: The New Communist Manifesto
description: The failure of Soviet economic policy was so staggering that it is hard to believe anyone would seriously suggest trying it again. But that is just what the Russian Communist Party proposes. With a few concessions to the changed nature of the Russian economy, the Communists would essentially roll back history and reinstitute the kind of command system that left the Soviet Union in a stupor.

title: William F. Storke, 73, Producer Of Acclaimed TV Dramas, Dies
description: William F. Storke, a producer of television drama whose programming was regarded as a cultural oasis in commercial television, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: Tokyo Stocks Off Slightly
description: Japanese stocks traded very slightly lower here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 2.71 points, or three-hundredths of 1 percent, to stand at 21,953.48. On Friday, the Nikkei index rose 69.84 points.

title: American Topics
description: Two Indiana teenagers thought they had devised the perfect scam: signing checks with disappearing ink. But the too-clever teens, who allegedly passed $2,000 in such checks, forgot one detail: the name of one of the two, Jeffrey J. Pyrcioch, was permanently printed at the top of the checks. The vanishing signatures, moreover, can be restored at a police laboratory, authorities say. The suspects, Pyrcioch and Heather M. Green, could face eight years in prison.

title: Mario Is Looking Better With Age
description: At the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles last month, Nintendo created an exhibit so extravagant that it could make Hollywood blush. In the lights-flashing, sound-blaring display the company presented its long-delayed video gaming box called Nintendo 64.

title: Ex-Senator May Get Role in Ulster Talks
description: Britain and Ireland are expected to appoint George J. Mitchell, the former Democratic Senator from Maine and chairman of an international commission on disarmament of paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland, to a major post in the peace talks that start on June 10, British officials said today.

title: POP REVIEW;The Trials of Youth, Lovers And Long-Distance Truckers
description: Richard Shindell mentioned that he was a seminary dropout during his set on Thursday night at the Fast Folk Cafe, and it showed in songs from his most recent album, "Blue Divide" (Shanachie).

title: Turbulence Marks Races In Primary
description: When New Jersey's longtime Democratic Senator, Bill Bradley, announced last year that he would resign at the end of his current term, he set off a chain reaction among state politicians. Two Congressmen, a Democrat, Robert G. Torricelli, and a Republican, Dick Zimmer, soon announced that they would vacate their House posts to pursue Mr. Bradley's seat. And other hopefuls for both the Senate and the House were soon drawn into the vacuum.

title: In First Free Election in Chad, Voters Are Eager but Wary
description: Long lines began forming early this morning throughout this ragged city of mud houses and dusty, littered streets as voters turned out in large numbers for the first democratic presidential election in 36 years of independence from France.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Surveys Rate Nigeria as Most Corrupt Nation for Business
description: Nigeria tops the list of countries that international business people consider the most corrupt, according to a ranking published yesterday by a Berlin-based independent organization, Transparency International.

title: Equity Offerings Planned for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible-debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Czech Center-Right Coalition Loses Its Majority
description: The center-right coalition of Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus narrowly lost its parliamentary majority, according to unofficial election results released today.

title: Taking In the Sites;On Languages, the Web Really Is World Wide
description: Da li vi govorite Engleski?

title: YACHT RACING;Australian Testing Ground In Storied Northeast Waters
description: The lure of competing in new state-of-the-art sailboats honed by highly skilled crews isn't that easy for expert yachtsmen to pass up. Add to that a touch of history -- race waters that run deep with cup lore -- and it's not hard to figure out why an America's Cup team from Australia headed north last week.

title: Essay;Netanyahu's 'New Way'
description: What a landslide!" was President Clinton's telephoned greeting to Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli candidate he worked so hard to defeat.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Following are tentative release dates for key economic indicators this week:

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Kemp Is Cool, And the Sonics Have a Date In Chicago
description: The Seattle SuperSonics busted out of their straitjackets.

title: Advertising;Now that it is a separate company, Lucent is spending $50 million to create an image.
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES, up until a few months ago, had an image problem: it had no image. In fact, Lucent Technologies Inc., the former AT&T subsidiary that was spun off earlier this year, had no name, no logo and no corporate identity.

title: TENNIS;Seles Overcomes Long Shadows of the Past and Maleeva to Advance
description: The last time Monica Seles faced Magdalena Maleeva on red clay on a dank, dark day like this one, they were in Hamburg, Germany, on April 30, 1993. So was Gunther Parche, a deranged fan of Steffi Graf's, who, during a second-set changeover, yanked out a kitchen knife and stabbed Seles in the back.

title: Chinese Pirate Factories Have Roots Abroad, U.S. Study Says
description: A detailed study by the Clinton Administration of Chinese factories that are pirating billions of dollars worth of American software, music and videos shows that almost all the operations are partly owned by foreign companies, some of them working from nations that are close allies and trading partners of the United States.

title: Skeletal' Models Create Furor Over British Vogue
description: After stepping into a minefield of controversy over the connection between fashion and health, the Swiss watch manufacturer Omega reversed its decision to stop advertising in a British fashion magazine that used what it called "skeletal" models.

title: Talks in Chechnya As 4 Killed by Mine
description: Four Russian soldiers were killed today when their armored personnel carrier hit a mine in Chechnya, and an international mediator met with Russia's military commander in the separatist republic to try to get negotiations back on track after fighting marred the first day of a cease-fire on Saturday.

title: California Regents Criticized as Hasty on Affirmative Action
description: The nation's largest college faculty organization has issued a report that criticizes the decision last year by the University of California Board of Regents to end affirmative action as hasty and politically motivated.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;To Revive a Public Voice
description: Wilfredo Caraballo, who was New Jersey's Public Advocate for three years until Gov. Christine Todd Whitman abolished the office, wants the state to restore its consumer-advocacy muscle.

title: Missionary Killed in Opium War Canonized
description: Pope John Paul II today canonized a French missionary who was executed in 1840 in China and paid tribute to Catholics still suffering there.

title: Asian-American Racial Identity? Look Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Critiques of Science Open a Useful Door
description: To the Editor:

title: Smart Phone' Makers Seek Cheaper and Easier Way to Reach the Internet
description: Despite the considerable attention being paid to the development of the network computer, the gateway to the Internet may not be a $500 PC but a $250 telephone -- or both.

title: A Weekend Without War Over the Abortion Issue
description: In workshops and seminars, 100 people from both sides in the fight over abortion met here this weekend to talk about their beliefs without proselytizing or condemning each other.

title: HORSE RACING;Two Trainers With Triple Vision
description: The odds are astronomical. Every year more than 35,000 thoroughbreds are born in the United States. About 75 from each crop end up in the barns of two trainers, D. Wayne Lukas and Nick Zito. And yet, for the last three years, those two men have won eight consecutive Triple Crown races, with Zito's victories in the 1994 Kentucky Derby and 1996 Preakness Stakes providing the bookends for Lukas's record run of six straight.

title: Asian-American Racial Identity? Look Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy, Former President of India, 83
description: Neelam Sanjeeva Reddy, a former President of India who was at the center of a split in the powerful Congress Party in 1969, died of pneumonia on Saturday, hospital officials here said. He was 83.

title: Book Sequel Creates a New Civil War
description: Writing a sequel to a passionately loved American novel is no easy task, as the author Alexandra Ripley found when she tried her hand at a continuation of Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" in 1991. The result, "Scarlett," was pummeled by the critics, even as the public lapped it up so fast that the book recouped its $5 million advance within 90 days and sold 2.2 million copies in hard cover.

title: Adopting Across the Color Line
description: When I was a little boy, my older brother Richie would often try to dupe me into believing I was adopted. It was easy enough. My mother is white. My 11 siblings, including Richie, are black. Growing up, I looked nothing like our biological mother, a Jewish immigrant from Poland. Neither, of course, did Richie, but his power over me defied all logic. So anytime I got on his nerves, which was often enough, his ruse would begin. "You're adopted, man," he would say. "Mommy's not your real mother. Your real mother's in jail. And she's coming to get you soon."

title: CHRONICLE
description: Rarely do book parties require the guests to do more than congratulate the author, have a drink and an hors d'oeuvre, and maybe gossip.

title: Simon Potok, 58, Rabbi in Rockland
description: Rabbi Simon Potok, who headed the Nanuet Hebrew Center in Nanuet, N.Y., for 20 years and was a founding board member of a New York Holocaust studies center, died on Tuesday at his home in Nanuet. He was 58.

title: Peres Speech Invokes 'Israeli Dream'
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres, who failed to sweep up enough of his nation in his vision of peace, delivered a political testament today, saying Israel should honor an agreement with the Palestinians and reach accords with Syria and Lebanon.

title: Asian-American Racial Identity? Look Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope, and Pragmatism, for U.N. Cities Conference
description: Twenty years ago the United Nations held a conference in Vancouver to talk about a worrying world trend toward urbanization, especially the uncontrolled growth of cities in some of the poorest countries.

title: Justices to Hear Challenge to Law on Inmates' Access to U.S. Court
description: Meeting on Monday in a rare end-of-term argument session, the Supreme Court will hear a challenge to a new law that limits access to Federal court by state prison inmates.

title: Motive Sought In Killing At a Church
description: An argument among uninvited guests led to a wild shooting at a baptismal party in a church basement in Queens that left one person dead and five others injured, the police said yesterday.

title: After Israeli Election, Is Peace Just a Dream?;What 'New Power'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Chips May Scramble U.S. Export Ban
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation has quietly begun selling a powerful data-scrambling chip set that is likely to undermine the Clinton Administration's efforts to restrict the export of the fundamental technology for protecting secrets and commerce in the information age.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Broncos Waive Pritchard
description: The Denver Broncos yesterday waived the veteran wide receiver MIKE PRITCHARD, whose two years at Denver have been plagued by injuries that limited his production. Pritchard, 26, was a University of Colorado star and Atlanta's first-round draft choice in 1991. (AP)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;What Eluded News Cameras at Tiananmen Square
description: Taking umbrage at the showing of "The Gate of Heavenly Peace" at last year's New York Film Festival, the Chinese Government prevented Zhang Yimou, a prominent director who had nothing to do with the documentary, from attending the event. The action only served to draw more attention to this American-made account of the 1989 student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in Beijing. Tonight a much larger audience can see a slightly shortened version of the remarkable work, courtesy of "Frontline."

title: IN PERFORMANCE;POP
description: Infusing 1930's Nostalgia With a Tangy, Modern Edge Mary Cleere Haran Rainbow and Stars

title: Julio Bocca to Return
description: Julio Bocca is to return to American Ballet Theater to dance "La Bayadere" at the matinee tomorrow at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Bocca was forced to cancel three performances this season because of a knee injury. He is also to dance "La Bayadere" on Thursday, Balanchine's "Apollo" on Friday and "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux" on Saturday. Information: (212) 362-6000.

title: Court Restricts Prayer at a Mississippi School
description: In a closely watched Mississippi school prayer case, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the public schools of Pontotoc County had violated the First Amendment rights of a family that had protested school prayers and religious instruction.

title: Advocates of Sustainable Mahogany Harvests Counter Boycott
description: THE mahogany tree, with its dark and beautifully grained wood, has become a lightning rod for environmental activists committed to saving the tropical forests of Latin America. The Rainforest Action Network, based in San Francisco, says the bigleaf mahogany, which grows from southern Mexico to Brazil, is in danger of extinction, and it has called for a boycott of mahogany products by American consumers and international action to restrict the mahogany trade.

title: She Pushed and a Pipeline Moved;A Dutchess County Woman Fought a Utility, and Shamed It
description: In the tradition of ordinary people who wage crusades against big business, Anne Marie Mueser may set a new standard of stubbornness. To fight a pipeline, she put aside just about everything for 10 years, including, she says, cleaning her rickety farmhouse and painting her dilapidated barn.

title: Families of Valujet Crash Victims Find Lawyers Ignore Solicitation Ban
description: Where there is a disaster like the crash of Valujet Flight 592, there will always be lawyers looking for clients. And if the Valujet crash is a guide, they cannot be stopped by the state bar's ban on solicitation of disaster victims and their families, nor by threats of disbarment.

title: Warner Music Plans to Shift Key Executives
description: In a move aimed at consolidating their control over the Warner Music Group, the co-chairmen, Bob Daly and Terry Semel, are relocating several crucial executives to Los Angeles, where Mr. Daly and Mr. Semel are based.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Formica Selects Carmichael Lynch
description: The Formica Corporation in Cincinnati, a subsidiary of BTR P.L.C., said yesterday that it had named Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis as the first agency to handle advertising and marketing for its laminate flooring products. The billings were estimated at $10 million. Carmichael Lynch was awarded the account after a monthlong review that also included Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis and the Martin Agency in Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York continues to handle advertising for Formica surface products.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Moon Signs Big Deal
description: He is nearing 40 years old and his 13th season in the National Football League, but yesterday quarterback WARREN MOON became the highest-paid player in Minnesota Vikings history when he agreed to a three-year, $15 million contract extension.

title: TENNIS;In a Day of Upsets, Muster and Edberg Fall
description: It was a sweet enough spring day, but Roland Garros germinated a pair of bitter defeats. The tunnel-visioned Thomas Muster can no longer pursue a second consecutive French Open crown, and Stefan Edberg, the consummate tennis professional, will retire without ever having earned one.

title: Peru Suspect Held in New York
description: A 46-year-old Peruvian man held inside a Federal jail in Manhattan has been charged with participating in the Shining Path insurgency in Peru, including a guerrilla ambush five years ago that killed six police officers.

title: Sideshows Redux
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Corporate Insolvencies Climb 14% in Germany
description: Corporate insolvencies in Germany climbed 14 percent in the first quarter, led by a strong rise in the eastern part of the country, the Federal Statistics Office reported yesterday. Eastern Germany's economy has been hit particularly hard by a recent slowdown. Germany's economy is estimated to have contracted for the second consecutive quarter in the first quarter.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Scholarships Honor a Victim
description: Stephen Flatow, the father of a New Jersey woman killed last year in a terrorist bombing in the Gaza Strip, awarded scholarships yesterday to five Jewish students to study in Israel this summer, The Associated Press reported.

title: From the U.S., Mixed Signals On Bosnia War Crime Issue
description: Pentagon officials said today that NATO peacekeepers in Bosnia were not stepping up their efforts to catch accused war criminals, despite the insistence of Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Sunday that the troops would start conducting more aggressive patrols, increasing the likelihood of arrests.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Impish Noisemakers Revel In Sounds of the Century
description: One thing is undeniable about the Bang on a Can Marathon on Sunday: David Lang, Michael Gordon and Julia Wolfe, the composers who organized this ninth annual event, have tapped into an audience curious about new music.

title: New York Investigating Lloyd's of London
description: The New York State Attorney General's office is investigating Lloyd's of London, the British insurance market that is battling fraud allegations in 11 other states, a New York official said today.

title: New Look for NATO:A Balance of Strategic Aims
description: PARIS  The critical trade-off that opened the way to NATO's radical reorganization involved the job descriptions of some senior European officers in the alliance, including French officers who will assume slots for the first time in 30 years.

title: Marine Dies in Training
description: A marine plunged to his death and five others were hurt on Sunday night in mountain training in the Angeles National Forest.

title: Once a Friendly Fixture, a Telephone Operator Finds Herself Obsolete
description: Rose DiMaggio Trela has been a telephone operator since neighborhoods were linked on a single party line and family members gathered around the phone for the rarity of a long distance call.

title: A Woman of Words That Win Pulitzers
description: When "William Cooper's Town" won the Pulitzer Prize for history this year, its author, Alan Taylor, had every right to rejoice. The prize confers honor and, within fairly modest limits, guarantees additional sales. His editor at Alfred A. Knopf, Jane N. Garrett, shared his delight but perhaps not his surprise. In her 29 years at Knopf, Ms. Garrett, an Episcopal priest who works out of her home in Leeds, Mass., has edited six Pulitzer winners in the history category.

title: BASKETBALL;Camby Tells Newspaper He Got Gifts
description: Marcus Camby, college basketball's player of the year, told The Hartford Courant that he accepted money and gifts from agents before and during his junior season at the University of Massachusetts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACME-CLEVELAND ACCEPTS TAKEOVER BID FROM DANAHER
description: After rejecting earlier overtures, the Acme-Cleveland Corporation said yesterday that it had accepted a takeover bid from the Danaher Corporation, based in Washington, after the maker of tools and environmental control products raised its cash offer to $30 a share, or $200 million. Acme-Cleveland, which makes communication, motion control, and measurement products and systems, signed the agreement after Danaher increased its bid from $27 a share in March. Acme-Cleveland's stock rose 62.5 cents to $29.75, and Danaher, which is based in Washington, fell 50 cents to $41.

title: POLITICS: BALANCED BUDGET;Dole Plans a Swan Song: A 2d Vote on Amendment
description: Setting the course for his final days in the Senate, Bob Dole announced today that he would bring up the proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget for what he expects to be another losing vote.

title: Money Mustn't Dictate New York Coliseum Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: Constitutionality Is Conceded In Habeas Corpus Arguments
description: Lawyers arguing over an important challenge to a new law limiting appeals by death-row inmates and other convicts agreed in principle before the Supreme Court today that the legislation did not violate the Constitution.

title: After Israeli Election, Is Peace Just a Dream?;Fundamentalism Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;No Parole in Child Killings
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill yesterday that would require a life sentence with no parole for anyone convicted of murdering a child under the age of 14 during a sexual assault.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Plan Is Protested
description: Dozens of parents who worry that their suburban school districts will be forced to cut programs descended on the State House yesterday to deliver more than 10,000 letters protesting Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's school financing proposal.

title: TRACK & FIELD;Fredericks Displays Speed, While Johnson Shows Form
description: There were concerns in this northern suburb of Paris that Michael Johnson's sore right hamstring might keep him from crossing the Atlantic and headlining this grand prix meet.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MELVILLE SELLS ITS CHAIN OF THIS END UP FURNITURE STORES
description: The Melville Corporation, one of the nation's largest specialty retailers, said yesterday that it had sold its chain of This End Up furniture stores to an unidentified investor group. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Melville said it would take a one-time after-tax charge of about $148 million in the second quarter to cover the sale and other actions, which are part of a restructuring announced in October. This End Up, which originated the crate furniture style, sells its products through 172 stores and catalogues. Under the reorganization, Melville plans to create two publicly traded chains: the CVS Corporation and Footstar Inc. The plan also calls for cost-cutting and store closings. Melville's stock rose $1, to $41.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sony to Sell a Headset With a Video Screen
description: The company that gave the world the Walkman is taking personalized entertainment into a new dimension with its latest gadget: an individual movie screen mounted in a headset.

title: Upheaval in India
description: As India begins settling down after a political roller-coaster ride that produced two Governments in two weeks, many in this nation of 930 million people wonder whether they have entered a new era of recurring political upheavals.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES INC., Phoenix, named Richard Goodmanson executive vice president and chief operating officer and said he would eventually take over the posts of president and chief executive from William Franke, who will remain chairman of the airline. Mr. Franke will also serve as chairman and chief executive of America West Holdings Corp.

title: Government Will Offer Seal For Energy-Efficient Products
description: The Energy Department and the Environmental Protection Agency said today that they would offer manufacturers of appliances and building materials the right to use a Government seal of approval, the Energy Star, if their products meet Federal efficiency standards. The program is an effort to lower energy consumption, save money for consumers and cut pollution.

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar's Trip to Hollywood Is Threatened by Another Foot Injury
description: The same problem foot that sidelined the superhorse Cigar earlier this year has flared again. Cigar has "a little bruise or an abscess" in his right front foot, his owner, Allen Paulson, said yesterday. Although the injury does not appear to be serious, according to Paulson, any significant time lost could keep Cigar from his next scheduled start, the $1 million Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park on June 30.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALLERGAN PLANS TO CUT JOBS AND TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE
description: Allergan Inc. said yesterday that it was cutting 450 jobs from its staff of 6,000 to improve profit margins hurt by competition and acquisitions. The cuts will result in charges that will reduce pretax earnings by as much as $75 million, or 81 cents a share. Spun off from Smith Kline Inc. in 1989, Allergan made a series of acquisitions last year and expanded its operations in Asia and Latin America. But those moves added overhead while managed-care concerns have restrained sales growth. Allergan of Irvine, Calif., said the restructuring charges could be distributed in any or all of the second, third or fourth quarter. In 1995, Allergan profits were $72.7 million.

title: Reports Show More Strength In Economy
description: More signs of economic strength appeared today, as a major forecasting index showed its third straight gain and the Government reported a sizable, broad-based rise in new construction.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;WPP Says Revenues Rose 10% in 4 Months
description: The British advertising company WPP P.L.C. said yesterday that its revenues in the first four months of 1996 were up 10 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier, with profit margins rising by more than 1 percentage point. WPP, the world's biggest advertising company, said in a brief trading update that its debt had dropped by 21 percent in the corresponding period to L166 million from L211 million a year before. (Dow Jones)

title: 5 Charged in Series Of Bank Robberies
description: Five men, all from the Charlestown section of Boston, have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges of engaging in 11 bank and armored-truck robberies across New England, including one in which two guards were killed.

title: Yeltsin Holds Talks on Strife in the Caucasus
description: In an elaborate effort to reassure Russian voters that the upheaval in the Caucasus has begun to subside, President Boris N. Yeltsin held an unusual summit meeting today with top leaders from the troubled region.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Scott Flood was named president and chief operating officer of Waring & LaRosa, New York, a new unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. As president, Mr. Flood succeeds Saul Waring, co-chief executive, who was named co-chairman, joining Joe LaRosa, who is also the other co-chief executive. The position of chief operating officer is new. Mr. Flood was most recently executive vice president and general manager of Altschiller & Co., New York. William Gray, a senior partner, executive group director on the American Express account, and head of client services at Ogilvy & Mather New York, was promoted to the new position of managing director. Mr. Gray will become an adviser on the American Express account, while John Seifert, a senior partner and worldwide client service director who is responsible for the international portion of the American Express account, will assume the day-to-day responsibilities for the account as executive group director.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADAPTEC AGREES TO ACQUIRE COGENT DATA TECHNOLOGIES
description: Adaptec Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Cogent Data Technologies Inc., a maker of computer networking equipment, for $68 million in stock. The acquisition would increase Adaptec's expertise in a technology called fast ethernet, which speeds up the transmission of computer information through small computer networks in corporate departments. Adaptec, based in Milpitas, Calif., makes electronic components for personal computer manufacturers. Adaptec's shares fell $1.875, to $58, in Nasdaq trading.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Henkel of Germany Says Pretax Profit Rose
description: Henkel, a German maker of detergents, said yesterday that its four-month pretax profit rose 4 percent, as sales rose at an even faster pace. Pretax profit in the four months to the end of April was 254 million marks ($166.8 million). Sales were up 12 percent, to 5.275 billion marks.

title: Bell Atlantic Agrees to Open Network
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, hoping to demonstrate that it can play according to the new open-competition telecommunications rules, announced an agreement yesterday to let the cable television company Jones Intercable Inc. connect to its telephone network in Virginia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Buys Distributor
description: City and Suburban Delivery Systems Inc., a subsidiary of The New York Times Company, said yesterday that it had bought Imperial Delivery Service Inc., a newspaper wholesaler that distributes newspapers and other periodicals throughout Long Island and Westchester and Fairfield counties. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. City and Suburban is the major distributor of The Times in metropolitan New York. John R. O'Reilly, City and Suburban's president, said in a statement that the acquisition would allow the company to expand its newspaper delivery, sales and merchandising coverage to roughly 85 percent of the greater New York market.

title: Hebron Arabs Fight Troops
description: Stone-throwing Arabs clashed with Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank town of Hebron today.

title: Violence Puts Women on the Welfare Track
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;McCann to Acquire Torre Renta Lazur
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide said in New York yesterday that it had expanded its health care advertising operations by agreeing in principle to acquire the Torre Renta Lazur Healthcare Group in Parsippany, N.J. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Divers Recover Large Jet Sections and Remains
description: Divers recovering wreckage from Valujet Airlines Flight 592 today found sections of aircraft as big as five or six feet, along with human remains and belongings like wallets and photo albums.

title: More Recent Migration of Humans From Africa Is Seen in DNA Study
description: WHEN molecular biologists tackle the problem of how modern humans evolved, they do not go on fossil-hunting expeditions as paleoanthropologists do. Instead, they look inward, into human DNA.

title: Pilar Lorengar Is Dead at 68; A Spanish Soprano in Berlin
description: Pilar Lorengar, a Spanish soprano who was best known for her portrayals of Mozart heroines but whose repertory ranged from zarzuela to Puccini, Verdi and Wagner, died on Sunday at the Park Sanitarium in Berlin. She was 68 and lived in Berlin, where she was a star of the Deutsche Oper for more than 30 years.

title: GTE Gets Contract From the Big Board
description: The GTE Corporation said today that it had a contract to provide a wireless-data system and communications services on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOBIL TO REORGANIZE 3 DIVISIONS INTO 11 GROUPS
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that it was reorganizing its 3 worldwide divisions -- exploration and producing; marketing and refining, and chemical -- into 11 business groups. The new regional business groups will each report to an executive office headed by Lucio A. Noto, Mobil's chairman and chief executive. In North America, exploration and development will be split into two groups. Four regional business groups -- Africa and the Middle East; Asia and the Pacific; Europe and the Commonwealth of Independent States, and South America -- will combine exploration and production with refining and marketing, the company said. Four global business groups will cover chemicals; liquefied natural gas and independent power projects; new exploration and production, and supply, trading and transportation. One business group will focus on technology.

title: Glad Rags to Riches In the Resale Market
description: The sale of a Charles James couture evening dress at a William Doyle Galleries auction on April 24 for $49,450 was unprecedented for a designer from the second half of the 20th century. But as surprising to those who don't regularly wield a paddle was the Hermes bags, Chanel jewels and Judith Leiber clutches from the last decade that went for close to their original prices.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On the "Guiding Light," FRANK DICOPOULOS plays Frank Cooper, a heroic rookie policemen who goes out of his way to help people in states of distress.

title: POLITICS: WHITEWATER;Prosecutor Says Witness Can Be Given Immunity
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the special prosecutor for Whitewater matters, today helped clear the way for one of President Clinton's chief accusers to testify, possibly next week, before a televised session of the Senate Whitewater committee.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Canada is coaxing Americans to go north and help reduce or eliminate its travel  imbalance.
description: OR years the number of Canadian tourists visiting the United States has far exceeded the number of Americans who visit Canada.

title: No Headline
description: Arguably this is the most remarkable insect in the world,"

title: BASEBALL;Mets Waste Isringhausen's Strong Outing
description: The Mets were pounding the National League's hottest pitcher, John Smoltz, and Jason Isringhausen was in such a groove that his five-game losing streak was all but forgotten. Here were the last-place Mets beating the defending World Series champions in their home park.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CABLETRON SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY ZEITNET IN STOCK SWAP
description: Cabletron Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Zeitnet Inc. for about $137 million in stock to expand the computer networking company's line of switching products. Zeitnet has 120 employees and specializes in connecting groups of workers and the computer servers they use to the high performance asynchronous transfer mode, or A.T.M., networks. Cabletron, based in Rochester, plans to exchange 1.92 million of its shares for all of the closely held Zeitnet, based in Santa Clara, Calif. Cabletron's stock fell $3 yesterday to $69.75; the company has annual revenues of $1.1 billion and about 6,000 employees.

title: The Medicare Argument
description: President Clinton won the political war over the budget by accusing the Republicans of viciously cutting Medicare. Newt Gingrich fired back last weekend, accusing the Clinton Administration of falsehoods. The G.O.P. budget, he said, would raise Medicare spending by about 7 percent a year per retiree.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Union Pacific's Plan to Merge Hits Resistance At 3 Agencies
description: The Justice, Transportation and Agriculture Departments said yesterday that they were against a proposed $3.9 billion merger of the Union Pacific Corporation and the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation.

title: Cicadas: They're Back!
description: It was a most unusual coming-out party. The host wore a tan plastic raincoat, not a dinner jacket. There was no bubbly music by the likes of the band leader Lester Lanin. And the swarms of gawky 17-year-olds? They were fashionably late.

title: Stocks Are Modestly Lower on More Interest-Rate Fears
description: Stocks fell for a second session yesterday amid concern in some quarters that rising interest rates could limit corporate profit. Leading the decline were interest-sensitive utility and bank shares.

title: Broadway's Tony Winners for 1996
description: Following are the winners of the 1996 Tony Awards, presented on Sunday night at the Majestic Theater in Manhattan by the American Theater Wing and the League of American Theaters and Producers:

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Being 2d to Pataki
description: As the battle between Gov. George E. Pataki and Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross broke into widespread public view, Ms. McCaughey Ross accused the Pataki administration yesterday of waging an anonymous campaign to discredit her through "petty political persecution."

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PARAGON GROUP INC., Dallas, a real estate investment trust, agreed to sell its commercial property service unit, Paragon Commercial, to Insignia Financial Group Inc., Greenville, S.C., for about $18.5 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Two Sued in Charity Fraud
description: Sometimes the solicitors claimed to be raising money for a group called Missing Children, U.S.A. At other times, the recipient was supposedly a firefighters' group, or the Atlantic City Jaycees, or a camp for handicapped children.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dutch Company to Buy Univar for $303 Million
description: The Dutch transport and tank storage company Pakhoed N.V. said yesterday that it would acquire the Univar Corporation for about $303 million. Pakhoed, which already owns 28 percent of Univar, is offering $19.45 a share for the 15.6 million remaining shares in the company, which is based in Kirkland, Wash.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Upholds Credit-Card Late Fees In a major victory for banks with interstate credit-card operations, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a bank could charge any late-payment fee permitted by its home state, regardless of the state law where a cardholder lives. The court upheld a ruling by California's highest court concerning Citibank.

title: Syria's Leader, at Cairo Meeting, Sees No Hope of New Israel Talks
description: In his first public comment since Israeli voters elected a new Prime Minister, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria said today that he had no hope that peace talks between Israel and Syria would resume soon and that he believed that "things are not going ahead in a positive direction."

title: PRIVATE HOSPITALS IN NEW YORK SIGNAL A DEEPENING CRISIS
description: At least a dozen of New York City's private hospitals are planning large-scale layoffs next month or are late in paying significant bills, concrete signals that the long-predicted financial crisis for the region's private hospitals has finally arrived.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Paul C. Sereno;Imp's Evolution To Fossil Finder
description: IT is 9 A.M. on a weekday, and Susan Lesher's fifth-grade class from the University of Chicago Laboratory School is agitatedly awaiting the entrance of the dinosaur hunter Dr. Paul C. Sereno. Minutes later, the door to the lecture room at the university swings open and Dr. Sereno -- in jeans, a West African charm necklace and one turquoise earring -- strides to the front, grinning broadly at his adulatory audience. Jaws fall open, revealing braces on teeth, and a few hands shoot up with burning questions, prompting a raised-eyebrow caution from Ms. Lesher.

title: Reports Find Class Size Up And School Supplies Scant
description: At Ralph McKee High School on Staten Island, the woodworking shop is running low on wood and the cosmetology department is short on shampoo and nail polish. At Wingate High School in Brooklyn, there is only one music teacher for 3,066 students. And at Truman High School in the Bronx, the ratio of students per teacher has risen by 6 in the last two years, to 27 this year from 21 in 1994.

title: Market Place;An unusual security helps people like Eli Broad cash out.
description: LI BROAD has become rich twice by anticipating the needs of the Baby Boomers and trying to meet them. Now he is moving to cash in a substantial part of his profits, on terms that could give him about $194 million tax free.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Akzo Nobel Moving Some Output to Poland
description: Akzo Nobel N.V., a Dutch chemical company, said yesterday that it planned to move part of its textile rayon production to Poland from Germany and the Netherlands. "We have chosen to relocate the most labor-intensive phase of the production process," said Huub Verbeeten, an Akzo Nobel spokesman.

title: HORSE RACING;Large Field Aims to Go Distance At Belmont
description: No one can sweep thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown this year. In an era when $1 million races are commonplace, the purse of $500,000-added seems almost quaint. The distance, a mile and a half, has become an anachronism in American racing.

title: Ally of Yeltsin And Reformer Out as Mayor
description: The Mayor of St. Petersburg, a liberal who was an early, close ally of Boris N. Yeltsin and remains a symbol of Russia's reform movement, narrowly lost his bid for re-election on Sunday to his former deputy.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Picking a PC for the College Trunk
description: CONGRATULATIONS to all the high school graduates, and good luck to all the parents, grandparents and other benefactors who are now thrust into the role of shopping for a computer for college-bound scholars.

title: Henry Schwarzschild, 70, Opponent of Death Penalty
description: Henry Schwarzschild, a refugee from Hitler's Germany who became a prominent American spokesman for civil rights and against the death penalty, died on Saturday at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, where he lived. He was 70.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Curb on Phone Ads Advances
description: It's a familiar experience: You rush to pick up the telephone, only to find yourself listening to a prerecorded sales pitch. It is already illegal under Federal law to place such calls from one state to another. Yesterday, the Assembly Transportation and Communications Committee passed a bill to ban the calls within New Jersey as well. The measure now goes to the full Assembly.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Two Veteran Linemen Retire
description: Two 33-year-old offensive linemen, RON HELLER of Miami and TOM NEWBERRY of Pittsburgh, both announced their retirements yesterday. Heller played in 171 career games in 12 seasons with Miami, Tampa Bay and Philadelphia. Newberry started 18 games for the Steelers, including the Super Bowl. He played his first nine seasons with the Los Angeles Rams. (AP)

title: Do Less in Albany
description: June is a dangerous month in Albany, when the New York State Legislature begins a mad dash to end its session. Most of the bills that become law get passed during this frantic race toward adjournment, under circumstances that are least conducive to quality legislation.

title: Herman Starobin, 75, Ex-Aide Of Garment Workers' Union
description: Herman Starobin, a former research director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a critic of free-trade policies, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Finish Lower In Wake of Economic Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities traded in a narrow range yesterday before finishing moderately lower, as mixed readings of three separate economic reports kept investors off balance.

title: U.S. Seeking to Strengthen Nuclear Agency
description: After the Persian Gulf war, when international inspectors got a better opportunity to look around a defeated Iraq, they discovered that President Saddam Hussein had secretly been developing nuclear weapons.

title: INSIDE
description: Ranch Electricity Is Cut

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Banco Bilboa to Buy 40% of Colombian Bank
