description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya S.A. of Spain said yesterday that it would acquire a 40 percent stake in Banco Ganadero S.A., of Bogota, Colombia, for about $300 million. Banco Bilbao, based in Bilbao, Spain, will participate in the management of Banco Ganadero, and both companies will have equal representation on Ganadero's board.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Repeating a Season as Season-Ending Ballyhoo
description: Like NBC's "Seinfeld," HBO's "Larry Sanders Show" is a television original, an uncompromising ode to inspired lunacy. While "Seinfeld" brags that it is about nothing, "Larry Sanders" is wickedly content to be about less than nothing, namely, the big names wading ingloriously in the small pond of late-night talk shows. Trapped helplessly in the eternally wary and smilingly sour disposition of Garry Shandling, Larry is, both on and off his talk show, the self-obsessed center around which the neuroses of his staff and guest stars are allowed to blossom hilariously.

title: Witness to Beating in the Hamptons Has Felony Record
description: As Suffolk County authorities continued yesterday to prepare their case against the New York City police officer charged in the clubbing of a young man in eastern Long Island last week, a man who was with the officer on that night of violence has emerged as a significant witness.

title: Sports of the Times;Jordan's Wink Means Business
description: WITH 2.5 seconds left in the third playoff game against the Knicks a few weeks ago, and the score tied, the Bulls were taking the ball out of bounds under their basket. The tension could have been cut with a meat cleaver. Michael Jordan, however, standing at the 3-point line, winked at someone seated in the first row behind the basket. That someone was Trent Tucker, a former teammate of Jordan with the Bulls.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Atlanta 1996: 45 DAYS TO GO;Baumgartner's Solitary Life Brings Singular Achievement
description: He grows asparagus in the garden, bakes his own Christmas cookies, dabbles expertly in woodwork and collects stamps. Bruce Baumgartner owns every regular and commemorative stamp issued in the United States since 1959. He also owns two of the three Olympic gold medals issued to superheavyweight wrestlers since 1984.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Opening a Debut Recital With a 20th-Century Gamble Willsonia Boyer, soprano

title: COMPANY NEWS;BJ SERVICES INCREASES BID FOR NOWSCO WELL SERVICE
description: The BJ Services Company of Houston increased its bid yesterday for Nowsco Well Service Ltd. by 23 percent, to about $731.5 million (Canadian), or $534 million (United States). BJ Services and the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation, based in Lafayette, Ind., are both bidding for Nowsco, an oil services company in Calgary, Alberta. BJ Services' new bid, which is $35 (Canadian) a share, comes after Nowsco last month rejected a previous bid of $27 a share and opted instead for Great Lakes' offer of $30.90. Houston-based BJ Services also said today that it had asked Nowsco for access to the same confidential information provided to Great Lakes for more than two months. Nowsco shares rose $2, to close at $25.875 in Nasdaq trading.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Virginia Warner Undaunted By G.O.P. Rebuff

title: Chief of Prudential Mutual Fund Unit Resigns Unexpectedly
description: The chief executive of Prudential Mutual Fund Management Inc., the mutual fund arm of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has unexpectedly resigned, leading some fund industry analysts to question whether Prudential is readying itself to begin selling its funds directly to consumers in addition to offering them through its stock brokers and insurance agents.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;$3 Billion Later, Japan Financier Is Bankrupt
description: Shinkyoto Shinpan, a Japanese finance company, filed for bankruptcy today, under the weight of $3.24 billion in debts.

title: Agents Cut Electricity In Standoff In Montana
description: Federal agents today cut off electricity to the 960-acre ranch where 18 people have been holed up for 71 days, hoping to force leaders of the Freemen, a radical anti-government group, to resume negotiations for a peaceful surrender.

title: Observer;Easy As Pie
description: The Whitewater business is easy enough to understand: A bunch of people in Arkansas are charged with operating a small savings and loan as if it were their own property. The further suggestion is that President and Mrs. Clinton were in cahoots with this crowd when they invested in a real-estate development named "Whitewater."

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Festival Turns 50, With History and Smiles
description: This is not the best place to listen or to play, but music history keeps passing through this blessed valley. Stravinsky regularly made the excursion north from his home in the Hollywood Hills. Copland came and conducted. Pierre Boulez's visits began nearly 30 years ago, and he has been back with the Los Angeles Philharmonic for the last three days and nights celebrating the 50th season of the Ojai Festival.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Was Eliot Anti-Semitic? An Author Says He Was
description: T. S. ELIOT, ANTI-SEMITISM AND LITERARY FORM By Anthony Julius 308 pages. Cambridge University Press. $49.95.

title: Split Journal;A Tabloid Buzzes Like a Gadfly, Stings Like a Bee
description: The way Victor Ivancic, editor in chief of the Feral Tribune, sees it, his biggest problem is not the latest of 26 civil libel suits against him, this one for more than half a million dollars, or the charges that he defamed the President, which could land him in jail, or even losing almost all his advertisers, because, he says, the Government scared them away.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SIZZLER PLANS TO SEEK BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Sizzler International Inc. said yesterday that it was closing more than 130 of its company-operated Sizzler restaurants and filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Sizzler also said it would close 6 Buffalo Ranch Steakhouse restaurants in the United States. The company said it would take a charge of $108.9 million, or $3.92 a share, for costs associated with the closings and related reorganization, which would result in an unspecified loss for the year that ended on April 29. Sizzler, which had 451 Sizzler restaurants worldwide, said it would still have 85 restaurants in the United States. The company said it would concentrate on its American Grill restaurants.

title: New Test for Progression to AIDS
description: THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a new test to help determine how fast an individual's infection with H.I.V. is progressing to full-fledged AIDS.

title: On My Mind;The Warp From Israel
description: Before the Israeli election, the U.S. and European public kept receiving a warped picture of Israeli political reality. After the election, they still receive it. And chances are that they will keep getting it, on and on.

title: After Israeli Election, Is Peace Just a Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: Father and Son Are Arrested In Sale Tied to Japanese Sect
description: A father and son who sell military surplus and camping gear on Long Island were arrested yesterday on charges of illegally exporting gas masks, chemical protective suits and other products, some of it linked to the Japanese religious sect involved in the Tokyo nerve gas attack.

title: LATE FEES UPHELD FOR CREDIT CARDS
description: In a major victory for banks with interstate credit card operations, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that national banks could charge any late-payment fee permitted by their home state, regardless of whether the fee violates the law of the state where a card holder lives.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Padres' Joyner Out Six Weeks
description: The first-place San Diego Padres were dealt their first big setback yesterday when they learned that the smooth-fielding first baseman WALLY JOYNER will be out for at least six weeks with a fractured left thumb.

title: TRACK & FIELD;Translating U.S. Tradition Isn't Easy, Even for an Icon
description: For almost a quarter of a century, Lee Evans has been trying to teach African runners to approach the excellence and intensity that in the 1968 Mexico City Olympics led him to two gold medals and a world record that lasted 20 years.

title: Kinder, Gentler Push for Metric Inches Along
description: TO some it has seemed as insidious as the supposed dangers of creeping communism or water fluoridation. To others it is the future cornerstone of America's competitive edge as an industrial power. It's the metric system, and even after more than a century of debate, Americans cannot make up their minds what to do about it.

title: BASEBALL;Belle Straddles Line Of Intimidation Tactics
description: With an unintended touch of irony, the commissioner's office (the one without a commissioner to fill it) released yesterday the first results of the fan voting for next month's All-Star Game, showing Ken Griffey Jr. well ahead of all American League players. Seattle's Griffey gets the votes; Cleveland's Albert Belle gets suspended.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Astros Release Swindell
description: Three disappointing seasons after signing pitcher GREG SWINDELL to a $17 million contract as a free agent, the Houston Astros cut their losses yesterday by releasing the left-hander.

title: F.T.C. Issues Guidelines for Mergers
description: The Federal Trade Commission proposed yesterday that antitrust regulators considering a merger give greater weight to cost savings and other efficiencies gained both by companies and consumers.

title: Patterns
description: A New Anne Klein Star

title: Chess
description: There is no official world champion for "quickplay" chess, which is contested at the rate of 25 minutes per player per game, no matter how many moves it goes. But if there were one, it would be the Russian grandmaster Vladimir Kramnik, who will be 21 years old on June 25.

title: Q&A
description: The Dry Line

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Breaking The Swiss Banking Silence
description: Success in Swiss affairs often seems to hinge on organized vagueness and abstraction, so much so that a public figure who will have nothing to do with either can appear to be an enemy of the system.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the effects of the opening of a 20-mile stretch of Interstate 287 in New Jersey misstated the given name and title of an official from the Tri-State Transportation Campaign. He is Jonathan Orcutt, not John, and he is the group's associate director, not executive director.

title: Airport Officials Are Pleased With Debut of the Monorail
description: The first weekend of operation for the monorail at Newark International Airport went smoothly, and airport managers say they are addressing travelers' concerns about safety and the new rail's service to distant parking lots.

title: Russia's Election: Expect the Extremes
description: Is Boris Yeltsin a democrat or an autocrat? Do Russia's Communists intend to re-Stalinize the country, or have they learned their lesson?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Blues Sign Casey
description: Goalie JON CASEY, who emerged from backup status and helped the St. Louis Blues nearly upset the Detroit Red Wings in the second round of the playoffs, signed a multiyear deal with the team yesterday. (AP)

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Romantic Lark and Modern Thunder
description: The old and the new came together in sometimes startling apposition on Friday night when the New York City Ballet presented dances by George Balanchine and Peter Martins.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CLEAR CHANNEL TO BUY BIGGEST SPANISH RADIO COMPANY
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the nation's largest Spanish-language radio company, the Heftel Broadcasting Corporation, for about $218 million in cash and $118 million in assumed debt. Clear Channel of San Antonio agreed to pay $23 a share for the 79 percent of Heftel, based in Las Vegas, Nev., that it does not already own. The purchase includes a 40 percent stake held by Heftel management. The acquisition is Clear Channel's third in the last month. Heftel has 17 stations in markets that include New York, Los Angeles, Miami and Chicago. Clear Channel's shares fell $1, to $80.25, on the New York Stock Exchange while Heftel slipped 25 cents, to $22.25, in trading on the Nasdaq.

title: Factories That Never Close Are Scrapping 5-Day Week
description: Tony Moreno is an outgoing, churchgoing man and the father of three.

title: Lieutenant Governors, Take a Back Seat
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak felt so ostracized by Gov. Hugh L. Carey that she wound up challenging him in a primary at the end of her first term. Alfred B. DelBello abruptly resigned from the same job after grumbling about not having enough to do under his boss, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. And his replacement, Stan Lundine, had his share of thankless work, including a time when he was spit at and pelted with stones while lobbying on behalf of the Governor.

title: Fed Looks Into Cash Discrepancies at Branch
description: The Los Angeles Federal Reserve bank branch appears to have had trouble counting its money, and a report published today said that cash reports sent to Washington had been doctored to conceal discrepancies totaling tens of millions of dollars.

title: Posturing on Abortion
description: The indignant voices of the pro-life movement and the Republican Party will likely reach new decibels in the campaign to urge Congress to override President Clinton's veto of the bill banning so-called partial-birth abortions. But Congress should sustain the veto. The bill does not provide an exception for women whose health is at risk, and it would be virtually unenforceable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Don Grolnick, 48, Songwriter And Backup Pianist to Pop Stars
description: Don Grolnick, a pianist, songwriter and producer best known for his work with songwriters, including Bonnie Raitt, Paul Simon and James Taylor, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 48 and lived in New York City.

title: Council Says Mayor's Budget Is $350 Million Too Gloomy
description: Signaling that talks over New York City's next budget have begun in earnest, the City Council's leaders said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had underestimated next year's tax revenues by more than $350 million, a pot of cash they hope can be used to scale back some of the Mayor's budget cuts.

title: Micron Accuses Korean Rivals
description: Micron Technology Inc. has accused two South Korean rivals of selling computer chips in the United States below cost, an illegal practice known as dumping.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Ragtime Life on CD-ROM
description: DR. ROBERT WINTER, a professor of music at the University of California at Los Angeles, has been a pioneer in the field of music-oriented multimedia software on CD-ROM. His programs about Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring," among others, were among the first to hint at the ways multimedia presentations might work in music education. But they seemed limited by the hardware and software of the era.

title: By Design;Carefree Hair for Summer
description: Whether her hair is long or short, any woman who is active in the summer wants a cool and relatively carefree hairdo. Here are ideas from three of New York's top hair professionals.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Of Reggae And Rock From Wales
description: There may not be a Welsh pop invasion anytime soon, but prepare for a small offensive this summer. Outside of Tom Jones, Shirley Bassey, John Cale of the Velvet Underground and the Young Marble Giants, Wales has not been known for producing high-caliber pop. But it should come as no surprise that there's a thriving music scene in Wales since it has produced so many great voices in classical music (Bryn Terfel, Margaret Price, Robert Tear). Wales's pop voices range from mostly southern groups making loud guitar rock as if they were in the next Seattle (Gouge, Novocaine, 60 Ft. Dolls, Flyscreen, Dub War) to innovative, mostly northern pop-makers who mix Welsh and English (terrific bands like Gorky's Zygotic Mynci, Datblygu, Super Furry Animals and Ectogram, all well-documented on last year's "Triskedekaphilia" compilation on Ankst records).

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1969, DANIEL CALLAHAN and WILLARD GAYLIN, his neighbor in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., established the Hastings Center, a research institution devoted to the study of ethical issues raised by advances in medicine and biology.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League

title: POLITICS;In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Are Off Sharply As Weather Enables Planting
description: Corn prices dropped sharply yesterday as dry weather enabled farmers to continue sowing crops in regions where rain had delayed planting.

title: China Confronts Retardation Of Millions Deficient in Iodine
description: Like a thousand other villages in the rural archipelago of China, this collection of black-tiled roofs and dusty courtyards looks from a distance like just another smudge on the sea of wheat fields blanketing the central China plain.

title: Peres Backers and Peace Activists Left in Gloom
description: A cloud of gloom has settled over Israel's peace advocates, Labor Party professionals and other supporters of Prime Minister Shimon Peres after his unexpected defeat at the hands of Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Protect Bosnia's Election
description: It is abundantly clear that there will not be ideal conditions for free and fair national elections in Bosnia come September. It is equally apparent that the United States and other countries with troops in Bosnia have no desire to postpone that election date. Delay would mean that NATO would have to end its military mission without elections or postpone its withdrawal until next year or later.

title: Study Rethinks Relationship Between Welfare and Work
description: As state and Federal lawmakers seek to overhaul welfare and move more people into jobs, a respected child advocacy organization reported today that the number of children living in poverty while their parents work has sharply increased over the last generation.

title: N.B.A. FINALS: NOTEBOOK;Jackson Can't Picture The Nets in His Future
description: Phil Jackson's prolonged contract talks with the Chicago Bulls have not deteriorated to the point where he is job-hunting. But if he were, East Rutherford, N.J., would not be the first address he would mail his resume.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Busy Sonics Count Ways To Stop Jordan
description: Now for the bad news.

title: For Red-Tape Mess, Blame Businesscrats
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;American League Suspends Belle For Five Games
description: For the third time in less than 100 days, Albert Belle, the Cleveland Indians' angry young man, has been disciplined by a Major League Baseball official. But unlike the other two actions, which resulted in a $50,000 fine and orders to undergo counseling, this time Belle was suspended for five games.

title: After Israeli Election, Is Peace Just a Dream?;Security Is Paramount
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unigate of Britain Sells U.S. Restaurant Chain
description: Unigate P.L.C., a British food manufacturer and distributor, sold its Black-Eyed Pea restaurant chain yesterday to the DenAmerica Corporation for $65 million, moving a step closer to disposing of its United States restaurant assets. Unigate said it would take a charge of L59.5 million ($89.8 million) to write off good will and other costs.

title: Who Can Start a Children's Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Cast Votes
description: Today is primary day in New Jersey. In addition to primaries for the United States Senate seat and all 13 House seats, there will be races for many local offices. Polls are open from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. at the standard polling places throughout the state.

title: Crowded Van Collides With Cars on Wet Queens Highway, Killing 2
description: A crowded van that might have been speeding went out of control on a busy, rain-soaked stretch of a Queens highway yesterday afternoon, hurtled across a low concrete divider and struck oncoming cars with terrible force, killing two men and injuring about 20 people, the authorities said.

title: Sales Climbed 17% in May For Chrysler
description: Chrysler and General Motors reported unexpectedly strong sales for May.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;No Cachet In Panthers Versus Avalanche
description: Nobody is suggesting the Colorado Avalanche and the Florida Panthers did not earn their berths in the Stanley Cup finals. Any team that beats three other teams over six weeks deserves to be in the championship round. That's the law.

title: HORSE RACING;A Fading Race Track Finds Slot Machines And Hits the Jackpot
description: Like most race tracks built more than 50 years ago, Delaware Park has a grandstand that dwarfs the several hundred fans who gather on a weekday card to watch the horses. As the runners near the wire, the cheering is less a roar than several individual pleas. In the section closest to the finish line, only a handful of the 384 seats are occupied.

title: North Fails To Make Open
description: Bad weather suspended play yesterday at both United States Open qualifying sites in Ohio, and two of golf's more notable names, Lanny Wadkins and Craig Stadler, withdrew from the field at Columbus, while two-time Open champion Andy North failed to qualify at Chicago.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Camden Zone Is Approved
description: After more than a year of negotiations, the state agreed yesterday to allow Camden to set up an Empowerment Zone, a move that will eventually bring the economically depressed city $21 million in Federal money. To win the state's support, Camden had to agree to set up a nonprofit organization to run the program and establish specific goals and schedules for what the city expected to accomplish, said Robert W. Friant, a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs.

title: Plane Bombing Is Described in Terror Trial
description: Prosecutors focused yesterday on a deadly midair explosion that Ramzi Ahmed Yousef is accused of carrying out as a rehearsal for a planned wave of attacks on a dozen American jetliners, a continuation of a terror campaign that the indictment says began with the World Trade Center bombing.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices Decide, 9 to 0, That the Death Penalty in the Armed Services Is Constitutional
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of the death penalty in the military. The 9-to-0 decision removed doubts about the validity of an executive order that President Ronald Reagan issued in 1984 to bring the death-penalty provisions of the Uniform Code of Military Justice into line with the Supreme Court's current approach to capital punishment.

title: BASEBALL;Glavine Counsels Patience
description: Tom Glavine looks at the Mets' young pitching staff and can't help but think of his Atlanta staff during its infancy. While the Braves' rotation is regarded as the best in baseball, success wasn't achieved without early rocky outings that were similar to what the Mets' youngsters have experienced this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article last week about a melee outside a Westhampton Beach, L.I., nightclub misspelled the surname of a figure in the case in some editions, and a correction in this space yesterday misstated the date of the original reference, also in some editions. The man is Austin Offen, not Offner; the erroneous reference appeared on Saturday, not Sunday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New York Places Campaign in Review
description: The New York State Department of Economic Development said yesterday that it had placed in review its travel and tourism account, known as the "I [Love] New York" campaign. The account has been handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York since January 1995. Though the 1997 spending has been estimated at $11.5 million, the department said it would entertain proposals to parcel projects out to various agencies.

title: Burning Cross Is Found on a Lawn on L.I.
description: A Haitian family that moved to Long Island 25 years ago found a cross on fire on the lawn of their house in South Setauket late Sunday night, the police said today.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were higher this morning. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 135.4 points, or more than six tenths of a percent, to 21,723.98. On Monday, the Nikkei lost 367.67 points, or 1.67 percent, hurt by an upturn in the yen and concerns over interest rates in the United States.

title: NYC;If Term Limits Are So Good, Who's First?
description: EFFORTS are afoot to counter a form of Marxism that haunts New York: the ideology of term limits, imposed on local politicians by referendum three years ago. We're talking about Groucho Marx, who didn't want to belong to any club that would have someone like him as a member.

title: TV SPORTS;The N.H.L. Wins One By Avoiding Face-Off
description: The Stanley Cup and National Basketball Association finals will do-si-do across our television sets over the next two weeks, never competing on any single day against each other. The cup series starts tonight, the N.B.A. tomorrow.

title: Albany Faces A Shortfall: Legislation
description: As it begins the last month of an unusually fractious session, the New York Legislature has not only failed to adopt a budget on time for a 12th straight year. Lawmakers have also been unable to agree on many other major proposals, suggesting that this could turn out to be one of their least productive gatherings in recent memory.

title: Kodak Introduces Low-Priced Digital Camera
description: Continuing an industry effort to create a mass market for digital cameras, the Eastman Kodak Company introduced a product yesterday that the company expects to sell for less than $350.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;POP
description: Hunting the Relationship Between Salsa and the Beatles 'Tropical Tribute to the Beatles' Radio City Music Hall

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Scott Reed, the manager of Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, misattributed a quotation in some editions. It was John Buckley, the campaign's communications director, not Mr. Reed, who said, "The stars have not fully moved into alignment for us."

title: 2 Officers Held in Fraud
description: Two New York City police officers were arrested yesterday and charged with using illegal so-called cloned telephones to make thousands of dollars in calls, the police said.

title: BASEBALL;Torre Presses the Right Buttons
description: Joe Torre makes his stressful job sound so simple. No mysteries, no complaints and no ulterior motives. Just manage. Just find nine Yankees who can win that day.

title: For Some Women, Losing Pounds Could Add Up to a Hip Fracture
description: IT is taken as an article of faith that a leaner body is a healthier body. But for some people, losing weight appears to be a health hazard.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GEORGE BUSH and DANA CARVEY are not finished with each other yet. On Sunday, the former President turned the tables on the comedian. He did his impression of Mr. Carvey imitating George Bush at the Williams College commencement in Williamstown, Mass., The Associated Press reported.

title: ICE SKATING
description: Broadening an Art Form With Choreographers 'Home Show 1996' Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers

title: NATO Plans New Component That Will Be Purely European
description: To make it easier for France to rejoin NATO and to deal with future European peacekeeping missions, the alliance's ministers approved a plan today that would assign European units to accomplish regional goals using American equipment and assets, including air transport and satellites.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ZILA PLANS TO BUY BIODENTAL TECHNOLOGIES IN STOCK DEAL
description: Zila Inc., based in Phoenix, plans to acquire the Biodental Technologies Corporation for as much as $45 million in stock, which would make Biodental, which sells dental products to dentists, the exclusive United States distributor of Zila's oral cancer test once regulators approve it, the companies said yesterday. Biodental shareholders would receive between 0.75 and 0.825 share of Zila common stock for each share of Biodental common stock. Based on Zila's closing price yesterday of $8.5625, up 31.25 cents, the purchase is valued at $41.1 million to $45.2 million. Shares of Biodental, based in Sacramento, Calif., rose $1.25 to $5.375 in Nasdaq trading.

title: BASEBALL;Fishing for Future Stars in the Draft
description: If it is true that the hardest feat to perform in sports is to hit a round ball squarely, then surely the second hardest feat is to figure out just which of the thousands of high school and college prospects may excel at enough of the baseball skills to play at the major league level.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Atlanta Out for Joyners
description: Injuries will prevent FLORENCE GRIFFITH JOYNER and her husband, AL, from realizing their dream of an Olympic comeback next month.

title: Fire Destroys a Black Church in Alabama
description: A rural black church was burned early today, but members said they were apprehensive about saying whether the fire could have been racially motivated.

title: After Israeli Election, Is Peace Just a Dream?;Likud in Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fallen Rubble Blocks Trains
description: Downtown traffic was tied up for several hours and Amtrak and New Jersey Transit train service was disrupted up to 30 minutes yesterday afternoon when a chunk of ornamental concrete fell onto Market Street from the trestle leading into Pennsylvania Station here, an Amtrak spokesman said. No one was injured, said the spokesman, Richard S. Remington. Inspectors determined that the trestle was structurally sound, he said.

title: Franco Harris Rushing Again, Toward Plant's Rescue
description: It was a blow to Park Heights, where the elegance of old Baltimore intersects with what Karen Evans calls "grime and crime," when the Parks Sausage Company, the city's largest black-owned business, locked the gates of its plant late last month.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Complex for Elderly Sought
description: When Senior Campus Living, a Baltimore developer, presented plans in December for a 2,000-unit retirement community on the site of the former American Cyanamid plant, the Township Council rejected the project as too big, Council President James Russo said yesterday.

title: New 42d St., Old Theater: You'll Find It Up the Block
description: To make way for a 25-screen movie complex, the latest addition to an updated Times Square, a developer plans to pick up a 42d Street burlesque house and move it 70 feet down the street.

title: Hong Kong Holds Vigil -- the Last? -- for Tiananmen Victims
description: In a vast sea of people sequined by thousands of candles, the Chen family held lighted tapers tonight and sang, the chorus of voices swelling around them, spilling over Hong Kong's Victoria Park:

title: N.B.A. FINALS;For Sonics, Uphill Battle With Bulls
description: Save the talk about matchups and strategy for a moment. The National Basketball Association championship series boils down to one question: What realistic chance do the Seattle SuperSonics have against the Chicago Bulls, who put together a 72-10 regular season followed by an 11-1 run in the playoffs?

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHROP GRUMMAN SELLS SHARES TO REDUCE DEBT
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said it had sold seven million common shares at $63.25 each, raising $422.75 million. The military contractor, based in Los Angeles, said the proceeds would be used to reduce debt incurred from its $3 billion acquisition of the military and electronics business of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which it completed March 1. The shares were offered simultaneously to United States and foreign investors. The company said it had set aside another 1.05 million shares for unexpected demand. Northrop shares rose $2.50 yesterday, to $65.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BASEBALL;Clemson and Florida Advance
description: Doug Livingston's two-run double in the top of the ninth drove in the go-ahead run against Alabama, and starter Billy Koch came on in relief to nail down Clemson's 14-13 victory today. The loss eliminated the top-seeded Crimson Tide (50-19) from the College World Series.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Being Drawn Into Spying When It Doesn't Work
description: THE WORLD AT NIGHT By Alan Furst 257 pages. Random House. $23.

title: Thief With Tractor Crushes the Law
description: A police officer escaped with minor injuries early Monday after a man drove a stolen 10-ton tractor over the officer's cruiser with him inside, the authorities said today.

title: Small Home Markets for Wind and Sun
description: Though it is in overseas markets that America's alternative energy companies are thriving, there is at least a small constituency for their products at home.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spain Cuts Interest Rate In Bid to Spur Economy
description: The Bank of Spain cut its key money market rate by a quarter percentage point yesterday to 7.25 percent, hoping to stimulate the economy after a recent downward revision of 1996 growth forecasts. The rate cut, the fifth this year, brings the key money market rate down from 9 percent in January.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Spoleto at 20: Still Volatile, Still in Menotti's Shadow
description: Arts organizations have usually settled and solidified by the time they reach their 20th year, but the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., which is celebrating that milestone at the moment and which runs through Sunday, seems still to be in the molten lava stage, with eruptions of one kind or another seemingly always imminent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXCEL ENTERS LONG-DISTANCE DEAL WITH WORLDCOM
description: Excel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay Worldcom Inc. $900 million over four years for long-distance telephone service, which it will resell to business and residential customers. Excel shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $35.25, on the New York Stock Exchange; Worldcom shares rose $1.875, to $51.375, in Nasdaq trading. Excel, based in Dallas, said it would buy about 1 billion minutes on Worldcom's long-distance phone network every three months. Worldcom is based in Jackson, Miss.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Colorado's Answers: Rat Traps and Roy
description: Resourceful if not inspired, the Colorado Avalanche's fans have come up with an answer to the Florida Panther's fans in these Stanley Cup finals. Call it a new version of the trap defense.

title: A Life-and-Death Proposal
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Sunflower Seeds Replace Ukraine's Old Missile Sites
description: Ukraine officially completed its nuclear disarmament today with a scattering of sunflower seeds by the top defense officials of the United States, Russia and Ukraine.

title: Rock Review;Fire Behind the British Cool
description: Jarvis Cocker, Pulp's lead singer, has perfected the English rock-star gaze. At Irving Plaza on Monday night, he faced the sold-out, squealing audience with a level stare, serious and unflappable, neither bored nor surprised.

title: U.S. Sues Chrysler After Auto Maker Refuses to Recall Cars
description: The Transportation Department ordered a recall today of most 1995 model Chrysler Cirrus and Dodge Stratus passenger cars, saying their rear seat belts were not strong enough.

title: GOLF;When He's in Doubt, Singh Swings a Club
description: When he finds himself alone in a hotel room after a long day at the golf course -- and where Vijay Singh is concerned there are no short days at the golf course -- he will often rearrange the furniture. He will move the easy chair over against the wall, the coffee table next to the bed, the desk chair into the bathroom.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sony Chairman Falls Ill And Overwork Is Blamed
description: The chairman of the Sony Corporation, Norio Ohga, was taken to a Tokyo hospital by ambulance yesterday after complaining of feeling ill, company officials said early today. Initial tests did not turn up anything unusual, and doctors said Mr. Ohga, who is 66, was likely suffering from overwork, a Sony spokesman said. He will remain in the hospital for two to three days, the company said.

title: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;Poll Indicates Stable Ratings For President
description: The standings of President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole remain relatively unchanged from polls of two months ago, despite events that could have roiled the Presidential race, including the convictions of Mr. Clinton's former business partners and Mr. Dole's resignation from the Senate, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Blood Bank Is Held Liable in AIDS Case
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court ruled today that the organization that oversees the safety of the nation's blood supply was negligent in the early 1980's for rejecting tougher screening tests for AIDS contamination in donated blood.

title: Thomas Smith, 68, Ex-Jersey City Mayor, Dies
description: Thomas F. X. Smith, a former Mayor of Jersey City who helped revive the city's downtown area but lost in the Democratic primary when he made a bid for Governor in 1981, died on Friday at his home in Jersey City. He was 68.

title: TV Notes;CBS to Make It Official
description: After a curious delay, CBS will announce officially today that Jon Stewart, the young comedian who previously was the host of talk shows on MTV and in syndication, has been signed by David Letterman's Worldwide Pants company to a deal that promises him, among other possibilities, a chance to start a new 1:35 A.M. talk show on CBS.

title: Japanese Down Navy Plane In an Accident; Crew Is Safe
description: A Japanese naval destroyer has accidentally shot down an American bomber during joint military exercises in the central Pacific, forcing the two American crew members to bail out seconds before the bomber plunged into the ocean. Neither was reported to have been seriously injured.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korean Official Arrested in Scandal
description: Prosecutors investigating a bribery scandal arrested a top official of the South Korean Ministry of Finance and Economy yesterday, just two days after the arrest of the chief stock market watchdog, a prosecution official said.

title: Sports of the Times;Let Players Also Enjoy Gravy Train
description: MARCUS CAMBY was unconscious for 10 minutes after he fainted last January. The doctors cleared him of heart trouble, but the only theory they could come up with was that he had not been eating well. Lying in his hospital bed, Camby should have said, "Doc, on the pennies these people dole out, how can I eat right?"

title: TV Notes;11 Subway Adventures
description: Rosie Perez, a certifiable New Yorker, had the idea: Ask New Yorkers to tell their wildest subway stories, then film them. The result is an HBO anthology movie wrapping together 11 short films, produced by Ms. Perez, Jonathan Demme and Edward Saxon for HBO NYC Productions, the pay-cable network's six-month-old New York-based movie division.

title: Netanyahu, Past and Future
description: Benjamin Netanyahu has the potential to be most effective Israeli Prime Minister since David Ben-Gurion. I know this from having closely watched Mr. Netanyahu's brilliant work as Israel's permanent representative to the United Nations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WITCO CORP., Greenwich, Conn., acquired parts of Ferro Corp.'s plastic lubricants business and sold its oil additives division to Ferro.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Talk of Creditors' Deal Raises Eurotunnel Shares
description: Shares of the Eurotunnel Group, the debt-strapped operator of the Channel Tunnel, rose as much as 9 percent yesterday, extending Monday's surge, amid talk of an accord with creditors that would limit shareholder losses. "I don't think anyone is questioning that there will be an agreement," said Francois Marchal, head of institutional sales at SGE Delahaye in Paris.

title: TENNIS;Sampras Scrambles to Win, but Seles Exits
description: Pete Sampras survived the inquisition and the two-sets-to-none scare Jim Courier supplied, but his counterpart at the head of the women's draw, the three-time champion Monica Seles, did the unthinkable and lost because she played scared.

title: Personal Health
description: Perhaps there are a few things you inevitably procrastinate about. For me, it is sending condolence letters and sorting and filing those ever-growing piles of paper that, had I tackled them when the piles were short, would have been much less forbidding.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Investigates Citibank Role in Mexican Deals Through an elaborate series of transfers involving Citibank, Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of the then-President of Mexico, whisked more than $80 million out of Mexico in 1993 and into Switzerland.

title: TV Notes;The Tonys in a Slump
description: What kills a show on Broadway? Poor box office and harsh reviews. But the Tony Awards broadcast continues to run on CBS.

title: Wine Talk;Frank J. Prial
description: SOMEONE once described rose as the wine equivalent of Colonial-style furniture. It was what you bought when you weren't sure what to buy.

title: The Nuclear End Run
description: The threat of nuclear terrorism is about to take a leap forward because of a deal now being worked out by Russia, France and Germany in which Russia will supply highly enriched bomb-grade uranium for use in research reactors. This is the kind of fuel used in the Hiroshima bomb.

title: Law School Women Question the Teaching
description: Lauren Aste sat for a year in the third row of a classroom at New York University Law School, with her casebooks and outlines of the important points in each case. But Ms. Aste, 24, never raised her hand to speak in class. Like many women at the school, she said, she found the large classes and the confrontational atmosphere intimidating.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;In a Word: Charge!
description: SEASON SERIES (1-1)

title: Ford Reports Slim Sales Gain As Some Models Lose Ground
description: The Ford Motor Company's domestic vehicle sales rose just 1.3 percent in May, and sales of many models were lower, the company said today.

title: Princeton's Graduates Hear What a Yalie Has to Say
description: The graduates clapped and cheered, as graduates always do. The salutatorian gave a funny speech in Latin, as salutatorians always do. But for its 249th commencement today, Princeton University broke a graduation-day tradition as old as the college itself: the president who gave the speech under the maples in front of Nassau Hall was not the president of Princeton, but the President of the United States.

title: Ex-Official of Camden County Is Acquitted on Fraud Charges
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan acquitted a former official of Camden County, N.J., yesterday of charges that he was paid kickbacks in exchange for steering municipal bond business to a New Jersey bank.

title: Indiana Approves A Floating Casino
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. said yesterday that it had won approval from Indiana authorities to operate a floating casino on Lake Michigan.

title: INSIDE
description: Woman Is Badly Injured In Daylight Park Attack

title: Don't Discriminate on Mental Health Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks traded higher in Japan this morning, one day after the Tokyo market recovered from its sharp decline of the beginning of the week. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 shares was up 23.31 points, or 0.11 percent, at 21,881.43. On Tuesday, the Nikkei advanced 269.60, almost recouping Monday's 367.67-point loss.

title: BASEBALL;Clemson Pitcher Is Top Pick in Draft
description: As expected, baseball, borrowing a theme from politics, made obvious its needs yesterday, all but declaring it's the pitching, stupid. More than half the major league clubs used first-round choices in the 1996 free- agent amateur draft to rearm.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about prospects for summer jobs in the New York region misidentified the lifeguard shown, who works at Jenkinson's Pavilion in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was Ed Sarluca, not Mike Hovanyetz.

title: TV Notes;First-Runs for Summer
description: Summer television doldrums beginning to creep in already? To keep viewers' attention, some networks are sprinkling original episodes among the reruns this summer, and CBS has even called "Do-over!" for its failed soap opera "Central Park West."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Senate Race Narrows to Two
description: The race to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley narrowed to two Congressmen as Dick Zimmer, a three-term House member, easily won the Republican nomination. He will face Robert G. Torricelli, a seven-term member who ran unopposed in the New Jersey primary.

title: Business Travel;ITT Sheraton is pouring on the extra amenities at its six airport hotels in Europe.
description: IN Europe, ITT Sheraton is making its six airport hotels more than beds for the night -- with extra services to pamper world-weary business travelers.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Rise From Dead And Bury The Braves
description: If the Mets played most of their games with the determination and explosiveness they displayed in dismantling the Atlanta Braves tonight, Manager Dallas Green wouldn't be insisting that changes need to be made to make his club more competitive.

title: At the Nation's Table: Provincetown, Mass.;Eclectic Kitchen Among the Artists
description: Many restaurants bill themselves as eclectic, but Napi's on Cape Cod is one that lives up to the word.

title: BASEBALL;Bullpen Gives Gooden The Support He Needs
description: Dwight Gooden recorded the victory, John Wetteland the save. Although there is no statistic for it, Mariano Rivera should be credited with another assist, this time for helping cement the Yankees' 5-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Clinton Told to Testify on Tape Again
description: President Clinton must testify by videotape in another Whitewater-related trial, a Federal judge ruled today. The defendants are two bankers accused of financial improprieties stemming from contributions.

title: Corrections
description: The Metropolitan Almanac listing in the Weather Report each day from May 25 through yesterday mislabeled the year for the cumulative annual precipitation and comparative temperature totals. The totals were for 1996, not 1995.

title: A Mount Vernon Civics Quiz;Are Schools About Jobs, Contracts or Education?
description: Blacks make up 54 percent of the population here, and that has meant political power. The Mayor, Ernest D. Davis, is black. And four of the five City Council members are black.

title: Federal Judge to Resign, Citing Political Attacks
description: Saying that political attacks on judges had hampered his ability to render independent decisions, Judge H. Lee Sarokin of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit today announced that he would resign from the bench. The judge, adding his voice to the stinging political oratory coming from the Clinton and Dole camps over the qualifications of the Federal judiciary, said that "to hold judges responsible for crime is like blaming doctors for disease."

title: Bahrain Holds 44 It Says Are Tied to Pro-Iran Plot
description: Bahrain announced the arrest of 44 people today in connection with a purported pro-Iranian plot to overthrow its Government.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Coca-Cola Enterprises Adds to Europe Stake
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., continuing to increase its share of the European market, said today that it would buy the British bottling operations co-owned by the Coca-Cola Company and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. for about $1.9 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: United Sugars Corp., Moorhead, Minn., a unit of American Crystal Sugar Co., to Martin/Williams, Minneapols, a unit of the GGT Group, to handle its account, previously handled by Miller Meester Advertising, Minneapolis. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million. Olin Corp., Norwalk, Conn., to Mason & Madison, New Haven, to handle advertising and marketing for its pool chemicals and new products, previously at Grey Advertising, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Editorial Notebook;A Republican Lament
description: New York's Lieutenant Governor says she is being persecuted by the Pataki administration. This is something new, even in a state where unhappy lieutenant governors are pretty much the norm. None of her predecessors have claimed that high-ranking officials conspired to make them late for a State of the City speech. But Elizabeth McCaughey Ross did indeed tell The Times she had overheard a phone call made to a state trooper who was taking her to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's address in New York City, ordering the driver not to "make it there on time." It was, she said, part of a pattern of "petty political persecution" intended to discredit her.

title: Retailing Issues Lead Rebound in Stocks
description: Stocks ended a two-day decline yesterday with an advance led by retailing issues.

title: Ron Brown's Plane and False Economies
description: To the Editor: Two months before Commerce Secretary Ronald Brown was killed in April when the plane flying him to Dubrovnik crashed in stormy weather, military transport planes based in the United States were banned from flying into the Dubrovnik airport in such weather (front page, May 31). This ban did not apply to the plane carrying Mr. Brown because that plane was based in Germany.

title: Strike at McDonnell Douglas
description: Members of the machinists' union at a McDonnell Douglas Corporation plant here went on strike early today because of concerns about the company's plans to have outside companies do work now done by union members, a practice known as outsourcing.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOMETOWN BUFFET AGREES TO ACQUIRE BUFFETS FOR STOCK
description: Hometown Buffet Inc. of San Diego will acquire Buffets Inc. for stock worth more than $175 million, plus other considerations, the restaurant companies said. The combined company will operate 252 Old Country Buffet Restaurants, 93 Home Town Buffets and 2 Roadhouse Grills in 32 states with annual sales around $661 million. Under the agreement, Hometown shareholders will receive 1.17 Buffets common shares for each Hometown share held. Buffets, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., will also assume $41.5 million in Hometown debt securities convertible into common stock. Hometown shares fell $1.125, to $14, in Nasdaq trading; Buffets shares fell 12.5 cents, to $12.375.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KIMBERLY-CLARK MOVES TO SATISFY ANTITRUST CONCERNS
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to license its Scotties facial tissue brand in the United States and to sell a tissue mill in New York to Irving Tissue Inc. The sale is intended to satisfy antitrust issues related to Kimberly-Clark's $9.4 billion acquisition of the Scott Paper Company. Terms were not disclosed. Dallas-based Kimberly-Clark, which was required by the Justice Department to license the Scotties brand and to sell up to two tissue mills by Sunday, said it had asked the department to extend the deadline to July 12 and to accept the sale of the mill in Fort Edward as satisfying its requirement. Irving Tissue is part of the Irving family of businesses, which is based in St. John, New Brunswick.

title: Salt Is Regaining Favor and Savor
description: AS pure sodium chloride becomes acceptable once again, people are becoming salt-savvy. Cooks are using not just one but a variety of salts. Several specialty stores are promoting salt as a rare and exotic condiment, a multiflavored new ingredient. And those who never stopped lusting for salt have emerged victorious.

title: POLITICS: THE PRESIDENT;CLINTON PROPOSES U.S. TAX CREDITS FOR COLLEGE AID
description: Proclaiming higher education the linchpin of economic progress, President Clinton came to one of the most costly colleges in the nation today to propose a new $1,500 tax credit aimed at making the first two years of college as commonplace for Americans as high school already is.

title: Siege Is Now Part of the Landscape
description: With the standoff between Montana's anti-government Freemen and Federal agents having reached its 72d day here, the siege has settled into something of a routine.

title: Merger Is Not Expected to Help NEC in Japan
description: Although the NEC Corporation is the leading personal computer company in Japan, the company has not been much of a force outside its home market. And even at home, its PC market share has been slipping.

title: COMPANY NEWS;$575 MILLION DEAL FOR TDK SEMICONDUCTOR UNIT
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Silicon Systems Inc., the American semiconductor production unit of the TDK Corporation of Japan, for about $575 million. Texas Instruments said the acquisition would strengthen its hold as the leading supplier of hard-drive semiconductors and allow it to compete in the development of digital videodisks, the high-capacity information storage medium that is expected to surpass the compact disk for the storage of music, full-length movies and computer programs. The unit will be sold in exchange for a large cash payment and a long-term note, as well as a contingency payment of up to $50 million based on the unit's future performance. The acquisition was announced after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of Texas Instruments fell 87.5 cents, to $54.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Woman Is Found Beaten and Unconscious in Central Park
description: A woman was found badly beaten and unconscious yesterday afternoon in a wooded area of Central Park, after an attack that apparently occurred in broad daylight, the police said.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From Address To Princeton Graduates
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech at Princeton University yesterday, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:

title: How to Cast a TV Pilot? Here's How
description: If television stardom is a glittering golden prize, then Gilda Stratton sits in front of the bank vault where it's kept. She can't open the door for you, but if she thinks you can act and likes your looks, she can let you have a few spins of the combination lock.

title: Netanyahu Vague on Pledge To Withdraw From Hebron
description: Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu's tough campaign language began to yield today to a more gingerly approach to Israel's problems.

title: Journal;Class of '71
description: Timothy Leary had been fired from Harvard four years before we arrived as freshmen, but it's still appropriate that his obituary was front-page news as the class of 1971 returned for its 25th reunion this week. We were the 60's kids whose anti-war protests, wreathed in marijuana smoke, brought police to Harvard Yard and whose strike for multicultural causes brought classes to a halt. If you want to locate the epicenter of the boomer elite that so many Americans, especially those who despise Bill Clinton, love to hate, here we are.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Marrying Classical Form to Romantic Content
description: Natalia Makarova's spectacular 1980 staging of "La Bayadere" for American Ballet Theater has seen many excellent principals but none as sexy as Nina Ananiashvili and Jose Manuel Carreno on Monday night. Don't miss them when they dance tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Study Finds Metal Debris Punctured Tether Pulled by Shuttle
description: A $400 million experiment in generating electricity in space failed because debris punctured insulation in a 12-mile-long cord and caused a short circuit, an investigating board said today.

title: At the Nation's Table: Philadelphia;A Menu Inspired By Cezanne
description: The produce of Provence, the coastal region in the South of France, where Paul Cezanne was born and died, is almost as much the star of the exhibition that opened last week at the Philadelphia Museum of Art as Cezanne himself. In still life after still life in this major retrospective, the father of modern painting displays his reverence for the fruits and vegetables that grow in the fields around his native Aix-en-Provence.

title: A Verbal Curve Ball
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Lobster Fra Diavolo
description: A recipe for lobster fra diavolo last Wednesday omitted wine from the ingredients. Here is a corrected version:

title: COMPANY NEWS;MORRISON KNUDSEN WINS TUNNEL CONTRACT IN TAIWAN
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday it won a contract to provide management and technical services on the Pinglin highway tunnel project in Taiwan. A company spokesman would not disclose the value of the 14-month consulting contract, which could be extended up to five years. The cost of the eight-mile-long tunnel, which will help connect Taipei with the Pacific coast, is about $700 million. The tunnel is part of a 19-mile highway designed to speed travel through Taiwan's central mountains. Morrison Knudsen agreed last month to be purchased by Washington Construction Group of Highland, Calif., for about $380 million.

title: Food Notes
description: More Farmers' Markets

title: 3 Swiss Slain in Burundi
description: Three Swiss Red Cross workers were ambushed and shot to death today in Burundi, said a spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Clinton Isn't Convincing on Youth Curfew
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Ager Arrested in Slaying at Party at Queens Church
description: A teen-ager was arrested and charged with second-degree murder yesterday in a shooting that erupted Sunday in a Queens church basement where a baptism was being celebrated and left one man dead and five others wounded, the police said.

title: Beatrice P. Frelinghuysen, 77, Political Matriarch
description: Beatrice Procter Frelinghuysen, the wife of one Congressman and mother of another, who was on the boards of nonprofit organizations in the fields of botany and ballet, died on Monday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J., where she lived. She was 77.

title: Theater in Review
description: Touched by an Angel In a Workman's Guise 'Orphee' Bouwerie Lane Theater

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Umpire Off the Hook
description: BRUCE FROEMMING, a National League umpire, is off the hook for seeking autographs from Los Angeles Dodgers players. A league spokeswoman, KATY FEENEY, said that the National League's president, LEONARD COLEMAN, spoke with Froemming yesterday about the matter. "He was satisfied with Froemming's answers, and considers the matter closed," Feeney said.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From McCaughey Ross Versus Castro
description: Following are excerpts from a transcription of a conversation between Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross and Parks Commissioner Bernadette Castro on WABC radio yesterday morning, provided by the radio station. The moderator, Michael Lebron, uses the name Lionel on the air.

title: Jury's $150 Million Award Against G.M. Touches Off Furor
description: An Alabama jury has awarded a record $150 million in damages in a case involving apparently faulty door latches on a General Motors vehicle, triggering calls for tort reform as well as an investigation of the auto maker's handling of the issue of the latches over a decade when they were installed in millions of vehicles.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ford and Mazda to Close Factory in New Zealand
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Mazda Motor Company said yesterday they would close their assembly plant in New Zealand next March. They spent $60 million to build the assembly plant in the city of Manukau in 1986-87 to get around New Zealand's 55 percent duty on imported vehicles. The tariff, which has declined yearly, will be 25 percent in July and only 15 percent by the end of the decade.

title: 2 Women Killed in Park
description: The bodies of two female hikers were found over the weekend at a campsite near the Appalachian Trail, and the authorities said on Monday that the deaths were being investigated as homicides.

title: Let's Pay U.N. Debt For Future's Sake
description: To the Editor: The cliche that "some people never learn" is being played out in Congress today. The issue is the severe financial crisis confronting the United Nations, due primarily to the refusal of Congress to pay the $1.5 billion America owes the world body in back dues and peacekeeping assessments.

title: BALLET REVIEW;A Workshop That Ends With a Bang And a Tribute
description: The Workshop performances that are an annual rite of passage for the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet came to a close on Monday night at the Juilliard Theater with a loving tribute and awards.

title: POLITICS: ALBANY;Pataki Plays Down Rift With McCaughey Ross as Aide Attacks Her
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he was "too busy running the state" to worry about charges by his Lieutenant Governor, Betsy McCaughey Ross, that his aides had mounted a McCarthyite smear campaign to discredit her.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;5 Indicted in Loan Fraud
description: The newspaper advertisements offered loans of up to $10,000, even for people with bad credit or no credit. But instead, thousands of customers of the A-1 Finance Company were defrauded of hundreds of dollars apiece, authorities say.

title: Voluntary Rules Are Proposed For the Privacy of Internet Users
description: The on-line and direct marketing industries today proposed voluntary guidelines intended to protect Internet users against unauthorized collection of personal information.

title: PESO TRAIL -- A special report.;A Mexican Mover and Shaker Got the Red Carpet at Citibank
description: The instructions from Citibank's New York headquarters to clerks at the bank's Mexico City office were clear: Ask no questions.

title: Capital-Case Trial Averted
description: A Tunisian immigrant pleaded guilty today to stabbing his estranged girlfriend to death in front of her 7-year-old son. The plea saved him from a possible death sentence.

title: Microsoft Joins Compuserve in Internet Deal
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it planned to deploy an array of commercial Internet software services, code-named Normandy, that it will use to establish a beachhead in the Internet market, which is dominated by the Netscape Communications Corporation.

title: Don't Discriminate on Mental Health Benefits;No to Pooling Provision
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL;Camby Embroiled In Uproar On Gifts
description: Once as smooth and fluid as his play on the floor, Marcus Camby's path from college player of the year to the National Basketball Association has become tangled with revelations that he accepted improper cash payments and gifts, leading to a crossfire of accusations by sports agents and others.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Youth, Attuned to Love And Political Protest
description: Works for large casts dominated the Senior Dance Concert that Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts presented on Sunday afternoon at the school. This gave many dancers a chance to display their expertise in an assortment of contemporary styles.

title: Insurer Weighs Sale While Reinsurer Bids for a Rival
description: The insurance industry moved toward further consolidation yesterday as a major life insurance company said it was considering a sale and a large Bermuda-based reinsurance broker bid nearly $1 billion to buy one of its competitors.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Parties to honor PETER DUCHIN, the band leader, are in full swing since the recent publication of his memoirs, "Ghost of a Chance," by Random House. Even the teeming rain on Monday night failed to deter a crowd of 200 from showing up at the Madison Avenue Bookshop.

title: Real Estate;The former Newsweek Building is getting a new name, the New York Magazine Building.
description: THE former Newsweek Building at 444 Madison Avenue will soon have a new name: the New York Magazine Building.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Newspaper Cuts Newsstand Price
description: The Los Angeles Times, the flagship newspaper of the Times Mirror Company, has halved its newsstand price to 25 cents in a move to increase circulation, hoping it can then raise advertising rates.

title: Communist Candidate Looks For Alliance Against Yeltsin
description: With less than two weeks remaining before Russia's presidential election, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the once aloof and defiant Communist Party candidate, set off on his final campaign swing today, apparently ready to compromise with anyone whose name is not Yeltsin.

title: Mega-Stores Will Dull New York's Edge
description: To the Editor: Your May 28 editorial "Making It in New York City," which favors Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to open up manufacturing areas to mega-store development, claims that "smaller operations can survive if they offer distinctive goods or better service." Tell that to the hundreds of small towns with dead main streets sucked dry by mall development.

title: Clinton Isn't Convincing on Youth Curfew
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Prices Rise on Outlook For Seasonal Surge in Demand
description: Gasoline prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on expectations that inventories at refineries would drop as a result of a seasonal increase in consumption.

title: Clinton Isn't Convincing on Youth Curfew;Dole Minus the Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Cone Endorses Treatment Of Aneurysm
description: David Cone said yesterday that he had "complete confidence" in the doctors who treated him last month for an aneurysm in his right shoulder and that he was puzzled by a published report that called into question the decision by doctors to allow him to pitch on May 2, eight days before he underwent surgery to repair the aneurysm.

title: Peter Glenville, 82, a Director On Broadway and in London
description: Peter Glenville, a director who won accolades for his staging of plays in the West End of London as well as on Broadway, died on Monday at a friend's home in Manhattan, while on a visit from his home in San Miguel, Mexico. He was 82.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Papa John's Picks Richards Group
description: Papa John's International Inc., a pizza-restaurant chain, said yesterday that it had named the Richards Group in Dallas to handle its national broadcast advertising account, which had been at Tucker Wayne & Company in Atlanta for the last year. Billings were estimated at more than $6 million and are expected to grow with the expanding chain.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. SURGICAL SAYS F.D.A. WILL REVIEW CANCER DEVICE
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation said the Food and Drug Administration was reconsidering its approval of a device used to detect breast cancer because an agency reviewer might have made a mistake. The company's ABBI biopsy system was approved through the agency's 510-K process, which allows speedy approval of medical devices similar to those already on the market. U.S. Surgical contends that its ABBI biopsy system is similar to so-called core needle biopsies, where multiple tissue samples are removed. The ABBI instrument is inserted only once and removes more of the tissue that one time. The company said a senior F.D.A. device reviewer had indicated that the F.D.A. might rescind marketing clearance for ABBI. The company's announcement came after the close of trading. Earlier, its shares rose 87.5 cents, to $34.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rate Rise for United Water
description: Bills from United Water Resources will rise $14.40 a year on average, as a result of a 4.5 percent rate increase approved yesterday by the State Board of Public Utilities. The utility has 750,000 customers in Bergen and Hudson counties.

title: Education Council Picks New President
description: The board of the American Council on Education, a research and lobbying organization in Washington, has named Stanley O. Ikenberry as the council's new president.

title: Oh, That Fra Diavolo!
description: To the Editor:

title: April Orders To Factories Slipped 0.1%
description: Weaker sales of aircraft cut the value of orders to factories in April, the Commerce Department said today, but other goods posted gains as depleted inventories of new cars were rebuilt.

title: Van in Crash Fatal to 2 Was Operating Illegally
description: The operator of a crowded van that overturned on a Queens highway Monday night, killing two people, had lost its license to transport passengers last month and was operating illegally, officials say. The van's driver, who had fled the accident after the crash, surrendered yesterday to face manslaughter charges.

title: Hillary Clinton's Fingerprints Among Those Found on Papers
description: Republicans on the special Senate Whitewater committee released a report from the Federal Bureau of Investigation today showing that the fingerprints of the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, were found on records discovered in the White House family quarters two years after they were first sought by investigators.

title: The Salts of the Earth: A Cook's Tour of How and What
description: DIFFERENT salts vary considerably in taste. To find out what you prefer, conduct an informal salt tasting by shaking a few grains on bread, boiled potatoes or sliced tomatoes. Try tasting just four salts at a time; any more is overwhelming.

title: At the Nation's Table: San Francisco;North Beach Spirit At Rose Pistola
description: Reed Hearon, the Texas-born chef who charmed San Francisco with his Provencal-inspired Lulu's and the flamboyantly Mexican Cafe Marimba, has turned his attention to things Italian. And for his new restaurant in the heart of North Beach -- San Francisco's Italian quarter -- Mr. Hearon asked Rose Evangelisti, 88, to grace his new venture with her old bar's illustrious name: Rose Pistola.

title: Dole Begins a Final Week Of Senate Vote-Taking
description: Bob Dole returned to the Capitol today for his final week in the Senate and, as expected, promptly lost the first of several votes that he has scheduled in his attempt to draw a bright political line between himself and President Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Fashion page yesterday about the rise of stores that sell used designer clothes misstated the location of one in Manhattan, Allan & Suzi. It is at 80th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, not Columbus Avenue.

title: Allstate Seeks Shelter From Florida's Disasters
description: Almost four years after Hurricane Andrew inflicted $16.5 billion of damage on Florida homeowners, the Allstate Corporation said yesterday that it would reorganize its property-insurance business in the state to limit the impact of future natural disasters on its balance sheet.

title: And They Cooked Happily Ever After
description: A BOOK for the June gift list might be "The Bride and Groom's First Cookbook," by Abigail Kirsch with Susan M. Greenberg (Doubleday, $25). It takes fledgling cooks by the hand, providing recipes suitable for every day but with an emphasis on entertaining. Each recipe provides a list of needed equipment and a step-by-step game plan. In the back of the book are lists of the basics needed for stocking a kitchen.

title: U.S. Senate Race in New Jersey Narrows to Zimmer and Torricelli
description: The race to fill the United States Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley narrowed to two contenders last night, as Dick Zimmer, a three-term Congressman from Delaware Township, handily defeated two opponents to win the Republican nomination.

title: Refashioning NATO
description: NATO, the Atlantic military alliance spawned and shaped by the cold war, has taken an important step toward restructuring itself for the needs of a new era. Foreign ministers from its 16 member nations agreed in Berlin Monday on more flexible ways for European members of the alliance to respond to future regional crises that do not require American military might.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When ELTON JOHN cleans out his closet, there's enough to fill a department store.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants to Cut Veterans' Pay
description: In an effort to trim their payroll and get their rookies signed, the Giants are executing a plan to cut the salaries of some of their highly paid veterans. Yesterday they waived safety Vencie Glenn, a 10-year veteran who started 15 games for the Giants last season.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Chance To Love Unsettles Daydreams Of a Loner
description: When Callie (Liv Tyler), a naive young beauty, is hired as a new waitress at the roadside tavern where James Mangold's "Heavy" unfolds, not much is said. Not much needs to be. The effects of Callie's arrival are quietly earthshaking, and Mr. Mangold assesses them with such simple clarity and precision that he might as well be defining the points of a compass. It takes only a few revealing words and glances for "Heavy" to establish not only Callie's impact but also Mr. Mangold's own.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What am I bid for a bicycle ridden by George Steinbrenner? Perhaps you'd prefer one belonging to Kathie Lee Gifford, Elisabeth Shue, Greg LeMond or Donald J. Trump?

title: Singapore Journal;Good Life Guide: To 5 C's, Like Cash, Add Clout
description: Let's grow up!" scolded Singapore's leader, Lee Kuan Yew, lecturing his countrymen on what he called the facts of life in an unfair world.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A PATENT FOR XOMA, AND ITS SHARES SURGE 14.3 PERCENT
description: The shares of the Xoma Corporation jumped 14.3 percent yesterday after the biotechnology company said it had received a patent for a line of products to treat bacterial infections. Xoma, based in Berkeley, Calif., said its BPI protein products, including Neuprex, enhanced certain common antibiotics, making them more effective treatments. The company is developing a family of drugs derived from BPI, or bactericidal and permeability-increasing protein. The company's shares rose $1, to $8, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Theater in Review
description: An Agreeable Heroine In Search of a Life 'Nice Chair' 46 Walker Street

title: BOXING: NOTEBOOK;Respect. Humility. In a Title Fight?
description: Julio Cesar Chavez and Oscar De La Hoya spoke almost reverently about each other yesterday, three days before their confrontation that could be the biggest closed-circuit sports event ever held.

title: Emergency Deal in Albany Keeps Government Going
description: In a compromise made to keep state government running, Gov. George E. Pataki and state legislative leaders said tonight that they had agreed on an emergency spending bill to pay state workers this week while negotiations on the long-delayed state budget continue.

title: Aide at the Modern Gets Post in Israel
description: James S. Snyder, special adviser to the director of the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and the museum's deputy director for planning and program support for 10 years, yesterday was named director of the Israel Museum in Jerusalem. Mr. Snyder, 43, is succeeding Dr. Martin Weyl, who will become the museum's director emeritus on July 1 after having served as its director for 15 years.

title: Perry Casts Doubt on Account That Brown Insisted on Flying
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said there was "zero evidence" to suggest that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown had insisted that pilots fly into a storm on the day that his plane crashed on a Croatian mountaintop, killing all aboard.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;KLM Profits Are Higher, Exceeding Expectations
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V. said yesterday that its profits had increased 16 percent for the fiscal year, helped by a higher value for its stake in Northwest Airlines. KLM said its net profit was 547 million guilders ($321.76 million), up from 470 million guilders. Sales rose to 9.54 billion guilders from 9.2 billion guilders.

title: Harnessing the Sun And Selling It Abroad;U.S. Solar Industry in Export Boom
description: Jolted by the oil embargoes of the 1970's, the Federal Government has been awarding research grants to develop solar power ever since. Twenty years and $1.4 billion in taxpayer money later, solar power is still not much more than a dim light bulb in the nation's energy constellation.

title: NEC and Packard Bell in Deal To Create the No. 4 PC Maker
description: Packard Bell Electronics, which dominates the American market for home computers but has not been consistently profitable, announced yesterday that it would merge with the foreign PC operations of the NEC Corporation of Japan, which has had little success outside its home market.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Nets' Search Continues
description: Continuing the search for a head coach, the Nets' president, MICHAEL ROWE, is expected to meet with the former Toronto Raptors coach BRENDAN MALONE this week in Chicago. Malone, who has been scouting for the Seattle SuperSonics since being dismissed by the Raptors, said he talked with Rowe a month ago, just before the Nets made an unsuccessful bid for RICK PITINO. A second talk with Malone, a 54-year-old who grew up in New York City, may mean he's a leading candidate.

title: Massachusetts Senate Candidates Debate Again
description: In the second public debate of their Senate campaign, Senator John Kerry and Governor William F. Weld engaged in some caustic exchanges here Monday night over who would better champion the interests of working-class families in Massachusetts.

title: Crash Investigators Focus on How Valujet And Contractor HandledDangerous Cargo
description: Early on Saturday, May 11, a maintenance worker at Miami's airport loaded five heavy cardboard boxes containing oxygen generators onto a truck and drove them to the gate area where Valujet Flight 592 was due to depart for Atlanta.

title: Child-Resistant Medicine Caps Do Save Lives
description: For any parent or grandparent who has ever struggled to open child-resistant bottles of medicine, there is good news. A new study shows that such containers do, in fact, save children's lives.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Apple Plans An Offering Of 6% Notes
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would offer $575 million in convertible debt, in what analysts called a positive step by the troubled company to raise cash.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Seal;From a Crucible Of Early Pain Comes the Gold Of Stardom
