description: THE artist formerly known as Sealhenry Samuel and now best known for his pop madrigal "Kiss From a Rose," the triple Grammy-winning ballad from the "Batman Forever" soundtrack, twiddled his ebony chopsticks with anticipatory zest but finally decided to forgo lunch. Almost.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the Stand for Children Rally in Washington misidentified the participant standing next to Representative Cynthia A. McKinney. She was Joan King, a member of the Women's Action for New Directions, a nonprofit group seeking reductions in military spending, not Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York.

title: Wife of Jailed Nigerian Opposition Leader Is Slain
description: A wife of the wealthy Nigerian businessman who is widely believed to have won a 1993 presidential election was shot and killed today.

title: Propane Leak Brings Blast
description: A roofing company's leaking propane tank touched off a chain of explosions at a Social Security office today, shattering windows but causing no injuries.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Pipe Break Blocks Route 1-9
description: Southbound drivers on Route 1 and 9 should expect substantial delays this morning and possibly this evening while crews repair a 100-year-old water main that ruptured early yesterday, blocking traffic and leaving some Bayonne residents with little water pressure, officials said. The busy four-lane road, also known as Route 440 in Hudson County, was closed between Culver and Communipaw Avenues for more than one hour, said Tim Bourne, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Michael Palmer was named to the new post of group executive for diversified services at Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, New York. He had been president of Palmer Bonner, Toronto, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, where he was succeeded by Liz Torlee, most recently the president and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, Toronto, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Ruth Parr was named to the new post of account planning director at DDB Needham Dallas, a unit of the Omnicom Group. She had been a senior vice president and worldwide planning director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of the WPP Group.

title: No Headline
description: It really doesn't matter how heavy it is as long as you put enough stuff underneath to hold it up."

title: Foreign Affairs;Israel's Arab Fallout
description: Bibi Netanyahu's election may have shaken up Israeli politics, but it's triggered an earthquake in the Arab world. Thanks to the peace process, Israel has become part of Arab politics, and everyone from Rabat to Baghdad is asking, how does Bibi help or hurt me? Here's an insider's guide to their thinking:

title: Attack Raises Doubts About the Park's Safety
description: The attack of a woman in Central Park in broad daylight has once again raised the question: Is Central Park safe?

title: Whooping Cough Is Often Missed in Adults
description: Although you are not a child anymore, that nagging cough you cannot seem to get rid of just might be whooping cough, otherwise known as pertussis.

title: U.S. Diplomat Told Staff to Be Optimistic on Bosnia Vote
description: The American diplomat heading the team in Bosnia that is supposed to determine whether fair elections are feasible there instructed his staff last week to focus more on positive developments in their weekly reports, rather than detailing the litany of obstacles to free elections.

title: Tax-Cut Tactics
description: President Clinton is redefining the art of political response. He moves before his opponent has done anything requiring a response. Last month the President embraced the Wisconsin welfare plan a few days before Bob Dole was to appear with its author, Gov. Tommy Thompson. Yesterday Mr. Clinton jumped ahead of Mr. Dole's expected tax-cut proposal with one of his own. Mr. Clinton's plan is shrewd politics but disagreeable public policy.

title: Sudan Asserts Militant Financier Has Left
description: Under diplomatic sanctions on charges of harboring terrorists, the Sudan has told the Security Council that it has asked one of the world's biggest financiers of militant Islamic causes to leave the country.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Out of the Bullpen, Into the Record Books
description: PAMELA DAVIS, a starter with the Colorado Silver Bullets women's baseball team, pitched one inning of scoreless relief last night in a Class AA exhibition game against male players and earned a line in the record book: She is believed to be the first woman to pitch for a major league farm club under the current structure of the minor leagues.

title: Dominic Quinn, 73, A Talk-Show Host And Fan of Opera
description: Dominic Quinn, a talk-show host in Philadelphia who cherished opera, the printed word and, very pointedly, the proper use of the English language, died on Friday at his home in Wayne, Pa. He was 73.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JUDGE DISMISSES ANTITRUST SUIT AGAINST TICKETMASTER
description: A Federal judge in St. Louis has dismissed a class-action suit against Ticketmaster, ruling that consumers had no grounds to pursue antitrust claims against the computerized-ticketing service. Los Angeles-based Ticketmaster said the case was a consolidation of 16 national class-action suits. The plaintiffs contended that Ticketmaster's exclusive ticketing contracts were anticonsumer and represented a monopoly. Ticketmaster argued that its contracts were negotiated in a fully competitive market. The decision by Judge Stephen Limbaugh was issued on Friday and disclosed late on Monday.

title: About New York;A Day Off (For Others) Rankles
description: THIS time of year drives Marilyn Bach crazy. It's not the scramble to prepare students for the Regents exams or finals that unsettles this Bronx teacher. Nor is it some vague, generalized fear about the state of urban public schools near the end of the century.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Vermont Escapees Arrested in Manhattan
description: Two men who escaped from a Vermont prison last week were arrested early yesterday near the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan. A "things to do" list, describing their escape route and when to buy guns and commit robberies, was found in a car they had stolen in Vermont, authorities said.

title: Ex-Colleague of Suspect in Bar Beating to Be Questioned
description: A New York City police sergeant has agreed to answer questions today from Suffolk County detectives in the racially charged beating of a black man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Three Restaurants Make Kosher Sushi (Hold the Shellfish)
description: FOR Joseph Ehrlichster, an Orthodox Jew and a real estate investor, keeping kosher gives him just about the same gastronomic privileges as everyone else in New York. Except when it comes to sushi.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LATE afternoon. I was sitting next to the window on a bus heading downtown for Pennsylvania Station. Traffic was exceptionally heavy.

title: No.2 Officer Will Replace Admiral Boorda
description: President Clinton has chosen Adm. Jay L. Johnson, the vice chief of naval operations, to succeed Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Navy chief who committed suicide on May 16, officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Costly Failure: Space Launch Is Aborted
description: A huge new rocket that had been intended to put Europe further ahead of the United States in the world commercial satellite-launching market had to be blown up today, 40 seconds into its maiden flight, after it veered from its trajectory.

title: Favorite Pastries Weigh In
description: THIS may not be what you want to read with your morning coffee. The June issue of Nutrition Action, the monthly newsletter of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, is informing its readers just what it is they consume when they have one of their favorite sweets for breakfast or as a snack.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Vanbiesbrouck Puts The Past Behind Him
description: John Vanbiesbrouck was among the last Panthers to leave the locker room tonight, but the goalie wasn't dodging questions. Far from it. In the past he may have been too upset to talk after a defeat. Tonight he was able to put it behind him.

title: BellSouth and Time Warner in Telephone Accord
description: BellSouth and Time Warner announced a sweeping agreement yesterday that would allow Time Warner to offer local telephone service throughout the southeastern United States. The deal is the latest in a raft of agreements struck by regional Bell companies to open their local phone networks in the wake of the new telecommunications law.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Business Day on Friday about a dispute between the New York Stock Exchange and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange overstated the frequency with which specialists on the New York exchange, who act as auctioneers, receive commissions. Specialists make commissions on fewer than 10 percent of trades, according to exchange officials.

title: POLITICS: THE VICE PRESIDENT;Taking Little for Granted, Gore Campaigns in Brooklyn
description: As his boss toured the halls of academia and privilege across the Hudson River, Vice President Al Gore went to the heart of Brooklyn yesterday, shaking hands with shoppers in the Fulton Mall and walking through a former crack house turned into a thriving day-care program.

title: Litchi Nut Is Spiky But Also Juicy
description: MOST Americans know litchi nuts only as syrupy canned fruit or as raisinlike dried fruit. But at this time of year, fans of fresh litchi nuts look for clusters of the rosy Ping-Pong-ball-size fruit, traditionally sold attached to the stems.

title: Jesse Hill Ford, 66, a Novelist Who Wrote of Race Relations
description: Jesse Hill Ford, the novelist whose haunting examination of the destructive relations between the races in his native South helped sow the seeds of destruction of his own acclaimed literary career, took his life on Saturday at his home in Nashville. He was 66 and had undergone open heart surgery six weeks ago.

title: When State-Fair Cooks Are Paired With Highfalutin Chefs
description: ALICE WATERS, the chef and owner of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., looked over all the recipes submitted by blue-ribbon winners from a dozen of the biggest state fairs in the country and picked the pickles.

title: Co-op City Emptied Bronx Neighborhoods
description: To the Editor: I'm sorry to hear about the struggles of Co-op City (news article, May 29), but that housing development was slated to fail from its inception.

title: HORSE RACING;McGaughey Puts His Faith in a Filly
description: She is descended from two champions, Personal Ensign and Easy Goer, who won 18 of the 20 races they ran at Belmont Park. She is tall, rangy and talented, and has a mind of her own. She won the Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies last fall. And she races for a stable that produces one champion filly after another.

title: POLITICS: ROSS PEROT;Reform Party Is Scheduling Its Convention For August
description: The Presidential nominating convention of the Ross Perot-backed Reform Party will in all likelihood be sandwiched between the conventions of the Republican and Democratic Parties in August, Mr. Perot said today.

title: U.S. Troops Rescued From Angry Serbs
description: French troops extricated about six American troops from an angry Bosnian Serb crowd near Sarajevo today after the Americans tried to confiscate unauthorized weapons, a NATO spokesman said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;An audience-data company faces unhappy clients named Conde Nast, Dow Jones and Gannett.
description: JUST how reliable are the magazine audience numbers cranked out by the nation's syndicated research firms?

title: COMPANY NEWS;READING & BATES SUSPENDS EFFORT TO BUY TRANSOCEAN
description: The Reading & Bates Corporation of Houston said yesterday that it was suspending its efforts to acquire the Norwegian driller Transocean S.A., after reviewing the latest proposal from a rival bidder, Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. Houston-based Sonat sweetened its offer to about $1.5 billion after some large Transocean shareholders threatened to back the Reading & Bates bid. Paul B. Loyd Jr., the chairman of Reading & Bates, said the company would "be in a position to reenter the process promptly if we believe we can do so on terms and conditions beneficial Reading & Bates stockholders."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Warning on Silted Harbors
description: A senior Coast Guard official warned a Senate committee yesterday that letting silt pile up in East Coast harbors was likely to increase risky offshore oil transfers, the cause of last month's oil tanker spill in the Delaware Bay.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;City College Praises Immigrant Achievers
description: In her address to this year's graduating class at City College, Yolanda T. Moses, the college's president, dwelled on the budget battle in Albany. The college, she said, was nearly "shattered by the budget crisis" and the tense battle to restore financing.

title: Pataki Deputy Is Continuing Her Attacks
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross today spurned an appeal from Gov. George E. Pataki to mute her criticism of his administration, stepping up her attacks on his aides, issuing a stack of evidence to back up her contention that she was being discredited and going so far as to call one of the Governor's most powerful and trusted advisers a liar.

title: Stocks Edge Up in Tokyo
description: Stocks were trading slightly higher at midday here, continuing to climb back from Monday's loss of 367.67 points. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 48.63 points, or 0.22 percent, at 21,930.06. On Wednesday, the Nikkei increased 23.31 points to close at 21,881.43.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Allders Unit Draws Bids From BAA and Swissair
description: Allders P.L.C.'s duty-free business drew two increased bids in four hours as BAA P.L.C. and a unit of Swissair A.G. vied for the British retailer's international division. BAA moved first, raising its offer to L145 million ($247 million) from the original L130 million. The Swissair Associated Companies, a hotel and catering unit of the Swiss airline, then offered L160 million ($247 million) for Allders International through the investment banker SBC Warburg.

title: Mr. Gingrich and Sterling Forest
description: The battle to preserve 20,000 acres of woodlands straddling the New York-New Jersey border has won the support of Republicans and Democrats in both states and in Washington. House Speaker Newt Gingrich pledged to help the campaign to save the area, known as Sterling Forest, six months ago. But a bill authorizing Federal money to help acquire the forest from developers remains blocked in the House by some Western Republicans, who are holding it hostage until they gain support of their own anti-environmental agenda to raid public lands in the West.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VALHI TO SELL SUGAR COMPANY TO A COOPERATIVE
description: Valhi Inc. said yesterday that it intended to sell its Amalgamated Sugar Company subsidiary to the Snake River Sugar Company, an Oregon cooperative of sugar beet farmers, for about $250 million. Amalgamated operates sugar factories in Twin Falls, Paul and Nampa, Idaho; and Nyssa, Ore. It also has other sugar operations in Oregon, Utah, Idaho, Colorado and Washington. Valhi said Snake River was still obtaining financing and membership agreements from 1,600 sugar-beet growers in Idaho, Oregon and Washington. Valhi, based in Dallas, has interests in chemicals, construction material, sugar and fast food. Valhi stock was up 62.5 cents, at $7.375 a share.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column yesterday, about procrastination, included an erroneous report from the publisher about the book "The Now Habit: Overcoming Procrastination with Guilt-Free Play." It is available in paperback from Tarcher/Putnam; it is not out of print.

title: Bodybuilding Officer Is an Unlikely Suspect
description: For most of Detective Constantine Chronis's 10-year career as a police officer, the only remarkable thing about him was his hulking physique.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A new campaign by British Airways generates some critical comments from consumers.
description: WITH a plain-vanilla tag line like "The World's Favorite Airline," it seems reasonable to assume that British Airways will not go out of its way to create turbulence with its marketing.

title: Syndicated Program For Chung And Povich
description: Connie Chung, who has not worked in television since being ousted as the co-anchor of "The CBS Evening News" in May 1995, said yesterday that she and her husband, Maury Povich, had agreed to be co-anchors of a syndicated program with news and information to begin in the fall of 1998.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Modern American Concertos
description: Adams's Fluid Lines

title: U.S. Offers Details on Inquiry Into Mexican's Cash Transfers
description: The Justice Department provided new details today into when and why it opened an investigation into the trail of tens of millions of dollars whisked out of Mexico to Switzerland in 1993 by Raul Salinas de Gortari, the eldest brother of the former President of Mexico.

title: Tommy Collins, 67, a Fighter Whose Beating Stirred Outcry
description: Tommy Collins, a popular fighter of the 1950's who was once beaten so savagely that his defeat sparked a national outcry to reform boxing, died on Monday in Boston. He was 67 years old.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;Fear of Cuts Clouds Day At Queens
description: At Queens College yesterday, there was a new addition to the traditional regalia of graduations. Along with corsages and doctoral hoods, most graduates, professors and administrators wore a round yellow sticker that read: "No cuts! No firings! Defend Queens College."

title: HORSE RACING;Belmont Forecast: Entry List to Rise to Record 16
description: It may not be the most distinguished field in the 128-year history of the Belmont Stakes. It may not be the fastest. It does not include the winner of the Kentucky Derby, who retired five days after his moment of glory. It does include one horse from England, one filly and many long shots.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hostile Offer Is Considered For British Car Parts Maker
description: The British engineering company BBA Group P.L.C. said today that it was considering a hostile bid for Lucas Industries P.L.C.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AFFILIATED COMPUTER SERVICES TO ACQUIRE GENIX GROUP
description: Affiliated Computer Services Inc., which provides information technology services, signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Genix Group, a unit of the MCN Corporation, for $135 million in cash. The merger would create the nation's fourth-largest outside provider of data-processing services, with annual revenues of more than $500 million, Affiliated said. Genix mainly serves the manufacturing, insurance and utility industries, complementing Dallas-based Affiliated's strengths in the health care, financial services, transportation and telecommunications segments. Genix, based in Dearborn, Mich., had revenues of $105.2 million in 1995.

title: Bertelsmann's New TV Venture Upsets Its Partners
description: Barely three months after Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, Canal Plus of France and B Sky B of Britain joined forces in the race to develop digital television broadcasting across Europe, the alliance is under severe strain as a result of a separate television deal negotiated by Bertelsmann, reportedly without consulting its two original partners.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Chicago's Bit Players Get a Few Moments Of Their Own Glory
description: For all the hoopla this week over Michael Jordan returning again to prime time in the finals, there were many other Bulls tales buried next to the tire ads.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;Wild Order: Every Plant Has Its Place (Naturally)
description: Ken Druse stood on the back porch of his little handyman's special in the northwest corner of New Jersey, talking about drought and flood. "We had the worst drought of the century here last summer, followed by 120 inches of snow," he said.

title: New Camcorder Features Allow the User to Play Director
description: WHILE the cost of gas goes through the roof, take solace: the camcorders used for saving vacation memories now have more power and more features, including even basic models. And many will bring the beach and mountains back home to the living room for a discount price of around $500, instead of the $1,000 of a few years ago.

title: BASEBALL;Key Feels All Right, But Takes a Licking
description: Jimmy Key said he felt elated. He said his arm hadn't felt this good since early in 1994.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;New Chief for France's Jet Engine Builder
description: The French Government appointed Jean-Paul Bechat to be chief executive of the state-owned jet engine maker Snecma today a week after dismissing Bernard Dufour.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL

title: Abortion as Intrusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin American Nations Rebuke U.S. for the Embargo on Cuba
description: In a display of near unanimity, the countries of the Organization of American States have criticized the United States for its recent extension of the economic embargo against Cuba as a probable violation of international law.

title: Liberties;Ross Comes a-Courtin'
description: It is fashionable this spring to talk about politics in terms of romance.

title: GOLF;At Westchester, a Gloriously Tough Dress Rehearsal for the Open
description: There is this popular misconception going around that the United States Open begins next week at Oakland Hills in Birmingham, Mich. In actual fact, it has already begun, right here on the skinny fairways, fast greens and thick rough of the Westchester Country Club, where the Buick Classic begins on Thursday.

title: Making an Exception in Singapore
description: Singapore's behind-the-scenes ruler, Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, has proclaimed a curious double standard for probity in his country. It is fine for him and his family to accept deep discounts on luxury housing and other favors from businessmen. But the rest of the society must not allow itself even a hint of unseemly conduct.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Quaker Oats Unit Consolidates 2 Accounts
description: The Quaker Oats Beverages unit of the Quaker Oats Company has consolidated its Gatorade and Snapple accounts, with combined billings estimated at $100 million, at Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Sugar Producer Gets $550 Million Offer
description: The French food concern Eridania Beghin-Say S.A. said yesterday that it had offered 2.85 billion francs (about $550 million) to acquire the sugar producer Compagnie Francaise de Sucrerie from Compagnie de Navigation Mixte S.A. Navigation Mixte, which is wholly owned by the French holding company Groupe Paribas, has accepted the offer and said final details would be decided in the coming weeks.

title: BASEBALL;Numbers Paint Poor Picture
description: George Steinbrenner was sitting in an office at Yankee Stadium, having just traveled to the Bronx from the owners' meetings in Philadelphia. He had two pieces of his paper in his hands and he wanted to let the numbers they showed do all the talking.

title: Couple Are Stabbed As Problems Delay Ambulance Service
description: A man and a woman were stabbed in their house in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Tuesday night by a man who walked in through their unlocked screen door, apparently to rob them, the police said yesterday.

title: Ex-Employee of Philip Morris Pleads Guilty to Bank Fraud
description: Edward J. Reiners, a former employee of the Philip Morris Companies, pleaded guilty to money-laundering and bank-fraud charges yesterday in a scheme that bilked eight prominent international financial institutions out of more than $350 million for more than two years.

title: Census Plan For 2000 Is Challenged On 2 Fronts
description: Three months after it introduced revolutionary plans for improving the nation's head count in the year 2000, the Census Bureau is being challenged by minority groups and some Republicans.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Take Driving Class, Pay Less
description: Starting July 3, New Jersey drivers will be able to get a 5 percent reduction or better on their car insurance rates in exchange for taking a defensive driving course approved by the state Department of Motor Vehicles, the Department of Insurance announced yesterday.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Nigerians Protest Death Of Top Dissident's Wife
description: Thousands of university students marched today through a western Nigerian city to protest the fatal shooting of a wife of Moshood K. Abiola, the jailed opposition leader.

title: BASKETBALL;L.I.U. Looks At Parker
description: Richie Parker's time as a basketball outcast may be nearing an end. Long Island University has offered the controversial player a basketball scholarship, two people with knowledge of the situation said yesterday.

title: China, on Eve of Trade Talks, Holds American as Smuggler
description: In a case that American diplomats say they believe is intended to send a political message to the United States, China announced today that authorities in Shanghai had apprehended an American businessman "under strong suspicion" of importing contraband.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Homosexual Rights Bill Clears Canadian Senate
description: The Canadian Senate passed a bill today to ban discrimination against homosexuals in federal agencies and federally regulated companies, clearing the way for the pioneering legislation to become law.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The DUCHESS OF YORK, fresh from her divorce from Prince Andrew, signed a contract yesterday with Simon & Schuster to write a book about her life. "We hope to land it in the bookstores by the week after Thanksgiving," said CAROLYN REIDY, president and publisher of the Simon & Schuster trade division.

title: To Win Russia's 'Generation X,' Yeltsin Is Pumping Up the Volume
description: Generation X" cannot complain that it is being ignored in the Russian presidential election. Young Russian voters are being wooed American-style -- to the sound of heavy metal.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen Reports 14% Rise in Sales
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its sales for the first five months of 1996 had risen about 14 percent, and it forecast a slight increase in sales and revenues for the balance of 1996. The German car maker said its worldwide vehicle sales rose to 1.65 million units in the period from January to May, compared with 1.44 million units in the period a year ago.

title: New Work Stations By Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company has introduced a line of computer work stations and servers aimed at strengthening its position in technical computing. The new machines, priced from $24,000 to more than $110,000, are available in small numbers immediately, with production in volume to begin this summer.

title: Prospects for Senate Testimony by Clinton Accuser Turn Dimmer
description: Democrats on the Senate Whitewater committee today succeeded, at least temporarily, in keeping one of President Clinton's chief accusers from testifying before the committee in coming days.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Luck of 'Lottery Doctor' Ends
description: Harold P. Weingold has a Ph.D. in psychology, but a Superior Court judge in Essex County had doubts about his credentials as a self-proclaimed "lottery doctor." Dr. Weingold was ordered to pay $500,000 to more than 2,000 people who sent him money in the hope that he could cure their bad luck, the state Division of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: Co-Author of Macintosh Program Quits Apple
description: The software engineer who was co-author of the program that gave Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh its distinctive look and feel, and who represented the current company's most direct link to its early innovative tradition, has left the company.

title: THE POP LIFE;Lollapalooza? No Thanks, Towns Say
description: Nobody seems to want Lollapalooza, the alternative-rock package tour that helped put such bands as Rage Against the Machine and Nine Inch Nails on the pop-music map. Since it announced its lineup (which features such loud guitar bands as Metallica, Soundgarden, the Ramones and Rancid) and began looking for fields to tour through, Lollapalooza has been confronted by city councils, community boards and police departments trying to keep the festival out of their towns and has been abandoned by some alternative-rock fans turned off by the show's heavy-metal headliner.

title: Good Call on Credit Cards
description: In a ruling involving billions of dollars, a unanimous Supreme Court this week upheld the right of national banks to charge late fees on overdue credit-card accounts -- in addition to charging interest -- even if a card-holder lives in a state that prohibits such fees. This was a clear victory for banks with interstate credit-card operations. But the outcome also stands to benefit consumers.

title: Sex Gap in Substance Abuse Is Closing
description: Women who abuse drugs and alcohol often escape notice and treatment because there is little understanding about women's motivations and recovery needs, a report said today.

title: A French Fort, Long Lost, Is Found in South Carolina
description: In an attempt to establish a refuge for Huguenots fleeing religious persecution and to challenge Spanish power in what is now the Southeastern United States, France in 1562 dispatched an expedition of two ships and 150 men under Jean Ribaut. On the coast of present-day South Carolina, Ribaut decided to build a fort overlooking a harbor he called "one of the greatest and fayrest havens in the world."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Flights to Atlanta
description: To fly to Atlanta, many New Jersey residents must first drive an hour or more to airports in Newark or Philadelphia. Today, Eastwind Airlines, which operates the only passenger jet service in central New Jersey, will begin offering flights to Atlanta from Mercer County Airport, near Trenton. Eastwind also flies to Boston; Providence, R.I.; Greensboro, N.C., and Richmond, and will resume service to Palm Beach and Jacksonville, Fla., in the fall, said James McNally Jr., the airline's president.

title: Economic Scene;A new rating of economies holds some surprises.
description: INDIVIDUALS compete. Corporations compete. But do whole economies compete? Writing in Foreign Affairs magazine two years ago, Paul Krugman of Stanford University labeled the idea "a dangerous obsession" used to rationalize government intervention on behalf of special interests and, more specifically, to justify trade protectionism.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Brian Ribbey was named to the new position of senior vice president and integrated marketing group di rector at Cole & Webber in Seattle, a unit of the WPP Group. He was pre viously general manager for the Mednick Group, Los Angeles.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Teamsters Theft Alleged
description: A father and son were indicted yesterday on charges of embezzling more than $600,000 from two International Brotherhood of Teamsters locals in Bergen County. Albert Sainato Sr. of Seaside Park and Albert Sainato Jr. of Fort Lee, who held several posts in teamsters locals 1518 in Leonia and 462 in Paramus, are accused of creating phantom jobs for themselves and relatives and fraudulently obtaining more than $51,000 in medical benefits between 1989 and 1993, said V. Grady O'Malley, an assistant United States attorney.

title: Essay;Jail to the Chief?
description: We now know that the Clintons benefited from a criminal conspiracy to steer taxpayers' money illegally into their Whitewater venture.

title: Conrail Increases Its Offer To Buy Rights to Routes
description: Conrail Inc. increased its offer today to buy the rights to some key routes from the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation and Union Pacific Corporation, in the event that their proposed merger goes through.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Chavez Says He's Fit
description: He may be 33 years old, in his 100th fight and dancing around in 100-degree weather when he faces OSCAR DE LA HOYA tomorrow night, but JULIO CESAR CHAVEZ yesterday pronounced himself as being in "my best shape since I fought Rosario."

title: 2 Marines Admit to Killing
description: Two marines were arrested on Tuesday after confessing to the killing of a fellow marine, the police said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Forest Preservation Gains
description: A House subcommittee voted yesterday to make preserving the 17,000-acre Sterling Forest a top priority. The move clears the way for a vote next week by the full Appropriations Committee to appropriate $17.5 million towards the purchase of the forest, which is in a watershed that supplies drinking water for 3 million New Jerseyans.

title: James B. Lewis, 84, Tax Lawyer, Professor and Founder of Clinic
description: James B. Lewis, a prominent tax lawyer, author and teacher, died of liver failure on May 25 at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Father as Drum Major For His Son's America
description: MESSAGES FROM MY FATHER By Calvin Trillin Illustrated. 117 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.

title: Urban Memo;A Sense of Sanctuary At the Heart of Horror
description: New Yorkers view Central Park with a stunning inconsistency. They will tell you it is full of risk, but they treat it like their cathedral. And when crimes like Tuesday's savage beating of a woman occur within the sacred glade, they respond with the shock and horror of those whose sanctuary has been despoiled.

title: Study Hints Mental, Not Physical Stress, Is Bigger Heart Problem
description: Reactions to mental stress may be a much better indicator of who will suffer heart problems than reactions to physical stress, like running on a treadmill, a new study suggests.

title: A Tax Cut We Can't Afford
description: This is the wrong time for a giant income tax cut. The economy is sound, inflation and interest rates are subdued and the budget deficits are sharply lower. But they were brought down through a bloody political war of attrition. A sweeping cut would throw away this progress and bring back the era of soaring deficits.

title: AIDS Prevention Is Too Valuable to Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Tuesday about the Bang on a Can Marathon at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday misstated the number of composers in the marathon who are in Steve Reich's age group. In addition to Frederic Rzewski, others of his generation whose works were played are Alvin Curran and Daniel Goode.

title: French Olympic Team Dives Into a Whirlpool With Holocaust Theme
description: France's synchronized swimming team had its Olympic program worked out: in black bathing suits, team members would goose-step in German military style to the side of the pool.

title: Energy Dept.'s Travel Money Badly Managed, Report Says
description: The Energy Department has spent $4.57 million on 16 foreign trips by the Secretary of Energy, including hundreds of thousands of dollars spent in questionable ways or simply wasted, according to a draft report by the department's Inspector General that was released today.

title: Leary, in Glamorizing Drug Use, Left a Legacy of Tragedy;Our Foibles Exposed
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Rises Despite Remarks Made by Ex-Chairman of Fed
description: The dollar ended slightly higher against most leading currencies yesterday, despite a suggestion from a former chairman of the Federal Reserve that the United States and Japan might curb the dollar's rise against the yen.

title: Stabilizing Lefrak City;Jewish and Muslim Immigrants Help Revive Troubled Complex
description: Back in Guinea, Mohammed Bolde had heard from those who journeyed to America of a place called Lefrak City. The promised land was dotted with hardships, but in Lefrak City the fellowship of Africans made them easier to endure.

title: Bridge
description: The winners of the 1996 Reisinger Team Championship, in a final on Sunday at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, were Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., Michael Kamil of Teaneck, N.J., Steve Becker of Old Greenwich, Conn., Richard De Martino of Riverside, Conn., Bruce Rogoff of Ridgewood, N.J., and Josh Parker of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. They won by 19 imps over Bob Blanchard, Jim Krekorian, John Rengstorff and Bjorn Fallenius, all of Manhattan; Bob Jones of Auburndale, Queens, and Bill Pollack of Warren, N.J.

title: Whose Life Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Capriati Finds Trouble At a Club in Tampa
description: Five days after getting eliminated from the French Open, JENNIFER CAPRIATI faces battery charges for an incident on Sunday night at a club in Tampa, Fla.

title: In Malawi, Pilgrims Throng to an AIDS Potion
description: It is midday at Billy Chisupe's compound, five rutted miles off the last paved road, deep in the hot countryside of cow dung huts, cotton, maize and sunflower fields.

title: Shifting Tactics, F.B.I. Puts Pressure on Montana Ranch
description: After more than two months of futile efforts to coax a group of Montana ranch dwellers into a peaceful surrender, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun taking what could become a series of increasingly aggressive steps to try to bring the Freemen back to the bargaining table, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Cuba Policy Faulted

title: For Wine, 5000 B.C. Was Quite a Year
description: Oenophiles might toast it as the first step toward civilization.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WHIRLPOOL EXPECTS STRONG LIRA TO HURT RESULTS
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said yesterday that the continued strength of the Italian lira against other European currencies would help push the operating results at its European unit lower than year-ago results. The appliance maker based in Benton Harbor, Mich., said that the strengthening of the lira has been more persistent than expected and said that if present exchange rates continued, operating profits in Europe this year could be about $50 million below planned levels. A company spokesman did not disclose what expectations had been for the company's European unit. Last year, Whirlpool's European sales totaled about $2.4 billion, or nearly 30 percent of the company's total sales of $8.3 billion. Whirlpool's stock fell $1, to $55.25.

title: POLITICS: THE HOUSE;In a Volatile District, a Battle for the Center
description: Here in the middle of small-town America, sudden moves and loud styles tend to raise eyebrows. And that seems to go for politics, too.

title: Israelis Place Hope Above Fear of Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: NBC to Get Subsidy Package To Expand a Cable Network
description: NBC and Microsoft announced yesterday that their new 24-hour cable news network, MSNBC, will move down the road from Fort Lee, N.J., to expanded headquarters in Secaucus in November, taking advantage of a hefty package of financial incentives offered by the state.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Three-Quarter Monte: As Usual, Bulls Win in End
description: Neither Michael Jordan nor Scottie Pippen ignited the fourth-quarter rally that propelled the Chicago Bulls to victory. Instead, it was Toni Kukoc who took over.

title: State Panel to Announce Riverfront Plan
description: Breaking a stubborn bureaucratic logjam, state officials are to release a long-awaited plan today for construction of a five-mile-long park on the West Side of Manhattan, and will recommend to the Governor that the state help pay for it.

title: Bahrain Coup Suspects Say They Trained in Iran
description: Bahrainis arrested in connection with a reported plot to overthrow Bahrain's Government said in televised confessions today that they received military training in Iran and Lebanon.

title: Israeli Soldier Kills Gaza Palestinian
description: An Israeli soldier shot and killed a Palestinian who ran toward an Israeli Army outpost in the Gaza Strip today, a military spokeswoman said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;4 Doors and Air, but No Heat
description: Though the Honda Motor Company's new City subcompact is priced to fit the pocketbooks of Asia's emerging middle class, is designed to withstand the pounding of Asia's muddy roads and is being assembled in Thailand, the company refuses to call it an "Asia car." Engineers who utter the forbidden words have to contribute money to the office coffee pool.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hambros' Pretax Profit Is Off 44% for Year
description: Hambros P.L.C., a British investment bank, said yesterday that its pretax profit for the year that ended on March 31 fell 44 percent amid a reorganization of its investment businesses. Hambros said pretax profit declined to L20.6 million ($30.9 million) last year, from L37.1 million the previous year.

title: Modular Regains Favor
description: IT'S about time someone thought of this, isn't it?" said Deborah Klein, pulling apart a modular sofa. Ms. Klein, the design director for Old Hickory Tannery in Hickory, N.C., a supplier to ABC Carpet and Home, was showing off an idea whose time has come again.

title: For 'Maniacs' Who Skate, New Curbs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council may disagree on how to spend $32.7 billion, how to run the city's public hospitals or how to reform welfare. But they did come to one final agreement yesterday: how to regulate Rollerbladers.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Bosnia Killings and the U.N.
description: Tonight "Rights and Wrongs" carries the first half of an hourlong charge against United Nations officials for failing to act to prevent a massacre of Bosnian Muslims by Serbs in the declared United Nations "safe haven" of Srebrenica last year.

title: Disney Plans To Open Store In Harlem
description: The Disney Company, lending its clout and world-famous name to a plan for an entertainment and retail project in the heart of Harlem, said yesterday that it would open a store in the long-delayed Harlem USA complex.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Landslides in China Kill At Least 66; 162 Missing
description: Heavy rain loosened rocks on a mountainside above a gold mine in southwestern China, triggering landslides that killed at least 66 people, the state-run New China News Agency said today. Another 162 people are missing.

title: Sculley Brothers Form an Investment Firm
description: John Sculley, the former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., will form an investment firm with his two brothers.

title: Leary, in Glamorizing Drug Use, Left a Legacy of Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Auschwitz Work Halted
description: Two days after resuming work on a mini-mall opposite the former Nazi death camp at Auschwitz, the developer suspended work again today.

title: Bogota Journal;Colombians Flee the Clutches of the Antichrist
description: The Church of the 20th of July is normally a haven where the faithful gather beneath soaring arches to ponder God and pray. But this week the church echoes with the wails of babies and the exhortations of an exasperated priest as parents rush to baptize their children before Thursday.

title: Cities of Despair
description: There is a dictatorship in Nigeria, powerful fundamentalist parties in Turkey and India, and religious violence in Algeria, Egypt and the Gaza Strip. One of the main reasons for this turmoil is overcrowded and polluted cities, where electricity, sanitation, water and other services are collapsing, even as peasants from the countryside continue to swarm in.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES SELLING DEBT TO PAY FOR DEALS
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it would sell $3 billion in debt in the third quarter to pay for three acquisitions announced since May. On Tuesday, the company said it would buy the British bottling operations owned by the Coca-Cola Company and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. for $1.85 billion in cash and assumed debt. It also bought Coke's French and Belgian bottlers for $915 million and two bottlers in the northwestern United States for $158 million. Coca-Cola Enterprises may consider a combination of bank and public debt, a spokeswoman, Margaret Carton, said. "It's something we will analyze over the next few months," she said. Coca-Cola owns 44 percent of Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is the world's largest bottler of that company's soft drinks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO MAKE KIRIN BEER IN THE UNITED STATES
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies plans to make and sell the Kirin Brewery Company's Japanese beers in the United States. Anheuser-Busch plans to start making Kirin's Lager, Ichiban Shibori and Kirin Light at its Los Angeles factory in March. The companies plan to form a joint venture to sell the beer, financed with $9 million from Kirin and $1 million from Anheuser-Busch, based in St. Louis. Kirin's shares fell $5, to $121.50, and Anheuser-Busch shares were down 25 cents, at $73.75.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Make An Offer To Calipari
description: The Nets have offered UMass's John Calipari a five-year deal worth $15 million to become their head coach, two people close to the negotiations said last night.

title: GLOOMY FORECAST TOUCHES OFF FEUD ON MEDICARE FUND
description: An official Government report today confirmed that the Medicare system was running out of money faster than ever, setting off a new round of political backbiting.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Japanese Maples

title: A Frantic Search for Help
description: Iris Fass was out for her usual dog walk along a secluded Central Park footpath when she turned a corner and saw it: the bleeding, unconscious body of a woman. No one else was around. "I asked her if she was O.K., and she wasn't," Ms. Fass said. "She just didn't answer."

title: Inquiry Starts In Camby Case
description: The State's Attorney covering Hartford said today that he would begin a criminal investigation into whether a lawyer used extortion in an attempt to become the agent for Marcus Camby, college basketball's player of the year.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;Good Neighbors Make Good Fences
description: SEARCHING for the spirit of America? Light up the grill. Look at the fence.

title: Pataki and Lawmakers Agree on Plan for Testing Newborns for AIDS Virus
description: Ending a protracted stalemate, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders today agreed on legislation under which state health officials would for the first time tell all parents the results of H.I.V. tests performed on their newborns.

title: Israelis Place Hope Above Fear of Danger;Begin's First Move
description: To the Editor: "Peace How?" (Week in Review, June 2) does a disservice to former Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel when it says, "Mr. Begin didn't make the first move; Anwar el-Sadat did." Mr. Begin did indeed make the first peace move; Israeli intelligence uncovered a plot to assassinate the Egyptian, and Mr. Begin informed Mr. Sadat, thus saving his life.

title: Egypt and Jordan Urge Israel to Honor Pact
description: The leaders of Jordan and Egypt joined Yasir Arafat today in urging the new Israeli Government to honor commitments to the Palestinians and to recognize that ultimately there is no alternative to a Palestinian state.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAXTER TO CALL SPINOFF ALLEGIANCE HEALTHCARE
description: Baxter International Inc. said yesterday that it would call its health care products and cost-management services business, which it plans to spin off later this year, the Allegiance Healthcare Corporation. In November, Baxter announced plans to split into two publicly traded companies, separating the medical supply and services business from its medical technology group. The medical technology business, which makes drugs and devices to treat hemophilia, kidney and heart disease, plans to retain the name Baxter. The Allegiance unit had sales of $4.5 billion in 1995 and employs about 20,000 people worldwide.

title: POLITICS: POLITICAL BRIEFING;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Iowa An Outsider, Yes, But Not an Unknown

title: Park on West Side Takes Big Step Ahead
description: Breaking a stubborn bureaucratic logjam, state officials are to release a long-awaited plan today for construction of a five-mile-long park on the West Side of Manhattan, and will recommend to the Governor that the state help pay for it.

title: A Real Estate Merger
description: Two Buffalo-area companies have merged to form the largest independent real estate company in New York state. Stovroff & Herman Realtors Inc. and H. Potter Realtors Inc. announced Tuesday that they had joined forces to create a company with combined 1995 sales of $782.3 million and more than 900 sales agents. The new company is called Stovroff & Potter Real Estate Inc. and will cover Erie and Niagara Counties, which have a combined population of about 1.2 million. The merger creates the 35th-largest real estate company in the nation. Its headquarters will be here in Amherst, a suburb of Buffalo.

title: Data on Travel Office Head Sought After His Ouster, Letter Shows
description: Seven months after it dismissed its travel office staff, the White House sought information about the director of the office from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to a 1993 letter made public today.

title: BASEBALL;Baseball's Leaders Put Schott on Notice
description: Marge Schott, the embattled owner of the Cincinnati Reds, today escaped a second suspension in three years for making racial and ethnic slurs, but the reprieve from fellow owners may last only one more week.

title: McDonnell Douglas Is Working Despite Strike
description: On the first day of a machinists' strike against McDonnell Douglas Corporation here, the company reassigned 1,500 engineers and white collar workers to assemble aircraft.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Rise Ahead Of Jobs Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities turned higher in light trading yesterday, getting a lift from falling commodities prices.

title: What Men Won't Discuss: Their Health
description: MIDDLE age is a time when a man's body becomes vulnerable -- to prostate cancer, heart disease, hypertension, weight gain, impotence and depression.

title: G.M. Names An Executive For Saab Unit
description: In a further sign of its eagerness to capitalize on the lessons learned at its Saturn division, the General Motors Corporation is set to appoint another Saturn executive to a ranking position.

title: HOUSE PROUD;60-Room White Elephant Trumpets Again
description: ADVERTISEMENTS for fixer-uppers beckon with primordial force: an abandoned house, a low price tag, the promise of getting something great for nothing much.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A report on May 19 about the wedding of Mary Carter Belknap and Michael George McKee omitted the first name of the bride's father. He is Robert Ernest Belknap 3d.

title: Crude Oil Prices Drop Sharply As Inventories Show Big Jump
description: Crude oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report showed a surge in American refinery inventories and there was speculation that Iraq would seek to increase the amount of oil it can sell under a recent agreement with the United Nations.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;AEG of Germany Approves Daimler Move
description: Shareholders of AEG of Germany voted yesterday to end the company's existence, accepting a proposal by Daimler-Benz A.G. to absorb the remains of the 113-year-old industrial company, despite protests from some small shareholders.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mixed Data Spur Some Hope in Germany
description: Germany's gross domestic product fell by half a percentage point in the first quarter of 1996, its worst performance in three years, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Lose, But They Do Show 'Belly'
description: There have been plenty of ugly losses during the Mets' young season. Too many times they have blundered through nine innings before flopping over like dead fish. This was not one of those nights, even though the outcome was another defeat.

title: Bosnian Serbs Are Threatened in Sarajevo
description: Undermining the vision of a multi-ethnic Sarajevo espoused by the Bosnian Government, some of the remaining Bosnian Serbs in Sarajevo's suburbs are being threatened, beaten or expelled from their homes by groups of Muslims the police say they cannot control.

title: Legislators Agree to Strengthen Law on Suspended Physicians
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and senior legislators from both parties announced today that they had agreed on a bill that would bar doctors whose licenses had been suspended or revoked for incompetence or serious misconduct from practicing medicine while they appealed their punishment.

title: POLITICS: THE SENATE;Maine Candidate Again Faces 1990 Child-Sex Accusation
description: A Maine Republican seeking a seat in the United States Senate who has cast himself as a champion of family values, became a center of controversy today after New England newspapers published six-year-old accusations that he had had sex with his children's 12-year-old baby sitter.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Banks to Rescue German Engineering Group
description: The German engineering group Klockner Humboldt Deutz A.G. said today that it would undergo a major restructuring, including a 1.06 billion mark bank bailout -- the equivalent of $692 million -- a week after uncovering losses that had threatened to bankrupt it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ralston Purina Wins Grand Effie
description: The Ralston Purina Company in St. Louis won the top prize last night at the 28th Annual Effie Awards, given by the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association in recognition of effectiveness in advertising.

title: Calendar: Artisans, Exhibitions And Tours
description: Gifts From an Architect Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street; (212) 708-9400.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CALVIN KLEIN SUES PRICE COSTCO OVER JEANS SALES
description: The Calvin Klein Inc. jeanswear company said yesterday that it had sued Price Costco Inc., contending that the warehouse retailer has been selling counterfeit goods under the Calvin Klein trademark. Calvin Klein said that a private investigation had found that Price Costco was selling bogus goods, as well as flawed and damaged goods, as Calvin Klein Jeans. Calvin Klein, of New York, has asked the court to prohibit Price Costco, based in Issaquah, Wash., from selling any Calvin Klein trademarked jeans and jeans-related items.

title: Elders at Home, Out of the Fray
description: The Clintons have never called Dr. Joycelyn Elders since she was more or less run out of Washington on a political rail. But the former Surgeon General could not sound less resentful as she soothes the children on her pediatric rounds and takes pride in the very candor that drove her from power.

title: OLYMPICS;Hartwell Back in the Money for Cycling
description: For six straight years, Erin Hartwell of Colorado Springs won the national championship in one of bicycle racing's classic races, the men's one-kilometer time trial over a velodrome track. But last August, beset by health problems and stress, he finished second to Sky Christopherson, then a 19-year-old Wunderkind.

title: Senate Foes Waste No Time Lashing Out at Each Other
description: Energized by primary night celebrations, the two New Jersey candidates for the United States Senate used the first day of their general election campaigns to outline the themes they will debate between now and November, when one of them will be chosen to replace the outgoing Senator Bill Bradley.

title: County Says Sale of Bonds Is Successful
description: In a deal that will lift it from bankruptcy, Orange County, Calif., sold nearly $900 million in bonds yesterday to a forgiving market -- but at a price.

title: The Market for Young Directors Has Warmed Up
description: For years film directors have been caught up in an elaborate caste system. There was an A list of a dozen or so film makers who were pampered by studios and sought by movie stars and who demanded millions of dollars for their services. There was a B list, a much bigger group whose work was often uneven but who could be counted on to bring a film in on time and on budget. And there was a C list of relatively inexperienced and often young directors who made riskier films on credit cards.

title: William Dwight, 92, Publisher Who Pushed for China Coverage
description: William Dwight, who as president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association helped clear the way for American reporters to gather news in Communist China, died at the Bishop Gadsden Nursing Center in Charleston on Tuesday. He was 92.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Arrested in Cocaine Case
description: Officials investigating a Colombian narcotics case in New York and New Jersey seized 1,100 pounds of cocaine, $200,000 and five vehicles, Assistant Chief Patrick Hartnett of the New York City Police Department's Narcotics Division said yesterday. At least two people were arrested. The authorities in northern New Jersey and New York scheduled a news conference for today to announce details.

title: Sports of The Times;Sonics Notice There's More Than 'Air'
description: THE team that won 64 regular-season games looked like everything it was forecast to be, a footnote to history. The team that won 72 looked like everything it won't be remembered for, a well-balanced machine.

title: Hilton Is Said To Be Near Deal for Bally
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation is close to an agreement to acquire the Bally Entertainment Corporation in a stock-swap deal that would value Bally at $28 a share, according to a person familiar with the talks.

title: Amos Tversky, Expert on Decision Making, Is Dead at 59
description: Dr. Amos Tversky, a cognitive psychologist who changed the way experts in many fields think about how people make decisions about risks, benefits and probabilities, died on Sunday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 59.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bears and People Clash
description: The state's black bear population has quadrupled over the last decade to about 400, and these days, bears and people seem to be coming into contact more often as suburbia encroaches into the animals' habitat. The Senate Natural Resources and Economic Development Committee today will consider whether action is needed to try to reduce the frequency of these encounters. Bear hunting was permitted until the early 1970's, but there are no plans to bring back a hunting season, State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., Republican of Middletown and the chairman of the committee, said yesterday.

title: Memory Chip Prices Revive, But the Increases Might Not Last
description: Prices for memory chips have rebounded slightly after Korean and Japanese semiconductor manufacturers said they would cut back production. But industry analysts say they do not expect the price gains to last, and they do not believe the production cuts are deep enough to create a sustained firming of prices.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Olympics, Up Close and Promotional
description: The Summer Olympics in Atlanta and NBC's coverage are still more than a month away, but something of an Olympics onslaught is already under way. The television field is quickly becoming cluttered with stirring tales of triumph and misty remembrances of memorable moments. Let the merchandising begin. Wrap those moments of glory in sales pitches. Turn that energy into synergy.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Despite Dip, Volvo Expects Rise in Sales
description: Volvo A.B., a Swedish luxury car maker, said car sales fell 1 percent in the first five months of this year, to 170,491 cars, compared with the corresponding period last year. Nevertheless, Volvo expects sales for the full year to rise 2 percent, to 382,000 cars.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Bluesy And Casual On Piano And Sax
description: The pianist Junior Mance and the saxophonist Joe Temperley led a trio through standards, blues pieces and Thelonious Monk compositions at Zinno on Monday night. The two, joined by the bassist Calvin Hill, were having fun, playing casual, conversational improvisation, the sort musicians engage in after hours or at home.

title: New Tool in Political Combat: Computers to Track TV Ads
description: Is Senator Bob Dole buying television time in California, where President Clinton leads in the polls? Is Mr. Clinton spending money in Florida, a state he lost in 1992? Is each spending just enough to force his opponent to burn up resources by responding?

title: TALKS COLLAPSE ON STATE BUDGET
description: Negotiations on the state budget collapsed in disarray and acrimony today, virtually guaranteeing that this year's budget would be the latest on record.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NABISCO HOLDINGS CORP., Parsippany, N.J., the maker of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, plans to raise its quarterly dividend by 12.7 percent to 15.5 cents a share, payable on July 1 to shareholders of record on June 14.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Big Drug MakerPlans Asset Sale
description: The French chemical and drug company Rhone-Poulenc plans an imminent sale of some of its pharmaceutical assets, the company confirmed today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURLINGTON TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 1,100 JOBS
description: The textile producer Burlington Industries announced yesterday that it would close two plants and cut 1,100 jobs as it works to eliminate its money-losing knitted fabrics division. The plants are in Denton and Wake Forest, N.C., and are expected to close by the end of summer. Burlington tried two years ago to retool the division, which produces cotton and cotton-blend fabric for golf shirts, turtlenecks and other items. Burlington expects to take a charge of $20 million to $23 million against its 1996 results. Burlington reported earnings of $68.4 million on sales of $2.2 billion for the year that ended Sept. 30. Burlington's stock rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $13.625.

title: HOCKEY;Smith Sees Style Shifts In Store For Rangers
description: If Neil Smith continues as president and general manager of the Rangers, there could be major changes in the philosophy of the front office and the playing style on the ice.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Give Queiroz 1-1 Draw Against Former Team
description: Carlos Queiroz could hardly have imagined that three months after he was dismissed as head coach by Sporting Lisbon he would be coaching against his former team in New Jersey.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JANET FISHER, the widow of the philanthropist Avery Fisher, was strolling on the Upper East Side the other day, taking flowers to a friend, when suddenly a car pulled up. Out jumped two women with cameras who asked to take her picture.

title: Welfare Recipients Can Help Break Stereotype
description: To the Editor:

title: Aid Plan That Inspired Clinton Is a Success
description: In proposing a $1,500 tax credit for college tuition on Tuesday, President Clinton cited as his inspiration an ambitious Georgia scholarship program that is so popular many political analysts view it as the reason Gov. Zell Miller won a second term.

title: Arrest in Rape Attempt in L.I. Park After Cyclist Foils Attack
description: Bridget Scarpinato was bicycling through the Massapequa Preserve on Tuesday when she saw something suspicious. A man whom she had seen on a bicycle only a short time earlier was now on foot, running closely behind a young woman jogger.

title: TV Host Urges Inspections
description: Kathie Lee Gifford joined hands with her critics yesterday and urged Wal-Mart, the company that sells her sportswear line, to allow independent monitors to inspect the factories making Wal-Mart apparel to make sure they are not sweatshops.

title: Shubert Leaders Got Fees From Workers' Funds
description: Over more than two decades, Broadway's biggest employers, Gerald Schoenfeld and Bernard B. Jacobs of the Shubert Organization, have received hundreds of thousands of dollars as paid advisers to the benefit funds of their own workers.

title: OPEC Dealing With Threat Of an Oil Glut Linked to Iraq
description: Iraq loomed large today as the beleaguered Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met to consider how it will accommodate the increase in oil production now that a six-year ban by the United Nations on Iraqi oil exports has been lifted.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: Debt American Stores Co., Salt Lake City, is selling $350 million of bonds due in 2026 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The bonds are priced at 99.262 to yield 8.066 percent. The issue is rated Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's

title: Peru to Send Red Army Guerrilla Suspect to Japan
description: Peru announced today that it would deport a suspected Japanese Red Army guerrilla, Kazue Yoshimura, whose capture here ended an international hunt for her spanning more than two decades.

title: I.B.M. Personnel Software
description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce on Monday computer programs to help big companies keep track of human resources information, posing a threat to niche companies like Peoplesoft Inc.

title: Indian Leader Is Promising A Broad List Of Reforms
description: The new coalition Government set an ambitious course today, promising to reserve a third of all seats in Parliament and a third of all Government jobs for women, review all laws to remove discrimination against women and eliminate within 10 years the illiteracy and poverty that afflict about 60 percent of India's 930 million people.

title: No Headline
description: No longer will France in the New World be epitomized only by Quebec and New Orleans."

title: Mystery Fuels Fears in Attack In Central Park
description: The police struggled in vain yesterday to identify the woman who was beaten nearly to death in Central Park on Tuesday, and the mystery surrounding the attack stirred the worst fears of some New Yorkers, who could not locate their wives, daughters, girlfriends or neighbors.

title: Europe Eases Its Beef Ban But Rebukes British Policy
description: The European Union agreed today to slightly ease its ban on British beef exports by allowing Britain to sell bull semen and beef-derived tallow and gelatin. But it strongly rebuked Britain for its defiant decision not to cooperate with the alliance, of which it is a member, until the broader ban is lifted.

title: TENNIS;Rosset Earns Honors in Survival Arts
description: He got advice from the Slam sage Stefan Edberg before his first-ever Grand Slam quarterfinal. He gave his racquet away to Jean-Paul Belmondo at courtside right after making a dramatic comeback that vaulted him into the French Open semifinals. And during the match he used Pete Sampras's quarterfinal revival from a two-set abyss yesterday to inspire him to a similar escape today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the film actor Lash LaRue misstated his given name. It was Alfred, not Albert.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF LAM RESEARCH FALL ON EARNINGS REPORT
description: The shares of the Lam Research Corporation fell yesterday after the company said its fourth-quarter earnings would be about 5 percent lower than previous expectations because of slower sales to computer-chip makers. Shares of Lam Research, which makes equipment used in production of computer chips, fell $3.25, to $34, as almost 3.3 million shares changed hands. Based on current sales, Lam Research's earnings for the fourth quarter will be less than the $1.34 a share that Wall Street analysts were expecting. Lam Research, based in Fremont, Calif., is now expected to report about $1.27 a share for the quarter ending June 30.

title: Urbanites, Too, Remembered War Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a $175 million acquisition involving two restaurant companies -- Buffets Inc. and Hometown Buffet Inc. -- misidentified the buyer and the seller. Buffets Inc. is acquiring Hometown Buffet Inc.

title: ON HOCKEY;Avalanche's Roy Paves Way To Carry Out His Big Plans
description: Hockey players sometimes hear ringing in their ears, especially after Claude Lemieux checks them from behind. But they do not usually wear earrings. That sort of jewelry appears more often on athletes in baseball, football and basketball.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Panthers Are Peeved About Enforcement of Rule
description: The Florida Panthers, who have been complaining about a lack of respect from fans and the news media around the country, today accused the National Hockey League of giving them one more reason to feel maligned.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday, about criticism of the use of very thin models in the British edition of Vogue, misstated some findings of a study by the Ms. Foundation for Women and Seventeen magazine on teen-agers and their body images. The study found that 5 percent of the young women and 12 percent of the young men surveyed said they judged themselves by how they look; they did not say they judged others on appearance.

title: U.S. Charges Peter Max With Hiding Art-Sale Income in Tax Fraud
description: Peter Max, whose psychedelic Pop Art of the 1960's turned the artist himself into an art-world icon, was charged yesterday with failing to report $1.1 million in art sales to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: 2 Lawyers Carry On Tobacco Suits
description: The national spotlight has dimmed on the well-heeled celebrity consortium of nearly 60 anti-tobacco lawyers who tried to mount the largest class action in American history. And the principal legal nightmare facing the nation's $45 billion tobacco industry faded as well, after a Federal appeals panel in New Orleans dismissed the case in May.

title: Metro Matters;Lieutenant Who Plays Game Badly
description: TO begin, some perspective from Emily Dickinson, circa 1875:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Orange County Bonds Sold With a Premium Yield In a deal that will lift it from bankruptcy, Orange County, Calif., sold nearly $900 million in bonds to a forgiving market. The bonds were priced to yield a premium as high as a fifth of a percentage point above prevailing interest rates.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CORNING PLANS TO BUILD ANOTHER FIBER OPTIC PLANT
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would build a second factory in the United States to manufacture the optical fiber used in telecommunications. The plant, which could involve an investment of up to $500 million, is to be built in the southeastern part of the country. Roger G. Ackerman, the chairman of Corning, said the plant was being built in the United States because this country is the largest single market for optical fiber. But about 50 percent of the output is expected to be sold internationally, he said. Corning, which is based in Corning, N.Y., already operates an optical fiber plant in Wilmington, N.C.

title: Currents;Children's Book Artists as Muralists
description: FOUR children's book illustrators are creative partners in one of New York's most colorful day-care centers: a 70-foot mural adorns the new headquarters of Women in Need, at 115 West 31st Street, designed by Jeffrey Murphy. The group provides housing for homeless women and their children. Rita Zimmer, its founder, said, "We have women who want to go back to work and who want to come in to the alcohol- and substance-abuse center for treatment but don't want to put their children in foster care. This center is for them." The mural, by Lisa Desimini, Dan Yaccarino, Sara Schwartz and David Ricceri, is destined for a children's book.

title: Man in the News;Low-Key Officer in a High-Stress Job -- Adm. Jay Lynn Johnson
description: Adm. Jay L. Johnson, one of the fastest-rising stars in the Navy, faces the most daunting challenge of his 28-year career in taking command of a service wracked by tragedy and turmoil.

title: Red Cross Suspends Operations in Burundi
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross suspended its work in Burundi today after the killing of three Swiss staff members in an ambush on Tuesday.

title: The Certified Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Guilty Pleas Are Entered In Election Case
description: Joseph Waldholtz, the estranged husband of Representative Enid Greene, pleaded guilty today to providing her with false information about her 1993 taxes and to falsifying Federal election reports.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Riesenberg May Say No
description: DOUG RIESENBERG is still considering the Giants' proposed salary reduction, but it appears that he won't accept it and could be waived as early as today.

title: UNDER THE HOOD WITH: Lucille Treganowan;Life's Miraculous Transmissions
description: YOU step on the gas and turn the key: the car starts. You shift into drive: the car rolls forward.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Market Place;Kmart offers convertible stock, but only the brave need apply.
description: THE Kmart Corporation has been struggling for months to get its retail act together while easing its nettlesome debt obligations. And now it is hoping that investors will make that job even simpler.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Investor Group to Buy 50% of Ducati
description: Cagiva S.p.A., an Italian motorbike maker, will sell a 50 percent stake in its Ducati division to a United States investment fund in a transaction worth 500 billion lire, or $320 million, after deciding not to sell the stake to the United States financier Sam Zell.

title: Navy to Study Outside Jobs
description: Prodded by attention to moonlighting by a new Navy leader, the Pentagon said today that it would re-examine its policy of allowing senior military officers to earn extra income on their own time. The announcement came a day after Adm. Jay L. Johnson, President Clinton's choice to be Chief of Naval Operations, resigned as a $33,000-a-year director of a company that sells insurance to military service members.

title: Real Estate;In Edgewater, N.J., luxury apartment construction is reviving on the Hudson shoreline.
description: By August, work will begin on transforming a patch of the Hudson River shoreline here into a luxury apartment enclave, ending an eight-year dry spell in new residential construction.

title: Former U.S. Senator Picked to Head Northern Ireland Peace Talks
description: Ireland and Britain today appointed former Senator George J. Mitchell, who headed an international commission on disarmament of paramilitary forces in Northern Ireland, to be the chairman of the broad-based peace talks scheduled to start on Monday in Belfast.

title: Bail Is Set for Suspect Held In Officer's Death
description: A Bronx judge set bail yesterday at $10,000 for a man charged in the death of a police officer last month, rejecting a request by prosecutors that the suspect be held without bail.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Citizen Welles: Sledding to His Own Xanadu
description: ROSEBUD The Story of Orson Welles By David Thomson Illustrated. 461 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Delmar Dennis, 56; Gave Key Testimony In '63 Killing Case
description: Delmar Dennis, a former Ku Klux Klansman whose testimony helped convict Byron De La Beckwith in the 1963 slaying of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, died on Saturday at Fort Sanders Sevier Medical Center in Sevierville. He was 56 and lived in Sevierville.

title: Alexander Racolin, Theater Lawyer, 88
description: Alexander E. Racolin, a lawyer and theater producer, died on Thursday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: San Francisco Joins Assault On Tobacco
description: Opening up yet another front in the legal assault on the tobacco industry, San Francisco sued yesterday to recover millions of dollars it spent on health problems attributed to smoking.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PULLMAN TO BE SOLD FOR $266 MILLION
description: The Mayflower Corporation, a British engineering and automotive parts company, said yesterday that it would buy the Pullman Company, a maker of automotive suspensions and other parts, for $266 million in cash. Pullman, a closely held concern in Lebanon, N.J., emerged from bankruptcy in December 1994 and began exploring the sale of its businesses in October 1995. Mayflower will pay about $117 million for shares in Pullman and $149 million to settle some of Pullman's outstanding obligations, including $135 million in bank debt. Pullman, which is best known for the railroad coaches it once made, became a private company in 1988. Its primary business now is the Clevite unit, which makes suspensions. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: From Strangers, Comfort for a Shattered Victim
description: The woman in the ninth-floor intensive care unit has one nurse devoted to her at all times, but that doesn't keep others from drifting into the room so that they can simply hold her hand for a few seconds or give her hair a few strokes with a wide-toothed comb.

title: World News Briefs;Opening Way for Talks, Mexico Frees 2 Zapatistas
description: Two men who were serving jail terms for being Zapatista rebel terrorists were freed today by an appeals court, opening the way for peace talks to resume.

title: Uranium Munitions Return to Haunt Us
description: To the Editor: Re "Japanese Down Navy Plane in an Accident" (front page, June 5): You report that the jet was brought down by an American-made gun, but do not mention that this weapons system, the Phalanx, shoots bullets made of depleted uranium, the highly toxic, radioactive byproduct of the uranium enrichment process.

title: Bosnia Elections Will Promote Dayton Fantasy;War Criminals at Large
description: To the Editor: It has become clear that the West, through the NATO Implementation Force, is losing much of its credibility by failing to apprehend the Bosnian Serb President, Radovan Karadzic, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb leader, both of whom have been indicted on multiple war-crimes counts by the War Crimes Tribunal at The Hague. If these two big fish are not brought to face trial for their direction of the siege of Sarajevo and a host of other atrocities committed under their command, the whole exercise of indicting lower-ranking criminals will become pointless, and public confidence in true justice being served will evaporate.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of France Lowers a Key Rate
description: The Bank of France unexpectedly cut a key interest rate in a move that economists said was an attempt to breathe life into the sluggish economy.
