The central bank, whose monetary policy central council met yesterday, trimmed the floor intervention rate by 10 basis points, to 3.60 percent, defying predictions it would wait until Germany, Europe's largest economy, cut its rate.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of England Cuts Interest Rates
description: The Bank of England unexpectedly cut interest rates yesterday by a quarter of a percentage point to 5.75 percent in a move that the finance minister said was justified by falling inflation. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, whose Government faces a general election within a year and is eager to improve consumer confidence, justified the move by calling it sensible. Banks immediately followed suit. The Midland Bank said it was cutting its base lending rate by a similar amount, to 5.75 percent. (Reuters)

title: Rail Projects, for Airport Link And Freight, Gain Approval
description: Port Authority directors approved two rail projects yesterday, one intended to move people to Newark International Airport and the other to move freight from the sea.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;DOLE SEEKS WORDS TO BROADEN PLANK ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: In what he described as an effort to promote civility, Senator Bob Dole called tonight for a "declaration of tolerance" in the Republican Party platform on abortion and other issues that threaten to split the Republicans at their August convention and in the fall campaign.

title: Virtual Art Opens Hearts to Real Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Approval Recommended For Stroke Drug
description: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously today that a blood-clot dissolving drug, Activase, be approved for use in the treatment of stroke. The drug is expected to revolutionize the treatment of stroke, the third-leading cause of death in the United States and the leading cause of long-term disability.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Sabrina 1995. Paramount. $102.32. Laser disk, $44.98. 127 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: Tuesday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;W. B. Doner Is Chosen For $10 Million Account
description: The Hill Stores Company in Canton, Mass., a regional discount department store chain, named W. B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich., to handle its account, which had been previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $10 million. The decision came after a three-month review whose other participants were not disclosed. Adweek listed the two other contenders as the Richards Group in Dallas, and Suissa Miller Advertising in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Beware! Bug-Eating Worms!
description: Look out, Japanese beetles. Beware, root weevils. The Rutgers nematode is on its way. Researchers at Rutgers University have bred a parasitic worm that attacks the larvae of several destructive soil-dwelling crop and garden pests. And under a licensing agreement with an Italian biotechnology firm signed on Wednesday, the nematode should be on the market within a year.

title: Bronx Factory, Lacking Farberware Label, May Close
description: The 700 workers at the Farberware cookware factory in the South Bronx had been hoping that the plant's new owner would do right by them, but this week they got the news they did not want to hear.

title: Art in Review
description: Daniel Spoerri Zabriskie Gallery 41 East 57th Street Through June 14

title: Progress Seen In Accounting Board Dispute
description: Progress is being made in resolving a fight over the makeup of the body that picks accounting rule makers, Arthur Levitt Jr. , the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RONALD ROBERT MITCHELL JR. did more than graduate when he stepped onto the stage of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Monday to receive his degree from St. Francis College: he also became engaged. The moment was the culmination of four years of study and months of secretive planning.

title: 30-Year Bond Up Sharply For 3d Session
description: Prices of Treasury securities posted strong gains yesterday for the third consecutive session as market participants braced for today's employment report.

title: On My Mind;Keeping on the Ladder
description: This was a story guaranteed to upset anybody who loved New York and understood how much public higher education has done for the commerce and creativity of the city. Poor students struggling up the ladder were being pushed down, or entirely off, by inflexible city officials.

title: Environment Bill's Approval Now Likely After Panel's Vote
description: After months of negotiations, a House subcommittee today unanimously approved legislation on municipal drinking water quality that seems likely to become the first major environmental bill to pass the 104th Congress and be signed into law.

title: Haze and Diplomacy Intrude on U.S. Park
description: Big Bend National Park in Texas is often covered in a haze traced to Mexican power plants, clearly exposing a limitation in the environmental provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIBREBOARD AGREES TO ACQUIRE STONE PRODUCTS
description: The Fibreboard Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire, for about $52 million, Stone Products, a maker of simulated stone for building exteriors, fireplace facings, pavement, retaining-wall surfaces and other products. Stone Products, which is based in Napa, Calif., has a plant in Napa and another in Navarre, Ohio, and other operations in San Bernardino, Calif., and Columbus, Ohio. It had revenue of $34 million last year. Fibreboard, the maker of building products, is based in Walnut Creek, Calif. (AP)

title: 2 Held in a Plot to Kill Black Disney Tourists
description: Two youths identified as members of an all-white gang in Fort Myers, Fla., have been charged with planning to disguise themselves as Disney characters and then kill black visitors to Walt Disney World.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: HORSE RACING;Breeders' Cup Pulls Out of Canada
description: The Breeders' Cup series of seven races with purses of $11 million was withdrawn yesterday from the Woodbine Race Track in Canada because of a continuing labor dispute and was expected to be reassigned to Churchill Downs in Kentucky.

title: Hilton Hotels to Buy Bally Entertainment for More Than $2 Billion
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Bally Entertainment Corporation in an all-stock deal valued at more than $2 billion that would give Hilton a long-sought presence in Atlantic City.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Lockout Possible for N.B.A.
description: As labor problems between the players union and the National Basketball Association continue, Deputy Commissioner Russ Granik did not rule out another lockout this summer.

title: Karpov Holds an Edge As Chess Match Opens
description: Anatoly Karpov showed Gata Kamsky of Brooklyn who was the master and who the disciple yesterday in the first encounter in their world title match. The game is not finished, but Karpov has a decisive advantage and stands to win easily when play resumes today.

title: NYC;At the Wheel Without A License
description: NEW YORKERS may yet thank their stars for the city's horrific traffic jams. At least when nothing moves, the citizenry is protected from the cerebrally challenged who consider it their God-given right to get behind the wheel and roar down the avenue at 70 miles an hour, indifferent to anyone who may get in their way. Sometimes it looks like bumper cars out there.

title: For Children
description: Henry Luce Nature Observatory Belvedere Castle Central Park West 81st Street entrance (212) 772-0210 Recommended for all ages

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Lachey Calls It Quits
description: The three-time Pro Bowl tackle JIM LACHEY announced his retirement yesterday after 11 National Football League seasons. Lachey, who was one of just five Redskins left from Washington's last Super Bowl champion team of 1992, called it quits after injuries limited him to 17 games over the past 3 seasons. The retirement decision was cemented when a torn rotator cuff didn't respond well to increased weight training. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Taking Guns from Abusers
description: A police officer responding to a domestic violence call is now allowed to confiscate a gun if he sees one. Under a new bill approved yesterday by the state Senate Women's Issues, Children and Family Services Committee, the officer would be required to ask if there are any weapons around.

title: Frank H. Kenan, 83, Businessman in Oil
description: Frank H. Kenan, who founded several oil and transportation concerns and became a major benefactor of his alma mater, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, as well as many other American colleges and universities, died at his home in Durham on Tuesday. He was 83.

title: OLYMPICS;Life Begins Anew at 42 On the Road to Atlanta
description: In 1975, when Kent Bostick received his bachelor's degree at Vermont, Mike McCarthy was in first grade and Adam Laurent in nursery school. In 1977 in Seattle, Bostick rode in his first national cycling championships, and, as he recalled, "Everybody had beards and long hair and drove around in Volkswagens."

title: More Reports About Pol Pot Say He Is Seriously Ill or Dead
description: Unconfirmed reports circulated in Cambodia today that the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, was seriously ill and perhaps had died in his jungle hideout near the border of Thailand.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAJORITY STAKE IN FINISHMASTER TO CHANGE HANDS
description: Maxco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 67 percent stake in Finishmaster Inc., a distributor of automotive paint and supplies, to LDI Ltd. for $62.6 million. As part of the deal, Maxco and LDI agreed not to compete with each other for five years. Maxco, a maker of construction materials and tools, is based in Lansing, Mich. LDI, which is based in Indianapolis, has operations in recorded videocassettes; motorcycle, snowmobile and watercraft parts and accessories; mountain bicycles, and wood millwork. (Dow Jones)

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Calipari Leaving Scrutiny Behind to Take Nets Job
description: It might seem as if John Calipari has slipped out the back and avoided the turmoil at the University of Massachusetts, likely closing the door behind him in relief. But this is not an escape hatch.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;DDB Needham Office In Deals for $20 Million
description: The Chicago office of the DDB Needham unit of the Omnicom Group was awarded two accounts, with combined billings estimated at more than $20 million.

title: FILM REVIEW;Break Into Alcatraz? Why Not?
description: DURING a typical Zen interlude in "The Rock," a race through the kitchen of the Fairmont Hotel escalates into an even wilder chase in the San Francisco streets. Commandeering the first car at hand -- it happens to be a yellow Ferrari -- an F.B.I. scientist named Stanley Goodspeed (Nicolas Cage) pursues Patrick Mason (Sean Connery), the world's most attractive escaped convict. Only in a classic Simpson-Bruckheimer joyride is it possible to spend 30 years in Alcatraz and come out looking this Malibu.

title: TENNIS;Paris Review: Graf and Sanchez Vicario Reach a Showdown
description: Maybe they will close their eyes and play it from memory. Steffi Graf and Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, last year's French Open finalists and veterans of 34 tugs-of-war against each other, asserted their dominance today with straight-set semifinal victories.

title: Maastricht Journal;Dutch Want Back the Fossil Napoleon Took Away
description: The full story of this quarrel begins in the age of dinosaurs when a giant reptile lost its head. When the head was found in a local quarry more than two centuries ago, it caused a sensation. No one had ever seen the likes of it, a fossil with wicked rows of teeth set in jaws more than three feet long.

title: In Israel, Bargaining for a Cabinet Begins
description: A week after his victory in the Israeli election, Benjamin Netanyahu is finding his American-style campaign increasingly supplanted by Middle Eastern haggling over the political spoils.

title: Sports of the Times;Now Calipari Puts His Ego In the Swamp
description: THE man was always dressed snazzily, as if for a job interview, so John Calipari's imminent departure is not exactly a surprise to the University of Massachusetts. The school even turned his status as a hot young coach into surprisingly prescient copy in the team press guide last season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Repsol Buying Stake In Argentine Company
description: Repsol S.A., a Spanish oil company, agreed yesterday to buy a 37.7 percent stake in Astra Capsa, one of Argentina's leading oil companies, for $360 million. The company will pay $3.11 a share for each of the 115.8 million shares, an Astra official said. In April, Astra said the families holding a controlling stake in the company had hired J. P. Morgan & Company to analyze offers for their holdings. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Kermit Axel, 75, Wine and Spirits Importer
description: Kermit Axel, a former principal of 21 Brands, a wine and spirits importing company, died yesterday in New York. He was 75.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: No Headline
description: This money does not in fact exist. This money is not backed by anything."

title: Mr. Pataki's Big Cleanup Plans
description: In a surprise move that floored some of his political opponents and delighted most environmental groups, Gov. George Pataki yesterday proposed a $1.5 billion environmental bond act for clean air and water projects.

title: Deal Comes as Atlantic City Is on a Roll
description: With its deal to acquire Bally Entertainment, Hilton Hotels is buying a place at the table in Atlantic City, the East Coast's largest gambling center, just as the Boardwalk rolls toward a major expansion of its ambitions.

title: Restaurants
description: Aah," croons the crowd downstairs at Sullivan's Restaurant and Broadcast Lounge. "Ooh," they cry again a moment later. Some of us seated in the glamorous upstairs space rush to the grand staircase, certain a celebrity has been sighted. We peer into the two-story mirror over the bar craning to see what has caused the commotion. Then we look sheepishly at one another, shrug with embarrassment and return to our booths.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Place Found for Harbor Silt
description: The United States Army Corps of Engineers has approved a plan to put some of the contaminated silt that is clogging the shipping lanes of Port Newark underneath a shopping mall in Elizabeth, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday.

title: ART REVIEW;An African Anthology Of Rewarding Objects
description: AFRICA: The Art of a Continent," which opens today at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, is an exhibition that should already be regarded as obsolete.

title: OLYMPICS;800 Champion Denied Games
description: Wilson Kipketer is the defending world champion in the 800 meters and, under normal circumstances, he would be an overwhelming favorite for Olympic gold in the same event this summer. After months of bureaucratic wrangling, Kenyan officials this week rejected the Danish Olympic Committee's final request to allow Kipketer, a native of Kenya, to compete for Denmark in Atlanta.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: RUNNING;Loroupe Back in New York
description: TEGLA LOROUPE was all smiles yesterday, but her friends were worried.

title: Japanese Denials on Brothels Anger China
description: China expressed "strong indignation" today over assertions by Japanese lawmakers that Japan did not force women in its military-run brothels to become prostitutes during World War II.

title: FILM REVIEW;Of Revolution and Two Prostitutes
description: Watching Li Shaohong's film "Blush," it is easy to imagine how Hollywood might have schmaltzed up this story of a friendship between two women that survives in spite of overwhelming obstacles. A ready-made tear-jerker, with plot elements from "Gone With the Wind" and "Old Acquaintance," "Blush" has almost everything you could ask for in a sudsy historical epic: a sweeping revolution, an anguished romantic triangle, prostitution, illegitimacy, a stay in a convent and a baby one woman doesn't want and the other adores.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Cavs' Daugherty Retires
description: BRAD DAUGHERTY, a five-time All-Star who has not played for the Cleveland Cavaliers since suffering a back injury in 1994, is retiring from professional basketball.

title: F.D.A. Rejects Sale Of Drug for Shingles
description: The Food and Drug Administration refused today to approve a new anti-shingles drug for use in the United States after 15 people in Japan died after using it.

title: GOLF;Els Burns the Front Nine To Take Lead in Buick
description: Each year, something about Westchester Country Club seems to bring the best out of the same cast of players. Familiar faces and names pop up on the leader board like customary acts on a Broadway marquee, and this year is no different. It's time to round up the usual suspects.

title: Children's Conspiracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor's Empire Is Now in Ruins
description: When J. Fife Symington 3d first ran for governor in 1990, he promised Arizonans that if elected, he would run the state just like he ran his own ostensibly thriving Phoenix real estate empire.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Former Giants Get a Team
description: Five members of the Giants' first Super Bowl championship team have purchased an interest in an Arena Football team that will play at Continental Arena beginning next April.

title: Bring in the Car, Bring in the Hat;Smithsonian's Road Show Brings Americana to Coliseum
description: They might have been parking a car in a tight spot. It just happened to be a space capsule.

title: Robert J. Zeller, Bank Chairman, 79
description: Robert J. Zeller, who retired in 1982 as chairman and chief executive of the Dollar Savings Bank in the Bronx, died on Tuesday at his daughter's home in Somers, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Foundation's Racism Lawsuit Is Dismissed in Pennsylvania
description: A Federal judge has thrown out the Barnes Foundation's lawsuit asserting that its neighbors had conspired with officials of Lower Merion Township in a racist effort to hurt the foundation's gallery.

title: Court Overturns Award to Injured Officer
description: A New York City police officer who was injured during a high-speed car chase cannot hold the city liable for his injuries, the state's top court ruled on Thursday, overturning a lower court award of $200,000.

title: Icahn Says He May Renew Proxy Fight at RJR Nabisco
description: Carl C. Icahn, who failed in April to win control of the board of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation with his ally Bennett S. LeBow, formally severed his agreement with Mr. LeBow yesterday and said he was contemplating another proxy battle to force an immediate spinoff of the company's food unit from its tobacco operations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNIT OF COASTAL TO RAISE STAKE IN IROQUOIS GAS SYSTEM
description: The energy division of Tenneco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 13.2 percent stake in the Iroquois Gas Transmission System to a subsidiary of the ANR Pipeline Company for about $30 million. The 375-mile Iroquois pipeline system is owned by a partnership of 10 United States and Canadian energy companies, including ANR, a unit of the Coastal Corporation. ANR already holds a 9.4 percent interest in the pipeline, which brings natural gas from Canada to the Northeastern United States, the Tenneco division said. Tenneco Energy said that it remained committed to a strong presence in the Northeast and that it had sold its interest in Iroquois to try to strengthen its market share through projects over which it has more control. (Reuters)

title: Council Panel Backs Higher Minimum Wages
description: A City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would require some city contractors to pay higher minimum wages to their employees, affecting about 3,500 workers and increasing the city's contracting costs by about $15 million a year.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pilkington Reports 47% Jump in Profit
description: Pilkington P.L.C., a British glass and building materials maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 47 percent in the year that ended on March 31 before a reorganization charge. The profit was L212 million ($326.5 million) before the previously announced charge of L155 million. A year earlier, pretax profit was L144 million before charges. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Art in Review
description: The Art Exchange 60 Broad Street Financial district Through June 15

title: ON BASEBALL;Tigers Setting New Standard For Futility on the Diamond
description: On an ordinary day, it is easy to wonder if the baseball gods have forgotten that there is a major league team in Detroit. On days like yesterday, it is more than obvious that they have.

title: Undertaker Held After Decomposed Bodies Found
description: A Brooklyn funeral home director was arrested yesterday after investigators discovered five badly decomposed bodies in the basement of his business that had apparently been there for six months, the police said.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the break following the morning session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 101.79 points, or nearly half a percent, at 21,702.67. On Thursday, the Nikkei closed down 76.97 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Royal Naif Betrayed By a Cold, Cruel World
description: Few situations are sadder than the plight of a lonely child monarch who grows up to discover that his world is a wasp's nest of conspiracy, treachery and manipulation. One reason that the story of Kaspar Hauser, Europe's most famous "wild child," has inspired more than 2,000 books and a film by Werner Herzog is that it carries a version of this scenario into the realm of myth. If you accept that this foundling discovered on the streets of Nuremburg in 1828 and assassinated five years later at the age of 21 was really the heir to the throne of Baden, the situation assumes the dimensions of a fiendish real-life fairy tale with a tragic ending.

title: Monkey Study Accents Risks Of Oral Sex
description: In a study that underscores the risks of oral sex, scientists have found that an AIDS-like virus can infect monkeys after it is dabbed on the backs of their mouths.

title: Art in Review
description: Thomas Trosch 'Musical Comedy Medley' Jessica Fredericks Gallery 504 West 22d Street Chelsea Through June 30

title: U.S. Says D'Amato Profited As Brokerage Broke Rules
description: A Long Island brokerage house violated its own rules -- and did so for questionable motives -- when it earned Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato a profit of $37,125 in one day of stock market trading in 1993, according to a report prepared for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: ART REVIEW;Color Sets the Tempo, and Numbers Go Ticktock
description: The first thing to be said about the mammoth one-person show by Hanne Darboven at the Dia Center for the Arts is that from a distance it is remarkably pretty to look at. Part mosaic and part bulletin board, it consists of 1,590 wall-mounted wood-framed panels of uniform format and size, and 19 other objects. They constitute a many-sided cultural history of the years from 1880 to 1983.

title: BASKETBALL;Camby Proves Supportive Of Calipari's Move to Pros
description: Saying it was always John Calipari's dream to coach in the National Basketball Association, the University of Massachusetts's second-most prominent defector spoke freely today about his former college coach and the current controversy surrounding himself.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS PLANS $348 MILLION IN ACQUISITIONS
description: The U.S. Office Products Company said yesterday that it had reached agreements to acquire 53 companies for $324 million in stock and $24 million in cash. U.S. Office Products said that under the agreements, its domestic contract stationer and office furniture divisions would buy 22 companies; those divisions have already completed five other acquisitions that had not been announced previously. U.S. Office Products, which is based in Washington, will also buy 4 businesses that provide commercial maintenance supplies, and its coffee service division will buy 17 companies. Also, the company's school supply division will buy five companies. The total annual revenue of the businesses being bought is $775 million, U.S. Office Products said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T Capital Agrees To $2.2 Billion Buyout AT&T Capital, an equipment-leasing group that has been on the block since September, agreed to a $2.2 billion leveraged-buyout offer. The sale, which will take much of the company private, is part of the parent AT&T's revamping plan.

title: No Decisions in Bertelsmann TV Venture Dispute
description: After a day of rampant speculation, contradictory statements and hurried denials, Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, Canal Plus of France and B Sky B of Britain were unable -- or unwilling -- to clarify tonight whether their three-month-old partnership to develop digital television broadcasting in the region still existed.

title: TOP RUSSIAN BANK IS TOLD BY YELTSIN TO RELEASE FUNDS
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin has ordered Russia's Central Bank to transfer the equivalent of $1 billion to the federal budget in an election-year move that has alarmed economists and created new worries about resurgent inflation

title: BOXING;De La Hoya and Chavez: Snappy Versus Seasoned
description: The old one will lure the young one into a brawl, perhaps.

title: Call for Curbs If Top Serbs Are Not Held
description: The president of the international war crimes tribunal on the Balkans said today that the United Nations should reimpose sanctions on the Serbs if the two top Bosnian Serb leaders are not arrested.

title: From the War On Crime, War on Grime
description: New York City sanitation officials are analyzing tickets for littering, compiling thick loose-leaf notebooks of information on major property owners and putting a sanitation superintendent squarely on the hot seat -- all as part a new initiative aimed at cleaning up the dirtiest neighborhood in the city.

title: With Netanyahu, Can Allies Be Friends?
description: There was a time in 1990 when Benjamin Netanyahu, as Israel's Deputy Foreign Minister, was so out of favor with the American administration that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d banned him from entering the State Department.

title: Mortgage Rates Increase
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.30 percent this week, the highest rate in more than a year, a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation showed. They were up from 8.03 percent last week and were at the highest level since an average of 8.37 percent in the second week of April 1995. Fifteen-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.80 percent, up from 7.54 percent a week earlier. For one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.86 percent, up from 5.76 percent last week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1984, HENRY F. GRAFF, a professor of history at Columbia University, was invited by President Ronald Reagan to bring his new book, "The Presidents: A Reference History," to the White House library. On Wednesday, Mr. Graff, now a professor emeritus, returned to the White House to present the second edition, published by Scribner's, to President Clinton.

title: Wind, Equipment and Pilot Decisions Called Factors in Crash of RonBrown's Plane
description: Questionable decisions by pilots, a possibly faulty radio beacon and strong crosswinds were among the factors contributing to the April 3 crash of an Air Force jet that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today.

title: Interest Strong in Kmart Preferred Shares
description: A preferred convertible stock offering by the Kmart Corporation was so well received today that the company has decided to offer $870 million of the securities instead of the $750 million that had been originally planned.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Pressure on Payton in Bid to Come Back
description: Microphones, cameras and tape recorders were in Gary Payton's face yesterday. The Chicago Bulls' defense will be in Payton's face tonight.

title: Market Place;A proposed deal by Warnaco raises fair questions of conflict.
description: IT'S been six years since the Warnaco Group, needing to raise cash to pay down debt from its 1986 leveraged buyout, sold a division to its management. Yesterday, Warnaco offered to buy back that division, now called the Authentic Fitness Corporation, for a vastly higher price.

title: Art in Review
description: David Deutsch Surveillance' Jay Gorney Modern Art 100 Greene Street, near Spring Street SoHo Through June 22

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about the casting of "Jules," a television pilot, misspelled the surname of the actress who won the part of the protagonist's best friend. As noted in the article, she is Felicity Huffman, not Hoffman.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Inside Art
description: A Sotheby's-Emmerich Venture

title: Food Safety Bill Is Based on New Science
description: To the Editor: Re "Don't Jeopardize Food Safety" (editorial, May 28), on H. R. 3200, which would reform the Food and Drug Administration to make it more responsive to changes in science and the marketplace:

title: In a $2.2 Billion Buyout, AT&T Capital to Go Private
description: The AT&T Capital Corporation, which has been on the block since September, agreed yesterday to a $2.2 billion leveraged-buyout offer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner Is Step Closer To Turner Deal
description: A Delaware judge yesterday removed a major obstacle to Time Warner's acquisition of the Turner Broadcasting System, ruling that Time Warner's agreement with U S West Inc. does not preclude its pending $7.5 billion purchase of Turner.

title: Some Gay Rights Advocates Question Drive to Defend Same-Sex Marriage
description: Fearing a political battle that will divert attention from what they regard as more critical issues -- and one that will ultimately be lost -- some influential homosexuals are questioning the high-profile campaign by major gay groups to defend same-sex marriage.

title: TV SPORTS;Pugilistic Throwback: A Closed-Circuit Fight
description: Don't look for tonight's Oscar De La Hoya-Julio Cesar Chavez fight on pay-per-view television. A bout like this, so natural for pay-per-view, where five friends can split a $40 tab, will be carried the closed-circuit way, in arenas, theaters, bars and race tracks, where those five friends will pay $40 each.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURLINGTON RESOURCES BUYS OIL AND GAS HOLDINGS
description: Burlington Resources Inc., an oil and natural gas company, said yesterday that it had bought the offshore holdings of Gulfstream Resources Inc., an independent oil exploration and production company, for $77 million. The purchase includes interests in three oil and gas operations off the Louisiana coast in the Gulf of Mexico. These produce 29 million cubic feet of natural gas and 1,300 barrels of oil a day, the company said. Gulfstream, which is privately held, is based in New Orleans. The stock of Burlington, which is based in Houston, fell 37.5 cents, to $39.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

title: L.S.U. and Miami To Play for the Title
description: Louisiana State University advanced to its third national championship game in five years today, outlasting Florida, 2-1, as Eddie Yarnall, a left-hander, prevailed in a rare pitching duel in the College World Series.

title: BASEBALL;Williams Flies High To Spark Yankees
description: It seemed as if Bernie Williams spent most of his day yesterday in the air. If he wasn't flying home from Puerto Rico, where he had gone to visit his ailing son, Williams was getting ready to board a plane with the rest of the Yankees for a six-game road trip that begins tonight in Detroit.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: 25 and Under
description: Asia in the Village

title: 1.5 Billion Bond Act Sought By Pataki for Environment
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a $1.5 billion bond act yesterday to attack environmental problems that he said have dogged New York State for decades.

title: POLITICS: THE CAPITOL;Congress Is Moving On Political Issues, Not on Legislation
description: For the second time in 15 months, the Senate failed today to approve a proposed constitutional amendment that would require the Government to maintain a balanced budget. No one expected otherwise.

title: 3 Suspended in Inquiry Into E.M.S. Response to Fatal Attack
description: An Emergency Medical Services dispatcher and two ambulance crew members were suspended without pay yesterday as part of a city investigation into why it took 36 minutes to get an ambulance to the house of a Queens couple who were bleeding to death from stab wounds.

title: Abroad at Home;'Bare The Secrets'
description: It will be 25 years next week since the decision that, more than any other, established the modern independence of the American press -- its willingness to challenge official truth. That was the decision of The New York Times to publish the Pentagon Papers.

title: FILM REVIEW;The Ghost Who Walks And His War With Evil
description: Back in the days when the archeologist Indiana Jones was locked in mortal combat with Nazi minions intent on achieving international hegemony through possession of the Ark of the Covenant, it seems that a similar heroic effort to thwart overweening evil was in progress elsewhere.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Colorado Scores Early and Often
description: Throughout the Stanley Cup playoffs, Florida Coach Doug MacLean has been sensitive to criticism of his team's cautious, defensive style. He has denounced published observations that the Panthers' tight-checking approach creates too many boring, low-scoring games.

title: Fears of Debt Have Brought Rejections of Recent Bond Acts
description: By proposing a $1.5 billion environmental bond act today, Gov. George E. Pataki hopes to win the support of a public that appears to have turned against such measures in recent years because of fears the state has already amassed too much debt.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Everybody's a Critic

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Two if by Sea 1996. Warner. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 96 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: 10,000 Bail Set for Suspect In the Death Of an Officer
description: A Bronx judge set bail yesterday at $10,000 for a man charged in the death of a police officer last month, rejecting a request by prosecutors that the suspect be held without bail.

title: Art in Review
description: Anne Truitt Andre Emmerich Gallery 41 East 57th Street Through June 21

title: Family of Four Quit Compound Of the Freemen
description: In the first defections from the right-wing Freemen fugitives in two months, a couple, along with the woman's two children, today voluntarily left the group's High Plains farmhouse and were whisked away by Federal agents.

title: Diplomatic Haze Pervades Air Pollution Dispute At Big Bend NationalPark
description: Spanish explorers called it El Despoblado, the uninhabited place. Astronauts came to this vast Chihuahuan Desert moonscape to practice lunar expeditions. And for decades, visitors to the Big Bend have encountered spectacular, seemingly endless vistas of the Chisos Mountains in West Texas and the Maderas del Carmen range in Mexico.

title: Bosnia Elections Will Promote Dayton Fantasy;Property Claims Panel
description: To the Editor: Your June 1 front-page article about ethnic Serbs and Croats (as well as Muslims) in Sarajevo whose apartments are being expropriated by the Bosnian Government presents a critical subject that should be within the responsibility of the Commission for Real Property Claims established under the Dayton accords. Despite the urgency of the situation, however, the commission has yet to begin its work.

title: POLITICS;Text of Dole's Statement On His Abortion Stance
description: Following is Senator Bob Dole's statement on abortion, as provided by his campaign office:

title: TV WEEKEND;Going Home to Mother And Other Bad Ideas
description: In "Lily Dale," Horton Foote, author of some 40 plays, rummages once again through an exquisitely neurasthenic past, its taut emotions stretched almost painfully beneath flutterings of propriety. Mr. Foote's work was seen at its best in the film version of "The Trip to Bountiful," directed by Peter Masterson and starring Geraldine Page. Mr. Masterson also directs "Lily Dale," being presented on Sunday on Showtime, but alas, despite a generally fine cast, there's no Page-like turn to galvanize the production.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Tyson Request Is Rejected
description: A zoning inspector has denied MIKE TYSON's request to keep a lion cub and two tiger cubs on his estate in Southington, Ohio, and the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion is appealing that ruling.

title: H.I.V. Is Still Spreading Rapidly, U.N. Says
description: The virus that causes AIDS continues to spread rapidly in large parts of the world, especially Asia and southern Africa, and the number of people sick with AIDS has also climbed steeply, the director of the United Nations program against the disease said today.

title: Retailers Had A Good May, Gaining 4.6%
description: Retail companies charged through May with strong sales, demonstrating that Americans are willing to keep stocking their closets with new shirts and fetching accessories, especially those that can be had cheaply.

title: For Gay Film Festival, a Shift in Focus
description: In its eight-year existence, the New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival, also known as the New Festival, has evolved into something considerably more complex than a selection of recent movies by gay and lesbian film makers and video artists. It is more like a multicultural fair, centered on movies, with a gay slant.

title: Art in Review
description: Sandro Chia Sidney Janis Gallery 110 West 57th Street Through June 22

title: Judge Sarokin's Retreat
description: In his resignation letter this week to President Clinton, Judge H. Lee Sarokin frames his decision to quit his seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit as a principled response to Republican political attacks on his record. But his retreat under fire does not serve the cause of an independent judiciary.

title: Hospital Says Cash Problem Delays Payroll
description: Interfaith Medical Center, a financially troubled hospital in central Brooklyn, failed to pay its employees yesterday, their scheduled payday.

title: Home Video
description: Changes of Plans

title: ART REVIEW;Paul Cadmus, a Mapplethorpe for His Times
description: When Paul Cadmus was 29, in 1934, his career was rocketed by a stroke of Mapplethorpe-ish luck. His campily carnal painting "The Fleet's In," a view of full-bodied sailors and women cavorting in drunken revelry, was removed from a show at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington by demand of the United States Navy. The grounds? That it made America's sailors look sleazy. (Nearly 60 years later, the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe's work got a similar boost when -- at the Corcoran again -- a Mapplethorpe show was canceled on the assumption that some of its images might trigger the wrath of Congress.)

title: OPEC Is Expected to Delay Action on New Oil Output by Iraq
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting here, appeared paralyzed today, stuck between a certainty of lower oil prices if it failed to reduce its 11 members' output, but stymied by its members' refusal to cut their current market shares.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Happiness in 20th-Century Avant-Garde Art' New York Academy of Sciences 2 East 63d Street Through June 28

title: L.I.U. Awaits Parker Decision
description: Officials at Long Island University are awaiting a decision by Richie Parker, the former Manhattan Center High School standout, regarding an offer of a basketball scholarship.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Surprise British Rate Cut Hurts Pound vs. Dollar and Mark
description: The British pound fell against the dollar and the mark yesterday after the Bank of England suprised currency traders by cutting interest rates.

title: World News Briefs;Chinese Province Bans Tests for Sex of Fetus
description: Fujian province has banned medical tests specifically to identify the sex of unborn babies after surveys have indicated that large numbers of females are being aborted, the Xinhua news agency reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMERICAN BANKNOTE CORP., New York, a printer of stock and bond certificates and other products, has acquired a 55 percent stake in Leigh-Mardon Security Group, an Australian securities printer, from Amcor Ltd. The total valuation of Leigh-Mardon is $80 million.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Russian Visiting 1970 Cuba
description: The disastrous effects of Fidel Castro's Communist revolution on the Cuban people is the theme of "A Park in Our House," the earnest, unsuccessfully poetic new play by Nilo Cruz, who is himself a Cuban-American in his early 30's. The production, directed by Loretta Greco, opened last night at the New York Theater Workshop, the estimable Off Broadway theater that most recently gave us Jonathan Larson's award-winning "Rent."

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAKER OF PLASTIC PARTS FOR CARS AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED
description: The Bailey Corporation, a maker of molded plastic parts for the auto industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Venture Holdings Trust for $8.75 a share in cash, or about $47.7 million. Subsidiaries of Venture, which is based in Fraser, Mich., also make plastic components for the auto industry. Bailey, which is based in Seabrook, N.H., said its directors had voted unanimously for the merger, saying it was in the best interests of stockholders. The company's shares closed unchanged yesterday at $8.375. (Reuters)

title: Cambodian Killers' Careful Records Used Against Them
description: Sous Thy played an important role in the mass killings by the Communist Khmer Rouge that for nearly four years turned Cambodia into one of the most terrifying places on earth: He was a clerk.

title: Unabomber's Misdeeds Didn't Arise From 60's
description: To the Editor: Your exploration (news article, June 1) of the social and political sea in which Theodore Kaczynski, the suspected Unabomber, swam during his early days as a graduate student and teacher of mathematics is interesting. But it is misleading when it suggests that Mr. Kaczynski's disturbed behavior years later was, as one person quoted in the story put it, "a product of what was in the air."

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Father of the Bride, Part II 1995. Touchstone. $103.92. Laser disk, $39.99. 106 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: Tuesday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ketchum Is Selected For Pacific Bell Account
description: Pacific Bell Communications, the new long-distance division of the Pacific Telesis Group, named Ketchum Advertising in San Francisco to introduce local, long-distance and other telecommunications services to California and Nevada. Billings were not disclosed, but trade publications estimated them at $80 million.

title: Martin Ormandy, 95, Cellist With the Philharmonic, Dies
description: Martin Ormandy, a cellist who played for 36 years with the New York Philharmonic and then became a fixture in many of New York's freelance orchestras for another three decades, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 95 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pure Software To Buy Astria In Stock Deal
description: Pure Software Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Atria Software Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $928 million.

title: 2 Producers Said to Reject Disney Offer
description: Executives from the Walt Disney Company held discussions in recent days with Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner, the heads of the leading independent television production company, about taking over management of ABC's slumping entertainment division, an executive familiar with the discussions said last night.

title: Giants Will Likely Waive Riesenberg
description: Doug Riesenberg yesterday rejected the Giants' proposal to reduce his salary for the 1996 National Football League season and it appears likely that the team will waive him today.

title: City at the Crossroads
description: The key to peace in Bosnia is a small river city called Brcko.

title: Jury Exempts N.A.A.C.P. From Sex-Harassment Payments
description: A jury ruled today that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People did not have to help pay the $332,400 promised by its former executive director, Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., to settle an employee's sexual harassment claim.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JULIA CHASE-BRAND, 53, also graduated with a distinction yesterday: she became the oldest person ever to receive a medical degree at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University in the Bronx.

title: Test Hints at New Risk in Mixing of Environmental Pesticides
description: Certain pesticides and other chemicals like PCB's persist in the environment for many years. Though their concentrations are minute, some biologists have long been concerned that the substances' chemical similarity to hormones like estrogen may enable them to wreak havoc with the fertility of various wildlife populations and even of humans.

title: COMPANY NEWS;APRIA TO BUY VITAS HEALTHCARE, A HOSPICE PROVIDER
description: Apria Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Vitas Healthcare Corporation of Miami for $212 million, which includes an unspecified amount of assumed debt. The value of the deal is based on Apria's closing stock price of $32.125 a share on Wednesday. The deal was announced after stock markets closed yesterday; Apria's shares had fallen by 25 cents to close at $31.875 on the New York Stock Exchange. Vitas, a closely held hospice provider, will continue to operate under the same name. It had $230 million in revenue in its last fiscal year. Apria, which provides home health care, had revenue of $1.13 billion last year. It is based in Costa Mesa, Calif. (Dow Jones)

title: Who Needs Pitino? Nets Land Calipari
description: A week after being turned down by one successful college coach, Kentucky's Rick Pitino, the New Jersey Nets landed another -- John Calipari of Massachusetts. Calipari, who has never coached in the pros, received a five-year deal. He will have to revive a struggling franchise.

title: POLITICS;Drop Out, Congressman's Predecessor Says
description: Saying he now feels embarrassed for helping Representative Wes Cooley win election two years ago, his retired predecessor, Bob Smith, said today that he should drop his re-election campaign.

title: Police Search Woman's Home in Park Case
description: Police detectives last night searched an apartment on West 57th Street to try to determine whether the young woman who lived there might be the same person who now lies unconscious at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, the victim of a brutal assault in Central Park on Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about fraud charges against Joseph Waldholtz, the former husband of Representative Enid Greene, misstated the number of guilty pleas he entered. As the article noted, it was four, not two.

title: James Harvey, 61, Transamerica Chief
description: James R. Harvey, a former chairman, president and chief executive of the Transamerica Corporation, died yesterday at a hospital in San Francisco. He was 61 and lived in San Francisco and in Moraga, Calif.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Medeva to Buy Fisons From Big Drug Maker
description: The British drug maker Medeva P.L.C. said yesterday that it would acquire Fisons P.L.C.'s former operations in Rochester and licenses to sell various drugs from Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. for $400 million. The sale comes a day after Rhone-Poulenc Rorer's parent, the French chemical and drug company Rhone-Poulenc S.A., said it planned to sell pharmaceutical assets.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Timothy Leary on Saturday misstated the surname of his surviving son Zachary. Formerly a stepson, Zachary was adopted by Mr. Leary. He is Zachary Leary, not Chase.

title: BASEBALL;Pulsipher Still Brings Life to Mets
description: It was Wednesday afternoon, about two hours before the Mets would play the Atlanta Braves. Bill Pulsipher made his entrance into the Mets clubhouse. Dressed in an orange Mets T-shirt and baggy blue gym shorts, he let out a bellow, intentionally shattering the silence of his teammates' inner sanctum.

title: Diner's Journal
description: You're going to get a suntan," says the maitre d'hotel jovially.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Outdoor ads, featuring bouncing dinner plates and gigantic women, are redefining big and bold.
description: MICHAEL J. PEARSON sculptures larger-than-life objects like bugs, baseball bats and witches. Last month, his company, Atomic Props and Effects Ltd., created eight Amazon-sized women clad in swimsuits perched on short diving boards for a billboard in Minneapolis for the Dayton Hudson Corporation's Target store chain that read, "Take the Plunge."

title: Adoption Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lottery Tickets Go Uncashed
description: It may be hard to believe, but every year between $8 million and $12 million in state lottery winnings go uncollected. A proposed constitutional amendment will be introduced on Monday that seeks to use $600,000 in unclaimed prize money to save the financially strapped Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, a spokesman for State Senator Robert W. Singer, Republican of Lakewood, said yesterday. If the measure is passed by the Legislature it would then have to be approved by voters.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a celebration in Hebron misstated the estimate of Jewish settlers who live there. It is about 450.

title: World News Briefs;Burmese Rulers Ban Speeches by Dissident
description: The Burmese military has prohibited the country's leading democracy advocate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, from holding her weekly speech to supporters outside her home, opposition officials said today.

title: T. Rowe Price Closes Fund to New Investors
description: T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. is taking steps to prevent new investors from buying shares of one of the company's most popular mutual funds because it is getting too big.

title: An Abortion Right
description: To the Editor: There is a flaw in Gregory Rummo's argument (letter, June 6). Granting the legal right to abortion did not intrude on anyone, least of all the medical profession. No one is forcing women to have abortions or physicians to perform them. The right is there, it has been affirmed.

title: In America;Trashing Art Careers
description: Allan F. Hershfield, president of the Fashion Institute of Technology, has been speaking out lately about the large numbers of New York City youngsters who are being denied access to rewarding careers in art and design because the public school system has systematically trashed its arts programs.

title: State Racing Commission Chief Is Found to Violate Ethics Code
description: The chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board violated the state ethics code when he did business with people whom his agency licenses, the State Ethics Commission said today.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: World's Population Is Growing Less Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;How Hyper-Machismo Can Turn Into Violence
description: The angry young men who skulk through Tim McCann's film "Desolation Angels" are forever shooting each other up with the verbal equivalent of steroids.

title: DANCE REVIEW;An Ailey Company Gala
description: Savion Glover danced and talked. Gregory Hines and Vanessa Williams put in appearances, and there was some powerful dancing from members of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and its junior company, the Repertory Ensemble. But the high point of "Ailey's Spring Gala 1996," presented on Wednesday night at the John Jay Theater, was a baptismal dance from Ailey's "Revelations" performed by six young student dancers from the Ailey American Dance Center.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Renewed Interest by Industry Pushes Copper Prices Higher
description: Copper prices recovered somewhat yesterday as a five-day slide in prices renewed demand from manufacturers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BENEDEK BROADCASTING BUYS 13 TV STATIONS
description: The Benedek Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired 13 television stations from the Brissette Broadcasting Corporation and Stauffer Communications Inc., a unit of the Morris Communications Corporation, for a total of $324.5 million. The purchase, which consists of eight stations from Brissette, for $270 million, and five from Stauffer, for $54.5 million, makes Benedek, which is based in Rockford, Ill., the biggest television group in the nation, with 22 stations, the company said. Of the 13 stations, 8 are affiliated with CBS, 3 with NBC and 2 with ABC. Benedek already has nine stations; four of them are CBS affiliates, four are ABC affiliates and one is an NBC affiliate. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: INSIDE
description: Vigil for Unidentified Victim

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton Has a New Gift for the Middle Class
description: In another appeal to the middle-class, President Clinton moved today to lower closing costs by $200 for first-time homebuyers who use Government-backed loans financed by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: HORSE RACING;Star Colts Are in Short Supply So Crowded Field Turns Out
description: From Saratoga Dandy on the inside to Secreto de Estado on the outside, 15 horses will line up in two starting gates tomorrow for a crowded Belmont Stakes that will match the record for the fullest field in 128 years.

title: Thomas H. Dawson, TV Executive, 82
description: Thomas H. Dawson, an early television industry executive who was president of the CBS network in the late 1960's, died on Sunday at a medical center in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 82.

title: Half-Ton of Cocaine Seized In Raids on Colombian Ring
description: Seven people reputed to be members of a Colombian drug-smuggling ring were arrested and about 1,100 pounds of cocaine was confiscated in a series of raids in northern New Jersey on Wednesday, law-enforcement authorities said today.

title: Heresy at Fed: Calls for Cuts In Interest Rates;Greenspan Critics Say War On Inflation Has Been Won
description: Few here were surprised in February when Alan Greenspan won renomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve, given the success of his nine-year war on inflation. But three months later Mr. Greenspan's confirmation remains stalled in the Senate over questions of whether he has carried that war too far.

title: Claims for Jobless Benefits Increased 9,000
description: New claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly shot up by 9,000 last week, but analysts said they remained at a level consistent with modest employment growth.

title: The Backbone Of Natural History
description: THE casts of fossil skeletons have been hung from the beautifully restored Victorian Gothic ceiling with care, like decorations at a fancy-dress ball for paleontologists: a 16-foot armored fish, a giant turtle, a seagoing plesiosaur and assorted pterosaurs, flying reptiles from the time of dinosaurs. They hover spectacularly and invite exploration of a gallery on the early history of vertebrates, animals with backbones.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lab Workers Flee Fumes
description: Twenty-seven employees of the Corning Clinical Laboratories were overcome by toxic fumes yesterday after a ventilation system malfunctioned in a laboratory where pathologists were conducting biopsies. One of the employees was hospitalized. The fumes came from xylene and methanol, two solvents routinely used in the preparation of slides for biopsies, said Al Reynolds, a spokesman for the lab, formerly known as Medpath Laboratories. All 2,000 employees were ordered from the building for about two and a half hours.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NOWSCO ACCEPTS HIGHER BID FROM BJ SERVICES
description: Nowsco Well Service Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said yesterday that it had accepted a sweetened takeover bid of $578 million (United States) from the BJ Services Company of Houston. The Nowsco board had previously endorsed an offer of $30.90 (Canadian) a share from the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation of West Lafayette, Ind. But on Monday, BJ Services raised its offer to $35 (Canadian) from $27 a share. Earlier yesterday, a Great Lakes spokesman, Greg Griffith, declined to comment on whether Great Lakes would increase or walk away from its bid for the Canadian company. BJ Services provides tubing and casing used in the drilling of oil and gas wells. Nowsco also provides services to the oil industry. (Reuters)

title: Art in Review
description: Ragna Berlin and Michelle Segre Lauren Wittels Gallery 580 Broadway, near Prince Street SoHo Through June 26

title: In Concession, China Is Ready To Ban A-Tests
description: China today abandoned its longstanding insistence on its right to conduct nuclear explosions for non-military purposes, and said it hoped an international treaty banning all nuclear testing could be concluded by the end of the year.

title: ART REVIEW;Philip Johnson and the Modern: A Loving Marriage
description: If there has been one constant in the varied public life of the architect Philip Johnson, who is about to turn 90, it is probably the Museum of Modern Art. His architectural style has shifted radically over the decades, from International Style austerity to post-modern frivolity, to his current interest in non-Euclidian expressionist geometries. His politics have also shifted, including a notorious period of Fascist leanings in the late 1930's. Mr. Johnson has called this phase a mistake, in much the way that he once called himself a "whore" with regard to the often garish skyscrapers he designed in the 1980's.

title: POP REVIEW;Bo Diddley and His Guitar
description: In the first of two sets on Wednesday night at Tramps, Bo Diddley showed signs of wear and tear. His historical importance, as a song-delivery stylist and rhythmic innovator who helped turn rhythm-and-blues into rock-and-roll, is undeniable. But his 67 years and decades of traveling from show to show seem to have taken their toll, and on Wednesday he seemed damaged by all the moving and shuffling around. He slipped a disk in his back last fall, and had to remain seated throughout the show, moving on and off stage only with difficulty. Mr. Diddley's five-piece band performed like museum curators, so in awe of the masterpiece in their presence that they spent most of their time concerned with how to please and take care of it.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More Money for Rail Project
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee yesterday recommended spending $105 million next year on the Secaucus Transfer. The measure, if approved by the full committee and then by Congress, would nearly complete financing for the train station in Secaucus, which is now under construction and has already received $313 million in Federal funds.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Sonics Still Searching For Clue to Solve Bulls
description: Shawn Kemp and Gary Payton have rattled the psyches of their opponents all season. So, they can expound -- sometimes not so eloquently -- on the beauty of mental toughness.

title: Volunteers Arrive to Help Fight Alaska Fire
description: Hundreds of firefighters from across the nation arrived today to join the battle against a 64-square-mile wildfire that tripled in size in a matter of hours and cast smoke over Anchorage, 50 miles away.

title: A Nuclear Test Ban Within Reach
description: For the past 40 years, diplomats have dreamed of negotiating a treaty that would ban all nuclear weapons tests. Such an accord could significantly slow the nuclear arms race, which has diverted hundreds of billions of dollars from civilian needs and heightened the risk of nuclear warfare.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Sims Named Sharks' Coach
description: As new coach of the San Jose Sharks, AL SIMS says his first order of business is an attitude adjustment. The Sharks, winners of only 20 games last season, could use it.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Matta-dors and Jugadors' Sports Drawings by Matta From the 1950's Mary-Anne Martin/Fine Art 23 East 73d Street Through June 22

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;History Channel Cancels Plan For Series on U.S. Companies
description: Abashed by criticism of their plan to produce a series of television profiles of American corporations with those companies, executives of the History Channel decided yesterday to scuttle the project.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Sudden Death 1995. MCA/Universal. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 111 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: U.S. Approves Drug to Fight Blindness From Glaucoma
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a new drug to help glaucoma patients fight blindness, but they will have to accept the risk of a bizarre side effect: the drug can turn blue eyes brown.

title: Bosnia Elections Will Promote Dayton Fantasy
description: To the Editor: While your overall reporting on Bosnian developments has become more balanced, your editorials miss the real issues. For example, "Protect Bosnia's Election" (editorial, June 4) supports the Dayton fantasy, believing that Bosnia can be reconstituted and survive as a reintegrated country.

title: Giuliani Criticizes G.O.P. And Dole on Immigration
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized Senator Bob Dole today for supporting Republican-sponsored legislation that would restrict Government aid to immigrants and called those restrictions "a terrible, terrible mistake."

title: Bitter Infighting Brings Down Turkey's Coalition Government
description: Attacked from both inside and outside his center-right coalition, Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz of Turkey resigned yesterday, ending a three-month-old Government that had been grounded from the start by acrimonious infighting.

title: The Navy's Blues
description: Adrift" is the word most associated with the Navy these days, an image the newly appointed Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Jay L. Johnson, must work to dispel. Well before the tragic suicide of his predecessor, Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the feeling inside the Navy was that the service had lost its focus as a fighting force.

title: U.S. Judge Throws Out Claims Against Three Mile Island Plant
description: A Federal judge late today threw out more than 2,000 damage claims filed against the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, saying plaintiffs offered a "paucity of proof" in support of their cases.

title: INSIDE
description: Monitor Resists Deadline For Election in Bosnia

title: Let Organ-Donor Family Make Dignified Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Producers Are Said to Reject Bid to Run ABC Entertainment
description: Executives from the Walt Disney Company held discussions in recent days with Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner, the heads of the leading independent television production company, about taking over management of ABC's slumping entertainment division, according to an executive familiar with the discussions.

title: Attacker in Central Park Is Thought to Be Stranger
description: Having identified the woman who was beaten nearly to death in Central Park on Tuesday, investigators said yesterday that they believed that her attacker did not know her and that he had robbed her in addition to trying to rape her.

title: Caught in Milosevic's Web
description: When the United States and its partners pulled together the Bosnian peace accord, they tried to ensnare the region's warmongers in a web of peace. Six months later, it's hard to tell who ensnared whom.

title: Promised a Surprise, Student Is Murdered
description: Lured by the promise of a surprise, a high school senior walked with her eyes closed into the woods with a classmate, who then stabbed her to death because "nobody liked her," he told the police.

title: U.S. Officials See More Hope for an End to Montana Standoff
description: With two children now out of the Freemen farmhouse near here, Federal law-enforcement officials say they have broader options in their standoff with the anti-Government fugitives.

title: An Auspicious Day for Ireland
description: Monday may be an auspicious day for Ireland. For the first time, representatives of the groups that have wrangled for 75 years over the fate of Northern Ireland are scheduled to sit down together to talk. For making this possible, the Irish and British Governments deserve high praise for political courage. If the talks proceed in an orderly and purposeful fashion, the people of the British Isles have a chance to put the violence of this ugly conflict behind them.

title: Clean Needles Saved My Life
description: Ten years ago, while I was waiting around for my heroin connection, a friend saved my life. I was at risk for AIDS, she said. To protect myself, I should always use my own works or, if I had to share, I should first clean the needle thoroughly with bleach and water.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Job Market Booms, Raising Inflation Fears Employers added twice as many workers as expected to their payrolls in May. The Labor Department reported that payrolls expanded by 348,000, a solid indication that the economy is picking up momentum. The news sent interest rates soaring and raised fears that the Federal Reserve might move soon to slow growth to curb inflation.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $1.5 billion bond act for environmental projects misstated the position of the New York State Business Council on a similar bond act in 1990. The council supported that act.

title: World News Briefs;Moscow Bomb Wounds Mayor's Running Mate
description: The running-mate of Moscow's popular reformist mayor in the June 16 election was badly wounded today in a bomb blast that officials said was an attempt to sabotage the vote.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report and a picture caption in the Art in Review column of Weekend yesterday misstated the given name and misspelled the surname of an artist whose sculpture is on view at the Art Exchange, an alternative art fair running through June 15 at 60 Broad Street in Manhattan. He is Jerry Mischak, not Joe.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Release Riesenberg
description: The Giants waived tackle DOUG RIESENBERG yesterday, a day after the nine-year veteran refused their proposal to reduce his 1996 salary to $350,000 from $1.7 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Lloyd Is Highest-Paid Steeler
description: GREG LLOYD has signed a three-year contract worth $11.2 million with the Pittsburgh Steelers, making the 31-year-old linebacker the highest-paid player in franchise history, his agent said yesterday. Lloyd, a five-time Pro Bowl selection and a Steeler for nine seasons, is entering the final year of a three-year, $6.6 million contract. (AP)

title: Times Sq. Shuttle Is the Paper's Time Line
description: The Times Square-Grand Central shuttle became a time line yesterday when panels and posters on The New York Times centennial went up in subway cars and on platforms.

title: World News Briefs;North Korea May Get Aid From U.S. and Asia Allies
description: The United States, South Korea and Japan indicated today that they would unite to provide emergency food supplies to North Korea after a new appeal this week by the United Nations.

title: When Postmodernism Becomes a Cul-de-Sac
description: To the Editor: In deploring Alan Sokal's prank article in Social Text and our book, Jonathan Roughgarden and his students (letter, June 3) display a touching faith in the reasonableness of postmodern commentary on science.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SITEL ANNOUNCES ACQUISITIONS TOTALING $289 MILLION
description: The Sitel Corporation announced three separate acquisitions yesterday for stock and cash totaling $289 million. Sitel, a telemarketing concern, said it would acquire Mitre P.L.C., a London-based teleservicing company, for stock valued at $230 million. Sitel will exchange 9.2 million of its shares for Mitre, which will then own about 27 percent of Sitel. Sitel also agreed to acquire Atlanta-based National Action Financial Services Inc. for about 1.4 million shares. National Action provides telephone-based accounts-receivable management services and collections. Omaha-based Sitel also acquired a 69.2 percent stake in Teleaction S.A., a Spanish teleservicing company, for about $24 million. Sitel's stock was up $4, or 16 percent, to $29, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Arab Leaders Meet Again to Discuss the Israelis' Harder Line
description: In the third Arab mini-summit meeting in five days, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria conferred today with leaders of Egypt and Saudi Arabia in search of a strategy to counter Benjamin Netanyahu's declared unwillingness to trade land for peace with Syria.

title: Russia Vote Is a Testing Time For a Key Friend of Clinton's
description: Nelson Strobridge Talbott 3d, Deputy Secretary of State, Russia expert, renowned journalist and graduate-school classmate of Bill Clinton, stopped dead in front of a television.

title: Religion Journal;Israeli Events Reshape a Reform Leader's Speech
description: In recent weeks, as Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie began drafting the sermon he is to give today at his installation as president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, he drew up a call to strengthen religious learning and a sense of spirituality among North America's 1.3 million Reform Jews, which the union represents.

title: POLITICS: THE RACE ISSUE;Powell Strongly Defends Use of Racial Preferences
description: A strongly worded defense of racial preferences by Gen. Colin L. Powell has angered conservatives and heartened liberals and could cause headaches within the Presidential campaign of Senator Bob Dole, who still hopes to persuade the popular general to be his running mate.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Mayor Backs Police in Melee
description: Mayor James Bishop said he was confident that his Police Department acted with appropriate restraint during a melee in which several officers were injured after a stabbing Wednesday night, but he said the Essex County Prosecutor's office and the local police would investigate. Five officers were injured in a clash with a group of about 25 youths near Montclair High School. Several youths were arrested, mainly on assault charges.

title: COMPANY NEWS;250 MORE JOBS TO BE ELIMINATED IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, based in Maynard, Mass., said yesterday that it was eliminating 250 or more jobs during its fourth quarter, which ends this month. A spokesman would not indicate how many workers would be let go and how many would leave through attrition. Digital, the nation's third-largest computer company, also ended the third quarter with 250 fewer employees than it had at the start. The company cut 70 jobs earlier this week in its troubled personal computer business as it exits the consumer end of the PC market, a spokesman, Dan Kaferle, said.

title: Soccer Goes Back Home to England for the Euro 96 : The World Will Focus on This Ball
description: LONDON  Einstein's theory that nationalism is an infantile disease, "the measles of mankind," might explain why the world is so open to the spread of soccer.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Argyle Diamond Mine Leaving De Beers Cartel
description: The owners of the world's largest diamond-producing mine, the Argyle mine in northwest Australia, have decided to pull out of the De Beers cartel. While a blow to De Beers, a unit of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, the move is not likely to cripple the cartel. De Beers controls about 75 percent of world diamond trade through the Central Selling Organization in London.

title: Medical Accounts Won't Siphon Patients;Fixing Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH CARE BILL FAILS OVER DISPUTE BETWEEN PARTIES
description: Health insurance legislation, hailed six weeks ago by Senator Bob Dole as proof that Congress could overcome election-year stress to help ordinary Americans, foundered today on sharp disputes among Republicans and between Republicans and Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article in some editions of Business Day yesterday, about talks between the Walt Disney Company and the Hollywood producers Marcy Carsey and Tom Werner concerning the ABC entertainment division, was omitted. A corrected version appears today on page 45.

title: No Headline
description: America needs more than a new President. It needs a whole new political culture. I do not anticipate being President of the United States. My ambitions are to raise the status of the dialogue."

title: I.B.M. Endures A Rough Day On Wall St., but Finishes Up
description: Shares of the International Business Machines Corporation took a wild ride yesterday, plunging about 5 percent when trading opened, after the company had warned late Thursday of increasing pressures on its second-quarter results and several Wall Street analysts had lowered their earnings estimates.

title: Fizdale and Gold Tribute
description: A tribute to the piano duo Robert Fizdale and Arthur Gold, who performed together for more than 30 years, is to be held on Wednesday at 5:30 P.M. at Paul Hall of the Juilliard School, at Lincoln Center. Mr. Fizdale died in December at 75; Mr. Gold was 72 when he died in 1990. Speakers at the tribute, which is open to the public, include Jerome Robbins, the choreographer; Betty Comden, the lyricist, and Rosamond Bernier, the art historian. There will also be performances by Valentina Lisitsa and Alexei Kuznetsoff, who will play Poulenc's "Sonata for Two Pianos," a piece that was written for Mr. Fizdale and Mr. Gold, and by Norah Amsellem, a soprano who will sing music by Satie and DuParc.

title: TV Comedy Is Serious Business. No Joke.
description: Make it real. Make it funny. But don't tell a joke.

title: Journal;D'Amato's $37,125 Flip
description: So much for all those felony convictions in Little Rock: Bill Clinton remains 20 points ahead in the polls. Why does everyone still not care about Whitewater?

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Attacks The President On Plagiarism And Honesty
description: Bob Dole called President Clinton everything but a liar today, saying the President had "plagiarized" Republican ideas, had given the country "zig-zag leadership" and that voters were "looking for someone to tell the truth."

title: World News Briefs;Official of Khmer Rouge Says Pol Pot Is Alive
description: A Khmer Rouge official based at the guerrillas' stronghold in Phnom Malai, Cambodia, today denied reports that the group's leader, Pol Pot, is dead.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCCORMICK, SPICE PRODUCER, PLANS PRETAX CHARGE
description: McCormick & Company, the spice producer, whose profits have been falling, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $57 million this quarter for restructuring moves that would reduce sales about 5 percent. McCormick, based in Sparks, Md., said it would close a packaging plant in Brooklyn, sell a dehydrating operation in Cairo, and also sell a number of small noncore businesses. It said that in parts of the United States it would change from a direct sales force to a broker sales force. As a result, sales will be reduced by about 5 percent, it said. McCormick earned $97.5 million, or $1.20 a share, on sales of $1.86 billion in 1995.

title: Humana Sees Weak Profit This Quarter; Stock Drops
description: Shares of Humana Inc. fell 18 percent yesterday after the company cut its second-quarter earnings forecast, saying an unexpectedly large number of patients in its health plans had visited hospitals and medical specialists.

title: A Surge in Jobs Shows Strength In the Economy
description: Employers added twice as many workers as had been expected to their payrolls in May, Government figures showed today, giving new signs that the economy has been picking up momentum. The report sent interest rates soaring and raised fears on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to slow growth to prevent a jump in inflation.

title: Baseball Hall of Famer Is Sentenced in Tax Case
description: Willie McCovey used to sign autographs for fans with a smile, even though he was in pain from bum knees. Yesterday, there was no smile, but there was a hint of pain.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Observer;Reading For Bill And Bob
description: Summer reading is supposed to be reading you can do while in a coma and not miss a thing. This is a perversion; originally summer reading was meant to be difficult reading, the kind of reading you couldn't do in the bleak winter without overloading patience, eyes and soul.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A $410 Million Sale of Hard Rock Cafes
description: The Rank Organization said today that it had bought the popular Hard Rock Cafe chain and rights to its brand name from Peter Morton, co-founder of the original Hard Rock restaurant, for $410 million in cash.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the "America's Smithsonian" exhibition opening on Tuesday at the New York Coliseum described the admission policy incompletely. Admission is free, but tickets are required. A limited number will be available daily at the door beginning at 9 A.M. Others must be ordered in advance by telephone, with a service charge of $3.50 apiece. The reservation number is (800) 913-TOUR.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police Changes in Camden
description: A week ago, the State Police stopped patrolling New Jersey's most crime-ridden city after nearly six months of emergency assistance. Yesterday, the Camden Police Chief, George Pugh, said that schedules and duties would be rearranged on the 348-member city Police Department to put more officers on the streets during peak crime hours.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees A Team The Tigers Can Beat
description: Joe Torre sounded like baseball's version of Lou Holtz when he mentioned how he dreaded opposing the terrible Tigers tonight. He conceded he was "nervous" about the first-place Yankees opposing the last-place Tigers. Huh?
