title: Strong Capital in Pension Settlement
description: In a settlement with the Department of Labor, Strong Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee agreed this week to pay $6.9 million to reimburse pension fund clients for trading activities that violated the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, which is commonly known as Erisa.

title: Jerry Plotkin, 62, Who Spent 444 Days as a Hostage in Iran
description: Jerry Plotkin, the only nongovernment worker among 52 Americans held hostage for 444 days in the United States Embassy in Iran, died on Thursday in a San Fernando Valley hospital. He was 62.

title: World News Briefs;Nazi War Crimes Witness Hurt in Jump From Hotel
description: A former Nazi officer broke his pelvis today after jumping 15 feet from a second-story hotel terrace in an apparent effort to flee before he was to testify against another SS officer accused of war crimes in World War II.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HUGE INVESTMENT PLANNED FOR TRANSMISSION DIVISION
description: The General MotorsCorporation will invest $275 million in its Allison Transmission division in Indianapolis to modernize its plant and add a new automatic transmission line. The investment will enable Allison to produce transmissions for large-sized pickups. Production will begin in 1999. Allison has traditionally concentrated on automatic transmissions for large heavy-duty trucks, buses and off-highway vehicles. Modernization work at the Indianapolis plant is expected to be completed in 1998.

title: Stoopball? Ringalevio? Hey, It's the 90's!;Flash, Speed and Money Replace Old Street Games For Children of the City
description: It is almost time to put the school year to bed, so let the summer street games begin. In the brick courtyard of Confucius Plaza in Chinatown, a group of teen-agers play handball against a wall obstructed by a light pole and fire plugs. They speak to each other in Chinese, but they put plenty of English on the ball.

title: Two Teen-Agers Are Arrested In Slashing of Youth on Subway
description: A 15-year-old boy was viciously slashed with a box-cutting knife early yesterday by two 17-year-olds on a subway train in the Bronx, in what the authorities said may have been a bias-related attack.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;In Bells and Microtones, A Legend Comes to Life
description: Charles Ives's "Universe Symphony" started out as a musical rumor, almost a folk legend. Stories were told of a mad sketch for orchestras playing atop mountains, voicing the murmur of nature and the music of the spheres. It was taken for granted that the symphony could not be realized on Ives's terms. The myth of Ives as a craggy prophet implied that only later, better-heeled composers could undertake such complex schemes. (Enter Karlheinz Stockhausen.)

title: Sports of the Times;No-Names Need Not Apply
description: HUNDREDS of miles from where John Calipari was being anointed king of Continental Arena, Butch Beard was leaning over a balcony in a small gymnasium here yesterday, trying not to fall over the edge and right on out of the N.B.A.

title: At Hearing, Washington's Leaders Protest the Closing of PennsylvaniaAvenue
description: What was considered a simple solution to a serious security problem, the closing of Pennsylvania Avenue and two nearby blocks in front of the White House, provoked much protest today at a House subcommittee hearing.

title: Must Tennis Now Be Game, Set, Grunt?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Journal;In These Frazzled Times, Finding Time for Tea
description: Tendrils of steam plumed from the teapot's spout as Yip Wai-man splashed the parchment-thin ceramic thimbles with boiling water. Then, in a liquid ballet, he filled a tiny red clay pot with water, spilled tea into a blue and white china jug and carefully poured a mouthful of pale amber liquid into each thimble.

title: Let Organ-Donor Family Make Dignified Choice;Not Before Death
description: To the Editor:

title: E.D.S. Regains Independence From G.M.
description: Electronic Data Systems, which was sold by Ross Perot to the General Motors Corporation for $2.5 billion in 1984, finally won its independence back from G.M. today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALUMINA PRODUCTION TO BE CUT 350,000 METRIC TONS
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would cut its annual alumina production by 350,000 metric tons, or about 3.3 percent, because of weaker demand for the material, which is used to make aluminum. Alcoa is the world's largest maker of alumina through Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals, its 60 percent owned joint venture with WMC Ltd. of Australia. Alcoa World Alumina produced 10.6 million metric tons of alumina last year at refineries in Australia, Brazil, Suriname, Jamaica and the United States. Alcoa will immediately begin curtailing alumina production worldwide to bring it "into balance with market demand," said Al Posti, a spokesman for the Pittsburgh-based company. Alumina is a white powdery material that is refined from the mineral bauxite and used to make aluminum.

title: Don't Destroy Cicadas' Woodland Shelters
description: To the Editor: Re "Cicadas: They're Back!" (Science Times, June 4), on the reappearance after 17 years of the generation of cicadas designated as Brood II:

title: TENNIS;Sampras Is Depleted And Defeated
description: He referred to himself as a car that ran out of gas, a balloon that popped, a Center Court sleepwalker who was too tired to heed his wake-up call, a disappointed man who came painfully close to attaining a Grand Slam honor so rare that only four men in the history of tennis have ever achieved it.

title: Swiss Diplomat Resists U.S. On Certifying Bosnian Vote
description: The Swiss diplomat in charge of determining whether conditions exist for fair elections in Bosnia is resisting intense pressure from the Clinton Administration to announce that the vote should go ahead as scheduled in September, according to Swiss and American diplomats.

title: Election Fraud Charges Filed Against Mexico's Ruling Party
description: Prosecutors here say they have determined that the governing party spent $38.8 million -- more than 30 times the legal amount -- to win a 1994 election in Tabasco, a crucial oil state where the opposition has been pressing accusations of electoral fraud.

title: Surge in Jobs Stirs Fears of an Increase In Interest Rates : Don't Brake Economy, Clinton Tells Central Bank
description: NEW YORK  The U.S. economy created double the number of jobs in May that was forecast, prompting President Bill Clinton to appeal to the Federal Reserve Board not to raise interest rates and kill the nation's economic expansion in an election year.

title: Let Organ-Donor Family Make Dignified Choice;Smell of Money
description: To the Editor: I take exception to Lloyd M. Krieger's article suggesting honorariums for the harvesting of donor organs (Op-Ed, June 5). While it is true many die while awaiting organ transplantation, it is also true that transplantation remains experimental.

title: BASEBALL;A Team Built on Pitching Takes a Shelling
description: General Manager Joe McIlvaine believes that the Mets, despite residing in last place in the National League East, can still contend for a wild-card berth this season.

title: World News Briefs;Burmese Dissident Plans To Ignore Ban on Meeting
description: A leading Burmese advocate for democracy, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, said in a statement today that she would go ahead with her regular weekend meeting in defiance of a Government ban.

title: Correction: Retailers' Sales in May
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday of the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index appeared with many bars partly obscured. Here is a corrected chart.

title: Music in Review
description: The Penetrating Power Of Chinese Instruments Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra Alice Tully Hall

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL ENERGY GROUP AGREES TO AN ACQUISITION
description: National Energy Group Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Alexander Energy Corporation for about $64 million in stock and $44 million in assumed debt. Each share of Oklahoma City-based Alexander will be exchanged for 1.7 shares of National Energy, under the terms of the definitive agreement. In January, when National Energy first said it would acquire Alexander, the proposed price was $129 million, including $48 million in debt. Dallas-based National Energy had revenue of $7.9 million in 1995. Alexander Energy's revenue was $19.2 million. National Energy shares fell 18.75 cents, to $2.9375, and Alexander's shares rose 43.75 cents, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: U.S. Sues New York Police Department in Sex-Harassment Case
description: The Federal Government filed suit against the New York City Police Department yesterday, charging that a female police officer assigned to a Queens precinct was subjected to "constant and pervasive" sexual harassment by male officers who watched pornographic movies in the precinct lounge and posted sexually explicit pictures in the station house marked with her name.

title: Company Briefs
description: GALEY & LORD INC., New York, a manufacturer of cotton fabrics, acquired Dimmit Industries S.A. de C.V. of Mexico, a clothing subsidiary of Farah Inc., El Paso, for $22.5 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Businesses Turn Less Bearish
description: Japanese industrial leaders are becoming more optimistic about the economy but remain divided on prospects for a durable recovery, according to a quarterly survey released yesterday by the Bank of Japan. The central bank's "tankan" survey of nearly 10,000 companies found that pessimists continued to outnumber optimists, but by a smaller margin than in March.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram on Thursday showing the site in Central Park where a woman was found badly beaten misstated the day of the attack. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;On Day 1, Calipari Puts a Happy Face on Nets' Future
description: He was almost carbonated, as bubbly and inexhaustible as an infomercial star, a sharply dressed guy who was pumping and pushing and promoting a product few would know about if he didn't own the time slot.

title: Israeli Executives Urge Moderation on Netanyahu
description: Israeli business leaders, who overwhelmingly supported Shimon Peres in the race for Prime Minister, are now urging the more hawkish winner, Benjamin Netanyahu, to show moderation on security issues in an effort to avoid scaring away potential domestic and foreign investors.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Once Again, Rodman Is Most Valuable Bull
description: He is a man who fanatically attaches himself to a cause at any particular moment. In Game 2 of the finals, with his team about to give Seattle a grand opportunity to win in the last seconds, Dennis Rodman's cause was to track down the basketball.

title: Jan Kerouac, 44, the Novelist And Daughter of a Beat Icon
description: Jan Kerouac, a novelist and the only child of the Beat Generation's icon Jack Kerouac, died on Wednesday at Lovelace Medical Center here. She was 44.

title: POLITICS: A THIRD PARTY;Ex-Governor of Colorado Hints at Perot Party Bid
description: Giving the strongest hint yet that he might want to compete for the Presidential nomination of Ross Perot's Reform Party, former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado yesterday urged Coloradans to sign petitions that would give a candidate from the third party a line on the 1996 state ballot.

title: About New York;South Bronx: Despite Hype, Hope Builds
description: TRINITY AVENUE and East 158th Street in the Bronx was once littered with castoffs: charred skeletons of stolen cars, mounds of illegally dumped debris, skinny prostitutes who plied their trade in an abandoned school.

title: No Lost Sleep At Governor's Over Budget
description: With the record for the latest budget ever looming hours away, Gov. George E. Pataki was asked today what he would be doing at 4:52 Saturday morning, the moment the state is to pass that dubious milestone.

title: Medical Accounts Won't Siphon Patients
description: To the Editor: I am amazed at your continued opposition to medical savings accounts.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;BBA Says It Will Not Make a Bid for Lucas
description: BBA Group P.L.C. announced today that it would not make a bid for Lucas Industries P.L.C., removing the chief obstacle to Lucas's planned $2 billion takeover of the Varity Corporation of Buffalo.

title: Cali Cartel Chief Confesses
description: The leader of the world's most powerful drug cartel has confessed to charges of drug trafficking in return for a reduced sentence.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Ballet Rooted in the Details
description: Alonzo King is a choreographer whose sensibilities and reputation owe as much to dance on the East Coast as to his work in San Francisco, where his Lines Contemporary Ballet company is based. The two New York premieres presented by Lines on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater had an intriguingly bicoastal feel, as well as the stamp of an unmistakably individual voice.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IDT IN FINAL NEGOTIATIONS TO TAKE OVER ECONOPHONE
description: The IDT Corporation, which provides international telephone and Internet services, said yesterday that it was negotiating the final terms of a deal to acquire Econophone Inc. Econophone, a closely held New York City-based company, provides full telephone services in the United States and long-distance service in Britain. It had annualized telecommunications revenue of about $50 million as of June 3. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. IDT, based in Hackensack, N.J., said its strategy was to bundle telephone service with Internet access and expand its overseas Internet operations.

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Forsberg's Family Ties Pay Off
description: A day before facing the Florida Panthers in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals here on Thursday, Peter Forsberg confided to his father that his legs felt very heavy. Then the son went out and scored three goals in the first period, propelling the Colorado Avalanche to an 8-1 victory that left the Panthers more or less on their last legs.

title: Tree That Grew in Brooklyn Is Dying All Over New York
description: Throughout New York City, in the public parks as well as in the grittiest neighborhoods, where it is often the sole provider of natural shade in a landscape of asphalt and crumbling brick, the tree of heaven is dead or dying.

title: Whitewater Panel Cancels Questioning
description: With only a week left in its Whitewater investigation, a Senate panel canceled plans to question President Clinton's chief accuser, who refuses to speak unless ordered by a court or given immunity.

title: White House Says Request For F.B.I. Files Was Wider
description: Senior White House officials said tonight that they had discovered new facts about a White House request to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for information about an employee who was dismissed in 1993, showing that the request was an innocent mistake.

title: Lily Auchincloss, 74, Trustee At the Museum of Modern Art
description: Lily Auchincloss, a philanthropist and major supporter of the Museum of Modern Art, the American Academy in Rome and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 74.

title: Political Memo;The Question Is Raised Once Again: Is Giuliani Really a Republican?
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the week with a sharp attack on the chairman of New York State's Republican Party, accusing him of party bossism, and ended it with a rebuke of Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee. The question after all of this is: Does he still consider himself a Republican at all?

title: Music in Review
description: High-Flying Spirituality Over Low-Down Rhythms Me'Shell Ndegeocello Mercury Lounge

title: HORSE RACING;Big Field Set to Contest Last Jewel of '96 Crown
description: The Triple Crown will come to an end today when New York stages the 128th running of the Belmont Stakes with no sweep of the series possible but with fanfare, summery weather, a large crowd and a field of 15 horses that will match the record cast of 13 years ago. It will be New York's grandest day at the races since last October, when the Breeders' Cup was held at Belmont Park.

title: City Asks Tree Lovers To Fill Their Buckets
description: First came a late summer drought in 1995, then the snowiest winter on record. Now for the 500,000 trees along New York City's sidewalks comes a manmade scourge that may prove worse than anything conjured up by nature.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BOXING;Breland Triumphs in Garden
description: Just when his contemporaries are saying goodbye, Mark Breland is saying hello. He returned to Madison Square Garden last night after 10 years, a time during which he won and lost two welterweight championships, and he won a decision from an overmatched but dogged Darryl Lattimore.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bailout Measure Advances in Japan
description: The lower house of Japan's Parliament approved a $6.3 billion Government cleanup plan today for the country's defunct housing lenders.

title: In a Swirling Storm, the Fed Governors Stay Calm
description: By 9:15 this morning, when the Federal Reserve Governor Lawrence B. Lindsey arrived at his office, the bond market had already rendered its judgment on the news, released 45 minutes earlier, that employment growth in May was stronger than expected: It sent long-term interest rates sharply higher in the expectation that the Fed would soon tighten monetary policy to cool down an economy at risk of overheating.

title: COMPANY NEWS;$1.9 BILLION OFFER FROM CONRAIL IS REJECTED
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected Conrail Inc.'s revised $1.9 billion offer to acquire major portions of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation's system. Conrail said on Wednesday that it increased by $400 million its previously rejected offer to Union Pacific for Southern Pacific's eastern lines. Conrail sought to buy Southern Pacific lines running from Chicago to Houston; between Houston and New Orleans, and throughout Texas, Louisiana and Arkansas. Philadelphia-based Conrail initially offered $1.5 billion last September for the lines after the proposed merger between Southern Pacific and Union Pacific was announced. Union Pacific rejected the offer. The merger has run into opposition from Federal agencies and some shippers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bank Robber Dies in Crash
description: A bank robber who led a dozen police cars on a 20-mile chase from Middletown Township onto the Garden State Parkway and Route 35 was killed yesterday afternoon when his truck hit a tree, the police said. The man, Gordon Maxon, 43, of Oakhurst, robbed a Midlantic Bank of about $7,700 at gunpoint, the police said.

title: GOLF;Els Plays Big for a Big Cushion
description: Ernie Els has that look again, that effortlessly powerful mein, a bearing that says he is back in control of his enormous game. For the second day in a row, the big man from South Africa tore into the West Course at Westchester Country Club, adding a 66 to his first-round 65 and padding his lead in the Buick Classic to five strokes over David Frost and Craig Parry and six over Greg Norman and Kevin Sutherland.

title: George Davis Snell, 92, Dies; Won Nobel for Genetics Work
description: Dr. George Davis Snell, an authority on genetics and tissue transplantation who shared a Nobel Prize in 1980 for milestone research that helped make human organ transplants possible, died on Thursday at his home in Bar Harbor, Me. He was 92.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENENTECH SET TO END DEVELOPMENT OF CANCER DRUG
description: Genentech Inc. said yesterday that it would stop developing its drug Actimmune as a treatment for renal cell carcinoma because of clinical data that showed the drug caused no significant benefit for the condition. Genentech, a San Francisco-based biotechnology company, said patients treated with Actimmune fared no better than a group that was administered placebos. Renal cell carcinoma is a type of cancer that attacks the kidneys. Genentech said the findings do not change the current recommendations for Actimmune in treating chronic granulomatous disease, an immunodeficiency disorder. Genentech's stock slipped 25 cents, to $52.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Payton Jaws At Jordan
description: Gary Payton could not contain himself any longer. One of the league's most animated trash talkers finally traded words with Michael Jordan in the final seconds of Game 2 tonight, and His Airness responded with a few barbs of his own.

title: Fierce Foes Encroach On Superstores' Territory;New Rivals Appear Around Every Corner
description: Here in suburban Houston, there is a store packed with enough home-decorating plunder to fill the floor of the Astrodome twice over.

title: Let Organ-Donor Family Make Dignified Choice;Better a Tax Credit
description: To the Editor: In "A Life-and-Death Proposal" (Op-Ed, June 5), Lloyd M. Krieger proposes a funeral honorarium to address the shortage of organ donors. Rational citizens could hardly be persuaded to complete an organ donor card on the tiny chance their family would be spared funeral costs.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;B Sky B Renews Deal For Broadcasting Soccer
description: British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to pay L670 million ($1 billion), almost four times what it paid previously, to renew its multiyear contract to show English Premier League soccer from 1997. B Sky B, 40 percent owned by the News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, now has more than 5.3 million subscribers.

title: Budget Chaos in Albany
description: The histrionics and legislative scare tactics that surround every negotiation on a New York State budget have reached a frantic pitch. With political attitudes shifting in New York and elsewhere, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle increasingly feel they must defy Gov. George Pataki and reject his demands for sharp cuts in education and social programs. A week of intense negotiations has failed to break the impasse. What all sides need to do now is take a deep breath and recognize that they cannot have everything they want, set priorities and negotiate a deal that protects those who most depend on government for their survival.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Amnesty Yields Millions
description: Collections of delinquent taxes totaled $313 million during the tax amnesty period from March 15 to June 1, with 15,000 last-minute checks yet to be counted, The A.P. said. Those payments could reach another $7 million, the taxation director, Richard Gardiner, said.

title: Bail Ruling Reignites Verbal War
description: For politicians, it's been easy pickings to attack judges as soft on crime: some rulings struck many as outrageous, and the judges themselves have chosen not to reply, believing that silence, however pained, is the seemly response.

title: The Unfair War on Alan Greenspan
description: Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has single-handedly blocked a vote to confirm Alan Greenspan's reappointment as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Greenspan will no doubt be approved, eventually. But the annoying delay could grow worse if, as is now threatened, his confirmation is tied to that of a number of controversial judicial nominations.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects Albany Limit On Medicaid Clients' Home Care
description: In a victory for thousands of disabled and elderly people, a Federal judge in Manhattan ordered the state yesterday to stop limiting Medicaid applicants to four hours a day of home-based health care.

title: Islamic Party Gets 2d Chance To Form Coalition in Turkey
description: Turkey's Islamic party, still treated as a pariah by much of the mainstream political establishment, was offered another chance to form a government yesterday as President Suleyman Demirel looked for a way out of the country's continuing political deadlock.

title: Princeton Grads Wanted Wisdom, Not Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Independent Rolls Grow
description: New voter-registration figures indicate why both President Clinton and his presumed Republican opponent, Bob Dole, are already campaigning hard in New Jersey. The number of registered independent voters in the state is up nearly 20 percent since 1992, to 2,149,135 from 1,792,488, according to figures provided yesterday by John McCullough, a spokesman for the New Jersey Secretary of State, Lonna R. title: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS
description: Thurow has officially opened the season on elder bashing. He sees the elderly pitted against children, in their opposition to school taxes and in huddling in retirement communities that exclude the young to avoid having to pay school taxes. Let's forget that 75 percent of the elderly are homeowners and live mostly in the communities where they have always lived and where they continue to pay school taxes. This is an increasing trend toward "aging in place," which means that the elderly prefer intergenerational communities. But even in retirement areas like Fort Lauderdale, they pay school taxes. Let's also forget that grandparents are emerging as the primary care-givers for children in single-parent households or those with two working parents -- a vital contribution to the economic well-being of the nation.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;An Animated Life
description: At the age of 21, Bill Hanna decided that he "would be blissfully happy if I could make cartoons for the rest of my life." As he says in A CAST OF FRIENDS (Taylor, $22.95), written with Tom Ito, a freelance journalist, Mr. Hanna and Joe Barbera knew they were a winning combination from their first meeting, in 1937. In short order, their collaboration produced Tom and Jerry, the classic cat-and-mouse team. When they founded Hanna-Barbera Productions in 1957, the two were pioneers gambling that their new limited animation techniques would enable cartoons to move from movie screen to television. Huckleberry Hound, Yogi Bear and Boo Boo, the Flintstones and the Jetsons, among many others, were the result. Now 85, still happily at work in his "cartoon quarry," Mr. Hanna pays tribute to wife, family, animation colleagues and employees while giving his two children and seven grandchildren credit for helping him bridge the generation gap. To this day, he watches pencil sketches evolve into exuberant cinematic fantasy and always finds the result "somewhat astonishing." He takes the reader backstage and lets him feel that excitement. "Cartoons," he says, "symbolize enchantment." The fellow who obligingly screeched and yowled on cue to give voice to Tom and Jerry in the early years has never lost sight of the grand vision that captivated him as a youngster. Leslie Chess Feller

title: ART;Personal Responses To a Page of History
description: FORTY-TWO years have passed since the Supreme Court ordered schools to integrate "with all deliberate speed." But heavily black and Hispanic schools still proliferate, not least in New Jersey, whose schools remain among the nation's most segregated.

title: The Morgue Is Alive
description: IT IS NOWHERE RECORDED just how and wherefore the name "morgue" first came to be given to the archives that newspapers keep of their own materials. It almost certainly happened more than 100 years ago -- within a century during which the French word, meaning "a haughty and contemptuous attitude," came to be applied (rather mysteriously) to the building in Paris that temporarily housed the transient and unknown dead. The forgotten newsroom wordsmith who took the word to its next stage performed a wonderful act of compression -- of poetry, really.

title: FACETS OF CLINTON
description: Of all the possible photographs of President Clinton that you might have used, why did you choose one that is all but a caricature of the man? Your politics are showing.

title: Two Workers In the Field
description: When I saw the photo of the auger and tree planting ["At Halsey Farm, It's Bees, Apples, Flowers and Doughnuts," April 21] it reminded me of a story I heard that I turned into a poem. I rewrote it a bit to match the photo.

title: 100 Years of Pictures;LOOKS
description: Gosta Peterson See-through raincoats, New York City, 1965

title: A RIVER RECLAIMED: Reversing Pollution's Toll -- First of twoarticles.; Shaking Off Man's Taint, Hudson Pulses With Life
description: In his 40 years as a commercial fisherman on the Hudson River, George Kucera has seen a lot of stomach-turning things, not least the diseased striped bass he would find in his nets 30 years ago. A repulsive crust resembling cottage cheese covered many fish.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS
description: I don't know whether he was right or not, but it's interesting to consider W. H. Auden's view of memoirs: "Literary confessors are contemptible, like beggars who exhibit their sores for money, but not so contemptible as the public that buys their books." All the more elegant was "A Letter to My Mother, Carolina Oates, on Her 78th Birthday," by Joyce Carol Oates, in which Oates gives the illusion of confession but reveals nothing.

title: GARDENING;Forsythia's Gone. Get Out the Pruning Shears.
description: IT is hoped that all good gardeners have pruned their forsythia. The bright yellow flowers have long since faded. This shrub is not just one of the first major displays of spring, it is also an indicator plant for a few chores that should be done.

title: Round-the-Clock Factories Mean More Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Spinning Fantasies On Confections
description: THE 19TH-CENTURY piano transcription, which was still considered something of a guilty pleasure 20 years ago, has slowly crept back into the repertory of reputable pianists. Liszt specialists like Jorge Bolet, Stephen Hough and, more recently, Jean-Yves Thibaudet have shown that transcriptions are more than keyboard Cliff Notes and deserve to be taken seriously on their own musical terms. Even so, recordings of piano transcriptions have tended to concentrate on pieces based on the undisputed classics, with Liszt's reductions of the nine Beethoven symphonies occupying the capstone position.

title: Warning Israel, Arab Chiefs Set Summit Session
description: In a firm message directed at Israel's new conservative Government, leaders of Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia announced plans today to convene the first Arab summit meeting in six years and warned against any Israeli retreat from past commitments to peace.

title: My First Assignment
description: Susan Meiselas One of my first assignments was for Harper's Bazaar in 1973. It was about an artist who made fashion out of food. I shot this young woman wearing nothing but an asparagus vest and salami necklace. I think there were some scallions involved, too.

title: Freewheeling Net Meets Free Market
description: LAST year was the year when nearly a thousand newspapers, magazines and new-media start-ups rushed to the Internet. This year, as the bills pile up, the same gang is puzzling over how to get these electronic ventures to pay their own way.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Hearing Alarm Bells In Those Cold Calls
description: INVESTORS, brokers, readers: listen up. There are impostors among us. Would-be brokers, unlicensed and dangerously devoid of knowledge, are often cold-calling prospective clients, opening accounts and, in some cases, executing trades. The National Association of Securities Dealers, the industry watchdog, has been unable to stop these abuses of its own rules, despite some effort.

title: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS
description: A modest proposal for how to deal with the power of elderly voters: when these folks turn 65, why not just take away their voting rights?

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: AN ACTUAL LIFE By Abigail Thomas. Algonquin, $17.95.

title: WEDDINGS;Lorene Burkhart, Whit Whitehouse
description: Lorene Elizabeth Burkhart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Burkhart of New Canaan, Conn., is to be married today to Franklin S. Whitehouse 3d, the son of Lucretia P. Whitehouse of Charlotte Court House, Va., and the late Mr. Whitehouse Jr. The Rev. Michael Jude Fay is to officiate at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John in Darien, Conn.

title: Perspective;Graduation Gifts of Stardom and Expectations
description: The phone call never came last Tuesday night, the long-awaited call ringed with rainbows that would justify his coach's obsession, turn his "family adviser" into his agent and condone his own lackadaisical approach toward schoolwork. Al Hawkins was supposed to be picked in the first or second round of the amateur baseball draft and grab a ride to The Show.

title: A Presidential Scholar Who's in Touch With Life
description: JOSHUA GOODMAN'S red hair was neatly combed for this, his fifth interview in little more than a week. The graduating senior at Scarsdale High School here has been studying independently this term and was something of a visitor at the school building recently, smiling greetings at secretaries and friends as he led the way to a quiet conference room.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE ART FAIR By David Lipsky. Doubleday, $22.50.

title: James K. Woolnough, 85, Dies; General Directed Army Training
description: Gen. James Karrick Woolnough, an Army combat officer of the Battle of the Bulge and the Korean War who went on to command the First Cavalry Division as well as the Army's Vietnam-era central training command in Virginia, died on May 30 at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 85 and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: Book Notes;A Father and Son Explore Their Relationship
description: DESPITE its title, "My Father, My Son," did not begin as a book meant for Father's Day sales.

title: SOAPBOX;Why I Voted
description: Turnout in the New Jersey primary on Tuesday ranged from light to nonexistent. Partly that was because there were few major contests on the ballot, the Presidential lineup having been settled when most of the state was still under two feet of snow. And partly it was because primaries, in which one must declare an affiliation, are simply not a New Jersey habit. (As one of seven poll watchers in Northvale, Bergen County, told the lone voter who showed up at 8 A.M.: "People don't like other people knowing their party. It's like giving away your bank account number.")

title: ART;Strange Gusto Is Shown in Polish Posters
description: AS a sales medium, commercial art must meet its beholders halfway, the better and faster to seduce them. But apparently that is not enough for the Polish posters hanging in the Katonah Museum of Art here: the images, boldly drawn and filled with color, especially red, fairly descend from the walls and buttonhole visitors at the door. Not for nothing is the show titled "Combat on Paper."

title: TECHNOLOGY VIEW;True Lies: Acoustical Verity Gives Way to 'Impact'
description: FOR AS LONG AS ANY audiophile can remember, acoustical engineers have been trying to build a better loudspeaker, one that would more accurately reflect the musical sounds of the real world. Until very recently, few loudspeaker designers or consumers could have imagined any other objective; and to the extent that some speaker companies veered from the imperative of musical truth, placing visceral impact above natural verity, their creations were dismissed as anomalous and perverse.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Restaurant Neighbors Want Noise Off the Menu
description: John Van Doorn can't say he wasn't warned. When he moved into his apartment on West 72d Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue two years ago, he was told by other residents that the noise from the Dallas BBQ Restaurant across the street could be overwhelming, especially on weekends. He took the plunge anyway, figuring that as a seasoned city dweller, he could take it. Besides, he would occupy a rear apartment and was a sound sleeper.

title: Alvin Strock, 85; Advanced the Art Of Tooth Implants
description: Dr. Alvin E. Strock, a retired oral surgeon who advanced the art of tooth implants while in his residency in Boston, died on May 31 at the Alice-Peck Day Hospital in Lebanon, N.H. He was 85 and lived in Lebanon and formerly in Newton, Mass.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ If the Fed does raise interest rates, savvy investors will be looking to make money, not just minimize their losses. By Michael Brush.

title: WEDDINGS;Stella Kaplow, Jack Kwang-Huei Lee
description: Dr. Stella Ruth Kaplow, a daughter of Riena Kaplow of White Plains and the late Milton Kaplow, was married yesterday evening to Jack Kwang-Huei Lee, a son of Yun Ching and Han Chong Lee of Garden City Park, L.I., and Anaheim, Calif. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz on the Park in New York.

title: Leary's Legacy Is, Like, Flipped, Man
description: TIMOTHY LEARY was no great advocate of rules, but somebody has to keep track of them. And his death last weekend, with the attendant wash of nostalgia about the 1960's, raised a question: were you supposed to tune in before turning on and dropping out, or did you turn on first?

title: BOXING;De La Hoya Hits Hard as Chavez Blinks and Loses
description: They cleaned the ring with a mop.

title: WEDDINGS;Darcy Vassiliadis, James Wyckoff
description: Darcy Ann Vassiliadis, a daughter of Joan O'Sullivan and Archie Vassiliadis of New York, was married yesterday to James William Wyckoff, a son of Marjorie Cummings of Huntington, L.I., and the late Edward T. Wyckoff. The Rev. Donald Collier, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Bronx River Parkway Reservation in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: Elsbeary Hobbs, 59, Singer With Drifters
description: Elsbeary Hobbs, the bass singer with the rhythm-and-blues vocal group the Drifters, died on May 31 at Veterans Hospital in Manhattan. He was 59.

title: HELPING;Trying to Patch the Holes in the Safety Net (and, Sometimes, the Roof)
description: Mary Cameron is 73 now, and Alzheimer's disease has taken her memory. She has been known to wander around Newark in a fog, looking for offices where she can pay her bills with what little money she has.

title: ON THE STREET;A Flash of Silver on Black
description: As summer approaches, the deluge of all-black continues unabated and has found fresh energy in the work of the designer Tom Ford for Gucci, which is being widely worn by men and women. This spring, the market is already flooded with imitations of the Gucci look. Its signature silver-toned hardware -- belts, belt buckles, necklaces, loafers decorated with horse bits and the large "G" on the tops of boots -- have given black a new emphasis. Even backpacks and mules are marked with interlocking G's in white vinyl. Sandals have a discreet "Gucci" on the backs of the heels. A group of young men from the Ballet Hispanico, above, all wore black, in the spirit of Gucci, even to the open-front shirts with plunging V-necks. Mr. Ford's work is often compared with that of the Halston-Elsa Perretti collaboration. But Mr. Ford has made the look his own by adding his newly redesigned Gucci jewelry and the signature bamboo handle to bags.

title: CUTTINGS;Voluptuous Eggplants Love Sunbathing Weather
description: Some vegetables earn their place in the garden for productivity (like squash) and some for superior homegrown flavor (like tomatoes). Eggplant gets in on sheer beauty.

title: A Tale of Love, Art and Money;A Collector, His Secretary, Their Children, and More
description: During the decade before World War I, in a beautiful 15th-century villa overlooking the bell towers of Florence, an English art collector and his Italian secretary had an affair. Or so it is alleged.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Unincorporated Eastchester;Rich Housing Mix in Rustic Westchester
description: IN "The Lake Isle of Innisfree," the poet William Butler Yeats contemplates a life of solitary reflection on a little wooded island off the coast of Lough Gill in County Sligo, Ireland. A great place to "live alone in the bee-loud glade," he wrote, "where peace comes dropping slow."

title: WEDDINGS;Noelle Kennedy, Kevin McCulloch
description: Noelle Christine Kennedy, a daughter of Roseanne and Robert Kennedy of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Patrick McCulloch, a son of Dorothy and Stephen McCulloch of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Gerald Dentile, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Queen of the Rosary Church in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: Teachers Still See a Pocketful of Reasons to Vote No
description: Leonard Mazin, a New York City high school history teacher, voted against the last teachers contract proposal in December. He had a simple reason: his salary would have been frozen until the fall of 1997.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Hyundai Elantra;Rounding The Rough Edges
description: MY wife came through the door, frazzled from the day's work and a long commute by train, and the first words out of her mouth were these, "Whatever that is in the driveway, I'd never have such a car."

title: WEDDINGS;Anne E. Tate, Robert Massie 4th
description: Anne Elizabeth Tate, an assistant professor of architecture at the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence, was married yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Robert Kinloch Massie 4th, the executive director of the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies, a nonprofit group in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Swanson performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: UP AND COMING: NO DOUBT;All the Music They Grew Up With
description: NO DOUBT, THE SOUTHERN California ska-pop band, was a couple of hours into a recent photo shoot in a loft on the fringe of Chelsea in Manhattan. The drummer Adrian Young had his hair done up in horns. The singer Gwen Stephani kept changing outfits, switching from a 40's-style cotton dress to a pair of tartan hip huggers. The band members calmly posed in a freight elevator, then let the cameras click away while milk was poured over their heads.

title: Just the Way You Are
description: I.D. How Heredity and Experience Make You Who You Are. By Winifred Gallagher. 234 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 19 about software that permits voice communications over the Internet referred incorrectly to the technology of the leading commercial on-line services. Because of technical changes, Compuserve and America Online now permit users of some computers to communicate by voice.

title: Hungry for Books
description: Babel Tower By A. S. Byatt. 622 pp. New York: Random House. $25.95.

title: Now Give Challengers Level Electoral Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrity Scents: Simply Resistible
description: PEOPLE may love celebrities -- their clothes, their looks, their foibles. But for stars looking to cash in on the smell of their success, a message has emerged -- don't push your luck.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;New Arena, Old Strategy for a Money Manager
description: LAURA J. SLOATE'S corner office in midtown Manhattan has all the signs of a successful money manager. Piles of annual and 10-K reports swamp her desk. A computer spits out stock quotations at a rate of 240 words a minute. Several Eisenstaedt prints, including two of her favorite conductor, Leonard Bernstein, adorn the walls.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Brunger And Mark Hudson
description: Elizabeth Lawson Brunger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Brunger of Madison, Conn., was married on Friday to Mark E.C. Hudson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. T. Hudson of Redditch, England. The Rev. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: WEDDINGS;Elise Rosensweet, Bruce L. Rosen
description: Elise Sue Rosensweet, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elliott Rosensweet of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Bruce L. Rosen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry D. Rosen of Oradell, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated at the North Shore Synagogue in Syosset, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about health care referred incompletely to a newborn baby at the County Medical Center. The baby, Sabrina McCormack of New Rochelle, was born prematurely, but was healthy. She was receiving intensive care in the hospital's neonatal unit.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Postings column on May 26 about house tours in Harlem misstated the title of a novel by Ralph Ellison. It was "Invisible Man," not "The Invisible Man."

title: TENNIS;Graf Wins Wrenching French Epic
description: From ferocious to fragile and back again, Steffi Graf, the defending champion of the French Open, retained her title today in a 3-hour-3-minute epic confrontation with fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez Vicario of Spain.

title: Montauk Light, at 200
description: The first stone for the Montauk Point Lighthouse, commissioned by George Washington in 1792, was laid on June 7, 1796. Celebrations of the 200th birthday are being held throughout this month and the rest of the summer. The light, which now flashes every 5 seconds, is among the 16 Long Island lighthouses photographed by Margaret Casella of East Williston, who is campaigning to preserve the landmarks. Article and photographs, page 17.

title: Habitats/West 17th Street;For Four Decades, Waking Up to a Chelsea Morning
description: THERE is a certain raffishness about that block of Chelsea: the assemblage of buildings; the grand old tenement with the geranium-filled window boxes next to the abandoned, graffiti-scarred brick stable building; the Spanish radio program wafting through an open window. It is an afternoon block, an evening block, but not a morning block; a sense of bustle, of harsh sun, seems out of place.

title: Goatsucker's Kin
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: NO SHIRT. NO SHOES. . . . NO PROBLEM! By Jeff Foxworthy. Hyperion, $19.95.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;Rabbi Sees Hope for His Dwindling Congregation
description: Gone are the days when there was a synagogue on every block of the Lower East Side. Rabbi Jacob Spiegel remembers a time when more than 400 congregations flourished in the neighborhood, serving the half-million Jews who filled local tenements before World War II.

title: June 2-8;The Jug of Wine Just Got Older
description: In the land of Omar Khayyam, celebrator of the loaf of bread and jug of wine, people seem to have acquired a taste for the grape early on. As soon as they settled down to farming and village life, they began making and drinking wine. After a hard day in the fields of barley, a cup of cheer may have relieved the stress of living in an increasingly complex society.

title: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS
description: Never has anything I've read in the Magazine made me as angry as Lester C. Thurow's "Birth of a Revolutionary Class" (May 19). We are faulted for a lifetime of hard work and for saving our money or investing it wisely.

title: NEW FILES PROVE VIETNAM COVER-UP
description: Newly declassified Government documents prove that the United States, after sending hundreds of Vietnamese commandos into North Vietnam during the 1960's, deliberately declared them dead, lied to their wives and then buried their story under a shroud of secrecy.

title: WEDDINGS;Tyler Garvens, Paul Dougherty
description: Tyler Garvens, the daughter of Barbara Dominick of Newburgh, N.Y., and Gary Garvens of New Braunfels, Tex., was married yesterday evening to Paul Christian Dougherty, a son of Thomas Dougherty of Bethesda, Md., and the late Ann Dougherty. The Rev. Bruce Poynter performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Memorial United Methodist Church in Washington.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;Cornered In by Subway Plans
description: The storefront at the northeast corner of 16th Street and Eighth Avenue in Chelsea has been empty since Verso Books closed last January, and the owner, Michael Field, and his partners, worry that the modernization of the 14th Street subway stop for the A, C and E lines will make it unrentable despite its desirable location.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: ON BASEBALL;An Old Coach Says There's No Explaining Belle
description: Skip Bertman was trying to steer his team into yesterday's College World Series championship, and people kept asking him about a player who didn't play for him in the 1987 College World Series. "I've had so much time used up with Albert Belle," the veteran Louisiana State University coach said the other day. "I don't know what I can say to help you."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KEW GARDENS HILLS/FLUSHING;He Saw the Horror, but Everest Still Calls
description: It was just after 5 P.M. on May 11, a day after Mount Everest's worst disaster took the lives of eight climbers, when Dr. Kenneth M. Kamler got the call in his tent at Everest's Camp 3, 24,000 feet above sea level. "Beck is alive, but I don't know for how long," a fellow climber told him by radio from Camp 4, 2,000 feet farther up the mountain.

title: WEDDINGS;Shannon O'Leary, Juan A. Pujadas
description: Shannon Adair O'Leary, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John O'Leary of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Juan Adolfo Pujadas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Juan J. Pujadas of North Tarrytown, N.Y. Msgr. Walter F. Kenney performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: FILM;Bertolucci Proves You Can Go Home Again
description: AFTER COMPLETING HIS NINTH feature film in 1981, Bernardo Bertolucci decamped from Italy, disillusioned with the terrorism and corruption that were eating away at his native land. He felt he could no longer live in -- or believe in -- a country that tolerated violence and worshiped money. He kept homes in both Rome and London but, as an artist, he was eager to turn his back on Europe, preferring to set his next three films -- "The Last Emperor," "The Sheltering Sky" and "Little Buddha" -- in Asia and North Africa.

title: U.S. Case Could Shift 5 Congress Districts
description: THE oddly configured boundaries of the 5th Congressional District, which includes parts of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, may be substantially changed as a result of a redistricting case in Federal court, Representative Gary L. Ackerman, who represents the area, said last week.

title: Swimming In Evening Lowers Rates
description: FOR those who think the prettiest time of day at a beach or pool is late afternoon, there is good news: the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation has just lowered admission to its swimming spots from 4 to 6 P.M.

title: FACETS OF CLINTON
description: If, as Purdum writes, Clinton must co-opt the Republican legislative agenda to remain viable, if he is so ethically and morally compromised that he has essentially forfeited the bully pulpit, he can nonetheless offer himself to the electorate as the Great Empathizer. But therein lies the trap: are we as a people so mired in self-pity that we would rehire him chiefly to fill that role? Do we now regard the Presidency as a kind of office of national shrink?

title: Mayor and Council Seem to Be Near a Deal on School Repairs
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the Democratic leaders of the City Council have neared an agreement on a plan to spend more than $1 billion to repair New York City's crumbling public schools over the next four years, officials on both sides said yesterday as their budget talks intensified.

title: The Magellan Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Roads to China: Nice, and Not So Nice
description: AFTER this month, in an extraordinary example of corporate diplomacy, the Boeing Company will airlift its entire board to China. Ostensibly, the directors will simply be holding their regular bimonthly meeting there, while touring sites like the vast construction hangars in Xian where, with Boeing's help, tens of thousands of workers are trying to transform China into a world-class aerospace power.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer L. Payne, Andre H. Gray
description: Jennifer Lynn Payne, the daughter of Carolyn and King Tillinghast Payne of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday to Andre Hardin Gray, a son of Katherine Hardin Gray and Donald Milton Gray Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Bradley C. Davis performed the ceremony at the New York Yacht Club Harbour Court in Newport, R.I.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;Dublin's Charms Are as Quiet As Its Fog
description: Correction Appended

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: BRENDAN PRAIRIE By Dan O'Brien. Scribner, $22.

title: June 2-8;. . . As Clinton Ups the Ante . . .
description: For 18 months, President Clinton has pressed the Republican-controlled Congress, in vain, to pass a $10,000 annual tax deduction for college education. But that didn't stop Mr. Clinton from trumping himself last week, with a new proposal for a $1,500-per-child tax rebate to offset the first two years of college tuition for families earning up to $100,000 a year. Any high school graduate would qualify for the first-year credit, but to keep it would have to maintain a B average. Families could choose either the deduction or the direct credit.

title: WEDDINGS;Lucy E. Perera, Matthew J. Adams
description: Lucy Elizabeth Perera, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence T. Perera of Boston, was married yesterday to Matthew James Adams, a son of James T. Adams 2d of Green Valley, Ariz., and Joan Lockwood Adams of Denver. The Rev. Alexander S. Daley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandfather Guido Perera in Yarmouth Port, Mass.

title: SOAPBOX;Passing a Literary Torch
description: WALT WHITMAN alone gives Brooklyn a glorious poetic history: he said his "Leaves of Grass" was influenced by his years there. And Brooklyn is the only borough to have a poet laureate. The latest holder of the title is Dennis Nurkse, a Brooklynite who has had three collections of poetry published. A 1970 graduate of Harvard University, he has taught at The New School and numerous workshops. He succeeds the first Brooklyn laureate, Norman Rosten, who died last year. Three other poets with Brooklyn ties were finalists: Edward Field, the author of eight books of poetry; Gale Patricia Jackson, who teaches at Medgar Evers College, and Louis Reyes Rivera, an instructor at Pratt Institute. Mr. Nurkse, pictured at right, will accept the honor at 1:30 P.M. today at the Brooklyn Public Library. Here are excerpts from the four finalists' work:

title: Laughing for a Living
description: If work can be so ludicrous, so comical, why all the long faces out there? Although our jobs can be stressful, they also give us so much to chuckle about. We know everyone is telling jokes around the water cooler or the copy machine. So share them with us. Send your best office jokes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A LA CARTE;In Hicksville, a Place to Savor Foods of India
description: AN Indian woman, her flowing pink sari billowing in the breeze, carried a child as she left the Bombay Trading Company with a compact disk containing the music of her homeland. Another, garbed in an elaborate pale blue sari, emerged from Maharaja Groceries a few doors down with a bag full of spices. The scene took place recently in Long Island's tiny, but growing Indian enclave in Hicksville.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Three Spanish Inns Offer Cooking Lessons
description: Three of Spain's government-run hotels, or paradors -- noted for their regional cuisine -- have begun offering a week of cooking classes that combine culinary instruction with sightseeing excursions into the countryside.

title: N.J. LAW;Child-Support Payments Under Review, With Cuts Likely
description: New Jersey is updating its four-year-old guidelines for determining child-support payments, basing the changes on new estimates of how much it costs to raise a family. But if the State Supreme Court accepts the revisions, payments for thousands of children will actually drop.

title: IN THE WORKS;A Dramatic Change of Address
description: Last week, developers announced a play to move the Empire Theater 170 feet west on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. The move, planned for the late fall, is part of an effort to preserve as much of the 93-year-old landmark theater, which as a designated landmark cannot be demolished but which blocks access to a large amount of space at its present site. The theater, which is to become the lobby and ticketing area for a new AMC multiplex cinema, weighs four million pounds. Preparations will take three months; the actual move will take three days.

title: NUISANCES;In Season: They Bite, They Sting. Beware.
description: Every year, just about, is a good year for insects. But this year in New Jersey is shaping up to be a very good year indeed, particularly for insects that menace and pester humans.

title: NOTICED;The Hotel Where Worlds Collide (Art, Film, Fashion and Nether)
description: TAKE "Stage Door," the fabled 1937 movie about a Broadway rooming house; crosscut it with "The Chelsea Girls"; add a touch of "The Rocky Horror Picture Show," and you get some notion of the atmosphere at the Gershwin Hotel, 7 East 27th Street.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: TALKING TO ANGELS A Life Spent in High Latitudes. By Robert Perkins. Beacon, $18.

title: New Curbs for Skaters to Trip Up On
description: Rollerblading, which 25 million Americans now do, is revolutionizing New York's cityscape.

title: FOOD;Fine Points of Grilling Seafood
description: SEAFOOD on the grill may dominate the menu for the next three months. Skewering seafood simplifies preparation and serving.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ART FOR 1996

title: Tax on Assets Provokes Suits in Pennsylvania
description: Montgomery County officials have sent out tax bills but are uncertain whether they will be paid because of lawsuits challenging the constitutionality of the county's tax on personal assets.

description: FOR centuries lighthouses have stood as the seafarers' beacons, the prime notification of danger ahead. Long Island's lighthouses have also served as a welcoming sign to whalers and others in search of safe land.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS
description: Once again, the novel has been pronounced dead. Your special issue "True Confessions" (May 12) was enjoyable insofar as it was eminently skimmable -- we could pick up the high points of one writer's life, take a glance at another's style and go our way. James Atlas's optimism about the correlation between the boom in memoirs and the reading habits of Americans is misplaced. We tend to read Michael Ryan's poignant memoir to get to the scene about sex with his dog, and Mary Karr's to get to the house afire. If this is "delivering the news," it's doing so in word bites. A good novel, on the other hand, cannot be skimmed -- the meaning lies not in "the journey from there to here," but in the moments along the way, which transcend one individual's blinkered existence to yield truths going way beyond the news.

I am excited, thinking someone is at last writing to and for those of us who travel alone. But in turning to the information on rates, one searches in vain for any indication of a single rate. How intimidating this is. Does this mean that the inns really don't want to be bothered with us, or that we will be turned away, as has happened to me in some places in Britain? title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Philadelphia Story
description: Even the air is palpable in TUMBLING (Morrow, $24), Diane McKinney-Whetstone's engaging first novel about a 1950's community threatened with gentrification. In the working-class black Philadelphia neighborhood that serves as the book's setting, the woeful plaint of Mahalia Jackson records mingles with the perfume of backyard honeysuckle. But the city's insidious attempts to buy out homeowners eventually spill into the domestic world of Herbie and Noon, a young couple whose lives have already been rerouted after not one but two little girls are abandoned on their doorstep. Herbie and Noon are more successful as parents than as spouses and they salve their marital wounds independently: Herbie in a nightclub singer's bed and Noon in her church and in her fight against the city's plans. But they are true partners in the love and care of their children, especially Fannie, who came first and who charms and frightens them with her occasional clairvoyance. Though the book's end is bluntly forecast from early on and more than a few events are puzzlingly unexplained, the story moves forward on the power of Ms. McKinney-Whetstone's characters. Herbie and Noon's neighbors -- from the meanspirited petty bureaucrat across the street, desperate to protect her meager authority, to the well-intentioned but miscalculating local pastor, who falls prey to his own pride -- are never merely props. Through these and other deftly portrayed individuals, whose wrongdoing stems more from fallibility than intent, Ms. McKinney-Whetstone captures the formidable struggle to protect both a community and a family. Lise Funderburg

title: No Radon Peril On the Island
description: Long Island homeowners needn't worry about radon ["Home Clinic, Testing for the Presence of Radon," April 14]. Why? Because Long Island does not have a radon problem. While radon is a naturally occurring gas, which means there has always been radon in the air, the United States Environmental Protection Agency states that concentrations of radon on Long Island are extremely low. Nassau County registered the lowest average level in New York State -- 1.6 picocuries per liter of air. Suffolk registers 2.0. The E.P.A. considers a reading below 4.0 to be acceptable.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;A Happy Medium on Prices
description: SOMETIMES it seems as though the world is divided neatly into spendthrifts and misers. On the one hand, you can't look out the window for more than a minute without seeing a dozen people go by looking mortgaged to the hilt. On the other, there is always someone in the office who brags about the peanut-butter sandwiches he takes on business trips.

It was to be a city like no other in the workers' paradise, a place where the unhindered ideals of socialism would fuel the quest for perfect truth.

title: The Subjective Eye
description: IT WAS THE MORNING THE GROUND WAR IN KUWAIT began, Feb. 24, 1991, and Sebastiao Salgado was on the phone from Venezuela. Salgado was already well known for his photographs of workers around the world, the first of which -- gold miners in Para, Brazil -- had appeared in the Magazine four years earlier. Now, he said, he wanted to go to Kuwait once the war was over, to photograph oil-field workers in the desert, where the fleeing Iraquis had rancorously set hundreds of wells afire. Would the Magazine send him? Would he be able to get in? How? Every great work of photojournalism begins on the phone.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: EAST HARLEM;Misery Compounded: Life in El Barrio, Life With AIDS
description: Life has always been hard in El Barrio, where teen-age pregnancy, poverty and drug addiction lurk beneath the merengue music and buoyant street life of upper Lexington Avenue. These days, AIDS is adding to East Harlem's misery, where, health officials say, one of every 35 adults is infected with the virus that causes the disease.

title: Shutting the Fresh Kills Dump
description: New Yorkers love their superlatives. Not long ago, someone thought that the world's biggest garbage landfill, sprawling across 3,000 acres of Staten Island, could even serve as a tourist draw. But the Fresh Kills dump is an environmental disaster that politicians have long promised to shut down. The problem has been that no readily available alternative exists for the city's garbage. Now, lawsuits and the growing ire of Staten Islanders have forced the politicians to act. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki have pledged to close Fresh Kills in five years. Their agreement is welcome, but they still need to develop a plan for disposal of the city's refuse.

But historically the rhythm section -- usually piano, bass and drums -- has defined the texture of jazz's various styles, giving them their rhythms and tempos, the muscle and soul of the music. Count Basie's well-oiled rhythm section created the paradigm for the swing era, and later groups led by Charlie Parker, John Coltrane and Miles Davis marked off their own territory.

He was on fire, he was a supernova and the future was so bright it hurt to stare into it.
