description: ORNELLA MORROW and her husband, Robert, bought their three-acre site on Long Pond in Bridgehampton as a weekend retreat, a place where they could enjoy the summer "in a quiet, serene country setting."

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Getting a Refund If a Cruise Doesn't Suit
description: Carnival Cruise Lines has set up a system to provide a refund to people who buy a cruise and quickly discover it is not for them. The new "vacation guarantee," according to Jennifer de la Cruz, a spokeswoman for the line, is intended to put cruising on a par with resorts when it comes to leaving and getting some money back. The refund plan applies to sailings aboard Carnival's 10 vessels between Aug. 8 and Nov. 22 but not to departures from Hawaii, Alaska or Hawaii.

title: WEDDINGS;Allison M. Boyle, Timothy Doern
description: Allison Marie Boyle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Boyle of Potomac, Md., was married there yesterday to Timothy Paul Doern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Doern of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. William C. Metzdorf officiated at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church.

title: June 2-8;A Fort Lost and Found
description: Three years before the Spanish established St. Augustine in Florida, and 45 years before the English settlement at Jamestown in Virginia, Huguenots fleeing religious persecution in France in 1562 built a raw fort on the coast of present-day South Carolina. This first French attempt to establish a colony on land now part of the United States lasted less than a year. Then the colony collapsed, the fort seeming to vanish without a trace, lost to history.

title: Love Fails Again
description: WORST FEARS By Fay Weldon. 200 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.

title: EARNING IT;Summertime, and Working in a Home Office Isn't Easy
description: VERY year about this time, Elaine Carey has a meeting with her children, Alexander, 12, and Sofia, 13. The subject of the talk is Ms. Carey's home office and the rules the children must follow in the summer so they do not disrupt her work.

title: The End of Germany's Economic Model
description: For many years, Germany's economic model has earned the respect and envy of many countries, including the United States.

title: World News Briefs;China Releases Dissident After 7 Years in Prison
description: Ren Wanding, a dissident, was released today after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations. Hours later he left for a seaside resort, his wife said.

title: A Tune That Carries Beyond Broadway;Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Group Has Disney-Sized Ambitions
description: In the beginning was the tune. And more than 25 years later that is how Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber still likes it to be. He writes the tunes for his hit musicals and lets others worry about what to do with the small fortune that "Cats," "The Phantom of the Opera," "Sunset Boulevard" and the like continue to earn him every year.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Outlawing Unsafe Hot Tubs
description: The May 25 death of a 16-year-old Lakewood girl who drowned in a health club hot tub during a post-prom gathering has inspired bills in both houses of the State Legislature. The Assembly Consumer Affairs and Regulated Professions Committee will hear two bills today. One would require that a hot tub have a shutoff switch nearby and the other would require an alarm loud enough to summon attendants. Both measures would require spa operators to make daily inspections. Similar legislation has been introduced in the Senate.

title: American Airlines Expected To Sign British Airways Pact
description: American Airlines and British Airways are expected to announce tomorrow that they will join forces as marketing partners, expanding a trend in global aviation that has seen airlines throughout the world begin to pair off.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARY MATALIN is getting a lot of practice at stepping out of the spotlight.

title: Churches Pray for Park Victim as Hunt for Suspect Is Pressed
description: Prayers for the victim of last week's vicious assault in Central Park were offered in solemn services at Armenian Orthodox churches across the metropolitan area yesterday as the police intensified the hunt for the assailant and a grieving family kept a round-the-clock hospital vigil for the comatose woman.

title: As Courts Remove Children, Lawyers for Parents Stumble
description: Early one morning in Brooklyn Family Court, a woman began to cry loudly in the crowded second-floor waiting room. "I want my baby," she screamed. People stared; some laughed. Nearby, a mother, her son and two lawyers, all trying to be heard over the din, discussed a plea agreement for the son. Suddenly, a dozen court officers raced through the room, scrambling to the third floor where a fight over a child had broken out.

title: INSIDE
description: Alliance in the Skies

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SWIMMING

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: British Air and American: Hands Across the Water American Airlines and British Airways are expected to announce tomorrow that they will join forces as marketing partners, selling seats on each other's flights and linking frequent-flier programs. A deal would mean that American's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, was dropping his opposition to code-sharing, a powerful shortcut in the computerized booking of space on an airline partner's flights.

title: HORSE RACING;3-Year-Old Title Still Wide Open
description: On the morning after the 128th Belmont Stakes, the 3-year-old horses were scattering for their homes with unfinished business: The Triple Crown races were run and won by three different horses, no dominant or even ranking horse had emerged as the leader of the class and all honors and championships clearly had to be decided in the "second season."

title: ATLANTA LEADERS SEE RACIAL GOALS AS OLYMPIC IDEAL
description: All across America, affirmative action has been chased into retreat by lawmakers and judges. But here in Atlanta, the private corporation that is staging this summer's Olympic Games has awarded almost a third of its $387 million in construction and vending contracts to companies owned primarily by minorities and women.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Panorama Of Feelings, Some Cool, Some Not
description: Silvia Martins is one of those performers who one suspects can make just about anything look good. But the dances she presented on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop did not require that stretch. Each piece had a personality of its own, though the program as a whole did not suggest Ms. Martins's possible range.

title: Clinton Apologizes Over Use of F.B.I. To Get G.O.P. Files
description: The White House issued an apology today with President Clinton's endorsement to several prominent Republicans because their confidential files were improperly obtained from the Federal Bureau of Investigation by the White House two years ago.

title: Debt-Relief Cost for the Poorest Nations
description: The cost of reducing the debts of the poorest and most heavily indebted developing countries so that they may raise their economic growth rates and attract more foreign investment could range from $5.6 billion to $7.7 billion over six years, a new study by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund has concluded.

title: Edward Bernstein, Economics Expert, Is Dead at 91
description: Edward M. Bernstein, who, as a leading international economist helped negotiate the international monetary system at Bretton Woods, N.H., near the end of World War II, died on Saturday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington. He was 91 and lived in Washington.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Mixing Jazz, Ritual and Japanese Banjos
description: The world presented by Crossovers, a series put on by the Asia Society at its Park Avenue hall over the weekend, has become increasingly complex and referential. The music, played by Asian-American artists, brought together Japanese, Chinese, Brazilian, European, African and African-American musics and esthetics. And it did it with a minimum of fuss; the music sounded organic.

title: Netanyahu Can't Afford to Keep Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Is Harassing Parishioners, Pastors of Burned Churches Say
description: Federal investigators are committed to finding the people responsible for dozens of fires at black churches in the South, even if that means giving church members lie-detector tests and searching church records, a top Justice Department official said today.

title: In Next Sequel, Let Scarlett, Like Atlanta, Personify New South
description: To the Editor: Re "Book Sequel Creates a New Civil War" (Business Day, June 3):

title: Chrysler Raises Prices on Some Car Models
description: The Chrysler Corporation said Friday that it had raised prices on certain 1996 model cars and mini-vans by as much as $300.

title: Making Workfare Work for Students
description: With more than a million of its citizens receiving some form of welfare, New York City is embarked on one of the most ambitious workfare efforts in the country. The Giuliani administration is pressing to place able-bodied recipients in public-service jobs, with the hope of shifting many of them into private-sector employment later.

title: ON BASEBALL;Injury Becomes Mets' Pitching Phenomenon
description: Jason Isringhausen pitched yesterday -- a victory in itself these days for the Mets' pitching class of 1996. That he won impressively was a salve. That he is the only phenom who will be winning at all for the Mets in the near future made the victory a bittersweet one at best.

title: OLYMPICS;Champion Wrestlers Fall at Trials
description: Two defending world champions and one former world champion were beaten for spots on the 1996 United States Olympic wrestling team in Spokane, Wash., Saturday. The team was determined in two-of-three-match wrestle-offs between the winners of April's national championships and the winners of a mini-tournament held Friday.

title: Editorial Notebook;Older, Simpler, Wiser
description: The brassy cacophony heralding the Atlanta Olympics has all but drowned out the haunting antiphony of a solitary trumpet announcing the resumption in Greece of the Nemean Games. With minimal ado the other day, some 500 sprinters from 28 countries heard a great shout as they emerged from an ancient tunnel into a stadium last used more than 2,000 years ago. But what truly established the antique flavor of this one-day festival was the prize for winners: a wreath of wild celery, neither salable nor edible.

title: Where Old Computer Parts Are Given New Lives
description: From the outside, Micro Exchange looks like a modest-sized store selling used computers from $99 (for an I.B.M. with a 386 chip) to $1,600 (for a Dell with a Pentium 166 chip).

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Talented Trio and Sailors On the Loose in Manhattan
description: For years, Leonard Bernstein's undeniable flair for musical theater was used as a stick with which to beat his "serious" compositions. But the convenient premise that all of Bernstein's theatrical works were great was as distorted as the easy dismissal of his concert works was unjust.

title: Diplomat Killed in Crash
description: A Vietnamese diplomat to the United Nations was killed in an automobile crash on Saturday, the Massachusetts State Police said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Top Judge Still Ailing
description: Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of New Jersey remained hospitalized at Mount Sinai Medical Center over the weekend, and there was no word on how long he would remain, his housekeeper, Araminta Mustafa, said yesterday.

title: Patents;A device aims to improve cardiopulmonary resuscitation by monitoring blood flow.
description: A device that might improve the success rate of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, has been developed by Ken Kelly, the president of Kelly Medical Products Inc. in Princeton, N.J.

title: Cities' Growth Is No Cause for Alarm
description: To the Editor:

title: Laurel Weiner, A Hadassah Leader, 68
description: Laurel Weiner, a national associate and former national vice president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, died on June 2 at Portsbridge Hospice in Atlanta. An Atlanta resident, she was 68.

title: Ex-Governor Would Accept Nomination
description: Former Gov. Richard Lamm of Colorado said today that he was willing to run for President on Ross Perot's Reform Party ticket and would increase by tenfold the Medicare savings proposed by President Clinton.

title: GOLF;Before Open, Els Makes An 8-Stroke Statement
description: In any sport, awakening a sleeping giant is a dangerous thing. Golf just got a whole lot more dangerous today. And, on the week leading up to the United States Open, a whole lot more interesting.

title: Bridge
description: The best North American score in the Alcatel Worldwide Contest played on Friday and Saturday was by Richard Bender and Patrick McCammon of Springfield, Mo., who recorded 78.58 percent in the Friday game, playing North-South. This may prove competitive internationally when the world scores are known later in the week.

title: An Assault Forces an L.I. Nightclub Into the Spotlight Again
description: Nineteen summers ago, a dough-faced postal worker from Westchester County jotted down his intentions to visit a popular nightclub in Westhampton Beach. His plan was not to dance but to spray the crowd with gunfire.

title: A Man With a Plan for Troubled Women's Magazines
description: Barely two months ago, Jay C. MacDonald was a struggling entrepreneur looking for someone to underwrite his idea for a company that would serve the needs of America's 27 million separated, divorced and widowed women. Today he is the proud owner of Working Woman, Working Mother and Ms. magazines, the leading champions of female empowerment in mainstream publishing.

title: Metro Matters;Going Private To Clean Up The Highways
description: PEOPLE are not very good at realizing what is not there, even if the unseen used to be annoyingly inescapable. A guide, then, to the absent.

title: A New Crackdown Pinches Tax-Resistant in Argentina
description: Tax evasion has long been something of a national pastime in Argentina. With few laws and little Government effort to prosecute tax cheats, many Argentines have openly boasted about how much they have defrauded the state.

title: Clinton Faces Few Protesters As He Begins Western Trip
description: President Clinton toured a former army base tonight that is being converted into a national park and raised $1 million for the Democratic Party, but he faced only a small cluster of protesters demonstrating against his recent announcement that he would sign legislation that would deny Federal recognition to same-sex marriages.

title: Killings Defile Sanctuary Of Nation's Remote Trails
description: The slayings of two young women beside a rushing stream near the Appalachian Trail made national headlines not so much because of who the victims were or how the killings were committed, but because of where the crime happened.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;3 Nightmarish Murders Followed by a Wave of Hate
description: Family viewing it's not. "Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills," tonight on HBO, is an unsparing account of the 1993 murders of three 8-year-old boys in West Memphis, Ark., and the subsequent trials of three teen-agers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Girl to Testify in Sex Case
description: A 16-year-old girl who has accused a Jersey City police officer of seducing her when she was 12 will take the stand today in his trial, said Carmen Messano, the Hudson County Prosecutor. The officer, Robert Cannon, 41, of Jersey City, met the girl while on the job in the summer of 1993 and was arrested a few months later after her mother learned about their relationship. He was charged with sexual assault and official misconduct and was suspended until the case is resolved, prosecutors said.

title: Jack Warren Lowe, 79, Pianist Best Known as Half of a Duo
description: Jack Warren Lowe, for more than 40 years the partner of Arthur Whittemore in a popular duo-piano team, died on June 2 at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 79 and had suffered from emphysema.

title: CHRONICLE
description: At its sixth annual benefit concert tonight, the award-winning Children's Aid Society Chorus is scheduled to premiere "There Are (No) Children Here," which was written for the chorus by the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Morton Gould and the lyricist PHIL GLADSTON.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Sonics See Rodman, Rodman Everywhere
description: Luc Longley slipped through the cracks.

title: Dr. Shih-I Pai, 82, Researcher Who Advanced Aerodynamics
description: Dr. Shih-I Pai, a retired aeronautical researcher at the University of Maryland who conducted pioneering studies focusing on the drag and lift of ever-faster airplanes, space engines and missiles, died on May 23 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 82 and lived in Beltsville, Md.

title: In the 2000 Census, Immigrants Will Lose
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Mood, Minor Melodies And Tributes to the Past
description: The Learning Alliance opened the jazz festival season on Wednesday with its own series, which lasted through the weekend and was called Vision for the 21st Century, with a double bill of bands that paid tribute to the past. John Zorn brought in his group, Masada, and the bassist William Parker performed two pieces with his group, In Order to Survive. In between shows, poetry was read, dancers danced, Peter Kowald performed a bass solo, and the clarinetist Perry Robinson played some blues with two guitarists and a drummer.

title: As Trade Booms, Little Fear of a Communist
description: Surrounded by beaver coats, ermine jackets and fox trim hats, Perry Green happily remembered the recent morning here when 13 Russian women walked into his store empty-handed -- and walked out with 15 mink coats.

title: 2 Churches, A Rivalry, And a Killing
description: They are two simple storefront churches, on the ground floor of two-story row houses on a modest block in Brownsville, Brooklyn. But since one opened a door away from the other about eight years ago, investigators said, the neighbors have fought bitterly, each accusing the other of slashed tires and hang-up phone calls, each hurling slurs questioning the other church's legitimacy.

title: On Line: A Bosnia Gallery
description: Bosnia: Uncertain Paths to Peace," an interactive photo essay and international discussion examining the aftermath of the war in Bosnia, begins today on the Internet as a special report by The New York Times on the Web.

title: Croatia Arrests a Bosnian Croat Accused of War Crimes
description: The Croatian police announced today the arrest of a Bosnian Croat charged by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague with the murder and mistreatment of Muslim prisoners.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Joseph R. Sequenzia Jr. was named to the new position of creative director at Fusion 5, Westport, Conn. He had been president at Sequenzia Design Inc., Fairfield, Conn., which closed.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Bulls Could Write the Book on Being Bad Guests
description: Many books have already been spawned by his magnificent season, but no one has yet to pitch the obvious angle to a cash-starved publisher: "The Art of Shutting an Enemy Arena Up," by Michael Jordan. With Scottie Pippen. Special acknowledgments to Phil Jackson.

title: Trial Is Set to Begin For a Congressman
description: Representative Joseph M. McDade goes on trial here on Monday in Federal District Court, more than four years after he was indicted on charges of racketeering, conspiracy and accepting illegal gratuities.

title: Series of Blasts Brings Shrugs From Leaders In Damascus
description: A series of explosions has caused unease here in Syria's capital, which has not seen a similar act of violence in more than a decade.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Pains of Love and Loss Seen in Quick Glimpses
description: Four worthwhile plays, themes of love and loss and some excitingly virtuosic acting are the welcome news from Series C of "Marathon '96," the third and final program of Ensemble Studio Theater's 19th annual festival of one-act premieres.

title: Envoys Call for Kashmir Rebels to Free Hostages
description: Four Western Ambassadors appealed to separatist guerrillas today to release four hostages, including one American, who have been held for 11 months, saying it was time to end the ordeal for them and their families.

title: Traveling Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance: DANCE
description: A Classic of Emotion Infused With Hot-Blooded Excitement American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Higher Bid for Tempest
description: ACE Ltd. said today that it had offered to increase its acquisition bid for Tempest Reinsurance by about $100 million. The bid offers Tempest shareholders, excluding the General Re Corporation, $743.9 million in total value, or $179.04 for each Tempest common share. The latest offer is superior to the one that IPC Holdings Ltd. made on June 3, which was for $736.6 million, excluding the General Re component, or $177.29 for each Tempest common share, ACE said. Under the new ACE proposal, General Re, which had previously entered into a separate agreement with Tempest to sell its shares for $172.4 million, would receive an additional $7.5 million.

title: Kishiwada Journal;In Japan, Deflating a Poisonous Pufferfish Legend
description: For countless centuries, one of the greatest and costliest Japanese delicacies has been fugu, or pufferfish. It is renowned for the possibility that it will leave the diner flopping on the floor, gasping for breath, and soon as dead as the fish itself.

title: Bidders for MGM Might Be Looking At the Money Pit
description: If the talk in Hollywood is any measure, the MGM/ UA lion has not lost its allure.

title: Taking In the Sites;Tie the Knot With Advice On the Web
description: Todd and Andrea Biske were married in September, but the ceremony lives on at their World Wide Web wedding site, where browsers can find photos of all 16 people in the wedding party, as well as a randy guest trying to slip Mr. Biske $20 for a better shot at the garter.

title: Gen. Tito Okello, Ex-Ugandan Leader, 82
description: Gen. Tito Okello, who briefly ruled Uganda after seizing power in a military coup in 1985 before being toppled himself, has died, the radio reported. He was 82.

title: Life After General Motors: Day 1 at E.D.S.
description: Electronic Data Systems begins trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange as a separate company, free after a dozen years of ownership by the General Motors Corporation. But E.D.S., the nation's largest independent computer-services provider, has been revving its engine, trying even to line up business from General Motors' rivals, for more than a year.

title: STANELY CUP FINALS;Even the Panthers Know Their Ship Is Sinking
description: The Florida Panthers don't kid themselves. Even to them, the climb back into Stanley Cup finals contention seems as steep as Mount Everest.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;McCann-Erickson Acquires Ad:vent
description: McCann-Erickson North America in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, acquired Ad:vent, an event marketing and promotion agency owned by Adcom Industries Inc. in New York, and merged it with its existing event and promotion agency, Momentum IMC in New York. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: In Performance: CABARET
description: Some Cole Porter Passion With the Original Risque Words Susannah McCorkle Oak Room

title: Fines Are Raised In B.C.C.I. Case
description: An appeals court today ordered stiffer fines against eight former executives of the failed Bank of Credit and Commerce International and waived financial penalties against two others.

title: Gas Pump Prices Decrease
description: Gasoline-pump prices took their first nationwide plunge of the year, dropping by more than a penny a gallon, an oil analyst said today.

title: Sports of The Times;Something Was Bound to Set Jordan Off
description: Don't blame Gary Payton. Someone or something was sure to set off Michael Jordan. If it wasn't Payton, it would have been Hersey Hawkins, or George Karl, or the SuperSonics' mascot. It would have been the Seattle weather, or the ferries crossing Puget Sound, or some guy at the latte bar who dropped an extra Sweet 'N Low into his big cup.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Sympathize As Williams Joins Son
description: Dignified. Classy. Caring. Polite. Deep. Talented. The compliments poured out of Manager Joe Torre's mouth this morning as he discussed Bernie Williams, the Yankee center fielder who scurried home to Puerto Rico on Saturday after his 5-year-old son underwent what one Yankee executive described as life-saving surgery for an undisclosed problem.

title: White House Says Provision Endangers Health Bill
description: The Clinton Administration today threatened to veto a health insurance bill if Republicans insist on including a large-scale program of medical savings accounts, and Representative Dick Armey, the House Republican floor leader, dared the President to do it.

title: Shakespeare as Catalyst For Brainstorming Actors
description: For Cicely Berry, it was an experiment in international acting. As the longtime voice director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, she has trained several generations of British actors, and she has frequently given classes in the United States. Last week for the first time, she worked simultaneously with people from both countries. Eight actors from the Royal Shakespeare Company joined 13 American actors, including Cherry Jones, Samuel L. Jackson and Blythe Danner, in a two-day Shakespearean workshop.

title: Corrections
description: A pop review on Friday about a performance by the rock guitarist Bo Diddley on Wednesday night misidentified the club at which he appeared. It was the Bottom Line, not Tramps.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Answers Call To Restore Proper Order
description: Dwight Gooden had watched the Yankees get embarrassed for two straight days by the awful Tigers. He realized the situation was urgent. He knew the Yankees needed an instant cure.

title: Search for Cause of Crash Unearths an Angry Feud
description: It had been a bruising struggle between two high-level, hardheaded Air Force officers. It ended five days before the jet carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others crashed, when the squadron's leader dismissed his deputy, who had been seen in the unit as fighting for safety over on-time performance, according to Air Force documents.

title: In Age of Instability, a King Anchors Thailand
description: More than a century ago, King Mongkut of Thailand put a new spin on the monarchy, accepting the fealty of his subjects, but also pledging his own loyalty to them.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Television Notes column on Wednesday about summer schedules referred incorrectly to a Fox network drama, "Sliders." It has been renewed for the 1996-97 season; it was not canceled.

title: Treasury Announces Offerings for Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about primary results in New Jersey misstated the current position of David Del Vecchio, the Democratic nominee in the 12th District Congressional race. He is currently Mayor of Lambertville, not former Mayor.

title: Keeping Peace Alive And Tensions Dormant;Diverse Far Rockaway Sees Room For Harmony as Jewish Enclave Grows
description: It was September 1991, the summer of the violence in Crown Heights. Tensions between blacks and Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn erupted after a Hasidic driver struck and killed a 7-year-old black child. In retaliation, black youths attacked and killed a Hasidic Jew.

title: William J. Baroody Jr., 58, A Top Aide to President Ford
description: William J. Baroody Jr., a high aide to President Gerald R. Ford who was also president of the conservative American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research from 1978 until he resigned in 1986, died on Saturday at Alexandria Hospital in Alexandria, Va. He was 58 and lived in Alexandria.

title: Corrections
description: The Real Estate column on Friday about a luxury apartment project in Edgewater, N.J., misspelled the given name of the writer. She is Rachelle Garbarine.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Deadly Punch Trial to Start
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today in the trial of a man accused of killing a counselor with his fist during a January 1995 fight at the Morris County Youth Detention Center.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded slightly lower here this morning. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 40.60 points --slightly less than two-tenths of 1 percent -- to stand at 21,711.21.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a plan to move the Empire Theater and incorporate it into a new movie complex on 42d Street referred incorrectly to the protected status of theaters on the block. Only the New Amsterdam is designated a city landmark; the others are protected from demolition by a historic-preservation agreement reached in 1981 by the city and New York State. The article also misspelled the surname of a structural engineer in the project. He is Robert Silman, not Stillman.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Love Defies Class Lines In the China of the Mings
description: Chinese opera -- that ineffably rich mix of song and theater, gesture and acrobatics, costume and makeup -- continues to yield fresh surprises.

description: MAXIM of the newspaper business is: the smaller the type, the more loyal the readers. Publishers or editors who are skeptical of that rule need only to listen to the experience of The Day, a daily in New London, Conn.

title: BASEBALL;Isringhausen's Gem Leaves Nothing to Chance
description: It was not so long ago that Jason Isringhausen said he was feeling as if he had to go out and pitch a perfect game every time he took the mound. Just to get a victory, mind you.

title: No Headline
description: We are past the point of going back to Brezhnev. Most people think that if Zyuganov comes and tries some things in the old style, he will eventually have to try the way of the market. CHARLES B. NEFF, who trains Russians in small-business techniques. [B9:4.]

title: BALLET REVIEW;Antiquity Standing In for Tradition
description: Stepping Stones," choreographed by Jiri Kylian, is the final new production of American Ballet Theater's current season. It is a work so outstandingly danced that its buried meaning is less important than its ingenious choreography.

description: It was a moment that perfectly reflected the frustration of the MetroStars and their fans.

description: If it is the aspiring writer's dream to publish a book while very young, the reality is that it happens rarely. Truman Capote was 24, Carson McCullers, 23; Gore Vidal and Brett Easton Ellis both 21, and Joyce Maynard, 20, when their first books appeared in print.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Lines of Communication Across Racial Divisions
description: Derek McGinty returns to television tonight on PBS, at 10 on Channel 13 in New York, with the first of three episodes of "Straight Talk," this one on the inescapable subject "Black and White in America."

description: At least five Israeli soldiers were killed and six wounded today in clashes with Muslim guerrillas in south Lebanon, security officials said.

description: A Russian cargo ship stranded at sea for two weeks with 450 passengers, including Liberian war refugees, has been chased out of Ghanaian waters, the Ghana News Agency said today.
