title: With a Smile, Dole Tries to Fight a Stern Reputation
description: By this point in the Presidential campaign of 1988, Senator Bob Dole had ordered a tenacious sidewalk questioner in New Hampshire, "Get back in your cage," had brought his campaign battle with Vice President George Bush to the Senate floor in a desk-pounding confrontation and had furiously demanded in a live television interview that Mr. Bush "stop lying about my record." "Saturday Night Live" was regularly lampooning him as a snarling misanthrope.

title: Al Poulin, Founding Editor Of Poetry House, Dies at 58
description: Al Poulin, a French-Canadian New England mill hand's son who had such an appetite for language that he managed to live the life of a poet in a world that sometimes seems to value typesetters more, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Brockport, N.Y., the Erie Canal town he had made a center of contemporary American poetry. He was 58 and the founding editor of BOA Editions, one of the nation's premier poetry publishers.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures on the Currents page of The Home Section on Thursday with a report about a mural made by children's book illustrators for a day-care center at Women in Need carried an incorrect credit. They were by Maurice Sherman.

title: OLYMPICS;Run Silent, Run Fast: Torrence Takes Shots at Medals, Not Opponents
description: The top women in sprinting had jousted with a particular viciousness for four years, leaving spike marks on the track and spite marks off the track.

title: At Home Abroad;Little England
description: There is an old wheeze about the insular outlook of the English, a newspaper headline that supposedly said:

title: In America;Nike's Pyramid Scheme
description: Think of it as a pyramid of exploitation. In the comfort zone at the very top is a stable of uncaring multimillionaire celebrities -- Michael Jordan, Andre Agassi, Spike Lee et al -- and their guru, the fabulously successful founder and chief executive of Nike Inc., Philip H. Knight.

title: Gay Marriage Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Words From Victim
description: In his first words since a near-fatal beating on Memorial Day weekend, Shane L. Daniels asked for his mother.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 20 about the job prospects of recent college graduates with journalism degrees misattributed an estimate of where the graduates are seeking work. The statement that three-quarters of journalism graduates will seek jobs in print, radio, television and Internet journalism was based on interviews with educators, placement directors and professionals around the country. It was not a finding of a survey of graduates by Professor Lee Becker of Ohio State University.

title: ON HOCKEY;Avalanche Finds Rats Appetizing
description: While dining in an ocean-front restaurant over the weekend, the Colorado Avalanche's general manager, Pierre Lacroix, got an appetizer not found on the menu. The staff conspired to serve him an arrangement of caviar and sliced hard-boiled eggs arranged to resemble three rats.

title: TENNIS;At Last, Kafelnikov Comes Of Age
description: Yevgeny Kafelnikov, who was told at 16 that he had no promise only to be chided at 20 for not living up to his talent, today became the first Russian to win a Grand Slam title when he defeated Michael Stich in the French Open final, 7-6 (7-4), 7-5, 7-6 (7-4).

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Web-Ripened Tomatoes?
description: People with visions of 4.5-pound tomatoes dancing in their heads ought to put their plants in the ground now if they hope to grow New Jersey's biggest tomato, Joe Heimbold, who has organized the state's annual tomato-growing contest since its inception in 1978, said Saturday. This year, Mr. Heimbold is offering growers help by way of a page on the Internet. Mr. Heimbold's web site is http:// www.njtomato.com. The winner will be announced on Aug. 24. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Court-Martial Proceedings
description: An Army sergeant goes on trial on Monday in a sniper attack here last fall that left one soldier dead and 18 others injured.

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A New York Debut Recital In Which Bartok Is the Test Ayako Yoshida Weill Recital Hall

title: World News Briefs;U.N. and Iraqis Begin To Dismantle Arms Plant
description: Iraqi officials and United Nations experts have begun dismantling a major biological weapons factory near Baghdad as part of the international sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in 1990.

title: Michael Fox, 75, An Actor in Film, TV and Theater
description: Michael Fox, a film, theater and television actor, died last Saturday at the Motion Picture Home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: The F.B.I.'s Files and the President's Fate
description: He misused the Federal Bureau of Investigation . . ."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bartle Bogle Gets 2 Accounts
description: Bartle Bogle Hegarty in London was awarded two accounts, with combined billings estimated at $45 million.

title: In Performance: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: An Israeli-Born Pianist In Beethoven and Rameau Mordecai Shehori Merkin Concert Hall

title: Hundreds of New Yorkers Add Efforts to Police Hunt
description: Even as a frustrating sense of helplessness settles over the search for a suspect in the Central Park beating case, officers on the 13th floor of Police Headquarters find themselves on the front lines of hope. What otherwise would be considered cacophony is music to their ears: telephones ringing around the clock.

title: SOCCER;United States Edges Ireland
description: Claudio Reyna scored in the 75th minute today to give the United States a 2-1 victory over Ireland in the Americans' opening game in the U.S. Cup '96 exhibition tournament.

title: Sports of The Times;At Meadowlands, Big Crowd and a Few Louts
description: THE problem with the large soccer crowd was that it obscured the handful of sneaks and louts among the 53,250 paying fans yesterday at Giants Stadium. They managed to make their presence felt by hurling plastic bottles onto the field as the Los Angeles Galaxy was toying with the MetroStars, en route to a 4-0 victory in the new Major League Soccer.

title: In Time for Campaign '96, A New Political Web Site
description: If advertisers balked at supporting two huge political sites on the World Wide Web, will they be more receptive to one big site?

title: ADVERTISING;How many baby boomers can you fit, comfortably, in the back seat of a convertible?
description: AS members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 50 this year, auto makers are slowly and cautiously beginning to adjust how they advertise convertibles. Their goal is to shift from the convertibles' traditional tie to youth to convincing aging buyers that convertibles are safe and practical, but still fun.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Rules for Jet Skiing
description: Only 8 percent of the 191,000 boats in New Jersey are jet skis, but they account for 40 percent of the accidents, according to the State Police Marine Bureau. Starting next month, everyone who owns and operates a jet ski will have to get a boating safety certificate. Certificates may be obtained by attending a state-approved boating safety course and passing a test. The courses are administered by the marine police, the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary or the United States Power Squadron, an education agency similar to the Coast Guard Auxiliary. The course covers rules and navigation, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Some of the courses also include charting and plotting courses.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 13, Drowns
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn youth on a church outing from New York City has drowned in Whaley Lake, the authorities said today.

title: Equity Offerings That Are Planned for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: A Hockey Championship in Miami? Maybe Not, but This Is No Sinking Ship
description: Their pockets still bulging with the toy rats they did not have a chance to throw onto the ice in celebration, Florida Panthers fans filed out of the Miami Arena quietly on Saturday night after their team's third loss in a row.

title: Day of Red, White and Boos At the Puerto Rican Parade
description: Tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans turned a hazy stretch of Fifth Avenue red, white and blue with a sea of miniature national flags yesterday, lining the street to cheer their heritage -- and many also to jeer Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- during the 39th annual Puerto Rican Day parade.

title: Chechen Rebels Cite Some Progress in Talks
description: Peace talks aimed at ending the war in Chechnya adjourned today without a signed accord, but a rebel spokesman said the two sides had agreed on a Russian troop withdrawal by the end of August.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rail Link to Speed Commutes
description: Commuters on New Jersey Transit's Morris and Essex Line will save up to 20 minutes this morning with the start of new direct service, the transit agency said Friday. Depending on the train, some passengers embarking at stations between Dover and Newark will be able to ride directly from their local stop to Pennsylvania Station in New York, while others can transfer at Newark's Broad Street Station before proceeding east. Thanks to a $69 million link between the Morris and Essex Line and the Northeast Corridor in Kearny, Manhattan-bound riders will no longer have to transfer from New Jersey Transit trains to PATH trains or ferries at Hoboken, the agency said.

title: Life's Hubbub Returns to Oft-Shunned Hudson
description: On the waterfront of Beacon, N.Y., the city's environmental director, Shabazz Jackson, pointed to a brush-choked peninsula jutting into the glittering Hudson River. A year ago, the one-acre site overflowed with rusting cars. Soon it will be restored and turned into parkland. "We're taking it back," Mr. Jackson said.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Yottabytes Are a Lotta Bytes
description: Now that kilo-, mega- and even gigabytes of computer memory look like small beer, and computer clock speeds even in nanoseconds begin to feel pokey, it's time to learn the next set of exponential prefixes destined to enter the modern vocabulary. Brace yourself for the coming world of computers with yottabyte memories and zeptosecond clock speeds (and Government deficits measured in petabucks).

title: Lost in Freemen Standoff: First a Father, Now a Farm
description: Dean Clark has lost his father and grandfather to the extremist right-wing Freemen cause. Now the 29-year-old farmer stands to lose his land and his livelihood.

title: Essay;Shame on the F.B.I.
description: Overlooked in the scandal of Travelgate has been the failure of F.B.I. Director Louis Freeh to protect the confidential files of citizens from political snoops. Say what you like about J. Edgar Hoover -- he never let the bureau become a doormat for White House aides.

title: Netanyahu Has Wait-and-See Stance on Arabs
description: The office of Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli Prime Minister-elect, today declined to make a formal response to the call for an Arab summit meeting, saying it would issue a statement once the new Government was formed.

title: In Performance: DANCE
description: Age as a Boon To Self-Expression American Dance Guild Frederick Loewe Theater

title: Gerry Adams, Ulster Pivot, Sees 'Best Bet' for Peace
description: Gerry Adams sat in a patch of sunlight in the tiny front yard of Connolly House, headquarters of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. The white stucco building on Andersonstown Road is caged by a double barrier of metal fence as a defense against attack, but on a recent relaxed Saturday afternoon the doors were left open so the breeze could blow in and "the lads" could wander in and out.

title: The New Encryption Universe
description: The development of inexpensive computer programs and hardware that scramble telephone calls and computer messages to prevent eavesdropping is rapidly transforming the world of cryptography. Once largely the domain of governments and their intelligence services, encryption technology is now commonly used by corporations, banks, securities firms and individual computer operators. It is time to revise Government encryption policy to fit this new universe.

title: Frank Israel, Architect Inspired by California, Is Dead at 50
description: Franklin D. Israel, an architect whose designs for private houses and offices for film production companies epitomized the creative ferment of contemporary Hollywood, died yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 50 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: GOLF;Double Whammy: 2 Stars Pull Out of U.S. Open
description: Two of the biggest attractions in golf are out of the United States Open. Fred Couples, arguably the most popular American golfer, and Nick Price, the No. 4 player in the world, both withdrew from the tournament, which begins here Thursday at the Oakland Hills Country Club.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Weepers, Teasers And Hymns
description: Syd Straw

title: In Naming a New Executive, G.M. Tightens Reins at Saab
description: The General Motors Corporation took tighter hold of the reins at Saab Automobile A.B. today by naming an executive close to G.M.'s chairman, John F. Smith Jr., to run the Swedish auto maker.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Alice H. Whitmore was named to the new position of senior vice president and creative director at DDB Needham New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. She was previously a senior vice president and associate creative director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, a unit of the WPP Group.

title: Gunmen Kill a Leftist Politician in Mexico
description: Unidentified gunmen killed a local left-wing opposition leader in the southwestern state of Guerrero, state authorities said today.

title: Chief Theater Critic Named
description: Ben Brantley was named chief theater critic of The New York Times yesterday. The announcement was made by Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor. The appointment will take effect with the new theater season in September.

title: ROCK REVIEW;Grooves Explored From All Angles
description: The lights traced circles within circles when the Dave Matthews Band performed on Sunday night at the Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, L.I. There were rings atop rings, turning gear shapes and twirling, pulsing moires. The interlocking patterns matched the best aspect of the music: the band's transparent, intricate grooves. Mr. Matthews and his four collaborators are masters of counterpoint and syncopation, and they can turn a vamp inside out while keeping it airborne.

title: Former Official, Under Detention, Issues Rare Challenge to China
description: The only senior Communist Party leader imprisoned after the 1989 pro-democracy uprising here today publicly challenged the basis for his continued detention at a remote police hideaway with no access to a lawyer, a doctor or a telephone.

title: Whiff of Organic Stuff Found Between Stars
description: Astronomers think they have found evidence that some of the stuff of life could exist out between the stars. The molecular clue could not be any less exotic. It is the presence of vinegar in a cloud of gas and dust near the center of the Milky Way, the galaxy of the solar system.

title: Food Ship Rushing to Polar Base
description: AN American polar research ship was reported yesterday to be fighting through thick pack ice in an effort to reach Russia's Mirny base in Antarctica, where 38 Russian scientists and technicians have nearly run out of food.

title: Hilfiger's New Blueprint
description: There is a saying about building castles in the air: Once they are there, you have to build the foundations under them.

title: Patterns
description: New Looks for Evening

title: Pataki Calls for Internet Wiring Day at Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki unveiled a plan today that would help connect every public school and library in the state to the Internet, putting out a call for volunteers to conduct a mass wiring of buildings across the state on a single day in September.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Actors Back Privacy Bill
description: A bill that would require the State Division of Motor Vehicles to get a driver's written consent before releasing information from its records to anyone other than an insurance company has drawn support from the movie industry. Richard Masur, president of the Screen Actors Guild in Los Angeles, will be at the State House today to express support for the measure. In 1989, Rebecca Schaeffer, a star of the television series "My Sister Sam," was killed in Los Angeles by a man who got her address through California's Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Whitewater Counsel Examining Use of F.B.I. to Get G.O.P. Files
description: The Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, has begun an investigation into how the White House obtained confidential F.B.I. files on several prominent Republicans, Government officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 29 about the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef referred incorrectly to the detention of a co-defendant, Wali Khan Amin Shah. While the authorities have said that Mr. Shah tried to escape from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, the attempt was unsuccessful and he is still in custody.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;If Traffic Stop Is Valid, Arrest On Other Charges Is Allowed
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that even if the police use a minor traffic violation as a pretext for stopping a car to look for drugs, an arrest for any drugs they find is still valid as long as the traffic stop itself was supported by probable cause.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Rodman Is Baiting; Seattle Is Bawling
description: Dennis Rodman did not get detention.

title: Doctors Happy With Progress Of L.I. Victim
description: Shane L. Daniels is expected to make a nearly complete recovery from head wounds that he received in a beating outside a nightclub in Westhampton Beach on May 26, his doctors said today.

title: PERIPHERALS;Big Picture, Low Price
description: MANY offices use suites of software, collections of programs like word processors, spreadsheets and databases bought together because they are designed to work together and are less expensive than the components bought one at a time. ABC Graphics Suite for Windows 95 is a relatively low-priced grouping meant specifically to work with Microsoft Office, itself a suite, although it will work with other programs. In an office already using the Microsoft package, that means people will find menus and icons in the places they are accustomed to seeing them.

title: By Design;Traveling Lightly but Prettily
description: Summer weekends start with a lightweight bag to carry essentials, with room for a few fun accessories.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;The Trouble Selling Kodak in Japan, Land of Fuji
description: In the small town of Odaicho on Japan's east coast, Isamu Yoshida says he would love to carry Kodak film in his little photo shop.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stock were showing some modest gains here this morning. At the midday break in trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 93.35 points, or about four-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,812,50. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 32.66 points.

title: Wagner Stott To Sell a Unit
description: Fidelity Capital Markets, the institutional brokerage trading arm of the Fidelity Investment Company, said today that it planned to acquire the Nasdaq trading division of Wagner Stott Mercator.

title: ON BASEBALL;Cox Draws Blueprint For Lasting Success
description: The general manager of the Atlanta Braves, the awful Atlanta Braves, went to a pay phone outside the ball park in Colorado Springs and called one of his scouts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DII GROUP AGREES TO ACQUIRE ORBIT SEMICONDUCTOR
description: DII Group Inc. has agreed to acquire Orbit Semiconductor Inc. for about $102 million in stock, the companies said yesterday. Under the agreement, Orbit shareholders will receive 0.45 share of DII Group common stock for each share of Orbit, a semiconductor maker. DII Group, a maker of circuit boards and related electronic equipment, plans to issue about 3.6 million shares of common stock. Shares of Orbit, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose $1.875, to $12, in Nasdaq trading, while DII Group fell $3.50 a share, to $27.50. DII Group, based in Denver, said the acquisition, excluding merger costs of about $3.5 million to $4 million, would slightly dilute third-quarter earnings and would add to the bottom line in the fourth quarter.

title: A Vietnam War Obligation
description: Nguyen Van Chinh cannot understand why the Pentagon refuses to pay him for clandestine work he performed for the United States during the Vietnam War. He has every reason to be puzzled. He spent 17 years in prison after being captured in North Vietnam on a sabotage mission, but recently declassified documents show that three decades ago the United States callously disclaimed any responsibility for his fate and that of dozens of other commandos it sent into North Vietnam.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Blades Trial Begins
description: In opening arguments yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., lawyers for Seattle Seahawks wide receiver BRIAN BLADES said the state would never be able to prove that Blades "actually pulled the trigger" in the shooting death of his cousin Charles Blades. Brian Blades is on trial in Broward Circuit Court on a manslaughter charge in the death last July 5. If convicted, he faces up to nine and a half years in prison. BRUCE ZIMET, a defense attorney, painted Charles Blades as inebriated, and at least partly at fault, when he struggled with Brian Blades in the football player's townhouse to keep him from grabbing a semiautomatic handgun. According to authorities, Brian Blades had sought to intervene in an argument down the street between his brother BENNIE, a Detroit Lions safety, and CAROL JAMERSON, Bennie's former girlfriend.

title: Yes, We Can Afford a Federal Tax Cut
description: The Federal Government will collect 19.1 percent of the $7.6 trillion gross domestic product in fiscal year 1996, according to the Congressional Budget Office's latest projections.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Unemployment Decreased in May
description: Germany's seasonally adjusted unemployment fell by 7,000 in May, to 3.93 million, its second consecutive monthly decline, the Federal Labor Office said yesterday. Unemployment, however, remains close to the record postwar high set in March. In west Germany, the jobless total was up 15,000, to 2.77 million, while the east had a decrease of 23,000, to 1.16 million. The unemployment rate remained at 10.3 percent. (Reuters)

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn and Soybean Prices Rise As Planting Is Stalled by Rain
description: Corn and soybean prices continued to climb on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after rain drenched the eastern crop regions of Ohio and Indiana over the weekend, further delaying planting.

title: R. Thornton Wilson Jr., Restaurateur and Arts Patron, 73
description: R. Thornton Wilson Jr., a former Manhattan restaurateur and patron of the arts, died on Wednesday at his home in Newport, R.I. He was 73.

title: Police Offer New Sketch in Park Attack
description: The police released a new sketch yesterday of a man sought in the near-fatal attack on a woman in Central Park. Investigators called it a revised version of an earlier sketch, but also acknowledged the possibility that two men might have been involved in the crime.

title: Officer Is Shot by a Suspect in Brooklyn
description: A police officer was shot and wounded last night during a struggle with a man he was questioning for suspicious behavior on a Brooklyn street corner, the police said. The man fled and was still at large early this morning, the target of a determined manhunt.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A White House Gaffe Puts Clinton in China's Corner
description: As the Clinton Administration heads into the last week of a showdown with China over its failure to live up to a major trade agreement, an oversight by the White House is putting President Clinton in the politically delicate position of having to assert that China is opening markets and lowering its barriers to American companies.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Daimler Denies It Misled Holders
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., the German industrial giant, denied today that its chief financial officer, Manfred Gentz, intentionally misled shareholders about impending losses in 1995.

title: C. Arnholt Smith, 97, Banker And Padres Chief Before a Fall
description: C. Arnholt Smith, once a multimillionaire California banker who brought major league baseball to San Diego but who was later convicted of embezzling $8.9 million from his business properties, died on Saturday in Del Mar, Calif., at the age of 97.

title: Britain Gives Europe a Taste Of Cooperation in Beef War
description: In what it called a good-will gesture in its conflict with its European partners over beef sales, Britain, which has vowed to block European Union decisions until its partners lift a ban on British beef exports, allowed two key measures to go through today.

title: All Aboard for the Train Straight Into Manhattan (No Hoboken)
description: Train 6410 rumbled into the station and, as the waiting crowd surged across the platform, the assistant conductor, Lewis Apgar, swung down from the last car.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAXXIM MEDICAL AGREES TO BUY STERILE CONCEPTS
description: Maxxim Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sterile Concepts Holdings for about $115 million in cash and the assumption of $32 million in debt. The deal would create the second-largest surgical kit and tray distributor behind Baxter International Inc. Maxxim, which made previous attempts to buy Sterile Concepts, agreed to pay $20 for each share. Shares of Sterile Concepts, which is based in Richmond, fell $1.875, to $19.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, and Maxxim, based in Sugar Land, Tex., rose 75 cents, to $18.625. Maxxim's first offer, made in February, was $16 a share.

title: Airline Pact Could Mean 'Open Skies' For Heathrow
description: A planned marketing alliance between American Airlines and British Airways may seem at first to be simply the latest in a series of partnerships between airlines. But the alliance is also expected to lead to an aviation accord between Britain and the United States to replace one that American officials have been dissatisfied with since it was signed 50 years ago.

title: Dow Chemical to Construct Polypropylene Plants
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it planned to become a major manufacturer of polypropylene, a petrochemical widely used to make such plastic products as fibers, film and car parts.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Burmese Leaders Expand Moves Against Dissident
description: The Burmese military has mounted a new offensive against the country's leading democracy advocate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, using 30-foot-tall billboards that denounce her as a stooge of foreign countries.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column on Sunday about a benefit dinner-dance at Windows on the World for the China Institute in America misidentified the woman at the right. She was Tina Liu Luce, not Jane Debevoise.

title: Investment Fund Plans to Inject $200 Million Into Kinko's Chain
description: Kinko's said yesterday that an investment fund managed by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc. would inject $200 million into its copying and business-services chain, which would help finance expansion.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CANADIAN NATURAL TO ACQUIRE SCEPTRE RESOURCES
description: Sceptre Resources Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, signed a deal to be acquired for about $700 million (Canadian), or $511 million (United States), by one of Canada's most successful energy companies, Canadian Natural Resources. Sceptre had been struggling with high costs and declining oil and gas reserves, and so put itself up for sale in March. Sceptre shareholders will be able to either receive 0.38 of a Canadian Natural share for each Sceptre share or 0.3025 of a share plus $2 for each Sceptre share. Sceptre's board said it would not solicit other bids. Sceptre shares jumped 35 cents, to $9.10, on the Toronto Stock Exchange; Canadian Natural rose 20 cents, to $24.05.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines Hull Trading $500,000
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc.'s regulatory arm said today that it had fined the Hull Trading Company $500,000 for violating the rules of the Small-Order Execution System, or S.O.E.S.

title: FILLING IN BLANKS ON ABORTION ISSUE, DOLE CREATES STIR
description: Senator Bob Dole today amplified his proposal to change the Republican Party platform on abortion in a way that surprised his own advisers and infuriated the leading conservatives who only days ago had praised his effort to smooth over internal party fractures on the issue.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Rate of Suicide by Youths Is Said to Rise in Europe
description: The number of suicide attempts by male teen-agers in Europe has risen sharply in the last 10 years, with unemployment and imitative suicides contributing to the rise, researchers said today.

title: Witness Says Sergeant Vowed To 'Mow Everyone Down'
description: A paratrooper who killed one soldier and wounded 18 in a sniper attack during morning calisthenics had warned the night before that he would "mow everyone down," a former member of his squad testified at a court-martial today.

title: BASEBALL;His Son Improved, Williams Returns
description: Unshaved and exhausted, Bernie Williams ambled into the clubhouse 90 minutes before tonight's game with the Blue Jays and expressed relief about being back. Because returning to the Yankees meant that Williams's 5-year-old son was no longer in danger after surgery Saturday to drain an infection behind his left ear.

title: Pact Is Signed on Steps to End Chechen War
description: Chechen separatists and Russian officials signed agreements today that could lay the groundwork for ending the 18-month war in Chechnya.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Store Accused Of Paying Off Gangsters
description: Prosecutors began interrogating executives of Japan's leading department store chain yesterday on charges that they paid as much as 1 billion yen ($9.2 million) to mob-affiliated extortionists. Three executives of Takashimaya Ltd. were under arrest in the case, one of the biggest ever involving criminals who extort money from corporations in exchange for insuring a trouble-free annual shareholders meeting.

title: On My Mind;Color Them White
description: Think of it: 34 white-congregation churches, synagogues or mosques are burned down in one part of the country, 23 in the last 17 months.

title: Police Officer Is Shot On a Brooklyn Corner
description: A police officer was shot and wounded last night during a struggle with a man he was questioning for suspicious behavior on a Brooklyn street corner, the police said. The man fled and was still at large early this morning, the target of a determined manhunt. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani interrupted budget negotiations at City Hall to visit the hospital.

title: Crashes of Asteroids Shed Tiny Diamonds In Glittering Trillions
description: SPEEDING rocks from space that have slammed into Earth periodically over the ages are usually seen as agents of destruction and death, begetting global palls of dust that block sunlight, disrupt the climate and do in creatures like the dinosaurs.

title: Untraditionally, Council Approves Recycling Cut
description: For more than a decade, mayors have made a habit of cutting New York City's recycling program. And just as habitually, the City Council has restored money to keep recycling at status quo.

title: Italy's Secessionist Party Exploits A Growing Army of Malcontents
description: This pretty, medieval town hardly seems the breeding ground of a revolt. Its main piazza is crowded at lunchtime with smartly dressed entrepreneurs, and its shops are brimming with expensive goods. Even its canals and back streets are well kept, with none of the faded brilliance of Venice, 15 miles to the east.

title: OLYMPICS;Kempainen May Miss the Marathon
description: Bob Kempainen, the American record-holder in the marathon who overcame an upset stomach to win the Olympic trials in February, is suffering from tendinitis that will "potentially" keep him from participating in the Summer Games in Atlanta, he said yesterday.

title: Suspects Are Held in 2 Fires at Black Churches in the South
description: A 13-year-old white girl was charged today with setting fire to an old wooden sanctuary on the grounds of a black church last week in Charlotte, N.C., while Texas authorities said they had detained three suspects in the burning of of another black church Sunday night in Greenville, north of Dallas.

title: No Headline
description: Personally I feel a deep sense of sorrow for a 13-year-old child not only because she ruined a church building but that she may also have ruined her life."

title: Mayor and Council Leaders Agree on $32.8 Billion Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and leaders of the City Council reached a tentative agreement early this morning on a $32.8 billion budget that would make sharp cuts in spending on municipal services but include a plan to borrow $1.4 billion for repairs to New York City's public schools over the next four years.

title: MCI and British Telecom to Join Networks for Internet Market
description: Projecting that the volume of computer-based communications traffic will soon surpass voice communications, the MCI Communications Corporation and its partner, British Telecommunications P.L.C., said yesterday that they planned to merge their international high-speed data networks and expand their capacity significantly.

title: Her Tap Shoes Tell the Story;Dancer's Career Is Filled With Pride and Prejudice
description: Inside Club Savannah, there was nothing but glitter and glamour, trumpets blaring and bassists strumming, movie stars cheering and chorus girls tapping, their shoulders shaking and their heels pounding as they snaked across the wooden stage. Drunk with the rhythm, one of the showgirls, Harriet Browne, looked down on the bejeweled audience and imagined that their world was hers. That when she left the smoky nightclub tipsy with drink, there would be a mink coat to wrap around her shoulders and a black Cadillac to carry her home.

title: CORPORATION WINS IN PENSION RULING
description: The Supreme Court ruled in a closely watched labor case today that an employer could require employees to give up various legal claims against a company as the price of receiving an early-retirement buyout with enhanced pension benefits.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Employers' Rights Upheld In Early-Retirement Plans In a closely watched labor case involving Lockheed Martin, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that employers can require workers to give up various legal claims against a company as the price of receiving an early-retirement buyout with enhanced pension benefits.

title: Executive Changes
description: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., said James Groff, who left this year, had rejoined the company as senior vice president and head of the new Internet appliance unit.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Light Laptops, Few Compromises
description: WHEN the plane touches down at gate A1 and the connecting flight departs from gate D437, the typical notebook computer becomes a clanking ball and chain. The two or three pounds you save by carrying a lighter model can spell the difference between mere crankiness and terminal depression.

title: BASEBALL;Key Limps Off With a New Injury After Six Solid Innings
description: Jimmy Key's sweaty face was twisted into a pained expression as he limped off the mound in the sixth inning tonight. He did not respond to a standing ovation from the enemy fans and barely shook hands with teammates as he hopped through the dugout and disappeared into the clubhouse. He was hurting.

title: After 104 Minutes, Colorado Wins the Cup
description: The Colorado Avalanche won the Stanley Cup this morning with a piece of exquisite drama, an epic 1-0 victory over the Florida Panthers in triple overtime on a goal by defenseman Uwe Krupp.

title: S O S for the City's Trees
description: New York City's street trees are dying at an alarming rate. Unless New Yorkers spring into action with buckets and garden hoses, many neighborhoods could find themselves denuded. The result would be a hotter and uglier city.

title: NEW YORK
description: NEW YORK

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tree Cutters Warned
description: The trees that surround the 5.7-billion-gallon Lake DeForest Reservoir act as a natural filtration system, helping to keep the water pure for 250,000 United Water customers in Rockland County, N.Y., and 750,000 in Bergen and Hudson counties in New Jersey. But with increasing frequency, some neighbors have been cutting trees on United Water's property to enhance their view of the lake, said Rich Henning, a spokesman for United Water. Yesterday, the company said it would sue anyone who felled trees on its property. Charles Holbrook, the Town Supervisor, said Clarkstown residents were probably unaware of the harm they may be causing. "It's always been a mystery where the water in Lake DeForest goes," he said.

title: Forstmann to Acquire Community Health for $1.1 Billion
description: Betting that small-town hospitals can thrive despite the cost-cutting pressures sweeping through health care, the New York investment firm Forstmann Little & Company said yesterday that it would buy Community Health Systems Inc. for $1.1 billion.

title: Jo Van Fleet, 81, an Actress Who Portrayed Proud Women
description: Jo Van Fleet, who won an Academy Award, a Tony Award and other honors for her portrayal of proud, stoical women, died yesterday at Jamaica Hospital in Queens. She was 81.

title: Q&A
description: Cry if You Want To

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. FILTER PLANS TO BUY DAVIS WATER IN STOCK SWAP
description: The United States Filter Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Davis Water and Waste Industries in a stock swap valued about $102 million. U.S. Filter, based in Palm Desert, Calif., plans to exchange 0.933 common share for each of the 3.25 million Davis Water shares. The deal values Davis Water at $31.372 a share. Davis Water's stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $29.875 a share. U.S. Filter stock was unchanged at $33.625. U.S. Filter provides industrial and commercial water treatment systems and services and has annual sales of about $472 million. Davis, of Thomasville, Ga., makes water treatment and pumping equipment and had revenues of $215 million in its 1995 fiscal year.

title: Biology's Big Project Turns Into Challenge For Computer Experts
description: THE University of Washington has jumped into the DNA sequencing business in a big way, building a world-class center to study the exact order of the chemicals that make up human DNA. And the seed money, the $12 million that has allowed the university to lure the stars of science to its campus? It came from Bill Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Farmers in a Poor Region of Russia Long for Stability and OpposeYeltsin
description: The idea of owning a private farm is just a passing fancy for Anatoly F. Gorda.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;BBDO Canada Wins Four Gold Medals
description: BBDO Canada in Toronto won the most awards at the 75th annual Art Directors Awards ceremony, sponsored by the Art Directors Club in New York.

title: Doing Police Sketches: 'Not an Exact Science'
description: In teaching classes on criminal procedure, Aaron H. Rosenthal favored the following trick: Midway through a lecture, a man would briefly stick his head in the room and ask an innocuous question. Later, Mr. Rosenthal would instruct students to describe the fleeting visitor.

title: Foster Care Agency Inflated Costs, Audit Says
description: The City Comptroller yesterday accused a private nonprofit foster care agency of improperly billing New York City for hundreds of thousands of dollars, asserting that it had charged the city for care it never provided to children as well as for a raft of unsubstantiated expenses.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANN TAYLOR TO ACQUIRE REMAINING STAKE IN JOINT VENTURE
description: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement for the $38.6 million acquisition of 60 percent of a joint venture that supplies much of the retailer's inventory. Ann Taylor plans to buy out the stake of Cygne Designs Inc. in their joint venture called CAT. Cygne has had financial difficulty, and the acquisition should help assure Ann Taylor of continued supplies of women's apparel. Together, Cygne, based in New York, and CAT accounted for 54 percent of the New York-based retailer's merchandise in the past. The definitive agreement calls for Ann Taylor to pay with stock worth $36 million and as much as $2.6 million in cash.

title: As the Cereal War Heats Up, Kellogg Reduces Prices
description: The Kellogg Company wheeled out the heavy artillery in the cereal war yesterday, announcing price cuts averaging 19 percent on Frosted Flakes, Raisin Bran and 14 other cereals, representing two-thirds of its domestic cereal sales.

title: Court Backs Lower Lawyer Fees For Poor in Death Penalty Cases
description: The state's highest court ruled today that lawyers representing indigent defendants in death penalty cases should get no more than $175 an hour.

title: Prison for Ex-Chief Of College Bound
description: The former chief executive of College Bound, George Ronkin, was sentenced last week in Federal court to six years in prison for fraudulently overstating the company's earnings in 1991.

title: BASEBALL;Hundley's Bat Gives a Boost To Feisty Mets
description: The Atlanta Braves may be the class of the National League East, but when it comes to bravado the Mets think they have every bit as much as the defending World Series champions.

title: Sports of The Times;Parker Deserves The Chance
description: SEVENTEEN months after pleading guilty to the crime of sexual abuse, and after several universities recruited him and then withdrew offers in the face of strong protests from many groups, Richie Parker announced yesterday that he would attend Long Island University and that the school would allow him to play basketball next season.

title: The Age Issue Dogs Senator Thurmond, 93
description: Senator Strom Thurmond has long commanded such respect in South Carolina that to this point in his legendary career, his age never really seemed to matter. As with Ronald Reagan during his second Presidential term, people might whisper that Mr. Thurmond, now 93, seemed a bit feeble, but saying it out loud was as unthinkable as insulting a beloved old grandfather.

title: Negotiations Begin on Auto Industry Pact
description: Officials from the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company were carrying baseball bats when they showed up here today for the ritual of opening negotiations on a three-year labor contract, but their meeting was cordial and largely ceremonial.

title: Curfews and Common Sense
description: The idea of imposing nighttime curfews on teen-agers is winning converts in high places. President Clinton recently urged more cities to adopt curfews to combat juvenile crime and promote family values. Bob Dole also spoke approvingly of the idea in a recent speech. Congress is considering $125 million in incentive grants to states that adopt various measures to combat juvenile crime, including curfews.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VALUEVISION TO BUY MONTGOMERY WARD CATALOGUE UNIT
description: Valuevision International Inc., the nation's third-largest home-shopping network, said yesterday that it would buy Montgomery Ward & Company's catalogue business, Montgomery Ward Direct, in exchange for warrants to purchase about 3.2 million Valuevision common shares at an exercise price of 1 cent each. The warrants would be worth about $24 million, based on the current stock price of Valuevision. If Montgomery Ward, a privately held retailer based in Chicago, exercised all of the warrants, it would own 26 percent of Valuevision, which sells Montgomery Ward products on its cable home-shopping channel. Valuevision, based in Minneapolis, would have full use of the Montgomery Ward name, the right to use Ward's 10 million-plus credit card file for direct mailings and the files of three million of Montgomery Ward Direct's catalogue users.

title: Sterling Forest Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: 1 Billion in Borrowing Is Sought for School Work
description: Assembly Speaker Jack Collins proposed a 25-cents-a-pack increase in the state's cigarette tax today to pay for a $1 billion bond issue that would in turn help pay for the state's most ambitious school-construction program in decades.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trade Surplus Shrinks in Japan
description: Increases in imports and in spending overseas helped to shrink the surplus in Japan's broadest measure of trade by 45 percent in April, the Ministry of Finance said yesterday. The current account surplus dropped to 555.2 billion yen ($5.09 billion), from 1.013 trillion yen in April 1995.

title: I.B.M. to Sell Storage Technology's Products
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it had agreed to resell under its own name storage systems for mainframe computers made by the Storage Technology Corporation. The products will begin appearing with the I.B.M. logo in July.

title: Marx Leads Team To a National Title
description: Leslie Marx, of Pittsford, N.Y., who had already won two titles at the United States Fencing Association's championship tournament, led the Rochester Fencing Center team to a gold medal over Salle Santelli of New Jersey today in women's epee.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOVIE GALLERY INC., Dothan, Ala., a video store chain, agreed to purchase Home Vision Entertainment Inc., which operates a chain of 55 video stores in Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts, for $32 million.

title: Japan and South Korea Pledge Aid to North
description: Japan decided today to donate $6 million to North Korea in response to a United Nations appeal to help stave off severe food shortages caused by floods, Government officials said.

title: Jersey Court to Decide Limits of Victim's Right to Address Jury
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court is expected to rule soon on a challenge to what has become a politically powerful new right, a victim's right to address jurors on the impact of a crime. After a decade in which a national victims' movement has won an expanded role in the criminal justice system, cases like the one here are testing the limits of the new victims' rights laws, stirring what amounts to a national debate about the purpose of criminal trials.

title: Clinton Veto Kept Abortion on Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: Agony, Ecstasy, Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Early Music Finds Niche As a Pop Hit
description: At a time when black despair hangs over large sectors of the classical music world, early-music specialists are actually wondering whether their business is too good. At a panel discussion addressing the phenomenon of best-selling Gregorian chant records, Katherine Bergeron, a musicologist at the University of California at Berkeley, spoke skeptically of "music lying in the cracks, in an ill-defined space between history, novelty and spirituality." Early music as a whole has fallen into that strange crossover zone. Through coffee ads and rush-hour radio programming, it has become part of the great subliminal murmur of mass culture.

title: Inside Lloyd Webber's Corporate Engine
description: To the Editor:

title: Crash Search Is Concluded After 4 Weeks And a Record
description: A month after the crash of Valujet Flight 592, Federal investigators today declared the search for more wreckage and human remains officially over.

title: Long-Winded Suit by Garbage Haulers Is Tossed
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit by private garbage haulers attacking the New York City agency created to regulate them. But the decision settled little and gave each side a chance to claim a victory.

title: TV SPORTS;The Newest Approach: All the Sports News But None of the Games
description: Four months ago, CNN and Sports Illustrated announced the creation of CNN/SI, a 24-hour all-news sports network. The notion of a service devoted solely to news and assorted blather -- without any games -- seemed audacious but flaky.

title: Russia Central Bank Acts to Curb Inflation
description: Struggling to limit the economic damage from President Boris N. Yeltsin's increasingly costly campaign promises, Russia's Central Bank imposed a series of measures today to tighten credit and keep inflation down.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Pinelands Bonds Advance
description: A $70 million bond issue intended to provide upgraded sewage treatment in the Pinelands region of central New Jersey was approved yesterday by the Assembly Judiciary Committee and sent to the full Assembly. The measure would provide grants and loans to municipalities, counties and authorities in the one-million-acre Pinelands area, which sits on top of an aquifer that is a major source of drinking water.

title: BASEBALL;Marquis Pitches Tottenville To Its Second Straight Title
description: Jason Marquis of Tottenville showed yesterday why he was a high draft pick of the World Series champion Atlanta Braves when he pitched his team to its second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League title.

title: Palestinian Police Rearrest Rights Advocate Who Criticized Arafat
description: A prominent Palestinian advocate for human rights and critic of Yasir Arafat's rule whose arrest last month caused an international outcry was rearrested by the Palestinian police early this morning.

title: Federal Reserve Board Has Too Much Power
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Peace Talks Open on Ulster

title: CHRONICLE
description: Just in time for summer reading, RICHARD P. NATHAN, provost of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government, a public-policy research group in Albany, has produced his new book list.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;5 Die, 38 Hurt by Bombs In Pakistan Punjab Area
description: At least 5 people were killed and 38 wounded in three bomb blasts in Punjab province today, the police and hospital officials said.

title: Transplant Successes
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;Westinghouse Considers Split Of Businesses
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation sent pleasing ripples through Wall Street yesterday when it confirmed longstanding rumors that it was considering ways to separate its broadcasting and industrial businesses.

title: Central Park Wasn't Meant as Retreat From City
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Dispute, Justice Addresses Students
description: Appearing unannounced at the last minute, Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas spoke before an eighth-grade awards ceremony here after his invitation had sparked weeks of protests and disputes among school board members.

title: Brookline Journal;Forget Fenway. Phillies Were Sweet This Night.
description: Under the lights at Fenway Park, at the top of the first inning, with 24,382 people watching, the hapless Red Sox were losing, yet again.

title: Integrated Device Shares Slide by 8%
description: Shares of Integrated Device Technology Inc. fell 8 percent yesterday after the company disclosed that its fiscal first-quarter earnings would come in below Wall Street's expectations because of declining demand for its integrated circuits.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Zoo Gets a New Life
description: Four months ago, the Turtle Back Zoo was on the brink of extinction. Now business is booming at the zoo, which is owned by Essex County, and it will stay open at least until the end of the year, thanks in large part to an overhaul and the efforts of volunteers from the New Jersey Zoological Society.

title: Kamsky and Karpov Spar a Bit, Then Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gata Kamsky stood each other off with correct play yesterday and agreed to a draw. Thus, after three games in their International Chess Federation match in the Kalmykian capital of Elista, the score is tied at 1 1/2-1 1/2.

title: MetroStars Switch to Cups
description: The MetroStars and Giants Stadium yesterday discontinued the sale of soda and water in plastic bottles after bottle-throwing incidents that led to eight arrests at the game with the Los Angeles Galaxy on Sunday.

title: Toll of Childbearing: 585,000 Women Die Per Year
description: In the first comprehensive survey in a decade to look at maternal deaths worldwide, Unicef reported today that about 585,000 women die each year in pregnancy and childbirth, many needlessly. Millions more, perhaps as many as 18 million women, suffer debilitating illnesses or injuries that often disable them.

title: Colombia Journal;A Rio Grande Bridge Too Far From Everywhere
description: Drive west along the southern bank of the Rio Grande from Nuevo Laredo, and about the only signs of life are the mesquite and the prickly pear cactus. Lizards skittering across the asphalt have more to fear from the occasional hawk wheeling overhead than from vehicles, of which there are few.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A new survey charts the habits of teen-agers around the world. They love basketball and TV.
description: IF all the world's teen-agers could hang out in one place tomorrow night, they would probably choose Key Arena in Seattle to watch the Chicago Bulls battle the Supersonics for the American basketball championship. Or so suggests a new survey of the habits, tastes and values of 25,000 adolescents in 41 countries.

title: BASEBALL;Baseball Picks Business Chief
description: Major League Baseball's search for a top business executive will end today with the naming of a president of a new subsidiary, Major League Baseball Enterprises.

title: After Newark Takeover, Hopes Fade for Quick Fix of Schools
description: The state government promised to end the rampant failure of Newark's students when it evicted the top administrators and the elected board from New Jersey's largest school district 12 months ago.

title: OLYMPICS;Putting Her Life Back on the Track
description: She was only 21, just beyond her junior year at Villanova, when Vicki Huber boldly moved to the front of the women's 3,000-meter race at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, seemingly positioning herself for a long, prosperous career in distance running.

title: Buzz, Honk, Click: Bats Reveal Presence to New Sonar Device
description: AS the sun goes down, two conservation biologists, Bruce and Carolyn Miller, trudge into the tropical forest of Belize carrying a portable table and laptop computer swaddled in plastic to keep the bugs from gumming up the keys.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOBIL TO SELL REAL ESTATE ASSETS TO WESTBROOK
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its community real estate business in seven states to Westbrook Partners, an investment fund, for $324 million. The deal includes 18 of 20 planned communities owned by Mobil Land Development, based in Reston, Va., one of the nation's largest organizations for planned community development. The deal is consistent with Mobil's strategy to sell assets that are "worth more to others" and invest proceeds in the company's oil, gas and chemicals business, the company said in a statement. Westbrook was formed in April 1994 by former senior executives of the Morgan Stanley Real Estate Fund. Westbrook controls more than $1.6 billion in real estate assets in 24 states.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Alienated in a City of Gloom, Fire and Dreams
description: AMNESIASCOPE By Steve Erickson 225 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $23.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korea Awards Communications Work
description: The South Korean Ministry of Information and Communications awarded licenses yesterday to groups led by LG Information and Communications Ltd. and Hansol Group for a new cellular telephone service called personal communications service, which will be started next year. The service is expected to transmit data and images as well as voices at less cost than conventional cellular service.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China Finds Insurers for Space Launchings
description: China will resume its commercial space program in July after international insurers agreed to underwrite the next launching, a spokesman for China's rocket launcher, the China Great Wall Industry Corporation, said today.

title: Police Shoot Woman at Mall Seeking Suicide
description: A woman was shot dead by the police in the parking lot of a Woodbridge strip mall early this morning in an episode that the authorities described as a form of suicide.

title: BOXING;De La Hoya Wants the Fans in His Corner
description: Oscar De La Hoya is chasing something that may be harder to capture than his startlingly easy victory last week over Julio Cesar Chavez: respect from the people who idolize Chavez.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Shirley M. Tilghman;Fighting and Studying Battle of the Sexes With Men and Mice
description: SHIRLEY M. TILGHMAN was talking recently to a group of young female scientists about a topic that like an old lover, remains close to her heart, but that she wishes would just go away: the dilemma of being a woman in science. She was trying to convince the young women that they could have it all, or at least most of what is worth having, and that they need not choose between a passionate devotion to their work, and a family, a home, love.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Adcom Executives Join Other Agencies
description: Two top executives at Adcom Investors Inc. and its troubled agency N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York have joined other agencies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SPARTECH TO BUY HAMELIN'S PLASTICS DIVISIONS
description: The Spartech Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Montreal-based Hamelin Group's plastic extrusion, color and molding divisions for about $60 million. St. Louis-based Spartech said the acquisition would allow it to open a new facility in the Northeastern United States or Canada by 1997. The acquisition is also expected to increase Spartech revenue by about $85 million, to $475 million, and increase Spartech's earnings immediately, the company said. Spartech makes engineered plastics, and the privately owned Hamelin makes plastic products for the industrial and housewares market.

title: NYC;To Russia, With Faith And Concern
description: WALL STREET is wondering how world markets will react, and the Pentagon presumably has people analyzing the national defense implications. But who gets to ponder the important question of the impact that Russia's Presidential election on Sunday will have on that nation's religious soul?

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Journey Fighting Fire, Wind And Evil
description: The Compagnie Ebene was one of the hits of the Lyons Dance Biennial in 1994. And many in the audience rose to give the performers a standing ovation on Sunday afternoon, when the group performed at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But "Yenenga," the hourlong piece presented by the company in this New York debut, was disappointing. Compagnie Ebene is based in Burkina Faso and Paris, and "Yenenga" straddled both worlds.

title: 47 Oppose Bill to Keep Illegal Aliens Out of School
description: In a warning to House and Senate Republican leaders, 42 Democrats and 5 moderate Republicans in the Senate threatened today to block pending immigration legislation if it included a House provision allowing states to bar children who are illegal immigrants from public schools.

title: Exxon Moves On Sakhalin Oilfield Deal
description: The Exxon Corporation, after five years of effort, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Russian Government that would enable a consortium of companies it leads to begin work on oil and gas fields off Sakhalin Island, a project that could eventually cost $15 billion.

title: Broad Ulster Peace Talks Begin, But Without I.R.A.-Linked Party
description: Broad-based peace talks on Northern Ireland lurched into existence today, involving the British and Irish Governments and all the major northern political parties except Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Plan for Trenton, Tax for Smokers
description: The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly has proposed a 25-cent increase in the state's cigarette tax today to pay for a $1 billion bond issue that would help finance the state's most ambitious school construction program in decades.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Rate Fears Push Prices Down Again
description: The bond market continued to slide yesterday as prices remained under heavy pressure from investors who increasingly expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swedish Bid for Supplier Of Building Materials
description: Skanska A.B. has offered to take full control of the building materials company Skane-Gripen A.B. for 3.01 billion kronor ($460 million), Skanska said yesterday. Skanska, a Swedish construction and property management concern, is offering 82.5 kronor ($12.61) for each class A and B share, a premium of 31 percent. In addition, Skane-Gripen has "bonus shares" for which Skanska is offering 116 kronor ($17.73) apiece.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASKETBALL;Parker Will Play at Long Island University
description: Richie Parker's mother was right next to him, sitting with her hands folded, jiggling her foot now and then under the table.

title: Possible Dual Threat From Ticks: Lyme and Another Disease, As Well
description: WITH the advent of the tick season come warnings that the insidious arthropods can deliver other illnesses besides Lyme disease, and that doctors must take care to treat each correctly.

title: Latest Health Insurance Bill Encounters Less Hostility
description: On the eve of Bob Dole's departure from the Senate, Congressional Republicans agreed tonight on a health insurance bill -- but with a provision for medical savings accounts that could invite a veto from President Clinton.

title: Images of Revolutions Old and New
description: Starting his career as a photographer in the early 1950's, Marc Riboud was lucky enough to have the founders of the Magnum photo agency as friends and advisers. While Henri Cartier-Bresson tried to broaden the young Frenchman's education, telling him what to read and what museums to visit, Robert Capa encouraged him to learn English and even arranged his first professional assignment.

title: Closing Long Chapter, Dole Looks Ahead
description: Hours before leaving the Senate, Senator Bob Dole declared that he had "no illusions about the difficulties ahead of us," but he told supporters at a black-tie Republican fund-raiser here that they should not despair about the next chapter in his political life: his campaign for President.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Youth Guilty in Gun Death
description: An Atlantic County jury convicted a teen-ager yesterday of murdering a 15-year-old girl who told him she was not afraid of his gun. The youth, DeWayne Simons, now 17, of Pleasantville, admitted shooting Le-Ann Washington in 1994 but told the police he was showing off the gun when it accidentally fired, said Ellen Loughney, an assistant prosecutor. "This girl had called his bluff," Ms. Loughney said. "He either had to use the gun as threatened or suffer the consequences to his manhood."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Slow Change for Schools
description: The state promised to end the rampant failure of Newark's students when it evicted the top administrators and the elected board from New Jersey's largest school district 12 months ago. There would be a new emphasis on classroom instruction, officials said, and no tolerance for abuses of the past, when board members kept cars and restaurant accounts while students lacked basic amenities. But as the academic year ends, there are few tangible signs of change. [Page A1.]

title: CITY BALLET REVIEW;Male Soloists Shine in Two Debuts
description: George Balanchine was always said to be more interested in choreographing for women than for men. Many of the male roles in his ballets, nonetheless, are intricate and difficult.

title: Senator D'Amato's Windfall
description: Alfonse D'Amato says the latest revelations about his remarkably profitable 1993 stock investment are "old news" floated by people "trying to embarrass" him. Yet the Senator's stock deal continues to raise legitimate questions about his ethical judgment that require prompt investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee.

title: Research Suggests Sleep Seizures May Be Linked to Immune System
description: AFTER decades of slow progress in understanding narcolepsy, a disorder characterized by sudden seizures of sleepiness, researchers say it may be linked to the immune system and may also be as prevalent in women as it is in men.

title: Clinton Calls on the Nation To Defy 'Forces of Hatred'
description: Jettisoning a planned announcement of an anti-drug effort, President Clinton turned instead today to the wave of arson that has destroyed black churches across the South, and called on the nation to "show the forces of hatred they cannot win."

title: Trading Halted In Home Link
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended trading in the shares of the Home Link Corporation for 10 business days. The S.E.C. said today that questions had been raised about the accuracy of public information about the company, whose stock price has skyrocketed in the last three weeks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALCOA ANNOUNCES CLOSING OF SAN DIEGO PACKAGING PLANT
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it had closed its Alcoa Electronic Packaging plant after failing to find a buyer for the subsidiary, which makes ceramic packages for microprocessors. Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, has been winding down operations at the San Diego plant since the beginning of the year after its principal customer, the Intel Corporation, said it would not be placing any new orders. In March, Alcoa laid off virtually all of the plant's roughly 600 regular employees. Alcoa said closing the plant would reduce its second-quarter earnings by $40 million after taxes. The charge is related to the expected loss from the sale of equipment and inventories. In the second quarter last year, Alcoa earned $219.4 million.

title: Blood, Money and AIDS: Hemophiliacs Are Split;Liability Cases Bogged Down in Disputes
description: Last December, Corey Dubin, a hemophiliac infected with the virus that causes AIDS, met for lunch at a Carrow's restaurant in Camarillo, Calif., with John Bacich, the president of a Baxter International Inc. unit that makes blood-clotting products.

title: Observer;Any Moment Now
description: The evidence was conclusive: The world was coming to an end. It was only a matter of days now, a few weeks at most. Scientists were unanimous. Dr. Edward Teller conceded there was nothing even he could do to stave off the end.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JERRY STILLER is about to have something in common with George Burns other than being known as half of a married comedic team (Stiller and Meara, Burns and Allen). On Sunday, he will receive the George Burns Memorial Award at a celebration of immigration called "The Lower East Side Festival: Gateway to the American Dream." Mr. Stiller grew up on the Lower East Side, among other places.

title: One More Mr. Nice Guy
description: Bob Dole removed his tie for a day but now regularly puts it on. Is he doing the same with the tie that binds him to a false, liberal definition of compassion?

title: Financier Sentenced In Italian Bank Case
description: A Milan appeals court sentenced the Italian financier Carlo De Benedetti today to four and a half years in prison for his part in Italy's most spectacular postwar bank failure.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;In Between Crimes, Adultery and Death
description: British television has produced two smashing police-detective series in recent years, each a superb vehicle for its star. Granada Television takes credit for both: "Prime Suspect," with Helen Mirren, and "Cracker," starring Robbie Coltrane. "Cracker," created by Jimmy McGovern ("Priest"), begins a third season of feature-length dramas tonight on A&E, three this time. Prepare for some serious rattling.

title: An Israeli-Palestinian 'Sesame Street'
description: How would you say "Grouch" in Arabic? Would Hebrew-speaking children understand it? Should a television character named Oscar the Grouch even exist in a conflict-riven country like Israel?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16

title: Exxon Wins $250 Million From Lloyd's for Alaska Oil Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation won $250 million yesterday from Lloyd's of London underwriting syndicates and other insurers that sold policies to protect the oil company from liabilities like those incurred after the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: HORSE RACING;Canada Keeps Breeders' Cup
description: With assurance that labor disputes will not interfere, Breeders' Cup officials said today that the races would take place Oct. 26 at Woodbine Racetrack near Toronto as originally scheduled.

title: I.N.S. Agents Return To Garment Factories
description: To the Editor:

title: States Have Moved to Keep Plaintiffs From Using Courts to MuzzleCritics

The attack brought to nine the Israeli death toll in southern Lebanon since the Israeli election and added to the mounting pressures on Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Law School Women Gain From Socratic Wars;Technical Knockout
description: To the Editor: The thesis of "Law School Women Question the Teaching" (Education page, June 5) is correct. Throughout the past year as a first-year law school student, I was present in classes where the opinions of female students were taken less seriously or where women were belittled through use of the Socratic method, in which students are called on by their professor and required to analyze cases in front of their peers. In one of my classes, a male professor stated that he was uncomfortable with the idea of women practicing law. However, my other male professors encouraged both male and female voices to participate.

title: Liberia Faction To DisarmDTL>MONROVIA, Liberia, June 11
description: Forces for the ethnic Krahns, one of the factions in Liberia's six-year-old civil war, agreed today to disarm and leave an army barracks that was at the center of recent fighting. About 500 members of the faction left the barracks and handed over about 50 weapons.

title: About New York;At Gathering Amid Beauty, Worldly Pain
description: BEFORE she goes to work each night as a nurse's aide downtown, Elizabeth Rogers journeys to Ralph Bunche Park, where she sits with her back to the United Nations. Maybe it's a comment on what she feels the international community has done to her native land. Ms. Rogers is Liberian and has many relatives ensnared by the chaotic limbo of that nation's six-year civil war, where warlords enlist children to fight the battles of men. While the looting and shooting of recent months have died down, life is far from normal as refugee-laden ships search in vain for a haven in other African nations.

An additional passenger coach was coupled to five trains, which run on the Morris and Essex line, and cars will also be added today to two trains on the Gladstone and Morristown branches, said the spokeswoman, Penny Bassett Hackett.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Bit of Fancy, Then Repose
description: The program was as it should have been when Alonzo King's Lines Contemporary Ballet danced on Sunday night. Earlier in the week, this San Francisco company had scheduled a new work by Mr. King called "Handel Pas de Deux" as part of its engagement at the Joyce Theater. But an injury sustained by Muriel Maffre, the French ballerina for whom it was created, prevented it from being shown. By the weekend, Ms. Maffre had recovered and was able to perform the duet with Benjamin Pierce as her partner. Both she and Mr. Pierce appeared with Mr. King's troupe as guest artists from the San Francisco Ballet. The pas de deux was well worth waiting for.

Iverson will endorse Reebok products, which is a switch. Georgetown players wore Nike shoes. (AP)

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Avalanche's First Title Is Taken With Flourish
description: Uwe Krupp and Stanley Cup don't rhyme quite perfectly, but the combination has a nice ring to it. Krupp, the big defenseman of the Colorado Avalanche, etched his name onto the silver trophy and into hockey history early this morning when he scored on a long slap shot in triple overtime to give his team the National Hockey League championship. The goal -- at 4 minutes 31 seconds of the third extra session -- gave the Avalanche a 1-0 victory over the Florida Panthers here, ending a tense, five-hour marathon and completing a four-game sweep. The game was a dramatic conclusion to an anticlimactic series at the end of a splendid tournament.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Retired Players Unite
description: Several former National Basketball Association players, including ALEX ENGLISH, DAVE COWENS, OSCAR ROBERTSON and JERRY WEST, gathered yesterday without a basketball in sight. They were in Manhattan to announce the first marketing venture of an organization known as XPRO, the association of retired professional basketball players. XPRO was formed to create a support system for the hundreds of former players who pioneered and popularized the game before the existence of adequate pension plans. Yesterday it announced a deal with Whitehall-Robins Healthcare's Anacin brand pain reliever, which will provide XPRO with funds to assist its 525 members and their families through scholarships, insurance programs and health care benefits. A television advertising campaign will feature the former players BILL WALTON, BOB COUSY, Cowens, Robertson and West. "Before, we could only use the super superstars like LARRY BIRD for marketing purposes," said English, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association and former eight-time N.B.A. All-Star. "This gives us the opportunity to market the players that were in the trenches and really built this league."

title: World News Briefs;Explosion in Brazil Mall Kills 44 and Injures 100
description: An explosion in a shopping mall on the outskirts of Sao Paulo at lunchtime today blew holes in concrete walls and killed 44 people. More than 100 others were injured. Rescue workers expected to find more bodies beneath the rubble, said Lieut. Col. Edson Alves Domingues of the Sao Paulo fire department.

title: CIRCUIT CITY PLANS 8 TO 10 CARMAX DEALERSHIPS NEXT YEAR
description: Circuit City Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would open 8 to 10 Carmax used-car dealerships next year and that it planned to operate 80 to 90 of the so-called superstores by 2001, up from 5 now. The company, which also operates the Circuit City electronics stores, said it planned to open Carmax dealerships next year in Miami, Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth. title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN SKIING TO SELL RESORTS TO SETTLE U.S. SUIT
description: The Justice Department won agreement yesterday from the American Skiing Company to sell two New Hampshire ski resorts as a condition of gaining Government approval for its $137 million acquisition of S-K-I Ltd. The Justice Department said that without the divestiture, American Skiing would have controlled eight of the largest ski resorts in eastern New England. To resolve a Government civil lawsuit filed to block the deal, American Skiing agreed to sell S-K-I's Waterville Valley and its own Mount Cranmore ski resorts. The lawsuit and agreement were filed simultaneously in United States District Court. S-K-I owns Killington and Mount Snow-Haystack in Vermont and a majority stake in Sugarloaf in Maine.

title: Foreign Affairs;Bosnia Election Blues
description: While visiting the Balkans recently, I spent a morning talking with two Bosnian Serb journalists in Pale, the capital of the Serb Republic. What I recall most about our discussion was how unabashedly these two women expressed their desire to never again live in the same country with their former Muslim and Croatian neighbors. "We can live next door to the Muslims, but we cannot live together anymore," said Jelena Dabarcic. "And by the way, if we raped and tortured them so much, as they say, why would they want to live with us?" Draga Grubic was slightly more poetic but no less blunt: "I have no desire to go to Sarajevo anymore. I don't even have a desire to go back to Zagreb, where I used to live. It's like a love relationship -- when it's over, it's over and you have to find another one." I've been thinking of that conversation as the debate heats up over whether the international community should certify that conditions exist in Bosnia for holding fair elections. Those conditions include the arrest of war criminals, access to media for opposition parties and an atmosphere free of intimidation. U.S. officials acknowledge that few of those conditions exist today, but they are pressuring European election organizers to authorize the voting anyway, arguing that with a little effort conditions will be good enough by Sept. 14, Election Day.

title: Reagan's Tax Cut Didn't Cause Deficits
description: To the Editor: Roger C. Altman (Op-Ed, June 6) perpetuates the myth that President Reagan's across-the-board tax cut produced the large budget deficits of the 1980's. The deficit increased in the 1980's because Government expenditures outraced Federal tax revenues, whose growth was 65 percent higher per year in the low-tax-rate 1980's than in the high-tax-rate 1990's. Mr. Altman says that substantial tax cuts would contribute to declining living standards and wages. In the wake of the Reagan tax-rate reductions, real median family income increased from $36,326 in 1982 to $40,890 in 1989. Since Congress raised income tax rates in 1990, however, real median family income has declined, from $40,087 in 1990 to $38,782 in 1994. Under President Clinton, the growth rate of median family income has been zero percent.

title: Whose Life Is It Anyway?
description: Wasn't Bob Dole's abortion dilemma settled only last week? No sooner had he announced his desire to include a ''declaration of tolerance'' for pro-choice Republicans in his party's platform than seemingly every G.O.P. leader, seconded by every major news organization, lined up to declare peace was at hand. On one network news show Friday night, no fewer than four party factotums, starting with Pat Buchanan, expressed varying degrees of contentment with Mr. Dole's masterly move. It all sounded like a done deal -- unless you paused to notice that not one of the leaders canvassed was a woman.
