title: BASEBALL;Selling Americans Their Own Pastime
description: If you've marketed brands like Entenmann's, Maxwell House, Lenders bagels, Pepsi Light and Tang, can you sell the world on Ken Griffey Jr., expansion, wild-card playoffs, interleague play and Albert Belle? Major league baseball hopes so. Baseball yesterday handed its marketing reins to Gregory Murphy, a diplomat's son who played Little League in Libya and was most recently president of Kraft Foods Bakery Companies. Murphy lacks sports experience, which did not scare off baseball. The erstwhile national pastime has come to be viewed as a vastly undermarketed product that long ago ceded market share to other sports and entertainments. "We determined that the position required experience that went beyond traditional sports marketing," said Bud Selig, the acting commissioner. Murphy, 47, insisted that the fundamentals of selling jars of coffee or bags of frozen bagels can be transferred to baseball. "Get deeply involved and understand your consumer and your brand," he said. "I think I'm prepared." Murphy, who will report to Selig, becomes president of Major League Baseball Enterprises, a new division that embraces television, advertising, public relations, licensing, sponsorships and international development. "My biggest shock when I became chairman of the executive council in September 1992 was to find that baseball never had a central marketing operation," Selig said. "This was a very necessary step." The structure of the new division bears similarities to those in pro basketball, football and hockey, which have marketed themselves with more savvy than baseball. "The N.B.A.'s efforts the past decade have been extraordinary," Selig said. Donald M. Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said he has long hoped that baseball would adopt a national marketing strategy. "Without it, you don't give yourself a chance," he said. A labor deal, which has long eluded negotiators, would be crucial to baseball's marketing, by assuring fans that work stoppages will not reoccur. But Fehr said, "It would help, but there are a lot of strengths baseball has and must figure out, make known and reinforce." Murphy was reluctant to reveal his possible strategies to increase revenue, attendance, television ratings and franchise values, his four main goals. "I want to be sure I deeply understand the baseball brand and the consumer," he said. "I'm reluctant to say, 'These are my programs.' " But, he said, he understands that baseball is weakened. "Fans are angry," he said. "I think disgusted. In many ways that's great because they really care. When you have such an intense feeling, there's a passion." Baseball's popularity has suffered most among youth. Fewer kids are playing or tuning in on television. A new survey of 2,477 adolescents by the Brainwaves Group, a unit of the advertising agency D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, showed 63 percent chose baseball or softball as a favorite sport to play or to watch live or on television. Basketball was named by 76 percent, football by 74 percent. Murphy was asked to compare marketing baseball now (on the eve of a possible suspension for the Reds' owner, Marge Schott) to marketing Kool-Aid for Kraft in 1978 after the mass suicides of Jonestown cultists who drank a fruit-flavored drink laced with cyanide. Murphy said that it was actually another beverage used in Jonestown. "It had little effect on Kool-Aid," he said. He added: "Everyone feels passionately about baseball. Even Marge Schott. The core equity of Kool-Aid and the core equity of baseball are strong."

title: Waldheim, in New Book, Sees Jews Behind His Exile From U.S.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AT&T TO SPIN OFF ITS REMAINING STAKE IN LUCENT
description: The chairman of the AT&T Corporation, Robert E. Allen, said yesterday that he expected the company to spin off to shareholders its remaining stake in Lucent Technologies Inc. in the third quarter and all of the NCR Corporation in the fourth quarter. In remarks prepared for delivery to a conference of securities analysts, Mr. Allen said, "NCR is making good progress toward its goal of breaking even or better for the year as they restructure and refocus that business." Mr. Allen had previously said only that AT&T would complete its divestment of Lucent and NCR by the end of the year. AT&T in April made an initial public offering for 18 percent of Lucent, which is its communications equipment subsidiary. The NCR Corporation is a computer company.

title: Budget Agreement at City Hall
description: The new budget accord between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the New York City Council stands out as a tribute to common sense and compromise. The $33 billion budget is more realistic than Mr. Giuliani's original proposal last winter, and it addresses one of the city's most urgent needs by setting aside $1.4 billion in borrowed funds to repair schools in the next four years. But the budget also contains risky assumptions about state aid, and it fails to solve the underlying imbalance between spending and revenues that forces the city to lurch from budget crisis to budget crisis every year.

title: Tourist Is Attacked At Columbus Circle
description: A 24-year-old tourist from California was attacked by a man wielding a pipe yesterday near Columbus Circle in Manhattan, the second such incident in the area in the last two days, the police said.

title: John Alton, 94, Whose Camera Helped Give Form to Film Noir
description: John Alton, whose cinematography helped define film noir and who later shared an Academy Award for ''An American in Paris,'' died on June 2 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A Leader Departs
description: Bob Dole today ended more than a decade as a Senate Republican leader, his tenure notable for deep commitment to the sometimes conflicting goals of deficit reduction, his party and the Senate itself.

title: Getting Ketchup To Pour
description: SOME bludgeon with the ham of the hand.

title: 2 Take Top Honors At the Addy Awards
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., won the Best of Show awards last week at the 29th annual American Advertising Awards, sponsored by the American Advertising Federation in Washington.

title: Last Act in a Dominican Drama
description: As the Dominican Republic heads into a second-round presidential vote on June 30, the outcome may be influenced by a grouchy old man capable of causing ruin if he cannot rule. Joaquin Balaguer, having served seven terms as President since 1960, agreed under pressure not to run again. But Mr. Balaguer has formed a pact with a longtime archrival to prevent a runoff victory by Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, who won the most votes in the first round. An undercurrent of racism is regrettably evident in Mr. Balaguer's maneuver.

title: Are the Bosses Watching?
description: There is no question that President Clinton's staff has a talent for forcing people to choose between incompetence and skulduggery as an explanation for their managerial ''snafus'' -- to use Mr. Clinton's term. The Clinton staff's initial foray into misuse of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was in 1993, when it asked the bureau to invent a cover story for the decision to sack the travel office staff. The latest shenanigan was the collection of Republicans' F.B.I. files as part of a purportedly mismanaged effort to speed up security clearances.

title: 'U.S. Open Champion': Golf's Magic, or Tragic, Words
description: It happens on the first tee of the first event the week after the United States Open. Whether it's at an exhibition, an outing, a PGA Tour event or a club tournament doesn't matter. When a player has just won the United States Open, that first public proclamation never fails to raise goose bumps.

title: When Lifetime Jobs Die Prematurely;Downsizing Comes to Japan, Fraying Old Workplace Ties
description: When a major Japanese tire-and-rubber company asked a 53-year-old senior researcher to retire early last year, he refused. So the company moved him to a bare desk in the corner of a factory and told him that every two weeks, he would have to turn in a report on the same topic: "My Second Life." For six months, he stubbornly stuck it out, writing about himself until he had nothing left to say. In desperation, he turned to a friend, Kiyotsugu Shitara, who gave him two books on insects and animals, which turned out to be his salvation.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-14

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCI AND INTEL TEAM UP TO SELL WEB PRODUCTS
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and the Intel Corporation teamed up yesterday to sell a combination of products and services that are aimed at helping businesses publish information on the World Wide Web. MCI planned to market the product, called NetworkMCI Webmaker, to small and medium-sized businesses. At a starting price of about $10,000, businesses could purchase preconfigured computers, based on Intel's Pentium Pro chip, and software to establish a secure Internet presence. MCI and Intel hope to save companies the trouble of assembling various communications links, computers and other products themselves.

title: No Headline
description: ''After 2 today, when somebody calls me about bringing up their amendment, I'll say, 'It's all right with me.''

title: Business Travel;President Clinton's proposal to increase the international departure tax raises  some hackles.
description: AIRLINES and the travel industry have usually supported taxes earmarked for improvements in aviation or infrastructure. But President Clinton's recent proposal to raise the tax on international departures from $6 a passenger to $16, with the money used to help offset the cost of attending college, has gone over with the business travel community like the proverbial lead balloon. The Air Transport Association termed the proposed increase "an absolute outrage to air travelers who already pay a long list of taxes and fees totaling more than $6 billion annually." Carol Hallett, the association president, said the proposal would cost an additional $500 million a year, "and not a dime will be used to fund runways, radar systems, or anything else that benefits aviation safety or overall system capacity." She added that the tax would lead to a new round of bankruptcies and layoffs by aircraft makers.

title: Mr. Dole Bends on Abortion
description: If there was any central theme in Bob Dole's affectionate farewell to his Senate colleagues yesterday, it was that good things simply do not happen in the legislative arena unless people of differing doctrines agree to split their differences. That is precisely what Citizen Dole is now telling his party's right wing. Good things will not happen in November unless they are prepared to compromise on abortion, the most divisive issue facing his party and Presidential campaign.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IAT GROUP OF CHILE TO BUY FRESH DEL MONTE
description: The IAT Group of Chile has agreed to buy Fresh Del Monte Produce N.V. for $534 million in cash, equity and assumed debt from Mexico's Grupo Empresarial Agricola Mexicana, company officials said yesterday. Fresh Del Monte, based in Coral Gables, Fla., is the third-largest producer of fresh bananas and the largest marketer of fresh pineapples. IAT is a closely held Chilean fresh fruit producer that sells grapes, plums and peaches. Fresh Del Monte was once a part of the Del Monte Foods Company, the largest fruit and vegetable canner in the United States. Since the 1970's, however, Fresh Del Monte has passed through several owners.

title: Hijacker Sentenced to 20 Years as Judge Rejects Claim That Bias Made His Crime Justified
description: An Ethiopian man who hijacked a German jetliner to New York in 1993 was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison after a judge rejected his assertion that the hijacking was justified because his visa application to the United States had been denied.

title: Health Reform, By Inches
description: After President Clinton's health plan crashed and burned in 1994, conventional wisdom flipped: Pundits who had agreed that health reform should be "comprehensive" declared that progress could happen only incrementally -- tackling a few problems at a time and building bipartisan consensus. So they cheered when a liberal Democrat, Senator Edward Kennedy, teamed up with a moderate Republican, Senator Nancy Kassebaum, to introduce modest health reforms. Kennedy-Kassebaum, as this legislation is called, would require insurance companies to accept applicants regardless of pre-existing medical conditions and to allow employees to buy job-to-job health coverage. With different versions passing overwhelmingly in both houses, the bill was to be the perfect example of how well the incremental approach worked.

title: Bangladesh Hopes Vote Will Exorcise Violent Past
description: For more than two decades, the political life of Bangladesh has been roiled by an event of shocking violence, the assassination of the country's founding leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, and more than a dozen of his family members and aides.

title: Woman Slain Opening Her Park Ave. Dry Cleaner
description: A 65-year-old woman known on the Upper East Side as ''the lollipop lady'' for the sweets she doled out to children and the kindnesses she extended to customers was beaten to death yesterday as she opened her dry-cleaning shop on Park Avenue near 88th Street.

title: Bitters: Magic Potion for Food and Drink
description: TAKE a look inside your liquor cabinet, way back inside. See that little bottle with the yellow cap? When was the last time you used it? If you don't drink Manhattans or Old Fashioneds, you probably haven't used bitters for a very long time. But if you like Caribbean cooking, you may find yourself moving that bottle to the front of the shelf. An increasing number of cooks are adding the herbal tang of bitters to an array of dishes, from soups to desserts. In some ways, bitters have the versatility and addictive qualities of the hot sauces that many people can't seem to live without these days.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CIRCUIT CITY PLANS 8 TO 10 CARMAX DEALERSHIPS NEXT YEAR
description: Circuit City Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would open 8 to 10 Carmax used-car dealerships next year and that it planned to operate 80 to 90 of the so-called superstores by 2001, up from 5 now. The company, which also operates the Circuit City electronics stores, said it planned to open Carmax dealerships next year in Miami, Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth. Shares of Circuit City rose 87.5 cents, to $36.25.

title: Democrats Charge Dole Violated Rule On Spending
description: The Democratic National Committee charged tonight that Bob Dole's Presidential campaign exceeded Federal campaign spending limits by nearly $350,000 last month, and urged Federal officials to move against Mr. Dole's financially strapped campaign.

title: Personal Health
description: WHEN Alberto Salazar won the Boston Marathon in 1982, he fell into a coma right after crossing the finish line. Mr. Salazar sweats heavily, and he became so hot and dehydrated during the race that his organ systems were near collapse. Dr. William Castelli and a police officer saved his life by squeezing more than three quarts of replacement fluids into his veins.

title: TV Notes;A Morning Show Delay
description: The debut of the retooled version of "CBS This Morning" has been moved back from Aug. 5 to Aug. 12, CBS News announced, at the request of CBS's affiliated stations. The July ratings sweeps period, whose ratings are used to help determine local stations' advertising rates, ends during the first week in August, and stations wanted to keep program continuity through that period. Jose Diaz-Balart, Mark McEwen and Jane Robelot will be the co-anchors of the new 7-to-9 A.M. show, to be called "This Morning," a name meant to allow local stations to attach their own call letters to it. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Hammering Men, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Morning Show Delay
description: The debut of the retooled version of ''CBS This Morning'' has been moved back from Aug. 5 to Aug. 12, CBS News announced, at the request of CBS's affiliated stations. The July ratings sweeps period, whose ratings are used to help determine local stations' advertising rates, ends during the first week in August, and stations wanted to keep program continuity through that period. Jose Diaz-Balart, Mark McEwen and Jane Robelot will be the co-anchors of the new 7-to-9 A.M. show, to be called ''This Morning,'' a name meant to allow local stations to attach their own call letters to it. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Plunges on Worries Of Possible Big Sales in Japan
description: Copper prices tumbled yesterday as a market already nervous about supply was roiled by speculation that a management change at a big Japanese trading company could lead to a selloff of its copper holdings. Traders said that rumors that Yasuo Hamanaka, the chief copper trader at the Sumitomo Corporation, had resigned sent copper prices plunging. Traders were betting that the company would sell its copper positions, said Wolfgang Becker, a trader at Iceni Commodities Brokerage in Hamburg, Germany.

title: The Bulls Prepare to Face Their Toughest Foe: History
description: Michael Jordan is not sure how to answer this one. If he says yes, Magic Johnson and Larry Bird might differ. If he says no, he is backing down.

title: BASEBALL;Braves Land Last Blow in the 13th Inning
description: There were no punches, shoves or serious glares exchanged last night at Shea Stadium, but that doesn't mean the latest edition in the developing Mets-Braves rivalry lacked for excitement. The threat of fisticuffs that prevailed Monday night and lingered into yesterday's pre-game comments gave way to an old-fashioned, hard-nosed baseball game that fittingly went into extra innings and left a crowd of 19,256 knowing it had gotten its money's worth.

title: Why Was D'Amato Dabbling in Stocks?
description: To the Editor: On Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's one-day stock investment, the issue isn't whether he received special treatment from a friend; it's whether he should have been investing in the stock market in the first place (news article, June 7). It is a basic guideline of investing that someone with only $70,000 in net worth should not be buying individual stocks, and certainly not volatile, new stock issues. This is especially true for someone who has not much better than a 50-50 chance of retaining his employment every six years. Moreover, the Senator should not have risked more than 10 percent of his assets in a single issue. That he chose to risk a substantial part of his assets in a risky venture demonstrates that he does not have the financial management skills to allocate our tax dollars, let alone to be chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Michael Fox, an actor, misidentified the starring actress with whom he appeared in a 1947 Broadway play, ''The Story of Mary Surratt.'' She was Dorothy Gish, not Lillian Gish.

title: CULBRO IS SELLING ITS LABELING AND PACKAGING BUSINESS
description: The Culbro Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its labeling and packaging business. Culbro did not disclose the sale price for the unit, CMS Gilbreth Packaging Systems Inc., which had revenue of $51 million in 1995. The buyer is an undisclosed United States investor group operating in the specialty labels and packaging industries. Net proceeds of the sale are expected to be ''somewhat over book value,'' Culbro, which is based in Manhattan, said. Culbro expects to use the proceeds of the sale to pay down debt and invest more in its cigar business, A. Ross Wollen, general counsel of the company, said.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Kemp Issues Challenge To All Cowardly Sonics
description: Some of the Seattle SuperSonics already have one foot in Hawaii. "It seems like a lot of people around here are starting to give up," Seattle forward Shawn Kemp said Monday, his team trailing the Chicago Bulls by three games to none in the National Basketball Association finals. The Sonics appear to be playing for sneaker contracts now, and it has their All-Star forward livid. "You never give up because you never know," Kemp said. "Anything can happen. Anybody can get hurt. Not just the players -- the coaches, everybody -- you can't just turn your back and walk away from this series when you still have a game. To me, that's ridiculous. Who knows if we'll ever be back in the finals? "The only way you can correct the problem is going out and giving it your all. If you just go out and just give up and not challenge the problem, then you're weak. I kind of feel like we gave up a little bit the other day in Game 3. "If you're going to come out here and just hand it to them, you're weak, man. You're a coward." This might go for the players' wives and girlfriends, too. An attractive woman approached Michael Jordan before Game 3 on Sunday, begging for an autograph. She was Monique James -- Gary Payton's fiancee.

title: What to Give The Newlyweds? Just Be Practical
description: AS the 1996 wedding season unofficially opens, many of this year's 2.5 million nuptial couples have some requests. Please, no more lava lamps, knitted pillowcases, temple bells from Thailand, electric forks, plastic trays laminated with sequins, monthly bagel shipments or cheese boards with chain-attached knives.

title: Newbury Street in Boston is changing from boutiques to chains, including a Niketown.
description: OF the delight of some and the dismay of others, the largest retail project in 70 years is now under construction on Newbury Street in the historic Back Bay neighborhood of Boston.

title: President Clinton's proposal to increase the international departure tax raises some hackles.
description: AIRLINES and the travel industry have usually supported taxes earmarked for improvements in aviation or infrastructure. But President Clinton's recent proposal to raise the tax on international departures from $6 a passenger to $16, with the money used to help offset the cost of attending college, has gone over with the business travel community like the proverbial lead balloon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Producer Prices Fell in May, Easing Threat of Inflation Prices at the producer level fell unexpectedly in May, the Government said, offering fresh evidence that inflation remains tame despite Wall Street's fears. Tumbling energy prices and stable food costs helped push the Producer Price Index down one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department said. Excluding volatile food and energy costs, the core rate was unchanged after rising one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the three prior months.

title: Port Dredging Clears Hurdle
description: A tax imposed on shippers could be tapped to pay for the disposal of contaminated mud dredged from Port Newark under a bill passed yesterday by a House Transportation subcommittee. Now, the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund may be used only to pay for dredging projects, not disposal sites. The new bill, sponsored by eight New Jersey congressmen, would offer an alternative to dumping the sludge in the ocean, which is now illegal.

title: Thorn EMI Says Profit Climbed 27% in Year
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C., the British music recording and consumer-rentals company that is set to break up in August, said yesterday that its pretax profit in the year ended March 31 rose 27 percent, largely on gains from its EMI Music recording unit. Pretax profit at the London-based company, which owns the Virgin and Capitol record labels, jumped to $:539.1 million ($827.5 million) before one-time items, compared with $:423.6 million a year earlier.

title: Bravo Group Wins A Clorox Account
description: The Clorox Company named the Bravo Group in San Francisco to handle advertising for its brands aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers, which had been handled by Siboney in New York since 1993. Billings were not disclosed. Sandy Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Clorox in Oakland, Calif., said that Bravo, which is owned by Young & Rubicam Inc., had been awarded the assignment after an informal review in which the other participants were not disclosed.

title: Citizen Dole Bids Farewell to the Senate
description: Bob Dole said goodbye to his Senate colleagues today, leaving the trappings and tribulations of the majority leader's post behind as he ventured off into America to campaign as ''just a man'' in pursuit of the ultimate political prize of the Presidency.

title: Child Deaths: Violence Rises as Accidents Fall
description: DRAMATICALLY fewer children are dying of accidental injuries than in the past, but many more are dying violent deaths, according to new research.

title: The Fun of a Husband's Class Reunion
description: I CAN'T remember the last time so many guys were staring at my chest. Too bad they're only searching for my name tag.

title: Pre-Season Corn on the Cob Works
description: Dinner at a friend's house the other night included corn on the cob, not yet in season where most people live. While not like corn on the cob from the neighborhood, it was tender and sweet. Corn from distant parts is better than it once was because it has been bred to hold its sweetness and tenderness after traveling several thousand miles. So if you can't wait until July, try some corn with this warm salad of potatoes and simply seasoned grilled lamb.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAIC HOLDINGS INC., Birmingham, Ala., an insurance company, agreed to buy Momed Holding Co., St. Louis, a liability insurer, for $18.7 million. MAIC plans to exchange either 0.779 share of its common stock or $25.32 in cash for each Momed share.

title: Personal Health
description: WHEN Alberto Salazar won the Boston Marathon in 1982, he fell into a coma right after crossing the finish line. Mr. Salazar sweats heavily, and he became so hot and dehydrated during the race that his organ systems were near collapse. Dr. William Castelli and a police officer saved his life by squeezing more than three quarts of replacement fluids into his veins. Few recreational athletes push themselves to such limits. But even those who, say, play an hour and a half of singles tennis or run a 10-K or cycle 20 miles, especially on a hot day, often risk the detrimental effects of dehydration.

title: New York Festivals Names 5 Winners
description: The New York Festivals has named five grand Best of Show winners at the 38th annual international print and radio competition.

title: UMass Begins Inquiry
description: University of Massachusetts administrators met yesterday to discuss allegations that the former center MARCUS CAMBY accepted gifts from agents while playing for the Minutemen.

title: Food Safety Legislation Tolerates Carcinogens
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Schott Should Not Be Booted
description: IT seems certain that Marge Schott will be forced to decide today whether to relinquish control of her ball club, the Cincinnati Reds, or suffer a suspension again, for a one- or two-year sentence.

title: Bosnia Election Blues
description: While visiting the Balkans recently, I spent a morning talking with two Bosnian Serb journalists in Pale, the capital of the Serb Republic. What I recall most about our discussion was how unabashedly these two women expressed their desire to never again live in the same country with their former Muslim and Croatian neighbors. ''We can live next door to the Muslims, but we cannot live together anymore,'' said Jelena Dabarcic. ''And by the way, if we raped and tortured them so much, as they say, why would they want to live with us?'' Draga Grubic was slightly more poetic but no less blunt: ''I have no desire to go to Sarajevo anymore. I don't even have a desire to go back to Zagreb, where I used to live. It's like a love relationship -- when it's over, it's over and you have to find another one.''

title: Law School Women Gain From Socratic Wars;A Comfort Level?
description: To the Editor: The Socratic method (Education page, June 5) knows no gender. You go to law school to be able to think on your feet, to be quick-witted, analytical and thoughtful. When a woman lawyer stands before a tough judge, a demanding client or a brilliant opponent, should she plead with them to ask only questions that make her comfortable?

title: Bond Firm Being Sold To NatWest
description: The NatWest Group, which is trying to build a substantial global investment bank, agreed yesterday to pay $590 million in cash to acquire Greenwich Capital Holdings Inc. from the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. The acquisition, which was negotiated over the last several months, had been widely expected.

title: He Hasn't Decided What His Role Will Be
description: Twelve pounds heavier from nights of burgers and room service, Bill Bradley returned recently from a trip around the country to promote the book he wrote that made him realize he no longer wished to be a United States Senator.

title: BASEBALL;News on Wilson Isn't Good
description: The Mets received troubling news before last night's game when a magnetic resonance imaging test performed on the rookie right-hander Paul Wilson revealed a slight tear in the fiber cartilage lining the front of his pitching shoulder. It can't be determined if the injury is new or old. The Mets are hoping the primary cause of the discomfort that landed Wilson on the disabled list June 5 is tendinitis, which could clear within two weeks. However, Wilson could be out at least until the All-Star Game break, if not longer. "Right now we're still trying to beat the tendinitis and get back out there throwing," Wilson said. "But the problem is, no one knows exactly what's causing the problem. I certainly don't want to be on the shelf for the rest of the year. But we'll have to see what happens."

title: Why Was D'Amato Dabbling in Stocks?
description: To the Editor: Frank Rich (column, June 8) gleefully recounts how the brokerage firm Stratton Oakmont bent its rules in Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's favor in 1993. Stratton customarily required a client net worth of $500,000. The impecunious junior Senator from New York admitted to a meager net worth of $70,000.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On the soap opera "The Young and the Restless," Victor Newman, a powerful business tycoon, lies in a hospital bed after having been shot by an unknown assailant. But take heart, fans. ERIC BRAEDEN, the actor who has played Victor Newman for 16 years, is in fine fettle and will appear on a Lincoln Center stage tomorrow night. Mr. Braeden will introduce the New York premiere of "Feu Follet: A Cajun Love Story," to be danced at Alice Tully Hall by Elisa Monte Dance. The company, which will perform through Saturday, is performing as part of a series of Cajun events in New York this week and will benefit from a dinner afterward.

title: Looking for a Winner in Seattle? Look at 1979
description: GO ahead. Make the comparison. Chicago versus any champion previously recognized as great. I'll buy it. Any team with Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen, the ability to relentlessly pressure the ball and the Bulls' offensive versatility can stand the test.

title: Director of Lyric Opera To Retire Next Year
description: Ardis Krainik, general director of the Lyric Opera of Chicago, is to retire on April 30 next year. Ms. Krainik, who accepted the position in 1981, said in a statement that she was retiring for health reasons.

title: Hong Kong Press
description: To the Editor:

title: STANLEY CUP FINALS;Stanley Cup Celebration Raises Mile-High Spirits
description: Fans whose pro football, baseball and basketball teams had never brought home a league championship finally got to celebrate when the newest franchise in town -- the Colorado Avalanche -- completed a sweep of the Florida Panthers early this morning to capture hockey's Stanley Cup. More than 12,000 people -- including Gov. Roy Romer -- packed McNichols Sports Arena for a free showing of the 1-0 triple-overtime triumph, which was broadcast from Miami by ESPN and gave the Avalanche a 4-0 series victory over the Panthers in the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Unlikely Hero Who Turned The Dutch Into Opera Fans
description: When Pierre Audi was named artistic director of the Netherlands Opera in June 1988, the company was in trouble. Only 18 months earlier, it had moved into the new Muziektheater in Amsterdam, but it was already running a huge deficit, public interest in its productions was fast fading and everything suggested that the latest attempt to install opera in the Netherlands was doomed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Port Dredging Clears Hurdle
description: A tax imposed on shippers could be tapped to pay for the disposal of contaminated mud dredged from Port Newark under a bill passed yesterday by a House Transportation subcommittee. Now, the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund may be used only to pay for dredging projects, not disposal sites. The new bill, sponsored by eight New Jersey congressmen, would offer an alternative to dumping the sludge in the ocean, which is now illegal.

title: Hong Kong Press
description: To the Editor: A June 5 news article says the Hong Kong press has been warned that after 1997 it will be subject to China's laws on treason and subversion. China in 1994 had already begun to jail Hong Kong journalists reporting from China for normal activities. The Hong Kong Journalists Association called press freedom "endangered."

title: Not All the Comfort Is Being Left Behind
description: When Bob Dole announced on May 15 that he was resigning from the Senate, he said he would be leaving behind ''all the trappings of power, all comfort, all security,'' and was off to seek the Presidency ''with nothing to fall back on but the judgment of the people.''

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Mapping Cyberspace in Bay Area Garages
description: A nerd, the Oxford Dictionary of New Words reports, is American slang for "a contemptible or boring person, especially one who is studious, conventional or 'square.' " Synonym: dweeb. Well, Oxford, it won't do. In this country nobody who has made $10 million or $100 million before he is 30 is contemptible or boring. And the tieless wonders who made it by fooling around with computers are anything but conventional or square. If you have doubts, call up "Triumph of the Nerds: The Rise of Accidental Empires in Silicon Valley."

title: Death in Burundi
description: On June 4, three delegates of the International Committee of the Red Cross were murdered in northern Burundi. Reto Neuenschwander, Cedric Martin and Juan Ruffino, all in their 30's, understood the risks they were taking by working in Burundi, where an average of a hundred people have been massacred every week for the past year.

title: BASEBALL;Calf Injury Sends Key to the Disabled List
description: Jimmy Key cannot walk without pain because of a strained left calf muscle, so the Yankees placed him on the 15-day disabled list today for the second time in less than a month and watched his torturous attempt to regain his former efficiency continue. Key limped off the Skydome mound in the sixth inning Monday night during the Yankees' 5-3 victory over the Blue Jays after telling Manager Joe Torre that he "blew out" his calf muscle. Despite pitching five and two-thirds reliable innings to defeat his former team, Key was distraught because the pain told him something was awry.

title: Toshiba Joins in Move To Cut Chip Output
description: The Toshiba Corporation said yesterday that it had joined other Japanese chip makers in cutting back production of 16-megabit D-RAM computer chips, a move mainly prompted by weak demand and heavy price competition. The company will trim its planned production of 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips by 20 percent from its original forecast, a Toshiba executive, Koichi Suzuki, said.

title: In Era of Smaller Schools, One County Finds Improvement FromConsolidating
description: Just a few years ago, the 93 public schools in Guilford County, a rolling expanse of cities and towns nestled between the Blue Ridge Mountains and Carolina coastal plains, needed help. Test scores and dropout rates varied widely among schools. Classrooms were crumbling, and some students graduated barely able to read. So, Guilford County voters reluctantly agreed to an overhaul.

title: Head of J. Paul Getty Trust to Retire in 1998
description: Harold M. Williams, who as president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles helped transform it from a local museum in Malibu to a multibillion-dollar trust dedicated to scholarship, conservation and education in the visual arts and humanities, announced his retirement yesterday. He will step down on Jan. 5, 1998.

title: World News Briefs;Drugs Reported Found In Office of Arafat Critic
description: Palestinian police officers have raided the office of a human rights activist who is a leading critic of Yasir Arafat, and the Palestinian attorney general said today that drugs had been found in the search. Dr. Eyad R. Sarraj was arrested on Sunday. He was arrested last month after criticizing Mr. Arafat's government, but was released nine days later after an international outcry. An attorney for Dr. Sarraj said he believed the drugs were planted to justify keeping Dr. Sarraj in jail.

title: Journal;Whose Life Is It Anyway?
description: Wasn't Bob Dole's abortion dilemma settled only last week? No sooner had he announced his desire to include a "declaration of tolerance" for pro-choice Republicans in his party's platform than seemingly every G.O.P. leader, seconded by every major news organization, lined up to declare peace was at hand. On one network news show Friday night, no fewer than four party factotums, starting with Pat Buchanan, expressed varying degrees of contentment with Mr. Dole's masterly move. It all sounded like a done deal -- unless you paused to notice that not one of the leaders canvassed was a woman. At the offices of the two bellwethers for the pro-choice majority in their party -- Ann Stone, of Republicans for Choice, and Susan Cullman, of the Republican Coalition for Choice -- phones and fax machines were fielding a far less tranquil reaction. Many pro-choice G.O.P. women and men are not satisfied with the back-of-the-bus status of being "tolerated"; they want the abortion plank, with its call for a Human Life Amendment, removed entirely. "My surprise is how duped the press was," says Ms. Cullman. "They seem to think if the religious right is quiet, then the problem must have been solved. It's as if there's no understanding that we still go to the polls, thank you, and can vote, even if we can't put up the same noisy protest that the right does."

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Lose Early Gains
description: A report showing an unexpected decline in producer prices sent Treasury prices surging yesterday, but profit taking in the afternoon erased the gains. Bond prices have been under pressure since Friday, when the May employment report showed surprising strength, suggesting that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates next month. In two sessions, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- which moves in the opposite direction from the bond's price -- rose to 7.12 percent -- its highest level in more than a year.

title: A Budding Rivalry Stirs Mets' Emotions
description: The Mets may be a distant speck in the Braves' rearview mirror when it comes to the teams' positions in the National League East standing. But for the better part of a week, the last-place Mets have proven to be the itch the first-place Braves cannot scratch.

title: A Bit of Fancy, Then Repose
description: The program was as it should have been when Alonzo King's Lines Contemporary Ballet danced on Sunday night. Earlier in the week, this San Francisco company had scheduled a new work by Mr. King called ''Handel Pas de Deux'' as part of its engagement at the Joyce Theater. But an injury sustained by Muriel Maffre, the French ballerina for whom it was created, prevented it from being shown.

title: Data Seem to Show a Solar System Nearly in the Neighborhood
description: In less than a year, astronomers have advanced from not knowing if there are any planets around other ordinary stars beyond the solar system to finding striking evidence of planets orbiting at least five other stars. The latest discovery, announced today, seemed to bring the phenomenon of other planetary systems intriguingly close to home.

title: Rivals of American and British Air Quickly Assail New Alliance as Anticompetitive
description: American Airlines and British Airways formally announced their plans yesterday for a broad marketing alliance, setting off sharp criticism from competitors and raising questions about the likelihood of their partnership winning approval from Government regulators in both countries.

title: Ulysses Dove, Creator of Dark, Driving Dances, Dies at 49
description: Ulysses Dove, a choreographer of brooding, explosive dances that are performed by companies including the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the New York City Ballet, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Slight Rebound In Indicator of Chip Demand
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded slightly in May, although it still pointed to weak demand, providing a first sign that the five-month-old slump might be nearing an end, a trade group said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOAMEX INTERNATIONAL TO SELL ITS PERFECT FIT UNIT
description: Foamex International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Perfect Fit Industries unit to an investment group and Perfect Fit management for $50 million. Foamex, a chemical company based in Linwood, Pa., said it planned to take a $38 million charge in the second quarter and restate its loss in the 1995 fiscal year to $1.73 a share from the previously reported $2.01. Perfect Fit, a maker of home furnishings, had sales of $98.5 million in 1995.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Hangs On To Win His 10th
description: If someone caught a glimpse of Andy Pettitte after Ed Sprague scorched one of his pitches for a three-run homer in the first inning, he would not have guessed this would be the pitcher's night. Pettitte had his hands on his hips and his eyes on the next batter after Sprague gave the Blue Jays a swift lead. He was "very upset." Fast forward to any other inning except for, perhaps, the sixth, and the glimpses of Pettitte changed dramatically. Tonight looked like his night.

title: International Briefs:;News Corporation Offers Shares for British Unit
description: Shares in News International P.L.C., the British newspaper publisher, soared yesterday after its stockholders were offered preferred shares in its parent company, the News Corporation, in exchange for their 9 percent stake. The News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, already owns all the ordinary stock of News International and 82 percent of the publicly traded special dividend shares of the subsidiary. After the exchange, News Corporation will own all the shares in News International and the unit will cease to trade. The swap, which offers 1.33 preferred News Corporation shares for each News International special dividend share, values News International shares at 410 pence each. The shares closed up 79 pence yesterday, at 387. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: NEWS MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Take Top Honors At the Addy Awards
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., won the Best of Show awards last week at the 29th annual American Advertising Awards, sponsored by the American Advertising Federation in Washington.

title: Lightning Bolt Starts Blaze In Fuel Tank In New Jersey
description: Lightning struck a fuel tank holding three million gallons of gasoline yesterday in Woodbridge, N.J., sending the huge steel top of the tank flying into the air and setting off a fire that spewed blue-black smoke clouds and brilliant orange and red flames 150 feet into the sky.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Worker Killed on Turnpike
description: A New Jersey Turnpike maintenance foreman was killed before dawn yesterday when his pickup truck was hit by a truck driver who fled on foot and was later charged with drunken driving. The victim, Robert Baran of Bayonne, was following a truck carrying workers picking up cones at the time of the crash, said Lynn M. Fleeger, a spokeswoman for the Turnpike Authority. The truck driver, James Van Albert of Staten Island, turned himself in five hours later, said Sgt. Daniel Cosgrove of the state police. Mr. Baran is the fifth maintenance worker to die on duty in the agency's 44 years, Ms. Fleeger said.

title: Food Safety Legislation Tolerates Carcinogens
description: To the Editor: Contrary to Representative Scott Klug and Michael Pariza (letter, June 7), the food safety bill would jeopardize food safety by replacing the Delaney Clause's zero standard with a "tolerance" for carcinogenic food additives. Advances in analytic technology are irrelevant to Delaney, which prohibits the deliberate addition to food of any level of chemicals known to induce cancer in humans or animals. Furthermore, the advances of understanding in the molecular basis of carcinogenesis over the last few decades are consistent with our inability to set tolerances or safe thresholds for any one carcinogen, let alone on multiple carcinogens in food. Animal tests for carcinogens give results that are highly predictable to humans. All 23 recognized human carcinogens are also carcinogenic in animals. For many of these carcinogens, the animal data preceded human confirmation, in some instances by decades. At a time when cancer risks are escalating, the Clinton Administration is wise to insist on retaining the Delaney Clause, and on protecting consumers against avoidable exposure to carcinogens that are in food.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thorn EMI Says Profit Climbed 27% in Year
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C., the British music recording and consumer-rentals company that is set to break up in August, said yesterday that its pretax profit in the year ended March 31 rose 27 percent, largely on gains from its EMI Music recording unit. Pretax profit at the London-based company, which owns the Virgin and Capitol record labels, jumped to L539.1 million ($827.5 million) before one-time items, compared with L423.6 million a year earlier. Thorn said its EMI Group P.L.C. music businesses would assume debts of L131.4 million ($201 million) after the breakup. The Thorn P.L.C. rentals business will assume the remaining L260 million of Thorn EMI's current net debt of L391.4 million. (Bloomberg Business News)

description: Beheading a Mob Empire

description: EVERY year around this time, the mail includes a substantial number of letters inquiring about the next vintage chart. This year there were fewer than usual. Are wine drinkers tiring of the annual numbers game?

title: BASEBALL;Answer Due Today on Whether Schott Will Step Aside
description: Major League Baseball's executive council is expected to learn today whether Marge Schott will voluntarily relinquish operation of the Cincinnati Reds or subject herself to a suspension of possibly two years. The council, at a meeting last Wednesday, set today as the deadline for Schott to agree to step aside as the Reds' managing partner or be suspended for violating the terms of her seasonlong suspension in 1993. As of the close of business yesterday, people familiar with the matter said, it was unclear what Schott would do. They said lawyers for baseball and the Reds' owner were still going back and forth in their negotiations.

title: Stanley Cup Celebration Raises Mile-High Spirits
description: Fans whose pro football, baseball and basketball teams had never brought home a league championship finally got to celebrate when the newest franchise in town -- the Colorado Avalanche -- completed a sweep of the Florida Panthers early this morning to capture hockey's Stanley Cup.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillies' Stars Still Ailing
description: LENNY DYKSTRA and DARREN DAULTON, the Philadelphia Phillies' two ailing stars, aren't likely to return this season, General Manager LEE THOMAS said yesterday. Dykstra, 33, went on the disabled list May 21 with a sore left side, but it quickly became apparent that the bigger problem was the continuing pain in the center fielder's back. Daulton, 34, played the first week of the season, then announced that his knees were too sore to continue playing, even though he wasn't catching anymore. (AP)

description: Jane Pauley is the latest high-profile name at NBC News to join the MSNBC cable prime-time lineup. She will serve as anchor of the 7-to-8 P.M. program, "Time and Again," on the new 24-hour news channel, a joint venture of Microsoft and NBC News, that is to begin July 15. Using NBC News archival film, "Time and Again" will revisit major news events of the 20th century. The program, like many in the MSNBC venture, will have interactive companion activities on the Internet.

title: News Analysis;Bosnia Uproar: Why U.S. Pushes for Early Vote
description: The United States and other outside powers that sponsored the Dayton peace accords, as well as those engaged in the four-year war in Bosnia -- Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia itself -- will all meet tomorrow in Florence to assess how the peace plan is faring after its first six months. Peace reigns, so far, on the ground. But hanging over the meeting will be a sharp dispute over whether the necessary conditions exist for elections by Sept. 14, as called for in the accords, and whether the United States, for its own political reasons, is manipulating the process it devised to insure a free and fair vote.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rare Falcon Chick Is Born
description: Only 15 pairs of nesting peregrine falcons can be found in New Jersey, and one of them has lived for more than a decade on a ledge outside a penthouse suite at the Grand Hotel. (The only other urban pair lives at a power station in Kearney.) Yesterday, a chick born to the Atlantic City pair was given an official welcome, and an identification band from state biologists so that they can track its progress, The Associated Press reported. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Billions Short, but Gratitude Aplenty
description: At Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn, where school officials have been grappling with the twin problems of overcrowded classrooms and crumbling buildings, there was a feeling of gratitude at reports that the City Council and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had agreed to allocate $1.4 billion for school repairs over the next four years.

description: What's in a name? The focus of a lawsuit if the name is Cousteau. JACQUES COUSTEAU and his son, JEAN-MICHEL COUSTEAU, have reached a settlement in a bitter dispute over the name of a resort opened by the younger Mr. Cousteau in the Fiji Islands.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New York Festivals Names 5 Winners
description: The New York Festivals has named five grand Best of Show winners at the 38th annual international print and radio competition. In print, there were four winners: the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, for the best consumer campaign, for Altoids Mints, which are marketed by a unit of the Philip Morris Companies; Euro RSCG Ball Partnership in Singapore, a unit of Euro RSCG, for the best newspaper advertising, for the Samaritans, a society dedicated to the prevention of suicide; Lewis Moberly in London, for the best design for a package, for Boots Childrens' Batteries, marketed by the Boots Company P.L.C., and Wunderman Cato Johnson in Eschborn, Germany, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., for the best direct mail, for Andersen Consulting.

description: There were no punches, shoves or serious glares exchanged last night at Shea Stadium, but that doesn't mean the latest edition in the developing Mets-Braves rivalry lacked for excitement.

title: A Comfort Level?
description: To the Editor:

title: Law School Women Gain From Socratic Wars;Hammering Men, Too
description: To the Editor: As a woman who has just completed her first year of law school, I have never felt that the Socratic method discriminated against women (Education page, June 5). Sure we're intimidated by the process. Sure we're anxious and afraid that we're going to be the next ones hammered by the professors. So are the guys! As to your article's assertion that more emphasis should be placed on political and social issues that affect the law and that more women should be hired in our law schools, those claims are meritorious. But the argument that women are unfairly abused in law school classrooms and that we cannot deal as well with the demanding nature of the Socratic method is wrong.

title: GOLF;Open Bypasses Long Island
description: The executive committee of the United States Golf Association decided late tonight that the Black course at Bethpage State Park in Long Island will not be the site of the 2001 United States Open. However, the public course is still under consideration for the 2002 Open. Early in the day, Bethpage Black and Southern Hills Golf Club in Tulsa, Okla., were the two front-runners for the vacant 2001 date. Southern Hills, which last hosted a major championship in 1994 when Nick Price won the PGA Championship there, was the apparent favorite for 2001 with Bethpage still under consideration and strongly endorsed by David Fay, the U.S.G.A.'s executive director. Later, however, after much debate in the executive committee meeting and following a lengthy dinner meeting, Bethpage was eliminated from consideration for the 2001 date and U.S.G.A. officials declined to identify the chosen site.

title: DANCE REVIEW;With an Emphasis on the Emotion, Not the Mechanics
description: Antony Tudor's ballets are about emotion. As Tudor, American Ballet Theater's founding choreographer, once said, he wanted to "feel" the music, not count it. Feeling is certainly what "The Leaves Are Fading" is all about, and this 1975 Tudor masterpiece received a glowing performance from two different sets of principals at the Metropolitan Opera House. On Monday night, Marianna Tcherkassky, who will make her farewell to Ballet Theater after 26 years on Saturday night, was seen for the first time in New York in the leading female role. She was partnered with masculine grace by Robert Hill, while last Saturday afternoon, Amanda McKerrow and Wes Chapman led a virtually all-new cast. In each performance, the tone of young love deepening into tenderness was marvelously sustained. Ms. Tcherkassky and Ms. McKerrow are, however, very different dancers and each brought her individuality to Tudor's expressive use of the classical idiom. Ms. Tcherkassky has excelled in 19th-century Romantic roles and she slipped naturally into the gestural flow of Tudor's neo-Romantic style. In the central duet, she looked properly ecstatic and impressed by Mr. Hill's flourish. If the more passionate choreography had a few glitches in the partnering, every swoon and lift spoke of intensification of feeling. With at least four couples engaged in tricky partnering, "Leaves" presumes a high level of technique. Ms. McKerrow, at her best in neo-classical ballets, brought that level to the choreography and also superbly captured its lyricism. Mr. Chapman was on her wavelength and danced with the same daring in his timing. Especially lovely was their exit in the duet. Here the ballerina, slowly dipped head-down by her spinning partner, is finally carried off in profile at his side, head thrown back. Amplifying the love image are three other duets. There was a girlish sparkle and lightness to Yan Chen, dancing with a boyishly eager Angel Corella. Christina Fagundes and Andrei Dokukin, who also had a folk-flavored solo to the Dvorak music, were grand in their boldness. Maxim Belotserkovsky and Martha Butler were ill-matched but did well enough. On Monday, Ms. Tcherkassky stepped into Lar Lubovitch's "Brahms Symphony" as the girl in cherry red. Her main duet with Keith Roberts had the sweep and surge brought to it by the rest of the excellent ensemble.

title: Sifting Through the Snows of Summer
description: SORBETS are the yogurt of the 1990's. Many bear no resemblance to the original mixture of frozen fruit, sugar and water, just as oversweetened, nut-topped yogurts are totally unlike the plain, tart cultured milk of Caucasus fame.

Giuliani and the City Council's leaders agreed yesterday to provide an immediate infusion of $276 million to repair New York City's public schools but only after making an unusual demand that they, not the Board of Education, dictate where the money is spent and on what.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Store Chief in Japan To Quit in Payoff Case
description: The president of Japan's largest department store operator said yesterday that he would resign after company executives were arrested on charges of paying gangster extortionists. The executive, Hiroshi Hidaka of the Takashimaya Company, said he "feels responsibility" over the scandal involving payments to "sokaiya," racketeers who blackmail companies by threatening to disrupt their annual meetings. One former and two current Takashimaya executives were arrested on Saturday for reportedly paying 80 million yen ($730,000) to sokaiya to insure a peaceful annual meeting in May 1995. Two sokaiya have been arrested. Mr. Hidaka denied that he was aware of the payments, but he acknowledged meeting the mob leader, Isao Nishiura. (AP)

title: World News Briefs;Iraq Bars U.N. Inspectors From a Weapons Site
description: United Nations weapons inspectors were denied access today to an Iraqi military site where they were searching for materials relating to its weapons programs, United Nations diplomats said. The standoff, which lasted eight hours, was reported to have taken place near a prison in a Baghdad suburb.

title: COMPANY NEWS;T.W.A. PLANS TO RAISE $183 MILLION IN A STOCK OFFERING
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it planned to raise about $183 million by offering investors eight million common shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the carrier, which is based in St. Louis, said the proceeds from the offering would be put toward general purposes, including capital expenditures and working capital. Paine Webber Inc., Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. and the BT Securities Corporation are managing the offering, which could include another 1.2 million shares to cover additional demand. T.W.A. expects to have about 45 million shares outstanding after the offering. Shares of T.W.A. fell $1.875 yesterday, to $19.125, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Selling Americans Their Own Pastime
description: If you've marketed brands like Entenmann's, Maxwell House, Lenders bagels, Pepsi Light and Tang, can you sell the world on Ken Griffey Jr., expansion, wild-card playoffs, interleague play and Albert Belle?

title: IAT GROUP OF CHILE TO BUY FRESH DEL MONTE
description: The IAT Group of Chile has agreed to buy Fresh Del Monte Produce N.V. for $534 million in cash, equity and assumed debt from Mexico's Grupo Empresarial Agricola Mexicana, company officials said yesterday. Fresh Del Monte, based in Coral Gables, Fla., is the third-largest producer of fresh bananas and the largest marketer of fresh pineapples. IAT is a closely held Chilean fresh fruit producer that sells grapes, plums and peaches. Fresh Del Monte was once a part of the Del Monte Foods Company, the largest fruit and vegetable canner in the United States. Since the 1970's, however, Fresh Del Monte has passed through several owners.

title: Saying A.A. Is Religious, Court Lets Inmate Skip It
description: Ruling that Alcoholics Anonymous ''engages in religious activity and religious proselytization,'' New York State's highest court declared yesterday that state prison officials were wrong to penalize an inmate who stopped attending self-help meetings based on the organization's teachings because he said he was an atheist or an agnostic.

title: Westport Man Gives $1 Million As a Matching Grant to Library
description: When Joel E. Smilow made his first $1 million gift in 1988, to endow the position of head football coach at Yale University, people asked him why he had not chosen something more highbrow.

title: ''Biography'' Offshoots
description: How popular is ''Biography,'' the signature program of the A&E cable network? Already scheduled six nights a week on A&E, the series is about to sprout several new offshoots, including a separate Biography cable channel and a prime-time series, ''Biography for Kids.''

title: Real Estate;Newbury Street in Boston is changing from boutiques to chains, including a Niketown.
description: OF the delight of some and the dismay of others, the largest retail project in 70 years is now under construction on Newbury Street in the historic Back Bay neighborhood of Boston. For years the street has been known for its high-priced, one-of-a-kind retail shops. They occupy the first or second floors of the Victorian-era red-brick row houses that dominate the eight blocks of Newbury Street, from the Public Gardens to Massachusetts Avenue.

title: Dole, Ignoring His Advisers, Lashes Out at Abortion Foe
description: Bob Dole today brushed off the advice of some of his closest aides, who had urged him to pacify abortion opponents, and instead took the offensive against one of his most vociferous critics on the Republican right.

title: Broker Settles In Gibson Case
description: Gary S. Missner, a former broker at a unit of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, agreed today to pay $100,000 to settle Federal charges stemming from the sale of derivatives securities to Gibson Greetings Inc.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GERMAN COMPANY TO ACQUIRE SHERIDAN SYSTEMS FROM AM
description: AM International Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell the assets of its Sheridan Systems division to Heidelberger Druckmaschinen A.G. of Heidelberg, Germany, for about $56 million in cash. Sheridan Systems, a supplier of systems and components to both the printing and newspaper publishing industries, had revenues of $182 million in 1995. It has about 700 employees worldwide. The sale does not include AM's AM Multigraphics division, which has operations in North America and Japan. AM International, based in Rosemont, Ill., said it intended to use the proceeds from the sale to reduce liabilities and provide working capital.

title: Downsizing Comes to Japan, Fraying Old Workplace Ties
description: When a major Japanese tire-and-rubber company asked a 53-year-old senior researcher to retire early last year, he refused.

title: A Chef Goes Back in Time
description: BRENDAN WALSH, who helped define Southwestern cooking in Manhattan when he was the chef at Arizona 206 about 10 years ago, is going back to his roots in Ridgefield, Conn. Mr. Walsh has taken over the kitchen of the Elms Restaurant and Tavern, an 18th-century establishment at 500 Main Street, where he once worked as a waiter. ''It's a piece of history,'' said Mr. Walsh, who plans a menu of chowders, stews, smoked shellfish roasts and spoonbreads. The refurbished restaurant is expected to open in about a month. Mr. Walsh has been working on Long Island, at Coyote Grill, North Street Grill and Paddy McGee's.

title: Glass-Steagall Overhaul Is Abandoned
description: Short of time and facing mounting opposition, the chairman of the House Banking Committee today abandoned an ambitious election-year effort to overhaul the financial-services industry.

title: Mapping Cyberspace in Bay Area Garages
description: A nerd, the Oxford Dictionary of New Words reports, is American slang for ''a contemptible or boring person, especially one who is studious, conventional or 'square.' '' Synonym: dweeb.

title: Law School Women Gain From Socratic Wars;No Gender Disability
description: To the Editor: I was dismayed by your June 5 Education page report of criticism of use of the Socratic method in law schools because women students find it intimidating to be required to express themselves orally in class and to have their analysis of a legal issue subjected to rigorous scrutiny. May we assume the next step will be to prohibit a client or judge from asking a woman lawyer to support a position that she has espoused? As a lawyer in a firm where 7 of the 15 other members are women, as a man whose spouse is a lawyer and a former judge, and as the father of 3 daughters, I reject the suggestion that women suffer a gender-based disability in law schools. Cultural attitudes and pedagogical insensitivity at schools and colleges disadvantage female students. But by the time one is admitted to graduate school, presumably an adjustment has been made to compensate for that disadvantage. Legal concepts in our society demand rigorous examination. The law is not a profession for the faint of heart or mind, irrespective of gender.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;UMass Begins Inquiry
description: University of Massachusetts administrators met yesterday to discuss allegations that the former center MARCUS CAMBY accepted gifts from agents while playing for the Minutemen. The university expects to finish its investigation by the end of the summer and submit a report to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Pre-Season Corn on the Cob Works
description: Dinner at a friend's house the other night included corn on the cob, not yet in season where most people live. While not like corn on the cob from the neighborhood, it was tender and sweet. Corn from distant parts is better than it once was because it has been bred to hold its sweetness and tenderness after traveling several thousand miles. So if you can't wait until July, try some corn with this warm salad of potatoes and simply seasoned grilled lamb. Grilled Seasoned Lamb With Greek Potato Salad

title: Sports of The Times;Why Schott Should Not Be Booted
description: IT seems certain that Marge Schott will be forced to decide today whether to relinquish control of her ball club, the Cincinnati Reds, or suffer a suspension again, for a one- or two-year sentence. It is certain that Marge Schott embarrasses her fellow owners by her insensitive, boorish and bigoted remarks. Bud Selig, a fellow owner with the conflict-of-interest title of acting commissioner, said earlier this week, "Yes, she has hurt baseball, no question about it." If ever someone has advertised her ignorance it is the baseball team owner Marge Schott. She is on record of making slurs toward blacks, Jews, working women, Italians, Asians -- and these are only the ethnic and racial groups that she was asked about. As far back as 1992, she remarked to me that "Hitler was good in the beginning, but he went too far." That was one of the particulars in the indictment that got her suspended from baseball for a year in 1993. When on opening day this season in Cincinnati, the umpire John McSherry collapsed and died on the field in the first inning, and the game was canceled, she complained, "First it was snow, and now this!" It was as if she believed God was conspiring against her having a decent opening day. And when she sent the umpires flowers in an attempt to make up, the flowers were discovered to have been recycled. A television station had sent them to her the day before. Many people who know her describe her as a lonely widow, without children, and with a drinking problem. All this may be true. But in my time spent with Marge Schott, I have found her to be a person of firm convictions and with a pittance of information. She knew as little about Hitler, for example, as she did the infield fly rule. As for her drinking: When she made that Hitler remark to me, it was 10 in the morning, she was driving a car and driving it straight, under the influence of nothing but her simple, unworldly, minimally educated self. She does, however, appear to have a quirky if not crafty business sense. Her fellow owners will tell you that she knows nothing about how to run an organization. But if people are so set against her, then they would not, or should not, show up to her team's games. But they do. Last season, in the smallest metropolitan market of the 14 National League teams, the Reds had a home attendance of 1.8 million fans and outdrew eight of Schott's competitors, including the New York Mets, by 500,000. Her fellow owners will tell you that she knows nothing about baseball. But in the 11 full seasons she has owned the Reds, they have been winners. And in the 1990's, only the Atlanta Braves have a better on-the-field record than the Reds. And while the Reds are in last place this season and playing only .400 ball, they won their division last year -- the same twist experienced by the Boston Red Sox. Schott has the lowest ticket prices in all of baseball and has insisted on fans being able to buy a hot dog at Riverfront Stadium for a dollar. An organization in Chicago called the Fan Cost Index figured out that for a family of four to attend a ball game -- from tickets to parking to popcorn -- the Reds have the lowest total average cost: $81.31. The average is $102.58, with the Yankees coming in at $117.32 and the Mets at $104.80. As for hurting baseball, what hurt baseball more than the owners calling off the World Series in 1994? What hurt them more financially than the $280 million they had to pay the players for illegally colluding to hold down salaries? And not one owner had to relinquish control of his club, or was suspended for it, either. And just who are these fellow owners sitting in judgment of her? The admitted felon in the Bronx? Ted Turner of Atlanta, who urinated in public after his America's Cup yacht racing victory? The owners would distinguish themselves not by taking club control away from Schott, or by suspending her, but by saying that while her speech and actions are despicable, it is also true that in America everyone has a right to make a fool of oneself. It is the right of the customers, however, not to patronize such a fool. So far, the fans in Cincinnati and in the National League cities have not seen fit to send that message. But they should be the ultimate judges, not her pious fellow owners.

title: Hijacker Sentenced to 20 Years as Judge Rejects Claim That Bias MadeHis Crime Justified
description: An Ethiopian man who hijacked a German jetliner to New York in 1993 was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison after a judge rejected his assertion that the hijacking was justified because his visa application to the United States had been denied. The man, Nebiu Demeke, argued that he had been refused entry into the country because of his nationality. "I was forced to hijack the plane and I hijacked it politely," said Mr. Demeke, who the authorities believe is the only person to hijack a trans-Atlantic flight to the United States in the last two decades. But Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court in Brooklyn sternly rebuked the man. "When you spoke, Mr. Demeke, of how you are a victim of discrimination, you are preaching to the choir," said Judge Johnson, who is black. "I have understood that pain for many years. However sad and wrong that is, there is no justification for doing what you did." So ended an unusual case that moved from a sky-and-runway drama to the courts. Mr. Demeke, who had lived in Germany since August 1992, had deftly smuggled a starter's pistol under a wide-brimmed fedora onto Lufthansa Flight 592, which left Frankfurt with 94 passengers and 10 crew members on Feb. 11, 1993. The pistol fired only blanks. He seized the plane, bound for Cairo and Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and threatened to kill crew members unless they flew it to New York. He surrendered without a struggle when the wide-bodied, twin-engine Airbus 310 landed at Kennedy International Airport. Yesterday, Mr. Demeke asked for the minimum sentence on the charge, which carried a maximum of life imprisonment, because he had been so cooperative. "I freely surrendered," he said. "I helped the F.B.I. They wouldn't have known how I hijacked the plane. They wouldn't have known if I didn't tell them." Mr. Demeke acted as his own lawyer during a four-day trial in March and refused to raise an insanity defense. He was twice found incompetent to stand trial. But under medication for depression and hallucinations, he ultimately went to court, and a jury found him guilty in less than an hour. "When he was off medication, he was talking about people beaming him up to Mars," Alan Seidler, his legal adviser, said in an interview. Mr. Demeke, who was a student in Morocco before he moved to Germany, told the judge he had wanted to come to the United States "to redress a wrong." He had testified that he had sent an American lawyer some theatrical scripts and music that he believed would earn him a fortune. He later became convinced that the lawyer and his own father, who was in United States at the time, were stealing the scripts for their own financial gain. But the Federal prosecutor, Gordon Mehler, said yesterday that another undercurrent of Mr. Demeke's frustration was that his two brothers and two sisters obtained visas to study in the United States and he did not. Although he had applied for political asylum in Germany, he withdrew the application and asked the German Government to furnish him a ticket to return to Ethiopia. He used that ticket to hijack the plane. At the Frankfurt Airport, Mr. Demeke was asked to remove his Indiana Jones-style hat. He complied, pinching the pistol in the crown of the fedora. He was then scanned with a hand-held metal detector but only from the shoulders down.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Settlement in Medicare Fraud
description: Two medical supply companies accused of bilking Medicare by inflating prices for equipment have agreed to repay the Government $500,000, the United States Attorney's office announced yesterday. Summit Healthcare Systems and Global Medical Systems, both of New Brunswick, charged Medicare $3,000 to $5,000 each for lymphedema pumps used to treat a rare lymph disorder.

title: Drug Scandal Taints Panama's Reform Chief
description: Less than seven years ago, American troops invaded Panama and ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and the drug-dealing army that he commanded. Now, with a friendly Government in power and the hand-over of the Panama Canal looming, the United States finds itself again facing a familiar quandary here.

description: The News Corporation, the giant media company, stepped up its efforts to move into the Japanese market today as Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and chief executive, outlined plans for an array of new services.

description: The Clorox Company named the Bravo Group in San Francisco to handle advertising for its brands aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers, which had been handled by Siboney in New York since 1993. Billings were not disclosed. Sandy Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Clorox in Oakland, Calif., said that Bravo, which is owned by Young & Rubicam Inc., had been awarded the assignment after an informal review in which the other participants were not disclosed.
