description: Ameritech said today that it had formed a joint venture with Bell Atlantic, Nynex and Pacific Telesis to link the regional Bell telephone companies' voice-mail systems.

title: 2D MAN IS CHARGED IN L.I. BAR BEATING
description: Prosecutors today presented a new scenario of the Memorial Day Weekend beating of a black man outside a nightclub, suggesting that a white New York City police officer did not assault the victim but rather held bystanders at bay with a gun while a companion did the pummeling with a steel club.

title: Signs Emerge Of China Deal On Sanctions
description: China invited United States trade officials today to fly to Beijing immediately as new signs emerged that a last-minute Government crackdown on factories pirating American software, music and videos might persuade Washington not to impose $2 billion in sanctions on Chinese imports.

title: Court Confirms Pro-Divorce Vote in Ireland
description: A last-ditch bid to stop divorce from becoming legal in Ireland failed today when the Supreme Court refused to overturn the result of a referendum that ended the ban on divorce.

title: Vietnam Agents Deserve U.S. Compensation
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OPEN;Lots of Splashing, but Little Frivolity
description: This United States Open won't be any fun. Dramatic, probably, enthralling, certainly, and historic without question. But fun? Get serious. The Open is never fun, and rarely is that more evident than when it is played at Oakland Hills, this massive, menacing golf course on the outskirts of Detroit.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Chronicle column yesterday about Eric Braeden's appearance tonight to introduce the New York premiere of "Feu Follet: A Cajun Love Story," by Elisa Monte Dance at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center, misstated the timing of the benefit dinner. It is after the performance tonight, not Saturday night.

title: Progress vs. Ecology / A Battle for the Future : The Philippines Struggles To Salvage Its Beauty
description: MANILA  When President Fidel V. Ramos has guests to dinner, he sometimes likes to hand out autographed golf balls as souvenirs. For Mr. Ramos, an enthusiastic golfer, the sport is a symbol of the good life he wants to achieve for Filipinos. But in 1996, golf has come to symbolize more than good living in the Philippines. Environmentalists have elected the golf course as the latest battlefield in their struggle to save what remains of the country's sites of pristine natural beauty.

title: OPERA REVIEW;The Met Gives 'Turandot' a Night Out
description: In all but musical terms, the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's 30th year of free outdoor performances was not auspicious. Because maintenance work is being done on the Great Lawn of Central Park, the Met's traditional outdoor home in Manhattan, the performances were moved up to the North Meadow at 102d Street, just west of Fifth Avenue. Less convenient than the Great Lawn even at the best of times, access was made more difficult by a Museum Mile street fair that closed off much of Fifth Avenue nearly until curtain time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a passage was omitted last Sunday from the On Baseball column, about Albert Belle's suspension for running into an opposing player, Fernando Vina. Referring to film of the incident, the column should have read: "Belle's forearm is not seen striking Vina's face but instead appears to be no higher than shoulder level. It's possible, though the film is inconclusive, that Belle's forearm got Vina in the throat or chin."

title: No Headline
description: Just as the strength of the Internet is chaos, so the strength of our liberty depends upon the chaos and cacophony of the unfettered speech the First Amendment protects."

title: 2 Unions Sue Kmart Over Shareholder Vote
description: Two unions said today that they had filed suit against the Kmart Corporation, seeking to force the company to correct its tally of shareholder votes in a proxy contest at its annual meeting last month.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOECHST MARION ROUSSEL LTD., Kansas City, Mo., a manufacturer of drugs and chemicals, acquired a 20 percent stake in Premos Inc., a Pittsburgh-based provider of medical office information systems. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Clinton Says He's Sorry About F.B.I. Files
description: President Clinton said today that he was sorry the White House had improperly obtained confidential Federal Bureau of Investigation files on many prominent Republicans, but insisted that it had not been trying to compile an "enemies list."

title: Why Buy Into the Cynicism and 'Threats'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada and Mexico Join to Oppose U.S. Law on Cuba
description: In a united and increasingly defiant stance against their common ally, Canada and Mexico are stepping up their opposition to what they consider an unlawful United States effort to penalize foreign companies that trade with Cuba.

title: JUDGES TURN BACK LAW TO REGULATE INTERNET DECENCY
description: In a unanimous decision that celebrated the Internet as "the most participatory marketplace of mass speech that this country -- and indeed the world -- has yet seen," a three-judge Federal panel in Philadelphia yesterday declared unconstitutional major parts of a new law intended to regulate indecent material on the global computer network and blocked the law's enforcement.

title: Hugh Mitchell, 89, An Ex-Congressman
description: Hugh Burnton Mitchell, a New Deal Democrat who served Washington State in both houses of Congress half a century ago, died on Monday night at a nursing home here. He was 89.

title: 100,000 RUSSIANS RALLY IN MOSCOW TO BACK YELTSIN
description: As security measures tightened all over the city in the wake of Tuesday's deadly subway bombing, more than 100,000 people today celebrated Russia's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union in 1990 by attending a boisterous rock concert for President Boris N. Yeltsin. It was his biggest rally in Moscow since his rise to power in 1990 and 1991.

title: Before the Printouts, the Printed Page
description: On Saturday morning, I am going to check out a book from the library. In most communities, this would be an unremarkable event, but not here. A century after Andrew Carnegie's philanthropy made local libraries a common institution elsewhere, the 2,352 people who live in this remote Adirondack township, less than 100 miles south of Canada, are getting their first public library.

title: New Jersey Fuel Tank Fire Is Put Out in Its Second Day
description: Norman Leahy, chief of the Woodbridge Volunteer Fire Department, was driving home Tuesday afternoon from his job as a telephone lineman and listening to the radio when he heard a report about a gasoline tank fire in central New Jersey.

title: Sports of The Times;Schott's Penalty Only A First Step
description: MARGE SCHOTT, the owner of the Cincinnati Reds, hasn't burned down one black church. She hasn't defiled a Jewish cemetery or synagogue, burned a Vietnamese-owned fishing boat in the Gulf of Mexico, picketed a Korean deli because it has the audacity operate in a black community.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MacMILLAN BLOEDEL SELLS STAKE IN DUTCH PAPER COMPANY
description: The Canadian forest products concern MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. said yesterday that it had sold its remaining 7.8 million ordinary shares of KNP BT N.V., a Dutch paper and packaging company, to ABN AMRO Hoare Govett, for about $188 million. The company said it would initially use the proceeds to pay down debt. ABN AMRO Hoare Govett is a subsidiary of ABN AMRO Holding N.V., a Dutch banking and financial services concern.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;News Corporation Plans Digital TV for Japan
description: Rupert Murdoch, the media entrepreneur, announced plans yesterday to start a 100-channel digital broadcasting system in Japan within two years. Mr. Murdoch said his company, the News Corporation, would produce and supply only a handful of the channels, leaving most for Japanese programmers.

title: Last Youth Leaves Montana Ranch, Raising Hopes of a Peaceful End tothe Standoff
description: Moving one more tantalizing step closer to surrender, the Freemen released the last minor from their besieged stronghold today, a teen-age girl who had told a negotiator that she feared dying and that she was there only because her mother had brought her.

title: Head of Complaint Board Quietly Resigns
description: The chairman of the civilian agency that reviews reports of police misconduct quietly resigned last week, two years after his appointment seemed to promise a new lease on life for an agency beleaguered by chronic staffing shortages and a long backlog of incomplete investigations.

title: The Arabs and Mr. Netanyahu
description: Nineteen Arab leaders plan to meet in Cairo next week for a show of unity in the wake of Benjamin Netanyahu's election as Prime Minister of Israel. The gathering is a reminder that the prospects for peace in the Middle East depend as much on the conduct of Arab leaders as that of Mr. Netanyahu in the weeks ahead.

title: Orange County: Hard Lesson in Safety of Municipal Debt
description: When Orange County, Calif., emerged from bankruptcy yesterday, ending an 18-month cliffhanger over the fate of this wealthy enclave south of Los Angeles, there was a Hollywood ending: Worried bondholders got paid in full, taxpayers did not have to raise a dime to pay off a $1.6 billion loss and the municipal market, after being burned once by the county, eagerly lent it $800 million more.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Post Sharp Drop
description: Treasury prices ended sharply lower yesterday despite a report that showed inflation remaining moderate.

title: BASEBALL;Clark Fans 9 Braves; Mets Foil Maddux
description: So much has been made of Atlanta's Greg Maddux, his accountant's looks, the way he treats the plate like a spread sheet, penciling in strikes grid by grid. Always neat, always meticulous.

title: DSC Damage Award Is Reduced by Judge
description: The DSC Communications Corporation said today that a Federal judge had reduced the damages the company will receive from its lawsuit against the Next Level Communications Corporation to $137 million from $369.2 million.

title: Metro Matters;Maker of Suits Sticks to Vow: No Sweatshop
description: THE KRIEGERS were standing in a hallway of Augustus, their clothing company in Brooklyn, trying to explain why they do not manufacture their suits in sweatshops or in China or Honduras or Taiwan or anyplace else where labor is so much cheaper than in New York City. "I guess," Arlene Krieger said, "we do not speak the language."

title: Navy Grounds Type Of Transport Copters
description: The Navy grounded all 199 of its largest transport helicopters today after discovering problems with a bearing in the main rotor.

title: Slain Woman's Parents Testify for Defense
description: The puzzling slaying of Brenda Wolf in a bungled jewelry store robbery 15 months ago was raised anew in New Jersey Superior Court here today.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the sale of a unit by Foamex International Inc. described Foamex incorrectly. It manufactures flexible polyurethane foam; it is not a chemical company.

title: Movie Musicals: Remembering
description: In the late 1950's and early 60's, the movie musical began a slow, sad death. The collapse of the studio system, the explosion of new music touched off by the Beatles, the lavish costs of making a musical, the onset of television as well as changing audience tastes led to the collapse of a genre that had defined the artistry of Hollywood.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;On Poulenc, Who Was Both Proper and Pop
description: The easiest way to incorporate popular music into classical forms is to be Francis Poulenc. There are fewalternatives; at any rate, people seeking the secret for reproducing this gift in their own image will get no help from reading the following. Better perhaps to enjoy the results and let the process remain the mystery it would always be anyhow.

title: At Windsor Castle, Former and Future Glory
description: WINDSOR CASTLE is aswarm with young woodcarvers using ancient draw knives to smooth 1,200-pound unseasoned oak beams, just as their predecessors did in medieval times. Plasterers are forming little flowers by hand, and gilders are busy applying gold leaf.

title: Ford Will Shift A Leasing Unit To a Subsidiary
description: The Ford Motor Company, which said last month that it would sell a vehicle leasing business owned by its U.S.L. Capital arm, announced today that it would simply shift the business to one of its subsidiaries.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUN HEALTHCARE SELLS ITS DAY SURGERY UNIT
description: Sun Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its day surgery unit, the Sunsurgery Corporation, for $27.9 million in cash and $5.6 million in assumed debt. The purchaser was the Medical Management and Development Corporation of Delaware Inc., whose principals include the unit's management. Sun, based in Albuquerque, N.M., had said it wanted to sell the unit because it was encountering marketplace resistance to integrating its services with the company's nursing home and rehabilitation businesses. Sunsurgery was the smallest of Sun's operating units, contributing 2 percent of the company's $320.3 million in revenue in the first quarter.

title: INSIDE
description: Pataki Assails Court Switch

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Cigar Sidelined With New Bruise
description: For the second time in three months, the superhorse Cigar will pass up a trip to California because of a bruised heel.

title: SHIP TO SHORE WITH: Joseph Wambaugh;Still a Bit Paranoid Among The Palms
description: NEATLY, if not altogether politely, Joseph Wambaugh summed things up. "Freedom?" the 59-year-old police novelist said, talking loudly over the engine noise of his cabin cruiser. He dismissed the concept with a mild profanity.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;British Spurn Johnson
description: The British athletics federation has banned the world champion MICHAEL JOHNSON from the July 12 London grand prix meet, saying it would be "demoralizing" to face the American in the 400-meter race.

title: Wilson Wyatt, 90, Politician And Louisville Civic Leader
description: Wilson W. Wyatt, a onetime wonder boy of Kentucky politics who shrugged off his failure to capitalize on his early promise by becoming one of Louisville's most active and revered civic leaders, died on Tuesday at a Louisville hospital. He was 90.

title: In Town Hit by Church Arson, Clinton Recalls South's Past
description: Gazing out over a cornfield next to a church built not far from the ruins of one destroyed by arson, President Clinton today recalled a time of segregation and lynchings in his native South and implored "every citizen in America to say we are not going back, we are not slipping back to those dark days."

title: A Billion-Dollar Dam Scam
description: Congress is again being asked to approve the most expensive dam in United States history -- the Auburn Dam on California's beautiful American River. Its stated purpose is to protect Sacramento from floods that even the dam's proponents admit would occur about once every five centuries, although it is designed to last only one century.

title: BASEBALL;Schott Agrees to Give Up Control Of Cincinnati Reds Through '98
description: Marge Schott, suspended in 1993 for her disparaging ethnic and racial remarks, agreed yesterday to relinquish her role as managing general partner of the Cincinnati Reds through the 1998 season after another series of questionable comments.

title: Defense Secretary Says U.S. Troops May Have to Remain in Bosnia WellInto Next Year
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that American ground troops may have to remain in Bosnia beyond their original December pullout date and well into next year to prevent the shaky peace in Bosnia from disintegrating again into civil war.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Atlanta 1996;Equipped With a One-Track Mind and Built for Speed
description: The Olympic track and field trials were four days away, but Michael Johnson was off the clock. He sat in an airy restaurant Monday night, munching on fried catfish and chewing on this odd thought: Among the three most prominent athletes from the Oak Cliff section of Dallas, he is the only one who has never appeared in public wearing a dress.

title: Economic Scene;Medical savings accounts: a solution without a problem?
description: IF legislation giving workers the right to keep their health insurance when they change jobs breathes its last, the cause of death will almost certainly be a political stalemate over medical savings accounts. But is this idea, so loved by House Republicans and so detested by the White House, really worth the fuss?

title: Report on Consumer Prices Shows Inflation Is Well Contained
description: Inflation remains well contained, despite an increasingly robust economy and the lingering effects of pinched oil supplies earlier in the year, Government figures showed today.

title: Arafat's Powers of Survival Being Put to the Test
description: Only a few weeks ago, Yasir Arafat was riding high, the elected ruler of a state that seemed about to be born.

title: European Topics
description: A call by some of France's greatest chefs to protect the purity of French cuisine has touched off a controversy. The chefs  Joel Robuchon, Alain Ducasse, Georges Blanc, Bernard Loiseau and Antoine Westermann  had warned of a tendency to "throw absolutely anything together on a plate to give the illusion of innovation."

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO BUY ANOTHER USED-CAR SELLER
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Carchoice Inc., an operator of used-car superstores, for $95 million in stock. In May, Republic announced an agreement to buy Auto Nation USA, a privately held company that is developing a chain of megastores for reconditioned vehicles, for $250 million in stock. Republic, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has interests in waste management, electronic security and used-car sales. It is controlled by H. Wayne Huizenga, the former chairman of the Blockbuster Entertainment Group. Republic's shares rose $3 yesterday, to $32.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Stock Soars After Report Of Cancer Test
description: The stock price of Biomerica Inc. quadrupled yesterday after the tiny medical technology company said it would produce a five-minute test for the diagnosis of prostate cancer.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DAYTON HUDSON PLANS TO SPLIT STOCK AND RAISE DIVIDEND
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation said yesterday that it would split its stock 3 for 1 and raise its quarterly dividend 9.1 percent. The Minneapolis-based retailer said the split, its first in 13 years, would bring its share price in line with most retail stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange. It currently has 72.2 million shares outstanding. The split will be effective July 17 to shareholders of record June 28. Dayton Hudson also said its dividend would rise to 48 cents a share on a presplit basis, from 44 cents. The dividend will be distributed Sept. 10 to shareholders of record on Aug. 20. The company's shares rose $2.25 yesterday, to $109.50.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Mind-Reading and Murder
description: Another clairvoyant is on the case of Newark's most vexing murder mystery. John Monti, a self-described psychic from Westhampton, L.I., who claims to have solved several murders, says he knows what happened to five teen-age boys who disappeared in 1978.

title: Bronx Man Questioned in Park Ave. Killing
description: Detectives were questioning a Bronx man late last night in the beating death of a popular Upper East Side woman who ran a dry-cleaning shop on Park Avenue, the police said.

title: Microsoft Prepares to Improve Its Threat to Netscape's Rule
description: The Microsoft Corporation will take another step in its effort to overtake the Netscape Communications Corporation in the market for Internet software when it presents a number of new technologies to 300 corporate executives at a meeting Thursday in San Jose, Calif.

title: COMPANY NEWS;F.C.C. APPROVES DILLER PLAN TO ACQUIRE 12 UHF STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission gave final approval yesterday to media executive Barry Diller's plan to acquire 12 UHF television stations that would form the foundation of a new network. The action permits Mr. Diller to take control of Silver King Communications and its stations, which carry home shopping programs. The F.C.C. had given Mr. Diller conditional approval, but stayed the decision following a complaint from the Urban Broadcasting Corporation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Goodby, Silverstein Wins Top Honors
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors last night, winning the $100,000 prize for the best commercial, at the fifth annual Radio-Mercury Awards presentation sponsored by the Radio Creative Fund of New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Tradewell Discount Investing, New York, to Emmerling Post, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the discount brokerage firm. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEWCOURT CREDIT TO ACQUIRE A UNIT OF PITNEY BOWES
description: Newcourt Credit Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the Custom Vendor Finance operations of the Pitney Bowes Credit Corporation, a unit of Pitney Bowes Inc., for undisclosed terms. Newcourt said it would acquire Custom Vendor Finance's existing operations, including 12 United States vendor finance programs. Newcourt will also acquire a portfolio of secured loans. The portfolio and related operations are valued at $126 million, the company said.

title: U.S. Aid for North Korea
description: The United States announced today that it had formally decided to provide North Korea with $6.2 million in food aid to ease a shortage caused by floods in 1995.

title: Company Stops On-Line Access To Key Social Security Numbers
description: Lexis-Nexis, one of the nation's leading private information brokers, has discontinued a new online offering that provided access to millions of people's Social Security numbers, after an onslaught of complaints from customers and the credit information bureau that originally supplied the data.

title: Bangladeshis Vote in Big Numbers on a Calm, Even Festive, Day
description: Voters turned out in record numbers today for a general election that many people here hope will put an end to political turmoil that has stunted economic growth and even raised fears of a new military takeover.

title: Insurers Lobby, Quietly, to Alter Consumer Law
description: Nearly three months ago, a group of prominent life insurance executives held a private meeting with the state's top insurance regulator. Their goal was to topple an 87-year-old consumer-protection statute that the industry has long resented.

title: Official Will Not Seek Vermont's Top Job
description: After recovering from a stroke, Lieut. Gov. Barbara W. Snelling announced today that she would forgo an effort to follow in her husband's footsteps as Governor of Vermont.

title: Learning From Losing, Karpov Wins
description: Some time in the last four days, Anatoly Karpov and his seconds unearthed a new move in the same situation in which he lost to Gata Kamsky on Saturday in Game 2 of their world championship match in Elista, Russia. This insight gave him the revitalizing counterplay he needed yesterday to stay out of danger, seize the initiative and win Game 4.

title: Central Islip Is to Be Site Of U.S. Court
description: After years of debate and delay, work will begin this summer in Central Islip on one of the nation's largest Federal courthouses, Federal officials announced today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the temperature of oxygen particles streaming from the sun misstated the measurement in some editions. Dr. John Kohl of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said that although the temperatures had not reached their peak, the particle readings had reached up to 200 million degrees Fahrenheit, not 200 degrees.

title: Executive Changes
description: COMPUTERVISION CORP., Bedford, Mass., named Kathleen A. Cote chief executive. She succeeds Russell E. Planitzer, who continues as chairman until at least June 1998.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Medical Tuition to Rise
description: Tuition at New Jersey's state medical university will rise as much as 30 percent for out-of-state students and 9 percent for residents next fall, officials said yesterday. They blamed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed budget, which reduces state subsidies by $7.9 million.

title: Drawing a Family History Out of Cyberspace
description: JACK KUPER lost his family when he was 8. Pretending to be an orphaned Catholic, he left the Warsaw ghetto and set off into the Polish countryside to escape the concentration camps.

title: Without Streets, And Loving It;In This L.I. Neighborhood, 'Walks' Are a Way of Life
description: Like most suburbanites, Patricia and Peter Lukas live in a single-family home on their own plot of land and have two cars. But they have no garage, carport or driveway. Or even a curb. Neither do their next-door neighbors, nor the ones living across the street.

title: Woes of 2 Israeli Cabinet Hopefuls Hinder Formation of Coalition
description: Adding yet another complication to Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu's tangled efforts to form a coalition, the Attorney General has advised him that two candidates for senior Cabinet positions face legal problems.

title: Escaping The Grid
description: YESTERDAY was an eventful day for architecture on the East and West Coasts.

title: A Shakespeare & Co. to Exit the Scene
description: For three years, Shakespeare & Company waged a battle against the sprawling Barnes & Noble bookstore that had moved in one block north and lured away half its business. But this week, the owners of the smaller bookstore, which has been as much a staple of the Upper West Side as Zabar's, decided they just didn't have it in them anymore.

title: Getty to Add A Collection Of Ancient Treasures
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., announced yesterday that it would be getting one of the world's finest private collections of ancient Greek and Roman art.

title: Nicholas Nunzio, 66, Washington Judge In Militants' Trial
description: Judge Nicholas S. Nunzio of the District of Columbia Superior Court, who presided over the trial of a dozen militants who seized three buildings in Washington and held more than a hundred people hostage in 1977, died on June 6 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 66 and lived in North Potomac, Md.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Fred Bridge, the founder of Bridge Kitchenware who died last month at 80, would have loved the honor bestowed upon him on Monday by the radio station WNYC, his son STEVEN BRIDGE said yesterday. The award, called Crabs Never Die, was presented at a dinner to benefit the station, which is losing its city funding on July 1.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Two Lives, One Lost to Alcoholism and the Other Surviving It
description: TERRY My Daughter's Life-and-Death Struggle With Alcoholism By George McGovern Illustrated. 208 pages. Villard/Random House. $21. DRINKING A Love Story By Caroline Knapp 258 pages. The Dial Press/Dell Publishing. $22.95.

title: Man in the News: Chester Trent Lott;A Polished and Pragmatic Ideologue
description: A blend of firebrand conservatism and polished tactical skills helped Trent Lott vault over more-senior members to the No. 2 job in the Senate's Republican hierarchy in 1994 and to the majority leader's seat today.

title: U.S. Mediator Survives Political Crossfire in Ulster
description: When former Senator George J. Mitchell was formally installed early this morning as chairman of the new broad-based Ulster peace talks, he had just survived his first personal lesson in the emotional, often vicious, sectarianism that has riven this British province for decades.

title: Market Place;May, too, was rich for mutual funds -- a year in five months.
description: CASH flows into mutual funds that invest in stocks slowed a bit in May from April's level, but demand remained strong, with aggressive growth funds continuing to attract the largest portion of assets, an industry group estimated yesterday.

title: New Treatment Helps Fight Crohn's Disease
description: Newly developed fish oil capsules appear to reduce flare-ups of Crohn's disease, a chronic inflammation of the bowel.

title: Mount Sinai and N.Y.U. Seek a Medical Merger
description: Two of the city's most prestigious hospitals, Mount Sinai Medical Center and New York University Medical Center, are close to agreement on a merger, a deal that would create a regional medical empire and reshape the New York health care market.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PHYLLIS GEORGE BROWN, the former CBS broadcaster and Miss America 1971, filed for divorce last week from her husband of 17 years, JOHN Y. BROWN Jr., the former Governor of Kentucky, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Pick Up An Extra Pick
description: The Knicks said yesterday that they would exercise their option on the 19th selection in the June 26 college draft, meaning they will have the 18th, 19th and 21st selections. The decision, announced by Ernie Grunfeld, gives the Knicks the option of packaging the picks in an effort to trade up in the first round, or include one or more in a deal.

title: U.S. Debates Whether to Punish Pakistan and China on Missiles
description: A long dispute within the Clinton Administration over how to handle Pakistan's acquisition of missiles and nuclear technology from China is intensifying, officials said today. Over the objections of the State Department, the intelligence agencies are arguing strongly for a finding that could bring about economic sanctions against both Pakistan and China.

title: Man Accused In 2d Attack, A Fatal One, With a Pipe
description: A homeless man has been accused of clubbing another drifter to death, then beating a tourist a day later in crimes whose aftermaths seemed yesterday to reflect both the anonymity and the caring that make up life in a big city.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 22,146.50, up 41.70 points, or almost two-tenths of 1 percent. On Wednesday, the index gained 287.18 points, or 1.32 percent, to 22,104.80, encouraged by buying in export companies like Sony and Matsushita Electric Industrial.

title: As Trump Reaches 50, A Not-So-Modest Bash
description: It was supposed to be a surprise. It was also supposed to be small and intimate. But Marla Trump found it difficult to plan a quiet, low-key 50th birthday party for her particular husband.

title: Retail Sales Up 0.8% in May But Were Below Expectations
description: Retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the third advance in four months, the Government reported today, partly because of an increase in auto sales.

title: Editorial Notebook;Bearish on Chicago's Bulls
description: The listless performance by the Chicago Bulls in their loss to the Seattle SuperSonics Wednesday night should bring a note of sobriety to the speculation about their all-time ranking. As dominant as Michael Jordan and his compatriots have been this season, they did not look like the best team ever assembled in the history of the National Basketball Association.

title: Zhirinovsky Savors Russian Kingmaker Role
description: The old woman on the poster is dressed entirely in black. She is wrapped in the arms of the only person she feels certain can guide Russia safely from the abyss, and a prayer for deliverance brightens her dark eyes.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Richard III 1995. MGM/UA. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 104 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Cruel World, Endless Until a Teacher Steps In
description: PUSH By Sapphire 179 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: U.S. OPEN;The Monster Isn't Baring Its Real Fangs Just Yet
description: The United States Open war of attrition began today on Oakland Hills' soft but swift greens, tricky surfaces fitted with pin placements that struck like serpents at the heels of the 156 golfers in the field. There were four-putts and there were missed one-footers and on a day where the the Monster was as docile as it is ever likely to be, some pleasant surprises surfaced on the leader board.

title: ON BASEBALL;What New York Fans Are All Missing: A Great Yankee Team
description: John Hart, the general manager of the Cleveland Indians who has earned the right to toss the word genius on his resume, talked about one of the most overlooked accomplishments of his club -- the Indians sold out every home game before this season started.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising;Mr. Whipple squeezes, Mikey eats and the Ginsu cuts as new cable network runs old commercials.
description: MARKETERS like Timex, Culligan, Chock Full o'Nuts and Schlitz, which are reviving bygone advertising slogans and characters, are being joined by a cable television network that is delving further into the attic of shared American memories by bringing back vintage commercials.

title: Dole Dismisses Clinton's Excuse on F.B.I. Files
description: Bob Dole today ridiculed President Clinton's position that a "bureaucratic snafu" led to the White House's obtaining F.B.I. files on former Republican officials, saying Mr. Clinton's Administration had been plagued by such "innocent mistakes."

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE SUSPECT;For Suspect, a Nether Life Spent on Fringes of the City
description: He led a spare and tattered life of need on the fringes of the city, but mostly he seemed to occupy some other world accessible only to himself.

title: Keep in Mind
description: "FATHER'S DAY WEEKEND," part of the "Roses! Roses! Roses!" celebration at the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park, the Bronx. Featured for dads are informal tours of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M. A harpist is to perform tomorrow from 2 to 4 P.M., and the Goldman Memorial Band will play on Sunday from 3 to 5 P.M. Also available on both days are golf-cart tours and guided forest tours. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $3 for adults and $1 for children 6 to 16; free Saturdays from 10 A.M. to noon. Information: (718) 817-8700.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: SENTENCING;Court Upholds Sentence in King Case
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal District Court properly took Rodney G. King's own misconduct into account in giving reduced sentences to the two Los Angeles police officers who were convicted of violating his civil rights by brutally beating him.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Heat 1995. Warner. $103.91. Laser disk, $39.98. 171 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Home Video
description: Delayed Delivery

title: FILM REVIEW;Complicated Life Redeemed by Love
description: Death by smallpox, a prodigal son's dramatic return to the family castle with his prostitute fiancee, a radiant young virgin auctioned off to a grotesque old man: there are enough racy Hogarthian tableaux in Pen Densham's film "Moll Flanders" to fill a good-sized art gallery.

title: Few Big Ripples Are Seen For the Global Economy
description: When a huge international financial institution like the Sumitomo Corporation announces that one of its traders has cost the company $1.8 billion in trading losses, Americans naturally ask how might this affect them. The answer seems to be that the impact will be negligible.

title: U.S. Grants Asylum to Woman Fleeing Genital Mutilation Rite
description: The highest administrative tribunal in the United States immigration system granted political asylum yesterday to a 19-year-old woman from Togo who said she had fled her homeland to escape having her genitals cut off.

title: Media General Purchase
description: Media General Inc. said today that it would acquire the Register Publishing Company, publisher of The Danville (Va.) Register & Bee, for about $38 million in cash. The Register & Bee is a morning newspaper, with a daily circulation of 23,000 and a Sunday circulation of 27,000. Media General owns newspapers and television stations primarily in the Southeast, including The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune and The Richmond Times-Dispatch. The company, which last year purchased a group of Virginia papers, said that its acquisition of the Register & Bee should close this summer.

title: Guatemalans Take New Step Toward Peace
description: Latin America's oldest civil war took another step closer to resolution today with Guatemala's ratification of a United Nations pact on tribal peoples. Guatemalan rebels had demanded the ratification as a crucial part of an eight-step United Nations plan to end the war.

title: Art in Review
description: Wifredo Lam Galerie Lelong 20 West 57th Street Through June 28

title: Blue Cross Warns Ohio Plan Not to Sell to Columbia
description: The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association said yesterday that it would terminate the licenses of Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield if the Ohio plan proceeded with a $299.5 million agreement to sell its main lines of business to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's biggest investor-owned hospital chain.

title: Nasdaq Delisting Weitek
description: The Weitek Corporation, a maker of computer memory chips, said on Wednesday that it would be delisted from the Nasdaq stock market. Weitek said Nasdaq had informed it that the company did not meet its listing requirements. The San Jose company said it planned to appeal the ruling. Weitek said it would seek a new listing on the Nasdaq-run OTC Bulletin Board if the company could not maintain its Nasdaq listing. Weitek's stock closed today at 96.9 cents.

title: Fidelity Considers Closing Magellan Fund
description: An executive at Fidelity Investments said the mutual-fund company would continue to examine the possibility of closing the Magellan fund, the $55 billion fund that is the country's largest, to new investors.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Blue in the Face 1995. Miramax. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.99. 89 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MORE INCREASES IN EARNINGS AND DIVIDENDS ARE SEEN
description: The chairman of the Philip Morris Companies, Geoffrey C. Bible, said yesterday that the company expected healthy earnings increases this year and beyond. Mr. Bible, in comments to securities analysts in New York, said that Philip Morris, the food and tobacco giant, expected to buy back $2.8 billion worth of stock in 1996. He added that the company was "more than living up to our commitment to increase dividends at least in line with earnings." Last year, the company raised its dividend by 21.2 percent while net earnings per share rose by 19.4 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GROUP TO BUY 9 MALLS FROM CANADIAN OWNER
description: First Union Real Estate Investments said yesterday that a joint venture it had with an undisclosed partner had agreed to acquire nine shopping malls for $316 million from Marathon U.S. Realties Inc. First Union said that the malls were in the Southwest and that its portion of the investment would not exceed $50 million. First Union, which is based in Cleveland, is a real estate investment trust that specializes in retail and apartment complexes. It is not related to the First Union Corporation, the bank company. Marathon U.S. Realties, which is based in Dallas, is part of Marathon Canada, an owner of office and retail buildings that is a unit of Canadian Pacific Ltd.

title: BASEBALL;Cox's Contract Extended
description: The Atlanta Braves today extended Manager Bobby Cox's contract by two years, through 1999, with an option for 2000. Cox managed the Braves from 1978-81 and the Toronto Blue Jays from 1982-85. He returned to Atlanta as general manager in 1985 and as field manager June 22, 1990.

title: Chief Justice of New Jersey Resigns After 17 Years on the High Court
description: Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz announced today that he would step down from the New Jersey Supreme Court, ending 17 years leading a court known around the country as both innovative and pragmatic on a wide range of social issues.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Guilty in Rutgers Protest
description: Three Rutgers University students yesterday were found guilty of obstructing a highway during an April 1995 protest against the school's president.

title: NBA FINALS;Kemp Grows Up In Front of Seattle's Eyes
description: Dennis Rodman has a new tattoo: Shawn Kemp's footprint.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Computerized Tolls Are Near
description: The State Senate sent Gov. Christine Todd Whitman legislation yesterday that would set the stage for computerized tolls on New Jersey's three major toll highways, The Associated Press reported.

title: Former Student In Patent Fight Leaves Prison
description: Petr Taborsky, a former student research assistant at University of South Florida who was imprisoned in November in a dispute with the university over the ownership of patents, was transferred today to a work-release center in Tampa.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: TV WEEKEND;9 African Stowaways And a Homicidal Crew
description: In 1992, after nine stowaways were discovered by several members of the crew of a Ukraine cargo ship sailing from Ghana, eight of the nine African men were murdered. Kingsley Ofosu survived to tell the story, vividly dramatized in "Deadly Voyage," which will have its premiere tomorrow night at 8. This is the first production of HBO NYC, a new Home Box Office movie division based in New York. The film, undertaken in association with the BBC, was made in Ghana and England.

title: FILM REVIEW;Trading Mischief for Malice
description: HOLLYWOOD has already rocked Alcatraz and blown away parts of Oklahoma; space aliens are poised to zap the White House in next month's "Independence Day." But the true disaster movie of the summer may just be "The Cable Guy," a grim, sour Jim Carrey comedy that erases the boundary between anarchic humor and sociopathic malice.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Box' Fotouhi Cramer Gallery 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo Through June 22

title: Don't Delay Bosnia's Vote
description: In the seven months since the Dayton agreement ended the Bosnian war, our mission in that country has achieved more than the cynics thought possible. The guns of war are silent; city streets are safe from snipers; once besieged towns are no longer cut off from the world, and bit by bit homes, schools, roads and factories are being rebuilt.

title: Ah, Wilderness, in the Female Lexicon
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE PROSECUTION;Morgenthau Will Consider Death Penalty
description: The killing of the owner of a Park Avenue dry-cleaning store could put the Manhattan District Attorney back into a legal coliseum that he has repeatedly said he loathes: the debate over New York's young death-penalty law.

title: Milken Group Holds Talks With Israelis
description: Representatives of an investor group headed by the junk bond pioneer Michael Milken held talks this week with the Eisenberg Group here about possible cooperation, a spokesman for Israel Chemicals said.

title: Energy Dept. Sees Lower Prices at the Pump
description: Gasoline prices could drop as much as 10 cents a gallon this summer, the Energy Department said today.

title: Sumitomo Says It Found Loss Of $1.8 Billion
description: The Sumitomo Corporation, the huge Japanese commodities and industrial company, said yesterday that it had discovered what it estimated to be an undisclosed $1.8 billion loss, largely the result of unauthorized trading by its head copper trader over the last 10 years.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Are Slain in Newark
description: Three men were killed late Tuesday in a pair of apparently unrelated incidents, bringing the number of homicides in the city this year to 45, the police said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Takeover Planned For Fokker Aviation
description: The Dutch industrial systems and services company Stork N.V. said yesterday that it had taken steps to take over Fokker Aviation, a company made up of the subsidiaries that survived the March bankruptcy of the Dutch plane maker Fokker N.V. Stork added it had spoken to Fokker administrators and would soon start an exclusive examination of Fokker Aviation's books.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Just a Neighborly Promotion
description: VINNY PAZIENZA and DANA ROSENBLATT exchanged intense but respectful glances yesterday at a Manhattan news conference promoting their Aug. 23 bout for the World Boxing Union's supermiddleweight title, a vacant and relatively obscure belt.

title: Bosnia Extradites 2 to Tribunal
description: Two Muslim prison camp officials accused of murdering and raping Bosnian Serb inmates were extradited today to stand trial here at the war crimes tribunal.

title: Weighing Political Words and Political Action
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Data East USA Inc., San Jose, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the manufacturer of sports video games. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: Investors Are Betting On Kmart's Revival
description: The Kmart Corporation has increased its sale of convertible preferred stock by 15 percent, to $1 billion, as more investors have been betting on the company's revival.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: NBA FINALS;Sonics Get Lesson In Jordan Rules
description: Poor Michael Jordan. His Chicago Bulls did not sweep in Game 4 and now he has to put away the broom and break out a hoe and a plow a for Game 5. It is slowly becoming grueling work, this leading America's basketball team toward a championship. It is not merely the Seattle SuperSonics making him work overtime. If you subscribe to his belief, those mean men with whistles for brains are against him, too.

title: Company Briefs
description: Citizens Financial Group Inc., the American unit of Royal Bank of Scotland P.L.C., has agreed to acquire Farmers and Mechanics Bank, Middletown, Conn., for $53.2 million.

title: Trump's 50th: No Surprise But Lots of Surprises
description: It was supposed to be a surprise. It was also supposed to be small and intimate. But Marla Trump found it difficult to plan a quiet, low-key 50th birthday party for her particular husband.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Paul Himmel and the Brodovitch Circle' Howard Greenberg Gallery 120 Wooster Street, SoHo Through June 22

title: OLYMPICS;Cocaine Wrecks Hurdler's Gold Medal Hopes
description: Danny Harris was expected to be one of the great comeback stories at the Olympic track and field trials here. A silver medalist at the 1984 Summer Games in the 400-meter hurdles, Harris later become addicted to cocaine. Lately, he seemed to have recovered both his career and his personal life.

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: A CALL TO 911;Language Barrier May Have Led to a Fatal Delay
description: A neighbor of the man held in four recent attacks on women said yesterday that she called the police on Monday because her neighbor resembled the sketch of the suspect in the beating of a piano teacher in Central Park. But she hung up because, she said, the operator did not speak Spanish.

title: SOCCER;U.S. Is on the Inside Looking Out
description: Three of the four national teams in the U.S. Cup '96 soccer tournament are still in contention for the championship, but the United States is no longer the favorite. That distinction now belongs to Mexico after the Americans suffered a stunning loss to Bolivia Thursday night and Mexico played Ireland to a deadlock.

title: Brigitte Helm, 88, Cool Star Of Fritz Lang's 'Metropolis'
description: Brigitte Helm, the German actress who defined the unobtainable, cool-eyed screen vamp as the haunting teen-age star of Fritz Lang's futuristic 1926 masterpiece, "Metropolis," died on Tuesday in Ascona, Switzerland, where she had lived in seclusion for more than 30 years. By her own account, she was 88.

title: Weighing Political Words and Political Action;Words on Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Speech in Cyberspace
description: In an eloquent decision that honors free speech, a special three-judge panel in Philadelphia has blocked an unconstitutional and wholly unnecessary new Federal law enacted earlier this year in the name of protecting children. The ruling rightly views the vast web of computer networks now used by millions of people not as a threat, as Congress seemed to when it passed the Communications Decency Act, but as "a never-ending worldwide conversation" entitled to maximum protection under the First Amendment.

title: U.S. Indicts Arizona Governor on Fraud and Extortion Charges
description: Gov. Fife Symington, whose multimillion-dollar commercial real estate dealings have been under Justice Department investigation for the last five years, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on 23 counts of fraud and extortion.

title: TV SPORTS;And Now, Albert Belle: The Movie
description: Albert Belle came to town yesterday. He met with two men. The first was the American League president, Gene Budig, to appeal a five-game suspension for the nasty forearm smash he delivered to Brewers second baseman Fernando Vina.

title: Two Top Directors Of the Philharmonic Are Resigning
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that its two top directors, Stephen Stamas and H. Frederick Krimendahl 2d, will leave their posts as chairman and president as soon as successors can be chosen. A search committee including the two was named to seek candidates.

title: Jury Gets the Case In Trial of Blades
description: The manslaughter trial of Seattle Seahawks receiver Brian Blades has gone to the jury one day after a gun demonstration put on by the state might have actually helped the defense.

title: Weighing Political Words and Political Action
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE OVERVIEW;Man Said to Admit a Week of Attacks
description: A rootless 22-year-old man whose only criminal record was for jumping a subway turnstile stunned investigators by confessing to the killing of a dry cleaner owner on the Upper East Side, the near-fatal beating of a woman in Central Park and brutal assaults on two other women, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: THE SUPREME COURT;Excerpts From Court's Decision Invalidating Four Congressional Districts
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision yesterday invalidating three Congressional districts in Texas and one in North Carolina as the products of unconstitutional racial gerrymandering, as transcribed by The New York Times. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote a plurality opinion that was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices Clarence Thomas and Antonin Scalia concurred separately.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BANK OF BOSTON OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENT TO 1,500
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation has offered early retirement to 1,500 employees as it cuts costs before it completes the purchases of Baybanks Inc. and another crosstown rival. Bank of Boston, the 18th-largest bank in the nation in terms of assets, plans to eliminate 2,000 jobs as it takes over Baybanks and Boston Bancorp, which operates the South Boston Savings Bank. Bank of Boston said yesterday that it had made the retirement offer to try to reduce the number of workers who will be dismissed. Even so, Bank of Boston will probably dismiss hundreds of the roughly 25,000 employees of the three banks, because only half the 1,500 workers are expected to accept the offer. The bank said 700 people had left their jobs and had not been replaced since the purchase of Baybanks was announced in December.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Trade Threats? Say Ho-Hum;Chinese in a Boomtown Busy Making Money
description: To Wu Bangdong, a garment manufacturer in this booming coastal city, the danger that the United States and China will impose trade sanctions on each other seems a distant worry.

title: Inside Photography
description: Kenro Izu is undaunted by the familiarity of his subjects: nudes, flowers and the world's great stone monuments, like the pyramids in Egypt, Stonehenge in England, the Angkor temples in Cambodia. Neither is he deterred by the laborious platinum-palladium printmaking process or his 300 pounds of photographic equipment, including a custom-made camera that produces 14-by-20-inch negatives.

title: Corrections: Rating Wine Vintages
description: The vintage chart with the Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Wednesday incorrectly labeled one category and omitted another. A corrected chart appears below.

title: Officers Fatally Shoot a Suspected Car Thief
description: Plainclothes detectives shot and killed a suspected car thief in Brooklyn yesterday after he reached between the front seats of the car as they tried to question him, the police said. The shooting prompted crowds to gather throughout the night in a vigil for the dead man.

title: California Dam Epitomizes Big Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Often Derided, a Borough Shines on Its Home Page;Hotels Are Few, but History Is Abundant
description: In the virtual Bronx, natural beauty shimmers around every corner. The air quivers with the smell of fine cuisine and the sound of soothing music. The streets are knee deep in history, and never is heard a discouraging word.

title: Woman in the News;Lawyer at 40 Rises to Chief: Deborah Tobias Poritz
description: Deborah Tobias Poritz was teaching English at Ursinus College near Philadelphia in the early 1970's when her husband, Alan, a mathematician, landed a new job in Princeton, N.J.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Case Dropped Against Rider
description: The police dropped their case against ISAIAH RIDER yesterday after the Minnesota Timberwolves guard spent a night in jail in Oakland, Calif., according to officials. Rider was released about 8:15 A.M. from the Oakland City Jail, where he had been held on $20,000 bail, according to J. JOHNSON, a record clerk at the jail.

title: Exxon Is Accused of 'Astonishing Ruse' in Oil-Spill Trial
description: In a stinging rebuke to the Exxon Corporation, its chairman and its lawyers, a Federal judge has held that they had all been part of an "astonishing ruse" to attempt to manipulate the jury that awarded $5 billion in damages to pay the victims of the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989.

title: Sports of The Times;No Logos, No Luck, No Lead
description: ON the 455-yard fifth hole, Tiger Woods pushed his tee shot into a fairway bunker, blasted out within 60 yards of the hole, then spun a 60-degree wedge off the pin into the cup. Birdie.

title: French Furor Over British Exports of Feed Linked to Mad Cows
description: The cows may be mad, but the French are furious.

title: Goldwater's Coattails
description: By choosing Trent Lott of Mississippi as majority leader, Republican senators have taken another step in their party's transformation of the balance of power in Washington. For the first time in history, both the House and Senate leadership posts are in the hands of two Republicans from the Deep South. It all began when Barry Goldwater swept the cotton South in 1964 and carried a handful of Republicans into the House. But unlike the South's Democratic barons in the past, these men have few if any political alliances with the urban centers of the Northeast and Midwest. If New York and other states in the North are not to lose more ground in the battle over Federal resources, they will have to unite and fight for their interests.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LUCAS ASKS NAVY TO REMOVE IT FROM BAN ON CONTRACTS
description: Lucas Industries P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had met with United States Navy officials to ask them to remove Lucas from a Pentagon blacklist that forbids it to bid on contracts. The Pentagon banned Lucas from seeking military contracts after an investigation showed that it had shipped faulty gearboxes for the Navy's F/A-18 Hornet planes. In October, Lucas paid $88 million to settle the charges. That payment came in addition to a civil penalty of $18.5 million it paid in January 1995, when Lucas pleaded guilty to fraud in connection with its sale of the gearboxes. Lucas has been looking for partners or a buyer for the Western Geared Systems unit, which is based in the United States and supplied the parts.

title: Weighing Political Words and Political Action;On Values and Friction
description: To the Editor:

title: Isolated Gene Is Suspected Of Causing Skin Cancer
description: Two groups of scientists say they have discovered the gene believed to cause the most common form of human cancer, basal-cell carcinoma, as well as a rare, inherited disorder that can result in multiple cancers.

title: Rulings Shaped by a Vision of Change
description: In his 17 years as Chief Justice, Robert N. Wilentz used the New Jersey Supreme Court to promote his vision of social progress and equality. Here is a sampling of his opinions.

title: Gold-Rush Misfortune
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Carroll Dunham Recent Drawings Nolan/Eckman Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo Through June 22

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: U.S. Sanctions on Investors in Libya or Iran
description: A House committee today approved a compromise bill strengthening American sanctions against Iran and Libya but giving the President considerable latitude in carrying them out. The bill, considerably modified from a tougher version, is directed at citizens of other countries who invest in Iran and Libya; Washington says the two countries support terrorism.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Argentine Bank Ends I.B.M. Deal
description: Banco de la Nacion Argentina, that country's biggest bank, has canceled a $249 million contract with I.B.M. for a new computer system.

title: At Home Abroad;Seeing No Evil
description: Indicted war criminals are dictating the agenda at the moment. They are saying what should happen."

title: New System of Assessing Health Risks Is Urged
description: In a draft report that is winning praise from environmentalists and the chemical industry, a Federal commission recommended yesterday that the system of assessing and regulating health hazards from environmental pollutants and other sources, like food additives, be overhauled.

title: BOXING;Holmes's Absolutely Final Bout (Or So He Says)
description: Larry Holmes is walking.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Aid Cutoff Stuns Camden
description: A state authority's decision to cut off financing for Camden's Urban Enterprise Zone caught city officials off guard, an aide to Mayor Arnold W. Webster said yesterday.

title: Board Members to Give In on Control of School Repair Money
description: Even though some Board of Education members fear that politics could influence which schools will have their roofs fixed, they say they will accede to City Hall's demand for final authority over how to spend the $276 million for school repairs that is part of the new city budget.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUP TO BUY BANK UNIT OF COLE TAYLOR
description: Cole Taylor Financial Group Inc., a financial holding company based in Wheeling, Ill., a Chicago suburb, has agreed to split off its Cole Taylor Bank subsidiary to an investment group headed by the company's chairman, Jeffrey W. Taylor. Under the agreement, the holding company will get 4 million to 4.5 million shares of Cole Taylor Financial stock from the investor group. Besides the stock, the holding company will receive cash and receivables ranging from about $82 million to about $98 million.

title: For Urban Sprawl, Blame Land-Use Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: NBA FINALS;Pippen, the Fall Guy, Will Not Give Excuses
description: Wearing a golf cap turned backward, Scottie Pippen sat amid reporters yesterday and tried to explain why the Chicago Bulls were practicing instead of celebrating.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: THE DECISION;HIGH COURT VOIDS RACE-BASED PLANS FOR REDISTRICTING
description: Invoking its precedents against the use of race in legislative districting, the Supreme Court today invalidated one Congressional district in North Carolina and three in Texas as the product of unconstitutional racial gerrymanders. All four districts had been drawn after the 1990 census to give minority voters more electoral influence.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Accusations Against Trader Likely to Roil Copper Trading
description: Copper prices ended lower yesterday before an announcement that a prominent copper trader had been accused of causing losses of $1.8 billion in unauthorized trades.

title: Files Show Clues Tying Suspect Held in Montana to Unabomber
description: Federal agents found extensive evidence of possible links between Theodore J. Kaczynski and the Unabomber before they searched his mountain cabin and arrested him near here, according to court documents released today.

title: Real Estate;A development of mansions -- around a Nicklaus golf course -- rises in Westchester estate country.
description: WHEN Tokio Kasuga looked for a huge property close to New York City to develop, it was the height of the real estate boom. By the time the right place -- for a championship golf course surrounded by mansions -- was found, a recession had set in.

title: An Attic Of Stuff, All Real
description: REMEMBER Father Guido Sarducci's classic "Saturday Night Live" routine, the "Five-Minute University"? The one in which he rushed through the highlights of every subject at breakneck speed? That's what visiting "America's Smithsonian," the vast exhibition that opened this week at the New York Coliseum, feels like. History? Here's Abe Lincoln's hat. Sports? Step right up and see Arthur Ashe's tennis racquet and a baseball signed by Babe Ruth. Culture? Yes, it must be, because there's a Henry Moore, and an Edward Hopper, and hey, that's an Andy Warhol over there. But keep moving, because now you're at Natural History, and you don't want to miss those dinosaur bones or the fossils preserved in amber. Ancient artifacts? Nice Cycladic figure over in that case, circa 2500 B.C. Want some reminders of American ingenuity? Have a look at Samuel F. B. Morse's telegraph key, the Jarvik-7 heart and Alan B. Shepard's Freedom 7 space capsule. Like literature? Then you'll be sure to love the portraits of Mark Twain and F. Scott Fitzgerald. Music? Dizzy Gillespie's trumpet, thank you.

title: Turkey Ponders Its Shift in Fortunes
description: When the Foreign Minister of Kyrgyzstan met with her Turkish counterpart at a recent international gathering, she asked him a question so painful and so blunt that it made front-page news in Turkey.

title: After 21 Years, Bangladeshi Party Is Returned to Power
description: Nearly 21 years after it lost its leader and its grip on power in an army massacre, the Awami League, the political party that won Bangladesh its independence from Pakistan, returned from the political wilderness today as the winner of a general election.

title: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Georgia Race Issue Oozes Into a Campaign

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Exxon Is Admonished On 'Ruse' in Valdez Case In a stinging rebuke to Exxon, its chairman, and its lawyers, a Federal judge held that they had all been part of an "astonishing ruse" to try to manipulate the jury that awarded $5 billion in damages for the victims of the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Referring to a secret agreement with seafood processors that had previously settled with the company, the judge said that Exxon had acted as "Jekyll and Hyde" by "behaving laudably in public and deplorably in private." [Page D4.] A Summer Dip in Gasoline Prices? The Energy Department said the price of gasoline could drop as much as 10 cents a gallon this summer. It also supported the industry's position that prices soared because of a jump in crude oil prices and because of a colder-than-normal winter. [D4.]

title: FILM REVIEW;Like, This Valley Girl Gang Is Ready to Rumble
description: There's nothing like a vintage exploitation movie to resurrect the fashion eyesores and stale political rhetoric of a bygone era with what in retrospect seems like a vengeful sense of parody. In Jack Hill's 1975 film "Switchblade Sisters," "Blackboard Jungle" meets "Foxy Brown" meets "Charlie's Angels" on the streets of a graffiti-spattered Anycity, U.S.A.

title: Brazil Surgeon Develops a Bold, Promising Operation for Patients With Heart Failure
description: Working under primitive conditions in a small rural hospital in Brazil, a surgeon has developed a bold new operation for heart failure that supporters say promises ultimately to allow tens of thousands of people to resume daily activities, stop many medications and avoid transplants.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Every year, one of her neighbors asks MOLLY BLOOM, 18, if she plans to attend "Bloomsday on Broadway," the annual celebration of James Joyce's "Ulysses" at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: U.S. Has Plan to Broaden Availability of DNA Testing
description: Issuing a report that documents the power of DNA testing to exonerate the innocent, the Justice Department is to announce today that it will step up efforts to make such tests as common as fingerprinting and will help accelerate the construction of a national DNA data bank.

title: No Need to Abandon German Economic Model
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICRON REPORTS LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED EARNINGS
description: Micron Technology Inc., the semiconductor company based in Boise, Idaho, reported late yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal third quarter fell 74 percent from a year earlier as prices for its computer memory chips plummeted. Micron's net income for the quarter, which ended on May 30, fell to $58.2 million, or 27 cents a share, including a $12 million one-time gain, from $220.2 million, or $1.02 a share, a year earlier. The company's sales rose 1.3 percent, to $771 million from $761 million. Analysts surveyed by IBES International had expected the company to report earnings of 31 cents a share.

title: Mixing Orthodoxy and Politics in Israel
description: Like most Israelis, Hani Shamir is not an observant Jew. She drives her car and turns on the television on Saturdays, violating the religious prohibitions of the Sabbath. But in the Israeli election last month she voted for Shas, an ardently Orthodox party that made big gains at the polls.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The return of red sauce is turning this town's Italian tables upside down. For a decade, fine Italian restaurants have proudly announced their northern heritage, but that might be about to change. In the last month, two proudly southern Italian restaurants have opened, each celebrating the gutsy, garlicky food of Naples.

title: LAST OF FREEMEN SURRENDER TO F.B.I. AT MONTANA SITE
description: The last 16 members of the Freemen anti-Government group handed themselves over to Federal agents tonight, ending one of the longest sieges by American law enforcement so peacefully that the surrender did not even disturb the cows grazing at the group's remote Montana ranch.

title: ART REVIEW;A Romantic Haze on Dead-End Lives of the City
description: When figurative painting returned to favor in New York in the early 1980's, the city itself became a subject, in a way it hadn't for decades, for several strong younger artists.

title: Restaurants
description: The woman at the next table keeps getting up. Each time she stands, the entire dining room takes notice, our eyes on the leopard skin shorts and the legs that unfold endlessly from beneath the table. The dining room watches, too, as the woman at the table opposite mine unbuttons yet another inch of lime green Chanel jacket. She is not wearing anything under it, and she laughs and swishes her shiny black hair as she toys with the collar.

title: Abortion Issue Jolts Republicans Yet Again
description: Despite Bob Dole's efforts to calm the Republican furor over abortion, the issue continues to explode through the party. In the latest bursts, the chairman of the Republican platform committee privately talked of quitting at one point this week, a prominent Senator is warning that he may boycott the Republican National Convention, and conservative groups in several states are trying to keep abortion rights supporters out of convention delegations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Air and Cruise Account Shifts at Harris Drury
description: Airlines and cruise lines have made account news for Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Stocks Surge in Japan
description: Stocks were trading sharply higher here today. The morning session ended with the Nikkei index of 225 issues up 290.19 points, or 1.31 percent at 22,372.59. On Thursday, the Nikkei slipped 22.40 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent.

title: Colombia's Leader, Cleared by Congress, Still Isn't in the Clear
description: Although Congress has cleared President Ernesto Samper of charges that Cali drug dealers financed his election, the Colombian leader faces an uncertain future. The threat of impeachment has been lifted, but calls for his resignation remain.

title: Celebrating a Font Of Music and Theater
description: This weekend a series of events will celebrate the fact that for more than a hundred years, the Lower East Side of Manhattan has been a wellspring of American culture. At the turn of the century, many Jewish immigrants from Russia and Eastern Europe and their children, living on the streets below 14th Street, laid the groundwork for the American musical theater. Irving Berlin lived at 330 Cherry Street. George and Ira Gershwin lived at many addresses, including the corner of Hester and Eldridge Streets.

title: 2 Held in Plot to Poison Politicians With Radium
description: Two Long Island men were arrested today and charged with planning to use radioactive material to assassinate several Suffolk County officials and political leaders.

title: HOCKEY;Smith's Goal: Baby Blueshirts
description: Armed with the new contract, Neil Smith plans to bring in new players and new ideas to the Rangers. The club's president and general manager repeated yesterday in stronger terms what he had said for the first time last week: The Rangers can't keep acquiring older, expensive players each season to build a Stanley Cup contender around Mark Messier, their 35-year-old captain.

title: Surrender Is a Victory for a Strategy of Patience
description: It was on Monday night that negotiators from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, after months of fruitless talks, began to sense that the standoff with the Montana Freemen was moving toward a peaceful close, Louis J. Freeh, the agency's Director, said tonight.

title: Ex-State Official Charged In Insurance Fraud Plot
description: The former assistant director of the New York State agency that combats insurance fraud was charged yesterday with taking bribes to suppress complaints about a friend's insurance-adjusting company.

title: New Testimony Raises Questions on Mrs. Clinton's Role in Deal
description: Four days before they are supposed to complete their investigation, Republicans on the Senate Whitewater committee today disclosed new testimony that they said raised fresh questions about the involvement of Hillary Rodham Clinton in structuring a land deal in 1986 that was later found to be fraudulent.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Aid for Industry Cleanup
description: Newark and Camden are among 20 cities across the country that will receive Federal money under a program, called Brownfields, to help them decontaminate abandoned industrial areas, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday.

title: London Stock Exchange Names New Chief
description: The London Stock Exchange has appointed a top official of a major London brokerage firm as chief executive, replacing Michael Lawrence, who was dismissed earlier this year.

title: OLYMPICS;Tribulations Aplenty At U.S. Track Trials
description: In a conversation before the track and field season opened, Coach Tom Tellez told Carl Lewis, "You're not finished." It might seem an odd thing to say to a man who has won eight Olympic gold medals, but after several disappointing seasons, age appeared to be running Lewis down in the homestretch.

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENC: THE INVESTIGATION;A Suspect in Custody Prays, and Then Confesses to Four Brutal Crimes Against Women
description: Late Wednesday night, in a second-floor interview room at the police station on East 67th Street in Manhattan, John J. Royster quietly announced that he wanted to pray.

title: No Leak Inquiry, Judge in Bomb Case Says
description: The judge in the Oklahoma City bombing trial refused today to order an investigation into news leaks in the case, saying it would be a waste of time.

title: COMPANY NEWS;F.T.C. CLEARS RAYTHEON PURCHASE OF CHRYSLER UNIT
description: The Raytheon Company has settled Federal Trade Commission charges that its $475 million purchase of Chrysler Technologies Holding Inc. would violate antitrust concerns, clearing the way for it to move ahead. Raytheon, the defense and aerospace giant, agreed to erect an "information fire wall" for the remainder of a bidding competition between it and the GTE Corporation for the United States Navy's purchase of a satellite communications system to be used in submarines. Chrysler Technologies, a unit of the Chrysler Corporation, is providing GTE with antenna and terminal controls that are used in a proposed satellite system.

description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Charges Against 2 Dropped in Singapore
description: Singapore has dropped a criminal investigation against two former Barings executives, saying yesterday that there was insufficient evidence to charge them in the collapse of Britain's oldest investment bank. The announcement by the Commercial Affairs Department, Singapore's white-collar crime police, marks the final chapter in the criminal aspect of the case, which led to a prison sentence for Nicholas W. Leeson, the young trader whose fraudulent deals brought down the 232-year-old bank.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HILTON MAY BUY SHARES OF BALLY'S GRAND, TOO
description: The shares of Bally's Grand Inc. rose nearly 9 percent yesterday after the Hilton Hotels Corporation said it was considering buying the 1.3 million shares of Bally's Grand that are not already owned by the Bally Entertainment Corporation. The shares of Bally's Grand rose $3.375, to $39.75, in Nasdaq trading; there are about 8.44 million outstanding. Hilton said last week that it planned to buy Bally Entertainment for about $3 billion in stock and assumed debt. The Bally's Grand shares, valued at about $47.3 million, would give Hilton complete control over the assets of Bally's Grand. They include Bally's casino in Las Vegas and 24 acres of adjacent land where Bally Entertainment plans to build the Paris Casino resort.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Phillips Is Arrested On Drunken-Driving Charge
description: St. Louis Rams running back LAWRENCE PHILLIPS, already on probation for assaulting a former girlfriend, was arrested for drunken driving early yesterday in Los Angeles.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: BASEBALL;Belle Goes To Great Lengths On Appeal
description: For the second straight time coming into Yankee Stadium, the Cleveland Indians not only brought a main act, one of the best teams in baseball, but also dusted off a warm-up, a trip to the office of the American League president by Albert Belle, the outfielder who is constantly either trying to fend off or appealing suspensions or fines.

title: FILM REVIEW;Of a Virgin And a Villa In Tuscany
description: On a hilltop outside Siena, a group of esthetes and dilettantes have gathered in languid splendor to while away summer days. Art, music, cuisine, bonhomie and nature are the cornerstones of their idyll, though pretentiousness also plays a major role. "Work -- the great tradition of art in these hills!" declares the resident sculptor, whose terra cotta figures haunt the lawn. "It's not my best play," says the writer in this group's midst, "but it's the one they'll remember me for."

title: NYC;Beating Cases May Be Solved But Fears Stay
description: AT the Central Park playground named for Diana Ross, the sighs of relief yesterday were almost strong enough to create a breeze along the benches where nannies sat in a row, interrupting their conversations now and then to pick up bottles that had been hurled from strollers.

title: On My Mind;Why Should We Care?
description: Americans have nothing to worry about if the Communists take over Russia again. Pepsi will still be in business there.

title: Casino That Floats
description: Donald J. Trump said today that he would spend $75 million to build a giant yacht, equip it with a casino and dock it at Trump's Castle Casino Resort here. The five-story, 430-foot yacht, which he said would be the world's biggest, would have 35,000 square feet of casino space and would be moored at the Senator Frank S. Farley State Marina, next to Trump's Castle.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;18 Fathers Lose Licenses
description: Eighteen fathers became the first in the state yesterday to feel the effects of a new law to punish them for falling behind in child-support payments. Their licenses were suspended by Judge Alvin Weiss of Superior Court in Essex County.

title: 25 and Under
description: Eyes can't help looking up on entering the Galaxy. Grand Central Terminal has its constellations, and the Galaxy has its stars, hundreds of twinkling bits of light glittering against a dark blue ceiling.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Plans to Revamp Japan Finance Ministry
description: Bank regulation and inspection should be removed from the Ministry of Finance's jurisdiction, Japan's ruling coalition parties said in an draft plan for the overhaul of the nation's most powerful ministry. The three-party legislative coalition said it planned to submit a reform bill in the regular parliamentary session next summer.

title: Le Mai, 56, Dies; Vietnam's Voice in Relations With the U.S.
description: Le Mai, Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister, who for many years was his country's voice in its edgy postwar relationship with the United States, died of a heart attack on Wednesday, the Foreign Ministry said today. He was 56.

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE;Remarks From the Mayor
description: Following are excerpts from the remarks of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani about the arrest of John J. Royster, a suspect in the Central Park attack last week and other crimes:
