description: She had spent the day at her job at a Manhattan computer company and joined friends for dinner before heading home to Yonkers.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: CONFIDENTIALITY;Justices Uphold Patient Privacy With Therapist
description: Finding that the confidentiality of psychotherapy serves important public as well as private interests, the Supreme Court ruled today that Federal courts must allow psychotherapists and other mental health professionals to refuse to disclose patient records in judicial proceedings.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;For a Growing Museum, Glittering New Galleries Can Be a Mixed Blessing
description: In 1970, on the occasion of its centennial, the Metropolitan Museum of Art began a vast expansion. The additions -- including the glass-enclosed wings for the Temple of Dendur, American, African and Oceanic art, and the Robert Lehman pavilion -- pushed the Met as far into Central Park as the city would allow. But few museums, and certainly not the Metropolitan, are content with what they have. One obvious reason: expansions and renovations attract patrons who, in return for their money, can have their names put on a new room or wing.

title: Corrections
description: The legend of a vintage chart with the Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Wednesday labeled one category incorrectly and omitted another. These are the correct categories: a) needs more bottle age; b) can be drunk now but should improve with time; c) ready now; d) approach with caution. A corrected chart appears today on page D19.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STOCK FALLS AFTER FMC SAYS EARNINGS WILL DROP
description: The shares of the FMC Corporation fell yesterday after the company said it expected its net income in the second quarter to be significantly below the $2.06 a share reported a year earlier. The shares fell $4.625, to $63.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. FMC, which is based in Chicago, attributed the lower earnings to higher costs for raw material and interest, as well as expenses related to expansion and other capital projects. The company, a provider of chemicals, military equipment and machinery, said it estimated that earnings would be $1.40 to $1.60 a share, compared with the average estimate of $2.17 by seven analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption yesterday about Senator Trent Lott's election as majority leader misidentified Susan Irby. She is his press secretary, not his secretary.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DARCI KISTLER, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, and PETER MARTINS, its ballet master in chief, became parents of a daughter yesterday. The baby has been named TALICIA TOVE MARTINS. The baby's first name combines those of her two grandmothers: Alicia Kistler and Tove Martins.

title: ART REVIEW;Early de Kooning Nudes: A Lesson in Overscale
description: The trio of giant women by Willem de Kooning at the Matthew Marks Gallery in Chelsea may be a tribute to the female anima, but they are also an essay on the folly of over scale. Each of the three massive bronze nudes -- "Standing Figure" (1969-84), "Reclining Figure" (1969-82) and "Seated Woman" (1969-80) -- is a flamboyant, strongly modeled effusion of breast-y, buttock-y bulges, hollows and thrusting limbs. As you walk around them the forms seem to shift and change, thanks to the turbulent surfaces and rich patina that attract a shimmering play of light in the tradition of Rodin and Bourdelle. Still, the viewer is conscious mainly of their overweening size.

title: Mortgage Rates Increase
description: Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.39 percent this week, the highest in more than a year, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The average was up from 8.30 percent last week and the highest since it was 8.41 percent during the week that ended on April 6, 1995. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.91 percent, up from 5.86 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.90 percent this week, up from 7.80 percent a week earlier.

title: Market Place;Wired, going public, is a real company, but makes no profit.
description: A LITTLE over three years ago, the publisher of a new magazine pegged to the hottest area in technology went public, offering 1.4 million shares at the modest price of $5. Today, Hypermedia Communications Inc., publisher of New Media magazine, trades in the $3 range. Rest assured no one on the roadshow for the initial public offering of Wired Ventures Inc. will remind investors of the Hypermedia story.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about conflicting signals in recent economic reports misstated the percentage of credit card holders who were behind in payments 30 days or more in the first quarter of the year. It was 3.53 percent, not 3.34 percent, according to the American Bankers Association.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany Leaves 2 Key Rates Unchanged
description: Germany's central bank left two key interest rates unchanged yesterday at its regular policy-setting meeting. The Bundesbank kept the discount rate at 2.5 percent and Lombard rate at 4.5 percent. The discount rate is the cheapest form of central bank refinancing; the Lombard rate is the rate at which banks borrow emergency overnight funds from the central bank.

description: Mighty Aphrodite 1995. Miramax. $100.72. Laser disk, $39.99. 95 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Run Into Resurgent Hershiser
description: It may not have been Turn Back the Clock Night at Yankee Stadium, but Orel Hershiser and Eddie Murray made it seem that way.

title: Two Arts Groups Agree to Merge
description: Two national arts groups, the National Assembly of Local Arts Agencies and the American Council for the Arts, have agreed to merge. The move, approved late Monday in a mail vote by members, is to take place on July 1.

title: Bonds Stage Sharp Rally On New Data
description: Bonds rallied sharply yesterday, for the first time in a week, following data that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation and prompt an immediate Fed response.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * William C. Lyddan was named president of Brouillard Communications, New York, a unit of the WPP Group, succeeding Stephen Cody, who resigned. Mr. Lyddan had been executive vice president and new business director at Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, owned by top management and the Interpublic Group of Cos. Also, James A. Gray 3d was named to the vacant position of president for public relations; he had been executive vice president and worldwide client services director at Manning, Selvage & Lee, Atlanta, a unit of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: Stopping By to Smell the Flowers
description: IN the rest of the world, spring arrives in a riot of color and a burst of warmth. Birds chirp and hearts gladden. In New York, the schedule is a little different. After winter slams down on the city like a frozen, cast-iron lid and imposes a color regime of gray and black, spring works a cruel hoax. It lingers just offstage in the seasonal drama and, with the audience primed for an appearance, it lingers some more.

title: Russia Far East Weighs New Era's Pros and Cons
description: Polina S. Novozhilova, a sinewy cement plant operator, remembers the glory days of working in this seaport: a 30 percent bonus for working in the Soviet Far East and guaranteed grocery supplies to ease life in a "closed city."

title: Santa Maria Atzompa Journal;Pots That Poison, and Potters Facing Broken Lives
description: Juan Juarez has been shaping clay pots and stoking kilns all his life, just like his wife, his brothers, his father and his father's father. He bristles at the suggestion that the family art may have damaged the family health.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WOOLWORTH HOLDERS REJECT SPINOFF OF SPORTS CHAINS
description: The shareholders of the Woolworth Corporation defeated a proposal yesterday to spin off the company's athletic-store division, which includes the Foot Locker and Champs stores. Woolworth said about 85 percent of the votes cast at its annual meeting were against the proposal, made by Greenway Partners L.P., a New York investment firm. The defeat was expected, as Woolworth management had urged shareholders to reject the plan, saying its current strategy to revive the company was working. Roger N. Farah, the chairman and chief executive, has said he plans to expand the company's successful businesses and to sell others.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Make Person Sweat Out Victory
description: Robert Person was on one knee, biting his fingernails in the Mets' clubhouse. He also might have been praying had he not been focused on the television screen overhead.

title: Senate Clears Way for Vote On Third Term For Greenspan
description: Senate leaders broke the logjam holding up the confirmation of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third term today, with Republicans agreeing to Democratic requests for an extended debate on monetary policy over several days before the confirmation vote next Thursday.

description: Father's Day Fishing Prospect Park Boathouse Ocean Avenue and Lincoln Road entrance Brooklyn (718) 287-3400 Recommended for all ages Sunday

title: No Headline

title: Farm Cooperative Indicted in Espy Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Sun-Diamond Growers of California on charges that the huge agricultural cooperative gave illegal gifts to Mike Espy while he was the Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Senate Passes G.O.P.'s Plan On '97 Budget
description: The Senate today followed the House in approving a $1.6 trillion Republican budget resolution, sounding the opening round in the 1997 budget fight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Film Company Expands Into Ads and Videos
description: Open City Films, a New York production company specializing in independent films, said yesterday that it would expand by opening Blow Up Pictures, a division to produce commercials and music video clips. Jonna Mattingly, 32, who has produced music videos for Seal and K. D. Lang and commercials for Elizabeth Arden and Pepe Jeans, was named to head Blow Up as partner and executive producer.

title: Iraq Bars U.N. Inspectors From 2 More Sites
description: Iraq barred United Nations inspectors today from entering two more bases suspected of holding banned weapons, a day after the Security Council passed a resolution demanding that the inspectors be given unconditional access to all such sites.

title: Baptists Move on Two Fronts In New Effort to Convert Jews
description: The Southern Baptist Convention today adopted a resolution calling for efforts to convert Jews to Christianity. And, for the first time in many decades, the denomination's domestic missionary agency has appointed a missionary to undertake such work.

title: Dallas Opening Southwest's First Rail Transit
description: After decades of feuds and false starts in an automobile-addicted state that remains the hub of the world's petroleum industry, Dallas plans to introduce the first modern rail transit line in the Southwest on Friday.

title: I. Donald Terner Memorial
description: A memorial service for I. Donald Terner, a developer of low-income housing in New York City and the San Francisco Bay area, will be held at 1 P.M. on Wednesday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Mr. Terner, 56, was a victim of the plane crash that killed the Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, and 34 others in Croatia on April 3.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DERRICK BELL, the former Harvard law professor who made a cause celebre of the law school's failure to hire a black woman for its tenured faculty, is hitting the road to talk about his new book.

title: Woman Gets 25 Years to Life In Death of 4-Year-Old Daughter
description: A woman convicted of killing her small daughter in a house where the children were routinely beaten was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of 25 years to life in prison.

description: How much misery can exploited workers endure before they rise up against their oppressors? And what are the spiritual and psychological forces that drive an individual to martyr himself for their cause?

title: CPC International to Settle Pricing Suit for $7 Million
description: CPC International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $7 million to settle a Federal lawsuit by customers who accused it of fixing prices on high-fructose corn syrup.

title: Pataki Seeks A Bill to Ease Ballot Access
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed legislation today that would sweep away most of the complex web of election rules that have made it extraordinarily difficult for candidates, from City Council members to Presidential contenders, to get on the ballot in New York.

title: Trade Group Will Decide Kodak Case
description: As expected, United States trade officials said today that they would file three complaints with the World Trade Organization contending that the Japanese Government had colluded with the Fuji Photo Film Company to exclude film made by the Eastman Kodak Company and other foreign producers.

title: North Korea May Still Hold P.O.W.'s, Inquiry Suggests
description: A Defense Department report has concluded that as many as 15 American soldiers taken prisoner during the Korean War are still alive in North Korea and that several may want to return to the United States.

title: Sports of The Times;Taking The Measure Of a Dream
description: HE placed his hands inches apart. "There's only this much space between Carl Lewis and me," Rod Tolbert said. "He's a normal person, he puts his pants on the same way I do, he has two arms, two legs, we breathe the same air. So what's the difference?"

title: New Deputy Commissioner
description: Deputy Police Inspector Edward Norris, the commander for old and unsolved cases, has been appointed as the New York Police Department's latest deputy commissioner for operations, the police said yesterday. Mr. Norris, 34, replaces Jack Maple, a protege of former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, as the department's top anti-crime strategist. Mr. Maple resigned in April, shortly after Mr. Bratton's resignation.

title: Journal;Down The Tube
description: Like flag-burning and same-sex marriage, television is a Heaven-sent punching bag for politicians. Every voter agrees that TV is responsible for our country's woes, and besides, what profit is there for any public figure in defending the medium that unleashed Jerry Springer? TV is in such bad repute that even its own titans now trash it. Ted Turner, speaking at Harvard Law School this month, said flatly that television "exploits children" and has an "overall negative effect on our society." Even the fact that he is selling his own TV empire to Time Warner did not prevent Mr. Turner from describing today's gargantuan media conglomerates, of which Time Warner is the second-largest, as "frightening."

title: Bridge
description: The winners of last week's Alcatel Worldwide Pairs were Wang Weidon and Hei Weidong of Beijing, with a score of 81.37 percent, the World Bridge Federation said yesterday. The top North American pair, Richard Bender and Patrick McCammon of Springfield, Mo., were sixth worldwide with 78.58 percent.

title: Clinton Wavers After Backing Welfare Plan
description: Four weeks after President Clinton endorsed Wisconsin's radical proposal to abolish welfare, citing it as an example of the "quiet revolution" in social policy occurring across America, Administration officials say they now have doubts and concerns about some of its most important provisions.

title: Excerpts of F.B.I. Report on Files
description: Following are excerpts from a report released today by the general counsel of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which conducted an inquiry into the bureau's providing files on more than 400 people to the White House at its request, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company. The excerpts are followed by the text of a statement by Jack Quinn, counsel to the President.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REGIONS FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE ALLIED BANKSHARES
description: The Regions Financial Corporation, a banking company based in Birmingham, Ala., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Allied Bankshares Inc. in a $136.3 million stock swap. Regions will offer 0.226 share of its common stock for each Allied share, or a total of about 2.9 million shares, in a tax-free pooling of interests. The acquisition, including four others that are pending, would raise Regions' total assets to about $18.8 billion, with $4.6 billion in Georgia. Regions operates 355 banking offices and has assets of $562 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PLANS SET TO CUT CASH DIVIDEND AS MUCH AS 71%
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company plans to slash its annual cash dividend as much as 71 percent as part of its plan to become a fast-growing managed health care company. The dividend reduction, which has been expected by analysts, will occur after the Hartford-based insurer completes its planned $8.9 billion acquisition of U.S. Healthcare Inc. In a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Aetna said it initially expected to pay an annualized dividend of about 80 cents to 83 cents, down from its current $2.76 a share.

description: In a finding that is likely to result in the largest land claim in the country's history, an official report released today says virtually an entire province was illegally taken from Maori tribes during the last century.

title: White House Supports Payment To 281 Vietnamese Commandos
description: The White House said today that it would support legislation to give $11 million in back pay to 281 Vietnamese who served as secret agents for the United States during the Vietnam war and were later written off as dead.

title: Tolerance? Civility? Read the Platform
description: There has been heated debate about Bob Dole's suggestion that the Republican Party platform express "tolerance" and "civility" toward those who favor abortion rights. But what is to debate?

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Rebounds on Bond Rally After Falling in Earlier Trading
description: The dollar rebounded from early declines yesterday as bond prices rallied after economic reports in the United States eased some concerns on inflation.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IN FOCUS SYSTEMS STOCK OFF ON COMPETITION WORRY
description: Shares of In Focus Systems Inc. fell 33 percent on worry that the company faces competition from Sony Electronics for equipment that lets users display computer-generated information on overhead projectors. On Thursday Sony said its new line of projection-display equipment would be available in August. New projection products were also introduced at the Infocomm trade show in Philadelphia by Panasonic, Sanyo and Sharp. In Focus fell $16.0625, to $31.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Pediatrician's License Is Suspended After Charges Of Molesting ThreeTeen-Age Boys
description: A prominent Westchester County pediatrician accused of molesting three teen-age male patients has had his medical license suspended pending a hearing on June 21. In suspending the license, the State Department of Health said that the doctor represented "an imminent danger to public health."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Red Light for Laser Guns
description: Laser guns used by state troopers to catch speeders aren't accurate enough to be used as evidence in court, a Superior Court judge, Reginald Stanton, ruled on Thursday. The state police began using the lasers, which they say are more accurate and more difficult for motorists to detect than traditional radar guns, along Routes 80 and 287 in Rockaway and Parsippany last August. They have written nearly 2,000 tickets based on laser readings, 30 of which have been challenged. Trooper Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the state police, said the ruling effectively bars troopers from using the guns.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Stock Prices Set On Asiasat Offering
description: Asia Satellite Telecommunications Holdings Ltd. has set the issue prices of its initial public offering at $20 (Hong Kong) a share and $25.832 for an American depository receipt (representing 10 shares), an official of Goldman, Sachs said yesterday. Asiasat has offered 105.3 million, or 27 percent, of its shares. Ninety percent will be listed as A.D.R.'s in New York and 10 percent in Hong Kong.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Irvin Is Indicted Again
description: Two days after charges against them were thrown out on a technicality, Cowboys wide receiver Michael Irvin and two topless dancers were indicted again today on drug possession charges.

title: State Commissioner Says He Won't Shut 13 Schools
description: Eight months after threatening to shut down 13 chronically failing New York City public schools, the State Education Commissioner said today that he would take no immediate action because some of the schools had improved and because Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew had submitted acceptable plans to reorganize the others.

title: Where Serbs Loosed Terror, Moderates, Too, Live in Fear
description: At 9:30 this morning, just as the American Ambassador to Bosnia was setting out on a five-hour round trip to this Bosnian Serb town for the sole purpose of meeting him, Rade Pavlovic told his secretary that he had been called to Serbia on an emergency and would return next week.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAR MAKER CUTTING STAKE IN PHARMACIA & UPJOHN
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish car company, will sell 46 million shares of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. as it cuts its ownership stake in Pharmacia to 4.7 percent from 13.7 percent. Pharmacia, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to register the shares for sale. Volvo said previously that it intended to cut its stake in the drug company. Volvo will continue to hold 23.77 million shares, or 4.7 percent of the company's outstanding 510 million shares, after the sale.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Priest Must Face Lawsuit
description: A state appeals court took the rare step yesterday of reinstating a suit for "clergy malpractice" filed against a former Episcopal priest from Bergenfield. The suit was filed by a woman who claimed the Rev. Alex MacDonell of All Saints Episcopal Church induced her to engage in sex after she sought counseling for emotional problems in 1992. Clergy malpractice suits have been rejected by many Federal and state courts on First Amendment grounds. Mr. MacDonell was suspended by the Episcopal Diocese in Newark over the incident in 1993 and has since retired. His lawyer, Gregory D. Winter, said he would appeal.

title: Scientists Optimistic on Use Of New Therapies for AIDS
description: Researchers are expressing continued cautious optimism that new, multi-drug therapies may prolong the lives of people infected with H.I.V.

title: Political Memo;A Watchdog Helps Protect Pataki's Flank
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki announced legislation on Thursday to overhaul the state's much-criticized election law, he stood next to an unlikely supporter, a Ralph Naderite who is not exactly a member of the Republican ruling class.

title: Young, Eager and Training for the World of Politics
description: After several shallow relationships, the Democratic Congressional candidate married his true love in a hot-air balloon.

title: SUMITOMO'S HUGE LOSS: THE MARKET;In London, Traders Sense A Real Need for Change
description: The London Metal Exchange held an emergency board meeting today and said it would revive a committee to investigate the copper market, following the disclosure that the Sumitomo Corporation had compiled $1.8 billion in losses of unauthorized copper trades.

title: POP REVIEW;Easy Rhythms, Calm Chords, And Songs Hiding in Sounds
description: The Cocteau Twins make music to bask in. Edgeless guitar chords unfurl and billow above stately, imperturbable vamps; Elizabeth Fraser's seraphic soprano floats serenely, with her words mostly lost in the reverberating chords. Even feedback and noise arrive swathed in echo, tempered by the mix.

title: Lawyer Had No Regrets In Pentagon Papers Case
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE MAYOR;For Giuliani, a Day of Police Praise and Policy Vindication
description: Taking quickly to the airwaves after the arrest of a suspect in four prominent violent crimes, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday let New York City know how proud he was of his Police Department and of his own law enforcement strategy.

title: Drilling Rig Count Is Down
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide dropped by 8 this week, to 773, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Tell What Can Be Done About Family Court
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Silver, Gold and Oil Post Gains; Wheat and Copper Prices Fall
description: Silver and gold prices settled sharply higher in New York trading yesterday after an early tumble that was prompted by concerns over the Sumitomo Corporation's huge losses in the copper market.

title: Copper Shares Take a Tumble
description: Shares of copper mining companies fell yesterday in reaction to a plunge in copper prices, after the disclosure by the Sumitomo Corporation that its chief copper trader chief had concealed as much as $1.8 billion in losses.

title: Cut Taxes? Not Before Taming the Interest Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Point in Siege: Freemen's Awareness That Allies Had TurnedAway
description: A month ago, the Government's efforts to settle the standoff with a group of Montana ranch dwellers peacefully seemed hopeless. The siege had dragged into its second month, the Freemen were adamantly refusing to surrender and dozens of mediators had come and gone empty-handed.

title: Why Contract Expired
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Briefs
description: JETFORM INC., Ottawa, said it would buy back Moore Corp.'s option to purchase a controlling stake in the company in a transaction valued at $33.75 million. The software company will issue about 1.8 million common shares to Moore, valued at $18.75 each, in exchange for Moore's option to buy 7.7 million JetForm shares by 1999.

title: 3d Man Held in Plot to Use Radium to Kill L.I. Officials
description: A plot to kill Suffolk County Republican officials by exposing them to radioactive material widened today with the seizure of more radium that may have been stolen from the military contractor Northrop Grumman and with the arrest of a third suspect, a Government electrical inspector at Grumman since 1973.

title: Burmese Repression
description: The Burmese military junta has outdone itself in advertising its own crude ineptitude. Frustrated by the popularity and prestige of their democratic opponent, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the generals have now erected huge red billboards denouncing the 1991 Nobel Peace laureate as a foreign stooge. But every Burmese knows that Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi endured years of house arrest rather than leave the country her father helped free from foreign rule. The real threat to the Burmese people is the junta, formally known as the State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc.

title: Freemen Were Alone
description: A month ago, the Government's effort to settle a standoff with extremists in Montana seemed hopeless until leaders of the far right abandoned the group. Article, page 10.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;In Pizzicati and Piping, a Reign of Strings
description: The New Music Consort almost had to resort to Morton Subotnick's "ghost" electronics, or something similar, for the final work in its "String Extravaganza" on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. By then, almost every imaginable unamplified sound had been coaxed or wrung out of the string instruments.

title: Theodora Ayer Randolph, Fox Hunting's First Lady, Dies at 90
description: Theodora Ayer Randolph, who rode the Virginia hunt country long enough and well enough to become known as the first lady of fox hunting, died on Tuesday at her Oakley Farm home in Upperville, Va. She was 90.

title: BASEBALL;Fans Throw Objects at Belle in Field
description: Albert Belle picked up a few souvenirs last night when he visited Yankee Stadium, but not the way most out-of-towners do.

title: SUMITOMO'S HUGE LOSS;In 1991, Agencies Were Told Of Letter on Sumitomo Trader
description: On Dec. 6, 1991, The Wall Street Journal reported in its commodities roundup that regulatory officials had been informed of allegations regarding the trading practices of Yasuo Hamanaka, the Sumitomo Corporation's chief copper trader. Following is an excerpt from that report:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Law Near to Require Children's Programming A rule calling for television stations to broadcast three hours a week of educational programs for children became a virtual certainty as James Quello, one of the Federal Communications Commission members who had been blocking the legislation, said he would drop his opposition. Mr. Quello agreed to a compromise under which an absolute minimum of three hours might not be required, if stations could demonstrate that they had performed a public service for children that was roughly equivalent. [11.] Industrial Production Rises Again Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, a bigger increase than analysts had expected. The jump in production was the second straight, and businesses also showed signs of rebuilding depleted inventories, a move that could mean even greater output and more jobs. [Page 33.]

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Most of These Guys Are Lawyers, Right?
description: Just how much Government time and expense went into drafting, debating and passing the Communications Decency Act, which was declared unconstitutional by a Federal district court last week?

title: Peter E. Obletz Memorial
description: A memorial service for Peter E. Obletz, a former chairman of Community Board 4 in Manhattan and a railroad buff who once made his home aboard two dining cars behind Pennsylvania Station, will be at noon next Saturday on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal. Mr. Obletz, 50, died of cancer on April 23.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Striving for Quietude In the Hubbub of a Club Bill Frisell, guitarist Iridium

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BPB of Britain to Buy Chilean Company Stake
description: BPB Industries has reached agreement with the Matte Group of Brazil to buy a stake in Volcan S.A., a Chilean gypsum company half owned by Matte. BPB, a British building materials, paper and packaging company, will pay about $58 million for 21.3 to 25.2 percent of Volcan, most of it to Matte.

title: Inquiry Finds Astra Sex Harassment Persists
description: Federal officials investigating charges of widespread sexual harassment at Astra USA said today that sexual abuse and retribution against supervisors who allowed employees to complain about it were continuing at the company, a maker of pharmaceuticals.

title: Reorganization By Chip Maker
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation has reorganized into four business units as the chip manufacturer struggles with declining profit and sales.

title: A Sumitomo Loss Felt Round the World;Principles Fall Victim To Practice
description: The business principles of the Sumitomo Corporation, framed and hung on the wall in many of the giant trading company's far-flung outposts, warn against speculation. "Under no circumstances," they state, should the company "pursue easy gains or act imprudently."

title: Syrian's Game: Both Ends Against the Middle
description: For five hours on April 22, Secretary of State Warren Christopher held intense discussions with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria at his presidential palace in Damascus to end the fighting between Israel and Muslim guerrillas in southern Lebanon.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN RICE TO ADD BUSINESSES OF SOUP MAKER
description: American Rice Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Campbell Soup Company's ripe and green olive businesses, including the Durkee and Early California trademarks. Financial terms were not disclosed. After news of the deal, American Rice stock jumped $1.25, or 76 percent, to $2.875, in Nasdaq trading. Campbell's stock fell $1.125, to $62.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. American Rice, of Houston, said the operations had annual sales of about $100 million. Included in the purchase are olive-processing and canning plants in Visalia, Calif., and Seville, Spain, as well as olive inventories.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Auditors of Gemina Balk on 1995 Results
description: Auditors said yesterday that they had refused to approve the 1995 operating results of Gemina S.p.A., an Italian holding company, citing a lack of information on Gemina's defunct capital markets group. Gemina's auditors declined to sign off on the accounts until management provided information from its subsidiaries and computed the value of Gemina Capital Markets.

title: Doles Report as Much as $7.7 Million in Assets, Most Mrs. Dole's
description: Bob and Elizabeth Dole have assets worth $2.3 million to $7.7 million, most of which belong to Mrs. Dole, according to a financial report released today by the Senate.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;NatWest Sells Stake In an Investment Group
description: The NatWest Group, Britain's largest commercial bank, said today that it had sold its 17.7 percent stake in the 3i Group, an investment company, for L464 million ($712 million). Natwest said last week that it would sell its 104.3 million shares of 3i, Britain's largest investor in private companies, but did not give a price.

title: DNA Tests and a Confession Set Three on the Path to Freedom in 1978Murders
description: Early in the morning of May 11, 1978, two sweethearts engaged to be married were abducted at gunpoint from a suburban gas station near here and driven into the darkness to die.

title: G.O.P. Makes an Issue of Replacing U.N. Chief
description: Taking advantage of the Clinton Administration's indecision over whether to support Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a second term as Secretary General, Congressional Republicans want to force the debate into the open and thus into the Presidential political campaign, where Bob Dole has already made bashing the United Nations a popular sport.

title: Serial Killer's Possessions to Be Destroyed
description: Items that belonged to the serial killer Jeffrey L. Dahmer are to be destroyed this month under an agreement reached between a civic group and families of some of his victims, a lawyer involved in the case said this week.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Ignores the Distractions to Get a Victory
description: There was so much going on around Dwight Gooden last night at Yankee Stadium that it would be easy to lose sight of his unflinching performance against the most ferocious lineup in all of baseball.

title: Credit Scenic Hudson for River's Revival
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Healthcare Chief Will Get $1 Billion
description: U.S. Healthcare's merger with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company will mean big bonuses for top U.S. Healthcare executives, especially the chairman, Leonard Abramson, who will get about $1 billion.

title: Protesters Dispute Police Version of a Shooting
description: A day after police officers shot and killed an unarmed man in a stolen car in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, prompting a night of anger and demonstrations, dozens of residents protested again yesterday, disputing the police account of the shooting and calling for an independent investigation.

title: Tell What Can Be Done About Family Court
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Engen of South Africa Selling Stake to Malaysia
description: The South African oil company Engen Ltd. announced yesterday that it would sell a 30 percent stake to Petronas, the state-owned oil company of Malaysia, for 1.88 billion rand ($436 million). Engen also plans to raise 605 million rand, or $140 million, through a rights offering to shareholders. It will use the fresh capital for debt repayment and future developments, it said.

title: Freemen in Court, but Not Without a Struggle
description: They denied their own names. They refused to let any court-appointed "bar association" lawyer defend them. They proclaimed the Bible their only law, stared at the judge as if he came from another planet and objected to the very fact of their arrests.

title: BASEBALL;Board Rejects Plan To Finance Stadium
description: The Milwaukee Brewers stadium board today rejected a new financing plan, leaving in doubt the future of the team's proposed $250 million retractable-roof ball park. The vote threatens the future of professional baseball in Wisconsin because the team has said it cannot survive without a modern stadium.

title: DANCE REVIEW;With a Cajun Band, Three Centuries of Struggles Overcome
description: Elisa Monte and David Brown have taken an imaginative and loving look at the history and culture of the Cajun people in "Feu Follet," a new piece presented by Elisa Monte Dance on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall. The 45-minute dance, set to traditional music and an original score by Richard Peaslee, sends its seven dancers through about three centuries of struggles and triumphs in three countries, traveling from France to Canada and on to the American South. The story and its telling are stylized with remarkable success.

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE OVERVIEW;Police Say Ploy Cleared a Path To Confession
description: Detectives said yesterday that they persuaded John J. Royster to confess early Thursday to the murder of a woman on Park Avenue and the near-fatal beating of another woman in Central Park by playing on his love of Asian martial arts and philosophy, and by bluffing about evidence they did not have.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Bulls Can't Win as a One-Man Show
description: Phil Jackson was asked if he could describe what the Seattle SuperSonics had done so well on defense against Michael Jordan in the fourth quarter tonight. "No," the Bulls coach replied, abruptly leaving the interview room.

title: About New York;A Kind Face, But Her Fists Are Fierce
description: MARTIN SNOW knew that Patricia Alcivar was different when the slender, raven-haired woman took his breath away. Actually, she knocked the wind out of him with a shot to the gut.

title: The State Senate's Flawed Health Plan
description: The New York State Senate passed a bill this week to deregulate hospital rates. Although the goal is sound, the bill would provide too little money to treat the poor and train medical residents. It thus threatens to cripple hospitals in New York City.

title: White Man Arrested in Arson at a Church
description: A 35-year-old white man was arrested tonight in connection with the latest in a string of fires that have damaged or destroyed black churches.

title: Aye, Aye' Can't Be Column A-Column B
description: To the Editor:

title: King World Said to Be in Talks Over Acquisition by New World
description: Like a long-running soap opera, the question of the future ownership of King World Productions continued yesterday with reports that it was discussing a sale to New World Communications for $1.5 billion.

title: Croat Journalists on Trial
description: Two independent journalists went on trial today accused of defaming President Franjo Tudjman in a case that has helped sour Croatia's relations with Western Europe.

title: Democracy Demeaned
description: One hundred years after the Supreme Court's decision in Plessy v. Ferguson set back the cause of racial justice by approving the doctrine of "separate but equal," a majority of current Court members have demonstrated a perverse determination to resegregate the nation's politics. A century from now, fair-minded Americans are bound to view the Court's evisceration of the Voting Rights Act this week with regret and even shame.

title: No Flames, No Guns in Montana
description: Without firing a shot or using force against the paranoid Freemen in their bleak Montana retreat, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has taken all 16 remaining fugitives and malcontents back to civil life, most of them into custody. The operation required 81 days of patient persuasion at a cost of roughly $75,000 a day that the outlaws had no business imposing on society. But the peaceable conclusion was worth the time and money.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Die in Plane Crash
description: A flight instructor and two students were killed when their Beech Bonanza crashed into the woods near a driving range Thursday evening, shortly after taking off from Cross Keys Airport half a mile away. Officials would not release the names of the victims yesterday but said all were male and one was a teen-ager. The cause of the crash has not been determined. ANDY NEWMAN

title: James S. Coles, 83, Ex-Head of Bowdoin College
description: James Stacy Coles, a former president of Bowdoin College who went on to lead the Research Corporation, a private foundation for the advancement of science and technology, died on Thursday at the J. M. L. Care Center in Falmouth, Mass. He was 83 and lived in Quissett, Mass., and in Manhattan.

title: Bringing Goat to the Table;New York Farmers Try to Widen the Market for Kid, an Immigrant Favorite
description: The land slopes at every turn in this pristine pocket of northern Otsego County. At times here, where an acre or more often separates neighbors, all that can be heard is the whisper of the pines or the low-pitched wail of a Holstein. It appears that little would link this quiet corner to the hurly-burly of immigrant hubs like Jackson Heights and Elmhurst in Queens, or Atlantic Avenue in downtown Brooklyn.

title: A 7th Attack Is Traced to 'Elevator Rapist'
description: The man known to the police as the Queens "elevator rapist" is believed to have struck for the seventh time on Tuesday, attacking a 19-year-old woman while she was with her baby girl, police officials said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Isringhausen and Mets Get Clobbered by Cards
description: Jason Isringhausen was hoping for a wonderful homecoming tonight, the kind the St. Louis native Robert Person had Thursday night when he pitched seven scoreless innings in a Mets victory.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Carlsberg of Denmark Says Profit Rose 22%
description: The Danish brewer Carlsberg announced yesterday a 22 percent gain in earnings in the six months ended March 31 but warned that its full-year earnings would be about even. The company said it had pretax profits of 741 million Danish kroner ($125.3 million), up from 607 million kroner in the first half of the previous fiscal year.

title: Observer;Taking The Saps
description: There are many explanations for why America is highballing down the low road to Doomsday. One of my favorites is government-sponsored gambling. Any people who let their own government sucker them into throwing their money away on games with prohibitively high odds haven't the wit needed to save great nations from doom.

title: Ballot-Access Bill Passed by Senate, With a Crucial Provision Removed
description: A day after Gov. George E. Pataki proposed far-reaching legislation to make it easier for candidates to get on the ballot, the Governor agreed today with the Republican leaders of the State Senate to weaken the bill by striking an important provision from it.

title: Man Accused in a Fraud for U.S. Benefits
description: A former air traffic controller was accused yesterday of defrauding the Federal Government of over $830,000 in Workers' Compensation benefits for back injuries since 1973, after he was seen loading 90-pound shelving units at his Long Island business.

title: U.S. Industrial Production and Business Inventories Rise
description: American industries increased production for a second consecutive month in May and businesses showed signs of rebuilding depleted inventories, a move that could mean even greater output and more jobs.

title: U.S. OPEN;Stewart Leads, But Norman Steals Show
description: When last seen in a major championship, Greg Norman was reeling, spinning toward the bottom like a shark that had just taken a bang stick to the head, squandering a six-stroke lead in the final round of the Masters.

title: Texaco Faulted Over Promotions
description: An official of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has found that Texaco Inc. failed to promote blacks in certain employee groups because of their race.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Flamenco's Varied Emotions
description: Many moods of flamenco were emphasized in "Flamenco Vivo," the program that the Carlota Santana Spanish Dance Company presented on Thursday night at the Clark Studio Theater. The first half of the evening featured short dances, some with choreography by La Repompa de Malaga and Joaquin Ruiz; others were based on choreography by Antonio Reyes and Miguel Canas. "Amanecer (Tangos)," an evocation of dawn in Seville, suggested that the sun rose in that Spanish city to the clapping of hands and the stamping of feet. Nelida Tirado's incessantly drumming feet in "Solea por Bulerias" made dancing seem an obsession.

title: Court Choice Faces Conflicts in Cases She Was Involved In
description: The woman nominated to become the next chief justice of New Jersey's Supreme Court, Deborah T. Poritz, could quickly leave her imprint on some long-lingering issues that have dominated political life in this state.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Finnair Says Profits Increased 27% in Year
description: Finland's national airline, Finnair, reported yesterday that its profit jumped by more than 27 percent in the year ended March 31. Finnair earned 533 million markkaa, or $113 million, in the latest year, compared with 419 million markaa a year earlier. Revenues were 7.18 billion markkaa, up from 6.65 billion. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Immigrant Jail to Reopen
description: The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that it would reopen its detention center in Elizabeth, which closed a year ago after inmates rioted. A spokesman for the agency, Tony Papazzo, said the Corrections Corporation of America, a private company based in Nashville, would reopen the center in September. The jail's previous operator, the Esmor Correctional Services Corporation of Melville, L.I., was faulted by the I.N.S. for inhumane conditions that led to the riot.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: G.M.'s Rocky Labor Ties: Do Rivals Have It Easier?
description: The Ford Motor Company has not suffered a strike in a decade, while the General Motors Corporation has endured eight strikes in the last three years, including a 17-day walkout in March that cost the company $900 million in after-tax profits.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CITYSCAPE FINANCIAL GETS HERITABLE FINANCE GROUP
description: The Cityscape Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had bought Heritable Finance Group, a British mortgage company, for about $66 million. The transaction was mostly in cash, with less than 5 percent in stock. Cityscape, a mortgage banking based in Elmsford, N.Y., said it would operate Heritable as part of its British subsidiary, the City Mortgage Corporation Ltd. Heritable was a subsidiary of Heritable Group P.L.C., which is 50.1 percent owned by the Philadelphia-based Corestates Financial Corporation. Cityscape's shares jumped $4.375, to $50, in Nasdaq trading. Heritable, based in Reading, England, had a loan portfolio of L130 million ($199 million) at the end of March.

title: No Headline
description: Death row does something to your emotions. When I left death row, I felt like I was leaving a mortuary with a bunch of bodies waiting to be dressed."

title: COMPANY NEWS;FALCON HOLDING GROUP TO PURCHASE PARTNERSHIP
description: Falcon Holding Group L.P. agreed yesterday to buy Falcon Cable Systems Co., a cable operating partnership in which Falcon Holding holds a minority state, for about $247.4 million. The privately held cable operator will make the purchase through an affiliate. Falcon Cable's partnership agreement provides for a distribution of all of its assets if the partnership is sold. Falcon Holding said the amount of the distribution would be set after the deal and the assets were appraised. The company said based on an appraisal at March 31, the distribution would be $9.17 a partnership unit based on 6.4 million units outstanding. On the American Stock Exchange, Falcon Cable units were down 37.5 cents at $9 each. Falcon Cable owns cable systems in California and western Oregon.

title: Wekiva Springs Leads Field
description: The Brooklyn Handicap will be run at Belmont Park today for the 109th time, but it will be without two star horses who are nursing foot injuries and without home simulcasting on cable television.

title: U.K. Probes Huge Losses By Japan Copper Trader
description: LONDON  Britain's Serious Fraud Office announced Friday that it had opened an investigation into $1.8 billion in losses that the Sumitomo Corp. said it had suffered as a result of unauthorized trades by its chief copper trader in Tokyo.

title: Bankruptcy Filing in Case of an Israeli Bank
description: An investor in a failed Israeli bank filed for personal bankruptcy in United States Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles yesterday, listing more than $212 million in debts, much of it claimed by Israel.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JOSTENS SHARES DROP AFTER LOWER INCOME ESTIMATE
description: The shares of Jostens Inc. fell yesterday after the company said its fourth-quarter earnings would be less than analysts estimated, in part because of higher costs for publishing school yearbooks. The company, a provider of class rings, yearbooks and achievement awards, said it expected earnings for the quarter ending on June 30 of 74 cents to 79 cents a share, compared with profit from continuing operations of 67 cents a year ago. The company was expected to earn 80 cents a share, the average estimate of three analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.

title: SUMITOMO'S HUGE LOSS: THE TRADER;Global Copper Superstar Or 'Ordinary Salaryman'?
description: With his aggressive trading style and the huge volumes he handled, Yasuo Hama naka was a commanding presence in the world copper market. The chief copper trader for the Sumitomo Corporation was dubbed "Mr. 5 Percent," in tribute to the scope of his trades, which were estimated to amount to roughly that fraction of the world's copper demand.

title: Cut Taxes? Not Before Taming the Interest Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Plan Take: $350 Million
description: The state collected $350 million in its tax amnesty program, more than four times the amount originally anticipated, officials said yesterday. State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer said that the program, which allowed individuals and businesses owing back taxes to pay without penalty between March 15 and June 1, brought in $45.30 per resident, making it the most successful amnesty ever run by any state. The money will be put toward a $300 million hole in the state budget caused by shortfalls in sales and business taxes.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Seattle's Domain Is Still Standing
description: They have lived to trash-talk about it.

title: World News Briefs;House Gets Sanctions Bill Aimed at Libya and Iran
description: A bill that would impose penalties against foreign companies that invest in the oil industry of Iran or Libya was sent today to the House of Representatives.

title: REQUEST FOR FILES 'VICTIMIZED' F.B.I., ITS DIRECTOR SAYS
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that he and the bureau had been "victimized" by improper requests from the Clinton White House for files on more than 400 people, most of them employees of prior Republican administrations.

title: Official Resigns At Grace Unit
description: W. R. Grace & Company said today that Constantine L. Hampers had resigned as chairman, president and chief executive of its National Medical Care unit.

title: Factions in the Balkans Sign An Accord to Limit Weapons
description: Taking one of the most important steps to carry out the beleaguered Balkan peace accord, Bosnian Serbs, Croats and Muslims, as well as the Governments of Croatia and Yugoslavia, signed a sweeping arms control agreement today that sets limits on the types and number of weapons each of the former warring factions can possess.

title: Corrections
description: The headline and introduction yesterday with excerpts from the Supreme Court decision on Congressional districts in Texas and North Carolina misstated the number of districts affected by the ruling in some editions. The boundaries of four districts, not three, were invalidated because the Court said they had been unconstitutionally drawn using racial gerrymandering. A map caption with an article about the ruling repeated the error in some editions.

title: Italy's Secession Urge Has Teutonic Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: North Carolina in Turmoil Over Redistricting Ruling
description: A political tornado touched down in North Carolina on Thursday, leaving members of Congress homeless, littering the landscape with redistricting maps and blowing the 1996 campaign year into a chaotic mess.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about two groups of scientists who say they have discovered the gene believed to cause the most common form of cancer, basal-cell carcinoma, was omitted from some copies. Readers wishing copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: Ford Unit to Auction Nearly $1 Billion in Municipal Bonds
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that its USL Capital subsidiary would auction almost $1 billion in municipal bonds as part of Ford's plan to shed its nonautomotive finance operations.

title: VW Allows G.M. Lawsuit To Advance
description: Volkswagen A.G., the German auto maker, agreed today to receive a United States civil complaint filed by the General Motors Corporation, which has accused VW of industrial espionage and is seeking punitive damages.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Blades Found Guilty
description: Seattle Seahawks wide receiver Brian Blades was found guilty of manslaughter today in the shooting death of his cousin and faces up to nine and a half years in prison.

title: Kamsky Accepts Draw Despite Strong Position
description: Was Gata Kamsky too generous in accepting a draw with Anatoly Karpov yesterday in Game 5 of their world championship match? Deep Blue, I.B.M.'s super chess computer, thought so after analyzing the play.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the sentencing of Sheraine Bryant for killing her 4-year-old daughter misattributed remarks about Ms. Bryant's reaction to photographs of her dead child. It was Justice Joseph Fisch of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, not Alvin Yearwood, an assistant district attorney, who said:

title: WITH VOTING NEAR, YELTSIN PROMOTES FIVE TOP GENERALS
description: With his presidency at stake in elections on Sunday, Boris N. Yeltsin took a dramatic and unabashedly political step to insure the support of Russia's top military chiefs.

title: Don't Know Much About History
description: Though I vowed, on graduation from high school in 1969, that I was leaving the suburbs forever, I now live in a town that is just 20 minutes from the one I grew up in. For all its problems and faults, suburbia offered me a superior public education, and I wanted my sons to have one, too.

title: U.S. OPEN;Trapped in a Slump On the Sloping Greens
description: He shot an 82 today in the United States Open at Oakland Hills after an 83 in the opening round. With a 36-hole total of 165, which was 25 over par, he wasn't even close to making the cut for the final two rounds.

title: Youthful Enthusiasm And Bitter Experience
description: It is a tale often told in the Clinton White House: a young, enthusiastic, inexperienced campaign aide, his ambitions of working in the West Wing fulfilled, finds himself under scrutiny by hostile Congressional investigators and facing a date with a Federal grand jury.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Guilty in Car Thefts
description: A Newark police sergeant faces up to 20 years in jail after his conviction yesterday by Superior Court Judge R. Benjamin Cohen for stealing four cars worth more than $100,000. The sergeant, John Montella, stole a Porsche that the police seized in a 1990 raid on a chop shop in Newark and three cars from the parking lot of an automobile importing firm, prosecutors said. Mr. Montella, who was also found guilty of misconduct and witness tampering in the nonjury trial, is still working in the communications division of the Police Department, said his lawyer, Anthony J. Pope. He plans to appeal the convictions.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;It's Back to Chicago: SuperSonics Force a Game 6
description: The Seattle SuperSonics and the National Basketball Association finals are both headed back to Chicago.

title: How Copper Lost Its Luster for Sumitomo;Five Years Ago, An Allegation Of False Trades
description: British regulators were aware five years ago of an allegation that a Japanese trader who has since been accused of losing $1.8 billion trading copper for the Sumitomo Corporation tried to create fictitious transactions.

description: To the Editor:

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE SUSPECT;Beating Suspect's Confession Eerily Echoes a Father's Life
description: The parallels are haunting. John P. Royster, the father, and John J. Royster, the son. Both smart, both drifters, both spurned by a woman -- both accused murderers.

title: World News Briefs;Mexico Court Rules Debt Can Be Paid by Paintings
description: They may not be pretty, these 19 canvasses spattered with contemptuous descriptions of a wealthy Mexican art dealer. But they are art nonetheless and the dealer must accept them in payment of a debt.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rutgers Bills Go Up
description: Starting in September, Rutgers University students will pay about $200 more each year to sleep and eat. Rates for room and board will rise to $5,134 from $4,936, an increase of 4 percent, school officials said yesterday. The university's board of governors has put off a decision on whether to increase instructional fees until later this month, when the school will learn its appropriation in the state budget.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Calipari Seeks 'Shark' for Nets
description: Intense coach, zealous motivator, expert groomer. About the only thing John Calipari is missing for his new role as National Basketball Association coach is experience, a blank that he may fill in by naming a general manager in the next few days. One leading candidate appears to be the former Bullets general manager John Nash, who spoke to Calipari on Thursday. Nash, a league insider for more than 15 years, seems to fit the criteria Calipari put forth in a teleconference yesterday, a week after signing a five-year, $15 million deal to save the Nets.

title: Shift on Children's TV Programs Will Lead to 3-Hour Minimum
description: A new Federal Communications Commission rule that would require television stations to broadcast three hours a week of educational programs for children became a virtual certainty yesterday, when James Quello, one of the commissioners blocking the regulation, said he would drop his opposition.

title: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE VICTIMS;One Who Was Beaten Speaks of Her Relief
description: For just one victim, yesterday brought relief.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD MOVES TO LIFT SHARE VALUE
description: Frederick's of Hollywood Inc. said yesterday that it would consider a variety of options for increasing the Value of its shares, including the sale of the lingerie retailer. Frederick's said it had retained the investment banking firm Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. to advise it on enhancing shareholder value. Class A shares of the Los Angeles-based retailer have fallen 31 percent in the last 12 months as earnings have suffered. The company's shares traded most recently on Thursday at $4.125. The Mellinger family trusts, which control about 50.2 percent of the common shares, "have liquidity problems which they can only solve by selling stock, which may or may not involve selling the company," said John Hatfield, Frederick's chief financial and administrative officer.

title: OLYMPICS;Joyner-Kersee Is Leading While Battling Ailments
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee is likely to win the heptathlon at the United States track and field trials. Her chances for a third gold medal in the Olympics are far more uncertain. At 34, she can get through the seven events, but she can no longer get through them healthy.

title: Harmony Rules a Country Music Fair
description: Lenny Wallace looked every inch the country star: tight jeans, sharp-toed boots, striped western shirt, white cowboy hat. For many of the 24,000 fans gathered here for a carnival of country music, autographs and barbecue, that was enough.

title: Beliefs
description: When the National Conference of Catholic Bishops meets next week in a hotel outside Portland, Ore., the facilities will be ordinary but the view of the Columbia River splendid.

title: Downe Journal;House Is Given Its Due: Darwin Cogitated Here
description: Set in the gentle rolling Kent countryside is a sprawling three-story white stucco manor, which Stephen Jay Gould, the Harvard evolutionary biologist, has called "the site of some of the most revolutionary thinking in the history of our species."

title: COMPANY NEWS;MADGE NETWORKS SHARES SINK ON WEAK PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The stock of Madge Networks Inc. plunged 27 percent yesterday, a day after the maker of computer networking products warned of weak second-quarter profits. Goldman, Sachs & Company cut its 1996 and 1997 earnings estimates for the company. The stock fell $6.375, to $17.125, as 6.6 million shares were traded on the Nasdaq. Madge said yesterday that it expected softness in its second-quarter revenues, and that as a result its net income "may fall significantly below pro forma first-quarter results."

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Thanks From 20 Artists For Early Helping Hand
description: For the last three and a half decades, Young Concert Artists has been spotting promising instrumentalists, singers and chamber groups, presenting their debut concerts and booking tours for them until they are picked up by larger management companies.

title: World News Briefs;Iraq Bars U.N. Team From Another 2 Sites
description: Iraq today barred United Nations weapons inspectors here from two more sites suspected of holding banned weapons material, raising to five the number of bases declared off-limits since Tuesday.

title: In Three Texas Districts Question Is, 'Now What?'
description: Constituents, politicians and election officials are struggling to assess the fallout of Thursday's Supreme Court ruling that a Congressional district here and two in Houston are unconstitutional examples of racial gerrymandering.

description: Phyllis Pittman and Arthur William Blanck were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. The Rev. Lisa Ward performed the Unitarian ceremony.

title: HOME CLINIC;Making Sure Water Is Safe to Drink
description: IN colonial times most people drank milk, cider, beer or wine. They avoided drinking water because they believed that it could cause sickness or even death. Actually they had good reason to distrust the water. Their privies and outhouses were often situated dangerously close to the well or stream, and the water was frequently contaminated by sewage.

title: I Am Not a Crook
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;At Fidelity, Shifts in Managers Bring Shifts in Holdings
description: WHEN Fidelity Investments shuffled the managers of its equity mutual funds in March, analysts read it as a tacit admission that the holdings of several of the group's funds bore little resemblance to the investment strategy implicit in the funds' names.

title: Independent Film Makers Turn to an 'Angel'
description: THE worst disappointment is when a film is lousy," said Irwin Young.

title: SUNDAY June 16, 1996: NEST EGGS;Gator Raid
description: It's like an Easter egg hunt in June, only the eggs come from alligators, and helicopters and airboats are mobilized for the search. Starting about now, when the gators start laying, Tommy Hines of Newberry, Fla., head of the American Alligator Council, will collect 10,000 eggs well before the 65-day incubation cycle ends. He'll receive $9 to $15 for each one from breeders who will then hatch and raise them to become shoes. Using a copter to spot the nests in remote areas of rough marsh and swamp, Hines and his team retrieve the eggs by airboat. With luck, Mama Gator has gone food shopping elsewhere. "When I was a kid," Hines says, "gators were coveted creatures. Now we're overrun with them."

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Barnes, George M. Knapp
description: Elizabeth Howland Barnes, a daughter of Helena and Richard Barnes of Washington, was married yesterday to George Mathias Knapp, a son of Adeline and Lyle Knapp of Los Angeles. Associate Justice Janie Shores of the Supreme Court of Alabama officiated at River Farm, the headquarters of the American Horticultural Society, in Alexandria, Va.

title: From the Rope to the Chair: 3 Centuries of Death
description: WHEN it comes to capital punishment, justice, such as it was, could be swift two centuries ago in New Jersey. On a December day in 1731, a man named Garrett Hoppe of Bergen County accused a slave named Harry of threatening him. The next day, Harry was put to death.

title: SUNDAY June 16, 1996: THAT'S ENTERTAINMENT;Notes From the Underground
description: As anyone who encounters entertainers in public places knows, not all performers are born to perform. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority recently held auditions to separate those who are from those who are not. A veritable vaudeville of 65 wannabes (culled from 200 tapes) hammed it up in the East Waiting Room at Grand Central, all hoping for headliner status on the transit circuit. Among them were Nancy Lyon, who turned into a mechanical doll (above); a female Israeli Army sergeant, who played a saw; two lawyers and an advertising buddy from Westchester, who played klezmer music; an ex-messenger, who strummed "Light My Fire" on a guitar. Among the appurtenances the aspirants brought were a dual-cassette karaoke center, bagpipes, trombones, a life-size female rag doll and a handkerchief. A few came with only their voices. Among the distractions they encountered were heat, renovations, poor acoustics, faulty amplifiers and judges.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;A Nasty Little Get-Together Out at the Rock
description: Moll Flanders Robin Wright, Morgan Freeman, Stockard Channing, John Lynch, Brenda Fricker, Aisling Corcoran Directed by Pen Densham PG-13 123 minutes

description: A RELENTLESS, jabbing pain in the skull, an urge to vomit, a need to lie down in a quiet, dimly lighted place -- that's the migraine headache.

description: To the Editor: I recently flew from New York to Miami and on to Grand Cayman, returning on American Airlines, and experienced flights with only beverage service, the subject of Letters on Travel ("Hungry on High," May 5). I would like to make a suggestion to the airlines.

description: A FEW weeks ago, a colleague urged me to try the Tri-Boro Diner because of its "lean" corned beef, "homemade" chicken liver, "excellent" cole slaw and "decent" iced tea. "They say they make their own baked goods," he wrote. So do all diners. I ignored the note.

title: WORD & IMAGE;Top Secret
description: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO TODAY, reporters, editors and owners of The Times stood accused in Federal court of treasonous defiance of the United States. We had begun to publish a 10-part series about the Pentagon Papers, a 7,000-page study of how four Administrations became entrapped in Vietnam -- progressively more committed and more frustrated than they dared at every stage to admit to the public. Although the documents were historical and lacking any operational value, they were stamped "Top Secret" and therefore withheld, like trillions of other Government papers, from public, press, Congress and even Executive officials not duly "cleared" into the priesthood of "national security."

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;The Lessons From Dad's Counter
description: MY father, like his father before him, owned a small, retail store. Syd's Camera Shop was in White Plains, N.Y., on Main Street -- the proverbial, provincial, home-town thoroughfare where Dad did business in cozy proximity to the 18-karat chic of Bramley's Jewelers and the even-then anachronistic charms of Murray's Army and Navy.

He was 71.

title: June 9-15;Giving a Tongue a Rest

The bile-mouthed managing partner of the Cincinnati Reds, suspended for the 1993 season for her disparaging racial and ethnic remarks, last week agreed to relinquish her role through the 1998 season after another series of questionable comments. (For example, "Hitler was good in the beginning, but he went too far.")

description: Dr. William J. Messinger, a founding physician at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died on Monday at his home in Floral Park. He was 85.

title: AUTO RACING;Villeneuve Chases Title And His Dead Father
description: It's a perilous journey for sons who follow famous fathers onto the race track. At best, if you're Al Unser Jr., you can claim to be an equal. A few, such as Michael Andretti, get close, which only seems to underscore the differences. And some have even died trying.

title: BOXING;Jones Does Double Duty In Ring and on the Court
description: Roy Jones is no show-off. Why, he wonders, is everyone so surprised that he played in a professional bas ketball game this afternoon and then defended his world championshipsupermiddleweight boxing title sev en hours later?

title: Churches in Flames
description: Congressional hearings on the wave of arson against African-American churches -- together with strong steps by the Clinton Administration -- have finally brought the problem the attention it deserves. President Clinton has met with victims and ordered Federal law enforcement agencies to intensify their efforts. At the same time, however, an organization that has monitored the arsons is raising troubling questions about the response of law enforcement officials, particularly at the local level.

title: DIARY: SETTING RECORDS;$1.8 Billion! Do I Hear 2?
description: What is it -- Olympic fever run amok? There seems to be some bizarre contest going on to see which trader holds the world record for losing the most money in some complex market. Oh, yes, Nicholas Leeson of Barings lost $1.3 billion on derivatives in Singapore, and Toshihide Iguchi of Daiwa Bank dropped $1.1 billion on Treasury bonds. Rank amateurs, it's now clear. They've been left in the dust by Yasuo Hamanaka of Sumitomo, who over 10 years managed to lose $1.8 billion trading copper. Mr. Hamanaka, it seems, was practically a one-man copper market, buying and selling perhaps 500,000 tons of it a year -- fully 5 percent of all copper traded worldwide -- not to mention the grab bag of futures and options that any self-respecting mega-trader must dabble in. The trouble was that he seemed to consistently pay too much, betting on higher prices, and he lost big. But the true Olympic feat was keeping Sumitomo in the dark about this huge hole in its pocket.

title: The File Furor;Why This Affair Isn't So Frivolous
description: TO hear President Clinton tell it, it was "all an innocent bureaucratic snafu," this seamy saga of the White House gaining access to confidential Federal Bureau of Investigation files on prominent Republicans -- files it had no business seeing. title: A Survivor's Breast Cancer Stamp
description: IN October 1993, Diane Sackett Nannery was given a diagnosis of breast cancer. Returning from the doctor's office to her house in Manorville, she slumped in front of the television set, "terrified out of my mind," she recalled, and began channel surfing.

title: THE HOLLOW MAN
description: I am grateful to Michael Norman for his chilling candor (Lives: "The Hollow Man," May 26). In eloquently revealing his personal experience on the battlefield, he has exposed war for what it is -- grotesque, sorrowful, evil. As the mother of sons (one of whom will be required to register with the Selective Service on his next birthday), I want your war stories real and unromanticized. May the difficult words of hollow men everywhere haunt us all into peace.

description: In Flatbush, where the Orthodox Jewish community survives through tradition and trust, the name Schick symbolized both. Schick's Bakery, and later the Schick family catering business, laid out delectable spreads for the Sabbath, holidays and all of life's milestones. The family was generous to the needy, produced yeshiva teachers and even established a fund for poor brides, named for a girl who died young.

description: When they appeared in court on Friday, and rejected everything from the American flag to the capital letters in their names, the 14 newly surrendered Freemen laid bare, in word and posture, the central spirit of the anti-Government group that held off Federal agents for 81 days.
