title: SPOTLIGHT;Success Story
description: Harbingers of the Summer Games are everywhere. The Olympic torch is making its way around the country, and here is RUN FOR THE DREAM: THE GAIL DEVERS STORY. Charlayne Woodard portrays the American runner who won a gold medal in Barcelona, and Louis Gossett Jr. plays her coach, Bob Kersee. Track stars like Willie Gault and Florence Griffith Joyner have cameos. Ms. Devers is a sprinter who developed Graves' disease, which affects the thyroid gland, and received radiation therapy to combat it. This made-for-TV movie - SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on SHOWTIME - depicts the onset of the disease as well as her fight to come back and qualify for the 1992 American Olympic team. She is expected to participate this year in Atlanta.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS;Lots of Data in a Call for Help
description: Rabbi Mechel Handler cannot forget the emergency call he got from a man who, between gasping and choking, spoke the word "booth." Certain that the man was on Booth Street in Flushing, Queens, Rabbi Handler sent out an ambulance and called the phone company to trace the call. Fifteen minutes later, torn between interrupting the trace and opening the phone lines for other emergency calls, the rabbi hung up the phone. The location turned out to be correct but the next day he found out that the man had died.

title: June 9-15;Asylum From Mutilation
description: United States immigration authorities last week ruled that female genital mutilation is a form of persecution and that the threat of it can be a basis for granting asylum. In a precedent-setting decision, the Board of Immigration Appeals granted asylum to Fauziya Kasinga, a 19-year-old woman from Togo who said she had fled to America to escape having her genitals cut off.

title: Corporate Greed, Meet The Maximum Wage
description: NOW that liberals have pushed a higher minimum wage onto Congress's agenda, some of these descendants of George McGovern are agitating for another idea to narrow the gap between haves and have-nots. It's called a maximum wage.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOVERNORS ISLAND;Dismantling a Harbor Base and a Way of Life
description: The ferries from Governors Island are heavy with moving trucks these days: the Coast Guard is shipping out. It is the closing of the country's longest continuously operated military installation, taps for the base that launched a thousand ships.

title: The African Queen Arrives in Connecticut
description: ABOUT four and a half nautical miles from Katharine Hepburn's summer residence in the Fenwick section of Old Saybrook, two important vessels in her film career -- the African Queen and the Thayer IV -- will soon become tourist attractions.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Black Ties, Tennis and the Homeless
description: FROM the beginning, the homeless have played a part in the Seventh Regiment Armory, the brick and iron mass of Edith Wharton New York built by impatient gentleman soldiers on the Upper East Side in 1879. When the city couldn't make up its mind about paying for an armory closer to their homes, the soldiers raised $461,000 from grandees like A. T. Stewart, the retailing king and one of the wealthiest men in the city. Workers at what is now 66th Street and Park Avenue cleared away 35 shanties; the fate of the newly homeless went unrecorded.

title: June 9-15;A One-Man Crime Wave
description: Though crime is down sharply in New York, the city still has trouble shaking the perception that it is a violent place. Case in point: the capacity of one man to grip and terrify the city over two weeks.

title: TELEVISION;A Theme That Never Failed To Accomplish Its Mission
description: THE INSISTENT, OFF-CENTER BASS line spelled trouble with no easy solution. But the flute melody, cutting downward where the bass line rose, had the unflappable efficiency of the Impossible Missions Force. That hot and cool contrast was only one ingenious aspect of Lalo Schifrin's theme for the late 1960's television series "Mission: Impossible." The theme has a new life, remade for the movie by U2's rhythm section, Adam Clayton and Larry Mullen.

title: WEDDINGS;D.L. Horowitz, Andreas Frey
description: Dr. Deborah Lynne Horowitz and Andreas Frey are to be married today at Tavern on the Green in New York. Judge Arlene Hahn of the New York City Housing Court, an aunt of the bride, is to officiate.

title: THE THEATER SEASON;Are Tickets Really Too Expensive?
description: To the Editor:

title: Protests Continue In East Flatbush
description: More than two days after police officers fatally shot an unarmed man in Brooklyn, residents continued to demonstrate near the site of the shooting in East Flatbush. About 100 people, most of them West Indians, gathered along Church Avenue between East 34th Street and East 35th Street around 6 P.M. yesterday to protest the killing of the man, Aswan Watson, 23, on Thursday. About 50 police officers were called to the scene but the protest remained peaceful throughout the night and there were no arrests.

title: WEDDINGS;Dr. Kearney, Dr. Levinsohn
description: Dr. Kathleen Elizabeth Kearney and Dr. James David Levinsohn, anesthesiologists, were married last evening at the Hotel Westbury in Manhattan. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated, and the Rev. Edward Kearney, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer K. Sun, David S. Friedman
description: Jennifer Katherine Sun, the daughter of Betty and Pershing Sun of North Woodmere, L.I., and David Samuel Friedman, a son of Lita and Stanley Friedman of Jericho, L.I., was married last evening at the Plaza in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, officiated with Rabbi Charles D. Lippman.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM/UPPER WEST SIDE;Ancestor of Rap Is Heard Again
description: Like a treasured oldie but goodie, the soft, mellow voice of Willie Bryant has been resurrected to introduce a generation raised on hip-hop, rap and disk jockeys known as spinmasters, to the bebopping, hiphopping music of their grandparents' time -- the 1940's and 50's when the D.J.'s were considered the rappers.

title: San Francisco Turns Out to Celebrate Its Biggest Cheerleader
description: Herb Caen, the man who loves this city almost as much as it loves itself, has been part of the geography hereabouts for more than half a century. Coit Tower was only three years old when Mr. Caen arrived as a young journalist in 1936. The Golden Gate Bridge did not even exist when Mr. Caen began writing a six-day-a-week column, which turns 58 next month.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;The D.M.V. a Year Later: Cheaper? Better? Well, Yes and No
description: Frank Baer thought it would take him an hour, tops, to get a new driver's license, giving him plenty of time go home to Secaucus and study for a computer final the next day at Dover Business College in Paramus. He was wrong by almost two hours.

title: ARTS/ARCHITECTURE;When Baseball Became an Industry, Not Just a Sport
description: ON JUNE 12, 1939, TY COBB WAS being his ornery self when he missed the opening ceremonies for baseball's 100th birthday celebration in Cooperstown, N.Y. The rest of the game's living legends -- Babe Ruth, Connie Mack, Walter Johnson, Grover Cleveland Alexander, Honus Wagner, Tris Speaker, Larry Lajoie, Cy Young, George Sisler and Eddie Collins -- were already on hand when Cobb arrived. Along with 10,000 fans, they were gathered there for the dedication of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum and the induction of those legends.

title: NOTICED;Crunch Inc.: Marketing a Gym, as Well as a Way of Life
description: EIGHT, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one -- and stand," the gym instructor shouted above the driving disco beat. The scantily clad bodies, men and women, rose like a wave, lifting their bottoms off their stationary bicycles.

title: BOOKEND;Virtually A-Wake
description: STATELY, plump Joyceans everywhere are probably descending from the stairhead right this minute, dressing gowns ungirdled, and tucking with relish into big Bloomsday breakfasts consisting of the tangy inner organs of beasts and fowls. My own celebratory plan is to log on, as I do almost every day, to my Internet server and receive the mail brought to me courtesy of J-Joyce and F-Wake, the mailing lists that collectively make up Joyce on line. Thanks to the two of them -- J-Joyce for discussion of Joyce generally and F-Wake for discussion of matters specifically regarding what the members often refer to simply as the "Wake" -- my computer screen has begun to bloom, so to speak, with almost daily epiphanies. If I had not been a subscriber to the Joyce list, for example, I wouldn't have known about the latest "Ulysses" references in Tank Girl, the Generation X comic book ("Stately, plump Booga descends the stairhead of Chateau Tank Girl," goes a line in one story), or about the one in Woody Allen's "Take the Money and Run." (A recent J-Joyce posting read, "In the bank robbing scene . . . the date is prominently displayed: it's June 16th. Coincidence?") Nor would I have had any idea that James Joyce has contributed in a crucial way to the work of Rodney Dangerfield. (In the movie "Back to School," check out Sally Kellerman's orgasmic reading of Molly Bloom's soliloquy, which Dangerfield, bursting from his classroom seat, punctuates by shouting "Yes! Yes!")

title: The Nation;A Carrot and Stick For Parenthood
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON is calling for curfew laws and a computer chip and rating system that would prevent children from watching TV programs their parents find objectionable. The Christian Coalition and some conservatives are advocating laws asserting the rights of parents to raise their children as they see fit at the same time other conservatives are pushing laws holding parents responsible for children go astray.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan M. Chu, Geoffrey Blaisdell
description: Susan Moon Chu, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Young Kwon Chu of Virginia Beach, Va., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Charles Blaisdell, the son of Janet Simmons and the stepson of Harold Simmons of Rockland, Me. The Rev. William Kaiser-Lowrance, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Chrysler Museum in Norfolk, Va.

title: June 9-15;Taking Cash With Cannolis
description: The Genovese crime family, the most powerful Mafia clan remaining in New York City, was dealt a big setback last week when 19 of its leaders were indicted on charges ranging from murder and racketeering to loan sharking.

title: Famed Artist's Model Bared All for a Playwright
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigator Denies Intimidating Suspect Into Confessing a Rape
description: A New York State police investigator has denied intimidating a suspect into confessing his part in the gang rape of an unconscious woman.

title: Correction
description: A listing of lodgings, restaurants and events in Newport last Sunday misstated the telephone number of the Newport Music Festival box office. It is (401) 849-0700.

title: Admiring the City Of Broad Shoulders
description: IN my 20's, I took half a dozen pleasure trips, and four were to Chicago. Comments were made. A friend, once described as a "true Chicagoan" because he wore suspenders, lived in a rooming house and wrote muck-racking journalism, grew curious about my appetite for books on his hometown, as if I were claiming special knowledge of his mother's meat loaf. My colleagues in the New York publishing world picked my brain for insider knowledge about the city before attending the annual American Booksellers Association convention there.

title: CHATTER;New Jersey Movies: The Sequel
description: In honor of summer movie season, Chatter recently asked: If you could make a New Jersey movie, what would the plot be? Here are more answers.

title: Two Worlds of Navajo-Choate Exchange
description: PAMELA TRACY, one of eight American Indian exchange students at Choate Rosemary Hall this spring, found the preparatory school's Wallingford campus undaunting. "They told us it was really big, but I think it's small," said the 18-year-old who was brought up on the Navajo Nation's 14.3 million acre reservation, the largest in the United States.

title: In the Region/Westchester;2 White Plains Building Sales Reflect Market Forces
description: WHILE corporate consolidations continue to hobble Westchester's office market, they have been balanced somewhat by a recent infusion of outside investor interest. This has led some brokers to predict a full market recovery in the not-too-distant future.

title: POP MUSIC;In the Deadheads' Footsteps
description: WHEN THE ROCK band God Street Wine goes on the road this summer, Debbie Yi and three friends are going with them. "We're going to pack the car and do the whole trip, as many shows as we can," said Ms. Yi, who is 17 and lives in Rye, N.Y. She has been a fan of the band for four years and began traveling to its shows up and down the East Coast two years ago. "I've been as far as Washington to see them," she said. "If they get within 10 hours of New York, we're definitely going."

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Confessions of the Ultimate Cable Guy
description: JAN. 1, 1996: THE NEW ME! Clean. Kicked it, or at least trying to. Have to take it one day at a time from here on out. Promised the wife and kids after that scene on Christmas Eve. I don't remember much, but Vera says I channel-surfed nonstop for 17 hours before I blacked out. Program guides scattered everywhere. I just kept flipping, flipping, flipping. . . . There was nothing on.

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

description: Texas Ruling Supports Gay Republicans

title: FOOD;THE LIGHT BRIGADE
description: HOW AMERICANS YEARN TO EAT HEALTHILY. Particularly as the weather warms and layers of clothing can be shed, and light meals, prepared simply, seem so eminently feasible. And yet, as certainly as the sun sets, so does summer's resolve, leaving many of the lapsed hugging their sweaters, and not because of the breeze.

title: You Can Look, But Ask First
description: THESE days, when you don't have to be a queen (or know one) to get into Buckingham Palace, the hunt is on for anything in London still off-limits to the tourist crowds.

title: QUESTIONS FOR: TOBY SIMON
description: Are readers to assume that instead of academic offices, certain departments at Brown University have academic boudoirs, with four-poster beds, no less (Sunday: "Questions for: Toby Simon," May 26)? Had a man been the associate dean of student life and a human sexuality educator, would you have photographed him in the same setting?

title: U.S. Budget Cuts Imperil Remote Town's Lifeline
description: Much of the prosperity of this scenic mountain village depends on when the plows break through the giant snow drifts that block the Beartooth Scenic Highway.

title: Ben Tobin, 92, Investor in Hotels And in Real Estate
description: Ben Tobin, a hotel and real-estate investor who over the years held stakes in the Empire State Building, Broadway shows and the Hollywood Beach Hotel in Florida, died on June 7 at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 92.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;A New Era in the Care and Feeding of Artists
description: IN THE SCRAPBOOK OF MEMORIES shared by members of the classical-music industry, the artist manager Harold Shaw shows up in many guises: a triumphant impresario announcing that the pianist Vladimir Horowitz would join his roster and return to the concert stage in 1974 after a five-year absence; a devoted advance man tending to the considerable needs of the soprano Jessye Norman, another client; an urbane fixture in concerts halls and backstage areas for more than 40 years, known for his signature bow ties and berets.

title: MARKET WATCH;Investor Frenzy Beyond the Pale
description: Why not just throw your wallet out the window and save everyone a lot of time and trouble?

title: New Night Life Is Changing The Hamptons
description: WITH its pleasantly picturesque downtown, gracious summer houses and fine ocean beaches, the Village of Westhampton Beach has thrived for more than a century as an affluent resort on the western edge of the Hamptons.

title: Long Way Home
description: To the Editor: My companions and I recently traveled with Norwegian Cruise Lines in the Western Caribbean. They offer an air-sea program, which we opted for. Ten days before we were to leave from Newark for Fort Lauderdale to embark on our cruise, we were given our flight information. Trans World Airlines was our carrier and it was flying us from Newark to St. Louis, where we were to take a connecting flight to Fort Lauderdale. The return trip was equally absurd. Norwegian Cruise Lines, when asked, absolved itself of responsibility by saying we had the choice of arranging our own flights and that they had no control over the airlines that they contract with.

title: THE BIRTH OF A REVOLUTIONARY CLASS
description: It's good that we elders have so much political clout. We need it to withstand attacks like "The Birth of a Revolutionary Class," by Lester C. Thurow (May 19).

title: Bomb Believed Set by the I.R.A. Leaves 200 Hurt in British City
description: A suspected I.R.A. bomb exploded in a parked van in a busy area of downtown Manchester this morning, wounding more than 200 people, sending hundreds of shoppers fleeing in panic and shattering windows for blocks around.

title: Keeping Secrets
description: What happened to Linehan was no rare occurrence, for as managed-care organizations demand increasingly detailed justifications for medical treatment and file more and more data electronically, the cloak of confidentiality that once protected psychotherapy has become increasingly threadbare. A new bill, currently wending its way through Congress, represents the first comprehensive national effort to deal with this emerging problem. Introduced last November by Senators Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, and Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the Medical Records Confidentiality Act is intended, as Senator Bennett put it, to "create safeguards so that the folks who currently have access to your medical information cannot abuse it as it is being abused now."

title: Connecticut Q&A: Janet Vaill Day;Fighting Censorship at the Town Library
description: JANET VAILL DAY, the Woodbridge Library director and chairwoman of the intellectual freedom committee of the Connecticut Library Association, thinks about censorship, lectures on censorship and worries about censorship. "People always think of books when it comes to censorship but today it can be anything, videos, magazines even library programs," she said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Cape Cod
description: The Old King's Highway, better known locally as Route 6A, is one of the oldest roads in America. It meanders for 34 miles near the shore of Cape Cod Bay from Sandwich on the west past Orleans on the east. For decades before the Puritans sailed into Cape waters, it served Indians as a sandy footpath. For descendants of the first Pilgrims, it was the farm-to-market road and later the main stagecoach road to Boston. In recent years, as Cape Cod's permanent population has neared 200,000 (a number more than doubled by visitors in July and August), the Cape's well-organized and highly active protectionists have battled to preserve the two-lane road.

title: The Rebirth of a River
description: Every so often something happens to suggest that energetic citizen action and carefully drawn government regulation can turn a hopeless cause into a resounding success story. A case in point is the remarkable transformation of the Hudson River, documented last week in an authoritative two-part series by The Times's William Stevens and Andrew Revkin.

title: Their Finest Hour
description: LAND GIRLS By Angela Huth. 378 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $23.95. THE British novelist, playwright and journalist Angela Huth's lovely new book, "Land Girls," is a war story about the real heroes of World War II: not the generals but the ordinary citizens who left their workaday lives and fought for their country as best they could. The girls of the title were young women who joined Britain's Land Army; they left the safe, tea-cozy world of traditional female jobs -- university student, hairdresser, sweetheart -- and went off to take up the exhausting, dawn-to-darkness labor of agricultural work so the male farm workers could take up arms. At first blush, there is nothing exceptional about the three main characters. When gentle, cerebral Agatha, romantic Stella and fluff-brained Prue first assemble for their tour of duty on the Lawrence farm in Dorset, the reader might be deceived into thinking this is going to be yet another banal three-girls-meet-somewhere-and-become-friends novel, the sort in which there is inevitably one suicide, one ghastly abortion, a slew of beastly men and a great display of passive aggression. But the reader would be wrong; there is not one moment of melodrama in the entire book. And there is absolutely nothing banal about these women.

title: ON TRACK AND FIELD;The Shoes Can't Make Hurt Runner Just Do It
description: Two miles into his 10,000-meter heat Friday night, Todd Lewis felt the familiar, dreaded twitch in the muscle that runs under his stomach.

title: IN BRIEF;A New Way to Keep Track Of New Jersey Stock Prices
description: Economists at Fairleigh Dickinson University have created an index of New Jersey stocks, comparing the 20 largest companies based here.

title: To Bind Up a Nation's Wound With Celluloid
description: As soon as I heard wheels I knowed who was coming. That was him and bound to be him. It was the right nigger heading in a new white car up his driveway towards his garage with the light shining, but stopping before he got there, maybe not to wake them. That was him. I knowed it when he put out the car lights and put his foot out and I knowed him standing dark against the light. I knowed him then like I know me now. I knowed him even by his still, listening back. . . .

Starting this week, the Rooftop Concert Series begins on top of the Y.W.C.A. at 610 Lexington Avenue, with music varying from blues guitar to trumpet to the komungo, a Korean zither that was the instrument of ceremony in royal courts.

description: THE setting for this drama is a 14-acre, little-used state park overlooking the Housatonic River in Stratford. There are four boarded-up buildings on the land, one a former theater that once had an international reputation.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Ferry Will Linger On the Inside Passage
description: The Inside Passage along the coast of British Columbia is familiar to cruise ship passengers heading for Alaska, but settlements on some of the rugged islands and the Canadian mainland are not. To give access to them, B.C. Ferries of Victoria has refurbished the 376-foot Queen of Chilliwack for overnight service until Sept. 27 from Port Hardy at the northern end of Vancouver Island to Bella Coola, the gateway to the Cariboo Chilcotin coast of the mainland with its fjords and mountain lakes.

title: BASEBALL;The Cardinals Take Advantage of the Mets as Ordonez Hesitates and the Game Is Lost
description: With all the great plays Rey Ordonez has made this season, an out is expected every time he gloves a ball. But guess what? He is human after all.

description: Early last month, Ronald Breland, who runs a little nursery called Bumps in West Nyack, N.Y., was admiring his apple tree in full bloom.

title: One Director Who's Proud To Be Called Commercial
description: WHEN IT COMES TO action movies, there is one unbreakable rule: the audience must have popcorn. So even here, inside a tent serving as a movie theater in the middle of Alcatraz, the people at Disney have set out boxes of popcorn. And cans of soda. And licorice. All for the 500 celebrities and members of the press who have sailed to this decrepit, abandoned Federal prison in San Francisco Bay for the premiere of "The Rock."

title: ON LANGUAGE;The Hard Way
description: MY INFORMAL job title in the Nixon Administration was Rejected Counsel. That's because, as a speech writer, I would occasionally put my head into the Oval Office to say: "Mr. President -- Do the popular thing! Take the easy way!" Mr. Nixon would ritualistically throw me out of the office, allowing me to submit a speech draft that would truthfully report: "Some of my aides have suggested that I do the popular thing, that I should take the easy way. But I have rejected such counsel."

title: Marjorie Gross, 40, Producer And Writer for TV's 'Seinfeld'
description: Marjorie Gross, a writer and producer of the television series "Seinfeld," who also wrote a humorous article about her ovarian cancer in The New Yorker in April, died of the illness on June 7 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 40.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Greenpoint's Endangered Hampton
description: GREENPOINT, Brooklyn, is a river-front neighborhood, but the only way to reach the river is to get past a set of squat warehouses at the water's edge, climb through unsanctioned holes in a razor-wire fence and walk onto a crumbling, concrete-covered pier.

title: JAZZ VIEW;A New Champion In Town
description: OVER THE LAST EIGHT YEARS, THE JVC JAZZ Festival, which had been the most important of its kind in America, has been dogged by the What Is Jazz? Festival, the upstart concert series put on by the Knitting Factory, the center of avant-garde music in Manhattan. The struggle pits the ambitious young owner of the Knitting Factory, Michael Dorf, against the wizened head of JVC, George Wein. Mr. Dorf's intention seems clear: he wants to run the biggest and brightest jazz festival in New York.

description: A FEW years after the French aristocrat Alexis de Tocqueville traveled through America, trying to describe this new culture of democracy, his compatriot Astolphe Louis Leonor, the Marquis de Custine, did the same for Russia and its despotism.

title: STYLE;Animal House
description: Decorating around works of art is a perennial problem for everyone from serious collectors to parents of finger-painters, but rarely are the difficulties so overt as they would be with the sculpture of Damien Hirst, whose recent show at the Gagosian Gallery in SoHo included a much-talked-about piece entitled "This Little Piggy Went to Market, This Little Piggy Stayed Home," consisting of a pig sliced in half from snout to tail, with each side preserved in formaldehyde and suspended in a glass tank. One half, on a mechanized track, moves back and forth, so that the pig is repeatedly made whole and divided again. Here, five of New York's most distinguished designers offer their advice.

description: Marjorie Towle Emery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram W. Emery of Little Compton, R.I., was married there yesterday to Harold Irving Pratt Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pratt of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Richard DenUyl Jr. performed the ceremony at the United Congregational Church.

title: To Relieve Anxiety Over Dental Care
description: Pain and anxiety control is readily available for medical procedures such as surgery or uncomfortable diagnostic tests ["Dentist-Anesthesiologists Are Pushing for Formal Recognition," March 10]. Unfortunately easy access to the full spectrum of pain and anxiety control for dental procedures is not available in the United States today. Isn't the universal metaphor for a bad time having a root canal? Most people wouldn't think a root canal more aversive than having "wisdom teeth" extracted. Yet the metaphor isn't for the wisdom teeth. It's for the root canal. The reason is that "wisdom teeth" are usually removed by an oral surgeon, who usually has the ability to provide some form of pain and anxiety control, other than simple local anesthesia. The root canal is usually done by a dentist without that ability. So it's not the procedure that's aversive. It's the lack of adequate pain control. Wouldn't it be nice to have whatever pain and anxiety control you needed for a dental procedure? This is where dentist-anesthesiologists come in.

title: COVER STORY;On Saying What's Rarely Said And Showing What's Rarely Shown
description: AT the start of his first-person documentary about this refugee family's life in san francisco's bleakest neighborhoods, the 18-year-old film maker Sokly (Don Bonus) Ny says it was hard to live his life and videotape it at the same time. "Especially with my family," he said, speaking to his own camcorder. "We're from Cambodia, and we're pretty traditional. Talking about family secrets to the public: we don't do that."

title: WEDDINGS;Laura Spiro, Douglas Forbes
description: Laura Marie Spiro, the daughter of Joann Winkler of Cambridge, Mass., and Lionel Spiro of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Douglas Bowditch Forbes, a son of Grace and Crosby Forbes, also of Cambridge. title: William A. Bales, 79, NBC Producer and Writer
description: William Alan Bales, who contributed to NBC News coverage on radio and television during more than 32 years as a writer, editor and documentary maker, died on June 6 at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 79.

title: IN BRIEF;Joining Forces to Preserve The Vanishing White Cedar
description: Atlantic white cedar trees used to flourish along the Eastern Seaboard, especially in New Jersey, but no longer. The trees began declining here in the late 1790's, when swampy areas of what is now known as the Hackensack Meadowlands, which were covered with Atlantic white cedar forests, were burned to flush out the pirates who hid there. Now, New Jersey has only 30,000 acres of Atlantic white cedar, half the acreage it once had, said David Edelman, supervising forester with the state Department of Environmental Protection. The entire Eastern seaboard has about 115,000 acres left.

title: If There's Life Out There, It's Squeaky Clean
description: AIMING their radiotelescopes into the heart of the Milky Way, astronomers have found new hope that there might really be kindred spirits out there. Inside a cloud of interstellar dust, it was announced last week, scientists detected faint traces of a chemical called acetic acid -- common household vinegar.

description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Cleans Out Its Attics for an Auction
description: WHEN Joe Kabe Auctions in Milford ran a charity fund-raising event recently, someone donated an old Morris chair that had been relegated to the attic for years. It turned out to be a Gustav Stickley piece, currently a highly prized relic of the turn of the century Arts and Crafts movement. After spirited bidding, the chair sold for $7,700.

title: The View From: New Rochelle;Winning Points on a Quiz Show About All Things Religious
description: WHO single-handedly translated the Bible's original Hebrew and Greek texts into the Latin version, which dominated Church history for a thousand years? All Saints' Day is the first of which month? The Kol Nidre is sung on the eve of which Jewish holiday?

title: Correction
description: A News and Topics article last Sunday about an Essex County agency that provides services for abused, neglected or financially exploited adults misstated its size and mission. title: THEATER VIEW;Designing for the Dysfunctional Family
description: IT ISN'T EASY BEING THE SOLE protector of your family's values like Halie, the Illinois farm matriarch in Sam Shepard's "Buried Child." Things fall apart as soon as she goes out the door. One day she returns from a luncheon date with Father Dewis to find that a young woman in hip-hugging jeans, a total stranger, seems to have taken possession of her house. The hussy is making bouillon for old, dying Dodge, Halie's hard-drinking, cantankerous, unwashed husband. Not only that, but Dodge and Halie's slow-witted, middle-aged son, Tilden, is missing, and someone has taken away the wooden leg belonging to their other son, Bradley, leaving him stranded and furious, thrashing around on the rump-sprung sofa.

She said the reactions of her friends had been telling. One -- thinking of the Holocaust and chemotherapy -- burst into tears. Another -- going through a rough divorce -- cheered, "Good for you, girl!" The woman said she loved the freedom of her hair, but every time an attractive man approached, she found herself looking for a hat.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Vietnam Plans to Rebuild The Imperial City of Hue
description: THE Imperial Citadel here on the banks of the Perfume River, symbol to the Vietnamese of the poetry and art of their past, is one of the few places where the destruction of the Vietnam War can still be seen. Its thick and mossy walls are chipped from American tank and artillery fire during the 1968 Tet offensive, when North Vietnamese troops raised their red flag above the citadel for 24 days. Inside, some buildings are still shattered, as if the war that ended in 1975 had ended only yesterday. Hue, a quiet city of about 300,000 on the central coast, was the seat of the 13 Nguyen emperors and the nation's capital from 1802 to 1945. Today it is the cultural site Vietnamese say they hope to visit; it is still a center of Buddhism and education.

title: SPOTLIGHT;On the Road
description: No red-blooded film buff will forget two scenes from Preston Sturges's surreal gem SULLIVAN'S TRAVELES (1941). As a naive Hollywood-comedy director (Joel McCrea) searches for realism, note the cunning and greed on the face of a dangerous tramp and catch the sweetness of a minister, welcoming shackled convicts to his poor church to watch a cartoon. Sturges's regulars are on deck - from Hollywood parasites to a chain-gang warden and a little flunkie with a lantern. So is Veronica Lake, as McCrea's sidekick. The actor's stalwart profile and open countenance suit his can Dide-like odyssey. Sullivan learns and Sturges insists that life's best tonic is laughter - MONDAY at 9 P.M. on DIS.

The tormented spirits of Lear, Macbeth, Romeo and his Juliet are generating an awful lot of television drama, by everyone from Spelling to Bochco. Shakespeare has even become the language of contemporary literary criticism: Ophelia as victimized virgin, Othello as, well, "the Moor."

title: IN PERSON;Lord of the Bees
description: WHEN the temperature creeps up past 50 degrees and spring eases across the landscape, New Jersey's honeybees emerge from their sticky winter hideouts. But it is not until early summer, when the air turns humid and the flowers are lush, that Grant Stiles' work begins in earnest.

title: Buses Again Trouble Civil Rights Veterans
description: The tarnished silver buses that lumber along the avenues of this city are outdated, some of them 20 years old, but the cracked and faded seats are precious to many people. description: THEY are the children whose outbursts and interruptions often distract their classmates and frustrate their teachers. Although they are often bright and intelligent, their unpredictable behavior can be an obstacle to forming classroom friendships, and that behavior makes it difficult for a teacher to conduct a lesson. In an effort to control their disruptive actions, many of these children are being given Ritalin, a prescription drug, which helps them concentrate better.

But it is blessed by location: on the campus of the University of Maryland's dental school, home of the world's first dental college, it's just a few blocks from Camden Yards and the Orioles in downtown Baltimore. Opening wide Friday, this 7,000-square-foot, bi-level exhibit features enough razzle-dazzle displays amid the de rigueur historical collections to make even the most dentophobic forget his or her fears. Fittingly, it's a museum whose overall bite makes you smile, even if individual exhibits like the pocket tooth extractor at left don't.

title: Backtalk;Innuendo 7, Coach 0
description: One of the best college football coaches in the country, done in by shadows in Norman, Okla., can now be found sitting on his reputation in sunny Miami, waiting for a call and wondering what hit him. One year into a five-year coaching contract at the University of Oklahoma, Howard Schnellenberger was rendered jobless last December when his departure was announced as a "resignation." It was that only if you are willing to call a public hanging a suicide.

title: June 9-15;Mr. Mitchell Goes to Belfast
description: During his triumphal visit to Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic last December, President Clinton seemed prescient about what the future held for his friend, former Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell. "Well, George," the President said, "like the song says, 'I got the mine, but you got the shaft.' " Mr. Mitchell, who was later appointed by the Irish and British Governments as chairman of the new, broad-based Northern Ireland peace talks, laughed. But last week he wasn't smiling as Protestant unionist politicians sought to thwart his appointment. The unionists attacked him as an Irish-American Roman Catholic who would side with the province's Catholic minority. Mr. Mitchell, only part Irish and a Maronite Catholic, was finally confirmed, but he still faces a difficult summer. The talks are unlikely to succeed without representatives of the Irish Republican Army's political wing at the table. The political wing, Sinn Fein, is disqualified until the I.R.A. restores a cease-fire. JAMES F. CLARITY

title: Deconstructing the Bums
description: BROOKLYN'S DODGERS The Bums, the Borough, and the Best of Baseball, 1947-1957. By Carl E. Prince. Illustrated. 202 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $23. IT is enshrined in memory, the Brooklyn of the 1940's and 50's -- the object of (not always so good-natured) derision, a kind of joke borough, source of an accent that, when reproduced ludicrously by outsiders, was unrecognized by its denizens. A joke borough of ferocious loyalties, it was a matrix and it was a necessary place from which to flee. Those of us who fled have never stopped singing its praises: the sweet butter from tubs, the pickles, charlotte russes (concoctions of sponge cake and strawberry mash and fresh whipped cream contained in a coronet of heavy white paper), warm Italian whole-wheat bread, unlocked front doors, civil cabdrivers (all of whom, if they were to be believed, were working to send their sons to Yale), lemon ices (a generic description that included chocolate) -- and the Brooklyn Dodgers, Dem Bums.

title: An Ominous Gap In Suspect's Diary

That was the day, the police say, that he began a binge of attacks in which three women were beaten and one was killed. The police suggest that his rampage was spurred by unrequited love for a Japanese tourist, who yesterday spoke of their friendship and her anguish over how it ended.

title: Dead as a Dollar
description: CASH IS DIRTY -- THE NEW JERSEY Turnpike tried to punish toll collectors recently for wearing latex gloves (thus giving the driving clientele a "bad impression"), but who can blame them? Cash is heavy -- $1 million in $20 bills weighs more than you can lift, and drug dealers have been disconcerted to note that their powdered merchandise is handier for smuggling than the equivalent money. Cash is inequitable -- if you are one of the 50 million Americans poor enough to be "unbanked," you pay extortionate fees to seedy, bulletproofed check-cashing operations (even more extortionate than the fees charged for automatic teller machines, which are often up to 1 or 2 percent and rising). Cash is quaint, technologically speaking -- unless you're impressed by intaglio-steel-plate-printed paper with embedded polyester strips (meant to inconvenience counterfeiters). Cash is expensive -- tens of billions of dollars drain from the economy each year merely to pay for the printing, trucking, safekeeping, vending, collecting, counting, armored-guarding and general care and feeding of our currency.

title: ON THE STREET;Slithery Accessories

Last Sunday, it was in again at the 39th annual Puerto Rican Day parade, where young men and a few young women wore live pythons as pets, 2 to 10 feet long. The larger specimens were draped over shoulders, while smaller ones circled necks or wrists. Above, a straw-hatted python. Nineteen snakes were counted between 50th and 60th Streets. Some owners posed for passers-by. Most of the snakes had handsome beige or brown markings. The young man at the top far right wore a banana-yellow hat to match his snake.

title: Tales Out of Russia
description: IMMORTAL LOVE By Ludmilla Petrushevskaya. Translated by Sally Laird. 348 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $25. LYUDMILA PETRUSHEVSKAYA was born in Moscow in 1938, at the height of the Terror. Her father vanished when she was a baby, leaving her mother to support her during the war. When she was 9, she was sent to a children's home for a year, since her mother could not feed her. She was so thin, even among the emaciated orphans, that she earned the nickname moskvichka spichka -- the Moscow matchstick. Then came the privilege of sharing a mattress on a floor with her mother. She escaped these stifling conditions by going to libraries. Later she worked as a journalist and wrote plays and stories. Her first marriage ended tragically when her husband became paralyzed in an accident and then died, leaving her with a son to care for.

Jones, 38, was 2-2 with 2 saves and a 5.01 earned run average in 28 games. He was 2 for 7 in save situations and posted a 4.50 e.r.a. in April, 6.07 in May. Left-handers were batting .321 against him, right-handers .296.

title: Streetscapes/230 West 42d Street;From School to Residences, Flea Circus and Brothel
description: MORE than a decade of argument and millions of dollars have washed over 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and New York State's project for the redevelopment the block is only just beginning. By now some planner or preservationist could be expected to have at least walked through the oldest building on the block, designed by McKim, Mead & White, and later transformed into one of the most unusual restaurants in New York -- large portions of which survive.

title: Medical Monolith For City's Future
description: The merger of two of New York City's most prominent hospitals and medical schools -- Mount Sinai Medical Center and New York University Medical Center -- would create an institution whose prestige and power would virtually guarantee enough revenue to keep its medical research alive even in the face of diminishing financial support, say officials of both hospitals.

title: Long Island Q & A: Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz;Helping to Combat Child and Adolescent Mental Disorders
description: DR. HAROLD S. KOPLEWICZ is chief of child and adolescent psychiatry at Schneider Children's Hospital and Hillside Hospital at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center. After graduating from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Dr. Koplewicz completed a pediatric internship at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center. He studied general psychiatry at Cornell University and completed a two-year research fellowship through the National Institute of Mental Health.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;Russians Choosing Today: Either Reforms or the Past
description: Profoundly disenchanted by five years of faltering economic reforms but equally disturbed by the prospect of a new Communism that could drag this country back into the darkness of the Soviet era, millions of Russian voters will make the starkest political choice of their lives on Sunday.

title: WEDDINGS;Louise Armstrong, Randolph Barton
description: Louise Spencer Armstrong, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Armstrong of Boston, was married there yesterday to Randolph Barton 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Jr. of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Dean Elliott Wolfe performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church.

description: Not that long ago, golf people in Michigan were asking, "Where is John Morse?"

title: WEDDINGS;Gracelyn Santos, Michael Mroczek
description: Dr. Gracelyn Fernandez Santos and Dr. Michael Stanley Mroczek, both dentists, were married yesterday in West Brighton, S.I. The Rev. Gil Suaybaguio performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: Shocklets of Recognition
description: LEARNING TO DRIVE By William Norwich. 214 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.

title: DANCE VIEW;Entering a World Only Meredith Monk Can Map
description: TO DESCRIBE THE productions of Meredith Monk requires a vocabulary as extravagant as her creations. She is a choreographer, dancer, musician and film maker. She's also a storyteller, historian and prophet. And she can resemble an explorer or archeologist.

title: Coeducation at Fairfield, 25 Years Later
description: WHEN Susan Coon Howard arrived on the Fairfield University campus in the fall of 1971, she was a bright-eyed college freshman, "thrilled and scared."

title: MUSIC;It's Warm, So Festivals Are Here
description: NOW that warmer weather has arrived and driving is less of a chore, some long-established and not-too-distant festivals are beckoning Westchester concertgoers.

title: THEATER;Cultivating One's Garden in a Play of the Spirit
description: WHEN a critic called a play of hers "murkily symbolic," Heather McDonald gave up reading reviews. "It made me self-conscious," the playwright said. "I'd write a passage, and I'd stop and I'd wonder: 'Is this murkily symbolic?' "

title: THEATER;Edgily, a Distinguished Writer Turns Playwright
description: JUST A FEW WEEKS AGO, Cynthia Ozick said, she received a letter from Steppenwolf, the regional theater company in Chicago, turning down an early draft of her first play, about two concentration camp survivors and their encounter with a young man who questions their memories of the Holocaust. The draft had been sent to Steppenwolf by someone connected with the play at some point -- Ms. Ozick doesn't know who -- and bore the title "The Farmer in the Dell."

title: No Headline
description: I never knew how good our songs were until I heard Ella Fitzgerald sing them."

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE HEARTLAND;How Yeltsin Won Over a City That Looked on Him Coldly
description: When heavy winter snows blanketed this region just six months ago, President Boris N. Yeltsin's political prospects looked bleak indeed.

title: ON BASEBALL;Williams Is Passing The Endurance Test
description: There was a time when a handful of caustic players in pinstripes used to ride Bernie Williams constantly, and maybe, just maybe, they forced the Yankee center fielder to turn from the unsure, shy youngster he was into the confident veteran that he is. Just as a matter of survival.

title: Restlessness Among the Nation's Booksellers
description: The nation's instant summer community of literati is thriving with a healthy population of almost 40,000 conventioneers, but the growth has come with much grumbling from its longtime residents -- traditional publishers who have seen their once insular group transformed to reflect the sweeping changes in the industry.

title: Income Found to Predict Education Level Better Than Race
description: A study that tracked 25,000 teen-agers over six years has found that family income counts more than race, ethnicity, sex or scores on achievement tests in determining the expectations and future education of the group.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;An antidrug campaign takes aim at heroin -- and its image
description: THE Partnership for a Drug-Free America will introduce today its first national campaign aimed at fighting the use of heroin, which is also its initial antidrug effort aimed at those ages 18 to 25.

title: Sarcasm, Reality and Justice a la Singapore
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE FAR EAST;Vladivostok Enjoys Vote But Worries Over Result
description: A thick, chill fog muddled the masts and cranes of Golden Horn Bay, but inside the Palace of the Sailor, voters of various political stripes clearly shared a common joy on Sunday at exercising their right to elect a President.

title: U.S. OPEN;Jones Defies Odds and the 18th Hole
description: Steve Jones doesn't look like Ben Hogan. He doesn't play golf like Ben Hogan. But on an overcast and muggy afternoon at the Oakland Hills Country Club today, Jones won the United States Open on the same course that Hogan did by taking a page out of the Hogan book.

title: The Next Thing to Go Global Will Be Toll-Free Numbers
description: Toll-free telephone numbers are one of those things -- like country music and automobile cup-holders -- that flourish here but have never really caught on overseas.

title: Study Faults TV's Portrayal of Heart Emergencies
description: On television, restarting a stopped heart is miraculously effective. Heroic chest thumping and electrical jolts restore young victims of shootings, car wrecks and near-drownings to normal lives.

title: No Headline
Essay;Round 1: Yeltsin
description: Boris Yeltsin brought off a shturmoushchina.

title: ART REVIEW;Exalting Single Dot in Singular Ways
description: For more than 25 years, an Englishman, Andrew Forge, has been an integral part of the art community in Yale, first as dean and later as professor of painting in the Yale Art School. The Yale Center for British Art has now done him proud with a show of his paintings and works on paper from 1951 to 1996.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Excel, but Lose
description: The MetroStars were the better team today, but Jeff Baicher's goal 14 minutes into the game stood up and gave San Jose a 1-0 victory before 18,404 at Giants Stadium.

title: Film Glut Prompts Disney to Halve Production
description: Facing a glut of movies in an increasingly competitive marketplace and an uneven track record, the Walt Disney Company plans to reduce its annual output of films by 50 percent and trim its lineup of senior executives, company officials said today.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Keep Sonics Together? It Will Not Come Cheap.
description: They pushed one of the National Basketball Association's greatest teams to six games in the league finals, and learned a hundred lessons about championship basketball. But they have seven players who will be free agents.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the end of the morning session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 152.33 points, or almost seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,441.72. On Friday, the Nikkei index climbed 206.99 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Insurance Bill Offers Much-Needed Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio Is Trying to Court Youngsters and Advertisers
description: Heather Hogan is a full-speed-ahead chatterbox of a 14-year-old who does not yet know what she wants to do for a career. But she already has the kind of corporate title many might envy.

title: At Home Abroad;A Divided Italy?
description: The most memorable course I had in college was taught by a refugee from Mussolini's Italy, Gaetano Salvemini. He brought passion to the subject: the Risorgimento (literally, resurgence), the 19th-century movement that created a united Italy from a quilt of separate little kingdoms, republics and territories occupied by foreign powers.

title: Is There a Market for Gateway 2000's Large-Screen PC?
description: Intended to be the focal point of the family room for group games, TV and Internet viewing, the large-screen personal computer introduced by Gateway 2000 Inc. in April was the most aggressive move yet to transform computing into a multiperson, living-room activity.

title: Caldor to Delay Bankruptcy Exit
description: The Caldor Corporation does not expect to exit Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection before 1997, according to a bankruptcy court filing by a group of the company's creditors.

title: Bodies Pulled From River
description: The bodies of two New York City men whose boat tumbled over a dam were pulled from the Hudson River today, and authorities continued searching for a third. The men had been missing since Friday, when their 21-foot powerboat apparently missed a two-mile channel and went over the five-foot dam. The boat was registered to Robert S. White, 75, of Queens. The other boaters, Peter Danchuck, 73, of Brooklyn and Michael T. Dawry, 73, of Queens were retired city police officers, the state police said. The identities of the bodies were not yet confirmed, the state police said.

title: BALLET REVIEW;A Demure Juliet, Tcherkassky's Farewell
description: Marianna Tcherkassky, one of the dance world's loveliest ballerinas, closed her 26-year career with American Ballet Theater on Saturday night amid much affection and celebration.

title: E. Wemple, 75; Shaped Landscape Of Los Angeles
description: Emmet L. Wemple, a noted Los Angeles architect who let others design the structures while he concentrated on turning their settings into landscaped works of art, died on June 5 in Los Angeles, the city whose public face he helped shape for more than 40 years. He was 75.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Weird Case Of Mother Love
description: For five years, the chief artistic goal of Opera Manhattan has been to present younger professional singers in occasional concert performances of neglected operatic works. But Opera Manhattan has been equally dedicated to raising funds for AIDS research and care. Fifty percent of the profits are donated to AIDS organizations; to date, its total gift has been more than $50,000.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bad Year for Strawberries
description: New Jersey's strawberry crop is smaller than usual, and market prices have risen to reflect the shortage, some New Jersey farmers said last week. The unusual spring weather, in which a stretch of cold temperatures was broken by a three-day heat wave, is partly to blame, said John Ebert, co-owner of Springdale Farm and Market in Cherry Hill Township. His strawberry crops are as much as 25 percent smaller than last year's, and have been selling at $2.99 a quart, compared with $1.50 a quart. The crop is also suffering because many of the honeybees that farmers rely on to pollinate their crops are being killed by mites from Asia, said Bob Cooper, a consultant with the Gloucester County Agriculture Extension Service. TERRY PRISTIN

title: What Scandal?
description: On June 24, 1994, The Washington Times reported that "Croatia has become a major transit point for covert Iranian arms shipments to Bosnia with the tacit approval of the Clinton Administration."

title: INSIDE
description: A Brutal Turning Point

title: Economic Calender
description: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this wek.

title: Mel Allen Is Dead at 83; Golden Voice of Yankees
description: Mel Allen, the exuberant Alabaman who turned "How about that!" and "Ballantine Blast" into common parlance during a glorious reign as the voice of the Yankees, died yesterday at his Greenwich, Conn., home some time after watching the Yankees' game with the Cleveland Indians, his sister, Esther Kaufman, said. He was 83 years old.

title: No Headline
BASEBALL;The Mets Caught It, But Let It Slip Away
description: The Mets have seen this type of ending far too often this season. Sooner or later the repetition of late-inning disasters has to have a numbing effect. In some ways it is easier to lose by nine runs -- as the Mets did on Friday -- than to be beaten the way they were this afternoon at Busch Stadium.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Limiting Use of Gene Tests
description: A bill that would bar health and life insurance companies from using the results of genetic tests to deny coverage to anyone is scheduled for a final vote in the Legislature today. The bill would make it a felony to use or disseminate test data without a person's consent.

title: Seagram to Post Settlement Gain
description: The Seagram Company will record a gain of about $60 million in its second quarter related to the settlement of a 15-year-old tax case with the United States Government, a company executive said on Friday.

title: Trial to Begin for Arkansas Bankers
description: Two bankers appointed to state positions after contributing to President Clinton's 1990 gubernatorial campaign are scheduled to go on trial on Monday, accused of stealing from their bank to cover their political contributions.

title: ON BASKETBALL;Sonics Forget Lessons That Managed to Get Them Back to Chicago
description: The little Seattle schoolhouse did not make the trip. The lessons learned at home were forgotten on the road.

title: G.O.P.'s Whitewater Report Is Expected to Raise Questions Over ClintonTax Filings
description: The Senate Whitewater Committee, in its final report, raises new questions about whether President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton properly reported their tax liabilities from the Whitewater land venture to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: The White House and the F.B.I.
description: With each new disclosure, the Clinton Administration's handling of sensitive F.B.I. files seems more maladroit and disheartening. While it remains unclear whether White House aides were pursuing a political agenda in rummaging through the files, it is now apparent that there was great potential for mischief. Both the White House and the F.B.I. showed remarkably little regard for the privacy rights of Americans in their cavalier treatment of background files on more than 400 men and women who worked in recent Republican Administrations, including former Secretary of State and Bush campaign manager James Baker.

title: Soros Quiet on His Bets
description: In recent days, people who follow the financial markets have speculated that large hedge funds like the Soros Fund Management, run by the international financier George Soros, may have bet that the price of copper would fall sharply, contributing to the market's instability.

title: POP REVIEW;Goodness Gracious, a Glimpse of a Legend
description: Here's one working definition of a pop legend: a musician of a certain age who makes rare appearances, charges top prices and performs for just under 45 minutes. Jerry Lee Lewis, the 60-year-old rockabilly piano pounder, did exactly that at Tramps on Friday night, starting a two-night stand with cranky arrogance.

title: Showboat Shares Rise 7%
description: The shares of Showboat Inc. ended 7 percent higher on Friday amid speculation that it would be acquired by another gambling company interested in entering or expanding in Atlantic City. Showboat closed at $34.125, up $2.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. On Thursday, MGM Grand Inc. said at a conference that the company would consider buying an Atlantic City casino with adjacent vacant land. That would rule out every Boardwalk property except Showboat.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;After a Few Anxious Days, Jordan and Bulls Get Their Title
description: The journey took longer than the Chicago Bulls expected, but the final reward was still sweet, satisfying and special.

title: City Lights in Istanbul
description: It started as a trading post, but by mid-century it boasted 30,000 residents, and in four decades ballooned to more than a million population, which then doubled in 20 years. This was no third-world megacity but Chicago in 19th-century America, where the rate of urban growth was as dizzying as anywhere in today's world. Our own experience affords a useful perspective for judging the Habitat II conference that has just ended in Istanbul. The global urban explosion is not novel or inexorable, and is not necessarily calamitous, contrary to the gloomy jeremiads it has provoked.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Copper Inquiry Broadens With Look at U.S. Company Expanding the investigations into the $1.8 billion in copper trading losses at Sumitomo, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is investigating ties between Sumitomo and Global Minerals and Metals, a New York company that has conducted extensive trading with the Japanese giant. Authorities in Tokyo, Washington and London are trying to determine who might have helped Yasuo Hamanaka, Sumitomo's chief copper trader, in the schemes that resulted in huge, undisclosed losses. [Page D4.] Are other potential time bombs lurking on the balance sheets of Japanese companies? Worrisome regulatory mechanisms and accounting procedures have stirred worries that there might be. [A1.]

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Debate over advanced TV gives the F.C.C. a chance to be assertive.
description: IN today's escalating struggle for control of the nation's communications networks, the Federal Communications Commission is where the battle between commercial and public interest rages visibly -- and where the winners can be different one day to the next.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Tunnel For Trains Is Considered
description: The New York region's three transit agencies plan to begin soliciting public comments today on proposals to build a $3 billion commuter rail tunnel beneath the Hudson River.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;New Work and a Touch of Nostalgia
description: When Morton Feldman wasn't composing he was encouraging younger composers, and in 1975 he started a new music festival at the State University at Buffalo, where he taught. The series, called June in Buffalo, included master classes, open rehearsals, seminars and concerts, and after his death in 1987, the school kept it going. These days it is directed by David Felder, but Feldman's spirit clearly lingers over it. His "Why Patterns?" (1978) was the main draw of a sampler concert, called June in Buffalo in New York, on Thursday evening at Goethe House, and although Mr. Felder was also represented by a powerful work, it was the intricate Feldman trio that lingered in memory for hours after the performance.

title: Sports of The Times;It's Time for Changing of Guard For United States Track and Field
description: BY 10 o'clock Saturday night the warm-up area near the track at Olympic Stadium was an intersection of raging emotions.

title: At '96 PC Expo, Laptops Reserve Center Stage
description: For the head-scratching futurists of the computer industry, the issue of the moment is whether the personal computer is on its last legs, to be replaced someday by a $500 "network computer."

title: No Headline
description: Our country has seen all the horrors that mankind has invented." GEN. ALEKSANDR I. LEBED, the Russian nationalist who was running third in the presidential election. [A1:6.]

title: No Headline
With Sumitomo Loss, U.S. Widens Commodities Inquiry
description: Broadening an inquiry into $1.8 billion in copper-trading losses run up at the Sumitomo Corporation of Japan, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of the United States is investigating ties between Sumitomo and the Global Minerals and Metals Corporation, a small New York company that has conducted extensive trading with the Japanese industrial conglomerate.

title: Lulled by Subtle Play, Kamsky Misses Fatal Threats
description: One way to win is to make a show of weakness, and when your opponents are lulled into taking it for granted, jump them and exploit their gullibility. That was what Anatoly Karpov did yesterday in Game 6 of the world championship match with Gata Kamsky in Elista, Russia.

title: POP REVIEW;Improvisations of a Guitar Perfectionist
description: On Wednesday night at Tramps, Tom Verlaine, the elusive guitar virtuoso who led the underground band Television in the 70's, performed his first solo concert in eight years. And Mr. Verlaine didn't make any concessions to nostalgic fans, including four new pieces and several obscure ones in a nearly two-and-one-half-hour set. Even when he threw the audience a bone by closing his show with "Marquee Moon," one of Television's crowning achievements, he turned it into an unfamiliar piece by extending it with nearly 15 minutes of sinuous improvisation and extra false endings.

title: U.N. Climate Report Was Improperly Altered, Overplaying Human Role,Critics Say
description: A former president of the National Academy of Sciences has joined an industry lobbying group in contending that unauthorized alterations were made in a crucial chapter of a recently published United Nations scientific report on climate change.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;. . . But Not on Turnpike
description: The inner and outer roadways of the New Jersey Turnpike will be closed at various times this week for routine maintenance, Jim Robinson, a Turnpike Authority spokesman, said last week. All lanes on the inner roadway, which is normally open only to cars, will be closed southbound between Newark and Woodbridge from 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. tonight, Wednesday night and Thursday night. The southbound outer roadway along the same stretch will be closed during the same hours Tuesday night.

title: Struggle for Oneidas' Leadership Grows Bitter as Casino Succeeds
description: To his supporters here in Oneida Territory, Ray Halbritter is the kind of leader Indian people have needed for generations. His shrewdness in dealings with white officials, they say, won his Oneida Nation the right in 1993 to open the only casino in New York State. Now, they say, he is using gambling as a foundation for rebuilding his nation, recapturing lost lands and traditions.

title: Patents;A little box holds out the enticing promise of the lowest long-distance rate every time you call.
description: ON your last long-distance call, did you engage in mathematical calculations? In the seconds between picking up the receiver and punching the last number, did you sift through the hundreds of rates -- based on time zones, time of day and miles crossed -- to find the best deal?

title: Carrying a Dream: The Pre-Olympic Event;The Flame Arrives in Upstate New York
description: As the Olympic torch relay made its way from Syracuse to Albany today, a relatively straight shot on what is generally -- pardon the expression -- a tortuous route through the nation, those who gathered to watch it pass reacted much like the woman here who barely had time to snap a picture but was affected nonetheless.

title: Blow to Peace in Ulster
description: The bomb that caused so much damage in downtown Manchester on Saturday morning, which bears all the trademarks of the Irish Republican Army, is widely seen as the most devastating setback yet to Northern Ireland's tortured peace effort.

title: Fight Over a Cathedral for Los Angeles Turns on Faith in the Soul of aCity
description: Like most major American cities, Los Angeles is always looking for that big development project that will spark the rejuvenation of its struggling downtown business district.

title: On Fringes of Health Care, Untested Therapies Thrive
description: From green algae pills to coffee enemas, from acupuncture to aromatherapy, alternative medical treatments have grown into a big business and a powerful force in modern medicine, alarming many in the medical establishment and largely escaping scrutiny from regulators.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Harper and Rodman Grab Their Brass Rings
description: Ron Harper, the only person in Chicago to sulk when Michael Jordan returned last year, told his coach he was starting tonight or "we're fighting." This sounded like something Dennis Rodman might think to say on his more rambunctious days, but then he is not a troublemaker anymore, remember?

title: In America;Crossing the Abyss
description: Lost in the spectacular media coverage of the arrest of John Royster for a series of nightmarish attacks on women was the spectacular police killing last Thursday of a suspected carjacker in Brooklyn.

title: No Headline
In Debris of a Bombing Laid to the I.R.A., the People of ManchesterCarry On
description: The day after a bomb suspected of being planted by the I.R.A. wounded more than 200 people here, there was little evidence of trauma today in Manchester.

title: Is Suspect in Attacks Fit to Stand Trial?
description: John J. Royster, who is at Bellevue Hospital Center for a psychiatric evaluation, will probably undergo another psychiatric examination to determine whether he is fit to stand trial in a string of attacks that left one woman dead and two comatose, a member of his defense team said yesterday.

title: The Great Mystery of Internet Profits
description: Luring talent has not been a problem for Mike Slade, president of the Starwave Corporation. The recruits to this startup company in suburban Seattle include refugees from well-paid jobs as editors, writers and advertising executives in New York and as software engineers in Silicon Valley. They have come to be pioneers in the new medium of publishing on the Internet's World Wide Web, to build a business and, if successful, to become rich.

title: Emerson and Ex-Chairman Settle Litigation
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation said Friday that the company, its chairman and his predecessor had settled litigation, with the chairman, Geoffrey Jurick, agreeing to give proceeds from future stock sales to his predecessor, Donald Stelling.

title: Mr. Pataki's Election Reform
description: Gov. George Pataki, who campaigned as a reformer but began his term as a business-as-usual politician, reclaimed his first, best image last week by proposing a critical election law reform. The Republican State Senate, which had resisted the idea for years, passed a slightly watered down version of the Governor's bill on Friday shortly after his surprise announcement. The measure now goes to the Assembly.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY

title: 2 Neighboring Schools Are Worlds Apart in Facing Fiscal Woes
description: Five blocks separate two very different public schools in New York City. One, Public School 9, has soared to popularity and academic success through the sweat equity of assertive middle-class parents. The other, P.S. 166, struggles with discouraging test scores, parental apathy and impoverished, low-achieving students.

title: I.B.M. Is Set to Begin Selling Laser Printers Once Again
description: I.B.M. is planning to announce tomorrow that it will start selling laser printers designed to be attached to networks of personal computers -- five years after spinning off its printer division for $1.5 billion.

title: Down to Wire For U.S. Talks With China
description: China and the United States reached the brink of a broad agreement early today on how to fight the piracy of music, movies and computer software, and negotiators appeared ready to call off $2 billion in trade sanctions that are scheduled to take effect later today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Dreams and Cultures Fade in a Roiling Melting Pot
description: ACCORDION CRIMES By E. Annie Proulx Illustrated. 381 pages. Scribner. $25.

title: Gunmen Kill an Israeli in West Bank
description: Gunmen shot at an Israeli family in a West Bank town today, killing the father and wounding the mother, Israeli officials said. Their young son was not hurt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Coke Upgrades Nestea Campaign
description: The Coca-Cola Company will try expanding the cola wars to another front with a marketing blitz for Cool from Nestea, a fast-growing brand of ready-to-drink iced tea aimed at younger consumers.

title: Netanyahu Is Ready to Talk to Syria, but Not to Yield
description: Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu today issued official policy guidelines confirming that his Government does not intend to cede the Golan Heights to Syria or to allow a Palestinian state, but declaring that he is ready for negotiations with both the Syrians and the Palestinian Authority.

title: Court Ruled Wisely on Prisoner Counseling
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OPEN;Love Rues the Bogeys That Cost Him a Title
description: It was nine years ago that the careers of Davis Love 3d and Steve Jones first intersected, on the final hole of the MCI Heritage Classic at Harbour Town Links on Hilton Head Island, S.C. Love was a promising young player, without a victory as a pro in his second season, a long-hitting wonder with limitless potential, and he was the leader in the clubhouse on a Sunday in 1987 when a fellow named Jones came to the 18th needing bogey to tie, par to win.

title: Soon, We Will Judge a Library by Its Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;YELTSIN AND COMMUNIST RIVAL TO BE PAIRED IN RUSSIA RUNOFF
description: Registering both their fear of the past and a cry for change, Russian voters on Sunday gave President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Communist opponent, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, enough support to face each other in a runoff election next month that will decide the future of the country.

title: MEDIA: PRESS;British newspapers are engaging in an exhaustive run of insider chatter.
description: By American standards, British newspaper journalism is a small and insular world that sometimes seems populated by surprisingly few people -- mostly the journalists, their friends and their enemies. They constitute a minuscule but powerful village that helps make up what Londoners call "the chattering classes," and many issues are devoted each week to their lives and opinions.

title: Age Bias Accord By British Gas
description: British Gas has agreed to pay $12 million to hundreds of women who were forced to retire at 60, five years earlier than men, a union said last week.

title: U.S. OPEN;Nicklaus's 40-Year String of Opens Is Over, It Seems
description: Jack Nicklaus left the door slightly ajar today, but very few United States Opens, if any, will make their way through it.

title: A Pre-Olympics Sweep Jails 765 in 3 Cities
description: Law-enforcement agencies have reported arresting 765 people described as career criminals and violent offenders in a 10-week sweep in Atlanta and two other Southern cities where spectator at the 1996 Summer Olympics are likely to visit.

title: OLYMPICS;Lacy Gets Basketball Berth
description: Venus Lacy, a former Louisiana Tech star, earned the final spot on the United States Olympic basketball team today, joining the 11 members of the women's national team that posted a 51-0 mark in exhibition play.

title: Big New Loss Makes Japan Look Inward
description: In the last several years, at least five Japanese companies have suffered huge losses from trading complex financial instruments, the most recent being the Sumitomo Corporation, which disclosed last week that a single copper trader had cost it $1.8 billion.

title: Equity Offerings Are Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Buenos Aires Journal;The Police May Need to Be Policed Themselves

title: TAKING IN THE SITES;The ABC's of Buying Foreign Stocks
description: Despite the incessant talk of a global economy, individuals who want to invest overseas might find that foreign stock exchanges seem very far away indeed.

title: I.S.D.N. Touted As a Contender
description: A Silicon Valley start-up company plans to introduce a small computerized system today intended to deliver on the promise of digital telephone system known as Integrated Digital Service Network, or I.S.D.N. for voice calls.

title: Pataki Proposes Allowing Sale of Insurance by Banks
description: In a move to broaden the potential operations of banks, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed yesterday that banks chartered by New York State be allowed to establish subsidiaries to sell insurance.

title: BASEBALL;Bullpen Helps Pettitte Notch 11th Victory
description: Over the last two seasons, nobody in the American League has had much success against the Cleveland Indians. Nobody but the Yankees, that is.

title: New N.E.A. Office Asks Corporations for Financing
description: For most of its 30-year history, the National Endowment for the Arts has been in the business of giving. Lately, it has been learning that it is also blessed to receive. Last week, the H. J. Heinz Company paid the first installment of a $450,000 gift to the endowment, the largest corporate gift the agency has ever received. The money, to be paid in equal parts over three years, will support arts programs for children that have been cut back or are in danger of being eliminated because of budget cuts imposed on the agency last year.

title: Sports of The Times;Normality Returns at Home for The Bulls
description: THE Bulls played this long and meandering season for the privilege to be home last night. The very good team from Seattle won 64 games, the 10th-best record in the history of the league, but the even better team from Chicago won 72 games, the best ever in pro basketball, and that superiority meant the Bulls would play the sixth game in front of their own people, and the seventh game, too, if necessary.

title: SOCCER;Mexico Ties U.S. to Take the Cup Title
description: In a frantic finish before a spirited Rose Bowl crowd of 92,216, Thomas Dooley's header in the final minute today gave the United States a dramatic 2-2 tie with Mexico in their U.S. Cup '96 showdown.

title: Woman Reports a Rape in Central Park
description: A 44-year-old homeless woman, who said she had fallen asleep in Central Park after a day of drinking, was raped near Wollman Rink early yesterday, the police said.

title: Metro Matters;A Victim Says Attack Injuries Never Heal
description: BEFORE a relieved city moves on, before the next crisis overtakes the latest and the memories of the horrific violence against four women begin to fade, Keirsten Rain wants people to understand something important. She wants them to understand that it is not really over and never will be for the victims.

title: Pandit Pran Nath, 77, Singer In Classical Hindustani Style
description: Pandit Pran Nath, an internationally renowned Indian classical singer and the teacher of leading American composers, died at Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley, Calif., on Thursday. He was 77, and lived in Berkeley.

title: Give Students Credit For Choosing Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: To Haggle or Not to Haggle on Car Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Mental Illness Is 'Real,' And It Has a Real Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Set to Introduce Personal Computer Line
description: Seven months after announcing its intention to enter the personal computer business, the Sony Corporation is expected to introduce its first two machines today, designed and built in the United States for the domestic consumer market. The "PC by Sony" will cost $2,000 to $3,000, depending on features, and will be available in August, people familiar with Sony's plans said.

title: Raytheon Completes Deal With Chrysler
description: The Raytheon Company said on Friday that it had completed its $475 million purchase of the Chrysler Corporation's aircraft modification and military electronics businesses, a day after settling Federal Trade Commission concerns about the transaction.

title: Reflecting on a Career, Tragic Heroines and All
description: Marianna Tcherkassky waddled across the floor of her dressing room at the Metropolitan Opera House the other day in a funny but all-too-convincing imitation of an exhausted dancer. She was to fill in that evening, unexpectedly, for an injured young ballerina. Not an unusual occurrence in the life of Ms. Tcherkassky, who has been a pillar of the American Ballet Theater for more than two decades. But this was also the week that she was to dance her last performance in New York with the company.
