title: Sports of The Times;Golf's New Jones Boy Is Inspired by Hogan
description: OF all the American names, Jones is one of the most common, but until now, the only Jones in golf was Bobby.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Budget Deal: Spending Cuts Overwhelmed by Rising Costs
description: Austerity never looked so good.

title: Soon, We Will Judge a Library by Its Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Overmatched Parents a Chance
description: Parents who are about to lose their children because of abuse or neglect are often at a legal disadvantage. Welfare authorities have the legal muscle of the city behind them. The children are generally represented by an experienced Legal Aid lawyer with a support network of social workers. But the parents are generally stuck with harried court-appointed lawyers who are juggling many cases, and who often show up unprepared and late for hearings. Given the possible consequences -- the loss of a child -- this is an intolerable imbalance that the city and private sources could help correct.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: CHECHNYA;Voting Reluctantly, When Shelling Eases
description: Most voters who went to the polls here today to elect the next Russian President and a new parliament for Chechnya were not happy.

title: Ex-Governor in Mexico Cleared in Killings
description: Judicial authorities in the southwestern state of Guerrero have cleared the former Governor of any connection to the killing of 17 leftist peasants a year ago, a state spokesman said today.

title: EU Fears Reform Efforts Are Stalled
description: BRUSSELS  Concern is growing across the European Union that its internal reform efforts are stalling, a development that could delay the membership ambitions of Central and East European countries.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Nude Club Under Siege
description: If the police vice squad has any say in the matter, all-nude dance clubs will not have a place in Atlantic City's upscale expansion plans. Undercover police offices raided Bare Exposure, the only such club in the city, as soon as it opened last August and arrested 10 dancers. Three of them pleaded guilty in Municipal Court to having physical contact with patrons, which the police say is considered a form of prostitution.

title: Bridge
description: The fourth in an unusual series of matches was played last month at the Capitol Hill Club in Washington. It was Corporate America vs. Congress, and it raised about $100,000 for the American Contract Bridge League's Educational Foundation and for the League for the Hard of Hearing. It was organized by Kathie Wei-Sender of Nashville and Patricia Cayne of Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the conclusions of the Republican majority of the Senate Whitewater committee incorrectly described the criminal conviction of Webster L. Hubbell. Mr. Hubbell was convicted of embezzling nearly $500,000 from his clients and partners at the Rose Law Firm, not Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Night Road Work On Hold
description: The Department of Transportation put a new policy of doing all highway construction at night on hold Friday in response to the predawn crash Tuesday morning that killed a New Jersey Turnpike maintenance worker. Transportation officials said they would meet with the turnpike employees' unions to address the concerns about worker safety that they voiced after the crash. Nighttime projects already in the works will continue, Transportation Commissioner Frank J. Wilson said.

title: No Headline
DANCE REVIEW;There Go Those Gobs With Their Fancies Still Free
description: Jerome Robbins's ballets are wonderfully varied, but they do bear family resemblances, as the New York City Ballet demonstrated at an all-Robbins program on Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, with a 52-week bill to be auctioned on Thursday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rival Candidates Agree
description: Ocean County residents concerned about the unusually high incidence of cancer among their children are getting support from both New Jersey Congressmen vying to succeed Senator Bill Bradley in the United States Senate. Representative Richard A. Zimmer, Republican of Delaware Township, said last week that Republican leaders had assured him that $1.2 million would be added to next year's Federal environmental budget to conduct a study in Ocean County, where 54 children have developed cancers of the brain and the central nervous system since 1979 -- 23 more than would have been expected.

title: To Haggle or Not to Haggle on Car Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Painter Is Chosen For Biennale
description: Robert Colescott, a painter whose bright, crowded figurative images satirize race relations in America, has been chosen to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale next year. Mr. Colescott, who is 71 and lives in Tucson, Ariz., was selected by the Federal Advisory Committee for International Exhibitions, which is part of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;End Near for Slaying Trial
description: Jury deliberations are set to begin today in a bizarre trial that has raised questions about the March 1995 slaying of Brenda Wolf during a bungled robbery of the Franklin Township jewelry store she owned with her husband. A. Peter DeMarco, an assistant prosecutor for Somerset County, told the jury in his summation last week that Mrs. Wolf was accidentally shot by her husband, Jeffrey, during a botched robbery involving five other people. But Joseph Hayden, the lawyer for Dr. Harry Insabella, a dentist who is the first of the five to be tried, said Mr. Wolf had lied about the circumstances of her death.

title: I.R.S. Ruling Clears the Way For Viacom's Cable Spinoff
description: Clearing the last hurdle in a regulatory steeplechase, Viacom Inc. said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had approved its plan to spin off its cable television systems on a tax-free basis to Tele-Communications Inc.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;YELTSIN COURTING LOSING CANDIDATES IN RUSSIAN VOTING
description: Having squeezed past the Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, in the first round of Russia's presidential election, President Boris N. Yeltsin on Monday began wooing the also-rans and maneuvering for a runoff date favorable to his voters.

title: Utility in Settlement With Chase Group
description: The Bonneville Power Administration said today that it had reached a $115 million settlement of a lawsuit filed by the Chase Manhattan Bank over the agency's decision last year to cancel its 20-year contract to buy electricity from a half-built power plant in Frederickson, Wash.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax for Schools Advances
description: A resolution that would ask voters to approve a school construction program to be financed by a 25-cent-a-pack cigarette tax increase passed its first legislative test yesterday when it cleared the Assembly Education Committee. Earlier this year, the Legislature rejected a plan to raise cigarette taxes to reimburse hospitals for treating uninsured patients.

title: Who Has Dole's Ear? Mostly Dole
description: Decision-making has long been a solitary process for Bob Dole.

title: Russia, Unchained and Uncertain
description: So in the end the contest for the Russian presidency comes down to two men shaped by Communism -- Boris Yeltsin, the apostate who broke with the Soviet faith, and Gennadi Zyuganov, still the acolyte. That seems fitting, for the voting patterns in the Russian election show a country still struggling to escape its past, and at least a generation away from making that leap.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lufthansa Forecasts Weak First Half
description: The German airline Lufthansa A.G. said yesterday that business had been disappointing so far this year. The airline said its traffic figures and financial results had lagged, but it did not confirm a report yesterday in Suddeutsche Zeitung, a major German newspaper published in Munich, that it had operating losses of 200 million marks, or $131 million, through the first five months of the year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GRAHAM-FIELD TO PURCHASE EVEREST & JENNINGS
description: Graham-Field Health Products Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the wheelchair maker Everest & Jennings International Inc. for as much as 1.8 million common shares and $14.4 million in cash. Based on Friday's closing price of $9 for Graham-Field shares, the transaction is valued at as much as $30.6 million. The stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $9.75, a 52-week high, while Everest & Jennings slipped 37.5 cents, to $4.50. Graham-Field, of Hauppage, L.I., said BIL (Far East Holdings) Ltd., the Everest & Jennings majority shareholder, would receive as many as 1.9 million additional Graham-Field shares for repaying about $25 million of Everest & Jennings debt. All the Everest & Jennings debt and convertible preferred shares held by BIL will be exchanged for about $60 million in Graham-Field convertible preferred shares.

title: Goldman, Sachs Earnings Register a Strong Increase
description: Heralding strong second-quarter earnings for Wall Street firms, Goldman, Sachs & Company earned $709 million before taxes for the three months that ended May 31 1996, John A. Thain, the firm's chief financial officer, said yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: The Eskimo Diet

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAY NETWORKS TO BUY SOME PENRIL DATACOMM ASSETS
description: Bay Networks Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire for $120 million the operations of Penril Datacomm Networks Inc. that remain after Penril distributes shares of its Access Beyond subsidiary to shareholders. Access Beyond, a maker of remote-access products, plans to go public and trade on the Nasdaq. After the spinoff, Penril's remaining operations will consist primarily of the digital signal processing modem business. Shareholders will receive one Access Beyond share for each Penril share held plus $10 in Bay Networks stock. Shares of Bay Networks fell 25 cents, to $26.875 yesterday; Penril stock rose $3.625, to $13.625. Bay Networks, based in Santa Clara, Calif., will also assume some of Penril's debts.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Petroleum Stores
description: The BP Oil Company opened 21 BP Express convenience store-service stations today and said it would open another 20 by the end of the year. BP Oil, a unit of the London-based British Petroleum P.L.C., said the new stores were near Cincinnati and Dayton, Ohio, and in northern Kentucky. The company said the stores would sellpastries and muffins baked on the premises, dairy products, deli sandwiches and fresh fruit, in addition to other convenience store items.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about 13 low-performing New York City schools under state review misstated the status of three of them. Although Chancellor Rudy Crew has ordered that the schools -- Public School 121 in Manhattan, and P.S. 122 and P.S. 62 in the Bronx -- be closed and reorganized this summer, they remain under the jurisdiction of their community school districts. They are not part of a special school district under the control of the Chancellor.

title: Dell and F.T.C. In Accord on Patents
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had approved an agreement with the Dell Computer Corporation, settling charges the company failed to tell a computer standards group that it held certain patent rights.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Swissair Says U.S. Backs Link
description: Swissair, Delta Air Lines and partners have received antitrust immunity from the United States Department of Transportation for their plan to coordinate services, Swissair said today

title: A Broken Pipe Puts Asbestos On East Side
description: A middle-aged steam pipe ruptured and spewed a pressurized plume of asbestos-laden debris onto a leafy block on the Upper East Side yesterday, less than 48 hours after Con Edison replaced the joints that linked two sections of the pipe farther down the block.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG FLOWER PRESS TO BUY SCANFORMS IN STOCK SWAP
description: Big Flower Press Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Scanforms Inc. for about $26.5 million, including debt. Scanforms, a direct-mail company in Bristol, Pa., had about $27 million in revenue for the 12 months that ended on March 31. Big Flower's Webcraft Technologies Inc. produces direct-mail products, promotional games and stamps and lottery tickets. Under the deal, Big Flower will acquire Scanforms in a stock swap that values the company at $5.75 a share. Scanform's shares jumped $1.5625, to $5.125; Big Flower's shares were unchanged at $13.875. New York-based Big Flower publishes advertising circulars and television listings for newspapers and Sunday comics.

title: Officer Thwarting a Car Theft Kills a Teen-Ager
description: A 14-year-old Irvington boy was shot and killed before dawn Sunday by a Newark police officer who was thwarting the theft of a car belonging to the wife of Mayor Sharpe James, the authorities said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Mattingly Closes Down Hometown Restaurant
description: The former Yankee DON MATTINGLY has closed his signature restaurant in his hometown of Evansville, Ind., laying off all employees and blaming competition from new eateries.

title: A. Phillip Goldsmith, 88, Garment Industry Leader
description: A. Phillip Goldsmith, a fixture in the garment industry for decades and a donor to Jewish institutions, died yesterday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 88 and lived in New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: As Peres Bids Farewell, Netanyahu Faces Delay in Naming Cabinet
description: The newly elected Israeli Parliament was sworn in today with a trumpet fanfare and a poignant speech from the departing Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, but still without a new government.

title: Valedictorians' Dispute Hurts Senior Classmates
description: To the Editor:

title: Police ID Can't Stop Drug-Sniffing Dog
description: When a Maryland state trooper stopped a car for speeding on Interstate 95 on Saturday and the driver identified himself as a New York City police officer, the speeder might have expected to get away with just a warning.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Richard S. Lindzen;A Skeptic Asks, Is It Getting Hotter, Or Is It Just the Computer Model?
description: AS climate experts firm up their view that human activity is seriously altering the atmosphere, one voice stands out in clarion dissent. It is that of Dr. Richard S. Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a shoemaker's son from the Bronx who has risen through the academic hierarchy as a leading expert on the physical processes of the atmosphere.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Duran, Camacho Trade Taunts
description: HECTOR CAMACHO was shadow-boxing for the cameras, while ROBERTO DURAN taunted him in Spanish from ringside yesterday at a training session in Manhattan. No punches were exchanged, but some unkind words were.

title: Review/Fashion;Four Designers' Visions of the 'Resort' Look
description: Now that summer has unofficially arrived and early fall clothes are in the stores, it's time to think about the season after fall. Some designers think of it as "resort," others as "pre-spring."

title: Grand Jury Is Investigating Copper Trader
description: Federal prosecutors started a grand jury investigation yesterday into whether a small metals trading company on Fifth Avenue had any role in the copper trading scandal that has cost the Sumitomo Corporation at least $1.8 billion.

title: Court Rules for a Telescope
description: A proposed telescope in Arizona, long stalled by environmentalists, won approval today from a Federal appeals court. In 1994, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit blocked the telescope, on Mount Graham, saying an environmental review was needed. But Congress approved a law saying no further review was required, and the court today upheld that action.

title: Abraham Rosen, 85, Harlem Store Owner, Dies
description: Abraham Rosen, who founded a Harlem discount store that has survived recessions, fire and unrest among people of different heritage and skin color, died on Sunday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 85.

title: Household International Buying Labor's Credit Card Portfolio
description: Household International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Union Privilege affinity card from the Bank of New York Company for about $575 million.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte's Elbow Is A Concern
description: Joe Torre's office door remained closed for almost an hour yesterday afternoon while the Yankee manager talked with General Manager Bob Watson and the pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre about Andy Pettitte's tender left elbow and the possibility of trading for a pitcher. Pettitte believes he will make his next start, but that does not eliminate an obvious need if another injury shatters the team's depleted staff.

title: 4 More Southern Churches Burn; Causes Are Not Yet Known
description: Four more Southern churches, three black and one white, burned today, leaving congregations pained and confused and expanding the ever-growing caseload of Federal agents investigating the fires.

title: Mortgage Payment Delinquencies Decline
description: The percentage of homeowners behind in mortgage payments fell slightly in the first quarter but remained above the year-earlier level.

title: British Officials Harden Stand On Talks With I.R.A. Allies
description: Stiffening their position after the bombing in downtown Manchester on Saturday, Government officials said today that it would be much more difficult for Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., to be admitted to the nascent peace talks on Northern Ireland.

title: Bosnia Elections Would Reward Wrong Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Baptists' Evangelism to Jews Offends;Unpopular, but Biblical
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Consolidation By 2 Marketers
description: Two consumer marketers said yesterday that they had consolidated their accounts.

title: YACHT RACING;Conner and Dickson Taking On the World
description: In an unlikely alliance of two yacht skippers known for their verbal badgering of each other, Dennis Conner and Chris Dickson are planning to team up together for the 1997-98 Whitbread Round the World Race.

title: Bosnia Elections Would Reward Wrong Side
description: To the Editor:

title: New Plan for Coliseum Site Is Praised by Some Past Foes
description: Twelve years after it first planned a behemoth of an office complex where the New York Coliseum now stands, leading to a fierce battle with civic groups, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority outlined a new plan yesterday that has won support from some of the original plan's severest critics.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;When Nature Frowns on Bright Ideas
description: WHY THINGS BITE BACK Technology and the Revenge of Unintended Consequences By Edward Tenner 346 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: NYC;A Firefighter Proud to Be 'The Torch'
description: THE Olympic torch relay lumbered into New York yesterday evening by way of the Bronx, a part of the city bouncing back from the days when "torch" meant to burn down a building in an insurance scam.

title: Passing of Lead From Mother to Child Is Shown
description: SCIENTISTS have found the first direct evidence that a girl growing up in a lead-polluted environment can pass that lead on to her children, putting their intellectual and motor development at risk.

title: Volcano Eruption Darkens New Zealand Sky
description: A volcano on New Zealand's North Island spewed molten rocks into the air like "thousands of bright red skyrockets" today, blotting out the sun with an eight-mile-high plume of steam and ash.

title: BASEBALL;Run in 10th Rescues Mets From Bullpen
description: When Manager Dallas Green said that personnel changes were needed to shake up the slumping Mets, he got them in the form of Pedro Martinez and Paul Byrd, relief pitchers who Green hoped would energize a struggling bullpen.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VARLEN TO ACQUIRE RAILROAD-CAR PARTS MAKER
description: The Varlen Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Brenco Inc. of Midlothian, Va., a maker of railroad-car bearings, for about $165 million. Varlen, which engineers products for the transportation industry, is based in Naperville, Ill., and has been acquiring small companies as the global market for railroad parts expands. The acquisition would add 1,000 employees to Varlen's current 2,200. The deal values Brenco shares at $16.125 each. Brenco's shares jumped $3.75, or 31 percent, to $16; Varlen shares rose $1.75, to $24.75. Brenco's founding family, which controls about 20 percent of the 10.2 million shares, has a separate agreement to sell its shares to Varlen.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Sonics Left a Little Older, a Little Wiser
description: Poise and experience. The Bulls had it, and that's why they are world champions. The Seattle SuperSonics didn't, but there's always next year.

title: Biggest Evolutionary Challenge May Be Other Half of the Species
description: IF there were ever to be a truce in the raging battle of the sexes, it ought to be during that magical moment when the elaborate dance between coy females and insistent males has at last been resolved in the communion of copulation.

title: A Crusader Makes Celebrities Tremble
description: Charles Kernaghan is the labor movement's mouse that roared.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HA-LO INDUSTRIES TO GET TELEMARKETER IN STOCK SWAP
description: Ha-Lo Industries said yesterday that it would acquire Market U.S.A., the telemarketer, for about $67 million in stock. Ha-Lo, which distributes advertising products such as hats and T-shirts to Fortune 500 companies, professional sports teams and other organizations, agreed to exchange about 2.5 million shares of its stock for the closely held company. Ha-Lo's shares rose 50 cents each, to $27.25, in Nasdaq trading. Market U.S.A., based in Des Plaines, Ill., reported revenue of $37 million in 1995 and projects 1996 revenue of $50 million. The company has 16 calling centers in the United States and Canada.

title: Southern Baptists' Evangelism to Jews Offends
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Digital to Close a Plant
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it would close a plant in Colorado Springs by the end of September. The plant, which produces information storage products for computers, has about 250 employees. Digital Equipment, the computer maker will offer financial support and outplacement assistance to employees who lose their job as a result of the closing. The closing is part of a plan to integrate is systems business unit.

title: Questions on Merger
description: The proposed merger of Mount Sinai and New York University Medical Centers, which was unanimously approved yesterday by their respective boards, represents a bold attempt to strengthen the two academic hospitals to survive in a market dominated by managed care.

title: Tenneco To Acquire Pullman
description: Tenneco Inc., in another small move toward reorganization, said yesterday that it would acquire the Pullman Company, a privately held maker of automotive suspensions and other parts, for about $300 million.

title: Boy Is Stabbed to Death
description: A 12-year-old whose body was found in woods near his Little League baseball park over the weekend was stabbed to death, the state police said today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Mark Rises Against the Dollar On Yeltsin Showing in Voting
description: The German mark rose to a one-month high against the dollar yesterday as Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, led in the first round of balloting.

title: Fast-Acting Insulin Approved
description: Diabetics will soon be able to choose a new type of insulin that promises to work faster than current therapy.

title: Insignia Financial to Acquire Edward S. Gordon Company
description: Insignia Financial Group, the huge property management company in Greenville, S.C., announced yesterday that it would acquire the Edward S. Gordon Company, New York's largest commercial real estate company, for about $74 million.

title: TENNIS;Muster Feels Slighted by Seeding for Wimbledon
description: Despite his strong showing on grass last week, Thomas Muster was seeded seventh for Wimbledon today, five spots below his world ranking.

title: Southern Baptists' Evangelism to Jews Offends;Catch Up With History
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rare Stop for Olympic Torch
description: The Olympic torch is scheduled to arrive in Jersey City at 9:17 A.M. today and will make a rare stop at 6:30 P.M., when a brief observance will be held in Princeton Cemetery at the grave of Prof. William Milligan Sloane. By recruiting American athletes, Professor Sloane helped Baron Pierre de Coubertin found the modern Olympic games in 1896. Relatives of Professor Sloane and of Robert S. Garrett, the Princeton University student who was America's first Olympic gold medalist, are expected to attend.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Michael Kelly Named New Republic Editor
description: After a search that had media circles talking for months, Michael Kelly, a writer and editor at The New Yorker and formerly a reporter for The New York Times, was named editor of The New Republic yesterday. Mr. Kelly, 39 years old, succeeds Andrew Sullivan, who announced he was leaving in April.

title: OLYMPICS;An Olympic Invitation Comes 60 Years Late
description: The envelope was postmarked Frankfurt, Germany, and bore the return address of "Der Prasident, Nationales Olympisches Komitee fur Deutschland." It was delivered last month to an elderly, white-haired Jewish woman living in a two-story brick house in the Jamaica Estates section of Queens.

title: OLYMPICS;Slaney Stumbles, But Still Qualifies
description: It had been a day of scares. First, an errant hammer throw landed 30 yards from Carl Lewis during the qualifying round of the long jump. Then this. With 200 meters left in a gutsy race to make the Olympic team at age 37, Mary Decker Slaney felt a clip at her heels and she stumbled.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Blades's Manslaughter Conviction Gets Reversed
description: Circuit Court Judge Susan Lebow surprised Seattle Seahawks wide receiver Brian Blades today by reversing last Friday's jury conviction for manslaughter in the death of his cousin Charles Blades.

title: Countdown Begins For Shuttle
description: Countdown clocks began ticking today for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia on what could be the longest shuttle flight ever, but unfavorable weather may delay the liftoff.

title: Trenton Votes Strict Limits on Use of Gene Tests by Insurers
description: The New Jersey General Assembly gave final approval today to legislation that would ban health insurance companies from denying access or setting higher rates for individuals who are genetically predisposed to certain diseases.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;German Central Bank Is Glum on Recovery
description: Germany's central bank said today that the country's economy might not have turned the corner yet, and it called on the Government to reduce a thicket of regulations that it said had strangled growth and pushed the unemployment rate to double digits.

title: No Headline
description: We feel that Mrs. Lambert was not treated adequately at the time of the Berlin Olympics. She was an Olympic candidate who did not get a fair chance. We wanted to do something for her, we felt she deserved it."

title: Cyprus Amax Halts Plan to Sell Stock
description: The Cyprus Amax Minerals Company withdrew its plan today to sell 12 million common shares after losses by the Sumitomo Corporation caused the copper market to plunge.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Airport to Get New Building
description: Plans to build a $42 million air cargo building that will increase cargo capacity at Newark International Airport by one-third will be announced today, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. Construction of the new building, on the site of the former People Express passenger terminal, will begin in August and is scheduled to be completed in early 1998.

title: Fitzroy Maclean, War Hero And Author, Is Dead at 85
description: Sir Fitzroy Maclean, an intrepid Scot known for his farflung military adventures in World War II and his writings about faraway lands, died on Saturday at the home of friends whom he and his wife were visiting in the English county of Hertford. He was 85 and lived in Strachur House, the family home in Strachur, a village in the Scottish county of Argyll.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Phillips Faces D.W.I. Charges
description: Misdemeanor drunken-driving charges were filed yesterday in El Monte, Calif., against Lawrence Phillips, the former Nebraska running back and top draft pick of the St. Louis Rams.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italy's Slow Growth Raises Fears of Recession
description: The Italian economy, which last year registered the strongest growth in the industrialized world, is now close to recession, the Finance Minister, Vincenzo Visco, said yesterday. Italy's gross domestic product grew 3 percent in 1995, and the treasury was expecting the same again this year, but a slowdown in other European economies has muffled Italy's recent export boom.

title: An Inmate Takes a Big Risk to Save His Name
description: Arthur Morrison cuts an impressive figure in court. In his impeccably pressed, navy blue pin-striped suit, starched white shirt and rep tie, he seems every bit the lawyer -- until he starts presenting his case.

title: Mama Jazz' Bows Out
description: Jazz is a distinctly American art form, and the great jazz singers are among its foremost interpreters, transforming lyrics as Picasso and Cezanne transformed visual life. Betty Carter, Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan come quickly to mind. But no jazz singer has burned so spectacularly, and found such universal acceptance, as Ella Fitzgerald, who died last week at 79.

title: Mrs. Clinton Again Denies Knowledge Of Law Files
description: Responding to the Senate Whitewater committee, Hillary Rodham Clinton today repeated that she did not know how long-sought legal records wound up in the White House, as her lawyer attacked the committee's report as "the politically preordained verdict of a partisan kangaroo court."

title: Hospital Releases Victim In Westhampton Beating
description: Shane L. Daniels was released from the University Medical Center here this morning and taken to a rehabilitation center in Pennsylvania, three weeks after he was beaten into a coma in a fight outside a Westhampton Beach bar.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;An Internet Primer by 3 Newbies
description: Experienced Internet users often make sport of newcomers to cyberspace, scorching the so-called newbies for their lack of knowledge about the Internet and the way it works. But three newbies acquitted themselves especially well last week, writing one of the most lucid primers about the Internet yet seen.

title: Southern Baptists' Evangelism to Jews Offends
description: To the Editor:

title: Esquire Appoints A New Publisher
description: Valerie Salembier, the president of Quest magazine, who previously held executive positions at The New York Times, Family Circle and The New York Post, was named publisher of Esquire magazine yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;McGraw-Hill Settles Suit on Book Reselling
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies said today that it had reached an undisclosed settlement with seven used-book brokers and wholesalers accused of reselling used McGraw-Hill textbooks scheduled for destruction.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Holding of Violent Sex Offender Who Seems Likely to Repeat Crimes Will Be Argued
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can continue to confine a violent sexual offender who is considered likely to repeat his crimes, but who has served his sentence and does not meet the ordinary criteria for being committed as mentally ill.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japanese Trade Surplus Slows for an 18th Month
description: Japan's global trade surplus slowed in May for the 18th consecutive month, declining 61 percent, and the surplus with the United States narrowed 40 percent, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sex Crime Law Still on Hold
description: A Federal judge has extended until July 3 his order barring county prosecutors from alerting communities about the whereabouts of paroled sex offenders. Judge John W. Bissell's March 15 injunction against that portion of "Megan's Law" had been scheduled to expire yesterday. The judge will hear arguments next Monday on the constitutionality of the notification provisions of the law.

title: Finish the Budget in Albany
description: Negotiations on the New York State budget are at an impasse. Not only is the budget the tardiest in history, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature have become increasingly irresponsible, with both sides multiplying demands just when they should be narrowing their differences. The deadlock poses a threat to the financial integrity of the state and its local governments and school districts.

title: First Union Agrees to Buy 2 More Bank Companies
description: The First Union Corporation, which has been growing rapidly, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two more bank companies, one in Connecticut and the other in Florida, for a total of $715 million.

title: Support Builds for Killer Who Broke Cycle of Fear
description: John Harper Jr. was the bully of Dictionary Hill.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. DIAGNOSTIC LABS TO ACQUIRE MEDITEK HEALTH
description: U.S. Diagnostic Labs Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Heico Corporation's Meditek Health unit for $13 million in cash and $10 million in securities. Miami-based Meditek Health owns diagnostic-imaging facilities in New Jersey, Florida, Georgia and Alabama. Heico, based in Hollywood, Fla., and U.S. Diagnostic Labs of West Palm Beach, Fla., both provide diagnostic-imaging services. Heico said the $10 million in securities could be converted into about one million U.S. Diagnostic common shares. Heico shares rose $1.625 to close at $27.375. U.S. Diagnostic shares closed unchanged at $14.125.

title: David Mourao Ferreira, 69, Lisbon Author
description: David Mourao Ferreira, a leading Portuguese writer of essays, fiction and poetry, died of cancer Sunday, his family said. He was 69.

title: East Germany's Dissidents Join An Old Battle
description: Organizers of the mass protests that toppled East Germany's Communist Government in 1989 joined with powerful politicians today to form an advocacy group that aims to help victims of East German authoritarianism.

title: Justices Will Handle Dispute Over Investigating Gun Buyers
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether a new Federal gun-control law violates state sovereignty by assigning local sheriffs the job of checking whether prospective gun purchasers have criminal records.

title: Corrections
description: A highlighted excerpt on Saturday in some editions from a Federal Bureau of Investigation report about how its employees furnished the files of more than 400 people to the White House carried the incorrect attribution. It was the F.B.I.'s counsel, Howard M. Shapiro, not Director Louis J. Freeh, who prepared the report and wrote: "It is incumbent upon us to . . . acquire . . . the proper balance between the very real and significant needs of the Government . . . and our profound obligation to ensure that the information only be disseminated in appropriate circumstances."

title: Ferruzzi Changing Name
description: The Italian energy and chemical company Ferruzzi Finanziari S.p.A. is changing its name and moving its official headquarters to further distance itself from recent scandals and near collapse. The company said on Saturday that its new name would be Compagnia di Partecipazioni Assicurative ed Industriali, or Compart. The company also changed its legal headquarters to Milan from Ravenna.

title: Pentagon Says It Has No Proof Of U.S. Captives in North Korea
description: The Defense Department insisted today that it had "no conclusive proof that Americans are being held against their will" in North Korea, even though an internal Pentagon report has suggested that as many as 10 to 15 American prisoners of war are still alive there.

title: Critics Attack Senate Bill To Aid Timber Company
description: Last week, Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska introduced a bill to give a highly unusual long-term timber contract to the Ketchikan Pulp Company, saying the arrangement was vital to the economy of the small town of Ketchikan in Alaska's panhandle.

title: New Branch Of Primate Family Tree
description: A CURIOUS, squirrel-size marmoset from the Amazon rain forest is the sixth new monkey species to be discovered in Brazil since 1990, and a scientist predicts that several more primate species will be found there by the end of the century.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHOENIX NETWORK INC., San Francisco, a provider of long-distance telecommunications management services, agreed to acquire Americonnect Inc., of Park, Kan., which buys and resells long-distance services, in a stock swap valued about $14.2 million.

title: U.S. Says Profits Rose in Quarter
description: Profits of manufacturers rose strongly at the beginning of 1996 after a weak finish in the closing quarter of 1995, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Gore Attacks Dole on Aide's Use of Quotations
description: When the Clinton White House has a tough job to do like squashing Ross Perot -- it turns to its Tennessee Terminator, Al Gore. Today the Vice President unleashed his full fire on Christina Martin.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;In Algeria, 27 Militants Get Death in Absentia
description: Two Algerian courts sentenced 27 Muslim militants to death in absentia for involvement in guerrilla activities, the official Algerian news agency said today.

title: Sports of The Times;The Genuine Jordan Puts Family First
description: HE couldn't hit a jump shot, and he cried like a baby. Michael Jordan was almost an ordinary man here Sunday night, physically exhausted and emotionally spent. More human, more appealing, more like the Mike we could all very well be.

title: Founder of Program to Build Students' Self-Respect, and Houses, Wins'Genius' Grant
description: Many of Dorothy Stoneman's friends went south to join the civil rights movement after college. Ms. Stoneman, who graduated from Harvard in 1963, went to Harlem, and stayed for 25 years. She founded a community service program that gave alienated, unemployed young people hope -- and skills -- by putting them to work rebuilding poor neighborhoods.

title: White House Announces Leave For Official Who Collected Files
description: Battered by criticism of its handling of confidential F.B.I. files, the White House announced tonight that the head of the office that collected them was being placed on administrative leave.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung Cuts Back Chip Production
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest memory chip maker, said yesterday that it shut its semiconductor plants on Sunday for the first time in more than four years to cut output.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Michael Burns, executive vice president and core group director overseeing the General Mills Inc. account at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was promoted to the new position of vice chairman.

title: New Israel Premier Accepts Religious Party Terms
description: Agreements signed by Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu and his religious party allies in the incoming Israeli government have spelled out the price that the Orthodox Jewish parties exacted for taking part in the new coalition.

title: Dance Notes
description: Competing for the Gold

title: CHRONICLE
description: You can't say that ISAAC MIZRAHI, the fashion designer, is not grateful to his pediatrician, Dr. BERNARD GREENBERG. In tribute to his former doctor, he is leading a fund-raising effort for the pediatric intensive-care unit at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, with which Dr. Greenberg, 83, has been affiliated for 48 years. Today, Mr. Mizrahi is to be the guest of honor at a luncheon at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Judge Allows Lawsuit Against Film Studios
description: A Federal judge ruled today that a sweeping price-fixing lawsuit against the major film studios can proceed, raising the possibility that Hollywood's accounting practices will be scrutinized in open court.

title: TV SPORTS;Allen's Distinctive Baseball Voice Entertained Generations of Fans
description: A different Yankee regime, the classless and cruel bunch, fired him after the 1964 season. The current owner will fly Yankee Stadium flags at half-staff through tomorrow for Mel Allen, the Voice of the Yankees, who died at the age of 83 at his home in Greenwich, Conn., on Sunday sometime after watching a Yankee victory. It is hoped that a plaque in the stadium's Memorial Park in left-center field will follow.

title: Dole Expresses His Confidence Of Healing Split on Abortion
description: Bob Dole said today that he was trying to heal the rifts on abortion within the Republican Party and that he expected his efforts to pay off.

title: INSIDE
description: More Church Fires

title: By Design;Nostalgia at the Beach
description: The bikini is back. And so is the swim dress, which used to be the choice of the middle-aged but now comes in perky youthful styles.

title: Murder Suspect's Father Sends Note Promising Help
description: From a maximum-security prison here, John P. Royster wrote a note today to his 22-year-old son. The father told the son that he loved him and would do everything in his power to help him weather his arrest on charges of killing a woman and assaulting three others.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Haitian Militia Leader Is Freed From U.S. Prison
description: A Haitian militia leader accused of killing or maiming hundreds of Haitians has been freed from a prison in Maryland where he had been fighting deportation, his lawyer said today.

title: Stocks Are Mixed as Dow Posts a Slight Gain
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday as a rally in bonds failed to shake investor concern that profits would fall short of expectations later this year.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Best of Times to Increase Computer Memory on the Cheap
description: RANDOM access memory, better known as RAM, is cheaper than ever. Just a year ago, eight megabytes of the most common form of RAM for personal computers cost about $270; today you can get it for about $70. That is not much more than the price of dubious software that claims to, but does not actually, "double your RAM."

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Bulls Stop to Ponder the Road Ahead
description: As the Chicago Bulls poured Champagne on Sunday night, uncomfortable questions about their future spilled into the celebration.

title: At Funeral, Memories of a Good Life
description: The traffic stopped at 11 A.M. yesterday around the Church of St. Sebastian in Woodside, Queens, as a hearse pulled up on Roosevelt Avenue, under the shadow of the elevated subway tracks, and the friends and family of Evelyn Alvarez came together to say goodbye.

title: On My Mind;$1 Billion Less, Please
description: The time has come for Israel to do itself and the U.S. a major political favor -- volunteer to take less American economic aid, or none at all.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHIVA PLANS EARNINGS CHARGE AFTER AIRSOFT PURCHASE
description: The Shiva Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the Airsoft Corporation, a closely held communications software developer, for $64.9 million in stock and would take a second-quarter charge of about $2 million for the purchase. Shares of Shiva, based in Burlington, Mass., tumbled $5.75, to $79.25, on the Nasdaq because of "concern about the slight dilution" of earnings in the current quarter from the acquisition, said James McCall, a portfolio manager at Pilgrim Baxter & Associates. Airsoft is not profitable and had 1995 sales of less than $1.5 million, Frank A. Ingari, Shiva's chairman, said. Airosoft specializes in developing communications software for branch office users' access to corporate networks.

title: ON BASEBALL;Yanks Having a Ball And Torre Leads Way
description: Of the 14 men who have managed the Yankees during the George Steinbrenner ownership, several hold noteworthy distinctions. Yogi Berra, for example, has been a singular man of his word. When Steinbrenner fired him 16 games into the 1985 season after saying he would manage 162 games, Berra said he never would return to Yankee Stadium while Steinbrenner was the owner. And he has stuck to that promise, inducements in the form of honors and payments notwithstanding.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's;Where Shouting Doesn't Do
description: Rodney Kendrick's 'Last Chance'

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Butler Begins Treatments
description: Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder BRETT BUTLER began radiation treatments for throat cancer yesterday. The treatments, which will continue for six weeks, started at a clinic in Atlanta, a family friend said.

title: Reversing Cuts, Pataki Gives Boost to Investigation Office
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that he was revamping the office that investigates corruption in state government, which he had left with little staff for much of the first year of his administration after dismissing nearly all its workers.

title: Valedictorians' Dispute Hurts Senior Classmates
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Trial Date Set for Irvin
description: Dallas Cowboys receiver MICHAEL IRVIN's drug-possession trial will begin next Tuesday, a Dallas court ruled yesterday. Irvin and two topless dancers were re-indicted Friday, two days after a judge voided the original charges because a member of the grand jury that indicted them April 1 lived outside the county.

title: Nudging TV On New Rule For Children
description: While the Federal Communications Commission is busy writing a new rule this week to require television stations to broadcast three hours a week of educational programs for children, momentum is gathering to help broadcasters comply.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: World Cup Qualifying

title: Observer;Baseball for Hitler
description: Baseball turned its back on Adolf Hitler last week. As the team owners said in a formal statement, "When your business has troubles as bad as ours, who needs to mess around with Der Fuhrer?"

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOEWEN AND BLACKSTONE TO MAKE JOINT PURCHASE
description: A joint venture of the Loewen Group and the Blackstone Capital Partners 2 Merchant Banking Fund L.P. agreed yesterday to buy Prime Succession Inc., a privately held operator of 146 funeral homes and 16 cemeteries in the United States, for about $295 million. Blackstone Capital will control the venture's board. Loewen's ownership in the venture was not disclosed. Blackstone Capital is an investment vehicle of the Blackstone Group. Loewen, based in Burnaby, British Columbia, operates funeral homes and cemeteries.

title: Canada Warns U.S. on Law Penalizing Cuba Commerce
description: Canada threatened retaliatory measures today against a United States law that penalizes Canadian and other foreign companies doing business in Cuba.

title: New Cancer Drug Approved
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the second in a new class of anti-tumor drugs for people with colon or rectal cancer that has recurred or spread.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After slipping badly, Bates USA works to regain its footing.
description: AFTER a year of living difficultly that included the departures of longtime clients and top managers, Bates USA is striving to regain its footing with an ambitious series of steps from bolstering offices outside its New York headquarters to bettering creative output.

title: After 26 Years, a Medal
description: Alvin Saltzman, a former marine who was once mistaken for dead and zipped into a body bag after a mortar attack during the Korea War, has finally got his purple heart.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VOICE CONTROL SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY VOICE PROCESSING
description: Voice Control Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Voice Processing Corporation, a developer of speech-recognition computer technology, for more than $40 million. Voice Control said the purchase price included four million of its shares, which fell 12.5 cents, to $10.125, in Nasdaq trading. Shareholders of Voice Processing, based in Cambridge, Mass., will own about 30 percent of the combined company's fully diluted shares after the transaction. Dallas-based Voice Control supplies speech-recognition and speaker-verification technology.

title: Joseph R. Shapiro, 91, Art Museum Founder
description: Joseph R. Shapiro, a prominent art collector and philanthropist who was the founding president of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago and an active trustee at the Art Institute of Chicago, died on Sunday at a hospital in Oak Park, Ill. He was 91 and lived in River Forest, Ill.

title: An Avoidable Crash
description: The April 3 crash of the Air Force jet carrying Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and 34 others was an unnecessary tragedy, according to the official Air Force investigation. There were three independent causes, in the language of the report, "any one of which, had it not existed, would have prevented the accident." If a general had obeyed orders from Washington, or if the crew had not cut so many corners in a rush to a tricky landing at Dubrovnik, Croatia, or if the landing pattern had been properly designed, the plane would have landed safely.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY TO CUT 1,300 JOBS
description: Vishay Intertechnology Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 1,300 jobs from its worldwide staff of 18,000 as part of a plan to cut manufacturing costs because of slow business. Vishay, a maker of electronic components based in Malvern, Pa., expects its reorganization to reduce second-quarter earnings by $16 million. Profits in the corresponding quarter last year were $24.7 million. Felix Zandman, Vishay's chairman and chief executive, said the job cuts were expected to result in annual savings of $24 million a year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Valujet Forced to Halt Its Operations Indefinitely The Federal Aviation Administration shut down Valujet indefinitely, saying that an evaluation begun after the airline's May 11 Everglades crash had turned up "serious deficiencies" in its operations. David R. Hinson, the agency's Administrator, said those included "multiple shortcomings" in its supervision of maintenance contractors.

title: N.B.A. FINALS;Bulls Score In TV Ratings
description: NBC's telecast of the Bulls' title-winning victory over Seattle in Game 6 of the National Basketball Association finals Sunday night generated a 20.9 overnight Nielsen rating, compared with a 14.1 in 1994 and a 21.8 in 1993. There was no Game 6 last season. The finals produced the second-highest five-game national average, a 16.3 rating, behind the 17.6 for the Bulls-Suns in 1993.

title: Genes and Insurance
description: The New Jersey General Assembly approved legislation that would ban health insurance companies from denying policies to -- or setting higher rates for -- people who are genetically predisposed to certain diseases. Although 11 other states have similar laws, New Jersey's measure is considered the most comprehensive because it covers both genetic testing and genetic information, like family history.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN WASHINGTON;U.S. Officials Praise Outcome And Express Guarded Optimism
description: Heaping praise on Boris N. Yeltsin and congratulating him on a "strong showing" in the first round of Russia's presidential elections on Sunday, President Clinton today all but endorsed Mr. Yeltsin in his coming head-to-head contest with the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov.

title: Patterns
description: Helmut Lang Casuals

title: Who Will Come to Duck's Rescue? Ancient Forebears Are Enlisted
description: IN what researchers say would be the first use of ancient DNA in a recovery plan for an endangered species, scientists are proposing that a duck known only from the tiny island of Laysan be introduced to other Hawaiian islands where fossil bones containing its DNA have been found.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Faces More Charges
description: A Jersey City police officer who was charged last year with beating a man to death was indicted Friday on charges of aggravated assault stemming from a separate incident, prosecutors said yesterday. Officer John Chiusolo beat German Barrantes in the head with a blunt metal baton known as a "come-along" after pulling him over for a traffic violation on May 4, 1995, said Edward J. DeFazio, first assistant prosecutor for Hudson County. Three days later, Officer Chiusolo got into a scuffle with another driver that resulted in the man's death.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 22,322.40, up 87.02 points, or 0.39 percent. On Monday, the Nikkei slid 44.01 points.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Saying It Erred, Tribunal On War Crimes Frees Serb
description: The United Nations criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia freed a Bosnian Serb today, saying it seemed to have been prosecuting the wrong man.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE KINGMAKER;From War Hero to Populist Politician
description: The retired general who came in third in Sunday's presidential race, and whose endorsement is now avidly sought by Boris N. Yeltsin, has been caricatured as a strident nationalist determined to rebuild the Russian empire on the ashes of the old Soviet Union.

title: Nothing Simplistic About Divine Camera
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun's Cruise Through Space Is About to Hit Bumpy Patch
description: OVER the last five million years or more, the Sun and its planets have had the good fortune to be gliding through one of the safer neighborhoods of the Milky Way galaxy. They have generally avoided the congestion and turbulence in evidence a few cosmic blocks away. But these halcyon days may be coming to an end.

title: F.A.A. Shuts Down Valujet, Citing 'Serious Deficiencies'
description: The Federal Aviation Administration shut down Valujet Airlines indefinitely tonight, saying an intensive evaluation, begun after all 110 people aboard one of the carrier's planes were killed in a crash last month, had turned up "serious deficiencies" in its operations.

title: Sarajevo Journal;Remembering Radovan, the Very Best of Friends
description: A block up the hill from both the American Embassy and the headquarters of NATO forces in Bosnia, the residents of an old Sarajevo neighborhood keep asking a question foreign diplomats and military commanders are having a difficult time answering.

title: ART REVIEW;A Museum's Metamorphosis: The Virtual Arcade
description: The Guggenheim Museum SoHo is back, all teched out and ready for the art of the 21st century. After a five-month renovation, the museum has reopened with "Media scape," an often dazzling display of 14 multimedia works, interactive and otherwise, that veers from fun-house madness to high, even pretentious, seriousness.

title: Average Car Price $20,000? Not Quite, It Seems.
description: When the Commerce Department calculated in late 1994 that the average price of a new car had broken the $20,000 level for the first time, the result was an immediate outcry over whether cars had become too expensive.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Drowns in Pool, Unseen
description: Sussex County authorities are investigating the drowning death of a 23-year-old man who they say lay at the bottom of a crowded pool at a Vernon Township health resort, the Spa at Great Gorge, for 15 minutes on Saturday without being noticed. Swimmers pulled the man, Jermaine Jackson, of Newark, out of the pool at a point where it is 14 feet deep at 5:34 P.M., the police said.

title: In Quests Outside Mainstream, Medical Projects Rewrite Rules
description: Ann Gill Taylor, a professor of nursing at the University of Virginia, thinks magnets may be the solution for a problem that has perplexed doctors for decades: chronic pain.

title: We All Stand to Lose in Orange County Fiasco
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Boris Leavitt, 91, a Pioneer in Direct Marketing
description: Boris Leavitt, a founder of one of the country's first successful direct-marketing companies and a collector of contemporary art seen in museums throughout the country, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 91 and lived in Palm Beach.

title: The House Is Putting Itself in Order
description: Just last year, a Price Waterhouse official called it "one of the worst-run organizations" the giant accounting firm had ever reviewed. Bookkeeping practices dated to the late 1700's and were so sloppy that auditors could not account for millions of dollars.

title: A Dangerous Game On Abortion
description: Can there be a truce in the abortion wars? A lot of people would like to think so. Bob Dole hopes that adding a rider on tolerance will take the sting out of the plank in the Republican platform that calls for a ban on all abortion. The feminist writer Naomi Wolf wants pro-choicers to acknowledge abortion as a "sin" and "moral iniquity" that is sometimes necessary, but sometimes a selfish indulgence. The Common Ground Network for Life and Choice tries to get activists on both sides to lower the decibel level, so that they can work together to lower the rate of unwanted pregnancies.

title: Southern Baptists' Evangelism to Jews Offends;A Need to Reach Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasuries Continue To Advance
description: Treasury prices rose for the third consecutive session yesterday as uncertainty mounted over whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next month.

title: BASEBALL;Mendoza's Failure Leaves the Yankees No One to Turn To
description: If General Manager Bob Watson wants to pursue a pitcher to enhance the Yankees' ragged rotation, the price surely escalated last night when the rookie Ramiro Mendoza stumbled through another sluggish start, continued to prove he is not ready for the major leagues and left Joe Torre confused and helpless.

title: In Attacks Case, Both Sides to Focus on Suspect's State of Mind
description: In the coming weeks, prosecutors and defense lawyers will be elbowing each other in an energetic attempt to peer into the cluttered mind of John J. Royster, the man charged with killing a Park Avenue dry cleaner and beating up three other women. Who is he, both sides will ask, and what made him snap?

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Nigeria Rulers Announce Steps Toward Democracy
description: Nigeria's military rulers announced tough guidelines for political parties today in what they have described as a gradual transition toward democracy.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Work Out Prospects
description: The Knicks, who have three first-round draft picks this year, yesterday worked out Kobe Bryant, a 17-year-old high school phenom, at SUNY-Purchase after they worked out Jermaine O'Neal, the other high school player in the National Basketball Association draft.

title: The New Buzz: Growth Is Good;Latest Strategy for Business Is a Positive Spin on Layoffs
description: What a difference a few months make. When they agreed to merge this spring, Bell Atlantic and Nynex pointedly passed up an opportunity to announce the elimination of 3,000 "overlapped" jobs. New markets would open for the merged company, they insisted, saving the workers from layoffs. "We think we will create enough new jobs to redeploy most of those 3,000 people," said Ivan G. Seidenberg, Nynex's chairman.

title: U.S. OPEN: NOTEBOOK;Gritty Jones a Worthy Victor
description: For a pure, unadulterated test of grit, there is no golf championship quite like the United States Open. The Masters has its immense charm, the British Open its history and the P.G.A. Championship its niche as the last major, but none of them scrutinizes a golfer's game and dissects his psyche quite the way the National Open does.

title: Rebuffed, Western Resources Tries Again
description: Western Resources Inc. sweetened its bid for the Kansas City Power and Light Company by about 11 percent yesterday in an attempt to force Kansas City Power's board to reconsider its agreement to merge with Utilicorp United Inc.

title: Next Effort: Health Care On Internet
description: Don't call it Healthscape, and it's not a Web site. Jim Clark's new business, the third after founding Silicon Graphics and Netscape Communications Corporation, is called Healtheon, and it plans to provide information services to help health plans and employers better manage benefits programs.

title: U.S. and China Agree on Pact To Fight Piracy
description: After a month of intense negotiations, China and the United States reached a broad agreement today on how to crack down more effectively on the piracy of music, movies and computer software in China, and Washington halted plans to impose $2 billion in trade sanctions.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Styles pages on Sunday about the wedding of Brooke Elizabeth Jewett and Bernhardt Manfred Nadell referred incorrectly to the bride's grandfather Charles Wood Jewett. He is not dead. Mr. Jewett, who was Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut from 1955 to 1959, lives in Lyme, Conn., with his wife, Mary Sheafe Jewett.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Top Bands Rock And Rap For Tibet
description: Alternative rock and rap have long been caught in their own insular worlds of apathy and rivalry, respectively. But on Saturday and Sunday afternoon at Golden Gate Park, before a capacity crowd of 50,000 each day, some of modern music's top rockers and rappers embraced international politics in what may prove to be the year's biggest pop concert. The cause was Tibet, and though many of the musicians might not have known previously about the conflicts between Tibetans and the Chinese Government, which has occupied the country since 1950, after the concert ended on Sunday several performers' eyes filled with tears as the monks of Sera Je Monastery blessed them backstage and thanked them for donating their time, music and sympathies.

title: Foreign Chip Share Passes 30% in Japan
description: Foreign semiconductor makers took 30.6 percent of Japan's lucrative computer-chip market in the first quarter, American trade officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Thirteen members of the banking, political and philanthropic Lehman family returned yesterday to their ancestral home in Rimpar, Bavaria, in Germany, from which their forebears were driven 150 years ago.

title: Gene-Test Bills Weighed
description: Both the New York and Connecticut Legislatures have considered bills that would bar health insurance companies from using the results of genetic tests to deny coverage or set higher rates.

title: OLYMPICS;Top Gymnasts Seek to Skip Olympic Trials
description: For United States swimming stars and track and field stars, the rules are brutally clear: miss the Olympic trials and you miss the Olympics.

title: Market Place;After Orange County, MBIA's bond insurance is in demand.
description: FOR more than a year, shares of MBIA Inc. have been buoyed by expectations that the Orange County bankruptcy would be good for business. The stock rallied sharply after MBIA insured the California county's offering of nearly $900 million of new bonds this month. And yesterday, MBIA, the nation's largest insurer of municipal bonds, closed at a 52-week high of $79.875.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE IMPLICATIONA;Runoff Is Yeltsin's to Lose
description: When the Communist Party dominated Russian parliamentary elections last December, its leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, assumed that the vote was a down payment on future triumphs.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Behind Laughter and Love, Sadness
description: Bill T. Jones returns in a sense to his past in the second program presented by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company in its season at the Joyce Theater. The dances, performed on Sunday afternoon, have a good deal of the stylishness and playfulness that characterized much of what Mr. Jones created with Mr. Zane, who died in 1988.

title: 3 Apparently Drown
description: Three children who were swept away by the Delaware River during a family picnic on Sunday were still missing today and feared drowned.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;TBWA Chiat/Day Loses an Executive
description: Richard N. Costello, the president and chief executive of TBWA Chiat/ Day East in New York, is leaving unexpectedly, effective July 15, to head a new strategic marketing unit of MCA Inc. in Universal City, Calif.

title: Wax Immortality on 42d St.;Tussaud's Seeking Luminaries Worthy of Museum
description: Will Donald Trump make the cut? What about Howard Stern? Al Roker?

title: Aspirin Proposed for Suspected Heart Attacks
description: The Food and Drug Administration is proposing to let doctors prescribe aspirin for patients to take during suspected heart attacks.

title: Racial Redistricting Serves to Balkanize
description: To the Editor:

title: Albania Party Says It Won
description: Albania's governing party has announced that it won the country's general election by a landslide, the state-run television said today.

title: Market Place;H.M.O.'s are having trouble maintaining financial health.
description: MOST health maintenance companies had a disappointing first quarter, and the gloom is not expected to lift when they report their financial results again next month.

title: A Versatile Low-Fat Protein? There's Always Canned Tuna
description: SOME years ago, a food writer wrote that he was astonished about a lunch Julia Child served him that included a salade nicoise topped with canned tuna. He forgot, of course, that the classic version of the dish is supposed to have canned tuna.

title: Starts of Housing Fall 4.7% As Mortgage Rates Climb
description: Builders, concerned that rising mortgage rates would choke off sales, cut the construction of new homes in May to the lowest level in five months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUSERVE REPORTS SMALLER LOSS
description: Compuserve Inc. yesterday reported narrower losses in the fourth quarter than were expected. The company, the nation's second-largest on-line service after America Online, reported a loss of $1.1 million, or 2 cents a share, down from $58.4 million, or 79 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected a loss of 6 cents a share for the quarter. Compuserve attributed the loss to increased marketing, customer service and network costs, much of it related to its new WOW on-line service. Sales rose 31 percent, to $215.2 million, as the number of on-line subscribers jumped 67 percent over the fiscal year, to more than five million in 185 countries. H & R Block is spinning off Compuserve, and sold a 20 percent stake in April. The earnings were released after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares fell 87.5 cents, to $23.25.

title: Aviation Agency Seeks to Shift Its Mission, Focusing on Safety
description: The Secretary of Transportation said today that he would ask Congress to eliminate the Federal Aviation Administration's mandate to promote aviation and leave safety as its primary concern, one of a number of steps to improve the agency's image and effectiveness after the Valujet crash near Miami on May 11.

title: Case of 'Zodiac' Gunman Sparked Panic in 1990
description: In the first half of 1990, the shootings of four people -- one of whom, Joseph Proce, a 78-year-old Brooklyn man, died -- sparked a wave of panic in New York City and the assembling of the largest police task force in the city since the Son of Sam murders in 1977.

title: About New York;Joining Hands To Rebuild Church Ruins
description: REDUCED to flickering television images, the sight of black churches burned to the ground may feel remote here up North. Watching from the comfort of living rooms in a bustling metropolis, some people might feel outrage, but no threat.

title: AUTO RACING: NOTEBOOK;A Split Second From History
description: It was 29 years ago that A. J. Foyt won the world's two most famous auto races -- the Indianapolis 500 and 24 Hours of Le Mans -- within a few weeks of one another. Davy Jones, another American, came within one second of matching that feat this year.

title: 2 More Black Churches Burn, This Time in Rural Mississippi, andInvestigators Flood In
description: More than 50 Federal and state investigators today pored over the shells of two predominantly black churches, less than five miles apart, that were destroyed by fire within minutes of each other on Monday night.

title: Aviation Official Embroiled in Furor Over Valujet Crash Resigns
description: Anthony J. Broderick, a top official of the Federal Aviation Administration who announced today that he was stepping down in the furor over the crash of a Valujet plane, has for years exercised immense influence on world air safety.

title: Spared by Washington's Budget Cutting, Research Universities StillFear the Ax
description: While Congress in recent weeks has spared leading universities from major cuts in Federal financing for research, those institutions say they increasingly fear that the estimated $13 billion a year they receive from the Government will become a target for reductions in the future.

title: Spread the Word on Asia Rights Abusers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Champion Puts Account in Review
description: The Champion sportswear division of the Sara Lee Corporation has placed its account in review. With billings estimated at $10 million, the account has been handled by the Merkley Newman Harty unit of the Omnicom Group in New York for the last year and a half.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korea to Ease Foreign Stock Ownership
description: South Korea disclosed a four-step plan yesterday to raise the ceiling on foreign stock investment in a listed company to 29 percent by 1999. The widely predicted move is seen as preparation to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development later this year.

title: Singapore Officials Employed Damage Control
description: To the Editor:

title: In Mexico, Pain Relief Is a Medical and Political Issue
description: Everyone in the building knew that the old woman in the first-floor apartment was suffering unspeakable pain. Her screams echoed through the lobby day and night.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Whitman for One Bond Issue
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday she would back a $300 million bond issue that would provide money for dredging the Newark and Elizabeth ports, but would oppose the other bond issues that are pending in the Legislature, including measures to finance construction of housing, new prisons and schools.

title: No Headline
description: Generally speaking, I think the leadership of households in Omiya is taken by wives. Things go best when the husband is swimming in the palm of his wife's hand."

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Japan Is a Woman's World Once the Front Door Is Shut
description: In the old days that grizzled men remember sweetly, a wife like Noriko Mizuguchi would have been waiting up all night for her husband's drunken stumbling on the doorstep, so that she could fling open the door and kneel down with her forehead touching the floor as she called out, "Welcome home, honorable sir."

title: COMPANY NEWS;ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS PLANS TO TAKE A BIGGER CHARGE
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that it would have to set aside more money than earlier projected to pay for a restructuring since its spinoff from the General Motors Corporation. The company said it expected to incur a second-quarter charge totaling $850 million before tax, or $1.12 a share after tax. The company previously thought the charge would total $750 million at most. In addition, E.D.S. said it expected to earn 49 cents to 52 cents a share in the second quarter, before the charge. Analysts have been expecting about 51 cents a share, according to a survey by First Call Inc. Of the $850 million charge, E.D.S. said $277 million would go to severance costs and $513 million would go to write down the value of technology.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA ELLERBEE, the former television newscaster and commentator and president of Lucky Duck Productions, has reassessed her opinion of the brain power of journalists. "I used to think that they thought very fast on their feet," she said yesterday, a day after she concluded that journalists are outdone by improvisational actors.

title: Dole Tries to Talk About Jobs, but Tobacco Keeps Intruding
description: Bob Dole came to California with a message to deliver: that President Clinton was weak on defense and had hurt the state's mammoth defense industry. But Mr. Dole's own earlier remarks on tobacco have been dogging him here -- he has even been trailed by a person dressed as a cigarette -- and he has had to keep swatting at those echoes like so many flies at a picnic.

title: Thomas Kuhn, 73; Devised Science Paradigm
description: Thomas S. Kuhn, whose theory of scientific revolution became a profoundly influential landmark of 20th-century intellectual history, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73.

title: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
description: U.S. Senior Open

title: BASEBALL;Robinson Says He Wants To Run Reds
description: When Marge Schott was forced by her fellow owners last Wednesday to give up day-to-day control of the Cincinnati Reds through the 1998 season for continued use of racial and ethnic slurs, the speculation about whom baseball would approve as a suitable replacement immediately focused on a handful of career executives. Among them were the former Angels president Richard Brown and the former Pirates president Mark Sauer.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cowie of Britain To Buy British Bus
description: In a latest instance of consolidation in the British bus industry, the Cowie Group said yesterday that it would pay L282.3 million ($434.7 million) for British Bus Ltd. The purchase would give Cowie a 16 percent share of Britain's bus market, putting it third behind Firstbus P.L.C. and Stagecoach P.L.C.

title: Defense Demands Halt to Police Leaks on Suspect in Beatings
description: Lawyers for John J. Royster complained bitterly to a judge yesterday about statements the police made to reporters in the murder case, and they demanded that prosecutors turn over copies of the confessions Mr. Royster was said to have made to officials last week.

title: Something Must Be Done
description: Confused? You are not alone. Here's what the experts (sometimes the same one) think.

title: A Boston Bank Merger Gets an Approval
description: The Justice Department approved the $2 billion merger of the Bank of Boston and Baybanks today after they agreed to sell 20 branch offices to the U.S. Trust Company.

title: F.C.C. Considers A New Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission is considering auctioning airwaves used by a small number of TV broadcasters, F.C.C. officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OSICOM TECHNOLOGIES TO ADD BUILDERS WAREHOUSE
description: Osicom Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Builders Warehouse Association Inc. for about $60 million in stock. Osicom, based in Santa Monica, Calif., makes digital video switches for the telecommunications industry. Builders Warehouse, also of Santa Monica, develops advanced networking products. The deal values Builders Warehouse at $15.04 a share, based on current stock prices. Osicom plans to issue 0.94 share for each Builders Warehouse share. In trading yesterday after the news, Builders Warehouse shares slipped 25 cents to close at $14.75, while Osicom shares dropped $1.625 to close at $15.875.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Ayer Catches Madison Ave. Merger Wave
description: N. W. Ayer & Partners, the oldest and perhaps most troubled of the major American advertising agencies, said yesterday that it would be acquired by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, signaling a new crest in the wave of deals that are remaking Madison Avenue for the second time in a decade.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Forecast of Growth in Ad Spending Is Cut for a 2d Time
description: Madison Avenue's leading forecaster has for a second time reduced his estimate of how much marketers will spend this year to advertise in the United States. But the reduction is small and he still expects a spending record.

title: Therapist's Privacy Privilege Isn't Absolute
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte and Stiff Elbow Will Take a Breather
description: The Yankees decided yesterday to proceed with caution regarding Andy Pettitte's stiff left elbow, so they bumped him back two days in their precarious rotation and will start him on Sunday instead of Friday in Cleveland. But their decision to protect their best pitcher, however sound it was, forces them to proceed with even more caution on Friday at Jacobs Field.

title: Governors Island Historic District Created
description: More than half of Governors Island was designated a historic district yesterday, giving protection to the island's past but leaving its future still unpredictable.

title: Famine Threat Drives Thousands of Somalis From Homes
description: In the last six weeks, more than 9,000 people have fled from food shortages caused by drought, floods and clan warfare in the Juba River valley, just north of this devastated port city, United Nations officials and local Somali leaders say.

title: Poor Tape Means Dropping of Charges for Officer
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office has agreed to drop charges against a New York City police officer because a tape in which he supposedly admitted taking a drug dealer's money was nearly inaudible.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More Curfews for Youths
description: Staying out late is about to get much harder for teen-agers in northern Hudson County. Three neighboring towns -- Union City, North Bergen and Weehawken -- agreed yesterday to impose a 10 P.M. curfew for those under 18 starting Aug. 1. On Fridays and Saturdays, the curfew will be 11 P.M., Anthony Iacono, Union City's business administrator, said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MULTICARE TO ACQUIRE PROVIDER OF HEALTH CARE SERVICES
