description: The Multicare Companies agreed yesterday to acquire ADS Group, the largest provider of long-term health care services in Massachusetts, in a deal valued at about $100 million, including assumption of debt. Multicare, which owns and manages long-term-care facilities, plans to pay $62.6 million, assume or repay about $27 million in debt and issue 531,507 shares of its common stock to acquire ADS, which is based in Newton, Mass. The stock of Multicare, based in Hackensack, N.J., fell 12.5 cents, to $20.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Privately held ADS owns, operates or manages 23 long-term-care facilities and provides consulting services. It also manages 21 hospital-based units, most of them in Massachusetts, and five assisted-living facilities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Units Expanding At Interpublic
description: Two units of the Interpublic Group of Companies are expanding.

title: FILM REVIEW;Shoring Up a Campaign With Mud That Sticks
description: Who're you going to vote for, the flu or the mumps?" asks a voter in "A Perfect Candidate," a fine, trenchant political documentary on a par with "The War Room." In this revealing film about Virginia's 1994 senatorial campaign, that voter's frustration seems an all too reasonable response to the choice he faces. What's more, the film finds the seeds of a profound cynicism everywhere in its account of the race between Oliver L. North and the incumbent, Senator Charles S. Robb. It would be hard to find a more chilling view of the American electoral process than what "A Perfect Candidate" captures on screen.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.A.A. Seeks New Mission In Wake of Valujet Crash The Secretary of Transportation will ask Congress to eliminate the F.A.A.'s mandate to promote aviation and leave safety as its primary concern, one of a number of steps to improve the agency's image and effectiveness after the Valujet crash on May 11. Also, the F.A.A. will tighten its supervision of airlines that rely on contractors for maintenance, as Valujet did.

title: S.E.C. Proposes N.A.S.D. Censure to Settle Rules Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed that the National Association of Securities Dealers agree to be censured to settle administrative charges that it did not adequately enforce its rules at large brokerage firms, securities industry regulators said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Unabom Suspect Indicted

title: Yeltsin and Communists Jockey for Advantage on Runoff Vote Date
description: The final round of the Russian presidential election could take place on July 7. Or maybe on July 3. Possibly June 30, though there is also a chance voting could be held on July 14.

title: World News Briefs;10,000 in Belarus Grave Said to Be Nazi Victims
description: A mass grave of about 10,000 people believed to have been killed by the Nazis during World War II has been discovered in Minsk, the Belarus capital, a Defense Ministry official said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SEAGATE BUYS HOLISTIC SYSTEMS FOR $84 MILLION
description: Seagate Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Holistic Systems Ltd., a British provider of business management systems, for $84 million in cash. Holistic, which has its United States offices in Edison, N.J., develops Holos, a system that has applications in executive information and decision support.

title: Circus Circus Plans Hotel
description: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. disclosed plans this week to build a 400-room hotel in Las Vegas with the luxury Four Seasons Hotels Ltd. resort chain and explore other opportunities with the company worldwide. The hotel is part of plans by Circus Circus to build a new resort consisting of about 4,000 rooms on a one-mile stretch of land on the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Clinton Announces Steps to Find Parents Who Owe Child Support
description: Seeing no immediate prospect of an agreement with Congress on welfare, President Clinton announced today that he was taking steps on his own to increase child-support collections and track down fathers who violate child-support orders.

title: At the Nation's Table: Austin, Tex.;Cookies and Milk Start a Career
description: Freshly baked cookies with a glass of milk is comfort food hard to come by these days for those without an obliging mom or other willing household baker. To fill that void and inaugurate a career as an entrepreneur, Paul Rodriguez has started Mount Bushishnu, a cookies-and-milk delivery service.

title: BASEBALL;Belle's Ban Gets Whittled to Three Games
description: Gene Budig, the American League president, reduced Albert Belle's sentence yesterday, but the Yankees could benefit from the decision even more than the Cleveland Indians.

title: CONCERT REVIEW;Schutz Gets a Turn in the Spotlight
description: Poor Heinrich Schutz! Or more to the point, the poor modern listener!

title: A Strong Quarter Stirs Optimism in Japan
description: Lifted by growth in almost all parts of the economy, Japan's gross domestic product jumped 3 percent in the latest quarter from the previous three months, or at an annual rate of 12.7 percent -- the strongest performance in 23 years, the Government said today.

title: Excerpts From Democrats' Report on Senate Whitewater Hearings
description: Following are excerpts from the report filed today by the Democratic minority on the Senate Whitewater committee:

title: Spread the Word on Asia Rights Abusers;Nike's Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: Return on Investment Rises 20% for Calpers
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System reported today that it had a 20.1 percent return on investments in the year that ended on March 31, up from an 8 percent return a year earlier.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Latte With Your License?
description: A visit to the Division of Motor Vehicles is not unlike a trip to the dentist -- not something to look forward to, but necessary, John Graf, a D.M.V. spokesman, said yesterday.

title: New Windows on a New World;Can the Food Ever Match the View?
description: IT is high anxiety at Windows on the World. One week remains before the restaurant reopens and the breathtaking panorama from the 107th floor of the World Trade Center competes once again with the chefs' creations.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China and South Korea End Talks on Jet
description: Talks between South Korea and China on a project to develop passenger jets collapsed today.

title: Grace Says U.S. Won't Pursue One Area of Grand Jury Inquiry
description: W. R. Grace & Company said today that the United States Attorney for New Jersey would not prosecute its National Medical Care unit in connection with the division's efforts to persuade the Food and Drug Administration to allow the resumption of imports from its dialysis products factory in Ireland.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Youthful, Idealistic Romeo Makes Ballet Theater Debut
description: Youth is definitely not wasted on the young in ballet. But the relative old-timers had the edge when American Ballet Theater presented new casts and a role debut in Sir Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet" on Friday night and Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Man Stabs Officer in Manhattan
description: A panhandler stabbed an off-duty police officer in the back on a busy sidewalk in midtown Manhattan, not far from a police station, prompting scores of officers to go to the scene to search for the fleeing assailant, officials said.

title: Sports of The Times;From Belle, To Rodman, To Bananas
description: THE nation now turns its weary sports eye from the conclusion of the basketball season to what is essentially, if not officially, the start of the baseball season. It turns, in fact, from the glitter of Dennis Rodman to the glower of Albert Belle.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Retreat as Tensions With Iraq Are Seen Easing
description: Crude oil prices retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday from Monday's sharp gains as traders bet that the United Nations and Iraq would try to smooth recent tensions that threatened to delay an agreement to allow a limited sale of Iraqi oil.

title: Albany Democrats Offer Welfare Plan
description: The Democrat-controlled State Assembly released a welfare plan today that would impose time limits on all cash benefits, but would continue to provide extensive services for recipients unable to find jobs.

title: Sparring Over Whitewater
description: Anyone who has followed the Whitewater story closely since it first surfaced in the 1992 Presidential election campaign knows that the full truth has not been told. Important documents have gone astray and some witnesses have been as elusive as the evidence.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IPC HOLDINGS SWEETENS ITS OFFER FOR TEMPEST
description: IPC Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it would increase the cash component of its $943 million offer for the Tempest Reinsurance Company after the money manager George Soros backed its bid. IPC increased the cash portion to as much as $380 million, from $275 million, nine days after a rival bidder, Ace Ltd., sweetened its own offer for the property reinsurer to $923.8 million. The IPC move comes after two funds associated with Mr. Soros -- Quantum Industrial Partners and Tivadar Charitable Lead Trust -- promised to invest as much as $40.3 million if more than 39 percent of Tempest's shareholders chose to receive cash instead of IPC stock.

title: Yeltsin's Edge: Fear of the Past
description: The world can sigh in relief. Sunday's Russian elections did not reproduce the experience of December 1993, when the party of the chauvinist and anti-Semite Vladimir Zhirinovsky received the largest number of votes for parliament, nor that of December 1995, when the Communists won a plurality. This time, Boris Yeltsin outmaneuvered his opponents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Because the masthead of Ms. magazine in its early years listed editors alphabetically and without indication of rank, "People never realized that SUZANNE BRAUN LEVINE was the main editor," GLORIA STEINEM, a founder of Ms., said the other day.

title: Illegal Immigrants Add to Population Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes;New Faces in Cable News
description: While the veteran 24-hour cable news network, CNN, hums along quietly, its two new competitors, MSNBC and Fox, made some hiring noise this week.

title: Mexico Plans To Repay U.S. $4.7 Billion
description: Taking advantage of new confidence in world financial markets, Mexico announced today that it would obtain private financing for $4.7 billion of the money it borrowed from the United States during last year's financial crisis, more than three years ahead of schedule.

title: POP REVIEW;At an Annual Festival for Jazz, Music That Strictly Isn't
description: The Knitting Factory started its annual What Is Jazz? festival on Monday night with a concert at Irving Plaza that probably wasn't jazz, even by the loosest definitions. But the double bill didn't fit snugly into any other category, either. The Roots, from Philadelphia, used a pop-jazz trio (electric piano, bass and drums) instead of a disk jockey to accompany rapping. And the guitarist Vernon Reid, formerly of Living Colour, and his new group, Masque, graft together rock, funk, hip-hop and jazz.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Greene King to Buy Magic Pub in Britain
description: Greene King, a British brewer and pub operator, said yesterday that it would acquire the Magic Pub Company for L197.5 million ($304.8 million), more than doubling the number of the regional brewer's managed pubs. After the deal, Greene King, the largest brewer in the south of England, will have 462 managed pubs and 677 leased pubs. Magic Pub has 277 pubs, hotels and inns. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: At the close of trading here today, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 34.96 points, or 0.16 percent, at 22,367.36. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 87.02 points.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Washington Forward Staying
description: MARK SANFORD, a sophomore at the University of Washington, announced yesterday that he has withdrawn his name from next week's National Basketball Association draft and will return to school for his junior season.

title: In Shake-Up, Army Officers Fill Top Police Posts in Mexico City
description: In a sweeping shake-up, a brigadier general assigned by President Ernesto Zedillo to take control of Mexico City's demoralized police force has replaced dozens of commanders with army colleagues, leaving Mexican law enforcement more firmly in military hands than at any time in recent years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: An American hero of World War II who was inducted into the Companions of the Order of Liberation by Gen. Charles de Gaulle was honored for his wartime service again yesterday in Paris. President JACQUES CHIRAC of France pinned the rosette of Officer of the Legion of Honor on JOHN HASEY, 79, of Arlington, Va., who was shot in the face and chest when he served in the French Foreign Legion during the 1941 Allied conquest of Syria.

title: Hanoi Set to Take 2,073 Vietnamese in Germany
description: Vietnam said today that it is ready to take back more than 2,000 Vietnamese living in Germany, in what would be the first major step toward bringing home some 40,000 contract workers and illegal immigrants.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TV SPORTS;Costas Re-signs With NBC
description: BOB COSTAS has signed a six-year contract to stay with NBC Sports that will let him take a six-month sabbatical starting next March.

title: Residents Strive for Normalcy in Wake of a Burst Steam Pipe
description: The day after a steam pipe broke on the Upper East Side, spreading asbestos and worry on a block of East 70th Street, residents began returning home, with mixed success.

title: Quebec Journal;With Convert's Ardor, Quebecer Embraces Canada
description: I don't exist for them any more," said Guy Bertrand, ruing lost friendship, including a brother's, since his conversion to federalism about 18 months ago. "It's very hard. This has been the hardest part of my life."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Parliament Votes Lenders' Rescue
description: After months of bitter debate, Japan's Parliament passed a Government plan yesterday to spend $6.3 billion in taxpayer money for an unpopular bailout of bankrupt housing lenders. The passage clears the way for establishing an institution to liquidate the assets of the housing lenders, which collapsed under the weight of bad loans made to real estate speculators before land prices plummeted in the early 1990's. The companies are believed saddled with more than $65 billion in bad debts.

title: World News Briefs;Ban on Heavy Weapons In Balkans Lifted by U.N.
description: The United Nations Security Council today lifted the embargo of heavy weapons it imposed in 1991 against the former Yugoslav republics, following an arms control agreement in the Balkans.

title: Food Notes
description: Wild Scottish Salmon

title: Spread the Word on Asia Rights Abusers
description: To the Editor:

title: Observing the Solstice the Swedish Way
description: IN Sweden, midsummer is a time to celebrate the gift of long daylight hours. On Friday, the Swedes will bring their festival to Central Park, where the summer solstice will be celebrated from 4 to 7 P.M. in an area near West Drive at 72d Street. There will be dancing around a flower-bedecked pole. Tasting plates of Swedish specialties from restaurants like Christer's and Aquavit of Manhattan will be sold to benefit the restoration of the Swedish Cottage in the park.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ATLAS AIR INC., Golden, Colo., entered a three-year agreement to provide Thai Airways International Ltd. with an Atlas 747-200 freighter aircraft in the fourth quarter. If all options are exercised, the value of the contract would be about $256 million.

title: TV Notes;'60 Minutes' Drops Trio
description: Don Hewitt, executive producer of the CBS news magazine program "60 Minutes," released a brief statement yesterday saying the eight-week-old commentary segment featuring the writers Stanley Crouch, Molly Ivins and P. J. O'Rourke will be dropped. They are "three talented people," Mr. Hewitt's statement said, "but our mail suggested the segment was not catching on and I never argue with viewers."

title: I.B.M. Prepares New Software In Push for Intranet Market
description: Responding to stepped-up competition from Microsoft and Netscape, I.B.M. plans to announce today its strategy for building internal corporate computer networks using new software from its Lotus subsidiary.

title: Atlanta Journal;Sponsors' Messages Vie In Games' Biggest Event
description: The huge Coke bottle rises six stories from its base just outside the Centennial Olympic Park in downtown Atlanta, a monument to corporate America and contemporary kitsch.

title: Man Held as Unabomber Is Indicted in 2 Slayings
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski, said by Justice Department investigators to be the Unabomber who killed 3 people and maimed 23 others in an 18-year nationwide campaign of explosive terror, was indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges involving 2 of the deaths and 2 of the injuries.

title: Securities Regulation Bill Advances
description: A bill to overhaul regulation of Wall Street had an easy time on the House floor today, gaining broad bipartisan support.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Malone Pays Tribute To Young Fan Who Died
description: Utah Jazz forward KARL MALONE was a pallbearer Monday at the funeral of a 13-year-old leukemia victim he had befriended. Danny Ewing, of North Salt Lake, Utah, died Friday. He had referred to Malone as "my angel," and had said that Malone "helped brighten my life."

title: Trademark, Copyright, Rock-and-Roll
description: To the Editor:

title: Spurned Refugee Ship Returns to Liberia
description: A Russian freighter with 450 Liberian refugees aboard, which had last been seen drifting and had been reported to be running out of water, returned to Liberia today.

title: YELTSIN CHOOSES A DEFEATED RIVAL FOR SECURITY POST
description: In a bold stroke to consolidate support before next month's runoff election, President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed his unpopular Defense Minister today and appointed Aleksandr I. Lebed, a retired general who finished a strong third in Sunday's first round, as his top national security adviser.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Release Walker, Shedding Third Veteran
description: In a move that wasn't a complete surprise, the Giants yesterday thinned out their crowded backfield and added more room under their salary cap by releasing Herschel Walker.

title: After a Battle, Israel Swears In A New Cabinet
description: Though still battling with key political associates over the final shape of his Cabinet, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his ministers were sworn in today as Israel's new Government.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Art Fraud's New Trick: Add Fakes To Archive
description: The public, if not the art world, has always harbored a secret admiration for the true masters of art forgery, men like Han van Meegeren, who hoodwinked experts in the 1930's with his fake Vermeers, and more recently Eric Hebborn, whose drawings attributed to others passed through Sotheby's and Christie's on their way to American and European museums.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SPEED SKATING;Blair and Cruikshank to Marry
description: The speed skaters BONNIE BLAIR and DAVE CRUIKSHANK will be married Sunday in Milwaukee. Blair won five Olympic gold medals, the most by any American woman in any sport. Cruikshank was on the 1994 United States speed skating team and is in training for next season. The ceremony will be private, with only family and close friends in attendance, according to Blair's agent, Advantage International. (AP)

title: Alert Is Sounded on Spread Of Exotic Parasitic Infection
description: At least 35 people in the New York City area have been stricken since early May by an exotic parasitic intestinal infection whose source is unknown, health officials said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Saints Sign Ex-Eagles Safety
description: GREG JACKSON, a seven-year National Football League veteran who played with the Philadelphia Eagles for the past two seasons, signed a one-year contract with the New Orleans Saints yesterday.Jackson, a star at Louisiana State University, was a third-round draft choice of the Giants in 1989. He played with the Giants for five years before signing with Philadelphia as a free agent before the 1994 season. (AP)

title: Subway Panhandlers Make Comeback
description: Begging on the subways is back. By early 1995, a police crackdown had almost eliminated panhandling and peddling on subway trains, but it seems to be ubiquitous again.

title: Los Angeles Acts to Spur Bilingual Students
description: Vowing to speed the progress of students to mainstream education programs from bilingual ones, the nation's second-largest school district will offer its schools financial rewards pegged to the number of their students who make the transition.

title: Clinton's Surprising Strength Forces Dole to Court South
description: Two years after President Clinton's advisers reluctantly concluded that he would have to concede the South to the Republicans in 1996, the President's home turf has suddenly become contested ground.

title: News Analysis;Conceding a Conflict
description: The announcement yesterday that the Federal Aviation Administration will try to shed its mission of promoting aviation was an acknowledgment that its dual role as industry cheerleader and watchdog had created a credibility gap with the public that could no longer be ignored.

title: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK;Except for Votes, Hundley Tallies All-Star Numbers
description: Todd Hundley does not have any campaign posters or plans to kiss any babies. But the Mets catcher firmly believes he deserves to be selected to play in the 67th All-Star Game, set for July 9 in Philadelphia.

title: Fatal Shooting of Youth Remains Mystery
description: This much is known about the death of 14-year-old Quayyohm Gilmer of Irvington:

title: TENNIS;Another Stumbling Block For the Capriati Comeback
description: Jennifer Capriati, whose attempts to jump-start her troubled career have apparently sputtered to a halt again, is expected to announce today that she is withdrawing from Wimbledon due to a lack of sufficient grass-court preparation.

title: 6 Soldiers Die In a Collision Of Helicopters In Kentucky
description: Two Army transport helicopters collided and plummeted to the ground today, just as soldiers aboard were about to carry out a mock rescue of others pretending to be injured on the ground. Six people were killed and at least 30 injured.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;As the Bulls Celebrate, Merchandisers Are Tagging Along
description: Most people resist wearing caps with tags flapping from them. But the Chicago Bulls celebrated their fourth National Basketball Association title Sunday night with headgear bearing the manufacturer's name, Logo Athletic.

title: Personal Health
description: THE doctor could tell the patient had once been an attractive woman. But now, though only in her 50's, her face was etched with wrinkles, her features gaunt-looking with prominent underlying bones and her skin shriveled and gray with purplish blotches. Diagnosis: smoker's face.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Chatting With Carol Burnett About Growing Up Poor
description: Bravo's "Inside the Actors Studio," a series of conversations taped at the New School for Social Research, usually focuses on the work of actors and directors in theater or the movies. Tonight television takes stage center with Carol Burnett, who remains remarkably cool and charming in an uneven interview with James Lipton, the series moderator.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ST. PAUL TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF ALLSTATE
description: The St. Paul Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the Allstate Corporation's commercial insurance unit for about $180 million in cash. Allstate is focusing on its core businesses of selling life, home and auto insurance. The unit being sold, Northbrook Holdings Inc., based in South Barrington, Ill., includes the Northbrook Property and Casualty Insurance Company, the Northbrook Indemnity Company and the Northbrook National Insurance Company. Northbrook Holdings has annual premiums of $587 million and total assets of $1.65 billion. It has about 1,100 employees. St. Paul said that it expected to cut an undetermined number of jobs.

title: Wine Talk
description: TRAVELING down to Burgundy from Paris, I usually plan to take the high-speed train from the Gare de Lyon at about 8 A.M. It arrives at Dijon before 10, which means a full day in the country.

title: TV Notes;Humiliation Is Out
description: In one week Rosie O'Donnell has become the talk of daytime television, mainly for repudiating what used to be the talk of daytime television.

title: Whitewater Hearing Cleared The Clintons, Democrats Say
description: Dissenting sharply from the final report of the Senate Whitewater committee, the Democratic minority on the committee said today that the Congressional investigation had found no evidence of wrongdoing by the President, the First Lady or any senior officials in the Clinton Administration.

title: At the Nation's Table: Savannah, Ga.;A Chef Promotes Market Cuisine
description: When asked what excited him most about creating a new menu for Bistro Savannah, a seven-year-old restaurant in what Margaret Mitchell called "that gently mannered city by the sea in Georgia," the new chef, Christopher Nason, answered with what has become his culinary mantra: "fresh market cuisine." Appointed chef of the bistro a month ago, Mr. Nason said his goal was to serve sophisticated, healthy food, using organically grown local and regional produce and the herbs and seafood that are available daily.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUN MICROSYSTEMS TO BUY LIGHTHOUSE DESIGN
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Lighthouse Design Ltd., a provider of object-based developer and productivity tools. Sun did not disclose the price but said it expected to take a charge of no more than 10 cents a share in its fourth quarter to cover acquired research and development. Lighthouse Design expects to operate as a unit of Sun Microsystems, which is based in Mountain View, Calif. Sun Microsystems reported net income of $128.2 million, or $1.26 a share, on revenue of $1.648 billion in the quarter that ended on June 30, 1995. Shares of Sun rose $1.125, to $57, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Technology Issues Fall, With Dow Off 24.75
description: Technology shares fell sharply yesterday, leading a nervous market lower, as investors grew concerned about difficult market conditions for high-technology companies.

title: Bill Requires Insurers to Pay Chiropractors
description: Legislative leaders have reached agreement on a bill that would require health insurance companies to pay for unlimited chiropractic services, a move that would confer new legitimacy upon a profession that remains embroiled in a debate over its effectiveness.

title: ATLANTA 1996: 30 DAYS TO GO;Track Trials Raise a Host of Questions
description: The Summer Olympics begin a month from Wednesday, but the anticipation and excitement are tempered by continuing questions about Atlanta's preparedness to host the centennial Games.

title: Counseling in Bomb Plot
description: A 13-year-old boy must undergo counseling for a year for plotting to blow up his school with a homemade bomb he learned to make from the Internet.

title: Therapist's Privacy Privilege Isn't Absolute
description: To the Editor:

title: A Penitent Christian Coalition Offers Aid to Burned Churches
description: After acknowledging that "the white evangelical church was not only on the sidelines but on the wrong side" of the civil rights movement, the executive director of the predominantly white Christian Coalition said today that his organization would try to raise $1 million to help rebuild churches burned by arsonists.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Security Myth Surrounds F.B.I. and Its Files
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Massachusetts No Partisanship On Environment

title: HOCKEY;Messier and Leetch Remain In Contention for Trophies
description: Mark Messier and Brian Leetch of the Rangers are among the finalists for two top awards to be presented tonight in Toronto during ceremonies honoring the best of the National Hockey League.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Fe, Fi, Fo, Whoa! The Inner Giant Has Taken Over.
description: THE SIBLING SOCIETY By Robert Bly 319 pages. Addison-Wesley. $25.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Partner Joins Disney-Backed Phone Group In TV Venture
description: Just when one Baby Bell television venture shows signs of slowing down, another is picking up momentum.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Roots in Japan, Vision in China
description: The Japanese retailing tycoon Kazuo Wada's latest gamble might seem like a long shot: he has built the world's second-biggest department store after Macy's in New York and stocked it with everything from a fire-engine-red Ferrari to imported cosmetics in this city whose population can mostly just gawk at such luxuries.

title: After a Shootout, Police Find Match To 'Zodiac' Prints
description: A 26-year-old Brooklyn man, who was arrested after a wild shootout with police officers in East New York yesterday, has been linked through fingerprints to the so-called Zodiac shootings of four men in 1990, police officials said last night.

title: Gerry Adams Says He Asks For a Truce From I.R.A.
description: Gerry Adams, the head of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, indicated today that he was trying to persuade the I.R.A. to restore its cease-fire after the bomb blast that wounded more than 200 people in Manchester, England, on Saturday.

title: Racial Redistricting Serves to Balkanize
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ponzi Scheme Charged
description: A Camden County couple was accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of defrauding investors of $8 million through a Ponzi scheme they ran out of their Cherry Hill brokerage. Rita Fabiani and her husband, William Richman, of Gibbsboro, falsely told investors that their defunct company, Mortgage Line, bought foreclosed homes from the Resolution Trust Corporation and sold them at a profit, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Man Is Convicted of Kidnapping Polly Klaas
description: A man was convicted today of kidnapping 12-year-old Polly Klaas from a slumber party in 1993 and murdering her, with another finding of the jury making him eligible for the death penalty.

title: Real Estate;The New York Times Company sells a building on Fifth Avenue to real estate investors.
description: A CENTURY-OLD, 11-story, 170,000-square-foot office building at 110 Fifth Avenue, at 16th Street, has been sold by The New York Times Company to companies owned by Arnold Goldstein and Mickey Rabina, real estate investors with holdings that include buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues in Manhattan.

title: Susan Kirk, 44, Aide to Florio And a Transportation Executive
description: Susan Kirk, a vice president of Parsons Brinckerhoff Quade & Douglas, a leading transportation engineering and consulting firm in Manhattan who had been an aide to Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, died on Monday at Riverview Regional Cancer Center in Red Bank, N.J. She was 44 and lived in Jersey City.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Undo Twins' Perfect Night in Five Pitches
description: Nothing about the evening seemed particularly perfect. More than two-thirds of the seats at Yankee Stadium were empty and there was a threat of rain. One starter had won once in his last four starts and the other had won once in 12 starts. No apparent reasons to ponder perfection.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Dead Man's Last Steps
description: The impact, if any, of the movie "Dead Man Walking" on the national debate over the death penalty remains to be seen. But its influence on at least one network news magazine is evident tonight as "Prime Time Live" visits death row at the Louisiana State Penitentiary at Angola, where part of the movie was made. The occasion is the execution of Antonio James, whose long fight to be spared that fate ended with a lethal injection on March 1.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden's Stuff Heads to Hall
description: Dwight Gooden last night grudgingly gave the Hall of Fame the Yankee cap he wore on May 14 when he pitched a no-hitter against the Mariners and one of the balls he threw that night, but Gooden does not plan to present his uniform jersey until the season is over because he only has two. "I wanted to keep some of this stuff," Gooden said. "They wanted my glove and I said no."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Barry's Jewelers, Monrovia, Calif., to Bates Southwest, Houston, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Nutty Bulgur, as Easy to Cook as Rice
description: THOSE who have not cooked the nutty grain bulgur might think it takes a lot of work. In fact, it is as easy to cook as rice. This chicken and bulgur is seasoned with Middle Eastern spices. Combine with water or broth, bring to a boil and cook until liquid is absorbed, just a few minutes. The sauce for the broccoli would be as good with bok choy or green beans.

title: Trash Haulers Face New List Of Charges About Fees
description: As Manhattan customers go, they were prized targets for commercial garbage haulers: the main Federal office building, a Federal jail, the Bank of New York and the Woolworth Building.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 11 with an article about changes in the Newark school system after a state takeover misidentified the school shown. It was Barringer High School, not Barringer Preparatory School.

title: TV Notes;Cross-Promotion Static
description: It seems top-rated NBC can still do something to annoy its otherwise deliriously happy affiliated stations. Like tell viewers to switch over to a cable channel instead of late local newscasts.

title: Bail Cut Won By Detective In an Assault
description: Constantine Chronis, the New York City police detective charged in the assault on Shane L. Daniels outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub, won a sharp reduction in his $1 million bail today, but not his freedom from jail.

title: Lucille Maurer, 73, Treasurer of Maryland
description: Lucille Darvin Maurer, a Maryland legislator whose expertise in public finance led her to the post of State Treasurer, died on Monday at her home in Silver Spring. She was 73.

title: Samsung Licensed to Market Digital's Alpha Microprocessors
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it had licensed Samsung Electronics to make and market its Alpha microprocessors worldwide in an effort to broaden the chip's use and establish it as an industry standard.

title: At the Nation's Table: Buffalo;Bottling the Secret Of the Wings
description: For 23 years devotees of Buffalo wings have flocked to Frank and Teressa Bellissimo's Anchor Bar and Restaurant on Main Street. There in 1963 the ultimate bar food was invented, and the recipe has been a family secret ever since.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Hearings Start Over In Irvin Drug Case
description: Lawyers renewed their pretrial jousting today in the drug case of Cowboys receiver Michael Irvin. Indictments for cocaine and marijuana possession against Irvin and two women were thrown out last week when it was discovered that a member of the grand jury lived outside the county.

title: A Prudent Agreement on Chinese Piracy
description: The Clinton Administration has reasonably withdrawn the threat of trade sanctions against China after Beijing renewed its commitment to stop pirating American copyrighted property. The Chinese have violated similar promises in the past, but it is worth testing their word before acting. A trade war would damage both the American and Chinese economies and poison diplomatic relations.

title: Clot-Dissolving Drug Approved to Treat Stroke
description: The Food and Drug Administration cleared the way today for stroke victims to take a clot-dissolving drug that could protect their brains from permanent injury, but only if they get to the emergency room fast.

title: Freemen Ordered Held Without Bail
description: A Federal magistrate today ordered 13 of the jailed members of the Freemen anti-Government group held without bond, saying they posed a threat to the community and would probably flee to avoid prosecution.

title: Iomega Shares Plummet on News That Rival Plans Faster Drive
description: Shares of the Iomega Corporation tumbled sharply today, after the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation announced that it was planning to manufacture computer disk drives based on the LS-120 technology. LS-120 is a high-density disk storage device that holds as much as 120megabytes of data, or 20 percent more than can be stored on Iomega's popular Zip drive.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times yesterday, about options for increasing computer memory, incorrectly described milliseconds (they are thousandths of a second, not millionths) and therefore misstated the difference in speed between random access memory (RAM) and hard drives. RAM can be more than 100,000 times, not 150 times, as fast.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Is Sued Over Smog
description: The Sierra Club filed a Federal lawsuit in Washington yesterday accusing the Environmental Protection Agency of failing to enforce the Clean Air Act, the organization's New Jersey chapter announced. Sierra Club officials said the E.P.A. had not implemented plans to reduce ozone levels in the Wilmington-Philadelphia-Trenton and Washington-Baltimore areas, the A.P. reported.

title: Whitewater Prosecutor Drops Files Issue
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, withdrew today from the investigation into how the White House improperly obtained hundreds of confidential background files on Republicans, and Attorney General Janet Reno then ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to complete the inquiry.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: COMPANY NEWS;WHOLE FOODS MARKET PLANS TO ACQUIRE FRESH FIELDS
description: Whole Foods Market Inc., the country's largest chain of natural foods supermarkets, agreed yesterday to acquire Fresh Fields Inc. in a stock deal worth about $134.5 million. Whole Foods, which has 47 stores in 12 states, said it expected to take an unspecified one-time charge in its fourth quarter in connection with the acquisition. Fresh Fields, a closely held company based in Rockville, Md., operates 22 natural foods supermarket stores. It had revenue of $213.6 million last year. Whole Foods said the number of shares it issued in the deal would be based on the average closing price of the stock in the 20 trading days ending one day before closing, subject to a price range of $24 to $28 a share. Whole Foods rose $1.625, to $28.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Foreign Affairs;Get Real on Russia
description: There is a bizarre quality to some of the recent commentary on the Russian elections. We are treated either to sniping from the left that it doesn't really matter who wins because Boris Yeltsin and Gennadi Zyuganov are both commissars at heart, who in the end will stamp out democracy. Or we are treated to sniping from the right that it doesn't really matter who wins because Boris Yeltsin and Gennadi Zyuganov are both czarists at heart, who in the end will stamp out Russia's neighbors. Enough of this nonsense.

title: HAVING COFFEE WITH: Patti Smith;Return of the Godmother of Punk
description: PEOPLE like to tell Patti Smith that she changed their lives. "It happens almost every day," says the woman who might be called the godmother of punk, chatting over caffe latte at Cafe Mona Lisa on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. A woman at the next table overhears and smiles. "I'm one of them," she says shyly.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with a dance review of Compagnie Azanie from Lyons, France, misidentified the site of the show. It was at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, not at the academy itself.

title: Caldor Closing Operation
description: The Caldor Corporation, the discount retail chain, is planning to close its distribution center in Newburgh, N.Y., probably about Nov. 1. Some 175 of the 400 jobs at the center will be phased out starting in August, with more layoffs due in September and October, the company said. Caldor will open a new distribution center in Westfield, Mass., in August. It filed for bankruptcy in September.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEWLETT-PACKARD REALIGNS ITS COMPUTER SALES UNIT
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company realigned its computer sales unit to add a group focused on individual customers and small offices amid surging demand for small-business products. The group will be headed by Pradeep Jotwani, formerly marketing manager for the Inkjet Products Group. Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., also announced formation of a commercial sales group to serve high-volume retailers. The company had previously announced creation of a group focused on large corporate customers.

title: Business Travel;Fare Rises Seen After Shutdown By Valujet
description: Valujet's sudden shutdown this week will sharply increase fares along the routes previously flown by the low-cost carrier, according to travel agents and others who watch air fares closely.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: New Windows on a New World;A Jazzy Decor for Dining in the Sky
description: CAN a meteor, once it hits the ground, soar again? That is the question posed by the reopening of Windows on the World next week, as the restaurant that became the emblem of New York City's revival in the late 1970's, and then went into decline itself, tries to take off all over again.

title: 60 Million For Boston Hotel
description: Fairmont Hotel Management, which was financed by a Saudi Arabian prince, is continuing its expansion with the purchase of the Copley Plaza in Boston in a deal estimated to be worth $60 million.

title: DANCE REVIEW;'For the Love of Dove,' and It Was
description: Sadly, the choreographer Ulysses Dove died a week ago, on June 11. But "For the Love of Dove," a long-planned and extraordinary tribute to him organized by the Actors' Fund of America went on as scheduled on Monday night with communal warmth.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Moulinex is Shifting Production to Mexico
description: The French household appliance maker Moulinex S.A. said yesterday that it would cut 2,600 of its 11,300 jobs and close four French plants to transfer production to Mexico. Moulinex also posted a loss of 702 million francs ($136 million) for the year ended March 31, more than triple its loss of 213 million francs a year earlier. The wider loss includes costs of 600 million francs for a three-year restructuring plan.

title: Kamsky Loses Crucial Pawn Just Before Adjournment
description: After nearly six hours of a grim battle, Gata Kamsky blundered a pawn yesterday and seemed headed for a loss in Game 7 of the world championship match in Elista, Russia. The game, adjourned at Move 57, is to be finished today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Enforcing Tobacco Laws
description: Health officials all over the state will be trained next week to conduct sting operations against people who sell tobacco products to minors, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Under the campaign, to begin July 1, teen-agers -- most of them volunteers, though some will be paid -- will try to buy cigarettes, and people who violate the law by selling to them will be cited by a police or health officer with the minor, said the state's Deputy Health Commissioner, Leah Z. Ziskin.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Parade of the Maverick Modernists, Joined by the Dead
description: Michael Tilson Thomas long dwelled in the shadow of Leonard Bernstein. Perhaps he imitated his mentor too much, right down to the debonair baritone. Now, in San Francisco, as the mastermind of a festival called Soundscape USA, he is creating something entirely in his image. Nothing quite like it has ever been seen in a concert hall: a raucous survey of the experimental tradition in American music, a sellout audience swamped by fans of the Grateful Dead.

title: Journal;How High the Moon
description: This is a sad day," said the smoky-voiced announcer on WBGO, the Newark jazz station, just around midnight Saturday night. "Ella has passed." But no one was sad for too long, because the radio was soon hopping with the sound of "Mack the Knife," as sung by Ella Fitzgerald with madcap, improvised lyrics in place of the words that famously slipped her mind at a concert in Berlin in 1960.

title: The Mean Streets That Nurture Art;A Photographer Finds Support And Community in East Village
description: It was two years ago in March, the month she turned 27, that Meryl Levin resigned herself to the reality that she might never make a living doing what she loves.

title: OLYMPICS;Lewis and Johnson on Stage
description: After a rest day at the track and field trials, Carl Lewis will make another attempt Wednesday night to qualify for the Olympic team in the long jump, while Michael Johnson begins his quest for a historic double victory in the sprints.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sweden Cuts Rate For 13th Time This Year
description: Sweden's central bank cut its chief money market rate again yesterday as part of its effort to energize the country's economy. The cut, the 13th this year, lowered the Riksbank's securities repurchase rate by 20 basis points, to 6.1 percent from 6.3.

title: World News Briefs;Colombian Security Chief Quits After Spy Charges
description: The director of Colombia's secret police resigned today after allegations that his agency had been trailing the American Ambassador and tapping his phones.

title: A New View On Training Food Experts
description: FOR years, the study of food, often narrowly defined as home economics, has been something of a backwater.

title: Turnaround by the F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's belated decision to ground Valujet Airlines as a safety hazard amounts to an admission of how wrong-headed the agency had been in its previous efforts to regulate the troubled low-cost airline. Five weeks ago the F.A.A. Administrator, David Hinson, and Transportation Secretary Federico Pena rashly assured the public that Valujet was safe to fly one day after one of its planes crashed in the Florida Everglades. Now they have been forced to acknowledge that Valujet is not up to standards, and Mr. Hinson has acknowledged that the F.A.A.'s inspections were not adequate to assure the airworthiness of Valujet's fleet.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: U.S. Bonds End Lower After Rally
description: Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, after failing to hold on to early gains on a housing report that showed unexpected weakness.

title: The Yeltsin-Lebed Alliance
description: Boris Yeltsin may have hit a political gusher yesterday by swiftly enlisting Aleksandr Lebed to serve as chief of his security council, the Kremlin's inner circle of diplomatic, military and law enforcement officials. In a single stroke, Mr. Yeltsin picked up the crucially important endorsement of Mr. Lebed, who drew 15 percent of the vote in Sunday's election, and gained the services of the retired general in managing Moscow's ragged military and security services.

title: Inquiry Into Files
description: After Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, concluded that he did not have the authority to investigate how the White House obtained hundreds of confidential files on Republicans, Attorney General Janet Reno ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to conduct the inquiry.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;New Women's League Holds Its Draft
description: The new women's American Basketball League assigned its premier players -- including the United States Olympic team members REBECCA LOBO and LISA LESLIE -- to its eight professional teams yesterday.

title: In Perfoormance;DANCE
description: Chinese Immigrants' Story, From the Gold Rush On Chen and Dancers La Mama E.T.C.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Approves Sanctions Against Investment in Iran The House of Representatives unanimously approved harsh economic sanctions against foreign companies that invest in Iran, widening the split between the United States and its allies over the use of American economic power.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;Beeches Will Weep for the Wizard of Channel Gardens
description: DON'T worry. There will still be a Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center. And the Channel Gardens -- that lovely surprise of fountains and ever-changing greenery that sweeps from Fifth Avenue down to the skating rink -- will still be there. But I wonder if topiary dinosaurs will ever stalk the earth there again -- or if a thousand silk flowers will bloom on a freezing February day.

title: HOUSE PROUD;When Familiarity Breeds Content
description: REMEMBER in "I Love Lucy" how Lucy and Ricky and Fred and Ethel always took their vacations together? And how, when the Ricardos moved to Westport, the Mertzes moved in with them? And how things like that never happened in real life?

title: INSIDE
description: Did Airline Ignore Warnings?

title: Mr. Netanyahu's Reassuring Start
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is sensibly reaching for the center in Israeli politics, despite efforts by some allies to tug him off course. After unveiling a moderate and pragmatic set of policy guidelines for his new Government, he has tried to allocate cabinet seats among his Likud, religious and immigrant party coalition partners with an eye to minimizing the role of hawkish ideologues and religious fundamentalists.

title: Bridge
description: A foursome that has a great recent record of success in the Grand National Team Championship won the two-session New York final a week ago. Playing at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street, Glenn Milgrim, Jared Lilienstein and Win Allegaert, all of Manhattan, and Fred Chang of Flushing, Queens, won by 55 imps against a group led by John Solodar of Manhattan. The team will compete against the champions of 24 other districts at the end of July in playoffs in Miami Beach.

title: Market Place;Regulators say Stratton Oakmont had a sure thing.
description: THE game was rigged.

title: Bank of New York Plans Larger Bad-Loan Reserve
description: In another sign that banks are running into unexpected trouble with their consumer loans, the Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it would put $350 million into its reserves for future losses in its credit card portfolio.

title: Mel Allen, the Former Yankees Announcer, Is Laid to Rest
description: Mel Allen was recalled today as a devoted brother and uncle, a man who once left a hospital bed for Yom Kippur services, and a gentle voice who elevated "broadcasting to a prayer with three words: 'How about that?' "

title: 3 Indicted in Beating Outside L.I. Nightclub
description: A Suffolk County grand jury has indicted three men, including a New York City police officer, in connection with the beating of a Long Island man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub on May 26, lawyers and law enforcement officials said today.

title: Assigned Counsel Are Seasoned at Family Law
description: To the Editor:

title: S.& P. Drops Rating On Some Kmart Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation has lowered ratings on two issues of debt securities of the Kmart Corporation, and it indicated that the outlook remained negative for the discount retailer.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Deliberations Must Resume
description: After three days of deliberations, jurors said yesterday that they were deadlocked in the trial of a dentist accused of murdering a woman during a bungled robbery last year at her Franklin Township jewelry store. But Superior Court Judge Leonard N. Arnold of Somerset County ordered the panel to resume deliberations today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNR AGREES TO SELL UNIT THAT MAKES SHOPPING CARTS
description: UNR Industries agreed yesterday to sell its Unarco Commercial Products unit, a maker of shopping carts, to Richards Capital Fund L.P. for $41 million. The sale is part of the Chicago-based holding company's plan to divest itself of four of its five operating divisions by the end of the third quarter. Last month, the company sold its Leavitt Tube steel-producing unit for $95 million. UNR Industries, through its main business, the Rohn division, makes and installs steel towers and equipment shelters for the telecommunications industry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;President Acquires Petry Latino
description: Carlos Barba, president of the Petry Latino Hispanic advertising sales division of Petry Television in New York, said yesterday that he had acquired the division through Netspan Inc., a holding company he owns with Marlin Entertainment, a communications company in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Buying Books: Theory vs. Practice
description: Let me begin with a confession.

title: In Many States, Abortion Feuds Splits G.O.P.
description: At the state Republican convention in Iowa last weekend, the party approved a platform that supports a total ban on a late-term abortion procedure and describes in detail how it is performed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Conagra Units Divide Assignments
description: The Armour Swift-Eckrich and Butterball Companies, which are owned by Conagra Inc., have divided their meat-products accounts between two agencies on the Conagra roster, Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis and Grey Advertising in New York. The accounts, with combined billings estimated at $29 million to $32 million, had been handled by Puskar Gibbon Chapin in Dallas for the last three and a half years.

description: New Romeo and New Juliet Radiate Ardor and Energy American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;An Inquiry On Metals By Britain
description: Responding to the Sumitomo Corporation's copper trading scandal, British regulators put the entire London-based metal market under scrutiny today.

title: Hustling High Culture With Fliers and Freebies
description: A cash card isn't just a cash card anymore: it can also get you free admission to a museum or a botanical garden. So can a ticket to a baseball game. And some airlines now offer culture as well as free trips in exchange for frequent-flier miles.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Accused of Aiding Nazis, Man Returns to Lithuania
description: Aleksandras Lileikis, who is accused of collaborating in Nazi atrocities as head of a secret Lithuanian police unit during World War II, has left Massachusetts and returned to Lithuania, Justice Department officials said today.
