description: SO you missed the boat on Russel Wright, Gustav Stickley, Heywood-Wakefield and T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Oilers Sign a Pick
description: Cornerback ANTHONY DORSETT came to terms with the Houston Oilers, the first of the club's 1996 draft picks to reach an agreement. Dorsett, a sixth-round choice out of Pitt, is a son of the Hall of Fame running back TONY DORSETT. The Oilers also announced yesterday that they had come to terms with tight end FRANK WYCHECK. He was third on the team in receiving last season with a career-high 40 receptions for 471 yards and a touchdown. (AP)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Capriati Pulls Out
description: As expected, JENNIFER CAPRIATI withdrew from Wimbledon yesterday, citing a lack of preparation for the grass-court Grand Slam tournament.

title: In California, Dole Opposes Public Spending on Education of IllegalAliens
description: Casting the issue as one of fairness, Bob Dole said today that taxpayers should not be forced to pay for the education of illegal immigrants.

title: Miriam Gideon, 89, a Composer of Vocal and Orchestral Music
description: Miriam Gideon, a prolific composer of vocal, chamber and orchestral music, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: When Voice of the Yankees Connected a Distant Father and Son;A Babe Error
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Disciplinary Action Weighed
description: When a natural gas pipeline exploded in Edison in March 1994, 100 people were injured and 300 lost their homes. In addition to coping with this destruction, residents of the Durham Woods apartment complex also had to deal with a small army of lawyers seeking to represent them in lawsuits against the pipeline company. Today, the State Supreme Court's Committee on Attorney Advertising will announce whether it will discipline any of the five lawyers accused of improperly soliciting clients at the explosion site, said the committee's secretary, Israel Dubin.

title: BASEBALL;Selig Says He's Still Not Interested
description: Is Bud Selig, the acting baseball commissioner, ready to become Bud Selig the commissioner? While talk has resurfaced about that possibility, Selig yesterday denied having changed his position, which has been that he is not interested in the permanent position.

title: New York Arrests 46 City Workers In Welfare Fraud
description: For the second time in a year, prosecutors have charged dozens of New York City employees with welfare fraud, accusing them of illegally obtaining thousands of dollars in public assistance while they were collecting city paychecks.

title: Shuttle Is Set to Fly Today if Weather Clears
description: The space agency resolved two technical problems today and cleared the shuttle Columbia for launching as officials waited to see if the weather would allow the mission to begin on schedule.

title: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': A CHANCE MISSED;1994's Arrest Fizzled With Fingerprints Destroyed
description: New York City police were tantalizingly close to identifying Heriberto Seda as the so-called Zodiac killer two years ago. But a legal technicality required that they destroy his fingerprints, prints that might have closed a serial murder case that had confounded more than 50 detectives for almost four years.

title: White House Handling of Files Is Called Lax as Hearings Begin
description: Republicans opened Congressional hearings today into the White House's improper acquisition of confidential F.B.I. files, with two former career employees of the White House security office testifying that the Clinton Administration was far more lax than its predecessors in its handling of such materials.

title: Navistar to Cut Jobs and Move Truck Production
description: The Navistar International Corporation, North America's biggest producer of trucks and school buses, said yesterday that it would eliminate 3,000 of the 5,000 jobs at its huge factory in Springfield, Ohio, and move its heavy truck production elsewhere by 1999.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Approaches To Bach, Rigid or Not
description: When Reinhard Goebel and Musica Antiqua Koln released their remarkably fleet recordings of Bach's "Brandenburg" Concertos in 1987, snide commentators suggested that if tempos had been just a bit faster, all six works would have fitted on a single CD. Those concertos are back now, in the Archiv Masters series, still on two CD's (447 287/8) but with their 86 minutes of frenetically invigorating virtuosity filled out by Bach's Orchestral Suites Nos. 1 and 4, more sensibly paced.

title: Malone to Talk With Knicks
description: Jeff Van Gundy will meet with Brendan Malone within the week to discuss the possibility of the former Toronto Raptors coach working as a Knicks bench assistant.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MINNESOTA MINING AND MANUFACTURING CO., St. Paul, set June 28 as the date for the spinoff of its data storage and imaging systems businesses, Imation Corp. Investors will receive 1 Imation share for every 10 shares of 3M stock held.

title: Suit Accuses J.& J. Unit of Trade Spying
description: The Bohringer Mannheim Corporation filed a Federal suit today against a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, charging industrial espionage in the market for diabetes-treatment products.

title: Woman Dies When Car Is Hit by Vehicle in Police Chase
description: A 38-year-old mother of two was killed in Oradell, N.J., early Tuesday evening when her car was hit broadside by a stolen vehicle being chased by four police cars. The authorities said yesterday that the officers involved complied with the State Attorney General's policy governing police pursuits.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Lose Gains To End Flat
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, retreating from early gains after an announcement on next week's sales of new two-year and five-year notes revived concerns about supply.

title: Co-Valedictorian Loses Court Appeal
description: A Queens senior who had gone to court to avoid sharing the valedictorian title with a classmate lost again yesterday, in her last bid to have the decision overturned before graduation ceremonies at Bayside High School in Queens on Tuesday.

title: TALKING SACRED SPACES WITH: Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber;Open-Door Policy in England...
description: SIR ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER, the fin-de-siecle Pooh-Bah of Popular Culture, was putting the finishing touches on a column for The Daily Telegraph of London the other day, whizzing past the Burne-Jones painting that hovers above the circular staircase in his duplex at Trump Tower.

title: SOCCER;All but One of the MetroStars Get the Point
description: The MetroStars' failure to score in three consecutive games has produced so much frustration that when Tab Ramos, the best player on the team, was replaced with 13 minutes left in tonight's game at Giants Stadium, the talented midfielder walked off the field.

title: Kiki Mason, a Writer on AIDS, Dies at 36
description: Kiki Mason, a brash advocate for people with AIDS who chronicled his own struggle with the disease in a column for Poz magazine, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 36.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;High School Student Wins Ad Contest
description: An 18-year-old at a high school in Long Island City, Queens, has won a contest to create a 30-second public service announcement that will be offered to local television broadcast stations and cable channels.

title: HOCKEY;Russian Brings History and Questions to Draft
description: Aleksandr Volchkov carries in his wallet a trading card that shows a picture of a hockey player named Aleksandr Volchkov. The man is his father, photographed while playing for the Soviet Union in 1972. It was taken during the Summit Series against Canada, a historic confrontation that widened hockey's horizons.

title: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': THE OVERVIEW;Police Say Zodiac Suspect Admits Attacks That Killed 3 and Hurt 5
description: Saying he had to kill them "because they were evil," a reclusive man obsessed with guns and the Bible has admitted slaying three people and wounding five others in two calculated waves that bound many New Yorkers in a fitful terror and became known as the Zodiac shootings, police officials said yesterday.

title: Some Black Booksellers Succeed, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Brewers localize their ad campaigns to get the down home flavor into their Texas commercials.
description: THE nation's premier brewers are jockeying for position in one of the largest markets -- Texas, and the resulting trend is a three-headed stallion galloping around the bend in advertising's latest sport: regional marketing.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADT TO ACQUIRE BRITISH SECURITY COMPANY IN STOCK DEAL
description: ADT Ltd. said yesterday that it would acquire Automated Security Holdings P.L.C. for about $131.1 million in stock. ADT, based in Bermuda, said it would issue about seven million shares of common stock for the acquisition. The stock closed yesterday at $18.375 a share, down 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. Automated Security is the leading provider of electronic security in Britain. A subsidiary, API Security Inc., is the largest electronic security provider in Southern California. Automated Security shareholders will receive three ADT shares for every 92 shares of Automated Security common stock. Holders of Automated Security's American depository receipts will receive three ADT shares for every 46 A.D.R.'s held.

title: For Those Who Clean Up the Streets, 2 Blocks of Glory
description: First came the Avenue of the Finest, to honor the police officers who patrol New York City's streets. Then came the Avenue of the Bravest, to honor the firefighters who battle smoke and flames.

title: Metro Matters;Quality of Life Works 2 Ways In Arrests
description: IT is because of New York City's crackdown on quality-of-life crimes that the Police Department was able to arrest John J. Royster, the man charged with murdering one woman and beating up three others in attacks that even detectives failed to link until they were able to identify his fingerprint from an earlier fare-beating arrest.

title: Alco Standard to Split Into 2 Companies
description: In the final dismantling of a once-huge conglomerate, the Alco Standard Corporation announced yesterday that it would divide into two companies -- one a distributor of paper products and the other of office copiers and fax machines.

title: Clinton and Southern Governors Confer on Efforts to Deter Burning ofBlack Churches
description: Meeting with a bipartisan delegation of Southern governors and law-enforcement officials, President Clinton vowed today to intensify efforts to prevent burnings of predominantly black churches, and ordered the Federal Emergency Management Agency to help communities form church-watch programs to deter arson.

title: Israeli Politics 101: Even the Premier Must Brawl
description: Called Israel's "first American politician" for the media-savvy style that brought him to the prime ministry, Benjamin Netanyahu is learning that the game at the top is still the tough Israeli brand of politics.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pact for DiSarcina
description: Shortstop GARY DiSARCINA signed a four-year, $11.7 million contract extension with the California Angels yesterday. The contract has an additional one-year option plus $750,000 in incentives. DiSarcina is hitting .226 this season with a home run and 22 runs batted in.

title: For Texas Instruments, Some Bragging Rights
description: Texas Instruments claimed victory yesterday in a bitter six-year dispute over the invention of the computer on a chip, a crucial component that has fueled the microelectronics era.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Moulinex Shares Up On Revamping Plans
description: The shares of Moulinex soared 21 percent yesterday, a day after the company, a French maker of household appliances, disclosed plans to cut a fifth of its work force over three years. The stock closed at 98.2 francs, up 17.2 francs, in Paris.

title: In the Name of the I.R.A.
description: The bomb that caused more than 200 civilian casualties in Manchester, England, last Saturday represented a triumph of ignorance over experience.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENNZOIL IN DEAL TO SELL RANCH TO A TURNER COMPANY
description: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Vermejo Park Ranch to Vermejo Park L.L.C., a Georgia company owned by Ted Turner, the media executive. Pennzoil, a maker of oil and lubricants, said it would retain the rights to oil and gas interests on the ranch. A Pennzoil spokesman said the 588,000-acre ranch in northern New Mexico and southern Colorado is a hunting and fishing resort and cattle ranch. Pennzoil, based in Houston, said the sale of the ranch, combined with other recent sales of Houston apartment and commercial properties, would generate about $103 million in cash. The company will use the proceeds primarily to reduce debt.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING ANNOUNCES ANOTHER INCREASE IN JET PRODUCTION
description: For the second time this year, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it would increase its commercial jet production to meet higher demand. Boeing said it would increase production of its 737 jetliners to 17 airplanes a month by the beginning of 1998. The Seattle-based Boeing now builds seven of the jets a month at its plant in Renton, Wash. Boeing shares rose $1.625, to $84.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the expanding market for goat meat in New York misidentified a shop in Elmhurst, Queens, owned by Alamzir Miah. It is the Shapala Grocery and Halal Meat, not the New Mian Grocery.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Litigious Coyote and Other News
description: COYOTE V. ACME By Ian Frazier 118 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Alitalia, Unions In Cost-Cut Deal
description: Alitalia said today that it had reached an agreement with its unions that would set the stage for cost-cutting and for a $1 billion capital infusion intended to save the airline.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. to Honor Trade Ruling Against It on Foreign Fuel
description: The Clinton Administration agreed today to honor a ruling against the United States by the World Trade Organization, saying it would change the way it applies environmental regulations to imported gasoline.

title: No Headline
description: Some leaders did not think about the men who fight for freedom. We have to fight for our honor. The problem is not money. No money pay for my life. But I think my honor and my friends' honor must get recognition."

title: Vietnam's 'Lost Commandos' Win Battle
description: Seeking to heal a wound from the Vietnam War, the Senate voted today to give up to $20 million to the "lost commandos," hundreds of Vietnamese secret agents written off as dead by the United States after being dropped behind enemy lines.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Penguin Chief Plans to Resign
description: Peter Mayer, the chairman and chief executive of the Penguin publishing group, said he would announce his resignation today.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 95.86 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,271.50. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 34.96 points.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Prices Fall as Data Show 'Disappointing' Demand
description: Gasoline prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a report showed a drop in stockpiles that was less than expected. The report raised concerns that gasoline consumption would not reach the record rates that had been forecast for the summer.

title: Economic Scene;Teen-age childbearing: the cost is put at $8.9 billion a year.
description: AN ambitious study issued last week by the Robin Hood Foundation in New York called "Kids Having Kids" will no doubt convince any remaining skeptics that teen-age childbearing is an economic as well as a social disaster.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Coca-Cola to End Bottling Contract
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would end a bottling and sales contract in Norway and Sweden to set up its own operations, forcing the bottler, Pripps Ringnes, to announce about 1,400 layoffs. Coca-Cola products account for about 35 percent of total sales for Pripps Ringnes, which is owned by the Swedish auto maker Volvo and the Norwegian consumer-products company Orkla. Coca-Cola will pay 1.1 billion Swedish kronor, or $166 million, to phase out its agreement.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Softbank Awarded Interactive Work
description: Two companies have named Softbank Interactive Marketing in New York to handle interactive advertising accounts.

title: Securities Reform Measures Gain Ground
description: The House of Representatives and a Senate panel passed securities overhaul bills today that would eliminate much state regulation of securities markets and broaden Federal oversight of mutual funds.

title: 14 in New Gang in Queens Are Charged in Major Crimes
description: Fourteen members of a Queens group that Federal prosecutors said was fast developing into a Mafia-style organized crime gang were indicted yesterday in a series of armed robberies, assaults and arson fires over the last three years.

title: Teacher Is Sentenced For Taking a Bribe
description: A New York high school teacher was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $2,500 yesterday for taking a bribe from a student in exchange for a passing grade, District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said.

title: Corrections
description: An item in the Political Briefing column yesterday about Arkansas elections misstated Richard Bearden's title. He is the executive director of the Arkansas Republican Party, not the state party chairman.

title: Maximum Wage? Tell It to Movers and Shakers;Health Care Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;Gray Hair And Golden Ambitions
description: GRAY hair. You don't expect to see an Olympic track and field athlete with gray hair, but less than two weeks away from his 35th birthday on July 1, Carl Lewis has gray hair.

title: Where Did Campaign Reform Go?
description: Nearly four years after Americans thought they had voted for campaign finance reform, the nation faces yet another Presidential election with no recorded improvement in a corrupt system that elevates the voice of wealthy special interests over that of the average voter.

title: Essay;The Shaker-Upper
description: Coping with the least of his prob lems moving into a new, fortified residence -- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu calmed the decorating concerns of his wife, Sara: "They're just not used to what we're trying to do."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;C.F.L. Pact for Frazier
description: Quarterback TOMMIE FRAZIER, who led Nebraska to two national titles, signed a one-year contract with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League yesterday. Frazier, the runner-up to Ohio State's EDDIE GEORGE in Hiesman Trophy balloting but passed over in the recent National Football League draft, is not sure when he will be available.

title: Currents;Emitting a Cinematic Glow
description: NOGUCHI had his rice paper; Jamie Anley looks to the rubbish bin for inspiration. "Our dictionary of materials is in the scrap yard," Mr. Anley, an English designer, said of the lamps, folding screens, stools and side tables that he and his partners, Astrid Zala and Matthieu Paillard, create from exotic industrial sources (flawed titanium gears from a Concorde factory, filigreed steel drums from a Whirlpool assembly line). A lamp named "Six Seconds," above, has six seconds of celluloid outtakes from an adventure film wrapped around a copper wire frame and joined at opposite corners with brass eyelets. It will be $80 at the Guggenheim Museum stores next month. It casts a lovely glow, but avoid movie-house meltdown: don't use a bulb hotter than 40 watts.

title: Currents;Spectators Move, Rowers Stay
description: OLYMPICS obsessed? If the rowers in Atlanta move a little too fast for you, here are some guys who will stay still long enough so that you can get a good look. A small exhibition of paintings at the National Gallery of Art in Washington that opens on Sunday offers some memorable images of amateur athletes by the Philadelphia realist painter Thomas Eakins -- and their brawny forms look great for 120.

title: Senate Votes For a Repeal Of One Ban On Abortion
description: The Senate gave abortion rights supporters an uncommon victory today, voting twice to repeal a longstanding ban on most abortions at military hospitals overseas.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Soccer Squads Have Two Colleges' Stamps
description: The accent was on Virginia and North Carolina yesterday when 18 men and 16 women were named to compete for the United States in the Olympic soccer tournament next month.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OSHKOSH B'GOSH TO CLOSE PLANTS AND DROP CLOTHING LINE
description: Oshkosh B'Gosh Inc. said yesterday that it would drop its Genuine Kids clothing line, close a plant in Tennessee and sell its European operation. The company, based in Oshkosh, Wis., said it planned to take a second-quarter charge of $7 million to $8 million for the moves. The charge will amount to $20 million to $22 million before taxes. The maker of children's clothes operates 88 Genuine Kids stores and 87 Oshkosh B'Gosh stores. The company, which had already said that it would close a plant in Red Boiling Springs, Tenn., said it would close a plant in Celina, Tenn., by late September. The plants employ 324 and 302 people, respectively. OshKosh B'Gosh made the announcement after the close of trading. Earlier, its shares rose 12.5 cents, to $16.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Talks on the Health Care Bill Appear to Move Backward
description: White House officials met again today with Republican Congressional aides to seek a compromise on the Republican proposal for medical savings accounts but made little progress on the issue, the last obstacle to final passage of a bill that would make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans.

title: 'Timbuktu'
description: Mr. Bones knew that Willy wasn't long for this world. The cough had been inside him for over six months, and by now there wasn't a chance in hell that he would ever get rid of it. Slowly and inexorably, without once taking a turn for the better, the thing had assumed a life of its own, advancing from a faint, phlegm-filled rattle in the lungs on February third to the wheezy sputum-jigs and gobby convulsions of high summer. All that was bad enough, but in the past two weeks a new tonality had crept into the bronchial musicsomething tight and flinty and percussiveand the attacks came so often now as to be almost constant. Every time one of them started, Mr. Bones half expected Willy's body to explode from the rockets of pressure bursting against his rib cage. He figured that blood would be the next step, and when that fatal moment finally occurred on Saturday afternoon, it was as if all the angels in heaven had opened their mouths and started to sing. Mr. Bones saw it happen with his own eyes, standing by the edge of the road between Washington and Baltimore as Willy hawked up a few miserable clots of red matter into his handkerchief, and right then and there he knew that every ounce of hope was gone. The smell of death had settled upon Willy G. Christmas, and as surely as the sun was a lamp in the clouds that went off and on every day, the end was drawing near.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT O. BOORSTIN, a former speech writer for President Clinton who is now an adviser to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, will be in New York today to discuss a subject he knows well: mental illness and the need for its victims to have the chance to do productive work.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Tele-Communications to Spin Off Satellite Unit
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, said yesterday that it would spin off TCI Satellite Entertainment Inc., its direct-to-home satellite business, into a separately traded company.

title: Bosnian Serbs Set Up Court for War Crimes
description: The Bosnian Serbs' self-styled parliament set up a court today to try people indicted for war crimes by the United Nations -- theoretically including the Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic.

title: EUROPE, DOWNSIZED -- A special report.;In Europe, a Wave of Layoffs Stuns White-Collar Workers
description: Downsizing is coming to Western Europe's white-collar workers, and fast. It is straining families, communities and politics on a continent on which 11 percent of available workers are already unemployed, double the rate in the United States.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Colombians Must Return 'Antichrist' Scare Money
description: The head of Colombia's Roman Catholic Church has ordered priests to forfeit any money they received for performing mass baptisms during a scare this month about the Antichrist.

title: Europe Scrutinizes Sects: Faith, or False Facades?
description: Gilbert Bourdin wears a winged crown, calls himself Lord Manarah the Cosmic Messiah, and lives with his followers in the Holy City of Mandar'om on a mountaintop in Provence in southern France.

title: U.S. Says Valujet Ignored DC-9 Defects
description: For more than a year before one of its jets crashed in the Everglades, Valujet Airlines flew planeloads of passengers in DC-9's that it knew to have broken or malfunctioning parts, without inspecting or repairing them, the Federal Aviation Administration said in a document released today.

title: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': THE HISTORY;In a Jittery Summer, a Killer Surfaced
description: It all began in the summer of New York City's collective nervous breakdown, as was said at the time -- a panic attack set off by a soaring rate of random, often drug-fueled violence and a deepening fear that the city was spinning out of control.

title: Man Freed by Judge Pleads Guilty in Assault
description: A Brooklyn man who punched his former girlfriend in the face after his release from jail by a judge who has since come under fire for his handling of domestic violence cases has pleaded guilty to assault.

title: Currents;Crazy Quilt, Inventively Updated
description: AMONG the most inventive items at last month's International Contemporary Furniture Fair was a modern take on the Victorian American crazy quilt -- an underappreciated wealth of design exploration, said Denyse Schmidt, 35, a former theater designer from Connecticut. Her quilts meld punchy graphics, sophisticated fabrics and delicate stitching learned while making bishops' miters and altar cloths at a Massachusetts monastery. She said she absorbed "an attitude of care about everything, that one can do something beautiful in a very simple gesture." She pieces each on a Juki machine, then sends it to Amish women for hand-finishing, a process that takes months. Prices start at $900, through the designer, at (203) 341-4316, and at Bendel's in September.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;West Publishing Purchase By Thomson Is Approved
description: The Justice Department gave conditional approval yesterday to the Thomson Corporation's $3.4 billion purchase of the West Publishing Company, but it insisted that Thomson sell 58 legal publications valued at about $275 million and license certain services to competitors.

title: Europe Edges Closer to Ending Ban on British Beef
description: The European Union and Britain edged closer to agreement today on a framework for resuming British beef exports, spelling out measures intended to quell fears about eating meat from cattle infected with the so-called mad cow disease, which has ravaged British herds.

title: Richard Roberts, 67, an Editor at The Times
description: Richard Roberts, a former editor of the New Jersey Weekly section of The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 67.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO SELL AT&T PARADYNE UNIT
description: Lucent Technologies agreed yesterday to sell its AT&T Paradyne unit to Texas Pacific Group for $175 million. The AT&T Corporation, which spun off Lucent in April, announced plans in October to sell Paradyne, which is based in Largo, Fla. Paradyne, which makes technologies for multimedia communications, has annual sales of $275 million. Lucent will retain Paradyne's data equipment service business. Texas Pacific Group manages TPG Partners L.P. of Fort Worth, a private investment partnership.

title: Olympics;Johnson Wins on Wings, Powell Wins on Prayer
description: Michael Johnson eased his way onto the Olympic team tonight with the third-fastest 400 meters ever run. If there was no suspense in the quarter mile, though, there was plenty in the long jump, where Mike Powell went from sixth place to first on his final attempt, and Carl Lewis hung on by an inch to qualify for his fifth Summer Games.

title: Turkey-Israel Military Pact Recalls Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY BALLET REVIEW;That Other 'Swan Lake,' Distilled to Its Soul
description: Showing off its distinctive streamlined style, the New York City Ballet injects a typical zing into George Balanchine's one-act version of "Swan Lake."

title: BASEBALL;For Yankees, Some Joy in Mudville
description: Joe Torre conceded yesterday that his pitching staff is in flux. And yet the Yankee manager said it was not the pitching that was bothering him. Mention his team's lack of hitting and Torre is liable to cringe.
