description: Coming to Painful Terms With Victory and Defeat 'Tokyo Cancan' Theater at St. Clement's

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Bryant Talks to 76ers
description: Dressed in an expensive Italian suit, KOBE BRYANT looked more like the pro basketball player he will become and less like the recent high school graduate that he is.

title: Prosecutors Tie A Clinton Aide To Conspiracy
description: Federal prosecutors today described Bruce Lindsey, one of President Clinton's closest advisers, as a conspirator in an illegal scheme to conceal a $30,000 withdrawal from a bank account that was maintained by Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign for governor of Arkansas in 1990.

title: Survey by Fed Says Economy Is Strong, With Little Inflation
description: Despite fresh strength in the economy, wages and prices remain largely in check, a survey by the Federal Reserve found today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Motorola Inc., Schaumburg, Ill., to Sicola Martin, Austin, Tex., to handle its Power PC account, which had been handled by Anderson & Lembke, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Though the billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $10 million to $12 million. Americhoice Corp., Vienna, Va., to Tierney & Partners, Philadelphia, a unit of True North Communications, to handle advertising for the health care company, which had been handled by Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Bill Aims to Bar Iran Investment From Overseas
description: The House of Representatives today unanimously passed harsh economic sanctions against foreign companies that invest in Iran, widening the split between the United States and its allies over the use of American economic power to force other nations to isolate rogue states.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Baroque Mosaic of Voices From the Heartland
description: For its latest choral spectacular, a performance of the Brahms "German Requiem" on Sunday at Carnegie Hall, Midamerica Productions ratcheted up its quality considerably. A fascinating hybrid of art and commerce, Midamerica is essentially a travel agency that sells New York City package tours to school, church and civic ensembles from all over the country, with a public performance as part of the deal. Typically, a handful of choirs from here and there are brought together for rehearsals and a concert, with the conductor and orchestra supplied by Midamerica. More often than not the choirs have proved to be quite good, while the orchestral playing and conducting have been average.

title: After Marathon Struggle, Karpov Collects the Point
description: In the second playing session of Game 7 of the world championship match in Elista, Russia, Anatoly Karpov took just 14 moves yesterday to defeat the hapless Gata Kamsky. The victory increased Karpov's lead in the series to 5 to 2.

title: Young Journalists Cited for Excellence
description: Three reporters have received the 15th Livingston Awards for Young Journalists, given annually for excellence in local, national and international reporting to those under 35.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Against Same-Sex Marriages
description: A bill to be introduced today would make New Jersey the 12th state to ban same-sex marriages. Twenty-eight Assembly members are co-sponsoring similar legislation.

title: Principal Is Charged With Thefts From School
description: A vocational high school principal has been indicted on charges that he stole tools, building supplies and several donated cars from the school over a five-year period and sold them for his own profit.

title: Calendar: Plant Images And Lamps
description: Garden Images Wave Hill, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, Riverdale, the Bronx; (718) 549-3200.

title: Maximum Wage? Tell It to Movers and Shakers;Just Imagine . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Judge Upholds Law on Violence Against Women
description: For the first time, a Federal District Court judge has upheld the constitutionality of the Violence Against Women Act of 1994, a Federal law that made crimes against the opposite sex a violation of the victim's civil rights.

title: Spread of Intestinal Infection Baffles Scientists
description: United States and Canadian health officials said yesterday that they were mystified by the outbreak an intestinal infection caused by an exotic microbe. So far, a few hundred cases have been reported in at least eight states and Toronto since early May.

title: U.S. WILL OPPOSE MOVE TO RE-ELECT TOP U.N. OFFICIAL
description: The Clinton Administration has decided not to support Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a second term as United Nations Secretary General and has informed him that Washington will use its veto, if necessary, to prevent his re-election, senior American officials said today.

title: Tenneco to Sell Its Gas Unit to El Paso Energy
description: Tenneco Inc., intent on transforming itself from a stumbling conglomerate into a nimble manufacturer, agreed today to sell its natural gas operations to the El Paso Energy Corporation for $750 million in stock and the assumption of debt and other liabilities.

title: In Perfoormance;DANCE
description: Evening of Flamenco, Heated In Both Spirit and Reality Noche Flamenca Theater 80

title: BASEBALL;Gilkey Snaps Out of It With a Swing and Salvages the Mets' Day
description: It had been a forgettable road trip for Bernard Gilkey. An 0 for 15 in St. Louis, hadn't gotten much better in Pittsburgh. He had just 4 hits in his previous 27 at-bats and his last home run was somewhere around Memorial Day.

title: HORSE RACING;They're Off. No, They're On.
description: Racing from Belmont Park was back on television yesterday when Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill extending in-home simulcasting until June 30 after the Assembly had left the measure dangling over the weekend.

title: Church for the 3d Millennium
description: IN 1656, when Bernini planned St. Peter's Square at the Vatican, he included two curved colonnades that almost encircle it. He compared them to the arms of the church, which "embrace Catholics, to reinforce their belief."

title: Suicide in Jail Leads County To Cancel Pact
description: Saying that a private health care company treating Westchester County Jail inmates stopped giving antidepressant medication to a 17-year-old girl who later committed suicide, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke today canceled the company's $10.2-million contract.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Meningitis Case Prompts Alert
description: A 10-year-old girl died Tuesday night of meningitis, and Ocean County health officials said yesterday they had warned about 30 people who had had close contact with the child to take antibiotics to stave off the disease.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEMPEST REINSURANCE ACCEPTS OFFER FROM ACE
description: Tempest Reinsurance Company agreed yesterday to a revised takeover offer from a Bermuda reinsurance rival, ACE Ltd. Under the agreement, Tempest shareholders will receive a cash dividend, ACE common stock and a "guaranteed value cash dividend" of as much as $50 million, the companies said. The companies did not disclose the total value of the deal. Earlier this month, ACE increased its cash and stock offer to $743.9 million, or $179.04 for each Tempest common share, from $640 million. Tempest also said that its board had terminated discussions with IPC Holdings Ltd., a reinsurance broker that offered $943 million in cash and stock.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OWENS-CORNING HINTS OF PROGRESS IN ASBESTOS SUITS
description: The shares of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation rose 2.5 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of building and industrial materials, said there were "significant developments" regarding multimillion-dollar asbestos lawsuits it faces. The company declined to comment furtherabout the developments, saying it would disclose details at a news conference today. The company, one of dozens of former makers of asbestos or asbestos-containing products, has been sued by former workers who became ill and by the estates of those who died from inhaling asbestos fibers on the job. Owens-Corning has $702 million in uninsured claims filed against it. On June 10, the Supreme Court rejected Owens-Corning's appeals of four asbestos-related punitive damage awards worth almost $24 million. The shares of Owens-Corning rose $1, to $40.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SENIOR CLASS;Living Five Score Or More
description: A BOUQUET of multicolored balloons rose above each table, and a violinist and an accordionist made the rounds playing "Let Me Call You Sweetheart" and "Come, Josephine, in My Flying Machine." Many of the guests sang along. Gov. Lincoln Almond threaded his way among the wheelchairs, passing out congratulatory certificates amid a volley of flashbulbs.

title: More Contracts Canceled For Social-Service Agency
description: City officials have canceled another group of contracts with the Queens social-service agency at the heart of a criminal investigation into the Giuliani administration's contracting practices, and leaders of the organization say the move leaves it virtually dismantled.

title: INCOME DISPARITY BETWEEN POOREST AND RICHEST RISES
description: Using new methods of collecting data that it says provide a more accurate picture of incomes, the Census Bureau said today that the gap between the most affluent Americans and everyone else was wider than it has been since the end of World War II.

title: ON BASEBALL;Plan Is to Keep the Kids And Hope for the Best
description: Joe Torre and Bob Watson emerged from the muck and mire of the Yankees-Twins rainout yesterday with two sets of priorities.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A More Intimate 'Passion' Throws Off Its Inhibitions
description: Sometimes it's hard to tell what's wrong with something until the wrong has been righted. Certainly, at least some of us who attended the first full production of Stephen Sondheim's "Passion," on Broadway in 1994, left it remarking on a scarcity of the show's title emotion.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Ella Fitzgerald misidentified the first feature film in which she appeared. It was "Ride 'Em Cowboy" in 1942, not "Pete Kelly's Blues" in 1955.

title: Law to Let Voters Approve Or Reject School Budgets
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed legislation that would for the first time give residents in the state's smaller cities the opportunity to approve or reject their school budgets in annual referendums.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AUCTION HOUSE SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK MORE OF ITS SHARES
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the New York auction house, has raised the number of common shares it plans to buy back to four million, from one million, the company said yesterday. Sotheby's attributed the increase to its positive outlook for the international art auction market and its strong financial performance. The buyback represents 10.3 percent of outstanding class A common shares and 7.1 percent of the total outstanding class A and class B common shares. Based on Tuesday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange, the buyback would cost $56 million. The shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $14.125.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Japanese Explain Error In Downing of U.S. Plane
description: The Japanese Navy blamed the chief weapons officer aboard a destroyer today for the shooting down of an American plane during maneuvers in the mid-Pacific this month.

title: I.R.A. Says It Set Off Bomb
description: The Irish Republican Army today claimed responsiblity for a weekend bomb in Manchester, England, that wounded more than 200 people and disrupted the Northern Ireland peace process.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Ford Executive Roles To Be Split in Europe
description: The chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, Alexander Trotman, announced a shake-up in the company's top-level European management today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday about the opening of a new Greek restaurant, Mykonian House, in Great Neck, L.I., misstated the relationship between Steve Tzolis and Nicola Kotsoni, who are partners in several restaurants in Manhattan. They are not partners in Mykonian House, and they are not married.

title: Pataki Backer Gets Job Offer
description: The brother of a Democratic state lawmaker who crossed party lines in 1994 and endorsed George E. Pataki's run for governor is in line for a $60,000-a-year administration job, officials said today.

title: Seles Passes Test On Grass Courts
description: Monica Seles, playing on grass for the first time in four years, beat Meredith McGrath in straight sets today to reach the quarterfinals of the Wimbledon warm-up tournament at Eastbourne. Seles won by 6-2, 6-4 in 69 minutes, relying on her trademark double-handed ground strokes to beat an opponent who has more than proved herself on grass.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dining Alfresco in Englewood
description: It isn't expected to rival Paris' Left Bank, but Englewood will soon have sidewalk cafes. An ordinance to allow outdoor table service won preliminary approval Tuesday night, and officials said they would begin issuing temporary permits immediately. Owners of about 10 restaurants have said they want to offer alfresco dining, Douglas M. Bern, president of the City Council, said yesterday.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Posthumous Send-Off For a British Original
description: Dennis Potter, the most important voice in television drama ("Pennies From Heaven," "The Singing Detective"), died of pancreatic cancer two years ago this month. Appropriately, the notoriously cantankerous British writer has been given an extraordinary send-off.

title: HOCKEY;How Many More Valuable Seasons Are Left for Lemieux?
description: Mario Lemieux's inspirational return to the National Hockey League was capped tonight when he was awarded the Hart Memorial Trophy as the league's most valuable player for the third time.

title: Counterfeiters of a New Stripe Give Japan One More Worry;Fake Cards Thwart Efforts to End Pinball Scams
description: Why is it that every time someone gambles with metal, the Sumitomo Corporation takes a bath? Everyone knows by now of the $1.8 billion loss that was caused by a rogue trader in copper futures. But only a month ago, Sumitomo was in the headlines as a victim of one of the largest electronic crimes in history -- involving, of all things, pinball.

title: When Voice of the Yankees Connected a Distant Father and Son
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;Where No 2 Legs Are Alike
description: CHRISTOPHER ROSS, 26, a sculptor, designs furniture inspired by the Guedra, a mystical dance performed by veiled women in Morocco. Their hands and feet are decorated with elaborate geometric patterns stenciled to the skin with henna paste. Mr. Ross uses salvaged white oak planks for his tabletops and laminates light and dark layers of walnut and maple for the whimsical legs (none alike). The top ends of the legs create striped effects on the table tops. His furniture is designed to stay outdoors and to weather. The coffee tables and stools, below, come in various shapes, around $1,500. Through the designer, at (212) 807-0083.

title: Killer of 2-Year-Old Is Executed in Arizona
description: A man was executed by lethal injection here early today for the kidnapping and murder of a 2-year-old girl.

title: Maximum Wage? Tell It to Movers and Shakers
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Black Men Are Arrested In N. Carolina Church Fire
description: Two black men were arrested today in connection with the burning of a historic building on the grounds of a local black church. Local and Federal officials said the arson was not racially motivated.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Retail Sales Slipped a Bit in May
description: Sales at British retail stores fell an unexpected one-tenth of 1 percent in May from those in April, the first monthly decline since January, as cold weather deterred shoppers from buying summer clothing. Sales rose 2 percent from a year earlier, unchanged from the annual increase in April, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Agreed: It Was a Jungle, In the Bad Old Days
description: If truth-in-advertising laws were applied to television titles, tomorrow night's edition of "Firing Line" would be in for it. The proclaimed subject, "Resolved: The Marketplace Is Not a Social Enemy," is scarcely on the minds of the affirmative forces led by William F. Buckley Jr., known as Mr. Conservative, or the negatives, led by Robert Kuttner, co-editor of The American Prospect, known as a liberal journal.

title: Backward Steps on Garbage Disposal
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has never shown much interest in garbage recycling. That statement does not necessarily constitute a criticism of his administration -- no New York City mayor can make every needed service a priority. If Mr. Giuliani were to admit that he finds combating crime, balancing the budget and improving child welfare services more compelling than disposing of the trash, few voters would recoil in horror.

title: BOXING;Moorer's Trainer Tries to Light the Flame
description: Michael Moorer, once a passionless heavyweight champion, leaned over to his trainer, Teddy Atlas, yesterday and said: "I want the championship again. Do you want to be connected with it again? Then will you leave me alone?"

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Opening Local Phone Market
description: In a step that will end the Bell Atlantic Company's virtual monopoly in New Jersey, the state Board of Public Utilities yesterday decided to allow long distance carriers and the cable industry to enter the local telephone market. The companies said the increase in competition would lower rates, increase the options available to customers and stimulate ideas.

title: Currents;Padded Like a 50's Pinup
description: SMILE and say "summer": new talent at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York included Elizabeth Paige Smith, 27, of Los Angeles, whose lighthearted chairs and tables were inspired by Bunny Yeager's stark pinup photos, 1950's pop culture and colors of the Caribbean, where Ms. Smith grew up. The curvaceous Lola armchair, $2,500, above, is upholstered with woven raffia and has a sand-colored velvet seat-cushion cover and nylon front wheels to roll it from indoors to outdoors. Another chair, Maria Stinger, $2,100, seems made of Silly Putty melted in the sun. Through the designer, at (310) 657-7350.

title: In Barring Waldheim, U.S. Followed the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;WEST COAST ENTERTAINMENT TO BUY 72 VIDEO STORES
description: The West Coast Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it had signed agreements in principle to buy up to 72 independent video stores. After the acquisitions, which are subject to numerous conditions, West Coast will own 575 stores in 25 states and three foreign countries. The company, which is based in Philadelphia, said the acquisitions would expand its presence in New Jersey, central Ohio, Kentucky and Boston. Financial terms were not disclosed. The company went public in early May at $13 a share, which is where the stock closed yesterday, after slipping 25 cents in Nasdaq trading.

title: More Cuts For Prices Of Cereal
description: General Mills Inc., which initiated price cuts in the cereal industry two years ago, said today that it would again cut its prices, by an average of 11 percent, on such cereals as Cocoa Puffs, Trix and Lucky Charms and increase the package sizes of some other brands.

title: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC': THE SUSPECT;Recluse With Message of Good and Evil
description: Gripping a Bible in his hand, Heriberto Seda would stalk around his scarred and battered East New York neighborhood, always at night, always alone. He would stride up to drug dealers in the alleys and on the corners and rail about good and evil, God and the Devil.

title: BASEBALL;Smoltz Hits The Mark With 14th Straight
description: John Smoltz was once considered the runt of the Atlanta Braves' glittering pitching staff, but no more.

title: Clarence Combs, 81, Dies; Veterinarian Was Polo Star
description: Dr. Clarence (Buddy) Combs, the galloping New Jersey veterinarian who rode his way into the United States Polo Hall of Fame, died last Sunday at his home in Colt's Neck, N.J. He was 81.

title: East Side Souk With Rugs
description: THE Great Hall of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 66th Street -- a skylighted gymnasium-like room that is more often the site of upper-crust diversions like the Winter Antiques Show -- has taken on the air of a souk. Interior designers are adding to the atmosphere by acting like flies, or at least dropping like them, in the unair-conditioned heat.

title: Alarm Bells Sounding as Suburbs Gobble Up California's RichestFarmland
description: Born and raised in this, the most fruitful farm county in America, David Mas Masumoto sighed as his van passed the pastel swaths of suburbia that have displaced many of the vivid orchards, vineyards and strawberry fields of his childhood.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Banks Agree To Bailout Fund
description: Japanese banks yielded to political pressure yesterday to make an extra contribution to a Government plan to bail out failed mortgage companies, known as jusen, to reduce the burden on taxpayers. The banks accepted the proposal made on Tuesday by the Finance Minister, Wataru Kubo, to contribute extra money to set up a new fund as a part of the plan.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Maple Galls

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER JENNINGS, the ABC News anchor, owns a house in Bridgehampton, L.I., on the north side of Highway 27 or, as he said yesterday, "on what has been historically known as the wrong side of the highway, the nonbeach side." But, he was quick to add, "I think of it as the right side."

title: Communist Struggles for Support as Rivals Back Yeltsin
description: As more presidential also-rans announced their unwillingness to support his candidacy, the Communist leader Gennadi A. Zyuganov struggled today to patch together a coalition that could defeat President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: THE TRAIL OF 'THE ZODIAC';Tracking a Killer
description: The letter that arrived at the 75th Precinct stationhouse in Brooklyn that day in November 1989 could have made sense only to the writer, someone who seemed steeped in astrology and thoughts of death and some connection between them that perhaps only he divined.

title: Albany on the Air: Politically Savvy And Cable-Ready;Legislators' Programs Heavy On Self-Promotion, Critics Say
description: Thomas M. Reynolds, an Assemblyman from upstate New York, was the guest earlier this month on "Assembly Calendar," a televised talk show billed as a straightforward news report on happenings in the Capitol, similar to the fare on C-Span or CNN.

title: Liberties;Clan of the Cave Bears
description: Imagine Bob Dole at the Watergate, meeting with his inner circle.

title: Texas Instruments Passes Over Two in Picking Chief
description: Texas Instruments passed over its two top executives today to name Thomas J. Engibous, 43 years old, as its new president and chief executive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The X Games: Going to extremes in an effort to tap a growing segment of sports
description: HERE's "Generation X" and "The X-Files," "Madame X" and X marks the spot. Now, ESPN Inc. hopes to add one more name to that list: the X Games.

title: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE REFORMER;A Onetime Scapegoat Savors Taste of Revenge
description: Just five months after the Yeltsin Government's foremost proponent of free-market reform was humilated and forced out of office, Anatoly B. Chubais has vanquished his enemies and made a triumphant return.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks were rising here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 52.95 points, or a quarter-percent, at 22,490.25 points. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 69.94 points, or 0.31 percent.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Clay-Bey Charged in '95
description: The United States Olympic boxer and prison guard LAWRENCE CLAY-BEY was arrested 16 months ago in Hartford on a charge of sexual assault with a weapon -- a vase -- and is enrolled in a court-supervised rehabilitation program. The criminal case is not expected to affect Clay-Bey's eligibility to compete at the Olympics. Clay-Bey, 30, lives in Bloomfield, Conn., with his wife and three children.

title: NEW VIDEO RELESES
description: Sense and Sensibility 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. Laser disk, $39.95. 136 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: TWO RADIO GIANTS TO MERGE, FORMING BIGGEST NETWORK
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it would acquire the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation for $3.7 billion, merging the nation's two largest radio broadcasters in a deal made possible by a new telecommunications law that lifted the limits on radio station ownership.

title: ART REVIEW;Savoring a Medium Whose Bite Has Grown With Age
description: ONE of the great things about "Thinking Print: Books to Billboards, 1980-95," the Museum of Modern Art's big, ecumenical account of recent printmaking, is that it takes both the high road and the low road.

title: CALIFORNIA JUDGES EASE 3-STRIKE LAW
description: Substantially watering down California's tough "three-strikes" sentencing law, the state's highest court ruled today that judges had the right to disregard a defendant's prior convictions if they thought a mandatory prison sentence would be too cruel.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Simunye' ('We Are One') Adelson Galleries, the Mark Hotel 25 East 77th Street, Manhattan Through July 1

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Report Said to Back U.S. on Cuban Downings
description: A United Nations investigation has concluded that Cuba's downing of two light civilian aircraft flown by Cuban-Americans occurred over international waters, a United States official said today.

title: Sports of The Times;No Owners Need Apply For Commish
description: IN the classic film "The Wizard of Oz," Dorothy (Judy Garland) discovers a befuddled chap posing as a wizard and indignantly tells the man (Frank Morgan) that he is a fraud. He musters up his dignity and insists that he is "a very good man but a very bad wizard."

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Where Twins Diverge On Human Tragedies
description: Maybe it's unseemly to suggest that a photographic exhibition documenting some of the last decade's most brutal events -- famines, wars, massacres and epidemics -- is an occasion to conduct a study of twins. But that, nonetheless, is unavoidable.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TELXON STOCK PLUNGES AFTER PREDICTION OF LOSS
description: The shares of the Telxon Corporation fell 31 percent yesterday after the company, which makes hand-held computers and wireless communication devices, said it would lose money in the first half of its fiscal year. Telxon said after the close of trading on Wednesday that it expected a loss of about 50 cents for the period, which ends in September. Analysts had expected the company, which is based in Akron, Ohio, to earn 39 cents a share in the first half, according to analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Telxon's shares fell $4.625, to $9.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: TV SPORTS;Boxing's Return to Networks Does Not Signal a Resurgence
description: First came Mike Tyson versus Buster Mathis Jr. on Fox last December.

title: Ingram, the Ex-Giant, Is Signed by Eagles
description: Mark Ingram, a free-agent wide receiver and a former Giant, signed a one-year contract today with the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: ART REVIEW;Spinning Myths Without Sentimentality
description: IF you harbor any doubts about whether Winslow Homer was the greatest painter America produced in the 19th century, the Homer show that has just arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art should dispel them. The doubts are understandable, considering that his images of rocky seascapes, freckled urchins and Adirondack woodsmen have been so thoroughly absorbed into our collective memory, and so degraded by generations of outdoor magazine illustrators, that it is possible to take Homer for granted, if not unconsciously to confuse him with his imitators. To a degree, Homer has become synonymous with a certain quaint, populist, long-gone Americana, and this has caused people to misgauge his achievement.

title: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;Perot Party to Open Convention In California, on Eve of G.O.P.'s
description: Seizing a chance to upstage the Republicans, officials of the Ross Perot-led Reform Party announced yesterday that its convention would open on Aug. 11 in Long Beach, Calif., the day before the Republicans begin meeting in San Diego.

title: FILM REVIEW;Saving the Human Race, Symbolically Speaking
description: It wouldn't be inaccurate to describe "Magic Hunter," Ildiko Enyedi's hopelessly pretentious meditation on the Weber opera "Der Freischutz," as a movie that dreams of saving the human race. Or as the Hungarian director nervily asserts in the film's production notes, "We people living today have done all we can to put ourselves in mortal danger and only a miracle can save us." The solution, she proposes, is to reconnect to the folkloric past, when the Devil and the Virgin Mary manifested themselves all over the place, and wait for salvation.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Muster Withdraws
description: THOMAS MUSTER, angered earlier this week at being seeded only No. 7 for Wimbledon when he was the second-ranked tennis player in the world, vowed to prove he could play on grass as well as clay.

title: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE OVERVIEW;ELECTION LOOMING, YELTSIN DISMISSES 3 TOP HARD-LINERS
description: Seeking to end a bitter power struggle within his campaign and cleanse his tarnished administration before the presidential runoff election 13 days away, President Boris N. Yeltsin today dismissed three of his most powerful and hawkish advisers, including his closest confidant and widely feared security chief.

title: Crash Kills G. David Schine, 69, McCarthy-Era Figure
description: G. David Schine, a catalytic figure in the fierce drama that brought to a climax the chapter in American history known as the McCarthy era, was killed on Wednesday when a single-engine plane piloted by his son Berndt crashed shortly after takeoff from Burbank, Calif.

title: Michel M. Ter-Pogossian, 71; Led Research on PET Scanner
description: Dr. Michel Mathew Ter-Pogossian, who led the research that turned the positron emission tomography (PET) scanner from an intriguing concept to a medical tool used in hospitals and laboratories everywhere, died on Wednesday while vacationing in Paris. He was 71 and lived in St. Louis, where he worked at Washington University Medical School.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: HANCOCK HOLDING CO., a banking company in Gulfport, Miss., will acquire Community Bancshares, Independence, La., for about $22 million.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Atlanta 1996;An All-New Dan Show
description: After winning his third world championship in the decathlon last summer, Dan O'Brien decided he could approach the future only by confronting the past.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Use for an Old Hall
description: In a step intended to broaden the city's appeal to visitors, the board of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Authority said yesterday that it would seek to develop the existing convention hall into a major arena where concerts, sports events and family shows could be staged. The move was recommended in a study conducted by a national consulting firm, Deloitte & Touche, on possible uses of the hall once the new Atlantic City Convention Center opens next May. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Israeli Religious Parties Perform No Disservice;Archeological Projects
description: To the Editor:

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Dip
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.3 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent last week, according to a national survey issued today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.93 percent, up from 5.91 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.81 percent this week, down from 7.9 percent a week earlier.

title: Charles Kades, 90, Architect Of Japan's Postwar Charter
description: Charles L. Kades, a lawyer who supervised the drafting of Japan's postwar Constitution, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Greenfield, Mass. He was 90 and had lived in Heath, Mass., since his retirement from law practice in New York in 1976.

title: POLITICS: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Oregon Honesty at Issue, Decision Is Put Off

title: FILM REVIEW;Sleepy Texas Town With an Epic Story
description: THE great, stirring epic "Lone Star" stands as a peak in the career of John Sayles, who already has such admirably serious films to his credit. Long admired for the independence and quiet intelligence of his work, Mr. Sayles this time delivers a vibrant history lesson about a Texas border town.

title: Ex-Officer Gets 18 Months in Briberies
description: A former undercover police officer who admitted accepting bribes from organized-crime figures in Chinatown for years and alerting them to police raids on illegal gambling dens and brothels was sentenced yesterday to 18 months in prison.

title: Semantics Won't Change the Abortion Debate;Dilemma Remains
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Park Victim Awakens in 'Crucial Step' to Recovery
description: The woman who was severely beaten in Central Park two weeks ago has regained consciousness and begun to communicate, a neurosurgeon at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center said, calling the change an "absolutely crucial step" toward recovery.

title: ART REVIEW;A Caribbean Take on Modern Styles
description: The Caribbean island nation called the Dominican Republic is the source of one of this city's fastest-growing immigrant populations. But for most New Yorkers, the idea of "Dominican art" probably draws a blank.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton to Back Amendment on Victims' Rights, Aides Say
description: Having opposed every other proposed constitutional amendment during his term, President Clinton now intends to support one intended to give crime victims the guaranteed right to be notified of and heard at court proceedings involving defendants in their cases, Administration officials say.

title: Iraqi Arms Plant Destroyed
description: United Nations monitors have completed the demolition of an Iraqi weapons plant used to make anthrax and other germ warfare agents, the world organization said today. A videotape of the destruction, with which Iraq cooperated, showed workers dynamiting buildings, smashing equipment and spraying water on chemicals.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Up 7.7% In April on High Oil Prices
description: The highest oil prices since the Persian Gulf war helped widen the American trade deficit as imports and exports climbed to record levels.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Reprieve for a Cathedral
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese will have to conduct rigorous environmental testing before demolishing a crumbling cathedral that is one of the few 19th-century buildings left in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Presidential contest in the South omitted the margin of sampling error for a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken May 31 through June 3, in which President Clinton led Bob Dole in the South by 47 percent to 41 percent. In a sample of the size used in that poll, the statistical margin of error is plus or minus six percentage points; that is, within accepted standards of probability, the result for either candidate in the entire South could have been as much as six points lower or higher than the result in the sample.

title: Homeless Chief Resigns
description: New York City's Commissioner of Homeless Services, Joan Malin, announced yesterday that she would resign, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani replaced her with a trusted administrator who now serves as chief of staff to First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers. Late next month, the new commissioner, Gordon J. Campbell, will take over direction of the homeless shelter system, which serves 25,000 people a day. Ms. Malin will become the executive director of the BRC Human Services Corporation, a nonprofit agency that provides shelter and counseling to the homeless.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUARTERLY EARNINGS RISE 86% AT LEHMAN BROTHERS
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose 86 percent in the fiscal second quarter, led by gains in investment banking and trading. Lehman, the fourth-largest American securities firm, said net income in the quarter, which ended on May 31, advanced to $108 million, or 89 cents a share, from $58 million, or 43 cents, a year earlier. That exceeded analyst expectations, which ranged from 78 cents to 81 cents, based on a survey by I.B.E.S. International.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Murdoch, With Softbank, To Buy Into TV Asahi
description: Rupert Murdoch is teaming with the Softbank Corporation, Japan's largest personal computer software distributor, to buy part of the major Japanese network TV Asahi. Softbank and the News Corporation, headed by Mr. Murdoch, will form a venture to buy Obunsha Media, a unit of the Obunsha Company, for about 41.75 billion yen ($386.6 million).

title: Clinton Aide Central in Fraud, Jury Is Told
description: In the opening of the second Whitewater-related trial, a prosecutor told jurors here today that President Clinton was not accused of wrongdoing in the criminal case against two bankers in connection with contributions to Mr. Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor.

title: FILM REVIEW;The Dancing Gargoyles Romp and Wisecrack
description: Having explored so many other avenues in the world of animation, Disney tries something new: self-parody. Or so it often seems during "The Hunchback of Notre Dame," the latest and most uncertain of Disney's animated efforts, with its manic mood swings and cloying, none-too-cuddly hero. In a film that bears conspicuous, eager resemblances to other recent Disney hits, the film makers' Herculean work is overshadowed by a Sisyphean problem. There's just no way to delight children with a feel-good version of this story.

title: Tribute for Helen Keane
description: A memorial tribute to the jazz record producer and manager Helen Keane is to be held on Sunday at 2 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. Ms. Keane died in April at 73. Among those scheduled to participate are the trumpeter Art Farmer and the singer Barbara Carroll.

title: 2 Startling Arrests Capture Growing Mood That New York Is Safer
description: From time to time, a single incident or series of events seems to leap out of the vast variousness of New York City life and come to symbolize some emerging shift in the public mood.

title: Departing F.A.A. Man: Expert Lacking Finesse
description: Soon after the crash of the single-engine plane that killed 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff on April 11, the calls poured into the Federal Aviation Administration. How could the agency let a child fly a plane?

title: No Headline
description: There is not a market for technical answers to issues of air safety, which are ultimately not satisfying to the public. There is a market for the terrible swift sword."

title: Chalco de Solidaridad Journal;Let the Heavens Fall, Mexicans Will Revere Virgin
description: Through assassinations, the collapse of the peso and bizarre scandals, tough times have made many Mexicans willing to believe the worst about Mexico of late.

title: The Charge Is Assault In a Beating at an L.I. Bar
description: Ignoring the recommendation of prosecutors, a Suffolk County grand jury has indicted a New York City police detective on a charge of first-degree assault rather than attempted murder in last month's racially tinged attack on a black man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub.

title: Doctor Defends Treatment Of Girl Who Killed Herself
description: A psychiatrist defended his treatment today of a 17-year-old girl who killed herself at the Westchester County Jail last month, saying that the girl did not want to take her anti-depressant medicine and that he could not force her to take it.

title: Chain Gangs Are Halted In Alabama
description: A year after becoming the first state to revive chain gangs, Alabama has yielded to pressure to end the practice of shackling inmates together as they work on roadside cleanup projects.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Calipari Toys With Idea Of Making Bryant a Net
description: Brace yourself. John Calipari may be new at this draft thing, but he's not afraid to make an unpopular or risky choice.

title: A Gypsy Suspect With Many Names
description: The man who might be named Larry Stevens was stunned when he strolled out of his Staten Island apartment Wednesday evening into the arms of two waiting suburban policemen.

title: In Close Vote, Law On Logging Survives
description: The House approved fiscal 1997 spending plans for the Interior Department and other natural-resources agencies today after a debate that underscored the potency of the environment as an election-year issue.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Feels Ready to Go
description: Andy Pettitte tossed 50 pitches off a soggy mound at Yankee Stadium yesterday morning, did not feel any new pain in his inflamed left elbow and declared himself ready to pitch against the Indians in Cleveland on Sunday. Well, sort of.

title: Second of Five Defendants Is Acquitted in '91 Gang Rape Case
description: The second of five men accused of raping an unconscious woman in a restaurant near here in 1991 was found not guilty of all charges yesterday.

title: Citing Abuses After Blast, Panel Cracks Down on Ambulance Chasing
description: Just before midnight on March 24, 1994, a natural gas pipeline exploded in Edison, N.J., destroying much of the nearby Durham Woods apartment complex and injuring more than 100 people. The ruins of the apartments were still smoldering the next afternoon when lawyers began arriving.

title: Wasteful Weapons Spending
description: Five years after the disintegration of the Soviet Union, Washington is still hooked on excessive defense spending. A Presidential election year may not be a promising moment to urge restraint, but the military spending binge Congress is contemplating bears little relation to the diminished foreign threats that face the United States.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: China Further Eases Trading Of Currency
description: China announced today that it would take a series of steps in coming months to make its currency, the yuan, more easily convertible.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Only 200 More Chances to See . . .

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Man Behind the Scenes At Infinity Broadcasting
description: While many media executives love to preen in the spotlight -- Did someone say Ted Turner? -- the man widely regarded as the nation's most successful radio executive, Mel Karmazin, has preferred to dodge the limelight. Until now.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALCO STANDARD'S STOCK FALLS ON SPINOFF ANNOUNCEMENT
description: The stock of the Alco Standard Corporation fell sharply yesterday, a day after the company, which provides paper and office equipment, said it would split its two operating units into independent companies and warned of disappointing earnings. The stock fell $9.625, to $49, on the New York Stock Exchange, where more than 6.4 million shares were traded. Alco, through its Ikon Office Solutions unit, is the largest distributor of office equipment in North America and Britain. Its Unisource Worldwide Inc. subsidiary is the largest marketer and distributor of paper and imaging products in North America. Alco, which is based in Wayne, Pa., also predicted lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings because revenues have been hurt by a drop in paper prices.

title: For Children
description: 'Game Day' The Arsenal Central Park Fifth Avenue and 64th Street entrance (800) 201-7275 Recommended for all ages Tomorrow

title: Zodiac Suspect Obtained Gun-Making Materials Via Mail Order,Detectives Say
description: Tucked away in his room at the back of a bullet-pocked Brooklyn building ridden with drug dealers, Heriberto Seda, the reclusive man the police are calling the Zodiac killer, never had to leave his doorstep to amass his homemade artillery. The ammunition and gun-making materials came right to his doorstep, delivered by United Parcel Service, and cost him no more than a pittance, $1.50 for 50 rounds via mail-order purchase, detectives in the case said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Westinghouse to Acquire Infinity for $3.7 Billion Westinghouse Electric will acquire Infinity Broadcasting for $3.7 billion, merging the nation's two largest radio broadcasters in a deal made possible by a new telecommunications law that lifted the limits of radio station ownership.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trial Begins in Chief's Death
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of a man charged with killing the retired police chief of Hanover in a Newark cemetery last July. But prosecutors said they would not be able to seek the death penalty against Thomas Cross, 24, of Irvington, because it was unclear whether he or a co-defendant, Warren Drew Jenkins of Newark, fired the shot that killed John Deventer. Mr. Jenkins will be tried separately.

title: Art in Review
description: Pamela Fraser Casey M. Kaplan Gallery 580 Broadway, near Prince Street SoHo Through June 29

title: On My Mind;Mugging Boutros-Ghali
description: The U.S. decision to veto the re-election of the Secretary General of the U.N. tells us a lot about the Clinton Administration -- all bad -- and nothing true about Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the talented and brave Egyptian diplomat Washington is trying to eliminate.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Sees Progress On Labor Agreement
description: David Cone surrounded his comments with words of caution, but it was the other words he used that provided the first public glimpse that baseball's labor negotiators are moving forward in their effort to end their two-year-old dispute. Two years and six days after the owners made their initial proposal for a new collective bargaining agreement, Cone spoke yesterday about "significant progress" and "optimism."

title: U.N. Chief, Defying U.S., Looks for Support in Europe
description: Defying Washington's threat to prevent him from serving a second term, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the United Nations Secretary General, began canvassing European allies for support today.

title: 25 and Under
description: Taxi cabs are almost always double- and triple-parked on First Avenue near 90th Street, where for almost 10 years El Pollo, a pleasant little Peruvian restaurant, has served the best roast chicken in town.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;$1 Million Purse and Record Waiting for Cigar
description: Cigar, needing one victory to match Citation's modern record of 16 in a row, will get back to serious work today or tomorrow and will probably try to equal the record in three weeks in a special race being created for him at Arlington International near Chicago.

title: NYC;The Calm At the End Of 911 Line
description: SUPPOSEDLY" is underlined here because the police say that a check of 911 tapes has turned up no evidence of such a call ever having been made. All the same, a shadow was cast, however briefly, over the entire 911 operation: a whiff of suggestion that Ms. Alvarez might still be alive had someone only moved faster to fetch an interpreter.

title: INSIDE
description: Newark Police Official Charged With Corruption

title: Semantics Won't Change the Abortion Debate;Language Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate;Real estate agents in New York City are trying to clear up a local tax situation.
description: A DISPUTE between the New York City Finance Department and several groups of real estate agents over the city's unincorporated business tax has eased after the department issued guidelines on which agents should pay the 4 percent income tax. Still, a series of appeals have been filed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR REVIVES FAIRCHILD OPERATION
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a new division from the assets of the former Fairchild Semiconductor and planned to spin it off as an independent company again. National Semiconductor's stock rose 87.5 cents, to $16.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Founded in 1958, Fairchild created the first computer chip that could be mass-produced. The company was acquired by National Semiconductor in 1987. The products that will form the new Fairchild represent about 25 percent of National Semiconductor's $2.6 billion in annual revenue. They include logic and memory chips. National Semiconductor, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it expected to take a pretax charge of $280 million to $320 million in the quarter ending in August because of the Fairchild move.

title: Senate Confirms Greenspan 91-7 for a Third Fed Term
description: The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve today, brushing aside arguments from a few Democrats that he had held back economic growth by focusing too narrowly on fighting inflation.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ENSERCH EXPLORATION TO SELL MOST ASSETS IN ROCKIES
description: Enserch Exploration Inc., an oil and natural-gas exploration and production company, said yesterday that it had reached agreements to sell practically all of its assets in the Rocky Mountain region for about $120 million. The purchasers were not disclosed. The company said the assets being sold represented proven reserves of 150 billion cubic feet equivalent of natural gas and average daily production of 45 million cubic feet equivalent.

title: India Warns It Won't Sign Test Ban Pact As It Stands
description: India told a disarmament conference in Geneva today that it would not sign a nuclear test ban treaty unless the agreement required the destruction of existing nuclear weapons within a prescribed period.

title: Art in Review
description: Laura Newman Tenri Cultural Institute 575 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through July 13

title: Intent on One Tiny Weakness, Kamsky and Karpov Adjourn
description: Heavy slogging against a tiny but immobile pawn weakness: that was the style of Gata Kamsky's campaign against Anatoly Karpov yesterday in Game 8 of their world championship match in Elista, Russia. After 57 moves, the game was adjourned; it is to be finished today.

title: FILM REVIEW;Celebrating a Neighborhood Of Runyonesque Deadbeats
description: If the Brooklyn deadbeats sauntering through "The Search for One-Eye Jimmy" generally avoid the "deses, dems and doses" of standard movie lowlifes, they still have their own colorful way of saying things. When a nearsighted car thief named Junior (Nick Turturro) loses his glasses during a scuffle on the streets of his Brooklyn neighborhood, he complains that his spectacles, which cost $37.50, will be hard to replace because they're "subscription."

title: No Headline
Restaurants
description: Hotel restaurants are so universally unloved that the best of them pretend not to be what they are. Think of Daniel, Lespinasse, Le Cirque and Les Celebrites: each is in a Manhattan hotel, but each has made its fortune by transcending the form and forging its own identity.

title: Nike Pays Good Wages to Foreign Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Aides Deceived Lawmakers, Inquiry Finds
description: Senior Immigration and Naturalization Service managers last year released detainees, including some with criminal records, to deceive a group of visiting House members about overcrowding and security problems at the agency's Miami operations, a Justice Department investigation has concluded.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Radio Days Of Glory And Defeat
description: THE MURROW BOYS Pioneers on the Front Lines of Broadcast Journalism By Stanley Cloud and Lynne Olson Illustrated. 445 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $27.95.

title: 30 Cab Fare From Airport Is Extended
description: The flat $30 cab fare from Kennedy International Airport, an experiment conceived to keep unscrupulous cabbies from taking passengers into Manhattan by way of, say, Staten Island, was made permanent yesterday -- at least until autumn.

title: TV WEEKEND;Helping an Ex-Sweetheart Who's on Death Row
description: Sometimes even a wagon full of quality talent isn't enough. Showtime's "Beyond the Call," having its premiere on Sunday, is loaded with substantial credits: the actors Sissy Spacek and David Strathairn, the director Tony Bill, the distinguished veteran television executive producers Bob Christiansen and Rick Rosenberg. But Doug Magee's script, described as "a fictional story inspired by actual events," is curiously inert, almost smugly solemn.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG INCREASE IN GLOBAL SALES VOLUME IS SEEN
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it expected global sales volume to increase by 8 percent to 9 percent for the second quarter, the biggest surge since the second quarter of 1995. Coca-Cola also said it was comfortable with Wall Street's expectations that it would earn 42 cents a share in the second quarter. In the second quarter of 1995, Coca-Cola earned $898 million, or 71 cents a share before a 2-for-1 stock split in May, on revenue of $4.94 billion. Analysts had expected a global volume increase of about 7 percent in the latest period. In the second quarter of 1995, global volume increased 10 percent. Separately, Carlsberg A.S., the largest brewer in Denmark, said that it was negotiating to become Coca-Cola's distribution partner in Sweden and Norway. Carlsberg already distributes Coke in Denmark.

title: Setback for Gay Group
description: The State Supreme Court has reversed a lower court order and ruled that the Texas Republican Party does not have to provide a homosexual Republican organization with an information booth at the party's convention.

title: THEATER REVIEW;From 1940 Broadway, A Musical of Politics
description: Were the good old days really better? Who's to know? But for argument's sake, take May 29, 1940, when the curtain went up at the Imperial Theater on the Irving Berlin-Morrie Ryskind musical "Louisiana Purchase."

title: Dr. Kevorkian Helps In Woman's Suicide, 3d Case in 9 Days
description: For the third night in nine days the body of a woman who had died in the presence of Dr. Jack Kevorkian was brought to a hospital emergency room tonight.

title: World News Briefs;Bosnian Serbs Pick Karadzic for President
description: In a direct violation of the Dayton peace accord, a local party board in the Serbian part of Bosnia today nominated Radovan Karadzic, an indicted war criminal, as their candidate for president, Serbian news organizations reported. The local board of the Serb Democratic Party in Pale, the Bosnian Serb headquarters during the war, unanimously agreed to the nomination, the news agency SRNA said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AEP INDUSTRIES TO BUY BORDEN PACKAGING UNIT
description: AEP Industries agreed yesterday to acquire Borden Inc.'s global packaging business for at least $360 million in cash and stock. The price will consist of $280 million in cash and at least $80 million in newly issued AEP common stock. In Nasdaq trading, AEP stock closed at $33.50, after falling to as low as $26.25 earlier in the day. Borden will get to name four of AEP's 10 directors; together with AEP, it will also get to name a fifth. But Borden has agreed not to increase its stake in AEP for at least three years after the transaction closes, which is expected to be in September. The acquisition will more than triple, to $900 million, the annual sales of AEP, which makes and sells polyethylene film products used for industrial and agricultural packaging.

title: Students' Math Scores Rise In Tests in New York City
description: For the second year in a row, elementary school students in all 32 New York City school districts raised their scores in a standardized test of math skills, and continued a four-year trend of improving math performance citywide, officials announced yesterday.

title: Market Place;Despite a suit, some analysts are recommending Sallie Mae.
description: THE long reach of the Orange County, Calif., crisis is having some odd repercussions. One of them is a $100 million lawsuit filed by the county against the Student Loan Marketing Association, better known as Sallie Mae. The suit contends that there was a scheme in which Sallie Mae and Merrill Lynch & Company engaged in a secret kickback deal to inflate profits to Merrill Lynch on Sallie Mae notes sold to Orange County.

title: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: NEWS ANALYSIS;A Shrewd Act of Self-Preservation
description: Whether he is standing on a tank facing down a coup, as he did five years ago, or dismissing his best friend in the name of saving democracy, as he did today, Boris N. Yeltsin has a gift for political theater that has repeatedly been his own salvation.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Israeli Religious Parties Perform No Disservice
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Anti-Stalking Law Extended
description: New Jersey's strict anti-stalking law was made even tougher yesterday when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed an amendment intended to protect the relatives of victims. The amendment expands the definition of stalking to make it a criminal offense to threaten someone's family. In addition, a conviction for stalking will automatically trigger a petition asking a court for a permanent restraining order on behalf of the victim.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WAYNE ENSRUD is an artist who has never had an accolade quite so startling as the one he received on Wednesday. A painting that he did for the men's room of La Serre, a two-month-old restaurant on East 61st Street, simply disappeared during the lunch hour.

title: Semantics Won't Change the Abortion Debate;A Permanent Sorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Stop Inflation Before It Starts
description: It's back-slapping time on the inflation watch.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a Congressional hearing at which the families of victims of the Valujet crash testified misstated the subject of the hearing. The panel was looking into the treatment of air crash victims' families by lawyers and airlines; it was not investigating the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: BASEBALL;Martinez Is Finding Way To Escape Huge Shadow
description: Whether Tino Martinez is entering Yankee Stadium, swinging a bat in the on-deck circle, patrolling first base or leaving the Bronx after a game, he has learned to expect and accept the legendary name that is tossed in his face like so many whipped-cream pies in a blooper sketch. "Don Mattingly" might as well be plastered across his forehead.

title: FILM REVIEW;He's Tough, Right? But Also Lucky
description: To start things off on the right note, "Eraser" begins with a savage attack. An unidentified man and woman are trussed and beaten in an episode involving gasoline, a noose, pliers aimed at teeth and knives in faces. Then into this fray comes John Kruger (Arnold Schwarzenegger), wearing a ski mask. Kruger is so tough he can haul two corpses across the lawn at the same time. What a guy.

title: Justices Grant U.S. Employers Tool to Bargain
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that it is not an antitrust violation for companies within an industry to get together and impose new contract terms on their unionized employees after labor negotiations have broken down.

title: Home Video
description: In theaters, Oliver Stone's "Nixon" ran 190 minutes, and so it will when it is released on videocassette on July 9. But viewers who keep the VCR humming after the final credits will encounter a little "Nixon" that lasts about another 20 minutes.

title: Morgan Stanley Expected to Buy Asset Manager
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, seeking to expand its asset management business, is expected to reach an agreement as early as this afternoon to buy Van Kampen American Capital Inc. from its controlling shareholder, Clayton Dubilier & Rice, for more than $700 million in cash, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: World News Briefs;Islamic Group Offers To Freeze Israel Raids
description: The military wing of the militant Islamic movement Hamas offered today to freeze attacks on Israelis in exchange for an end to the Israeli and Palestinian crackdown on its members.

title: Support Unpaid, Ex-Fugitive Is Jailed Again
description: A man who gained national notoriety for accumulating more than $600,000 in overdue child support was ordered back to jail yesterday by a Manhattan judge who said he had not kept his promise to pay up.

title: Rare Bipartisanship on Arson
description: Americans of good conscience are appalled at the epidemic of arson attacks that continue to devastate African-American churches, mainly in the South. The Federal Government was initially slow to mobilize a campaign to curb the attacks. But now a broad, bipartisan coalition of Federal and state political leaders is uniting behind an effort to find and punish the arsonists and rebuild the churches. Such unanimity has become increasingly rare in an archly partisan Washington.

title: Missing R's, Cont'd.
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Workers Protest
description: About 1,000 administrators, teachers and service employees blocked traffic with their cars and picketed outside the downtown offices of the Newark Public Schools yesterday, protesting possible layoffs and expected privatization in the state's largest, most troubled system. Many of the employees carried signs mocking the state for replacing the school board with a new administration dominated by educators from New York City.

title: In Congress, New York's G.O.P. Defends Turf
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. ISMAR SCHORSCH, the chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary, has received honorary doctorates in the past, three of them, in fact. But the one he is to receive next Friday will be far more than a personal honor, he said the other day.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: HOCKEY;Palffy Turns Down Isles' Offer And Could Become Free Agent
description: Mike Milbury, the Islanders' general manager and coach, escalated his war of words with Paul Kraus, the agent for Zigmund Palffy, the star forward who is about to become a restricted free agent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MANHATTAN BAGEL REPORTS ACCOUNTING IRREGULARITIES
description: The Manhattan Bagel Company said yesterday that it had found improper accounting at its I& J West Coast unit and would have to restate its financial results for the first quarter. Manhattan Bagel, a chain of bagel shops that is based in Eatontown, N.J., said it would also investigate other possible financial irregularities. The company will reduce its first-quarter earnings per share to 9 cents from the 12 cents previously reported. The announcement was made after the markets closed. Earlier, the company's shares fell $4.875, to $21.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Semantics Won't Change the Abortion Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Interest Rises Again on Big Board
description: With stocks continuing to surge, open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange have set their fifth consecutive monthly record in the most recent period.

title: Shuttle Blasts Off on Mission That Could Be Record Length
description: The space shuttle Columbia blazed a smoky trail through muggy skies today to begin what could become the longest mission in the shuttle program's history.

title: A POLITICAL LIFE -- The Nixon Years;For Dole, Nixon Was a Mirror and a Mentor
description: It was a political gesture that to many seemed oddly impolitic.

title: A Park on the Hudson River
description: Few cities are blessed with as much waterfront property as New York. Few have made such abysmal use of it. Now the city and state seem to be coming together on a plan that will turn the depressing expanse of rotting piers along the Hudson into a park that will allow residents and tourists to appreciate what it means to live along the water.

title: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: UNDATE;A Purge in the Kremlin
description: In a dramatic move seen as a victory for the forces of economic reform and democracy, President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed three senior officials he had long been close to. The three had driven liberals like Anatoly B. Chubais out of the government, strongly supported the war in Chechnya and were accused of urging Mr. Yeltsin to cancel the elections.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Sponsor for Women's League
description: The American Basketball League, the new professional women's league, appears to have the all the necessary ingredients to succeed: corporate sponsors, television exposure, good timing and 9 of the 12 members of the United States Olympic team.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Drop Out, Break the Law
description: A Camden lawmaker said he has come up with one way to help reduce crime, especially in urban areas. State Senator Wayne R. Bryant said students should be forced to stay in school until they graduate or reach age 18. His bill was approved yesterday by the Senate Education Committee with bipartisan support and was sent to the full Senate. About 17,000 students -- out of a school-age population of 1.2 million -- drop out each year before they graduate, the State Department of Education said. But in Camden, the proportion of dropouts is much higher -- 1,500 out of 22,000 students, Senator Bryant said.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Fears About Sumitomo's Plans Lower Copper Prices Again
description: Copper prices resumed their decline yesterday as traders remained concerned that Sumitomo Corporation stockpiles would soon be sold as the company tried to recoup a $1.8 billion copper trading loss.

title: At Home Abroad;'A Little Different'
description: Prime Minister Romano Prodi looked around his office in the Palazzo Chigi -- the gilt ceilings, the walls hung with tapestries -- and laughed. "It's a little different," he said, "from the last time you saw me."

title: 9 in Former Javits Center Union Held in Fraud
description: Nine members of a union that used to represent workers at the corruption-plagued Jacob K. Javits Convention Center were charged yesterday with illegally obtaining union health benefits, unemployment compensation and Social Security benefits, as well as with loan sharking.

title: ON BASEBALL;The Game Is Being Hurt by Its Falling Stars
description: This was supposed to be baseball's cleansing season, one in which the bilge of the strike years of 1994 and '95 would be swept clean by a 162-game season full of stars, uninterrupted promise and endless possibilities. Funny, how wrong things can go when everything seemed timed to go so right.

title: Inside Art
description: Looking for a Rescue in Paris

title: THEATER REVIEW;As the Boys Return, The Party Isn't Over
description: It is, apparently, O.K. to like "The Boys in the Band" again.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Changes Planned At 2 Agencies
description: There are changes involving two health care agencies.

title: Secret Service Official Disputes White House on How It Obtained Files
description: A top Secret Service official today sharply undercut the White House's explanation of how President Clinton's aides had improperly obtained confidential F.B.I. background reports on more than 400 former White House employees, some of them prominent Republicans.

title: Louis J. Lefkowitz, 22-Year Attorney General, Dies at 91
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, a crack political campaigner who served as attorney general longer than anyone else in New York state history, died late last night at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: To Infinity and Beyond: Is a Radio Deal Too Big?;Westinghouse Would Own 32% of Top Markets
description: Don Imus doesn't have much use for the argument that radio is coming under the grip of a few powerful owners.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EARNINGS RISE 47% AT ORACLE, LIFTING THE STOCK
description: The Oracle Corporation said yesterday that its net income rose 47 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter on strong sales of its data base software and a surge in foreign sales. Oracle said net income for the quarter, which ended on May 31, rose to $266.3 million, or 40 cents a share, from $181.7 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 44 percent, to $1.46 billion from $1.02 billion. The average estimate of 22 analysts from Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of 37 cents a share. Oracle is based in Redwood City, Calif. In after-hours trading, its shares rose as much as $2.125, to $37. The stock earlier closed at $34.875, up 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Pentagon Analyst Insists North Korea Is Still Holding P.O.W.'s
description: A mystery over the fate of Americans missing from the Korean War deepened today when a Defense Department analyst told Congress that he stood by a report that concluded that as many as 15 Americans are still being held prisoner in North Korea.

title: Owens-Corning Sues 3 Asbestos Test Labs
description: Owens-Corning Fiberglas, the big building-products manufacturer that has been chafing from decades of asbestos litigation, has sued three medical-testing laboratories, contending that they falsified tens of thousands of test results supporting claims against the company.

title: In America;Burning Their Bridges
description: If the racist firebugs in the South had any sense at all they would stop torching black churches. The fires are bad for the racism business. Each church that goes up in smoke generates sympathy for the very folks who have been so assiduously stereotyped and demonized over the last few decades.

title: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK;Brogna's Shoulder Is a Sore Subject
description: Rico Brogna was wearing a Band-Aid on the front of his right shoulder. It may have seemed small, but it said a lot about the way the injury-plagued first baseman was feeling.

title: Mediator Meets Nicaraguans' Kidnappers
description: A mediator began talks today with rearmed contra rebels who kidnapped 33 election workers and spirited them across the border to Honduras.

title: Semantics Won't Change the Abortion Debate;What 'Concession'?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Can't Be Sued for Disability Bias in Federal Programs, CourtRules
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government cannot be sued for damages for violating a law that bars discrimination against people with disabilities in programs run by Federal agencies.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Huddling Beneath Memory's Burdens
description: THERE is one transcendent moment in "The Shawl," the first play from the great writer Cynthia Ozick at the Jewish Repertory Theater. It involves nothing more than Ms. Ozick's language and a single actress, Dianne Wiest.

title: Bomb Similar to 4 Others Explodes in Brooklyn
description: A package bomb that investigators said resembled four others sent to New Yorkers over the last 14 years exploded yesterday when a Brooklyn man opened it, the police said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Step One For Bulls: Jackson Is Staying
description: Taking the first step toward keeping their championship team intact, the Chicago Bulls and Phil Jackson reached agreement on a one-year contract yesterday and ended a strained and lengthy process that had threatened Jackson's future as coach in Chicago.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;For Steeplechaser, Not a Moment to Spare
description: In a photo finish for the first four places in the 3,000-meter steeplechase at the Olympic trials four years ago, Tom Nohilly missed going to Barcelona with the United States Olympic team by four-hundredths of a second.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Evans Group To Quit an Account
description: The Seattle office of the Evans Group said yesterday that it would resign the account of the Northwest Ford Dealers Advertising Association because the Ford Motor Company was encouraging dealer groups to consolidate their accounts with the national Ford agency, the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of the WPP Group. Billings on the account, which Evans has handled since January 1995, were estimated at $10 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Won't Face Charges
description: A grand jury voted yesterday not to indict a police officer who shot and killed a man in a housing project in February, a prosecutor said. The officer, Patrolman Philip Perrone, who is white, shot Chris Thompson, 28, of Paterson, who was black, on Feb. 13 outside an apartment at the Alexander Hamilton Housing Project, The Associated Press reported. The shooting came nearly a year after an unarmed black teen-ager was killed by a white housing police officer during a drug raid. That shooting sparked days of rioting.

title: Chiefs of Securities Firms Get Paid More in Stock
description: Major Wall Street securities companies are paying their top executives better and have increased the proportion of stock in their compensation packages, an analysis of the recent proxy statements of 10 of the biggest companies shows.

title: The Spoken Word
description: THE ART OF SCREENWRITING, American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. Screenwriters will discuss and screen their films. Tomorrow, Buck Henry will speak about the 1967 film "The Graduate," following a 2 P.M. screening of the film and he will introduce a 5:30 P.M. screening of "To Die For." On Sunday, James Toback will introduce the 1978 film "Fingers" at 2 P.M.; and at 4:30 P.M. Todd Lippy, editor of Scenario Magazine, will introduce the 1980 film "Atlantic." Admission: $15 for tomorrow's discussion and screening ($10 for museum members) and on Sunday, $7 ($4 for the elderly and children 5 to 18 years old. Information: (718) 784-0077.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBRECHT & QUIST PLANS TO GO PUBLIC
description: Hambrecht & Quist Group Inc., the investment bank that has helped many high-technology and health care companies sell shares, yesterday filed to raise $80 million through its own initial public offering. The company, which is based in San Francisco, also gave the public an initial glimpse of its earnings. Hambrecht & Quist's income before income taxes totaled $71.9 million in the six months that ended on March 31, up from $25.4 million a year earlier. The earnings for the 1996 period exceeded the $71.89 million that Hambrecht & Quist earned before income taxes during the entire fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30. Yesterday's filing was the first step in an initial public offering process that will probably take at least several months. Hambrecht & Quist plans to wait until later to release details of the stock offering, including the number of shares to be sold and their price.

title: Art in Review
description: Mercedes Matter Drawings New York Studio School 8 West Eighth Street Greenwich Village Through July 13 Paintings Salander-O'Reilly Galleries 20 East 79th Street, Manhattan Through June 29

title: Indonesia's Rising Prosperity Feeds a Push for Democracy
description: By the standards of Indonesian politics, the threat by the nation's leading opposition figure was shockingly blunt: "If we wanted to, we could bring millions of people into the streets of every major city and town in the country. But we have decided not to do this at this time."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Barry S. Fischer, senior vice president and deputy media director at Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, left to join Turner Broadcasting Sales, New York, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., in the new position of executive vice president for marketing and research. * Sebastian (Nick) La Micela, vice chairman, executive vice president and creative director at Publicis/ Bloom, New York, a unit of Publicis S.A., has resigned. * Michael J. Kelly, advertising sales director at Entertainment Weekly magazine, New York, owned by the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., was promoted to publisher, succeeding Michael J. Klingensmith, who continues as president.

title: Newark Police Director Is Charged in Theft From Account
description: A Federal grand jury charged the Newark Police Director today with using a department fund as a personal bank account, spending the money on items like gifts for his wife and girlfriend, trips to Bermuda and Mexico City and campaign contributions to the Mayor and others.

title: Art in Review
description: Per Kirkeby Michael Werner Gallery 21 East 67th Street, Manhattan Through July 5

title: BOXING;Fighting Words: Camacho Draws the Line After Duran Crosses It
description: As a 10-year-old, Hector Camacho watched the exploits of Bruce Lee slam across the silver screen: the skill with fighting sticks, the wailing "Wah!," the balletic kicks.

title: BASEBALL;The Mets Misplace Their Keys to Success in Their Loss to the Reds
description: It is a painfully simple equation: Good pitching plus good defense plus good hitting equal success.
