description: To the Editor:

title: Pension Fund Taken Over
description: The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Government unit that insures corporate pension funds, has taken over the pension plan of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. The pension fund, which had a deficit of $29.3 million, covers 9,000 workers and retirees at the company, an apparel maker and distributor based here. It filed for bankruptcy-law protection earlier this year. "We are stepping in to make sure that the hard-earned pensions of these textile and garment industry workers will be secure for their retirements," said the Secretary of Labor, Robert B. Reich, who is also chairman of the board of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.

title: Guilty Plea Offered in Insider Case
description: A Manhattan business executive pleaded guilty yesterday to insider trading charges that he made $60,568 from information about pending mergers given to him by his daughter, a former paralegal for the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: BASEBALL;Belle Out for 2 Games Now
description: In yet another change in the Albert Belle suspension, the Cleveland Indians' notorious star will miss not five games, not three games, but two games, sitting out the scheduled day-night doubleheader with the Yankees today. He will also pay a $25,000 fine. That is, the Indians will pay the $25,000 penalty he was assessed in place of the third-game suspension.

title: King of Clubs Battles the U.S. Over Drug Bust;Sparse Crowds and Hard Times For Peter Gatien, Club Owner, Who Maintains His Innocence
description: These are bad times for Peter Gatien, the fallen nightclub king of New York's under-25 world.

title: Man Seized in Wave of Killings and Robberies
description: A Staten Island man was charged today with murdering a 65-year-old homeowner in April, and the authorities linked him to another murder on Long Island and a wave of vicious robberies against elderly people throughout the New York City suburbs.

description: Julio Galan Anina Nosei Gallery 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea Through July 14

description: DIVING

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;ABC Ends Weeks of Speculation By Naming Pair to Run TV Unit
description: After weeks of complicated negotiations, ABC announced yesterday that it had hired Jamie Tarses, the former NBC programming executive, as president of its entertainment division. At the same time, it promoted the man she is replacing in that job, Ted Harbert, to a newly created position of chairman of ABC Entertainment.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Leo Burnett Changes A TV Commercial
description: The Leo Burnett Company has changed a new television commercial for Fruit of the Loom that in a humorous comparison of underwear styles around the world asserts that Greek men go sans skivvies.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline in some editions on Monday about Dr. Steven Ruma, an adviser to medical-school deans, misstated his middle initial. It was J., not T.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Kept In Check
description: Signs of economic strength and concerns over inflation and supply combined to restrain Treasury prices yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sex Crime in Train Is Alleged
description: A suspended New Jersey Transit train conductor was indicted yesterday for sexually assaulting a 41-year-old passenger last January in a locked, empty car of a commuter train, the Essex County Prosecutor's office said. The woman, who had boarded the 7:38 A.M. train in New York en route to Princeton, had lost her ticket and tried to present the conductor, Bryan Dunda, with a photocopy of a co-worker's ticket, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the prosecutor. Mr. Dunda threatened to have the woman arrested and took her to the empty car, where he forced her to perform a sexual act, Mr. Weiss said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Scottish Power Appears To Win a Bidding War
description: Scottish Power P.L.C. apparently won its battle yesterday to acquire another British utility, Southern Water P.L.C., with an improved bid of L1.677 billion -- about $2.6 billion -- that the rival bidder, Southern Electric P.L.C., said it would not match. Southern Electric said it would allow its L1.6 billion offer to lapse on July 4.

title: Jazz Royalty and Revolutionaries
description: The next two weeks will find jazz fans raiding their pocketbooks. The Heineken "What Is Jazz?" Festival at the Knitting Factory has come to prominence this year, and with the simultaneous JVC Jazz Festival, the mixture makes New York City an extraordinary place to be for music. The JVC festival supplies some of jazz's last big names and some swing-era depth, while "What Is Jazz?" adds the thrill and chill of the new, of experimentation and some of the city's fervor. The two combined bring some 170 sets of music to the city.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Friends who live nearby tried to make me promise not to tell anyone about Taka. But that would be wrong.

title: U.S. Panel Proposes a Change in Administering Polio Vaccine
description: After nearly two years of debate among health experts, a Government advisory committee today recommended a major shift in the way polio vaccine is administered to infants, reinstating the Salk vaccine as part of the recommended immunization schedule.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;A Senate Insider Reappears on the Stump in a Chat With Farmers
description: Since he left the Senate more than a week ago, Bob Dole has been telling most of his audiences how important it was for his Presidential campaign to break free from the Capitol and risk losing everything, with nothing to fall back on.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Miami Players Arrested
description: In the latest blow to the University of Miami football team, three players have been arrested on charges of assaulting two other students, the Coral Gables Police Department said yesterday. JAMMI GERMAN, a star wide receiver for the team, JEFFREY TAYLOR and JAMES BURGESS, both linebackers, were arrested late Wednesday, police said. All three were starters. (Reuters)

title: Art in Review
description: Lee Stoetzel Tricia Collins-Grand Salon 83 Grand Street, SoHo Through July 27

title: Judge Clears Way to Send Bomb Suspect To California
description: A Federal district judge here cleared the way today for Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom case, to be transferred to Sacramento, Calif., where he faces 10 Federal charges related to the bombing deaths of two people and the wounding of two others.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lower Prices for Gasoline
description: After four months of increases, New Jersey gasoline prices fell during the past month by 1.8 cents per gallon, the Board of Public Utilities reported yesterday. Last week's fire in a three-million-gallon Shell Oil storage tank in Woodbridge did not affect prices at the pump, which now stand at $1.229 per gallon for regular unleaded gasoline, the board said. That is still 13.5 cents more a gallon than in February, when prices began increasing.

title: Shuttle Astronauts Start Study of Motion Sickness
description: Four crew members aboard the space shuttle Columbia assumed the role of guinea pigs today for a study of motion sickness.

title: Rig Count Is Down by 8
description: The number of rigs operating nationwide dropped by eight this week to 765, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. A year ago, 684 rigs were operating in the United States. Of the rigs running this week, 465 were exploring for natural gas and 295 for oil.

title: Accord in Drug Case Set at $351 Million
description: A Federal judge approved a $351.3 million settlement of a lawsuit against drug companies accused of conspiring to deny brand-name discounts to independent pharmacists.

title: White House Waffling on Health
description: The White House and Congressional Republicans are negotiating over the G.O.P.'s demand to include medical savings accounts as part of health-care reform. The White House once threatened to veto a bill that included these accounts. But now it is merely quibbling over details. The Administration needs to regain its sense of principle. The fight over medical savings accounts goes to the heart of the health-care debate. No one can say for sure what damage the accounts would cause. But they threaten to divide rich from poor, healthy from sick, young from old.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CLOROX BUYS LESTOIL FROM UNIT OF PROCTER
description: The Clorox Company purchased the Lestoil brand heavy-duty cleaner yesterday from the Noxell Corporation, a unit of the Procter & Gamble Company, for cash. Specific financial terms were not disclosed. Clorox said it expected the brand to have "a slightly positive impact" on earnings in the fiscal year beginning on July 1. The acquisition includes Procter & Gamble's global trademark rights to Lestoil and finished product inventories but no manufacturing facilities. Procter & Gamble said the sale was part of a corporate program announced last June to divest itself of certain nonstrategic brands.

title: Bridge
description: To worry about a four when the dummy appears might seem improbable, but it happened on the diagramed deal in April at the European Union Championships in Ostend, Belgium. The worrier was Jean-Marc Roudinesco of France, whose recent 478-page "Dictionary of Suit Combinations" is an essential reference for serious players. It not only gives detailed analysis of 2,000 combinations, but also general guidelines. It can be obtained from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y., 10025 for $45.95.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LTX SHARES OFF AFTER PURCHASE ORDER CLAIM IS DENIED
description: The LTX Corporation of Westwood, Mass., said yesterday that the Daewoo Corporation of South Korea had disavowed substantial purchase orders for LTX's electronics test equipment. After this news was announced, LTX's stock tumbled 30.5 percent in Nasdaq trading. It closed at $6.25, down $2.75 a share. Daewoo, which has a unit that makes consumer electronics, said the orders were not authorized and were the result of internal wrongdoing at Daewoo, according to LTX. LTX also said it had sued Daewoo over the matter. LTX did not disclose the value of the Daewoo orders. But without them, LTX said its orders in the third quarter ended April 30 would be down 8 percent from the third quarter of last year.

title: Quiet Clinton Aide Now in the Spotlight
description: In the vanity-steeped circles of White House power, no one has craved obscurity more intently than Bruce R. Lindsey, the lean and loyal lawyer who is President Clinton's closest political ally and deputy White House counsel.

title: Chip Trade Talks Make No Gains
description: United States and Japanese negotiators have made no progress in talks on extending a semiconductor trade agreement, a senior United States trade official said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Defendant Guilty; Jury, Too?
description: The jury returned a guilty verdict, but something was missing: the evidence, three pieces of cocaine that jurors in the crack manufacturing trial of John Brown and Jack Cook had asked to examine. Mr. Brown's lawyer, John P. Pieroni, said yesterday that he would ask for a mistrial in Thursday's conviction on the grounds that jurors may have committed a felony during deliberations. Officials could not find the drugs, worth $60 on the street, during a search of Superior Court yesterday. ANDY NEWMAN

title: U.S. Judge Criticizes School for Retarded
description: A Federal judge has declared Connecticut in contempt for failing to comply with court orders to improve conditions at the Southbury Training School, the state's only large institution for the retarded.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the growth of alternative medical treatments into a big business and powerful force in modern medicine referred incorrectly to the claims that are legally permitted in promotional material for dietary supplements. The material may contain certain claims about how a supplement affects the function or well-being of the body, but not a claim that it cures disease.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Abdur-Rahim Will Enter Draft After All
description: After a month of second thoughts, California forward SHAREEF ABDUR-RAHIM has decided to enter the National Basketball Association Draft, his college coach said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees' Finest Day Is Also One of Torre's Saddest
description: The fiasco considered so probable never developed. The Yankees tossed a pair of raw rookies -- Brian Boehringer and Ramiro Mendoza -- to the attack dogs known as the Cleveland Indians, closed their eyes and prayed that they would sneak through the long day.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;24-Hour Market Is a First
description: The casinos, the pawn shops and the bars are open all night, but Atlantic City, which has 36,000 residents, has never had a 24-hour supermarket -- until today. A 41,000-square-foot Thriftway store was scheduled to open this morning, the first new supermarket downtown Atlantic City has seen in 20 years. The store is the centerpiece of Renaissance Plaza, a $14 million shopping center expected to give a lift to the city's crumbling downtown and partly financed by the state's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority.

title: Times Expects Steady 2d-Quarter Earnings
description: earnings, excluding a one-time gain on a real estate transaction, to approximate its results in the comparable 1995 quarter. The latest results will include a charge against earnings for employee severance.

title: Robert Carmel, 59, Real Estate Executive
description: Robert Carmel, a New York real estate executive who contributed to Jewish and medical causes, died last Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 and also kept homes in Quogue, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

description: From Peaceful to Propulsive, Led by Swinging Computers Underworld Irving Plaza

title: Noted Finding of Science Fraud Is Overturned by a Federal Panel
description: In the conclusion to one of the most celebrated investigations of alleged scientific misconduct in the United States, a Federal appeals board yesterday rejected findings that a scientist faked data a decade ago in a report signed by a leading Nobel laureate.

title: Edvin Wide, 100, Olympic Track Medalist
description: Edvin Wide, who won medals at three Olympic Games and set three world track records in the 1920's, died on Wednesday. He was 100.

title: Eighth Game Quickly Fades Into a Draw
description: Gata Kamsky and Anatoly Karpov played seven perfunctory moves in 10 minutes yesterday, then agreed to a draw. Thus, after the second session of Game 8 of their world championship match in Elista, Russia, the score is Karpov 5 1/2, Kamsky 2 1/2.

title: Antananarivo Journal;A Palace Inferno Sears Madagascar's Very Soul
description: The British author of a travel guide to this island nation compared the fire to "Westminster Abbey, the Tower of London and Buckingham Palace being destroyed at once."

title: Peggy Clark, Pioneer Designer Of Stage Lighting, Dies at 80
description: Margaret Bronson (Peggy) Clark, who designed the lighting for more than 60 Broadway productions, including "Brigadoon," "Bye Bye Birdie" and "Auntie Mame," died on Wednesday at her home in Lexington, Ga. She was 80.

title: Some Big Names Battle Over a Small Hydrant
description: A fire hydrant is for firefighters to fight fires, so people are not allowed to park in front of them. But in New York City, it can be handy to have one at your front door -- and yesterday small armies of lawyers, city officials and the most influential public relations man around clashed over the efforts of Jerry I. Speyer, the real estate magnate, to move a hydrant 50 feet to rest before the huge town house he has been building.

title: POLITICS: THE MONEY;In Slap at President for Tort Veto, Silicon Valley Reduces Donations
description: Four years ago, Bill Clinton set out to win the support of skeptical executives in Silicon Valley by holding private meetings to solicit their advice and by promising to make high-technology businesses more competitive in world markets. High technology became a frequent theme of Mr. Clinton's campaign to "get America growing again."

title: THE AD CAMPAIGN;The Republicans Attack on Spending for Illegal Immigrants
description: Republican National Committee. Republican officials would not say where it is being broadcast, but Democratic officials, who are tracking the ads, said their research found Republicans spent $1.5 million for a week of advertising nationally, notably in California. PRODUCER: New Century Media Group.

title: Car Hits and Runs, Killing Queens Boy
description: An 8-year-old Queens boy was killed in an apparent hit-and-run accident after his school bus dropped him off in Flushing yesterday.

title: 3 Judges Back Files Inquiry By Prosecutor
description: An appeals court panel granted Attorney General Janet Reno's request today to allow the Whitewater special prosecutor to look into whether any laws were broken when White House workers requested files from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Reds Burned As the Mets Catch Fire
description: The Mets ought to call players-only meetings more often. If nothing else, the bullpen seemed to take the soul-searching session to heart.

description: As Ross Perot walked with a brisk, military gait through a booksellers' convention here recently, he looked into the television camera and threw a compliment to his new co-author and limited partner, Senator Paul Simon.

title: Songs of Innocence and Experience;Young Writers and Their Tragic, Discordant Lyrics of the South Bronx
description: Some of the boys had on neckties, the girls dressed up like the women they will soon become, and Margot Seaman's class of eighth graders settled into the dark for the pleasing torture of watching themselves on TV. Jewel Priester was horrified at the discovery that, as she put it, "I talk with my tongue." But in all, the video they made -- called "Tales From the Hood" -- was a hit: Their fellow students, 800 of them, roared to their feet at the end of what was, despite the glee in the showing, a violent, teen-age vision of the South Bronx.

title: A Publicized Drug Courier Pleads Guilty to 3 Felonies
description: An accused drug courier, whose case became a focal point in the bitter debate over whether judges are too concerned with protecting the rights of criminal suspects, pleaded guilty yesterday to three felony charges and now faces at least 10 years in prison.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about young artists in the East Village misspelled the surname of one artist. He is Andrew Boardman, not Bordman.

title: Bill Could Allow for Repeal of Tough Smoking Law in New York City
description: Backed by a well-financed lobbying and direct-mail campaign, the tobacco and restaurant industries are quietly pushing a bill through the New York Legislature that would give them the tools to repeal tough restrictions on smoking in restaurants in New York City.

title: Analysts Expect A Hard Look At Radio Merger
description: One day after the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation announced radio's largest merger ever, lawyers and industry experts said the $3.9 billion deal might cause the Government to rethink the way it measures concentration in the radio industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARRAH'S SHARES ARE DOWN ON DISAPPOINTING REVENUE
description: The shares of Harrah's Entertainment Inc. fell 11 percent yesterday after the company said second-quarter and 1996 profits would fall below expectations because of disappointing casino revenue. The Memphis-based company's stock fell $3.50, to $27.625, in trading of 3.1 million shares on the New York Stack Exchange. The company sees second-quarter earnings of about 33 cents to 35 cents a share, about 10 cents a share lower than expected. Harrah's estimate excludes an estimated 6-cents-a-share charge from start-up operations. Wall Street expected Harrah's to earn 43 cents a share, according to a recent survey of nine analysts by Zacks Investment Research.

title: 2 Senior Republican Lawmakers Buck Party to Oppose Effort to BarEducation of Illegal Aliens
description: Quietly bucking their party leaders, two senior influential Republicans privately oppose a proposal in pending immigration legislation that would allow states to bar children who are illegal immigrants from public schools. The two lawmakers say they will try to modify or kill the provision.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ex-Head of Vulkan Arrested in Germany
description: The former chairman of the bankrupt shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. has been arrested after the police raided his home and company offices as part of a fraud investigation. The executive, Friedrich Hennemann, 60, was detained Wednesday night and a formal arrest warrant was approved late on Thursday.

title: Brooklyn Bomb Tied to Series of 5 Apparently Random Attacks
description: A package bomb mailed to a Brooklyn woman appeared to be the work of the same person who killed one woman and injured five other people in similar attacks that began in 1982, the police said yesterday.

title: Republicans on Whitewater Panel Want Investigation Into WhetherWitnesses Lied
description: Senate Republicans who ran hearings on the Whitewater affair asked the independent counsel in the case today to investigate whether three friends and associates of President and Mrs. Clinton lied in sworn testimony to the panel.

title: Company Briefs
description: BOMBARDIER INC., Montreal, said its German Eurorail Waggonfabrik Talbot unit had received a letter of intent from Deutsche Bahn, the German state-controlled railway, to build 120 diesel-powered train cars in a deal worth about $250 million.

title: Dance in Review
description: Nonsense With a Gravity That Defies Explanation Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company Joyce Theater

title: COMPANY NEWS;HUBCO, BANKING SERVICE, EXPANDS IN CONNECTICUT
description: Hubco Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Westport Bancorp Inc. for as much as $37 million in stock, broadening its presence in Connecticut. The offer values Westport Bancorp at $6.49 a share, representing a 13 percent premium over Westport's closing price on Thursday. The stock rose 25 cents, to $6, in Nasdaq trading. Under the agreement, Westport shareholders would receive 0.3225 share of Hubco for each Westport share held. Hubco, based in Mahwah, N.J., provides retail and commercial banking services.

title: IMPASSE IN ALBANY ON BUDGET BEGINS STRAINING SERVICES
description: With New York State's record budget deadlock approaching the end of its third month, the budget is now so late that its effects are being felt far beyond the Capitol, seriously straining schools and local governments and threatening to disrupt services in the state's hospitals.

title: Serb Gangs Rule in Last-Chance Fief of U.N.
description: Chez Daddy's nightclub changed owners a few days ago in a business transaction that, as so often happens in the Balkans, dispensed with impediments like money and legal titles.

title: Lloyd's Tells Its Investors With Losses to Pay Up or Fight
description: Lloyd's of London took a vital step today in its bid to stay solvent, advising money-losing investors about the size of their final bills and threatening to fight anybody who will not pay.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TELEPHONE AND DATA IN CELLULAR TRANSFER DEAL
description: Telephone and Data Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to transfer interests in cellular systems to its U.S. Cellular Corporation subsidiary in exchange for $110.2 million in cash. The Chicago-based Telephone and Data said the interests represented about 614,000 potential subscribers, including 218,600 in and around Tucson, Ariz. Telephone and Data owns 80 percent of U.S. Cellular, which manages and invests in cellular systems throughout the nation.

title: A Cool Oasis for Frazzled Films
description: For the next few months, human New Yorkers can look forward to heat, haze, humidity and air pollution. If you happen to be a can of film from the Museum of Modern Art, the forecast is a lot better: cool temperatures, low humidity and pure air. Forever.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHARMACEUTICAL PRODUCT TO BUY BIOSCIENCE
description: Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Applied Bioscience International Inc. for stock worth as much as $467 million, creating one of the largest publicly traded pharmaceutical contract research organizations. Shareholders of Applied Bioscience, based in Arlington, Va., will receive between 0.3125 and 0.4054 share of Pharmaceutical Product stock for each share of Applied Bioscience. Based on Thursday's closing prices, the transaction values each Applied Bioscience share at $12.34 to $16.01. Applied Bioscience's shares jumped $2.4375, to $11.5625, while Pharmaceutical Product fell $4.50 a share, to $35, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Have Some Pre-draft Leverage
description: Mike Milbury is still a rookie as general manager of the Islanders, and he is bringing a pretty big bargaining chip to today's National Hockey League entry draft in St. Louis: the third selection.

title: Israeli Won't Rule Out Golan Compromise
description: As Arab leaders gathered for a summit meeting in Cairo, Israel's new Foreign Minister, David Levy, said he would not rule out territorial compromise on the Golan Heights in exchange for peace with Syria.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Special Tap Platform, Miked for Greater Impact Anita Feldman Tap Dance Theater Workshop

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A New Mozart Opera With Him in It? Sort Of
description: An opera composed by Mozart? Ho-hum (in a manner of speaking). An opera in which Mozart appears as a character? Not routine, exactly, but there is at least Rimsky-Korsakov's "Mozart and Salieri."

title: Kathleen Haberthur-Williams, Press Agent
description: Kathleen Haberthur-Williams, a theatrical press agent, died on Wednesday in the burn unit of New York University-Cornell Medical Center. She was 41 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Officer Says NATO Can Seize Serbs if Ordered To
description: Trying to deflect criticism that NATO forces have not been aggressive enough in Bosnia, their commander said today that he is willing to assume some risk in order to arrest the two major Bosnian Serb leaders accused of war crimes, if that is what Western politicians want done.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;How a Piano That's a Toy Is More Than a Plaything
description: The dictionary defines toys as things to be played with, most often by children. Implied is smallness, for those who will most use a toy are small themselves. To toy with something is to treat it flirtatiously, delicately, even indirectly. A toy is often the childish metaphor for the grown-up at work, the imitation of artifacts larger, more serious of purpose and more complex of design than a child will physically or mentally grasp.

title: Dole and Clinton Plan New York Treasure Hunts Monday
description: After a perfunctory and fleeting Presidential primary, New Yorkers will get a slight preview of the general election on Monday evening. President Clinton and Bob Dole are both coming to town in search of the same thing: money.

title: Suspect Is Charged in 4 Zodiac Cases in Queens
description: A Brooklyn man who the police say is the Zodiac killer -- a gunman who fatally shot three people and wounded five others in twin crime waves in the early 1990's -- was formally charged in the case yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Question Airline Merger
description: British regulators threw a hurdle in front of American Airlines' plan to link with British Airways yesterday, deciding the alliance was a merger and required further scrutiny.

title: Dance in Review
description: Cast Changes Bring Both Passion and Delicacy American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Stewarts Point Journal;Valuable California Abalone Draws Sportsmen and Poachers
description: On low-tide mornings north of San Francisco, hundreds of cars jam turn-offs along Highway 1. At the Stewarts Point Store, a wood-floored source of "general merchandise" since 1868, customers head for the swim fins, snorkels and weight belts.

title: OLYMPICS;Huffins Gets A Fast Start In Decathlon
description: Chris Huffins ran the fastest 100 meters in the 80-year history of the decathlon today, 10.22 seconds, to take the lead after five events over the world champion Dan O'Brien. How fast is 10.22? If this had been the open 100 meters, Huffins would have finished a mere hundredth of a second behind Carl Lewis.

title: Tinkering With the Test Ban Treaty
description: President Clinton has worked hard and successfully to energize the drive for an international treaty banning nuclear weapons tests. But now, with negotiators near agreement on most important issues, White House advisers recommend a revision in Washington's position that could put the treaty in limbo. Mr. Clinton should reject the proposed change.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FUND AMERICAN GAINS 50% OF FOLKSAMERICA HOLDING
description: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired a 50 percent stake in the Folksamerica Holding Company for $79.4 million. Fund American, an insurance company based in Norwich, Vt., said Folksamerica planned to use the money to complete its $88 million acquisition of the Christiania General Insurance Corporation of Tarrytown, N.Y., which is owned by the Norway-based Oslo Reinsurance Company.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Miami Suspends Receiver For Season After His Arrest
description: Butch Davis, the University of Miami football coach, was on vacation in Arkansas last summer when he learned that James Burgess, a top linebacker, had been arrested on charges of battery against a police officer and resisting arrest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a House vote on Interior and Energy Department spending misstated the White House position on the bill. Administration officials have recommended that President Clinton veto the bill should it reach his desk in its current form; the President has not said he would veto it.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;College Studies Name Change
description: So "Trenton State College" doesn't have the right ring to it? How about "The College of New Jersey"? Officials at Trenton State announced yesterday that the executive committee of its board had recommended the new name to reflect the school's statewide appeal and its status as the most selective public college in New Jersey. "We have more students from Bergen County coming into our freshman class than from our home county of Mercer," said Jesse Rosenblum, associate vice president for college relations. Besides, Mr. Rosenblum said, the college is in Ewing Township, not Trenton. The college's board will vote on the change on Thursday. Officials at Rutgers University, which often refers to itself as the State University of New Jersey, declined to comment.

title: Con Ed and Union in Talks To Avert a Strike at Midnight
description: Negotiators for Consolidated Edison and its 11,000 unionized workers were locked in intensive bargaining yesterday in an effort to reach a new contract before a strike deadline at midnight.

title: The Bear in the Woods, the Bear in Us
description: Late one dark night in Oakland, Calif., I was leaving a movie theater, after watching every last credit roll, when I noticed that my car was the only one left in the parking lot. I stepped around a homeless man sitting on the theater steps. He asked me for money, and I told him, honestly, that I had none.

title: Waiter Is Killed In Shooting At Topless Bar
description: A waiter at a topless nightclub in Manhattan frequented by celebrities was killed and a doorman gravely wounded early yesterday, apparently by three men who had been thrown out earlier and returned with guns after the club closed, the police said.

title: Maj. Gen. John C. Giraudo, 73, Who Flew in Combat in 3 Wars
description: Maj. Gen. John C. Giraudo, a combat pilot who commanded bomber and fighter units in World War II, Korea and Vietnam, died on Monday at Palm of Pasadena Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 73 and lived in St. Petersburg.

title: Journal;The Nation's Basement
description: There are some shows so dull they can't even give the tickets away. But who would have imagined that one of them would be produced by the Smithsonian Institution in celebration of its 150th birthday?

title: Dance in Review
description: A Classical Indian Form With Grace and Style Nrityagram Dance Ensemble Kaye Playhouse

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHICAGO DOCK MERGER WITH NEWSWEB UNDER STUDY
description: Fred Eychaner, who controls the Newsweb Corporation and is the holder of a 9.22 percent stake in Chicago Dock and Canal Trust, a real estate investment trust, will consider a possible merger of the two companies, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Chicago Dock signed an agreement on Thursday to provide confidential information on its operations to Newsweb. Chicago Dock's main asset is the Cityfront Center development in downtown Chicago. The company's stock slipped 12.5 cents, to $14.75, in Nasdaq trading. The Chicago-based Newsweb owns a television station and printing company.

title: Treasury Securites Gain; Hedge-Fund Buying Seen
description: Treasury securities improved in light trading yesterday, as talk of hedge-fund buying and rumors of central bank activity in the short end of the market helped support prices.

title: No Jail Time for Ex-Policeman Who Shot a Fellow Officer
description: The defense, the judge and even the victim came together yesterday in a surprisingly gentle final act to the wrenching drama of a white police officer who mistakenly shot an undercover black policeman on a Manhattan subway platform. They all agreed that the defendant should be spared jail.

title: Testimony Suggested For Hillary Clinton
description: A defense lawyer in the second Whitewater trial raised the possibility today of calling Hillary Rodham Clinton as a witness and compelling her first public testimony in the matter. But the lawyer later backed off, saying it probably would not happen.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canal Plus May End Bertelsmann TV Link
description: Canal Plus S.A. of France, Europe's biggest pay-television company, is talking with Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany on whether to end a two-year-old joint accord to develop digital pay-TV in Europe. Executives at Canal Plus and its main shareholder, Havas S.A., said they were reconsidering the link in the wake of Bertelsmann's alliance with Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Telediffusion -- a Canal Plus rival.

title: Arabs at Cairo Talks Seek Unity on Mideast Issues
description: It was nearly three decades ago that Arab leaders meeting in Khartoum, the Sudan, after the 1967 war with Israel took a stand known as the three no's -- "no recognition, no negotiation, no peace."

title: Plot Against L.I. Leaders Is Tied to Fear of U.F.O.'s
description: Fearing that space aliens had crashed on Long Island and that the authorities were covering it up, three members of a U.F.O. group plotted to assassinate Suffolk County officials with radioactive materials and seize control of county government, prosecutors said today.

title: An Ailing Woman Kills Herself With Help From Dr. Kevorkian
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian helped an ailing woman to kill herself on Thursday, the third time in 10 days he had assisted in a suicide.

title: New Bulk Mail Rates Challenged
description: Businesses that advertise through catalogues and mass mailings are trying to block the United States Postal Service from raising the cost of some types of bulk mail.

title: Ex-General's Voters Crucial to Yeltsin
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin had a big problem in Tula before he latched onto Aleksandr I. Lebed. People in that central Russian city -- even those who voted for him -- dislike Mr. Yeltsin intensely, according to focus groups meeting there on Wednesday, the day after Mr. Lebed, the outspoken former general who came in a strong third in last week's presidential election, was named to the Cabinet.

title: BOXING;Douglas Fighting Again After Fight for His Life
description: When he left the hospital barely 20 months ago, after falling into a diabetic coma and almost dying, the scale registered at "more than 325 pounds."

title: Edward Dugmore, Abstract Painter, 81; Works in New Show
description: Edward Dugmore, an abstract painter whose work is to be featured in an exhibition opening next month at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, died on June 13 at his home in Minneapolis. He was 81.

description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Green, 96, Creator Of Yiddish Film's Heyday
description: Joseph Green, who turned a walk-on role in the first talking movie, "The Jazz Singer," into a film making career that ushered in the golden age of Yiddish cinema, died on Thursday at the Grace Plaza nursing home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 96 and had emphysema.

title: No Trials For 2 Men Charged In Gang Rape
description: A day after the acquittal of the second of five men accused of gang raping a woman in an upstate New York restaurant in 1991, the State Attorney General said he would drop the prosecutions of two other defendants.

title: 2 Companies to Share Cost of Auto Recall
description: The Ford Motor Company and the United Technologies Corporation said today that they had agreed to share the cost of recalling 8.7 million vehicles that may contain faulty ignition switches supplied by United Technologies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOUNTING LOSSES TRIM SPS TRANSACTION STOCK 28%
description: The stock of SPS Transaction Services Inc. fell 28 percent yesterday after the company said mounting losses in its private-label credit card business would cause earnings to fall below expectations in the next three quarters. The company issues credit cards for the Tandy Corporation and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. SPS Transaction, based in Riverwoods, Ill., said it expected earnings for each share for the second quarter to be between 22 cents and 25 cents and earnings in the third and fourth quarter to be at or below those levels. Analysts had put the company's second- , third- and fourth-quarter earnings at 41 cents, 48 cents and 49 cents a share, respectively, according to First Call Inc. SPS's stock fell $7 a share, to $17.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Arab Leaders Seek Unity

title: Gulf War Illness May Be Linked To Gas Exposure, Pentagon Says
description: The Pentagon disclosed today that American troops may have been exposed to nerve gas shortly after the war in the Persian Gulf when an Army unit blew up an Iraqi ammunition depot that contained rockets armed with chemical agents. The announcement may help explain some of the mysterious illnesses reported by Americans who served in the gulf.

description: NEW YORK

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;At a Talk, Union Gives Its Applause To Clinton
description: Far from the fracas over F.B.I. files and backwater bank deals, President Clinton hit the campaign trail in front of a friendly labor audience today, reciting a rollicking partisan litany of his Administration's stands and lighting into Republicans as cold-hearted foes of the common man.

title: BASEBALL;Ochoa Recalled From Norfolk
description: Without further fanfare, here comes the Mets' right fielder of the future.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRONET SHARES LOSE OVER A THIRD OF THEIR VALUE
description: The stock of Pronet Inc. lost more than a third of its value yesterday after the company said its earnings for the second quarter would be below Wall Street's expectations. The Dallas-based Pronet, a wireless-communications services provider, said the lower earnings projections were attributable to competitive pricing and said it expected operating earnings for the three months ending June 30 to be between $5.3 million and $5.7 million. Pronet said earnings for the rest of 1996 are expected to be even with second-quarter results or slightly lower. Pronet stock closed at $11.50, down $6.8125, or 33.7 percent, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Troops Patrol Belfast Again, Raising the Tension
description: After nearly 22 months of peace, with only a routine presence of security forces on the streets of Belfast, the British soldiers are patrolling again, drawing beads with their automatic rifles on rooftops and down alleys where guerrillas of the Irish Republican Army, or Protestant paramilitaries, may be hiding.

title: Investigators of Church Fires Face Daunting Task
description: Standing under a tall oak tree with singed leaves near the charred remains of the Hills Chapel Missionary Baptist Church here, Louis A. Iliano explained how tough it is to find the cause of a fire amid the scattered piles of burned wood on the ground.

title: Court Halts Williamsburg Bridge Cleaning in Battle Over Showers ofLead Paint
description: In a resounding victory for residents who live near the Williamsburg Bridge and a setback for the city, a state appellate court has ordered an immediate halt to sandblasting on the bridge.

title: LACROSSE;Body Identified As Athlete's
description: A woman's body found in a north Philadelphia neighborhood was identified today as that of Aimee Willard, a star athlete at George Mason University.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Jobless Rate Drops
description: The state's unemployment rate dipped to 6.1 percent in May, the lowest rate since December 1990, Labor Commissioner Peter J. Calderone said yesterday. The jobless rate, down from 6.6 percent in April, is still higher than the national average of 5.6 percent. But New Jersey is doing better than most of its neighbors at creating jobs, Mr. Calderone said. The state added 6,800 jobs in May, especially in restaurants and other retail businesses.

title: Calipari Shops For Assistants
description: Forming a staff of assistants is one of the items on Nets Coach John Calipari's to-do list, with several names surfacing, including University of California Coach Todd Bozeman.

title: EUROPE MAY EASE BRITISH-BEEF BAN
description: Leaders of the European Union's 15 member countries agreed today to a plan that would gradually allow the British to resume exporting beef. In response, Britain ended its monthlong disruption of the union's decision-making.

title: OLYMPICS;Heartbreak of 4th Place Strikes Nohilly Again
description: Four years ago, Tom Nohilly ran fourth in the 3,000-meter steeplechase at the Olympic track and field trials in a photo finish -- only four one-hundredths of a second from making the United States team that went to Barcelona, Spain. Tonight he finished fourth again, this time by about five meters.

description: Baseball

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Crash Survivor Goes Home
description: The youngest survivor of last December's airline crash in Colombia was discharged from the hospital yesterday. Six-year-old Michelle Dussan walked out of Children's Specialized Hospital in leg braces and returned to her home in Somerville. Michelle and her father, Gonzalo Dussan, were two of only four survivors of American Airlines flight 965, which crashed Dec. 20 into a mountain outside Cali. The girl's mother and older brother were among the 160 people killed. Michelle, who suffered injuries to her head and spine, had spent her days at the hospital and her nights at home since returning to the United States last month.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Struggles With Rift On Abortion in Platform
description: Bob Dole met today with Representative Henry J. Hyde, chairman of the Republican Party platform committee, seeking to smooth over their differences on how to handle the explosive matter of abortion at the party's convention in August, but the effort appeared to fall short.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Celtics Trade Montross to Mavericks
description: The Boston Celtics traded center ERIC MONTROSS and the ninth pick in the National Basketball Association draft to Dallas yesterday for the No. 6 pick and the Mavericks' first-round choice next year. "We believe there's a quantum leap from six to nine," said M. L. CARR, the Celtics' coach and director of player personnel.

title: POP REVIEW;With Orchestral Pomp, a Soulful Balladeer
description: Milton Nascimento usually visits New York with his band. But on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, he had additional forces: the Brooklyn Philharmonic and choirs of boys and girls from Brazil.

title: Hitachi Develops Fastest Supercomputer
description: The Hitachi Corporation of Japan has taken over the mantle as the maker of the fastest supercomputer in the world, according to a study released yesterday by a researcher at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, an Energy Department research center in Tennessee.

title: No Headline
description: This place is like Frankfurt after the war, filled with war profiteers, hoodlums, demobilized SS and gangsters."

title: The Tree Gods Are a Bit Testy
description: In New Guinea, where many natives believe that certain forests are inhabited by the spirits of ancestors, those who dare to cut sacred groves risk retribution in the form of shriveled crops, barren wives and other ills.

title: Former Contras Free 33 They Kidnapped
description: Kidnappers released 33 Nicaraguan election observers and other officials in Honduras today after holding them for two days, the Nicaraguan Foreign Minister said.

title: Louis Lefkowitz, 22-Year Attorney General, Dies at 91
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, a crack political campaigner who served as attorney general longer than anyone else in New York State history, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

description: DIVING

title: Judge Agrees To Settlement in Drug Case
description: A Federal judge in Chicago gave final approval yesterday to a $351.3 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused the major drug companies of conspiring to deny discounts to independent pharmacists.

title: F.A.A. Says a Lack of Trained Pilots Leads Kiwi Airlines to Reduce ItsFleet by Four
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that Kiwi International Airlines Inc. had reduced its fleet to 11 Boeing 727's from 15 because many of its pilots were improperly trained and it lacked the personnel to run all its planes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.A.A. Says Kiwi Will Cut Operations The Federal Aviation Administration said that Kiwi International Airlines had reduced its fleet and its number of flights because many of its pilots were improperly trained and it lacked the personnel to run all its planes.

title: End Secret Trials of Judges
description: For years, the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct has asked the State Legislature to end the secrecy that surrounds the commission's proceedings. The Republican-led State Senate, prompted by public interest in the pending disciplinary proceeding against Judge Lorin Duckman, has responded with a promising measure to open the process for resolving charges against judges to the public. But as the Legislature hobbles toward adjournment, this worthy reform is in trouble.

title: Manhattan Bagel's Stock Drops 35% on News Report
description: Wall Street, which can be merciless when it gets unexpected bad news, took an enormous piece out of the Manhattan Bagel Company's market value yesterday, after the chain said it would lower first-quarter earnings results because of accounting irregularities at its West Coast unit.

title: Sports of The Times;Yugoslav Athlete Must Tread Water
description: UNTIL yesterday afternoon, Vlado Kozomara's childhood dream was hanging by the thinnest of threads. And then the thread was cut.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about G. David Schine, a central figure in the Army-McCarthy hearings in 1954, misstated the relationship of two of his sons. Berndt Schine, who died in a plane crash with his father, was the twin of Kevin, not of Mark.

title: The Asylum System Needs Work
description: The recent decision by the Board of Immigration Appeals to grant political asylum to Fauziya Kasinga, a young African woman who feared genital mutilation, was both a personal victory and a broader acknowledgment that many women are victimized by cultural practices that violate human rights. Ms. Kasinga's case has raised the profile of gender-based asylum claims. It also highlights the fact that these claims need fairer treatment by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Rich Control More of U.S. Wealth, Study Says, as Debts Grow for Poor
description: Wealth became more concentrated in the United States from 1989 through late 1994 as affluent families profited from financial markets while many poorer families fell deeper into debt, new data from the University of Michigan show.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the International Business Machines Corporation's re-entry into the computer printer business misstated the scope of Apple Computer's printer operations. Apple makes printers for use with computers that use Windows and Unix software, not just for its own Macintosh computers.

title: Hyatt Plans Nevada Hotel
description: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation plans to develop a $150 million hotel and golf resort in Henderson, a town just outside Las Vegas, as part of a $4 billion private real estate development. The project would be on the shores of man-made Lake Las Vegas, about 17 miles east of the gambling city, as part of a community being developed by the Transcontinental Corporation and the Texas billionaire brothers Sid and Lee M. Bass. Hyatt, which is affiliated with 171 hotels around the world, would be a part owner of the hotel with Transcontinental.

title: About New York;Some Lessons From a Poet's Mean Streets
description: THE afternoon sun bounced off the red-brick apartment buildings and cast a golden glow on Piri Thomas, who closed his eyes, bowed his head and breathed deeply. He was searching for "the Flow," that surge of life that had propelled him from Spanish Harlem to prison and into the literary world in a journey he chronicled in his 1960's memoir, "Down These Mean Streets."

title: TEACHERS RATIFY 5-YEAR CONTRACT
description: New York City's public-school teachers overwhelmingly approved a five-year contract yesterday, an agreement similar to one they rejected in December. The vote was a victory for the union leadership and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's labor strategy.

title: Religion Journal;Viewing Jerusalem Through Other Faiths' Eyes
description: This week, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel put the final touches on his country's new Government, it was inevitable that the subject of Jerusalem would keep coming up.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Sought in Baby's Death
description: Late Thursday morning, prosecutors say, Luis Medina called 911 to report that his live-in girlfriend's 16-month-old son was having trouble breathing. A day later, Adrian Reyes was dead of what the coroner labeled edema of the brain, a swelling also known as shaken baby syndrome, said Edward M. Neafsey, the Acting Union County Prosecutor. Mr. Medina, 22, who had been watching the child in the couple's apartment, is now being sought on aggravated manslaughter charges.

title: Observer;Going Nowhere Together
description: The good news from the Census Bureau is that the rich are getting richer faster than they used to get richer. The bad news, of course, is that the poor are still either getting poorer or not getting a bit richer.

title: Middle-Class Feeding Frenzy;Chains Like Sizzler Are Buffeted by Changing Tastes
description: Woe unto the restaurant chain that fails to give Americans exactly what they want, at the moment they want it, and at just the price they want to pay.

title: Quixote' Cast Changes
description: American Ballet Theater has announced that because of an injury to Amanda McKerrow, there will be three sets of principal dancers performing "Don Quixote" at the matinee today at the Metropolitan Opera House. The first act will be danced by Julie Kent and Guillaume Graffin. The second act will be danced by Susan Jaffe and Jose Manuel Carreno. The third act will be danced by Paloma Herrera and Angel Corella. Information: (212) 362-6000.

title: A Haitian Set for Deportation Is Instead Set Free by the U.S.
description: Back home in Haiti, Emmanuel Constant is his country's most wanted man, accused of supervising murders, rapes and torture of supporters of democracy.

title: OLYMPICS;An Arrested U.S. Boxer Gets to Remain on Team
description: A USA Boxing panel decided yesterday to let David Reid remain on the 1996 United States Olympic team that will compete in Atlanta despite his arrest Wednesday in Orlando on charges of beating his girlfriend.

title: WEDDINGS;Wendy Lyon, Kelly McCammon
description: Wendy de Bary Lyon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Lyon of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Kelly McCammon, the son of Robert H. McCammon of Miami and M. Judy Jorgensen of Phoenix. The Rev. Audrey Philcox performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: OLYMPICS;A Couple's Dream Wilts in Atlanta Heat
description: Mark Coogan toweled himself off, quickly mopping up any disappointment from the 5,000-meter race Friday night. It mattered little that he finished seventh. He had already made the Olympic team in the marathon. He grabbed his gear and a sports drink and headed into the stands at Olympic Stadium. The women's 10,000 meters was up next. His wife, Gwyn, was one of the favorites.

title: Iraqis, Hurt by Sanctions, Sell Priceless Antiquities
description: Browsing the antiques markets of London a few years ago, McGuire Gibson, an expert on Mesopotamian art and archeology at the University of Chicago, found some of his worst fears confirmed. In the stalls of Portobello Road and the shops of Bond Street, dealers offered him antiquities probably smuggled from Iraq, a modern nation in distress that sits astride the remains of several ancient civilizations.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton Backs Plan to Track Sex Offenders Nationwide
description: Keeping up his political offensive on law and order, President Clinton today endorsed legislation to create a national registry to track sex offenders and child molesters, and he ordered Attorney General Janet Reno to devise guidelines on setting one up even without a new law.

title: POLITICS: THE SENATE;It's One Seat, One Name, Two Candidates in Race
description: In Virginia, Warner vs. Warner is not a movie sequel or even a divorce case. It is a big-money Senate race, and the candidates are trying to one-up each other in the name game.

Johnson of New York. The Rev. R. Alan Johnson performed the ceremony at the First Church of Christ Congregational in Sharon.

title: An Anglo-French Corner of Quebec
description: ESTRIE, meaning kingdom of the east, is the official French-Canadian name bestowed in 1981 on the Eastern Townships region in southeastern Quebec. About the size of Massachusetts, it lies roughly, west and east, between the Richelieu and Chaudiere Rivers and, north and south, between the former seigneuries (feudal domains once owned by French nobles) along the St. Lawrence River, and the northernmost New England states.

Ronald Newlin performed the ceremony at the Colebrook Congregational Church.

title: Transit Official, Casting Doubts on Metrocard, Suggests Keeping Tokens
description: A year away from the scheduled elimination of the transit token, the Transit Authority's budget director has questioned whether it makes sense to do away with the token, leaving the Metrocard as the only way to pay a fare.

title: ART REVIEW;Treasures and Pleasures of the Orthodox Faith
description: ORTHODOX Christianity must be one of the least assertive religions to have reached the United States; to the uninitiated, the only sign of its presence is the church with a dome crowned by a three-bar cross. Be that as it may, the faith rooted in Byzantium claims more than three million adherents among Americans who are are, variously, Greek, Russian, Eastern European or Middle Eastern by birth or descent.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLORAL PARK;Suspect in Grandmother's Death Awaits Trial, and Inheritance
description: As a Italian immigrant who spoke little English and kept mostly to herself, Amalia Fortuna, 81, depended on her only son, Carmine De Cianni, for help. When Mr. De Cianni died in September 1992, his two sons, Carmine Jr. and Peter, moved into Mrs. Fortuna's red-brick house in Floral Park.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Dissent on an Inn
description: To the Editor: Your article about the Inn on the Common ("Three Vermont Inns in Varied Flavors," May 5) in Craftsbury Common made it sound like a fine place, but my husband and I had a less pleasant experience there on our wedding night seven years ago.

title: WEDDINGS;Eleanor Nichols, Anthony Morgan
description: Eleanor Dodge Nichols, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Nichols of Old Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Anthony Patrick Morgan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Morgan of Annapolis, Md. Msgr. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: DINING OUT;Marriage, Italian Style
description: TO welcome you to Chiarella's, the chef sends out a small plate of the tiny toast squares known as bruschette. Many chefs do. But the bruschette prepared by Franco Serafino, a chef in Milan, Italy, for 25 years before he came to New Jersey, are distinctive. The bread is fresh and crisp, not at all soggy, and the tomatoes, basil and garlic are dressed, not drowned, in oil. These bruschette are cool, light and refreshing; even the tomatoes taste beefy, and it's not even July.

title: WEDDINGS;Lyle Stillman and Warwick Carter Jr.
description: Lyle Davis Stillman, a daughter of Mrs. Cyrus Phillip Knowles of Alexandria, Va., and Walter Robert Stillman of Quechee, Vt., was married yesterday to Warwick Montgomery Carter Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter of Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Joseph Joshua Mundell performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Church in Washington.

title: Roaming An Ancient Bulgarian City
description: FOR most Westerners and practically all Americans, Bulgaria remains a mystery. We associate it vaguely with yogurt, and perhaps with the haunting melodies of the women's choir known as Le Mystere de Voix Bulgares.

title: SOAPBOX;Time of Your Life, Huh, Kid?
description: HIGH school is a battleground for the heart.

title: OUTDOORS;Content Without Firing a Shot on a Spring Turkey Hunt
description: Stumbling across a stubbled cornfield in the pre-dawn murk in Sheffield, Mass., behind the shadowy, 6-foot-5-inch form of my turkey-hunting host, Willard Weeks, I marveled, as I always do, at how the fierce anticipation of the night before could have so precipitously dwindled.

title: Their Moment;Giantess among the pixies
description: The Belarussian gymnast will not be pushed. In days of yore, when her coach asked for 10 routines on the beam, Svetlana Boguinskaia hopped to it. Now, at 23, she knows that five perfect run-throughs will suffice. "I'm not a little robot anymore, and I know what I need," she says. Indeed, Boguinskaia is the world's oldest working gymnast at the world-class level. In 1988, she won two golds, a silver and a bronze in Seoul. In Barcelona, she won another gold and then, at age 19, gracefully settled into the gymnast's brand of retirement: exhibition touring in the United States.

title: The Art Nouveau Glory of Szeged
description: IN the Hungarian city of Szeged, they call it "The Big Water." In spring 1879, a dike on the Tisza River burst, and the flood destroyed all but 300 houses in what was a prosperous town of 60,000 souls. The good news for posterity is that Szeged, near the border with Romania and Yugoslavia, was almost entirely rebuilt over the next few years, resulting in a remarkably unified cityscape, a quilt of leafy squares and gracious ring boulevards that remains today.

title: Their Moment;Shortstop with a surgeon's hands
description: The Americans on the Olympic committee are likely to kick themselves for not insisting 28 years ago, when it was first proposed, that women's softball be made an official Olympic contest. The other members of the committee won't be so glad, for the Americans are expected to dominate: they have lost only one game in the last 10 years, when they routinely clobbered their competitors by embarrassingly large margins of 20 or 30 runs.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BENEFIT FOR HUNGRY

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;A Strategy Pays Off Big, Before Taxes
description: VERY mutual fund manager dreams of an investment like the one made two years ago by Paul Stephens, manager of the Robertson Stephens Contrarian fund. In early 1994, he purchased a stake in Diamond Fields Resources, then a tiny Canadian company with interests in diamond mines in South Africa and off the coast of Namibia.

title: MARKET WATCH;Fattening The Calf With Only Petits Pois
description: For 18 months, mutual fund investors have been feasting on a fat stock market. Now, they are starting to look like gluttons.

title: Vast and Vain Hunt for 7 in Tokyo Subway Nerve-Gas Attack
description: A face stares anxiously from posters on just about every public bulletin board in Japan these days.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;More Care-Free Living Choices for Empty-Nesters
description: OVER the last four years Mart and Sharon Vaarsi scoured northern New Jersey for a residential community that would offer them an easier way of life as they head into their empty-nester years. Recently, their search ended.

title: Midwood Report Overlooks Diversity and Prosperity
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on circumcision in the May 19 Week in Review misstated Prudential Insurance Company's current coverage for newborn circumcisions. Although Prudential had stopped paying for routine neonatal circumcision in 1986, they resumed paying for it in 1992.

title: New York City Studies Bid For Olympics
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is forming a task force of city officials and business leaders to look for ways to bring the lucrative Summer Olympics to New York City in 2008.

title: IN PERSON;Think Big and Get Those Donations
description: COMING up Grand Street was a ragtag group led by a priest in crisp black clericals and white collar. They were the homeless and working poor, the elderly, the alcoholic and the addicted. Mostly men, they were sweating and grimy in faded knockoff designer shirts that said Tommy or Polo and in one case an enigmatic "Check ya self before ya wreck ya self."

description: A year away from the scheduled elimination of the transit token, the Transit Authority's budget director has questioned whether it makes sense to do away with the token, leaving the Metrocard as the only way to pay a fare.

description: Celebrating museums, young artists, the Actors' Fund and Outward Bound

title: WEDDINGS;Megan McDonnell, Courtland Boyle
description: Megan Mary McDonnell, the daughter of Mrs. Charles Edward McDonnell Jr. of New York and the late Mr. McDonnell, was married yesterday to Courtland Alexander Boyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Alexander Graham Boyle of Smith Parish, Bermuda. The Rev. Henry Shepard performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Christ Church in Warwick, Bermuda.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;After Iverson, a Draft Dominated by Underclassmen Seems Unpredictable
description: It would take clairvoyance to predict exactly what will happen on Wednesday during the National Basketball Association draft.

title: WEDDINGS;Johanna Berkman, Emanuel Weintraub
description: Johanna Beth Berkman, a daughter of Judith and Charles Berkman of Neponsit, Queens, is to be married today to Emanuel Weintraub, a son of Karen and Robert Weintraub of Manhattan. Rabbi Allan Blaine is to perform the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: THEATER;More Adult, And Stronger Than He Knew
description: WHEN WE WERE doing 'The Heiress,' " recalled Andre Bishop, the artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater, "a young director I won't name went backstage to visit Cherry Jones. He told her how great she was, and she asked him, 'What did you think of Gerry's work?' " She was referring, of course, to her director, Gerald Gutierrez.

title: We Knew What Glory Was
description: When I was growing up in the 40's and 50's, my father would pack up the car every August and squeeze in my mother, four children, several dolls and a picnic lunch. It was the time before air-conditioning, and the drive was hot, dusty and, after New York, without bathrooms.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: Prague's Historic Cemeteries
description: THE Czech novelist and essayist Milan Kundera, writing about the character Sabrina, an exile from Bohemia, mentions that "the only word that evoked in her a sweet, nostalgic memory of her homeland was the word 'cemetery.' " This odd statement gained new meaning for me when I visited some of the cemeteries of Prague. Notable for their beauty and tranquillity, burial grounds like the Slavin cemetery at Vysehrad and the Old Jewish Cemetery in Josefov also reminded me that the culture of a country and its people reveals itself through its dead as well as its living.

title: Seeking Out An Answer In the Ashes
description: The flames rise into the sky like malignant ghosts from the South's past, evoking some of the most racially charged images in the nation's history.

title: Mother's Arrest in Sons' Killings Has a Texas Town in Disbelief
description: Two weeks after her two young sons were stabbed to death, Darlie Routier is on a suicide watch in a Dallas County jail, and residents of this quiet community are unsure whether to believe that a killer is loose or that a popular, devoted young mother could have taken her own children's lives.

title: It's a Bird, It's a Plane, It's the U.N. Flouted
description: To show Arab solidarity, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi did not let even the United Nations stand in his way.

title: WEDDINGS;Serpil Yildiz And Ahmet Can
description: Serpil Yildiz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salih Yildiz of Sunnyside, Queens, is to be married today to Ahmet Can, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mehmet Can of Brooklyn. Imam Burhan Satar is to perform the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Unapologetic About Bullfights
description: IT was June 13, barely a month before the July 7 start of the running of the bulls in Pamplona, and the Club Taurino was holding its end-of-season gala.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Their Moment;  Return of a scarred Fidelista
description: It was a particularly dim moment in Cuban sports history. Less than half a year after Ana Fidelia Quirot won the bronze medal in the 800 meters at the '92 Olympics, the middle-distance runner and a favorite of Fidel Castro, was doing her laundry in her Havana apartment. She was seven months pregnant. With severe shortages of soap and bleach, many Cubans -- even an Olympic star -- are forced to use isopropyl alcohol to clean their clothes.

title: ART;Lining Up Chairs Along With Objects From China
description: IT is all chairs at the Pelham Art Center here: chairs old and new, large and small; chairs that are fit to sit on as well as good to look at and chairs that are neither. This is "Preferred Seating: A Brief History of the American Chair," and its organizer is Alan Brown, taking a busman's holiday from his own gallery in White Plains.

title: Correction
description: A front-page photograph last Sunday of a Tibetan-style debate omitted the credit. It was by Barbara Alper for The New York Times.

title: HORSE RACING;The Little Bumps Don't Stop Yanks Music
description: There won't be any sweep of the Triple Crown races for colts or fillies this year, but one fast filly could come close.

title: Spa in Versailles
description: To the Editor: After returning from a stay at Le Hameau du Trianon in Versailles, France, I was extremely interested to read Catharine Reynolds's article about it, "Versailles: Pampering Nonpareil" (May 19). My husband and I enjoyed the hotel and restaurants, but were deeply disappointed with the spa.

title: The Cruelty of Strangers: 3 Men Evoke a Fearsome Crime Trend
description: They are the killers everyone fears. They are those who, perhaps through pure happenstance or a logic known only to themselves, repeatedly attack strangers. They have no numerical objective that will cause them to stop, and they may pick you as their next victim.

title: What It Takes To Skate: Drive And Discipline
description: VICTORIA OULLETTE, who is 12 years old and lives in Simsbury, has a passion for ice skating and hopes to compete at the U.S.A. National Championships within two years.

title: 3 Injured on Roller Coaster
description: A Coney Island roller coaster that lost a wheel and injured two riders in May was the scene of another accident last night when two cars slammed into each another, injuring three people, the police said.

title: DANCE;Nureyev in Mind, the Paris Opera Ballet Moves On
description: WHEN THE PARIS OPERA Ballet moves into the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow, it will be sailing under its own proud flag, a company at the peak of its powers. But it will also still be flying the pennant of Rudolf Nureyev, whose career in the West began here when he bolted to freedom at Le Bourget Airport in 1961 and ended with six years as the company's director and two as principal choreographer.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;A Small-Town Fair, Just a Tram Trip Away
description: BEFITTING its atmosphere of a small town in the big city, Roosevelt Island will be the setting this week for a fair with more than 20 amusement-park rides.

title: June 16-22;Famine Threatens Somalia
description: In Somalia, the people of the Juba Valley are experiencing disasters of biblical proportions. It began with two years of drought. Then in May heavy rains in Ethiopia caused the Juba and Shabeli rivers to flood, drowning what few parched crops remained. Renewed fighting between warlords has meant killing and looting. Food has become scarce, and some children have starved. In six weeks, more than 9,000 hungry people have fled the port of Kismayu and toward Kenya. Whether the crisis becomes a full-scale famine depends on the July and August crop of grain. Unless there is rain, United Nations officials are pessimistic. JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

title: WEDDINGS;Mary E. Ward, Michael K. Beran
description: Dr. Mary Elizabeth Ward, a veterinarian, was married yesterday to Michael Knox Beran, a lawyer. The Rev. Charles T. Dougherty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Church in Shelter Island, L.I.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;World Trade Center Restaurant to Reopen
description: Since February 1993, the only New Yorkers who could enjoy their meals 106 stories up or higher have been the peregrine falcons. But that changes on Thursday, with the reopening of Windows on the World, the restaurant complex on the 106th and 107th floors of the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.

title: WEDDINGS;Miss Assarat, Mr. Schoonmaker
description: Andrea Panyabha Assarat, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Suthi Assarat of Bangkok, Thailand, was married yesterday to Samuel Vail Schoonmaker 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Schoonmaker 3d of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Paul F. Goetting performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Hope Quebec Brings Luck Yet Again
description: The Islanders have a history of success with forwards from the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League. They drafted Mike Bossy in 1977 and he made the Hall of Fame. They drafted Pat LaFontaine in 1983 and he was their star for many seasons. Although they did not draft Pierre Turgeon, they traded for him in 1991 and he was their best player for several seasons.

title: WEDDINGS;Kimberley Ryan And Nigel Ekern
description: Kimberley Ann Ryan, a daughter of Stephen and Marion Ryan of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Nigel Paul Ekern, a son of Anita Ekern of Darien, Conn., and the late George Ekern. The Rev. Michael Moynihan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich.

title: So Many Jokes, So Little Time
description: We know you're all working hard, with no time to surf the Internet, send E-mail to friends or goof off on company time. You certainly don't have the time to tell everyone all those great office jokes you've heard. So let us spread them for you. Send your best office jokes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: NEW URBANISM;Helping to Shape The Inner City
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NIGHT;Climbing Every Mountain
description: ADVENTURE, apparently, is where you choose to find it. At least, that's what many of the 800 guests attending the New York City Outward Bound Center's benefit at the Chelsea Piers sports complex on Monday night seemed to think.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Going Beyond Green
description: ALL trees have green leaves in summer, right? Wrong. Some trees have purple, yellow or variegated leaves. The possibilities for color in tree foliage are part of landscape artistry that can make summertime truly spectacular.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;On Draft Day, the Knicks May Not Wait Their Turn
description: On the surface, the Knicks are saying they must stock the cupboard again, that they have to worry about long-term rebuilding rather than quick reloading in Wednesday's National Basketball Association draft. With nearly $10 million to spend on July 1, the opening day of the Great Free Agent Auction, they seem content with finding the impact player they need in either the open market or a midsummer trade, rather than through the draft.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Clock Still Ticking on Alarms
description: The agreement was reached in April after nearly two years of sometimes bitter wrangling between Mayor Giuliani and the City Council. The Mayor was allowed to permanently pull the plug on about a third of the city's 16,300 fire alarm boxes, but none in poor neighborhoods, where many residents lack phones.

title: WEDDINGS;Laurie Sparling And Peter Smith
description: Laurie Jane Sparling, the daughter of Janice and Russell Sparling of Scituate, R.I., is to be married today in New Haven to Peter Jeremy Smith, the son of Eileen and David Smith of Great Neck, L.I. Dr. Mark Schenker, a justice of the peace in Connecticut and the dean of Branford College at Yale University, is to officiate at the Dwight Chapel at Yale.

title: EARNING IT;From 'Working Rich' To Endangered Clan
description: DUDLEY BRAND'S father was a carpenter, and the words he chose to guide his son into a blue-collar career were hammered home like galvanized nails driven deep into a plank of fresh-cut timber: "Get a toolbox and you can always get a day's work."

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Their Moment;Brute on a bike
description: Since, like, forever, Juli Furtado has been an Olympics junkie. She watches every event, eyes glued to the screen, from opening anthem to closing ceremony. So she took it particularly hard when overtraining blew out both her knees and canceled her chances in both the 1984 and 1988 Games. But that was then, when she was a starring member of the United States Ski Team. This is now, and Furtado has refashioned herself as a mountain biker.

title: DINING OUT;An Exciting Menu With Uneven Results
description: THE Magnolia Grille aims high. That is evident in its ambitious menu and homemade rolls, desserts and ice creams. It is also apparent in its attractive decor and large staff.

title: WEDDINGS;Emily Tagliabue, J.D. Rockefeller 5th
description: Emily Elizabeth Tagliabue, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Tagliabue of New York and Bethesda, Md., was married last evening to John Davison Rockefeller 5th, a son of Senator and Mrs. Jay Rockefeller of Charleston, W.Va., and Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: In the Region/Long Island;How Istea Refreshes Some of the Island's Byways
description: WERE it not for a Federal highway law that authorized funds for the enhancement of local roads, many projects now in progress -- from the creation of bike and pedestrian trails to the restoration of historic buildings -- might never have been undertaken.

title: CHOICE TABLES;Warsaw Moves Beyond Kielbasa
description: WARSAW is dancing to a capitalist tune. Today's public works, unlike the immense Soviet-built Palace of Science and Culture that still dominates the skyline, include a pedestrian mall lined with boutiques and restaurants. And the choice of restaurants seems to increase by the day.
