description: To the Editor:

title: How the Women Won
description: When the modern Olympics began in Athens in 1896, one dismissive tradition carried over from the ancient games. All 245 athletes from 14 nations who competed in Athens were men. Women were expected to lend their applause, not their athletic skills. Olympic historians now believe that two women ran the marathon course near or during the Games. If so, the organizers were unimpressed. Distance running by women was thought to be un-ladylike, a violation of natural law. The common wisdom held that a woman was not physiologically capable of running mile after mile; that she wouldn't be able to bear children; that her uterus would fall out; that she might grow a mustache; that she was a man, or wanted to be one.

title: Their Moment;A legend without a league
description: Sheryl Swoopes can play, the female Michael Jordan and all that, but damn if her name isn't euphonious. At least that's what the folks at Nike said, more or less, when they made Swoopes the first woman to get her name on a basketball shoe. The six-foot forward-guard clinched the deal by leading her Texas Tech team to the N.C.A.A. title in 1993, scoring 47 points in the championship game. After that, and a Player of the Year award, she did what any basketball star does if she wants to earn a living at her sport: she shipped off to Europe.

title: WEDDINGS;Adrienne Bye, Leland Westerfield
description: Adrienne Lenore Bye, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis E. Bye of Lincoln, Mass., was married yesterday to Leland Avery Westerfield, the son of Prof. and Mrs. H. Bradford Westerfield of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence H. Drennan performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Mashpee, Mass.

title: POP VIEW;The Divine Pleasures Of an 'Absent Genius'
description: I HAD A GOOD LOOK AT Ella Fitzgerald at the Los Angeles airport in 1980, when she was 63. She was walking with a black woman about her age to Gate 49 for a flight to New York. She was wearing a coat appropriate for her destination, though the Los Angeles February afternoon was warm, close to hot. She had on the thick eyeglasses I'd seen her wear in concerts, necessitated by several operations for cataracts. Her gait bespoke her weight rather than her age. Her companion strode in unison with her, though she appeared far more nimble than Ella.

title: When the House Becomes a Hyatt
description: ONE of the first changes Newt Gingrich and the Republicans ordered after they took control of the House of Representatives last year was to end the daily early-morning delivery of 891 buckets of ice to House offices.

title: 25 Years Later;Lessons From the Pentagon Papers
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago this month, The New York Times began publishing the Pentagon Papers, a documentary history tracing the ultimately doomed involvement of the United States in a grinding war in the jungles and rice paddies of Southeast Asia.

title: June 16-22;Upbeat N.Y.P.D Blues
description: In police stations around New York City, crowded files marked "unsolved" are a little roomier. First, the arrest on June 12 of John J. Royster in the murder of one woman on Park Avenue and the vicious beatings of three others, including a piano teacher in Central Park. Police said the suspect later confessed to the crimes. Then, they said, a 28-year-old military and Bible enthusiast from Brooklyn, Heriberto Seda, confessed Tuesday to a string of so-called Zodiac shootings that terrorized the city in 1990. And on Thursday, a 31-year-old Staten Island man was arrested in a murder and wave of assaults against elderly people throughout the city's suburbs.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: It wasn't the Beatles that killed the genre of great show tunes. It was the invention of tape, LP's and now CD's and of FM radio that opened everyone's ears to the tremendous variety and beauty and honesty of many other kinds of music. So now Americans of all classes can hear gospel music, country music and music from a thousand places.

title: AIDS Struggle Cuts Across Generational Boundaries
description: ALTHOUGH Miriam Spaier, a mother of two girls, 4 and 16, was given a diagnosis of H.I.V. five years ago, she just recently arranged for someone to raise her children if she dies.

title: A LA CARE;Some Renowned Chefs In Hamptons Kitchens
description: GREAT chefs make restaurants great, and this year the Hamptons has more celebrated chefs than ever. Aside from Manhattan, there may be no 30-mile stretch in the country with a larger concentration of gifted cooks than the East End. There are at least 10 who have been invited by the James Beard Foundation to its headquarters in Manhattan to prepare meals of their specialties in the Discovery and Rising Stars of American Cuisine series.

title: WEDDINGS;Doris M. Sevcik, Vincent Perfetti
description: Doris Maria Sevcik, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ludovit Sevcik of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Vincent Apollo Perfetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cosmo Perfetti of Mahopac, N.Y. Msgr. Edward M. Connors performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale.

description: To the Editor: Your May 26 Practical Traveler column, "When the Dog Tags Along," was very informative.

description: PAWPAW PATCH By Janice Daugharty. HarperCollins, $22.

description: Henry Regnery, a one-time New Deal Democrat who became the godfather of modern conservatism as the publisher of the movement's leading theorists after World War II, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Chicago. He was 84.

title: DINING OUT;Indian Fare With Flair, Without the Fire
description: INDIAN restaurants have not been easily found in Connecticut, so it's reason to cheer the discovery of a new one. Maharaja in Waterbury deserves a double cheer for the quality of its cuisine.

description: WHEN Stella Simakova was recently asked to step in for an ailing performer on one day's notice to play a full recital at Caramoor in Katonah, the 28-year-old Russian pianist did not hesitate.

title: EXIT REASONABLE RIGHT
description: The Senate has been very good to Alan Simpson ("Exit Reasonable Right," by Claudia Dreifus, June 2). After 18 privileged years, the Senator will be leaving Congress with an outrageously generous benefits package -- at taxpayers' expense.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: It was a pleasure to read so well conceived a piece, one that reminds us that, as Charles Ives wrote, "There is a place in the heart where old songs dwell."

title: A Painter-Novelist Draws a Line Between Erotic and Obscene
description: WHEN Melinda Camber Porter first moved to New York from Paris, where she had been cultural correspondent for The Times of London, she discovered that unlike the French, Americans didn't comprehend the distinction between the pornographic and the erotic, what the dictionary calls the depiction of sex as part of violence and power versus sexual desire in its relationship to love.

title: SPENDING IT;Why Those Backyards Are Looking Like Versailles
description: THE small fishpond that Dennis Broderick placed in front of his home in Merriam, Kan., in 1992 was more a tribute to the memory of his grandfather than a gardening statement.

title: WEDDINGS;Loree Politziner and Wayne K. Potters
description: Loree Beth Politziner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Politziner of North Brunswick, N.J. was married last evening to Wayne Kevin Potters, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford B. Potters of New York. Rabbi Bennett Miller performed the ceremony at Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: WEDDINGS;Valerie Norfleet, Patrick McMorrow
description: Valerie Walker Norfleet, a daughter of Diane Carroll Blow of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Norwood Norfleet, was married yesterday to Patrick John McMorrow, a son of Edward James McMorrow of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mary Jane McMorrow. The Rev. Jeffrey H. Walker performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: The Song of the Squeeze-Box
description: ACCORDION CRIMES By E. Annie Proulx. 381 pp. New York: Scribner. $25. WORDS are chewy things for E. Annie Proulx. She loves to roll them around in her mouth and bite down on them, the tougher the better. In "Heart Songs and Other Stories" (1988) and her first novel, "Postcards" (1992), she feasted on the jawbreaking language of northern New England, where the names of plants and trees -- "miterwort," "tamarack" -- seem to mimic the hard soil they grow from. In her second novel, "The Shipping News" (1993), which won both a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award, she moved farther north and east, to Newfoundland. There, on "the most utterly desolate and miserable coast in the world," she quarried even stonier words: "sunkers," "stribbled," "streeling," "skreel."

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A 47-Mile Hiking Trail Hard by Hong Kong

Forced to cut grants and personnel, they have begun to look for alternative sources of funding from companies and individuals to stay alive in the years ahead. The endowments' efforts deserve support, but they also pose a new kind of danger. Outside fund-raising should not siphon private giving away from other arts programs or compromise the endowments' independent mission.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Philadelphia Hotels Beat the Cezanne Rush

The packages are available through Sept. 1, and include two VIP tickets to the museum and the exhibition, as well as two days' and one night's accommodations for two, breakfast, free parking and two city transit passes. The VIP tickets allow holders front-of-the-line access to the exhibition at any time. (Regular tickets, which are sold out several weekends in advance, are for specific times and dates, and are available at the museum or by calling (215) 235-7469 from 9 A.M. to 8:30 P.M., seven days a week. A museum spokeswoman recommends calling after 7 P.M. The tickets are $12.50, $9.50 for seniors and students.)

She has been studying Chinese medicine and philosophy for the last couple of years, and she has been trying to emphasize "being and observing; letting life happen in a very present way."

As a powerful star with a hillbilly facade, his mistreats his staffers (like Patricia Neal and Walter Matthau) and scorns his adoring public. The drama's irony and sting has a familiar edge and should, coming from the Elia Kazan-Budd Schulberg duo of "On the Waterfront." This was the screen debut of Lee Remick. As for Lonesome Rhodes (Griffith), he gets what's coming to him, thanks to Neal. How? Tune in for a big, juicy surprise.

Last summer two of the five gardens, the Ledebour and the Small Palffy, were -- more than 25 years after being shut down -- restored and recreated. title: THE SONG IS ENDED

Yes, chalk it up, in part, to the decline over the last three decades in values, taste, professional discipline. But I suspect it's more because today's generation of songwriters has never known the depths of pain or peaks of exhilaration that the Depression, war and rampant racism -- and the victories over them -- bred in those earlier songwriting generations. The experiences of deprivation, lost love, shattered lives and racial injustice were at a level far removed from the discomforts afflicting today's consumer society. LANSING LAMONT New York

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Everybody's Master
description: No painter has been so hallowed by his fellow artists as Paul Cezanne. Picasso called him "the father of us all," Klee "the supreme master," Matisse "a kind of benevolent god of painting." Yet despite a century's influence and an abundance of literature that has successively denounced, extolled and interpreted his work, Cezanne remains an enigmatic artist, his impact on subsequent generations more quantifiable than his artistic intentions. In the introduction to CEZANNE (Philadelphia Museum of Art/Abrams, $75), an exceptionally handsome catalogue raisonne produced in conjunction with a traveling exhibition currently at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Francoise Cachin, director of the Musees de France, and Joseph J. Rishel, a curator of European painting at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, make no claims to providing new interpretations of either the artist or the man. Instead they concentrate on the shifts of Cezanne's critical fortunes. The result is a fascinating patchwork of opinions that illustrates not only how Cezanne has been reinvented as the patron saint of each successive movement from Fauvism to Cubism to early abstraction, but how monumentally important he remains. Each reproduction is accompanied by a short text that provides the provenance of the work, bits of biography, excerpts from letters and occasional anecdotes, as well as details about Cezanne's technique. More academic and less accessible is Pavel Machotka's CEZANNE: Landscape Into Art (Yale University, $45). Mr. Machotka, who teaches psychology and art at the University of California, Santa Cruz, has photographed the sites of Cezanne's landscape paintings, with an eye to approximating the spot and precise time of day that Cezanne painted each scene. He then attempts to analyze Cezanne's way of working, noting the correspondences as well as the changes between place and painting. The result is fascinating to look at, though frequently pedantic. Andrea Barnet

Virgil Thomson called the Second Symphony "vulgar, self-indulgent, and provincial beyond all description." Benjamin Britten looked at the Fourth Symphony and said that its composer must have been drunk. Rene Leibowitz, a disciple of Schoenberg, called the Fifth "the worst symphony ever written." Bartok thought none of the symphonies would last. Theodor Adorno, typically venturing farther than most, accused Sibelius of fascistic nature worship.

title: Their Moment;The power of positive sculling
description: On a cool May afternoon in 1992, in a warm-up area before a pre-Olympic race, two German scullers accidentally rammed their bow into Silken Laumann's right leg. While the accident severed five muscle groups and laid bare her shattered tibia -- the wound was so gruesome that both Germans fainted -- it also provided the sort of Olympic moment that the media hunger for. Laumann had been favored to win the women's single sculls. She was the darling of Canadian sports, a muscular, blond Norman Vincent Peale who preached respect for her competitors and the courage to dream. Now, the press reported that dream "shattered."

title: Crime
description: Something tells me that Rodgers and Hammerstein might not have been keen to write a musical about the Minnesota State Fair where Pete Hautman has set his frighteningly funny new crime novel, THE MORTAL NUTS (Simon & Schuster, $21). Some of the all-American sights at this giant fair seem normal enough: the farm machinery, the freak show, the scary sky rides and the 1,200-pound prize hog in the livestock tent. But when a psychotic ex-con named James Dean shows up at the fairgrounds with three doped-up skinhead pals and a gun, nobody waves the flag and breaks into song -- even though Dean's lust for fame and fortune, heavy drugs and good times is as American as any prize hog.

title: WEDDINGS;Lisa N. Skop And Ian H. Morris
description: Lisa Nichele Skop, a daughter of Anita and Robert Skop of Brooklyn, and Ian Howard Morris, the son of Renee and David Morris of Fair Lawn, N.J., are to be married today at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi Selig Salkowitz is to perform the ceremony.

title: Their Moment;From comrade to capitalist, grumpily
description: Some years ago, at the Neubrandenburg track club in East Germany, a coach took one look at 13-year-old Astrid Kumbernuss's height and made a notation: Shotput. "If someone else had looked at me on a different day," she says, "I could have become a sprinter."

title: A.M.A. Shelves Disputed Report on Drugs
description: A report commissioned by an influential committee of the American Medical Association has been shelved after some medical experts who reviewed a draft copy expressed outrage at its recommendation that marijuana be legalized and criminal penalties removed from other illegal drugs.

title: Scoundrel Time
description: HELLMAN AND HAMMETT The Legendary Passion of Lillian Hellman and Dashiell Hammett. By Joan Mellen. Illustrated. 572 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $32. HERE they come again: Dashiell Hammett and Lillian Hellman, the Nick and Nora of the limousine left, the ultimate fun couple of a decade when martinis before breakfast were de rigueur and mass murder was politically correct so long as the K.G.B. was picking the victims. Even under the best of circumstances, the prospect of wading once more into the moral muck of the Hammett-Hellman menage turns the stomach, and the title of Joan Mellen's dual biography, the first book to be based on Hellman's private papers, isn't exactly encouraging: surely it's a bit late in the day to be paying homage to a "legendary passion," which in point of fact appears to have been worthy of Krafft-Ebing at his most picturesque.

title: WEDDINGS;Alice Bers, John S. Baick
description: Alice Bers, a daughter of Dr. Susan Bers and Victor Bers of Hamden, Conn., is to be married today to John S. Baick, a son of Chung Ja Baick and Dr. Choong Hyun Baick of Irvine, Calif. Acting Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx is to perform the ceremony in the Faculty House at Columbia University in Manhattan.

title: YOUR HOME;The Buzz On Battling The Insects
description: IN winter, few sounds are as soothing as a wood fire crackling in the hearth. And in summer, few sounds are as satisfying as a mosquito crackling in the zapper.

title: WEDDINGS;Margaret Slusar, William B. Smith
description: Margaret Andrea Slusar, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Slusar of Wallingford, Conn., was married yesterday to William Bryant Smith, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Leslie C. Smith of Princeton, N.J. The bridegroom's father, the rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn.

title: No. 1 Problem For Tracks Isn't O.T.B.
description: At Belmont, Once Again the Future Is Uncertain" [June 2] glibly associates that most of that $26.7 million in wagering for the Belmont Stakes was part of the O.T.B. handle. It is not. If you looked it up you would see most of that handle is collected through the New York Racing Association's selling its races to race tracks and simulcast facilities around the world. And most of those tracks pay less back to N.Y.R.A. than do the New York State O.T.B. corporations

title: WEDDINGS;Cristina Conomos, Scott M. Kennedy
description: Cristina Maria Conomos, the daughter of Nina and Sperios Conomos of New Hyde Park, L.I., is to be married today to Scott Michael Kennedy, a son of Mary Reggio and a stepson of Robert Reggio of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. James Carmody is to perform the ceremony at Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church in New Hyde Park.

title: WEDDINGS;Wendi B. Rose, Joseph B. Rose
description: Wendi Beth Rose, the daughter of Marshall Rose of New York and the late Jill Rose, was married at her father's house in East Hampton, L.I., last evening to Joseph Benedict Rose, a son of Joanna and Daniel Rose of New York. The two families are not related. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: SOAPBOX;How to Walk the New York Walk
description: WHENEVER I take a walk of any consequence in Manhattan, I try to do it without stopping for red lights. I'd always assumed I was alone at playing this defiance game. But when I recently blurted out my secret to a few friends in a heated, over-drinks discussion about aerobic exercises that don't require a trip to the gym, the response caught me off guard.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Pelletreau, And Mr. Hughes
description: Katherine Day Pelletreau, a daughter of Dr. Pamela Day Pelletreau and Robert H. Pelletreau Jr. of Washington, was married yesterday at her parents' summer house in Woods Hole, Mass., to Kevin Craig Hughes, a son of Linda Williams Tobey of Cumberland, Me., and Peter B. Hughes of Standish, Me. The Rev. Anne P. Woodbury, the bride's aunt who is a chaplain at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, performed the ceremony.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: I grew up in the late 1940's and lament the loss so aptly described by Green. And lying in the grave next to the standards is social dancing. Until the early 60's, my wife and I could go to a dance with her parents and we would all enjoy ourselves. Not only is today's music undanceable, it is generationally divisive.

title: NOTICED;For Dog Walkers, A New Leash on Life
description: FOR a former psychotherapist it has provided a respite from lupus. For a highly paid corporate headhunter, it was a change that brought her closer to God. And for Tinee Birch, well, it's just her life.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Excavations in Rome Lay Bare the Forums
description: SCRATCH the surface almost anywhere in Rome and you will find a scrap of history. Excavators digging foundations last year for Rome's projected new Philharmonic Hall, designed by the architect Renzo Piano, were stopped by the Ministry for the Cultural Heritage when they unearthed an ancient Roman villa.

title: ART;A Profile of Sculpture's Concerns
description: PARTISANS of sculpture often explain their preference by saying that sculpture has an alluring immediacy. It occupies the same space as the viewer and thereby demands to be dealt with.

title: POSTINGS: Municipal Art Society Awards;Honoring Those Who 'Inspire Others'
description: In a ceremony held in the Governors Island movie theater -- part of New York City's newest historic district -- the Municipal Art Society handed out its annual series of awards last Tuesday to New Yorkers and New York organizations that, according to its president, Brendan Sexton, "light creative sparks" and "inspire others."

title: SPENDING IT;For Reverse Mortgages, a Fannie Mae Imprimatur
description: REVERSE mortgages, portrayed as a way for elderly homeowners to remain in their houses while providing them with an income, have also been criticized as too expensive and confusing. The elderly are often wary of these loans, and because of this, reverse mortgages have accounted for only a small fraction of the total mortgage debt held by consumers.

title: Golfing Success. Like Father, Like Son.
description: IT is a balmy evening in late spring and the best father and son golfing duo ever in Connecticut is practicing putting, side by side, near the pro shop of the Shorehaven Golf Club in Norwalk while engaged in some good-natured bantering. It is an appropriate venue and vignette, since it is at the club that Jerry Courville Sr. and Jerry Courville Jr. began as caddies and honed their games before embarking on remarkably similar, and successful, parttime careers as amateur golfers.

title: Indian Premier's Roots May Be Clue to His Course
description: When H. D. Deve Gowda was sworn in as Prime Minister of India this month, a crowd pushed into his family's low-roofed house in this village 1,000 miles from New Delhi to watch the live television coverage.

title: COPING;Our Shrunken Head: Warrior or Fraud?
description: WE took Timmy to the Museum of Natural History last week, and we left him there.

title: Ideas & Trends;Promises We've Heard Before
description: A plane crashes and the public learns that even before the accident the Federal Aviation Administration had been concerned about safety problems at the airline. The F.A.A. orders better oversight of maintenance contractors, and there are calls for fundamental change in the agency's mission.

description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: WEDDINGS;Lauren Angioletti, Theodore Kallina
description: Dr. Lauren Angioletti, the daughter of Barbara and Lee N. Angioletti of Norwood, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Theodore Francis Kallina, a son of Fay and Carl Kallina of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. William Scafidi performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: FOOD;Summer Bounty of Fruit Yields Cobblers and Crisps
description: HOME-STYLE fruit desserts, notably cobblers and crisps, are riding a wave of popularity. And no wonder. They are easier than pie. Fresh fruit judiciously sweetened is given just a topping of biscuit, streusel or batter.

description: MANY residents of Winsted and the surrounding town of Winchester -- their combined population is 11,300 -- are fiercely proud of their yellow brick hospital set atop a hill.

title: More Than Meets the Eye
description: THE POWER OF BEAUTY By Nancy Friday. 589 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $27.50.

title: PERSPECTIVES;A Midtown Rental Building on the Comeback Trail
description: WHAT brought Susan Rybin to the apartment building at 162 West 54th Street last month was its size. "Gigantic," she called it, with "a living room like ballroom." The 33-year-old Ms. Rybin, who runs a talent-management firm, pays about $2,200 a month in rent.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne Sachs, David Kornhauser
description: Anne Sachs, a daughter of Sheila and Leon Sachs of Forest Hills, Queens, is to be married today to David Robert Kornhauser, the son of Janet and Stanley Kornhauser of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Gerald Skolnik is to officiate at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

description: Sarah Bradley Bower, a Connecticut treasury official, and Robert Nicholas Bua, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford. The Rev. Peter Grandy performed the ceremony.

Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue in New York.

description: Kristen Beth Budlong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Ives Budlong of Windsor, Conn., was married yesterday to David Ralph Eckhardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Eckhardt of Dunedin, Fla. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;School Board Election Results
description: Six weeks after the ballots were cast, the Board of Elections has certified results in all but two of the city's 32 community school districts, No. 6 in Upper Manhattan and No. 18 in southeast Brooklyn.

title: ON THE STREET;To Market, to Market, As Crisp as Lettuce
description: For a few of the Saturday morning shoppers at the Union Square Greenmarket, dressing in a sophisticated sportswear style is a way of life that is not abandoned on weekends. The fashion pace and the market come to life after the dormant winter months with the arrival of dogwood branches in flower and continues through autumn leaves and December evergreens. The crispness of starched white linen and a lace jacket on some of the stylish shoppers, a long textured tanktop, a linen sweater on a young man who wears a matching beanie -- all these provide a counterpoint to the freshness of the produce. With the arrival of summer this week, wide-brim straw and cotton hats and an occasional parasol add a nostalgic touch of country life to this oasis in the center of the metropolis.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Once Again, Boston Comes to Brooklyn

title: The Athletic Esthetic
description: A woman might train her body to excel in an astonishing variety of sports, to be precise and fast, to run with longer strides and to reach with her legs for the finish line, bettering her personal record by precious seconds, until eventually she wins three Olympic medals and commands such widespread admiration that she is called "the greatest athlete of all mankind for all time." But could she find a husband? That was the question with which the press confronted Mildred (Babe) Didrikson after her triumph in the track and field events at the Los Angeles Games in 1932.

title: Walter Guevara Arze, 84; Rebel Became President of Bolivia
description: Walter Guevara Arze, a leader of the Bolivian revolution in 1952, died on Thursday at his home in La Paz, the Bolivian capital. He was 84.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Johan's the Sixth
description: ATLANTIC CITY'S most arrogant chef insists that he's mellowed. Johan Vroegop (pronounced VROO-hop, with a guttural h) still chews on a cigar, swigs a daily bottle of Chinese ginseng soda and boasts that any restaurant with his name on it is "the best in the world." But the man who used to run the most expensive restaurant in Atlantic City, if not the entire state, has changed his tune.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Filling a Void in Accounting
description: THE battle over who chooses the people who set accounting standards seems likely to end in some sort of compromise, with Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, prevailing in his effort to have people who represent the "public interest" added to the Financial Accounting Foundation.

description: For several years, I have taught English to adult Latin American and Chinese immigrants by singing selections from "The Great American Songbook" to my students, a cappella. My students often break in during my first rendition, devouring the strong melodies and clever lyrics.

She, her husband, Victor, and their 8-year old daughter, Sabena, stood at the edge of a lake recently catching fish with a bamboo pole as cicadas kept up a hum that some of the city visitors nearby thought was heavy machinery.

description: The founder of the modern Olympics, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, did not approve of female athletes and wrote in 1896 that the Games should promote "the exaltation of male sport." He went on to say, "It is indecent that the spectators should be exposed to the risk of seeing the body of a woman being smashed before their very eyes."

title: Back to Vietnam: Past Meets Present
description: THAO THACH missed her graduation ceremony from New York Medical College in Valhalla last month. Instead, she was visiting clinics in the rural provinces of Vietnam, bringing medical supplies to the country she fled by boat in the dark of night 15 years ago.

title: Dr. Daniel Mazia, 83, Pioneer In Study of How Cells Divide
description: Dr. Daniel Mazia, a biologist who carried out pioneering work on cell division, structure and regulation, died on June 9 in Monterey, Calif. He was 83.

title: ON POLITICS;Enter Harriet Derman, Lawmaker Turned Insider
description: Harriet E. Derman had been Governor Whitman's chief counsel only a few weeks when the Governor asked her to take a new job, the top post in her inner circle: chief of staff.

description: Iraq has agreed to grant United Nations weapons inspectors immediate access to sites suspected of housing banned weapons material, Rolf Ekeus, the chief United Nations inspector, said today at a news conference at the Iraqi Foreign Ministry.

description: TOTTENVILLE, the Staten Island community farthest from Manhattan and the southernmost point of New York State, escaped the frenzy of building after the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened in 1964.

title: Chile Zoo Seen as Unfit for Man or Beast
description: Twice recently, lions escaped from their cages at Santiago's public zoo and prowled the grounds as terrified visitors ran out of the way. And no sooner had zoo keepers caught the lions and placed them in more secure quarters than a deer attacked a zoo custodian.

title: FILM;The German Comedy, An Oxymoron No More
description: FOR AT LEAST A GENERATION, German films have been saddled with a melancholy image that makes them difficult to sell overseas. Think of German films, and you think of heavy and often depressing themes, stories of pain, loss and the burdens of being alive. When the director Helmut Dietl offered his marvelous 1991 comedy "Schtonk" to foreign distributors, he complained that trying to sell a German comedy was like trying to sell Swedish spaghetti: it seemed a contradiction in terms.

description: The scene was like "Gulliver's Travels" meets "The Fountainhead." A giant architect looms over Manhattan and plucks the Coliseum, a legal, political and economic sore spot for nearly a decade, from Columbus Circle. He substitutes a sleeker and larger building complex.

title: Their Moment;Body over mind
description: When Yael Arad, 29, took the silver medal in Judo at the Barcelona Olympics, she went overnight from an obscurity with a third-degree black belt to a hero who can't enter a restaurant without exercising defensive motions. Her country was transformed as well.

title: Their Moment;To the victor - 9 cattle, 16 sheep and dignity
description: Tegla Loroupe, 23, began running for the same reason that many children in her small Kenyan village did: if she was late for school -- 10 kilometers away -- she'd be beaten. But running for sport was hardly encouraged. Girls were groomed to marry, work the fields and have children. Even at play, they wore skirts down to their knees. "It wasn't very good for me," Loroupe says, "so I started to wear shorts. Then I was winning, and they didn't say anything more about it."

title: Connecticut Q&A: Elaine Zimmerman;Looking Out for the Needs of the Children
description: ELAINE ZIMMERMAN, executive director of the Connecticut Commission on Children, combines a missionary's zeal with a mother's determination in her work representing the interests of children. She must look after their needs from prenatal to age 21. To spread scarce money as efficiently as possible Ms. Zimmerman has emphasized the importance of prevention and the needs of the youngest Connecticut citizens.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: Green's article on the end of standards is excellent. However, when you consider that the humor of Benchley, Thurber, Perelman and the like has similar qualities and essentially the same birth and death dates, you realize that the specifically musical and theatrical aspects are extraneous. The real problem seems to be the illness, if not death, of irony, lightness, internal contradiction, ambiguity and the concept of dramatic monologue.

description: Victoria Sonne Pulling, a daughter of Sheila Sonne Pulling of New York and Thomas L. Churchill Pinder performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

description: A police officer was saved by wearing his bulletproof vest last night after he was shot in the back in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the police said.

description: Until recently, the people of this sprawling suburb of Trenton had no reason to recognize Connie Silakoski. Then Mrs. Silakoski, a homemaker and mother of three, waged a battle against the nation's largest discount chain. These days, she is known as the woman who fought off Wal-Mart.

title: Advertisements for Himself
description: GO AND TELL PHARAOH The Autobiography of the Reverend Al Sharpton. By Al Sharpton and Anthony Walton. Illustrated. 276 pp. New York: Doubleday. $23.95.

title: Where Life, Paintings and Bugs Overlap
description: Irene Hardwicke of Roxbury is a painter who has a sort of love-hate relationship with bugs. She's fascinated by them, frightened of them, perhaps, if judged by her work, obsessed by them. Her paintings, intricate detailed works, are filled with bugs of all sorts, woven through each model's hair, climbing up trellises in the background. And instructions about how to raise certain bugs are even inscribed in tiny handwritten instructions across the human bodies.

title: WEDDINGS;Carrie S. Barr, Garrison Miller
description: Carrie Susan Barr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Barr of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Lindley Garrison Miller Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Oyster Bay, L.I. Msgr. Charles W. title: GARDENING;Going Beyond Green in Landscape Color
description: ALL trees have green leaves in summer. Right? Wrong. Some trees have purple, yellow or variegated leaves. The possiblities for color other than green in tree foliage is part of landscape artistry that can make summertime truly spectacular.

title: Belize Tomb Yields New Insights on Maya
description: Archeologists digging at ruins in northern Belize have found what they think is a royal tomb, complete with the skeleton of a man bedecked in a jeweled necklace befitting the ruler of a minor city-state in the fifth century A.D., the early classic period of the Maya civilization.

title: Even in Slow-Motion, It's a Russian Revolution
description: WHEN the Soviet Union collapsed five years ago, many people not just Americans -- assumed that tomorrow had finally come to Russia. Just as Marxists view the withering of the state as a natural process of history, reformers regarded the end of Communist rule here as the final turn to the West.

title: Their Moment;Too old, too big, still wins
description: After winning at the Barcelona Olympics, Janet Evans turned hydrophobic: for four months, she wouldn't get wet except to shower. When she changed her mind and decided to compete again, she took a look around and noticed that things were not the same. The skinny high-school junior who had taken three golds in '88 with her awkward windmill stroke, then four years later plucked another gold and a silver at Barcelona, was now . . . bigger. Since Seoul, she had grown seven inches and put on 18 pounds.

title: SIGNOFF;Disorder in This Court? No Way!
description: IMAGINE that your case is being heard by a teen-age judge and jury. That your lawyer has a voice that still cracks and that the prosecutor uses strawberry-flavored lip gloss. Despite what grown-ups might think, Teen Court TV, Court TV's new programming block, offers evidence that this would not prove to be a case of disorder in the court.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Bums, Ingrates and Buzz Cuts
description: THE 1980's were certainly heady days at Astor Place Hairstylists, whose quick, cheap cuts exported East Village styles to a mass audience. They shaved, clipped and sculptured more heads than anyone except maybe the Army, and introduced a whole generation of New Yorkers to the joys of buzz cuts, Mohawks and spiked hair. Lines snaked around the block, customers were summoned by bullhorn, a mezzanine was added, then a basement. And the staff grew to 100 barbers from 6.

description: The unpredictable baseball continued between the Yankees and the Indians today, with lots of twists and turns. One team burst to a 5-0 lead. One team scored nine times during an inning that lasted 64 minutes. One struggling player pounded homers from both sides of the plate.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICANS;Dole Sees Ethical Arrogance In the Misuse of F.B.I. Files
description: Accusing the Clinton Administration of "a pattern of ethical arrogance," Bob Dole devoted a radio address today to the growing scandal over the White House's collection of the confidential F.B.I. files of more than 400 Republicans.

title: New Classes Fit Poorly Into Old Grading System
description: Rhahim Acosta, a ninth grader in East New York, Brooklyn, took home a report card recently showing that a teacher named Langston Jones had given him an 80 in a music course, a grade he should have been happy with. The only problem: Rhahim had not taken a music course and had not had Mr. Jones as a teacher this semester.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL/BROOKLYN HEIGHTS;The St. George Hotel: Back From the Brink?
description: It took a long time for the St. George Hotel to devolve from a vacation spot for some of the city's most dapper into a boarding house for some of the city's most desperate. Still, George Scott plans to resurrect a bit of the hotel's former style by the end of the summer.

description: Dismissal at Okeanos Mirrors a Split" [May 12] presents another separate, equally serious, issue. You reported the planned use by Okeanos of rehabilitation animals for exhibition in the aquarium. This use would be both ethically and legally incorrect.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: SHADY doings - by handsome suspects, evil children, molls and bad guys - are at the center of some vintage films on television this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-12

title: Tough Smoking Law Survives Challenge
description: HAVING survived a legal challenge in State Supreme Court earlier this month, the county's tough, new anti-smoking ordinance is now due to take effect on Sept. 1. Passed by the County Board of Health, the measure is considered one of the strictest in the state.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Taurus G vs. Chevrolet Lumina;Some Cheap Shots In the Price Fight
description: IT'S not easy being the king of the hill. Just when things are going nicely, some pretender starts taking shots at the throne.

title: Their Moment;From shepherdess to feminist
description: When Derartu Tulu, 24, of Ethiopia blew past the South African Elena Meyer in the last lap of the 10,000 meters at the Barcelona Olympics, she became the first black African woman to win a distance track medal. Draped in the Ethiopian flag, she took her victory lap holding Meyer's hand, becoming a symbol of the new, multiracial Africa. If at first Tulu seemed an unlikely heroine -- a giggly, waiflike former shepherdess from the remote highlands, where girls are routinely married off by the age of 12 -- she quickly learned how much weight she could throw around.

title: WEDDINGS;Amy C. Braverman, William Barr 3d
description: Amy Carr Braverman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jay Braverman of New York, is to be married today to William John Barr 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barr 2d of Cinnaminson, N.J. The Rev. Michael Crummy, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at St. Edward the Confessor Church in Milford, N.J.

description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Caroline Cook, Richard S. Alter
description: Caroline Joanna Cook, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Cook of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married last evening to Richard Samuel Alter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Alter of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Joseph Gilmore, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Quissett Harbor House, an inn in Falmouth, Mass. Rabbi Daniel Isaac took part in the ceremony.

title: Do Muses A Garden Make?
description: LIKE an intricate parterre, the Southport Garden Festival promises to challenge intellect and a sense of whimsy. Tours of a dozen gardens, table settings by designers, a pair of illustrated lectures and one-of-a-kind ornaments are among the attractions.

title: Say 'Cheese'
description: To the Editor: Your March 24 article "Where the Food Is New in Scotland" and a subsequent letter to the editor on April 28 praised Martins restaurant in Edinburgh, but I have a story from there to top their experiences. During the cheese course, the waiter not only lovingly described each domestic cheese but also showed me a photograph of the cow that had given the milk for it.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: To Jesse Green's lament that the great American song has died, I have two words: Billy Joel.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees And Howe Part Ways
description: Steve Howe spoke so calmly, it was eerie. He was so gracious that he freely dispensed his home telephone number to reporters. He expressed such appreciation for the Yankees that he did not sound like a pitcher who had been released just minutes earlier. But Howe was waived, and his six-year relationship with the Yankees is over.

title: BASEBALL;Ochoa (at Last) Has His Debut, and Mets Their Victory
description: Alex Ochoa had a pretty good idea why he was being summoned to his manager's office in the visiting clubhouse in Rochester late Friday night.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A 900 Number Planned For Passport Inquiries
description: The State Department plans to institute a 900 telephone number in November for information about passports. Though callers must pay for the service, the department expects them to get their information with less frustration than now. Federal workers have been so overwhelmed by inquiries that the State Department estimates that more than 30 percent of the callers give up without getting through.

title: WEDDINGS;Sally K. Fischer, Elliott J. Upton
description: Sally Kay Fischer and Elliott Joseph Upton are to be married today at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi Ira S. Youdovin is to perform the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: The Perspectives column last Sunday, about New York City's programs for tax-delinquent property, referred incorrectly to the sponsorship of a study aimed at establishing a system to identify housing most likely to be abandoned. The study is being done by the Wharton Real Estate Center and the School of Social Work of the University of Pennsylvania, and by the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University Law School.

title: INSIDE
description: A Most Unusual Spree

title: BOXING;Douglas Is a 3-Round Hit; Camacho Holds Off Duran
description: A rich man following his dream, Buster Douglas returned successfully to the ring tonight after a six-year retirement to gluttony.

title: ART GALLERIES;Don't Define Artists By Sex or Race
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION;Young Hands Take Young America's Political Pulse
description: JONATHAN KARL, Cable News Network's newest and, at 28, youngest political reporter, leaned back in his chair and blamed his elders for turning young people off television news. "How many Woodstock nostalgia stories do we have to live through?" said Mr. Karl, who believes that the sheer size of the baby-boom generation is crowding Generation X off the nightly news. "People are just now starting to think about my generation."

title: HOME CLINIC;If in Doubt, Bottled Water or Filters
description: LAST week this column focused on the need to test drinking water. While most drinking water is clean there are exceptions. A test performed by a state-approved laboratory can alert the homeowner to any contaminates that might pose a threat to human health.

title: Beep-Beep!
description: Coyote v. Acme By Ian Frazier. 118 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17. SOME people believe that there are better things a writer can do with his time than produce short, funny pieces. Unfortunately, a lot of these people are magazine editors, and their thoroughly misguided interest in the personality profile, literary short story and memoir are ruining Western civilization and making life hard for humor writers.

title: For Hikers, The Train To the Trail
description: Sixty-six miles north of Grand Central Terminal, and well beyond suburbia, lies a unique stop on Metro-North's Harlem line.

title: POP MUSIC;Heartbreak (Motel Inn) Hotel
description: MOST SONGS BEGIN WITH A SCRAP of paper on which a songwriter tries to capture an inspiration. Sometimes it's all written in one burst. Other times, a line or two is jotted down, then scratched out, and new ones are added later, when the muse returns. Beyond the beginnings of a memorable tune, such scribblings offer provocative glimpses of the creative process.

title: ART;A Century Of Culture And Art Sits For Its Portrait
description: ALMOST AS RICH AND VARIED AS THE WORLD of art and culture over the past century are the images that have traced and recorded that world. Many of those images can be found in the picture library of The New York Times, which holds some six million original prints dating back to the turn of the century. Many came from photo agencies, individual photographers and publicists. Others were by Times photographers, often anonymously in the early years.

title: Where Are the Good, Clean Musical Fights of Yesteryear?
description: MUSIC HISTORIANS OF the future, Virgil Thomson once suggested, will be better equipped to deal with the second quarter of the 20th century than with any other era. The reason is Modern Music, an impoverished yet influential quarterly that from 1924 to 1946 provided composers with a forum in which to critique one another's works and tell of music in their time.

title: MUSIC;Keyboard Training, and Playing
description: IT is not quite a festival, but it comes close: for two weeks, beginning next Sunday, Concordia College is host to a Keyboard Clinic and Chamber Music Intensive on its Bronxville campus. Last summer's piano focus has now been expanded to encompass other gifted student instrumentalists who, in addition to taking part in daily seminars, master classes and workshops, will themselves be performing in various ensembles.

title: WEDDINGS;Mandi Zaltas And David Kunen
description: Dr. Mandi Mary Zaltas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Zaltas of South Natick, Mass., is to be married this evening to David Alan Kunen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Kunen of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Harold Kushner is to perform the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

title: Foreign Affairs;Defusing the E-Bomb
description: President Clinton flies to France this week for the annual G-7 meeting. Here's the speech he won't be giving to the gathering of Japanese, Canadian and European leaders:

title: To Buyers, the Spoils of War
description: A BRAWL has broken out for the title of America's best-selling car, and consumers stand to benefit from some special deals for midsize sedans.

title: Insurance Plan Gives Boaters a Safety Net
description: WHEN a hurricane strikes the Florida coast, boat owners in Westchester feel the blow in the form of higher costs for boat insurance.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;The Day I Jumped Over The Moon
description: AND then there was the time I almost had 10,000 head of cattle delivered to my one-bedroom apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: WEDDINGS;Judith Fleishman, Douglas A. Silver
description: Judith Emily Fleishman, the daughter of Amy and Dr. Ernest Fleishman of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Alexander Silver, a son of Ann and H. Richard Silver of Sagaponack, L.I. Robert Gillette, a justice of the peace, officiated at his home in Redding, Conn.

title: Sports of the Times;When the Time Comes, Ozzie Smith Will Do Back Flips Into Hall of Fame
description: IN a sport that has been around for a century and a half, it is rare to be able to say that a contemporary just might be the best defensive player ever at his position. That is what some people were saying about Ozzie Smith last week, when he announced he would retire from baseball at the end of this season.

title: The Capitalist;Just Buy It
description: EIGHTEEN MONTHS AGO NIKE decided that it needed to market sneakers to women exactly as it does to men. The company's research had found that when young girls who played sports were asked what they thought of when they heard the word "Nike," they named some male athlete -- usually Michael Jordan or Charles Barkley. There was also a disturbing trend of young female basketball players buying men's shoes rather than women's. The company's concern was not for the girls' self-esteem, of course, but for its own potential profits: it feared that a booming new market would fall into the hands of a company shrewd enough to speak directly to women. So Nike quickly signed up a host of female hoopsters and even created the first basketball shoes named for a woman -- Air Swoopes, for the Olympian Sheryl Swoopes. They sold out immediately.

title: June 16-22;The U.S. Posts Its Opening For U.N. Secretary General
description: In an election-year challenge to the United Nations, many of whose members think the United States is trying to run the world unilaterally in any case, the Clinton Administration said it opposes a second term for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, 73, and would use its veto to prevent one.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Warsaw
description: Bustling with commercial energy and new deals hatching on every street corner, Warsaw sheds some of its serious business attitude during the summer. Song festivals, music in the parks, street fares and impromptu sidewalk fashion shows will be in full swing in the coming months. After a long winter and spring, the city is dressed in abundant green. Warsaw women are exceedingly fashion conscious these days, and their stylishness adds to the jaunty atmosphere.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Identity Crisis At the Airport
description: ONE last thing before you dash out the door to the airport: are you carrying something to identify yourself to the gate agent? It's a good idea, to judge by reports from readers and airlines.

title: FILM;Too Bad 'Oklahoma!' Had Already Been Used
description: It ended up with the name "Twister," but cyberspace dwellers had other ideas for the hit tornado movie. Here are a dozen alternative titles from the Internet, seen most recently on Dan Galvin's Thought for the Day mailing list: LISTSERV

title: MUSIC;Just Another Mom Who Sings at the Met
description: AT the end of the Princeton High School concert, the moms and dads applaud the student choir and orchestra. Then everyone claps for Josh and Zach Sweet's mom because she is the grown-up soprano soloist. And then she turns around and claps for the students.

title: What They Do for Love
description: A WALL STREET controller by day lights up at night as a song-and-dance man in a Gershwin musical. A labor-relations specialist goes for roles as brawny killers in gritty dramas. A junior high math teacher evolves from chorus girl to resident diva. And an industrial executive moonlights as a stage director.

title: LIVES;Fear of Flying
description: When I was 5 years old, a tornado lifted my family from our suburban neighborhood, in our Ford station wagon, and turned us onto our collective back like a bug. Then, strangely enough, the tornado lifted our car once more, and righted us. Flatter, yes, but restored to our wheels, bodies more or less intact. Inside the car were: my father, my mother -- eight months pregnant with what would soon be my sister -- two of my brothers, a family friend and I. My brother David and I were in what we called the "way back," the two facing seats in the rear of the car that folded down to create cargo space, up to accommodate children.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: Thank you for the elegant and bittersweet article by Jesse Green "The Song Is Ended" (June 2). It embodied the very elements of those wondrous songs that made -- and make -- them so dear to those of us who were fortunate enough to grow up with them.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN VALLEY;An Incident on Amsterdam: A Case of Police Brutality?
description: Their meeting had just ended and officials of the Community Free Democrats, an Upper West Side club, were filing onto Amsterdam Avenue when they came upon chaos: sirens, flashing lights, the police and a man lying on the pavement with his hands cuffed behind his back. Then, five witnesses said, they watched in disbelief as a police officer picked up the man and dropped him face-down onto the sidewalk.

title: CHATTER;Everyone's a Consultant
description: If you were managing the Senate campaign of Robert Torricelli or Richard Zimmer, what advice would you give your candidate?

title: BOOKEND;Our Jerusalem
description: KING DAVID'S conquest of the city of Jerusalem 3,000 years ago should perhaps be considered the true starting point of American literature -- if not of America itself. The Pilgrim Fathers mapped out this country Bible in hand, and American writers have been reading the image of Jerusalem into our culture ever since. The biblical city on a hill has played so formative a role in our understanding of ourselves that the anniversary of David's Jerusalem seems a peculiarly American event. (No wonder President Clinton felt so comfortable campaigning in the recent Israeli elections.) Recalling what our greatest writers made of Jerusalem reveals a good deal about the mysterious pull the ancient city continues to exert on our modern imaginations.

title: Notes on High Water Out West
description: It has been an abrupt, sodden spring in southwestern Montana. The rivers are full of snowmelt and will be full for many days to come. At Carter's Bridge, just south of Livingston, the Yellowstone River sucks at the concrete bridge pilings with a low, hydraulic hiss. The discolored current swarms with floating debris, mostly cottonwood branches, their bark half-stripped by the commotion. Upstream and down, the river gnaws at its banks, pulling away great fragments of earth, which appear to struggle for a moment and then to succumb, dissolving in a darker swirl of water.

title: WEDDINGS;Gretchen Johnson, Mark W. Biedron
description: Gretchen Ann Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Loring Johnson of Pottersville, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Winslow Biedron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Biedron of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. William A. Potter performed the Episcopal ceremony in the pine woods on the Johnson farm in Pottersville.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Three Airlines Expand Overseas Routes
description: Three United States airlines have recently added international routes. Trans World Airlines, (800) 221-2000, has begun twice-daily service between St. Louis and Toronto aboard MD-80 aircraft. Westbound flights leave Toronto in the early morning and evening. Eastbound flights leave St. Louis in the early afternoon and evening. Round-trip tickets start at $336, with a Saturday night stopover and 14-day advance purchase.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Heartland of Darkness
description: Although he may be best known to the general public as an actor, Sam Shepard has -- in more than 45 plays -- lured theatergoers into a nightmare vision of rural America with haunting images of incest and betrayal. Once the bad boy of the avant-garde, Mr. Shepard arrived on Broadway this spring with a revival of his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, "Buried Child." And in the fall he joins the ranks of Horton Foote and Edward Albee when New York's Signature Theater Company devotes its season to his works. In CRUISING PARADISE (Knopf, $23), a collection of short stories, dialogues and journal entries, Mr. Shepard deals mostly in recollections: A boy visits a seedy motel to find the mattress on which his drunken father burned to death. A woman slices off her lover's finger while wrapped in his embrace. A man and a woman spar bitterly and then part, for reasons unknown to either. A movie crew bakes under the Mexican sun while Indian voladores, or "flying men," dangle from a pole in an ancient ritual. There is nothing pretty about Mr. Shepard's supposed paradise: here people wrestle with their demons and, more often than not, the demons win. Kathryn Shattuck

title: County Aid Sought by Community Colleges
description: COMMUNITY COLLEGES, the largest and least expensive providers of higher education on Long Island, are turning to county governments for increased financial support in a time of uncertainty.

title: How the Mob Is Affecting The County
description: THE arrests earlier this month of 19 men accused of being members of the Genovese clan, including three who live in Westchester, may have weakened the New York City base of one of the most powerful Mafia families, but Federal and local law enforcement officials said both traditional and emerging organized-crime groups continue to pose a threat in Manhattan, the Bronx and surrounding areas.

title: Union and Con Ed Reach Pact
description: Averting a strike that could have affected millions of electric customers in New York City and Westchester County, Consolidated Edison and the union representing its 11,000 workers reached a tentative agreement last night on a new four-year contract.

title: Bridge
description: To compete in an international event with players from many countries is usually an expensive business, involving hotels and long-distance travel. But thanks to modern technology, that is no longer true: it is possible to sit at home at the computer, with teammates and opponents anywhere on the planet.

title: In Slow-Paced Vermont, the Dirt Road Reigns
description: You would think that everyone would want a better road. But in Vermont people fight to keep roads that freeze in winter, that turn into muddy sinkholes in spring, that kick up clouds of dust in summer, that gobble up shocks, mufflers and the occasional whole car.

title: OLYMPICS;This Time It Counts: Johnson Shatters Record
description: When Michael Johnson crossed the finish line of the 200 meters, he looked left at the clock and saw that it read 19.66 seconds, a stunning new world record. What he never did was turn around to look at the wind gauge.

title: A Commencement Is Also a Memorial For 8th Year in Row;Mistaken Belief in Immortality Seems the Only Link in Deaths At a Connecticut High School
description: When news spread last Thursday that Robert Jennings, a senior at Seymour High School, had been killed in a car accident, the response among his classmates and their parents ran from shock and grief to guilty relief.

title: BEYOND THE BOARDWALK -- A special report.;With Cash Rolling In, Atlantic City Raises Stakes
description: Many people have written epitaphs for this storied old town. The version a few years ago went like this: Atlantic City was about to be surrounded with state-licensed casinos that would open in Pennsylvania and Connecticut and probably in New York. Losing its exclusivity as the center of East Coast gambling, the city would rapidly sink, dragged down by problems of urban decay and poverty that would never be solved.

title: Rep. Bill Emerson Is Dead at 58; Missourian Served Eight Terms
description: Representative Bill Emerson, a Missouri Republican who was the vice chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, died on Saturday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. He was 58.

title: White House Plays Down a New Age Visitor
description: A new book has caused a stir with its detailed descriptions of White House visits to Hillary Rodham Clinton by a New Age psychologist, but President Clinton's spokesman said today that the meetings were nothing more than "a brainstorming session" for the First Lady's book-writing project.

title: Mavericks Adapting To Power Of Studios
description: A few years ago it would have been unthinkable for Sylvester Stallone or the "Baywatch" television actress Pamela Anderson Lee to appear in, of all things, an independent film. Independent films starred unknown actors and were defiantly edgier, riskier and most certainly cheaper than studio films.

title: Make Sure Work Pays More Than Nonwork;Maximum Wage
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;How Fly Fishing Is a Lot Like Reading but Wetter
description: A FLYFISHER'S WORLD By Nick Lyons Drawings by Mari Lyons. 287 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $23.

title: TAKING IN THE SITE;The Internet Provides Help for Planners of Meetings
description: Planning a conference, seminar or company meeting can be a nightmare: finding a hotel with the right mix of meeting facilities and amenities; arranging flights for participants; getting equipment and materials to the right room at the right hour; planning the agenda, and coming in on budget. For all but the last two tasks, there is a growing, if not comprehensive, body of information on the World Wide Web.

title: Equity Offerings That Are Planned for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: OLYMPICS;14 Perfect Jumps Earn a Trip to Atlanta
description: When the pressure is on, some riders greet it with a smile, others crumble. After the final stage of the United States Olympic equestrian team competition today at Hamilton Farms, Peter Leone emerged smiling.

title: Giuliani Links New Baseball Stadiums to Bid for Olympics
description: As city officials and top business leaders start on the long road to trying to lure the summer Olympics to New York in 2008, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that new homes for the Yankees and the Mets should be considered as part of any plan to build stadiums and arenas to house the Games.

title: Con Ed Union And Utility Voting on Pact
description: The late-hour contract agreement between Consolidated Edison and the union representing its 11,000 workers includes wage increases over the next four years and guarantees job security, the workers' fiercest concern, spokesmen for both the utility and the union said yesterday.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Abbey Lincoln on Risk and Experience
description: Close to the end of her show at Town Hall, Abbey Lincoln sang Bob Dylan's "Mr. Tambourine Man." The song is hardly a jazz standard, but Ms. Lincoln understood its intent. Instead of singing it as a 60's anthem to the wildness of youth, she sang from the perspective of 65 years old, where one realizes that risk and experience are worth living for.

title: Media: PRESS;In Canada, concerns about consolidation.
description: IN his 1993 memoir "A Life in Progress," the publisher Conrad M. Black describes his efforts to clean up a local lake when he was the co-proprietor of his first weekly newspaper east of Montreal.

title: Traffic Alert
description: This evening's commuting in the midtown Manhattan area may be harder than usual because of visits by President Clinton and Bob Dole. Both men will be at midtown hotels this evening, and are expected to be traveling by motorcades.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Red Dog Beer To Angotti, Thomas
description: The Plank Road Brewery, a division of the Miller Brewing Company that markets specialty beer brands, has reassigned the Red Dog beer account to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York from BBDO Toronto, which introduced the brand in the United States. BBDO Toronto, a unit of Omnicom Group, produced American work for Red Dog from September 1994 until last month. Kari McGrath, a spokeswoman for Plank Road in Milwaukee, said on Friday that Angotti, Thomas was awarded the Red Dog account after a review among the Plank Road and Miller roster shops, which also include the Bates USA unit of Cordiant P.L.C., the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago and Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York.

title: Republicans Challenge Notion Of Separate Jails for Juveniles
description: Republicans in Congress are moving to overturn what has been a fundamental principle of the American juvenile justice system for more than 150 years: the strict separation of jailed young offenders from hardened adult criminals.

title: NYC;Giving Back To Promote Getting Along
description: KELVIN CHRISTOPHER JAMES traces "the James thing," as he calls it, to a family ritual in Arima, the village in Trinidad where he grew up. On the first Sunday of the year, his mother would organize a feast for everyone in that rural outpost. For her son, it meant a full day of "working like a slave," but he learned an important lesson from his labors.

title: Pataki and D'Amato Praise Lefkowitz's Devotion
description: Calling his passing the end of "an era of giants" in New York State politics, Gov. George E. Pataki joined dozens of other dignitaries yesterday at funeral services for Louis J. Lefkowitz, a renowned campaigner who served as Attorney General longer than anyone in the state's history.

title: Correction
description: A chart with an article in Money and Business yesterday about companies' accounting practices misstated the titles of Sally Kasaks of Ann Taylor Stores. Ms. Kasaks is chairwoman and chief executive, not the former chief executive.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Capote Belle Wins the Prioress in Romp
description: She is a strapping bay filly, a daughter of Capote and granddaughter of Fappiano and Seattle Slew, she was bought for only $25,000 and she did not race until this year because she developed a stress fracture in her leg. But she ran second in her debut last month, won her second race by six lengths earlier this month and rocketed six lengths in front of the field yesterday at Belmont Park to win her first stakes race, the Prioress.

title: Political Memo;Superstores Set Stage For the Political Sell
description: New Yorkers want it all when it comes to shopping, says the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger. They want superstores with big selections and low prices, but they also want the cozy shops that give neighborhoods texture. They want all the possible economic blessings from New York City's plan to allow giant superstores into underused manufacturing zones, but none of the pinch if smaller stores get hurt by the competition.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Swing Influenced By Other Styles
description: Halfway through the Art Ensemble of Chicago's show at Town Hall on Wednesday night, the bassist, Malachi Favors, started a solo improvisation using a few notes from a blues scale. He repeated them and turned them into a dance figure, finally strumming his bass, drawing out overtones and buzzes and drones that made the solo resonant. Mr. Favors, who rarely performs in New York, was appearing with the band as part of the Heineken What Is Jazz? Festival.

title: Demonstrators And Devout Greet the Pope In Germany
description: On a day intended to evoke his long pilgrimage from Nazi-occupied Poland to the fall of Communism, Pope John Paul II was greeted with protesters' whistles, boos and obscenities as he arrived at the Brandenburg Gate here tonight to celebrate his vision of freedom.

title: Jerome Edelstein, Getty Official, 71
description: Jerome Melvin Edelstein, a former staff member of the Getty Center for the History of Art and the Humanities in Santa Monica, Calif., died on June 12 at a hospital in Providence, R.I. He was 71 and lived in Bristol, R.I.

description: To the Editors:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police Bills Up for Votes
description: Responding to the 1995 murder of a retired police chief who was escorting an elderly couple through a Newark cemetery, the Assembly is expected to vote today on a bill that would allow retired officers to carry guns. Officers would have to apply for permits within six months of retiring and would have to reapply annually. (The trial of Thomas Cross, one of the men accused of killing the retired chief, is scheduled to begin in Newark today.) A related bill also up for a vote today would mandate life imprisonment for anyone who is convicted of murdering a law enforcement officer and is not sentenced to death.

title: ARAB LANDS WARN ISRAEL OF DANGER TO IMPROVED TIES
description: Arab leaders warned today that they would be forced to rethink relations with Israel if its new Government does not adhere to principles they declared vital to a wider peace in the Middle East.

description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Figure Linked to Scandal Is Found Dead in Brazil
description: A central figure in the downfall of the former Brazilian President, Fernando Collor de Mello, was found killed this morning in northeastern Brazil, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times;Johnson's Record 19.66: A Performance as Hot As the Track Itself
description: When he runs, Michael Johnson seems to be more chest than legs. He resembles a race horse more than a greyhound, a race horse with an Olympic track that is clear and fast. And hot.

title: Advertising;BBDO and five sponsors publish a CD-ROM to assist with redecorating a house on line.
description: BBDO NEW YORK has developed an innovative interactive media project combining home remodeling and home pages.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY Bellsouth Corp Standard Prods Co

title: Ride Has Another Mishap
description: A car from a Coney Island roller coaster ride that malfunctioned last month, injuring a couple, crashed on Saturday night after the operator failed to apply the brakes, the police said. Three people suffered minor knee and chest injuries.

title: Terrel H. Bell, 74, Education Chief In Reagan Years
description: Terrel H. Bell, who served as President Ronald Reagan's Education Secretary and who was credited with starting a national school reform movement, died at his home here on Saturday. He was 74.

title: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Andreas Papandreou, Greek Leftist Who Admired and Annoyed U.S., Diesat 77
description: Andreas Papandreou, the former Prime Minister of Greece and a maverick who towered over Greek political life for more than two decades, died yesterday in Athens. He was 77.

title: In Night Ministry, Cookies and Condoms Carry the Message
description: Pimps, hustlers and teen-age runaways, homeless mothers and hungry children, lonely hearts and lost souls are all part of the congregation of the night, the flock the Rev. Bruce Moore was looking for at 12:30 A.M. on the first day of summer because it was his turn to drive the bus.

title: At Trenton's Year-Round Grade Schools,Test Scores and Attendance AreHigher
description: On the official first day of summer, the cry "no more books" did not echo across the asphalt playground behind Mott Elementary School. There were no giddy feelings of imminent freedom, and no hopes that the last bell would usher in dreamy days spent idling by a pool.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Speed Is Urged In Shift to Digital TV Senior leaders of the Senate and the House, in a letter to the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, have asked the agency "to move forward as expeditiously as possible" to loan every one of the nation's television stations a second channel so they can begin the transition to digital broadcasting. [Page D6.]

title: Enlisting A Small Publisher
description: When popular mystery writer Walter Mosley came calling with a book deal for the Black Classic Press, the owner of the small publishing company did what any businessman would do under the circumstances. He cried.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Escaping Pain of Budget Cuts
description: Study after study has shown that, proportional to the amount of Federal taxes its residents pay, New Jersey gets less Federal money than just about any state in the country. But that is not necessarily a bad thing in today's political climate, the Northeast-Midwest Institute concluded last week. As Congress tightens its budget and shifts more responsibility to the states, the nonprofit policy group found, New Jersey will find it easier to adapt than its neighbors. In other words, The A.P. reported yesterday, cutting New Jersey's already small share will hurt less.

title: PBS Names a Programmer
description: The Public Broadcasting Service named its chief of programming Saturday, filling the new position with a woman who formerly served as the senior vice president for programming. Kathy Quattrone, 45, a 20-year veteran of public television, was appointed executive vice president and chief programming executive by the president of PBS, Ervin Duggan, at the company's annual conference in San Francisco. Ms. Quattrone will be responsible for all programming distributed nationally by PBS, including children's, prime time and syndicated programs. She said she hoped to put more emphasis on history and arts programming.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Storms Wrack Parts of State
description: Residents of central and western New Jersey spent yesterday assessing the damage from a stormy Saturday night of tornadoes, baseball-sized hailstones, driving rains and 80-mile-an-hour winds that knocked out power to more than 38,000 homes and left a 26-year-old National Guardsman from Kings Park, L.I., dead. In one trailer park in North Hanover, Spartan Village, 70 percent of the 218 mobile homes were damaged by winds. "One home was totally destroyed. All the walls are gone," Mayor John Kocubinski of North Hanover told The Associated Press yesterday after giving Gov. Christine Todd Whitman a tour. At Fort Dix, Specialist Ronald Crima of the Army National Guard was killed when a tree he was trying to move collapsed on him. A tornado touched down in Mercer County, blowing out windows and knocking down trees along a two-mile-long path from Trenton into Hamilton Township.

title: World News Briefs;Founder's Heir Sworn In As New Bangladesh Chief
description: Two decades after the army assassinated Bangladesh's founding father, his daughter, who helped end the military rule that followed him, was sworn in today as Prime Minister.

title: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN FINANCE;Senate to Debate Bill to Ban 'Soft Money' From Elections
description: While President Clinton and Bob Dole shake the corporate and union trees for campaign money in New York on Monday, the Senate will begin debating legislation that would ban the practice and create voluntary limits on Congressional campaign spending.

title: POP REVIEW;Patti Smith, Surrounded By Ghosts, Still Rocks
description: Patti Smith opened her sold-out concert on Friday night at Irving Plaza with a 1974 poem about a 16-year-old escaping a dead-end job to come to New York City and "be somebody." She ended the two-hour show with "Farewell Reel," from her first album in eight years, a song about a 49-year-old woman recovering from the death of her husband and preparing to re-enter the world. In between these autobiographical sketches, an entire life unfurled.

title: Treasury Auction And Other Offerings Planned This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. Tomorrow, the Treasury will auction a two-year note, followed by Wednesday's auction of a five-year note.

title: Clement M. Hakim, A Tea Importer, 84
description: Clement M. Hakim, who helped develop the market for instant tea in the United States, died last Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Cybergold Plans New Marketing Approach
description: In an effort to use the Internet to cut out the middleman between advertiser and consumer, a new company, Cybergold Inc., plans to announce Monday an on-line approach to marketing and advertising that will permit advertisers to pay potential customers for reading their ads.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WALTER WAGER is an author who wants to pay homage to an unsung heroine: MARY ADELMAN, the proprietor of Osner Business Machines on Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ON BASEBALL;Could '96 Be a Triple Crown Year? A Former Winner Rates the Field
description: Is it an earthquake or simply a shock?

title: HOCKEY;For Lemaire, the Devils' Lack of Get-Up-and-Go Remains a Big Puzzle
description: So what did Jacques Lemaire learn from the disappointment of last season? What does a smart coach discover when his team defends a Stanley Cup by failing to even qualify for the playoffs?

title: POLITICS: THE HOUSE;Defying Odds in Mississippi, Black Carries G.O.P. Torch
description: The poverty runs longer and deeper through Mississippi's Second Congressional District than anywhere else in America. From the three-room shanties of Jackson to the skinny blacktop of the Delta, this is a postcard of failed dreams. Women still tote water in plastic buckets to bathe their babies, and the first of the month remains a time of great expectation because so many people exist on welfare, food stamps and Government peanut butter.

title: Democrats in Congress Introduce 'Families First' Campaign Theme
description: Congressional Democrats today introduced the legislative agenda on which they will campaign this fall, pledging to enact tax breaks and other measures to rival the Contract With America, the House Republicans' 1994 campaign manifesto.

title: A Dissident In Myanmar Now a Writer
description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the Burmese democracy movement, has taken up the journalist's pen to write a syndicated column about her life under her country's military rule.
