title: Santa Fe Journal;Texas Sashays Into Santa Fe -- and Pays Its Way
description: It was as if the Texas border had taken a sudden, 152-mile bend to the northwest, across mesas, arroyos and barbed-wire fences, to enfold a patch of what most maps still call New Mexico.

title: OLYMPICS;U.S. Diver Is At Odds With Coach
description: Less than an hour after becoming the final diver selected today for the Atlanta Games, David Pichler embraced his teammates under a giant American flag in a picture of harmony before proceeding to turn the trials upside down.

title: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming;Dare to Speak Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Xerox Auction Off Hot Air?
description: A software-based system that holds digital mini-auctions to distribute hot and cold air throughout a laboratory has been developed by scientists at the Xerox Corporation, marrying the laws of markets with those of electronics.

title: 2d Briton Is Charged In Computer Spying
description: The British police said today that they had charged a 21-year-old computer hacker with trying to gain electronic access to United States military files. The charges come just months after a teen-ager was arrested and accused of intercepting messages from United States agents in North Korea.

title: LOOKING GLASS;One Inspiration, Years of Payoff
description: Mae Boren Axton, a songwriter and a promoter of musical acts, was worried when she found one of her performers, a Memphis truck driver, gazing mournfully at the ocean outside his Dayton, Fla., hotel room. Worry turned to sympathy when Elvis Presley told her he was sad because he thought his mother and father wouldn't have a chance to see such a sight.

title: East Timor Strife
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Twins Score, but Tigers Win
description: This one was far from a shutout. The Detroit pitching staff's earned run average is 6.88, still the worst in the major leagues, after all. But the Tigers won three consecutive games for the first time this season with a come-from-behind 10-8 victory today over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Bernard Clarey, 84, Commander of Pacific Fleet
description: Adm. Bernard A. Clarey, a former Vice Chief of Naval Operations who commanded naval forces in the Pacific at the height of the Vietnam War, died on June 15 at Tripler Hospital in Honolulu. He was 84 and lived in Honolulu, where he retired in 1973 as commander of the Pacific fleet.

title: Prentice Bloedel, 95; Led Timber Giant
description: Prentice Bloedel, a founder of the Canadian timber giant MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., died on June 15. He lived in Seattle and was 95.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lake Mess Was Dead Shrimp
description: A brown slick that forced officials in Atlantic County to close a popular swimming lake Saturday afternoon turned out to be several thousand dead baby shrimp. Last week's heavy rains, said the county Parks Director, John Lamey, caused thousands of freshwater shrimp eggs in Lake Lenape to hatch all at once. Because the shrimp live for only a few days, they also died en masse, he said. The lake was reopened to swimmers after two hours. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Health on Line: Doctor Is In, and His Disk Is Full
description: Jim Clark has built two fortunes by identifying key technologies early and creating companies around them: three-dimensional computer imaging with Silicon Graphics Inc., and user-friendly tools for the World Wide Web with Netscape Communications. But with last week's start-up of his third company, the Healtheon Corporation, he leaped into what may already be the most crowded market in cyberspace: on-line health information.

title: Congress Asks F.C.C. to Begin Lending Channels for Digital TVBroadcasts
description: Senior leaders of the Senate and the House, in a letter to the Federal Communications Commission, have asked the agency "to move forward as expeditiously as possible" to lend all of the nation's television stations a second channel so they can begin the transition to digital broadcasting.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Rossini Jewel With Hints Of Old Times at Caramoor
description: When Walter and Lucie Rosen established a summer arts festival at their 100-acre Caramoor estate here in 1946, they dreamed of turning their home into an American version of England's Glyndebourne. The parallel could never be exact: Glyndebourne has always been exclusively an operatic haven, while Caramoor's main offerings have always been orchestral and chamber music. But opera was a staple at Caramoor from 1950 to 1980, with 20th-century works and revivals of Baroque and Classical rarities as the festival's specialties.

title: TENNIS;Before the Tournament Begins, There Comes Wimbledon's Volley of Words
description: Most English eyes are fixed on a different patch of grass, the Wembley soccer pitch where England's team has reached the semifinals of the European championships. However, Wimbledon has hardly gone unnoticed by the tennis elite.

title: An Ad Accuses Companies Of Overcharging for Drugs
description: The wealthy Omaha industrialist Phil Sokolof, whose full-page newspaper advertisements in 1988 accused food marketers of poisoning Americans with saturated fats, is at it again. In a fresh round of ads that he said cost him more than $550,000, Mr. Sokolof is accusing Merck & Company of charging too much for cholesterol-lowering medications.

title: 20% of World's People Live on Dollar a Day
description: More than one-fifth of the world's population lives on less than one dollar a day, according to a World Bank report on poverty released today.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;His Films Were Never Slick, but the List of Admirers Is
description: Remember, don't take anybody's word, including your mother."

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICANS;Chaotic Message to Dole Over the Abortion Issue
description: Out of the screaming and hissing that echoed through the Alamodome, the Texas Republican Party delivered an unmistakable message to Bob Dole this weekend: taming rebellious factions within his party may be far trickier than even he imagined.

title: It Takes a Skeptic to Ignore Global Warming;Integrity of Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: The Special Education Nightmare
description: New York's special education costs are growing at a bankrupting pace, and Gov. George Pataki is right to focus on containing them. But budget cuts cannot cure a poorly designed system that not only encourages overspending with built-in conflicts of interest but also fails to comply with the law. Restructuring the system -- while avoiding Federal sanctions and costly lawsuits -- will require serious thought and careful coordination among school systems, local governments and the State Legislature.

title: Singapore Court Gave American Due Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Muslim Rebels Close to Pact With Manila
description: The Government and Muslim rebels took a major step today toward ending a 24-year rebellion, and negotiators on both sides said they hoped that a peace agreement could be signed as soon as next month.

title: Cook Narrowly Misses Record
description: John Cook won the St. Jude Classic by seven shots today, missing a PGA Tour record by one stroke when his chip shot on the last hole bounced off the pin.

title: More Suitors Weigh Making Bid for MGM
description: With a deadline of 11:30 A.M. today for bids for the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, some companies were still deciding yesterday whether to jump into the fray. A winner could be announced as early as this week but perhaps not for a month, people familiar with the talks said.

title: U.S. Aid to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay;3 Scandals and Out
description: A cancer has been growing on the Clinton Presidency. Its locus is the office of the White House Counsel.

title: Unabomber Suspect Is Delivered To California to Face Charges
description: Under heavy guard, Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom attacks, arrived in California today on a flight from Montana to face Federal charges.

title: Abroad at Home;Tale Of A Bully
description: A shameful mark of the long years when Democrats controlled the House of Representatives was the abusive record of John D. Dingell of Michigan, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee. In the arrogance of his power, he terrorized individuals and institutions that he wanted to humble.

title: Japanese Stocks Up a Bit
description: Japanese stocks traded slightly higher here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 18.79 points -- less than one-tenth of 1 percent -- to stand at 22,549.44. On Friday, the Nikkei index gained 93.35 points.

title: BASEBALL;One Pitch Disastrous As the Mets Fall Short
description: Robert Person describes himself as a hard-luck pitcher. Last night, the Mets backed up his words.

title: Policy on Arming of Bosnia Requires an Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Finish Off Indians for a Perfect Weekend
description: Kenny Lofton sliced a rocket into the left-field corner in the tenuous eighth inning and the difference between the weekend remaining one of perfection for the Yankees and one of dejection for the Indians rested with the glove and fleet feet of Gerald Williams. Could Williams save the Yankees, beat the Indians and shape history with snazzy defense?

title: Technology: CONNECTIONS;The new Web publications hope to evolve to represent the on-line counterculture.
description: THERE are magazine articles for tattooed women ("Keep Your Tattoo Vibrant for Life") and conspiracy theorists (Dick Gregory on the O.J. Simpson trial). There are publications for demanding taste buds (Chile Pepper Magazine) and undemanding avant-gardists (Cliche). Even users of John Deere farming equipment and lovers of "Remembrance of Things Past" have their own periodicals.

title: Bishops Vow to Be Neutral on Election
description: Faced with widespread talk of Roman Catholics as swing voters, the nation's Catholic bishops finished a semiannual meeting here on Saturday determined to remain neutral toward candidates while speaking out on moral principles and specific issues.

title: Make Sure Work Pays More Than Nonwork
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Poritz Goes Before Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to consider the nomination of Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz to be Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court today. Ms. Poritz, nominated by Governor Whitman two weeks ago to replace the ailing Chief Justice, Robert N. Wilentz, is not expected to encounter much opposition. Last week, the Judiciary Committee easily cleared the nomination of Peter Verniero, now the Governor's chief of staff, to be the new Attorney General. The Senate could vote on both nominations as soon as Thursday, according to the committee's chairman, Senator William L. Gormley.

title: For the British Beef War: A Truce but No Victory
description: The great "beef war" of 1996 Britain's wrangling with the rest of Europe over its beef exports -- ended this weekend with an armistice in Florence.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Bealls Department Stores, Bradenton, Fla., to Crispin & Porter Advertising, Miami, to handle broadcast advertising for the retailer, previously handled by HMS/McFarland & Drier, Miami. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

title: All News, Almost All Profit, All the Time
description: Every morning, Edmond Garesche awakens in his Manhattan apartment to WCBS-AM, one of the city's three all-news radio stations, and listens for about two hours, as he lies in bed half-awake and then as he gets dressed for his job producing World Wide Web sites.

title: McCaughey Ross Is Likely to Be G.O.P. Delegate
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, whose loyalty to Gov. George E. Pataki and future in the Republican Party have been publicly questioned by state leaders in recent weeks, will most likely join New York's delegation to the Republican National Convention, the State Republican chairman said yesterday.

title: Tool Orders Lower in May
description: Orders for industrial tools made in the United States dropped 11 percent in May from the previous month, even as demand from abroad soared, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said today. Machine tool orders declined to $381.25 million in May after dipping to $428.55 million in April. Last month's orders, though tepid compared with the earlier months of 1996, were still seven-tenths of 1 percent higher than those in May 1995.

title: Justice in Exile
description: A few weeks ago, at a garden cafe in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, a businessman stopped by my table to greet Gerard Gahima, the Deputy Justice Minister. "How's business?" Mr. Gahima asked him. "Not bad," the man said. "How's justice?" Mr. Gahima shook his head. "Not so good," he said. When we were alone, he put it more bluntly: "After genocide, justice is impossible."

title: Answering Arabs, Israel Says It Rejects Conditions on Talks
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused Arab leaders today of dictating the terms of Middle East peace efforts in their statement concluding a summit meeting in Cairo.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: OLYMPICS;Holman, America's Best Miler, Finishes 13th and Fails to Make the Olympic Team
description: A month ago, Steve Holman was threatening the world record-holder Noureddine Morceli of Algeria in a mile race at the Olympic Stadium. Today, he seemed to be in perfect position to qualify for the Olympics at 1,500 meters, only to fall completely apart, dropping from the lead pack to 13th of 14 runners.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Close to Trading for a Pitcher
description: After almost three months of plugging pitchers into a patchwork rotation while refusing to execute a trade, Yankees General Manager Bob Watson said today that he could make a deal for a "middle of the road" starter by Monday or Tuesday.

title: Going to the Movies in Bryant Park
description: John Waters said to me, 'You realize you're the only person in your family who'll talk about this,' " Patricia Hearst said the other day from her car phone. Ms. Hearst was referring to "Citizen Kane," Orson Welles's 1941 classic film, which is about her grandfather, the newspaper publisher William Randolph Hearst. "It's a very biting portrait," Ms. Hearst said of the movie, "but I adore it."

title: Jack Lacy, 79, Dies; WINS Disk Jockey
description: Jack Lacy, a New York radio personality and disk jockey who was heard on WINS-AM from the late 1940's through 1965, died on June 9 at San Juan de Dios Hospital in San Sebastian, Spain. He was 79 and had lived in San Sebastian since 1989.

title: 76,000 Still in Jail in Rwanda Awaiting Trial in '94 Slayings
description: Peter Bisetsa believes he can prove his innocence, if he can just get out of jail long enough to see a judge.

title: OLYMPICS;Might a Revival in Sports Programming Be Coming Up Next on CBS?
description: In 1990, CBS Sports looked astonishingly powerful. Between January and October, its "Dream Season" featured the Super Bowl, the Final Four, the National Basketball Association playoffs and the World Series.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Night at the Opera With Saki's Wicked, Exotic Tales
description: The American Chamber Opera Company's specialty is contemporary opera in English, and over the last dozen years the troupe has offered an impressively broad survey of the field, with a balance of works that have become standards and of premieres by newcomers. The company's current production, which runs through tomorrow at the Dicapo Theater (184 East 76th Street, Manhattan), is the world premiere of "Beast and Superbeast," a set of four short comic operas based on stories by Saki, with likable, eclectic scores by Jorge Martin and cleverly dramatized librettos by Andrew Joffe.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARILYN BERGMAN, the lyricist who teamed with her husband, Alan Bergman, on songs like "The Way We Were" and "The Windmills of Your Mind," has won three Academy Awards, three Emmy Awards and two Grammy Awards. But none has quite the personal resonance of the award she is to be given today from her alma mater, the La Guardia High School of Music, Art and the Performing Arts.

title: Democrats Urge Dismissal
description: Two leading Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Paul Simon of Illinois and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, suggested today that the White House dismiss its director of personnel security because of the growing furor over its acquisition of more than 400 sensitive F.B.I. background files.

title: Patents;Bringing a sweeter peach to market in a new system that suspends the ripening process.
description: TASTIER fruit that can be shipped greater distances is the goal of three professors of food science who have patented a system for that purpose.

title: Fixing the F.A.A.
description: When Transportation Secretary Federico Pena called for a new Federal Aviation Administration charter last week, he invoked the longstanding complaint that the F.A.A. has the dual, often conflicting missions of promoting air travel and regulating its safety. But he overlooked an important part of the problem -- his own office, which by law has the same dual missions.

title: Olympic Crime Fervor?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dole Trails Clinton in Poll
description: Bob Dole's numerous recent visits to New Jersey have not done much to boost his popularity in the state: the probable Republican presidential nominee trails Bill Clinton by 19 points, 53 percent to 34 percent, according to a Star-Ledger/Eagleton poll released yesterday. A third of the 646 voters surveyed last week, however, said they might change their minds before the election. (The poll, with a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points, also found that choosing Governor Whitman for a running mate would not help Mr. Dole in New Jersey: 47 percent of voters said it would make no difference to them, while 28 percent said it would actually make them more likely to vote for President Clinton.)

title: General Magic Is Planning to Introduce New Products for the Internet
description: General Magic Inc., which intended to reinvent computing but missed out on the rise of the Internet, plans to introduce several products on Tuesday that will refocus the company on the global computer network.

title: World News Briefs;Many Tributes as Tutu Leaves Archbishop Post
description: Kings, presidents and clergy celebrated Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and his struggle against apartheid at a service today that marked his retirement as head of the Anglican Church in South Africa.

title: Police Study a 1991 Death For Links to Sumitomo Case
description: The state police have reopened the investigation of the 1991 death of a Vermont copper trader to try to determine whether it had any connection with an international trading scandal that cost the Sumitomo Corporation $1.8 billion.

title: An Emerging Prominence For Blacks in Publishing;Authors Press for Change in Minority Hiring
description: Career day comes to the fifth-grade class of M. G. Rhodes Elementary school bringing youthful questions about the nation's capital of book publishing that are too painful for candor.

title: In America;From Sweatshops To Aerobics
description: In the late 1980's Nike Inc. launched a serious campaign to capture the women's athletic shoe market. Nike was already the world's largest and best-known footwear company. In 1989 its sales of men's athletic shoes, powered by the Michael Jordan endorsements, got another huge boost from the famous series of "Bo Knows" commercials, which featured the multi-sports prowess of Bo Jackson.

title: No Headline
description: There's a rogue elephant on the way from Texas that means business." BILL PRICE, who stirred anti-abortion sentiment among Texas Republicans. [B6:1.]

title: Shimonoseki Journal;Japan's Whalers Start to Take On a Hunted Look
description: Sitting uneasily in the ship's mess, the afternoon sunlight filtering through a porthole and dappling his curly brown hair, Yasuhisa Abe acknowledged that he has chosen an unlikely occupation for the 21st century.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Big Casts, No Plots and a Computer Calling the Steps
description: Merce Cunningham loves to put movements together in unusual ways. He used a computer to help him choreograph the three works that the Merce Cunningham Dance Company presented on Saturday night at Page Auditorium on the campus of Duke University here.

title: EZ-Pass Meets Its Match: Summer
description: Sunday night backups at the tollbooths of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge lost their novelty long ago. The travelers in those mile-long lines share a spiritual bond with the salmon that lunges toward its spawning ground and the lemming that flings itself into the sea.

title: When On-Line Service Cannot Be Counted On
description: Blame sunspots or planetary alignment, computer gremlins or human error. More than a million computer network users suffered interrupted or erratic Internet and on-line service connections last week because of a variety of planned and unplanned service shutdowns.

title: Pushing for a New F.A.A. Focus
description: When Congress created the Federal Aviation Administration almost 40 years ago, it wanted the agency to promote not only safety but also aviation itself, a combination that safety advocates say creates an impossible conflict. Now, in the wake of the crash of a Valujet airliner in May, the agency's critics have new ammunition and have put the agency on the defensive, and the Secretary of Transportation has proposed that the agency be allowed to drop its promotional responsibilities.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;For Atlantic City, a Boom
description: Not long ago, the conventional wisdom about Atlantic City was that it was doomed by the imminent arrival of state-licensed casinos in surrounding states -- Pennsylvania, Connecticut, New York. But today, the city is beginning its biggest expansion since gambling was legalized in 1978. Casino revenues have soared, hotel occupancy is up and the competition that seemed so threatening has retreated, leaving the field open for more than $4 billion worth of new casino and hotel projects. [Page A1.]

title: Editorial Notebook;Russia's Blood Feud
description: Almost lost in the Russian election results was the epilogue to one of the great political rivalries of our time. Boris Yeltsin finished first in a field of 10 candidates last week with 35 percent of the vote, Mikhail Gorbachev finished seventh with less than 1 percent.

title: 100 Years at The Times Evoked in 4 Exhibitions
description: Four exhibitions are to open this week at major cultural institutions in New York City in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the purchase of The New York Times by Adolph S. Ochs.

title: BOXING;Camacho Lets His Fists (and Mouth) Do a Lot of the Talking
description: Fighters will say whatever is good for their ego. So at 1 o'clock this morning, an excited -- hyper might be more accurate -- Hector (Macho) Camacho floated a rumor that an emissary from the welterweight champion Pernell Whitaker was in the building and offering $2 million for a bout.

title: Board Enacts Biggest Rent Rise Since '89
description: With enraged tenants moving toward the stage and screaming, "Shame! Shame!" the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night approved the largest rent increases in seven years for the city's one million rent-stabilized apartments -- a 5 percent increase for one-year leases that come up for renewal starting Oct. 1, and a 7 percent increase for two-year renewals.

title: Legislature Approves A Registry Of Pesticides
description: Both houses of the Legislature unanimously approved a bill today that would set up a registry to track the use of pesticides, acting after United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato exercised his considerable influence here to persuade Republican state senators to support the measure.

title: Bacteria Seen to Evolve in Spurts
description: ACCOMPLISHING a feat impossible with nearly any other living organism, researchers studying the fast-growing bacteria known as Escherichia coli have observed 3,000 generations of evolution, the kind of long-term change typically witnessed only by paleontologists. Studying these organisms, which can go through six generations in a single day, the researchers say they have found evidence to support one of the most controversial ideas ever to emerge from the earth's rocky fossil beds: the theory of punctuated equilibrium.

title: CNN and '60 Minutes' To Share Amanpour
description: In a highly unusual arrangement, two major international news organizations, CBS News and the Cable News Network, will share the reporting talents of Christiane Amanpour, they announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SARA LEE AGREES TO ACQUIRE LOVABLE ITALIANA
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, based in Chicago, said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Lovable Italiana S.p.A., an Italian maker of intimate apparel with annual sales of $115 million. The company did not disclose financial details of the deal. "The acquisition of Lovable Italiana is consistent with Sara Lee's plans to build its portfolio of intimate apparel brands, which currently includes Dim, Playtex, Bali and Wonderbra," said Donald Franceschini, executive vice president of personal-products businesses for Sara Lee. Sara Lee's products include Hanes, L'eggs, Bali, Champion and Playtex.

title: Mrs. Clinton Calls Sessions Intellectual, Not Spiritual
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton complained today of "sensational" reports of a New Age "spiritual adviser" ministering to her in White House sessions, saying the visitor was merely one of the thinkers with whom she has met to seek insight into American life.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICRION STOCK FALLS AFTER REQUEST TO DELAY ORDER
description: Shares of the Micrion Corporation fell 27 percent yesterday after it said one of its largest customers, the Read-Rite Corporation, had asked it to delay shipment of a $60 million order because of sluggish demand for computer disk drives. Micrion's stock, which was above $40 last month, fell $3.25, to $12, in Nasdaq trading. Micrion, based in Peabody, Mass., makes systems used by disk-drive makers to increase the speed and quality of their production. Read-Rite requested that shipment of two-thirds of the equipment, or $39.7 million worth, be delayed beyond the original 12-month period, David M. Hunter, Micrion's chief financial officer, said.

title: Mother of Elisa Izquierdo Pleads Guilty to Murder in a PivotalChild-Abuse Case
description: Prosecutors laid out the details of their charges in a clinical, 30-second presentation yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan: Awilda Lopez had badly beaten Elisa Izquierdo, her 6-year-old daughter, and then allowed her to lie, dying and unaided, for nearly two days. The judge, loudly and bluntly, then asked the only question left: "Ms. Lopez, is that what happened?"

title: ON BASEBALL;Yankees Must Beware Fate of the 1988 Mets
description: The Yankees are feeling good about themselves after their four-game sweep in Cleveland, and well they should. No one has beaten up on the Indians that way in the two years they have been the class of the American League. But the Yankees should accept the weekend for what it was -- four victories in four games -- and not try to project any significance to a possible post-season series between the teams.

title: Wildfire Disrupts Hiking in Grand Canyon
description: Firefighters tried today to contain forest fires in northern and eastern Arizona that had forced numerous evacuations and led officials to airlift 10 hikers out of the Grand Canyon on Sunday.

title: Decision Time for Gerry Adams
description: This month's bombing in Manchester, England -- presumed to be the work of the Irish Republican Army -- decisively changed the chemistry of the Northern Ireland peace effort. It demonstrated that the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, has failed to persuade militants in the I.R.A. to pursue their goals by talking rather than bombing. Mr. Adams risks making himself irrelevant by failing to speak out against the violence. The contention that his opposition would alienate the war wing of the I.R.A. is increasingly untenable.

title: BASKETBALL;Calipari Close to Hiring Nash as Nets' New G.M.
description: The waiting room is full, with each candidate for John Calipari's Nets staff listening for the word "next."

title: Inquiry Lacking Due Process
description: AS scientists absorb the decision by a Federal appeals panel late last week dismissing all the charges of scientific misconduct against Dr. Theresa Imanishi-Kari, many are asking how the process for handling allegations of fraud in science could have got so badly off track.

title: On My Mind;Ms. Maloney and Mr. Waldheim
description: For a full half-century, with determination and skill, and with the help of the law, U.S. intelligence agencies have kept secret the record of how they used Nazis for so many years after World War II, what the agencies got from these services -- and what they gave as payback.

title: It's Indians vs. Loggers in Nicaragua
description: On the official map of Nicaragua, the lands where the Sumo Indians dwell show up as a solid swath of rain forest interrupted by a few dots that seem to signal tentative human forays through the jungle.

title: Germany's Concerns Over Rights in Tibet Clash With Trade Ties to China
description: A diplomatic confrontation raising Bonn's worst fears of trade reprisals has broken out between Germany and China, leaving the Government here to face the same balancing of powerful economic interests against human rights concerns that confronts Washington.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Torme, 20 Years at Carnegie, Shows the Uses of Silence
description: Mel Torme spent his 20th annual concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night singing jazz standards. Mr. Torme, who was appearing as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, regularly changes groups and repertory, and not all are equally successful. Though he has a reputation as a jazz singer, it's not, finally, his strongest suit. At times he lapsed into a hipster's attitude that wasn't justified by his improvisations.

title: Russian Communists, in Retreat, Talk About an Opposition Role
description: Although the leaders of Russia's Communist Party still say they have a chance to win next week's presidential election, they have already begun to portray their candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, as a man who stands to gain as much in defeat as he would in victory.

title: POLITICS: THE CHURCHES;Public Supports Political Voice For Churches
description: In evidence of a striking change in Americans' attitudes about religion and politics, a majority of the public now believes that churches should be allowed to express political opinions, a reversal from what a majority believed a generation ago, according to a new nationwide survey of religious identity and political opinion.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Movie Tunes of Graceful Heartbreak
description: The jazz generation that immediately followed Wynton Marsalis has more or less been relegated to history, and the trumpeter Terence Blanchard's show at Town Hall on Friday was a reminder of how imposing some of their music has been. Mr. Blanchard, joined by his old bandmate the saxophonist Donald Harrison, turned in a set that blended harmonic ambiguity with rhythmic decisiveness; it was exploratory, and dedicated to a cool beauty.

title: The United Nations Can Be Reformed. Right?
description: To the Editor:

title: Virtual University Will Offer Authentic Degrees by E-Mail
description: Without so much as a ritual shovel to break the ground or a granite slab to mark the spot, the governors of 10 Western states today laid an intangible cornerstone for a new "virtual university" that they promised would soon allow students to take courses by computer and earn degrees on line.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Royal Ahold Sells Shares To Raise $1.8 Million
description: The Dutch grocery giant Royal Ahold N.V. said yesterday that it planned to raise $1.8 billion through the sale of 36 million shares to pay for its planned purchase of the Stop and Shop Companies, New England's largest grocery chain. Of the 36 million shares, 14 million are being offered in the United States. The new voting shares will be listed on the Amsterdam, Brussels and Zurich stock exchanges, with American depository receipts listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: G.M. Takes Option to Buy Rest of Saab; Sales Push Set
description: The General Motors Corporation, which owns half of Saab Automobile, announced today that it had obtained an option to buy the other half, and an executive said G.M. was aiming to elevate Saab to a spot alongside its Cadillac division in the worldwide luxury car market.

title: Philadelphia Held Liable For Firebomb Fatal to 11
description: In a case that has haunted Philadelphia for 11 years, a Federal jury yesterday found the city liable for the fire that, in ending an all-day standoff between the police and the radical group Move, killed 11 people, including 5 children, and left a city block in ashes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There's no mystery about what MARY HIGGINS CLARK will be doing in November: she is planning to be married around Thanksgiving to JOHN J. CONHEENEY, a retired chief executive of Merrill Lynch Futures.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Azon Supports Illinois Tool's Bid
description: Illinois Tool Works of Glenview, Ill., has offered $302.6 million (Australian), or $240 million (United States), for Azon Ltd., trumping a rival offer from Pacific BBA Industries Pty. Ltd.

title: Pulp Mill Legislation Raises No Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Access For New Drug
description: Patients with Lou Gehrig's disease got Government permission today to vie in a lottery for free doses of an experimental drug that promises to slow but not stop their relentless paralysis.

title: USA Waste to Merge With Sanifill in $1.3 Billion Deal
description: USA Waste Services Inc., the third-largest solid-waste removal company in the nation, said today that it had agreed to merge with Sanifill Inc., a big waste hauling and disposal concern, in a deal worth about $1.3 billion. USA Waste, which is based in Dallas, said it would offer shareholders of Sanifill, which is based in Houston, 1.7 shares of USA Waste for each common share of Sanifill, worth a total of about $1.3 billion, and also assume about $400 million in debt.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;To Get On the Road Again
description: Traditionally, folk and country musicians have performed songs rooted -- musically and lyrically -- in a specific place and landscape. But today's performing songwriters, who slip through the cracks of folk and country as well as rock and pop, also slip through the cracks of geography. Citizens of a shrinking, assimilating world that tends to encourage dislocation instead of the setting down of roots, their concepts of home and place are mutating and fragmenting.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Bidding for MGM Ends; Questions Remain
description: Though bids for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. were due yesterday at 11:30 A.M., it was not clear whether Polygram Holdings, considered a leading bidder, had actually put in an offer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The Interpublic Group continues its buying spree, this time with a deal to acquire Media Inc.
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies -- among the most active players in the deal fever sweeping the advertising world -- agreed yesterday to expand further into media services by buying Media Inc., an independent force in that field.

title: Metro Matters;Fund-Raisers With Clouds Of Mystery
description: CHERYL DeGEORGE does not know who paid her way to Bob Dole's fund-raising event at the Sheraton New York last night. Somebody with the Republican Party offered her a ticket worth $500, and the real estate agent from Little Neck said she was thrilled to accept it. Same for her friend Gloria Piekarski of Whitestone, an aide to a state senator, and for Sylvia Kinard, a state agency employee, and no doubt for many, many others.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;As Summit Talks Near, A Defense
description: A few days before a meeting of top leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations, a senior United States Treasury official defended their stewardship of the world economy yesterday, saying they had corrected exchange-rate misalignments, reduced currency volatility and promoted fiscal discipline, while strengthening the international monetary system against shocks.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Committees Approve Budget
description: A new $16 billion state budget was approved yesterday by the Assembly and Senate budget committees, clearing the way for passage by the Legislature later this week. Lawmakers restored almost $80 million in budget cuts proposed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, ranging from $7 million for state environmental programs to $600,000 to let historical sites stay open.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: USA Waste to Buy Sanifill for $1.2 Billion The consolidation in garbage hauling continued as USA Waste Services said it would merge with Sanifill in a deal worth $1.3 billion plus the assumption of debt. The new company, which will retain the USA Waste name, expects to have revenue of about $1.3 billion a year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTEGRATED HEALTH TO SELL PHARMACY UNIT
description: Integrated Health Services agreed yesterday to sell its pharmacy division, Symphony Pharmacy Services, to Capstone Pharmacy Services for $150 million -- $125 million in cash and $25 million in Capstone common shares. Symphony Pharmacy provides institutional pharmacy and consulting services to 40,000 residents in more than 380 long-term care facilities in eight states. Capstone's stock jumped $2, to $13.25; Integrated rose 75 cents, to $24.25.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Hurt in School Van Crash
description: Two students and a staff member from a residential school in Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., for children in the foster care system remained hospitalized at Hackensack University Medical Center yesterday from injuries received when the van transporting them to a basketball game flipped over in Teaneck Sunday night. The driver, Alex Shaw, 35, of Spring Valley, N.Y., had glass in his hands, and one student suffered a collapsed lung, said Thomas Webber, executive director of the Edwin Gould Academy. Mr. Shaw told the police he was headed east on Route 4 at 10 P.M. when he was cut off by another driver and forced off the road, said Capt. Edward Koeser of the Hackensack police.

title: In Search for Campaign Fuel, Dole and Clinton Cross Paths
description: Racing their way through hotel ballrooms across midtown Manhattan, Bob Dole and President Clinton came to New York in search of money last night, using the burst of attention that attended the dueling appearances to advance their candidacies and assault each other's credentials.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Deadlock in Officer's Trial
description: A mistrial was declared yesterday after jurors said they were unable to reach a verdict in the case of a Jersey City police officer accused of raping a 12-year-old girl he met on his beat. Edward DeFazio, First Assistant Prosecutor for Hudson County, said Officer Robert Cannon, 41, of Jersey City would be retried on charges of sexual assault and official misconduct. The jury deliberated two days before telling the court it was deadlocked.

title: ON BASKETBALL;Logged Off the Draft, Duncan Surfs the Web
description: I couldn't hear his voice, but I could feel his cyber-conviction.

title: The Chess Column
description: During the match between Anatoly Karpov and Gata Kamsky, the Tuesday chess column by Robert Byrne will not appear. The column will resume after the match. An analysis of yesterday's match game appears on page C17.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Is Sharp, But Effort Is Wasted
description: Andy Pettitte began loosening up his left arm 20 minutes before tonight's game by tossing a ball softly. Every pair of eyes affiliated with the Yankees focused on Pettitte because his inflamed elbow had been a serious concern. General Manager Bob Watson stood about five feet from the mound and a minor league pitcher, Mike Buddie, was also in the bullpen as an emergency replacement in case Pettitte's elbow bothered him.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Account Review For Subway Chain
description: The Subway Franchise Advertising Board, which oversees the advertising operations for the Subway chain of sandwich shops, said yesterday that it had begun a review of its account, which has been handled by Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago for four years. Billings were estimated at $85 million.

title: Nabisco to Eliminate 4,200 Jobs And Trim Product Line by 14%
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the maker of Oreos, Bubble Yum and other snack foods, said yesterday that it would discharge about 8 percent of its employees and eliminate nearly 14 percent of its products in an effort to trim operating costs by 2.5 percent.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Carjackers Attack Doctor
description: Three carjackers in ski masks burst into the garage of a cardiologist in the heavily wooded suburb of Watchung yesterday morning, shot him in the arm and drove off in his Jeep, prosecutors said. Dr. Michael Chen was leaving for work when the men rushed in and fired at him through the window of his car, said Melaine Campbell, the Acting Somerset County Prosecutor. They then forced Dr. Chen out of the vehicle and drove off in it, only to abandon it in a parking lot two miles away, Ms. Campbell said.

title: Apartheid's Dispossessed Seek Restitution
description: Keke Koalepe can still see where the dairy was, where his father's restaurant was, where his family lived in a small house with a tin roof and a porch in the front.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Banking on Family Issues, Clinton Seeks Parents' Votes
description: Holding hands, the First Couple strode onto the stage today under posters of a child's line drawing of a house. Holding hands, the Second Couple followed. Like the bus trips of 1992, it was a Clinton-Gore extravaganza, at the Gores' annual conference on family and work.

title: Radar Peeks at Structure Hidden Inside Tornado
description: THE terrifying sight of a twister funnel roaring down a highway and peeling off the asphalt pavement like so much dead skin is enough to send sensible drivers scurrying to safety.

title: MUSEUM REVIEW: 100 YEARS (1896 - 1996);Fossils of Early Man: The Finds and the News
description: MAYBE ours is just a species of narcissists, but the story of how human beings evolved has enduring appeal. The credit for piecing that story together ultimately belongs to the paleoanthropologists who have made that task their life's work. But acknowledgment is also owed to the reporters and writers who have helped make the parade of Neanderthals, Cro-Magnons, Peking Men, australopithecine "Lucy" and all the rest of our long-lost kin so familiar.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Curfew for Jersey City?
description: Jersey City may join several Hudson County communities that have enacted curfews for young people. City officials held the first of three hearings last night on a proposal that would bar youths 16 and under from city streets after 10:30 P.M. on weeknights and 11 P.M. on Friday and Saturday unless they are accompanied by an adult. But Tom DeGise, the City Council President, expressed skepticism about whether a curfew could be enforced. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Patterns
description: Dressing Up With Hugo Boss

title: Same Liquid Used in 2 Fires At Black Churches, U.S. Says
description: Federal investigators said today that the same flammable liquid was used in two arson fires last week that destroyed black churches in the tiny northeastern Mississippi town of Kossuth.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Prices Drop Sharply In Speculation Over Sumitomo
description: Copper prices fell sharply in London and New York yesterday on speculation that huge sales by the Sumitomo Corporation could swamp the market.

title: 36 Arrested in Extensive Video Piracy Ring
description: Saying they had uncovered the largest video piracy operation yet seen in the United States, officials in Manhattan yesterday announced the arrests of 36 people on charges of producing and distributing hundreds of thousands of videotapes of American first-run movies and Asian karate and pornographic films.

title: New Color Scheme, Mostly White, to Reduce the Cost of Painting Police Cars
description: With sirens blaring and tires burning, the Police Department's blue and white radio patrol cars have been a staple of television, the movies and the gritty world of real New York City life for 23 years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;AT&T in a Shift From N. W. Ayer
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had moved the creative portion of its 1-800-CALL-ATT account to another roster agency, the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group, from N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Clash After Kurds' Arrest Injures 80 in Turkey
description: The police arrested 30 leading Kurdish party officials at the end of a party convention on Sunday night and then battled pro-Kurdish protesters today in a confrontation that left 80 people injured.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SBC Warburg Rebuffed In Investment Firm Bid
description: Banque Nationale de Paris said yesterday that it had rejected an offer from SBC Warburg for its 83.9 percent stake in Compagnie d'Investissements de Paris, an investment company in which SBC Warburg has a minority stake, but Warburg said it would extend the offer until noon on Wednesday. On Friday SBC Warburg, a unit of the Swiss Bank Corporation, offered to buy the bank's stake for $798 million. SBC Warburg's bid came a month after Banque Nationale de Paris said it would buy out the minority shareholders of C.I.P. in a one-for-one stock swap of the bank's shares for C.I.P. shares. Warburg's bid was seen as an attempt to get Banque Nationale de Paris either to raise its own offer for C.I.P. or give up its holding altogether. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: The Shoe That Will Be on Every Woman's Foot
description: There's an ancient saying that you cannot put the same shoe on every foot. It sounds like a truism, but for fall a surprising number of designers are suggesting the same sort of shoe for many feet. It has a squared-off toe, a strap high up on the instep and a thick high heel.

title: Q&A
description: Doodlebugs

title: Let's Add 4 To the G-7
description: The Group of Seven industrial nations has to be reformed, or its annual summit meeting should be scrapped.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, the opening section of an article about the change in ownership of the Farberware factory in the Bronx was omitted from some New Jersey copies yesterday. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: An Innovative New AIDS Drug Wins Approval from the F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first in a new class of AIDS medicines today, clearing patients to start adding the drug, nevirapine, to their treatment combinations in August.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;4 Rockets Hit Israeli Zone In Lebanon; No One Hurt
description: Four Katyusha rockets apparently fired by Muslim guerrillas exploded today in Israel's occupation zone in southern Lebanon, pro-Israeli security sources said.

title: ART REVIEW;To Be Young and Smitten With Roman Light
description: Anytime between 1780 and 1825, if you were young and gifted, and if you could raise the fare, Rome was the most fun place to be.

title: By Design;The Little Summer Jacket
description: Where have all the gold buttons gone? As minimalism prevails, designers have stripped summer jackets of all trimmings, closing them with discreet zippers up the front (a trend that continues into fall). Most of the jackets are fitted and hipbone length.

title: Performing Seances? No, Just 'Pushing the Membrane of the Possible'
description: Although her views on altered states of consciousness and reincarnation would strike many Americans as outlandish, Jean Houston has instructed executives from such buttoned-down companies as Xerox, lectured at such sober universities as Harvard and worked with such mainstream figures as Margaret Mead.

title: Japanese Stocks Fall
description: Stocks were slightly lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed at 22,597.17, down 6.03 points, or 0.03 percent. On Monday, the index gained 72.55 points.

title: Farewell to 'the General'
description: Colleagues who worked with Louis J. Lefkowitz often addressed him as "the judge" or "the general." But most New Yorkers referred to Mr. Lefkowitz simply as Louie or even as "the people's lawyer," the term he used for himself in a less cynical era. Mr. Lefkowitz, who died last week at 91, served for 22 years as Attorney General of New York State, becoming one of the most popular and unbeatable politicians of modern times. Much more than that, he transformed that office into a place of forceful advocacy for consumers' rights, environmental protection and many other causes that grew in strength because of his legacy.

title: Microsoft Hires 2 Apple Software Writers
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had hired two key software designers from Apple Computer Inc. to work on its chief software products, adding to its roster of star computer scientists.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Foschi Is Banned By International Group
description: The Long Island swimmer JESSICA FOSCHI, who tested positive for steroids last summer and has had suspensions repeatedly imposed and overturned since then, was banned from competition for two years yesterday by the sport's international governing body.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Free Jazz for the Wild, Relentless or Calm
description: The Heineken "What Is Jazz?" Festival revels in diversity, even incoherence, but some programs this year also coalesce around definite themes. Sunday night at the Knitting Factory was skewed toward free jazz and the experimental tradition. (Every night, granted, has events matching that description.) The Charles Gayle Trio, a 10-piece Anthony Braxton ensemble and the trio of Roscoe Mitchell, Borah Bergman and Thomas Buckner presented conflicting reports on jazz's outer limits.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;True Love and That Other Kind
description: Easy," Solomon Burke kept saying to calm himself and his band on Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall as he sang the smooth love testimonials that earned him the nickname King of Rock and Soul in the 1960's. In his songs, he spoke of a monogamous, undying love, of a night that could last forever and a forever that could last a night.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;After 37 Years, A Pennzoil Review
description: The Pennzoil Products Company, the maker of motor oils, said yesterday that it had begun a review of its account after 37 years at Lois/EJL Advertising in Houston. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: A Woman Is Charged With Selling Babies
description: Federal agents working with Hungarian officials have charged a woman with bringing pregnant women to the United States from Hungary and selling their babies to adoptive parents for as much as $80,000 each.

title: ATLANTA 1996 -- BADMINTON IN INDONESIA;This Is No Picnic: In Southeast Asia, Respect Rides on a Shuttlecock
description: Nobody knows precisely how many Indonesians were lining the streets of this massive, sprawling city when Susi Susanti and Alan Budi Kusuma came home in August 1992. Some estimates put the crowd at 500,000; others at more than a million.

title: Market Place;McDonnell Douglas pays a fine for a 1990 earnings report.
description: IN 1990, McDonnell Douglas, the military contractor, was a company under pressure. Its share price was tumbling, and would bottom in early 1991 after losing more than two-thirds of its value from its 1989 peak. The Pentagon had canceled one major program, the A-12 Avenger jet for the Navy, forcing a big write-off.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The last time she accepted a pulpit, the Rev. Dr. SUZAN JOHNSON COOK transformed the Mariner's Temple Baptist Church in Chinatown from a congregation of 60 to one of 500.

title: Yes, Evaluate Evolutionary Psychology
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;WOOLWORTH TO SELL CHAIN OF LADY PLUS STORES
description: The Woolworth Corporation said it will sell the Lady Plus chain of women's large-size clothing stores to Popken Classics G.m.b.H. and Company as part of a plan to streamline its operations. Terms of the sale, expected to be completed by Aug. 1, were not disclosed. The 34-store chain is run by Woolworth's Retail Company of Germany subsidiary. Woolworth plans to focus on general merchandise stores in Germany. New York-based Woolworth is a general merchandise retailer, operating more than 8,200 stores worldwide including Foot Locker, Northern Reflections, After Thoughts and Champs Sports. Woolworth stock rose 25 cents to close at $22.

title: Elbert P. Tuttle, 98, Federal Appeals Judge Who Sought Racial Justice in South, Dies
description: Judge Elbert Parr Tuttle, who as Chief Judge of the old United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ordered the integration of the University of Georgia and played a pivotal role in extending civil rights to black Southerners in the 1950's and 60's, died on Sunday at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta. He was 98 and lived in Atlanta.

title: DANCE REVIEW
description: A Triple Cast in 'Don Quixote' Shuns Modesty for Prowess American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: BASEBALL;Kent's Bat, Ochoa's Strong Arm Spur Mets
description: Alex Ochoa made the play of the game. And Jason Isringhausen battled gamely. But it was Jeff Kent, the forgotten, and often unwanted, regular who made the most significant difference for the Mets last night.

title: Maser Journal;The Good Word: Creature Comforts for Catholics
description: For centuries, the people who built and decorated Roman Catholic churches paid little attention to comfort. A church was a place of worship and of beauty; it could be ornate or it could be austere, but the sore knees of the faithful were never taken into account.

title: INSIDE
description: From Bus to Subway, Free

title: Morgan Stanley And Merrill Set To Add Money Managers
description: The money management industry continued its rapid consolidation yesterday as Morgan Stanley confirmed it would pay $745 million to acquire Van Kampen American Capital Inc., a mutual fund company, and Merrill Lynch & Company agreed to pay $200 million to acquire Hotchkis & Wiley, an institutional money manager in Los Angeles.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Dear Miss Manners, Be Yourself. Not!
description: MISS MANNERS RESCUES CIVILIZATION From Sexual Harassment, Frivolous Lawsuits, Dissing and Other Lapses in Civility By Judith Martin Illustrated. 497 pages. Crown Publishers. $30.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Auchan Offers to Buy All of Docks de France
description: Auchan, a French retail-chain operator, offered yesterday to buy the shares in the chain Docks de France that it does not already own, a move that would propel it into third place among French hypermarket operators, behind Carrefour S.A. and Promodes S.A. The offer is worth 14.75 billion French francs ($2.9 billion). Auchan said it would pay 1,250 francs a share for 11.8 million Docks shares. The stock closed at 1,090 francs on Friday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;More Job Cuts Planned By Credit Lyonnais
description: Continuing a drive to reduce staff and increase productivity, the troubled French bank Credit Lyonnais said yesterday that it would shed more than 14 percent of its French work force between now and the end of 1998. The 5,000 job cuts would lower the state-controlled bank's payroll in France to 30,000. The bank had already said it planned to cut 5 percent of its work force a year in 1996 and 1997.

title: Sports of The Times;An Olympic Moment For the Apple
description: MAYOR Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered a compelling gambit. Last weekend he announced the formation of a committee to study the feasibility of making a bid to bring the 2008 Olympics to New York City.

title: Iraq Agrees to Ease Way for U.N. Monitors
description: In a move that officials here regard as a significant concession by President Saddam Hussein, Iraq has signed an agreement with the United Nations that is intended to speed the process of eliminating all Iraqi weapons of mass destruction so that economic sanctions can finally be lifted.

title: Justices to Hear Appeal by Clinton on Postponing Lawsuit
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether all proceedings in a sexual harassment suit against President Clinton should be delayed until he leaves office.

title: Nicholas D'Agostino Sr., 86, Founder of Grocery Chain
description: Nicholas D'Agostino Sr., a founder of one of New York City's largest and most innovative supermarket chains and supporter of charities in this country and his native Italy, died Sunday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., his son Nicholas D'Agostino Jr. said. He was 86.

title: Jacob's Pillow Is Opening, but a Trauma Lingers
description: Visitors returning to the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshires this summer won't notice the change. The white clapboard houses and weathered barns nestled in the overgrown remnants of an 18th-century farm are still home to myriad flora, fauna and lithe young bodies in leotards. The season, which officially begins June 25, will again mix the familiar and the exotic, everything from the Mark Morris Dance Group to Malavika Sarukkai performing Bharata Natyam, the classic dance of South India.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sumitomo to Rotate Traders To Reduce Their Influence
description: The Sumitomo Corporation said today that it would rotate its traders every few years to prevent them from acquiring too much influence over a particular sector of the market.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's deal to acquire the Infinity Broadcasting Company misidentified Infinity's founder. The company was founded in 1972 by its chairmen, Gerald Carrus and Michael A. Wiener. In 1981 Mel Karmazin joined Infinity as executive vice president, and he was named president in 1986; he was not a founder.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHYSICIANS CORPORATION SELLS FLORIDA DOCTORS UNIT
description: The Physicians Corporation of America, based in Miami, said yesterday that it had sold Physicians First Inc., a network that includes 125 doctors in 40 medical centers in Florida, to FPA Medical Management Inc. for $23 million. The agreement includes a long-term full-risk contract with FPA, based in San Diego, to manage the medical care of the Physicians Corporation members who use the centers, the company said. The network provides medical services to about 90,000 people, mainly enrolled in health maintenance organizations operated by the Physicians Corporation. Physicians said the sale would add about $7.5 million to its second-quarter earnings.

title: Dolphin Safety Stirs New Storm
description: Felipe M. Charat, a Mexican tuna boat operator, recalls the Congressional hearing in Washington eight years ago at which an environmental group projected horrifying video pictures of the slaughter of hundreds of dolphins snared in the nets of a tuna boat.

title: Fortress Yields Clues To Israel's Ancient Foe
description: THE familiar biblical story of sibling rivalry, foreshadowing strife in the Middle East then and to this day, began when the pregnant Rebecca, wife of Isaac, was told by the Lord:

title: U.N. Says That Serbs Renewed Expulsions
description: The United Nations refugee agency accused Serbs today of resuming expulsions of Muslims, while NATO's commander in Bosnia criticized all parties for violations of peace accords.

title: Advanced Television Isn't Out of Woods Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Settles Passes Up Draft
description: JESS SETTLES, a first-team All-Big Ten selection last season, said yesterday he will withdraw his name from tomorrow's National Basketball Association draft and return to the University of Iowa for his senior year. The 6-foot-7-inch, 220-pound forward averaged 15.1 points and 7.5 rebounds a game for the Hawkeyes. (AP)

title: The Fraud Case That Evaporated
description: The most notorious fraud case in recent scientific history has collapsed in embarrassment for the Federal Government and belated vindication for the accused scientist. For most of the past decade investigators in the Department of Health and Human Services and in Congress have pursued a Tufts University scientist, Dr. Thereza Imanishi-Kari, on charges of falsifying laboratory data. The Federal Office of Scientific Integrity concluded five years ago that Dr. Imanishi-Kari fabricated data published in a 1986 journal article and, when challenged, made up more data to support her position.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Publisher to Buy Magazine Group
description: American City Business Journals Inc. said today that it would acquire Citymedia Inc., increasing its nationwide circulation by more than 27 percent.

title: U.S. Limits Law Intended to Fight School Corruption
description: The Justice Department last night put strict limits on a new law designed to help Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew fight corruption on local school boards, saying the Chancellor would have to seek its approval each time he sought to bar winners of board elections from taking their seats.

title: BASKETBALL;Ex-Big East Players Share Tourney Lead
description: Ken Dardis and Dave Kent, former Big East players, shared the first-round lead today at two-under-par 70 in the Met Life/Met Golf Association Ike Championship at the Metedeconk National Golf Club.

title: G.M.'s Labor Costs for Parts Exceed Rivals', Study Says
description: The General Motors Corporation's labor costs for auto parts are $440 higher a vehicle than the Ford Motor Company's costs and $600 higher a vehicle than the Chrysler Corporation's because G.M. buys fewer parts from low-cost outside suppliers, according to a study issued here today.

title: Giuliani Plans to Scrutinize Four Wholesale Markets
description: The Giuliani administration, which last year won new authority to crack down on suspected corruption and Mafia influence at the Fulton Fish Market, is planning to impose the same strict rules on New York City's four other major wholesale produce and meat markets, a top mayoral aide said yesterday.

title: The United Nations Can Be Reformed. Right?;Virtual Fiefs
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Warm Up for a Vote On the Campaign Finance Bill
description: Senators warmed up today for a critical vote on Tuesday on campaign finance legislation by arguing about whether the bill would lead the public to trust the political system again or whether it would suppress free political speech.

title: Chain Bookstores Stock Only What Will Sell
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Broadcasters Cleared to Send Digital Data
description: Television stations can begin using their standard video signals to send digital newspapers, computer software and other data to viewers under rules adopted today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League

title: Garbage Hauling Is Tied to Mafia in Suburbs
description: Federal prosecutors charged yesterday that a Mafia-controlled cartel used arson, bribery and violence to dominate the garbage hauling industry in the suburbs north and west of New York City, allowing companies to "grossly inflate" the price of garbage collection for tens of thousands of businesses and homeowners.

title: Baptists Are Invited To Holocaust Reckoning
description: To the Editor:

title: Lehman Brothers Names New Equities Chief
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. named Joseph Gregory yesterday to head its equities business as the firm, traditionally focused on its debt business, expands its stock underwriting, sales and trading businesses.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BARRETT RESOURCES CORP., Denver, an oil and gas exploration concern, plans to acquire natural gas, oil reserves and pipeline assets in Colorado's Piceance Basin for about $38.5 million in stock. The name of the party selling the assets was not disclosed.

title: TENNIS;That Was Quick: Agassi, Chang and Courier Fall
description: The lawns at Wimbledon were so plush, pristine and perilous today that no fewer than three highly seeded American men skidded out of contention in the opening round, a development that left Pete Sampras, the defending champion, the lone survivor from what had seemed a veritable army of high-profile statesiders.

title: BASEBALL;Howe Arrested at Airport on Gun Charge
description: Two days after Steve Howe was released by the Yankees, the controversial pitcher was arrested today at Kennedy Airport in New York for carrying a loaded .357 Magnum pistol in his luggage, the Port Authority police said.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Somalia Battle Escalates As Toll Rises on 4th Day
description: Artillery shells and missiles pounded positions of rival Somali factions today as this capital struggled through the fourth straight day of heavy fighting that has left 11 people dead and 37 wounded.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Kentucky Democrats Predict A Senate Victory

title: COMPANY NEWS;ISOLYSER AND MICROTEK MEDICAL RENEGOTIATE DEAL
description: The Isolyser Company said yesterday that it had renegotiated its $106.5 million acquisition of Microtek Medical Inc. to guarantee that Microtek shareholders receive Isolyser stock worth $16.50 a share. The deal includes the assumption of $19 million in debt. The companies said the ratio of Isolyser shares to be given to Microtek shareholders was changed because the value of Isolyser stock had fallen about 37 percent since the agreement was announced on March 18. The earlier deal between the medical supply companies said that Microtek could halt the sale if Isolyser's average trading price fell below $13. Isolyser stock rose 68.75 cents to close at $11.6875, and Microtek rose $2.25, to $15.

title: POP REVIEW;A Brazilian Mix: The Home Grown, Rock and Hip-Hop
description: Brazilian music has a new hotbed: Recife, in Pernambuco. On Saturday night, Pernambuco came to the Prospect Park Band Shell in a Celebrate Brooklyn concert that was part of the Brazilian Music Festival. The triple bill included a traditional forro group, Banda do Pifanos, and two leading Recife rock bands: Chico Science e Nacao Zumbi, and Mundo Livre S.A.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TCI Reaches Deal With Fox To Carry All-News Channel
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, completed a deal yesterday to carry Fox's planned 24-hour news cable channel in 10 million homes when the channel starts up this fall.

title: Iraq to Return Iranian Dead
description: Iraq has told Iran that it will return the remains of 144 Iranians killed during their 1980-88 war, the Iraqi News Agency said today.

title: The Twilight Zone of Kids' TV
description: Imagine this children's TV schedule: On Saturday morning, "Disney's Imagination Theater" airs on ABC; "Jim Henson's Reading Explorations" is on for a half-hour every day on CBS; "Math Detectives" is on NBC three times a week. And a cash-rich Public Broadcasting Service fills its daytime hours with original educational fare.

title: Astronauts Are Wired To Study Sleep Ills
description: Four of the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia are sleeping in wired nightcaps so researchers can learn more about insomnia both in space and on Earth.

title: Former Chief of Lotus Joins On-Line Venture With AT&T
description: After struggling unsuccessfully to produce new on-line information services aimed at businesses, AT&T said yesterday that it would turn the task over to Jim P. Manzi, the former chief executive of the Lotus Development Corporation. He had left that company last fall to join Industry.Net, which specializes in matching buyers and sellers of industrial equipment on the Internet.

title: Ex-Football Star Is Buying Parks Sausages
description: A company owned by Franco Harris, the former Pittsburgh Steelers star, has agreed to buy H. G. Parks Inc., the maker of Parks Sausages and the first black-owned business in the country to go public, for $2 million in cash.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: No Headline
description: There are cycles in this country that are almost unavoidable, I admit that, and we have taken a beating in the last year or so. NEWT GINGRICH, the House Speaker, describing why Republicans are down in the public opinion polls. [A18:4.]

title: In Times Square, Keepers of the Glitz;3 Women Overseeing Block's Rebirth Promise to Return Its Splendor
description: Not long ago, Gretchen Dykstra took a phone call from a merchant looking for business space. The merchant was no Michael Eisner or Richard Branson; he represented a small, very small, business. But Ms. Dykstra, the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, was enthusiastic about his proposal.

title: Panel Chairman Demands White House Security Records
description: The House Republican who is leading an investigation into the White House's handling of F.B.I. files today demanded a broad array of records about the White House security office that obtained the files.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHTING

title: COMPANY NEWS;ENERGY VENTURES TO BUY TUBULAR IN A $47 MILLION DEAL
description: Energy Ventures Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Tubular Corporation of America for about $47 million in stock, cash, notes and assumed debt. Tubular is a manufacturer of casings used in oil and gas exploration and development. Energy Ventures agreed to pay 500,000 shares and about $30 million in cash, notes and assumed debt. Energy Ventures shares fell 12.5 cents, to $33.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Energy Ventures, based in Houston, also plans to buy two drilling barge rigs from the Noble Drilling Corporation, which will be part of its Mallard Drilling rig contracting unit, for $32 million.

title: Trying to Save Friend, Teen-Ager on Field Trip Drowns in Motel Pool
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn student on a science field trip drowned in a Philadelphia motel pool Saturday evening, leaving many questions and conflicting reports, even two days later, about whether he and other students had been properly supervised by the adults who accompanied them.

title: Rock Slide Kills a Tourist
description: A rock slide on Sunday crushed a car in Glacier National Park, killing a Japanese tourist who was driving and injuring his sister.

title: Ex-Intel Engineer Sentenced to Prison Term
description: An engineer who stole information about the Pentium computer chip from the Intel Corporation was sentenced to 33 months in Federal prison today.

title: Observer;Itching for a File
description: The White House should not have asked for those F.B.I files. The F.B.I should not have given those F.B.I. files to the White House.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices End Day Flat
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday as market participants braced for new supply this week and a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers next week.

title: As a Pampered Generation Grows Up, Chinese Worry
description: It was just another school day for Liu Huamin when the father of one of her students burst through the classroom door and said his teen-age son was threatening to commit suicide by jumping off the fourth-floor balcony of the family's apartment building.

title: M.T.A. Planning Free Transfers Between Subways and Buses
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to allow free transfers between subways and buses throughout New York City beginning next year, officials said yesterday, in what promises to be the biggest change in transit service since the three separate subway systems were united in 1940.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the effect of the EZ-Pass electronic toll system on traffic at the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge misstated the approximate overall cost of the sys tem. According to Josh Taylor, a spokesman for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, it is $50 million, not $500 million.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Kidd Forces a Decision
description: If JASON KIDD thinks he can push around the Dallas Mavericks' new front office, the team's minority owner says, the star point guard had better think again.

title: Missing Records Found in Welfare Case
description: The Giuliani administration said last night that it had finally found a copy of missing records from the appointment calendar of an administration official -- records that mayoral aides said over the weekend had been inadvertently deleted from a computer file.

title: Coming Soon: The Personal Fire Hydrant
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;Gingrich, in Interview, Concedes Mistakes, but Says G.O.P. Trend Is Intact
description: Unlike Bob Dole, Newt Gingrich has not had a Capitol balcony named for him yet, but one comes with the Speaker's office, and he sat there in the late-afternoon sun one day last week, coat off, shirt sleeves rolled up, reflecting on the roller-coaster ride his political fortunes have taken in the 18 months since the Republicans seized control of Congress.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Fortay and Miami Settle
description: BRYAN FORTAY, who sued the University of Miami over what he claims were broken promises to make him the starting quarterback, settled with the school yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Clash Over Sex Crime Law
description: A decision by the United States Supreme Court yesterday supports the constitutionality of "Megan's Law," lawyers for the State Attorney General's office argued in Federal court. The Supreme Court ruled that the Government can prosecute people for crimes and seize their property at the same time. The decision overturned rulings that said requiring a convicted drug dealer to give up property amounted to punishing someone twice for the same crime. In April, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit relied on those rulings when it issued guidelines for judges to use to decide if notifying a community of the whereabouts of a paroled sex offender was unconstitutional.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXAS JUDGE OVERTURNS VERDICT AGAINST FLEMING
description: The Fleming Companies will get a new trial in a case brought by a former customer, David's Supermarkets Inc., after a Texas judge threw out a $211.2 million verdict in which a jury found that Fleming violated a supply contract that limited its markup on goods. Judge C. W. Duncan Jr. ruled that Fleming, a grocery distributor based in Oklahoma City, was entitled to a new trial because the judge that conducted the case earlier this year failed to disclose that David's majority owner, David Waldrip, had once loaned him about $3,000. "It's a result we thought was warranted," Fleming's general counsel, David Almond, said. An attorney for David's predicted that the company would win the second jury trial.

title: N.A.S.D. Hires S.E.C. Lawyer
description: The chief litigation counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission was named today to head the reorganized enforcement department at the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS TO CUT JOBS AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. said yesterday that it would close three plants and dismiss 220 employees, resulting in a pretax charge of $50 million in the second quarter. The New York-based company also said earnings would be hurt by slower customer reorders for fragrances in Europe and the United States and price cuts forced by competition. The company said it would close factories in Union Beach, N.J.; Mexico City, and Rio de Janeiro. Most of the job cuts will occur at the New Jersey facility, which will cut 170 jobs. Shares of International Flavors fell $1.75, to $49, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Scanners: Closer but Not Perfect
description: TRANSFORMING words on paper to words in computer files keeps getting more ambitious and more accurate without quite achieving perfection.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Aerospatiale and Dassault Close to Merger Agreement
description: Two French arms industry giants, the Government-owned Aerospatiale and the privately held Dassault Aviation, are close to a merger, Defense Minister Charles Millon said today.

title: BASEBALL;Johnson Just Hits Like No One Else
description: He is bidding to become the first player in major league history to lead both the National League and American League in hits. He will almost certainly become the third player to lead both leagues in triples.

title: Flocks of Biologists Take Wing to Michigan for Mating Season
description: BENEATH a brilliant three-quarter moon in a grove of quaking aspen five miles south of Lake Superior, William L. Robinson, a professor of biology, was in search of the woodcock.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Radio Broadcasters Shift Stations in 2 Deals
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the radio broadcaster Commodore Media Inc. for $200 million in debt and equity.

title: Speaker Insists on Hearings On Bill to Lift Insurance Rules
description: The Speaker of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, said today that he would block passage of a bill advocated by the life insurance industry that would change a decades-old consumer-protection statute.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Crash Report Is Delayed
description: At the request of the National Transportation Safety Board, New Jersey Transit will not release an internal report on a fatal collision of two commuter trains today as it had planned, officials said. Both agencies have been investigating the Feb. 9 crash that killed two engineers and a passenger and injured 162. Investigators say a missed stop signal and engineer fatigue may have led to the crash near the Secaucus-Jersey City border.

title: OLYMPICS;American Team Looks Ready to Sprint Back to the Top
description: At the Olympic track and field trials, the United States found a transcendent star in Michael Johnson, reasserted itself in the sprints and gave an indication that, like the heat, the gold medal count may be on the rise next month at the Summer Games.

title: Baptists Are Invited To Holocaust Reckoning
description: To the Editor:
