title: Daytona Beach Journal;'Birthplace of Speed' Has Adversary: Yes, a Turtle
description: In this city famous for fast cars and wide beaches, driving on the hard-packed sand is about as old as the automobile itself. The allure is not just the convenience, swimsuit-clad drivers explain, but also the tradition -- of slow cruising along miles of surf, of tailgate parties by the dunes, of sunbathing in the back of a pickup truck.

title: DANCE REVIEW
description: Classical and Modern, With a Potpourri of Music Anna Myer and Dancers St. Mark's Church

title: DANCE REVIEW
description: A Romp for Eight Youngsters Who Soar in the Night Breezes New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: TV SPORTS;Taking Sport to the Extreme: When Error Can Cost a Life
description: As he watched his friend and sky-surfing partner, Rob Harris, drop to his death from 3,000 feet above British Columbia, Joe Jennings wondered if what he saw was real, if their extraordinary sports "marriage" would end this way, shooting a Mountain Dew commercial.

title: POLITICS: THE BELIEFS;Survey Finds Wide Variation in the Intensity of Faith
description: Despite all the secular influences on their lives, from Hollywood movies to Madison Avenue advertising, the American people remain strongly religious. But a new nationwide survey shows that the intensity of their beliefs varies considerably among different religious groups.

title: PERIPHERALS;Instant Web Page, Easily
description: YOU want to, or have to, build a Web page. You simply must let 20 million people know about your pet peeves, your favorite movies, your home-brewed beer. Or you need to put your real estate office on the Web because your boss thinks it will help business, although neither of you can imagine just how it will help business.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;JUSTICES UPHOLD CIVIL FORFEITURE AS ANTI-DRUG TOOL
description: In a major victory for Federal prosecutors, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Government can both prosecute someone for a crime and seize his property through civil forfeiture without violating the constitutional bar against double jeopardy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIANA CONSIDERS ITS OPTIONS FOR A REORGANIZATION
description: The Diana Corporation has hired an undisclosed investment banker to help it consider a reorganization that could include the spinoff of operating units, the company said yesterday. Diana said its board would consider alternatives that involve separating units by industry, into independent public companies. Diana makes central office telecommunications equipment and distributes meat products. The company's stock fell $1.75, to $56.25. The stock was worth less than $6 a share a year ago and more than $120 a month ago. The New York Stock Exchange is reportedly investigating unusual trading in its shares.

title: Gasoline Prices Fall
description: Prices at the nation's gasoline pumps fell by more than a penny a gallon in the last two weeks, according to the Lundberg Survey of prices at 10,000 gas stations. The average price for all grades, including taxes, was $1.35 a gallon on Friday. Prices rose by 21 cents this year before peaking at just over $1.38 a gallon in the Lundberg survey of May 24.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Teen-Agers Scavenging For a Vestige of Hope
description: This is the relatively slow time of year when prime time makes room among its overwhelmingly middle-class images to slip in a glimpse of the nation's poor and often troubled youth, the kind who do not fit easily into television's preferred happy endings.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin's Trial to Begin
description: MICHAEL IRVIN, the All-Pro wide receiver of the Dallas Cowboys, must stand trial on drug charges, a judge ruled yesterday in rejecting several motions to have evidence suppressed and the indictment thrown out.

title: Is the U.S. Souring on Free Trade?
description: Ian W. Delaney, chairman of the Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian metals company with mining interests in Cuba, has just been warned by the State Department that he, his wife and his children may never be allowed to enter the United States again.

title: Bosnia's Muslim Refugees Find a Dilemma in Election
description: As a former salesman in what was once Yugoslavia, Ramiz Mehinovic knows the flavor of a bad deal. And, he says, he is coming to taste it again in the preparations for elections in his native Bosnia.

title: A Tenacious Kamsky Goes All-Out and Wins
description: After a drought of four games in which Gata Kamsky made only one draw against three losses, he came out fighting yesterday and defeated Anatoly Karpov decisively in Game 10 of their world championship match in Elista, Russia.

title: Minister, Jailed 10 Years, Gets New Appeal in an Abuse Case
description: A Methodist minister who has been in prison for a decade after being convicted of sexually abusing children at a Bronx day-care center was granted a new appeal yesterday by a Federal judge.

title: Narrowing Prisoners' Rights
description: A Supreme Court majority eager to roll back the rights of prisoners seized upon an Arizona case yesterday to narrow inmates' access to the court system. The decision is a retreat from precedent and the principles of fairness.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Coyote Hunting Is Allowed
description: Defying advocates for animal rights, the State Fish and Game Council voted last night to allow a coyote hunting season in New Jersey for the first time next winter, from Feb. 1 to Feb. 17.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TOKHEIM TO ACQUIRE GAS-STATION BUSINESS OF SOFITAM
description: The Tokheim Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the gas-station business of Sofitam International for $108 million. Tokheim, based in Fort Wayne, Ind., makes gas-station equipment, including pumps and credit-card transactions systems in North America, Europe and Africa. The company said the acquisition would strengthen its position in southern and northern Europe and Africa. Sofitam, which is based in Paris, is owned by Compagnie Generale des Eaux, a French municipal services, telecommunications and construction company.

title: TV Notes;News Chief Renewed
description: Happy with NBC News's output under Andrew Lack's leadership as president of the division, NBC has torn up his contract and given Mr. Lack a new one, good through the year 2002.

title: Company May Run Coney Island Hospital
description: Intent on finding private operators for the public hospitals that serve many of New York City's poorest residents, city officials plan to turn over Coney Island Hospital to a for-profit health care company, people familiar with the negotiations said last night.

title: Bring Emmanuel Constant to Trial
description: The United States has set back the cause of democracy and justice in Haiti by freeing Emmanuel Constant from an American jail and postponing deportation proceedings against him. Mr. Constant headed Haiti's most violent paramilitary group during the recent military dictatorship there, and the current democratic Government wants to try him for his alleged role in supervising scores of murders, rapes and cases of torture.

title: A Voice With Heart
description: When Mel Allen, the Voice of the Yankees, died last week at 83, I lost the man who ranked second only to my father for the sheer volume of attention during my childhood. (My dad, by the way, was a Dodger fan and Red Barber devotee.)

title: Competition Heats Up for Athletic Sites on Internet
description: As a free agent, the basketball star Shaquille O'Neal may or may not play for the Orlando Magic next year. It will cost the Florida team millions to sign him, rival teams millions to woo him away -- and the summertime negotiations are just under way.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Turnpike to Build Billboards
description: Until now, only private companies have made money from billboards visible from the New Jersey Turnpike, but not built on its property. Now, the Turnpike Authority wants in, and yesterday its board voted to erect billboards on toll road property for the first time.

title: OVER COFFEE WITH: David and Peter Turnley;Double Exposures in Parallel Lives: The Other Side of the Lens
description: IT was 1988 during the intifada, or uprising, in the Israeli-occupied territories. Tempers were short. The police officer who stuck his head into David Turnley's car was in no mood for pleasantries.

title: POLITICS: AIR TIME;Dole Campaign Would Accept Free TV Time for Short Speeches
description: A campaign to secure free broadcast television time for Presidential candidates received a boost this week when the Dole campaign said it would accept, with conditions, a new proposal that the candidates produce brief speeches for broadcast in the four weeks before the election.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Consumers Feel Less Confident, Survey Shows
description: Consumers felt markedly less confident about the economy this month, displaying a pessimism that could herald a slowdown in economic growth during the second half of the year, the Conference Board's monthly sampling of households showed today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Western Resources Plans A Hostile Bid for Utility Kansas City Power and Light rejected a sweetened takeover bid of $1.9 billion from Western Resources, and the spurned utility immediately countered that it would take its $31-a-share bid directly to Kansas City Power shareholders.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Invoking The Mystery Of Flight
description: There were some visually compelling moments in "The Captain's Nest," a dance by Leah Gillman for five acrobatic dancers and six gymnasts' balancing beams of varying lengths and heights. But such moments were few -- and in general, imagination was in short supply -- in "Double Take," a program of dance presented by the Next Stage Company on Sunday afternoon at the Next Stage.

title: Village Tosses Hat Into Rink For the Olympics;Lake Placid Would Savor The Glory of the Games Again, in Winter of 2022
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may have believed he was thinking far ahead. Even before the Olympic torch had reached Atlanta for this year's Games, he was considering a bid by New York City as host of the Olympics in 2008.

title: Market Place;The Growth, and Pain, of America Online
description: America Online, one of the big success stories in cyberspace, has certainly suffered some embarrassing setbacks lately. But are these growing pains or signs of a troubled company?

title: Building a Bumpy Road
description: Though townspeople may disagree, a company that does consumer reviews of new cars has a problem with local thoroughfares: they are too smooth.

title: Surprising Many, TB Is Found To Be Rampant in South Africa
description: Releasing a set of findings that surprised even the doctors issuing them, the World Health Organization and a team of international experts said today that South Africa has the worst tuberculosis problem in the world, and that drug-resistant forms of the disease are spreading rapidly.

title: Speaker Kills Bill to Weaken Anti-Smoking Law
description: The Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, said today that he was killing a bill that could have helped the tobacco and restaurant industries overturn tough restrictions on smoking in restaurants in New York City.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about a court ruling on conditions at the Southbury Training School in Connecticut misstated the date of the photograph. It was last year, not last week; the man shown, Richard Messier, moved out of the school in December. The caption also misstated his age; he is 52, not 50.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nycomed of Norway Sees '96 Profit Drop
description: Shares in Nycomed, a Norwegian pharmaceutical company, dropped more than 20 percent yesterday after the company warned that its profit might fall more than 30 percent in 1996. This year's earnings per share "will be closer" to 1994's 7.55 kroner ($1.16) than 1995's 11.20 kroner, Nycomed said. That is as much as 43 percent below analysts' average expectations of a 13.27 kroner profit, according to a survey by IBES International.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO AGREES TO PAY MORE FOR PULLMAN
description: Tenneco Inc. yesterday agreed to amend its merger agreement with the Pullman Company, increasing the price it would pay to $328 million from $300 million. Tenneco announced the original deal for Pullman, which was once known for its railroad coaches and is now a privately held maker of automotive suspensions and other parts, on Monday. Pullman, based in Lebanon, N.J., said its shareholders would now receive about $16 for each Pullman share, up from $13.50. In exchange, Pullman agreed to delete provisions of the original agreement allowing it to terminate the deal if it received superior proposals.

title: Repeated Lapses With Nuclear Weapons Raise Questions of Safety
description: In a cluster of oddly shaped industrial buildings rising from the wheat fields east of this city, behind strands of razor wire, guards with AR-15 military-style rifles and security devices that officials will not discuss, some 300 technicians are fulfilling the nation's commitment to dismantle thousands of nuclear weapons.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES CONLON does not take over as principal conductor of the Paris Opera until Aug. 1, but the French Government could not wait to give him one of its highest honors for cultural achievement.

title: Lockheed Will Shut A California Plant
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation will close its plant in Ontario, Calif., within two years, dismissing 500 employees, the company said today.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Get Mad, Then They Get Even With Twins
description: Bernie Williams spiked a helmet after lining out with the bases loaded, Wade Boggs flipped his trusty bat like a Frisbee after stranding two more runners and Manager Joe Torre was so incensed with one vociferous umpire that he refused to speak to him. The images provided snapshots of how the Yankees dripped with frustration.

title: Contempt Vote Avoided
description: The White House held off a contempt-of-Congress vote today by agreeing to let some House members view 2,000 pages of documents concerning the travel office firings.

title: Israelis Mustn't Let Orthodoxy Dictate
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Trobe Is Dead at 82; Helped Resettle War Refugees
description: Harold Trobe, a key figure in efforts to rescue and resettle hundreds of thousands of Jewish refugees from war-ravaged Europe, died on Monday at his home in Gainesville, Fla., where he had retired in 1980. He was 82.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Increase New York City Prices Debt Offering
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday after reports suggested that economic growth would soon slow, allowing the Federal Reserve to delay an expected increase in short-term interest rates. Strong demand at a Treasury auction of new two-year notes eased concerns about supply, further bolstering the market.

title: Meredith Monk Wins a Dance Festival Award
description: Meredith Monk, a multimedia artist who is a choreographer, dancer, composer, singer and film maker, received the 1996 Samuel H. Scripps/American Dance Festival Award on Monday night at Page Auditorium on the campus of Duke University here. The award of $25,000 was established by the philanthropist Samuel H. Scripps in 1981 to honor sustained achievement in modern dance.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BERG ELECTRONICS CORP., St. Louis, which manufactures electronic connectors and cable assembly products, agreed to buy the electronic connector business of L.M. Ericsson Telephone Co. of Sweden for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: BASEBALL;Jones Battles to Victory With the Rockies' Help
description: Bobby Jones said it was "reassuring" that the two home runs he allowed last night didn't cause more damage, and "reassuring" when Vinny Castilla's potentially tying rocket to center field bounced over the wall for what turned out to be a harmless ground-rule double.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton Calls for Amendment Guaranteeing Victims' Rights
description: Saying the justice system too often ignores the victims of crime -- "millions and millions of people who are completely innocent" -- President Clinton today called for a constitutional amendment to give victims a larger role in proceedings against the people accused of harming them. It was the first time in his Presidency he has supported an effort to change the Constitution.

title: City Council Proposes Term Limit Of 12 Years
description: Ever since voters overwhelmingly approved term limits in 1993, the leaders of the City Council have tried to find a way to evade the inevitable.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Wider Currency Choice In World Bank Loans
description: The World Bank said yesterday that it was changing its lending program and widen the choice of currencies in which countries borrow.

title: To Pray in a Tibetan Temple, Buddhists Built One in California
description: For years when Judith Leeper drove a back road near here, she was mystified by glimpses, first, of copper domes and pagoda-like structures shining through the trees, then of a towering golden monument that glimmered in the California sun.

title: Good for Financial Market, Bad for Workers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Emotional Ills Tied to Stunted Growth in Girls
description: ADDING to the accumulation of evidence of a connection between the mind and physical health, a large study has found a link between emotional problems in girls and stunted growth.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vote Set on Artists' Zoning
description: Is Jersey City ready to assume the role that SoHo occupied in the 1970's, when artists first began installing themselves in abandoned industrial buildings? The City Council is scheduled to vote tonight on a zoning amendment that would allow artists to live in a neighborhood of aging warehouses where many already maintain their studios.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Another Suspension at Miami
description: RICKY PERRY, a 23-year-old University of Miami offensive tackle who was arrested on felony gun charges in November and accused of punching his date last week, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Coach BUTCH DAVIS. The disciplinary action follows the suspensions last week of three other Hurricane players involved in the assault of a track athlete. Athletic Director PAUL DEE said the school just became aware of Perry's November arrest. The case surfaced after the 6-foot-7-inch, 330-pound Perry was arrested Friday. He was charged with hitting his 17-year-old date in the face as well as battery and burglary. (AP)

title: Food Notes
description: Here Come the Doughnuts!

title: Stocks Advance in Tokyo
description: Stocks were higher in Tokyo today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 69.63 points, or more than three-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,666.80. On Tuesday the Nikkei fell 6.03 points.

title: Officer Is Charged in Killing of Her Boyfriend
description: A police officer was indicted on murder charges today in the shooting of her boyfriend, who was also a Jersey City police officer, during a quarrel last September.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;J Sky B Satellite Planned for Japan
description: The Softbank Corporation and the News Corporation said yesterday that the focus of their recently announced joint venture would be digital satellite broadcasting in Japan. Softbank's president, Masayoshi Son, said that the venture would probably be called J Sky B, the name for a 100-channel digital satellite project recently announced by the News Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Rupert Murdoch.

title: In Israel, Chefs Are Inventing a Vibrant Native Cuisine
description: EYAL SHANI gathers herbs two or three times a week from the rock-strewn hills of Jerusalem. Mr. Shani, the chef and owner of Oceans, a small, highly regarded restaurant near the Old City, looks for sage, thyme and hyssop, a piney anise-flavored herb mentioned in the Bible.

title: At the Modern, the 20th Century in All Its Shades of Gray
description: This year, The New York Times is celebrating two centennials at once: that of its purchase by Adolph S. Ochs, whose descendants remain at the helm, and that of the first publication of photographs in its pages. This is, of course, more than a coincidence, since Ochs was nothing if not forward-looking, pressing for innovation right up until his death in 1935, at the age of 77. It was on his initiative two months earlier that The Times had inaugurated its wirephoto service, transmitting photographs over ordinary telephone lines, a direct ancestor of today's fax technology.

title: Sports of The Times;MetroStars 'Marvelous' In Their Way
description: THE last New York-area team to make a wretched start was cute and cuddly. But then again, the New York Mets came along in a kinder, gentler era, and they had Casey Stengel to grimace and babble and cover up for their shortcomings.

title: TENNIS;England Discovers Local Hero
description: Just after he captured his first Grand Slam title at the French Open earlier this month, Yevgeny Kafelnikov, the 22-year-old Russian prodigy whose supporters have forecast a No. 1 ranking for him in the near future, revealed himself to be a bit of a worrywart in the present.

title: Adolph S. Ochs of The Times, in the First Person Singular
description: In August 1896, the head of a major New York life insurance company gave some advice to a young newspaperman from Chattanooga, Tenn.: "Don't do yourself anything you can get others to do as well. Confine your efforts to the impossible things." The younger man, Adolph Simon Ochs, was making a career of doing things other people thought impossible. At age 20, in 1878, he had bought the failing Chattanooga Times with borrowed money -- his father had had to sign the papers since Adolph was legally underage -- and within a decade had turned it into one of the most successful newspapers in the South. And in August 1896, the 38-year-old greenhorn was about to acquire a controlling interest in what he called "one of the greatest newspapers in the world": The New York Times.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cigarette Tax Backed in Poll
description: New Jersey voters overwhelmingly support raising cigarette taxes by 25 cents a pack and using the money to construct and repair schools, according to a survey released yesterday by the Quinnipiac College Polling Institute.

title: About New York;So Her Place Is Like a Zoo? Guests Love It
description: TALK about house guest horror: Susan Yecies was host to a trio of visitors last weekend who took over a bathroom, demanded special meals and didn't even bring a fruit basket in gratitude. Worse yet, one of them had -- ahem -- an accident on the dinner table.

title: Wine Talk
description: WINE sales are up. Imports are booming, and California wineries are so busy they can't find enough grapes. And still, the industry is worried. Americans, the wine makers complain, simply don't drink enough wine.

title: Back to Sleep' Effort Is Said to Save 1,500
description: About 30 percent fewer American babies are dying of sudden infant death syndrome as the result of a campaign to teach caregivers to put infants to sleep on their backs instead of on their stomachs, a Federal official said Monday.

title: House Votes To Upgrade Water Quality
description: A bill that seeks to raise the quality of drinking water weathered a feud over money and was passed by the House on a voice vote today, moving Congress closer to enacting its first major environmental law since Republicans took power.

title: Pasquale De Santis, 69, Filmed Zeffirelli's 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: Pasquale De Santis, the Italian cinematographer who won an Academy Award in 1968 for his work on Franco Zeffirelli's film version of "Romeo and Juliet," died on Sunday in Ukraine. He was 69.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;A Big Band, a Big Challenge
description: The composer and big-band leader Maria Schneider did a brave thing at Florence Gould Hall on Sunday night. She brought in her own big band for a set of music, then spent the second half of the concert leading the Gil Evans Orchestra through some of Mr. Evans's classic arrangements. Comparisons were impossible to avoid, and the conclusions weren't always to her benefit.

title: Despite Doubts, Official Gives Go-Ahead to Bosnian Vote
description: The European diplomat in charge of organizing national elections in Bosnia said today that although conditions had not been met for free and fair elections, the vote should nevertheless go ahead in September as scheduled.

title: World News Briefs;Poland Adopts Plan To Preserve Auschwitz
description: The Polish Government adopted a new plan today to preserve the former Nazi death camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau as a place of remembrance.

title: Unusual Intestinal Ailment Has Now Affected About 120
description: Health officials said yesterday that about 120 people in the New York City area had been stricken by an intestinal ailment caused by an exotic microbe, and they said the illness had been reported in at least 10 states and in Ontario, Canada.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Glittery Movements And Shiny Medals
description: Barbora Kohoutkova, a 17-year-old dancer from the Czech Republic, won the gold medal at the 1996 New York International Ballet Competition, which ended with a gala ceremony and performance on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Ducking the Truth About Welfare Cuts
description: The Senate Finance Committee begins voting today on Republican welfare cutbacks that will throw children into poverty. How many children? That is the question Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York asked the Clinton Administration to answer. It has refused. Indeed, President Clinton has not even instructed his staff to begin preparing an answer. The evasive tactic reflects his desperation to sign whatever welfare bill the Republicans send his way without shouldering blame for its dreadful consequences.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;Cardinal Has Praise for Dole On Abortion
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York yesterday offered a strong affirmation of Bob Dole's opposition to abortion and dismissed suggestions that Mr. Dole's commitment would be diluted by his efforts to placate abortion rights forces in the Republican Party.

title: Artistic Director Resigning At the Long Wharf Theater
description: Arvin Brown, one of the longest-serving artistic directors of any major regional theater in the nation, announced yesterday that he would resign as head of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven at the end of the 1996-97 season.

title: Pataki Signs Bill to Combat Drinking by Young Drivers
description: Following a national trend, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that would for the first time impose penalties on people under the age of 21 who are caught driving with even trace amounts of alcohol in their blood.

title: A.M.A. Keeps Its Policy Against Aiding Suicide
description: Delegates at the American Medical Association voted today to continue the group's policy opposing doctor-assisted suicides.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the popularity of abalone on the Northern California coast misspelled the surname of a landscape architect who lives in the Sea Ranch, near Stewarts Point. He is Lawrence Halprin, not Halpern.

title: OLYMPICS;Growing Older on Parallel Bars
description: In both 1988 and 1992, the Olympic trials were a time for the American public to get acquainted with a new wave of gymnasts.

title: Senate to Vote on Raising Minimum Wage
description: After months of deadlock on a major Presidential campaign issue, the Senate's top Democrat and Republican agreed today to schedule a Senate vote on a proposed 90-cents-an-hour increase in the Federal minimum wage, making a pay raise for several million workers likely by the end of the year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jet-Ski Fans Seek Eased Rule
description: Legislators say they have been inundated with complaints about a new law that requires all operators of Jet Skis to get a safety certificate by Monday after taking a course or passing a test administered by the State Police Marine Bureau.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Exuberant Resurrection Of a Man and a Musical
description: Star power is evidently meant to be the draw for the revival of "Your Arms Too Short to Box With God," directed by the musical's author, Vinnette Carroll, and running through Sunday at the Beacon Theater. With Stephanie Mills, Teddy Pendergrass and BeBe Winans onstage, even people who hear gospel music only seldom, by accident, will know they are hearing singers they have heard before.

title: Rights Group Finds Abuse Of Suspects By City Police
description: Amnesty International, the human rights organization best known for publicizing torture and executions in countries like Guatemala and Nigeria, has turned its attention to the New York City Police Department, and said it found an unsettling pattern of abuse and excessive force.

title: Hudson River Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Grisham Gives Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile Will Enter a Big South American Free-Trade Bloc
description: In a move that expands free trade in South America, Chile agreed today to join the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur, which includes the continent's largest trading partners, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Bucks Star Pulls Out of Games
description: Glenn Robinson, the Milwaukee Bucks forward, has withdrawn from the men's Olympic basketball team citing an ongoing condition of tendinitis in his right Achilles' tendon. The USA Basketball selection committee said it intended to name a replacement by late tomorrow or Friday, with Seattle's Shawn Kemp considered the most likely to get the spot.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: INSIDE
description: Questions on Atomic Safety

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Piquant Tortellini, Lower in Fat
description: Fresh tortellini comes with dozens of fillings that go well beyond the ordinary meat and cheese. But when you are looking to keep the fat count down, mushrooms are a better choice.

title: Bomb Factory Described In Trial of Terror Suspect
description: A Filipino bomb-disposal expert testifying at the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef in Manhattan yesterday related how he and other police officers discovered a bomb factory in a Manila apartment allegedly rented by Mr. Yousef and a co-defendant after neighbors reported smoke billowing from it.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irish Adding Permanent Lights
description: First Wrigley Field, now Notre Dame Stadium. University officials announced yesterday that they are ending longstanding policy and will add permanent lights to the stadium as part of an expansion project. The decision was made to accommodate NBC, which has a contract to broadcast all Notre Dame home games and will pay for the lights.

title: Grading For-Profit Schools: So Far, So Good
description: It began with grandiose talk of thousands of private schools reinventing American education, quickly changed course into a radically different concept of public schools operated on a contract basis, and for a time seemed in danger of thudding to an ignominious end before its first school ever opened its doors.

title: Doing Wonders With Enough Charcoal to Fill a Shoe Box
description: Grilled Double-Thick Pork Chops With Southern Flavors Total time: 45 minutes

title: Russian Liberal Keeps Lines to Yeltsin Open
description: With the doors of political opportunity creaking shut, the liberal also-ran, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, has jammed his foot across the threshold, struggling to hold them ajar just a little longer.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo Begins Sale Of Its Pharmacia Stake
description: The Swedish auto maker Volvo said yesterday that it had begun selling its 46 million shares in the pharmaceutical company Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. The shares, which have a current market value of 13.2 billion kronor (about $2 billion), amount to two-thirds of Volvo's stake in the London-based drug maker.

title: Israelis Mustn't Let Orthodoxy Dictate;A Single Judaism?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Seek To Move Up In the Draft
description: The Knicks are trying to move up in today's college draft by trading their 19th and 21st picks to a team holding a selection between 10 and 15, a league official said last night.

title: Stage Set For Hostile Takeover Bid for Kansas City Utility
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said yesterday that its board had rejected a sweetened takeover bid from Western Resources, and the spurned utility immediately countered that it would take its case directly to Kansas City Power shareholders.

title: Yeltsin, in Another Political Purge, Dismisses 7 Top Generals
description: In a political purge, President Boris N. Yeltsin today dismissed seven senior generals with ties to the ousted Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING RECEIVES A JETLINER ORDER VALUED AT $1.6 BILLION
description: The Boeing Company has received a $1.6 billion order for 23 jetliners from the airline Garuda Indonesia, which is owned by the state. Boeing said the airline had ordered six 777's and 17 737's. Delivery is expected to begin in 1997 and continue through 2002. With the Indonesian contract, Boeing's backlog of 777 orders totals 249 planes, while the backlog of 737 orders is about 526 planes. As of May 31, the company, which is based in Seattle, had a backlog totaling 1,115 planes. Garuda Indonesia also has an option to buy six Boeing 747's. Shares of Boeing rose $1.375, to $90.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: An Overhaul of Workers' Compensation Is Major Obstacle In AlbanyBudget Talks
description: For weeks now, negotiations over the latest state budget on record have stalled in part because both parties refuse to budge on one of the thorniest issues to face the state in years: revamping New York's troubled workers' compensation system.

title: SENATE KILLS BILL TO LIMIT SPENDING IN CONGRESS RACES
description: The Senate killed campaign finance legislation today as most Republicans followed their leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and defeated an attempt to bring the issue to a vote.

title: Put Out the Ethnic Flames, Here and in Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Commonwealth Defers Sanctions on Nigeria
description: Commonwealth countries said today that they would not carry out a set of sanctions they had considered against Nigeria until the two sides had talked more about ending a seven-month crisis in relations over Nigeria's human rights conditions.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: POLITICS: ENDORSEMENT;Clinton Seeks Giuliani's Support, After Mayor Snubs Dole
description: President Clinton's advisers are openly seeking the endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who has snubbed Bob Dole and the national party.

title: Indian Point 3 Again on List Of Worst A-Plants in U.S.
description: For the sixth time in three years, the state-owned Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., was listed yesterday by Federal regulators as one of the nation's worst nuclear plants, provoking new calls by critics for the New York Power Authority to close it permanently.

title: BASEBALL;Howe Is Released After Arraignment and Returns Home
description: Steve Howe was released on his own recognizance and returned to his home in Montana today after an arraignment in Queens Criminal Court in New York on a charge of third-degree criminal possession of a weapon.

title: Rose Madder
description: ose Madder," the title of Stephen King's 29th novel, refers of course to the reddish pigment used in painting, on which depend important details of the novel's scary plot. But "Rose Madder" also sums up what the novel's heroine feels when she notices "a single drop of blood, no larger than a dime" on the sheet near her pillow while she is making the bed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a wedding of high romance and pragmatism, and all New York had the chance to listen in when ALAN GAMPEL, 32, a concert pianist, and Dr. MELISSA DUBROFF, 30, a psychiatrist, were married yesterday -- on the radio.

title: World News Briefs;Burundi Issues Appeal For Help to End Killings
description: Feuding members of Burundi's Government set aside their differences today to make their first appeal for foreign help to end ethnic killings in the central African nation.

title: Before the Testimony Began, the Verdict Was In
description: The hearings of the Senate Whitewater committee illustrated how the lack of legal protections allow politicians to misuse witnesses and distort testimony. The result of such bias: two final reports divided along partisan lines.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Are Ready for Anything
description: Coach John Calipari's two-week crash course in trade-rumor survival is over, with the Nets' appointed salvage man ready to make his first National Basketball Association decision today.

title: Revamping Is Approved For Mesa
description: Shareholders of Mesa Inc. approved a refinancing today that turns over control from T. Boone Pickens, the company's founder, to Richard Rainwater, a Fort Worth financier. But they did not go along peacefully

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Islanders Finally Sign Berard
description: BRYAN BERARD, who was the top pick in the 1995 draft but refused to play for Ottawa and forced a trade to the Islanders, agreed to contract terms yesterday. Details were not released. Berard, a 19-year-old defenseman from Woonsocket, R.I., had 31 goals and 58 assists last season for Detroit in the Ontario Hockey League. He also played for the United States in the world junior championships.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Psion of Britain In Talks to Buy Amstrad
description: The British information technology company Psion P.L.C. and the consumer electronics company Amstrad P.L.C. said yesterday that they were in talks that could result in the acquisition of Amstrad by Psion. They said any offer from Psion, best known for its computerized personal organizer, would be at a price of not less than 200 pence an Amstrad share, payable in Psion shares.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;'The Odyssey' as a Musical With a Search for Love
description: GETTING OVER HOMER By Mark O'Donnell 193 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;When Opera and Audience Understand Each Other
description: There are obvious drawbacks to performing opera in English translation: The marriage of language and vocal line as the composer conceived it is sacrificed; translations can be cumbersome, and many opera singers are terrible at projecting English clearly.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMMUNITY FIRST BANKSHARES TO BUY MOUNTAIN PARKS
description: Community First Bankshares Inc. of Fargo, N.D., said yesterday that it would buy the Mountain Parks Financial Corporation for $126.5 million in stock. Community First said that it would exchange 1.275 shares of its common stock for each share of Mountain Parks common stock and that it expected 4.05 million shares to be outstanding at the close of the deal. Based on today's closing price of $25, the deal is valued at $126.5 million. Mountain Parks is a bank holding company in Denver.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are 6% Higher on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose nearly 6 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: Yankees' Owner Leaning Toward New Stadium Site
description: George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, last night offered the clearest public indication so far that he was leaning toward moving the team out of Yankee Stadium, its tradition-soaked home in the South Bronx for the last seven decades.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SBC Warburg Drops Bid for Paris Company
description: SBC Warburg said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer for the shares in Compagnie d'Investissements de Paris held by Banque Nationale de Paris. On Monday, Banque Nationale de Paris, which owns 84 percent of Compagnie d'Investissements, declined SBC Warburg's offer of 205 francs a share for its stake, a total of $798 million.

title: TV Notes;'Naked Truth' to NBC
description: ABC has not yet become the biggest supplier of programs to NBC, but it seems to be heading in that direction, thanks to one of ABC's own production partners, Brad Grey.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Early Entries Will Jumble N.B.A. Draft
description: They are young. They are restless. But on Wednesday night, a group of talented underclassmen will finally be drafted and learn their destinations.

title: Man Charged In Bomb Case Enters Plea: Not Guilty
description: With no show of emotion, Theodore J. Kaczynski, who Government investigators say is the Unabomber, pleaded not guilty today when arraigned on charges that he was responsible for two of the deaths and two of the injuries resulting from a nationwide, 18-year campaign of terror bombings.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Nicklaus Says Yes to British
description: JACK NICKLAUS will extend his unbroken run of playing in major golf tournaments to 139 when he tees off in the 125th British Open at the Royal Lytham and St. Annes Golf Club in Lytham St. Annes, England, from July 18-21. Organizers confirmed yesterday that Nicklaus, who won the British Open in 1966, 1970 and 1978, had decided to enter the tournament. Nicklaus, 56, had said he would not make the trip to England unless he thought he could be competitive. (AP)

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL;A Sophisticated $14 Million Travel Information System is Having a Trial Run in Atlanta.
description: A SOPHISTICATED travel information system on trial through Sept. 30 in Atlanta might well become the norm in major cities in the United States in the not-too-distant future.

title: Personal Health
description: SURELY I am not the only person who returns from vacation in better shape than when I left. But my friends are astonished that I come home from trips -- even cruises -- minus a few pounds and with muscle tone as good as or better than when I left.

title: Where Terror Reigns in South Africa
description: On the eve of the local elections here, Thulani Gumede has welts all over his body and a bandage on his forehead covering five stitches. He tried to hang up his campaign posters last weekend and was stoned by a crowd that supported the opposition.

title: U.S. Finds Oldest Ally Is Renewing Friendship
description: For most of the postwar era, France and the United States have been quarrelsome allies, often differing over basic issues during the cold war like America's strategic role in Europe and how to deal with Russia and China.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Portrays Clinton as 'Misguided'
description: Describing an unsettled world threatened by instability in Russia and the Balkans, Bob Dole opened a new line of attack on President Clinton today, warning that the nation could not endure leadership by "would-be statesmen still suffering from post-Vietnam syndrome." He advocated a harder line in dealing with potentially hostile powers.

title: Head of C.I.A. Plans Center To Protect Federal Computers
description: Alarmed at the growing threat that computer hackers pose to national security, the Director of Central Intelligence today announced plans to create a "cyberwar" center to protect the bits and bytes that weave the nation together.

title: Consultant to First Lady Admits Error on Resume
description: Jean Houston, the woman who held several controversial consultations with Hillary Rodham Clinton, today corrected an entry in a widely distributed resume that said she had completed her doctoral studies in the philosophy of religion at Columbia University.

title: TV Notes;More Goofiness for Misties
description: Like a creature crawling out from the muck on its screen within a screen, "Mystery Science Theater 3000" has staggered back to life. The cable show, which features Mike Nelson and two robots making snide comments while watching drecky B movies, was canceled by Comedy Central in May. But the Sci-Fi Channel has picked it up for 13 new episodes, with one condition: the movies mocked on "MST3K" must all be sci-fi films in the new shows.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Wickes Says It Found Accounting Irregularities
description: The British building materials retailer Wickes P.L.C. said yesterday that it had found accounting irregularities that could go back several years. The company said it was likely that profits for 1995 were overstated, and that earlier profits might also have been overstated.

title: Franklin Set To Buy Heine In Another Big Fund Accord
description: Franklin Resources Inc., the nation's fifth-largest mutual fund company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Heine Securities Corporation from Michael Price, the well-known value investor, in a deal that could ultimately be worth at as much as $800 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIELDCREST HIRES PRUDENTIAL TO SELL ITS BLANKET UNIT
description: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Prudential Securities Inc. to help it explore the sale of its blanket unit, which had sales of $71 million in 1995 and assets of $40 million. Fieldcrest said information has been provided to some interested parties. Proceeds of any sale would be used to reduce debt and for reinvestment in its remaining core businesses. Fieldcrest, based in Eden, N.C., manufactures household textiles like towels, bedspreads, sheets and comforters. Its stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $19.875.

title: Trump's Castle Is Shifting To Publicly Held Company
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts said yesterday that it had formally agreed to buy Trump's Castle Casino Resort in Atlantic City from Donald J. Trump for about $525 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOVEREIGN BANCORP PLANS TO ADD FIRST STATE FINANCIAL
description: Sovereign Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire First State Financial Services Inc. in a transaction valued at about $60.7 million. Under the agreement, Sovereign plans to exchange $14.75 in stock for each outstanding share of First State Financial. Sovereign, based in Wyomissing, Pa., said it expected to issue 5.8 million shares in the deal. First State Financial stock rose $3.1875 a share, or 32 percent, to $13.1875, in Nasdaq trading, where Sovereign's stock was off 12.5 cents, to $10.0625 a share. The acquisition would give Sovereign 13 branch offices in central and northern New Jersey. First State Financial, based in West Caldwell, N.J., has assets of $630 million.

title: POLITICS: THE POLLS;Clinton Lead Is Unaffected by Troubles
description: Despite the almost daily discussion of ethics questions involving the White House, President Clinton's support is virtually unchanged from nearly three weeks ago, the latest New York Times Poll shows.

title: Israel Meets With U.S., but Sticks to Stance
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met yesterday in Jerusalem to try to repair relations between the Clinton Administration and the new Israeli Government.

title: Judges Block Mayor On Waterworks Sale
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suffered another setback yesterday in his long-delayed effort to sell New York City's sprawling water and sewer system to a public authority.

title: BASEBALL;Lasorda Is Hospitalized
description: Tom Lasorda, in his 20th season as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was in the hospital today with abdominal pain and was expected to miss at least a few games.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Topps Narrows Account Review
description: The Topps Company in New York, which markets trading cards, comic books, gum and candy, has narrowed the review on its account to five agencies from 12. The account, with billings now estimated at $7 million to $10 million, had been handled by Grey Advertising in New York for two and a half years until that agency resigned in April.

title: 6 Colleges With Bit of Genius Are Given $750,000 Rewards
description: The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, best known for its "genius" grants to creative individuals, is putting its stamp on six small, innovative liberal arts colleges that it says show a certain genius in how they educate students.

title: About Real Estate;High-Technology Theater for Tourists
description: The Plaza Theater on 58th Street just east of Madison Avenue, originally a stable for Cornelius Vanderbilt 2d, is entering the high-technology age.

title: Christopher Sees Netanyahu In a Fence-Mending Visit
description: In a trip intended to repair relations between the Clinton Administration and the new Israeli Government, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke warmly today about their shared desire for peace, while tiptoeing over their sharp disagreements on how to get there.

title: 22 Charged With Involvement In Violent Bronx Drug Gang
description: Twenty-two people were charged yesterday with running a Bronx-based cocaine trafficking gang that used guns, dynamite and even hand grenades in a wave of attacks against former members and business owners.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;America Online Has a New Strategy
description: America Online Inc., seeking additional revenue to supplement subscription fees, said yesterday that it would significantly revamp its advertising strategies.

title: X-Rays Hint At Foul Play For King Tut
description: Tempering their excitement with scholarly caution, two scientists said yesterday that X-rays may suggest foul play in the early death of Tutankhamen, the boy Pharoah who ruled Egypt more than 3,000 years ago.

title: California Agribusiness Sows Bitter Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: Oh, Sorry: Tabloids Lose the Soccer War
description: LONDON  Remember when England's soccer stars were being passed off as drunken louts, a harmless embarrassment, more likely to be dribbling down the fronts of their shirts than toward goal?

title: Foreign Affairs;A Time For Anger
description: Talking the past few days with Sinn Fein supporters in Belfast and America, it's been encouraging to see how angry they are over the I.R.A.'s latest bombing, in Manchester, which injured more than 200 people. It is a particular kind of anger -- the anger of people who have been too long at war, who for the first time were letting themselves believe that the future was about to bury the past, only to have the past come roaring back and smack them in the face. When I asked Senator Edward Kennedy -- who helped open the dialogue between Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, and the U.S. -- for his thoughts now, he declared: "The I.R.A. are no friends of Ireland. They are enemies of peace. No amount of I.R.A. rationalizing or dissembling can possibly justify their continuation of violence."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Prudential of Britain To Sell Stake in Unit
description: The Prudential Corporation, Britain's largest life insurer, said yesterday that it planned to sell a significant stake in its Mercantile and General Reinsurance subsidiary in a stock offering. Prudential, which is not related to the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said it had decided to focus on retail financial services and fund management.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADOBE SYSTEMS REPORTS AN EARNINGS DECLINE
description: Adobe Systems Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings fell 37.5 percent in its second quarter as a result of slow sales of its graphic-arts computer programs, but its operating profit was slightly higher than Wall Street had expected. Adobe, which publishes programs like Pagemaker and Illustrator, said its net income totaled $22 million, or 29 cents a share, in the quarter ended on May 31, compared with $35.2 million, or 47 cents a share, last year. Excluding a pretax charge of $14.7 million for a write-off related to its acquisition of Ares Software, the company said its profit from continuing operations totaled $34.1 million, or 45 cents a share. Wall Street expected Adobe, based in Mountain View, Calif., to report operating profits of 44 cents. Revenue rose 7.8 percent, to $204.3 million. Adobe's financial results were released after the stock market closed; earlier, the company's shares closed at $33.875, down 87.5 cents.

title: SOCCER;Donadoni And Ramos Revive MetroStars
description: Without Roberto Donadoni for five weeks and without Tab Ramos for some games in that span, the MetroStars went without a goal in Major League Soccer for 348 minutes, or nearly four games.

title: Rikers Inmates Injure 20 Guards in a Fight
description: Inmates on Rikers Island attacked correction officers searching for contraband yesterday, injuring 20 of them, in the second scuffle in the jail complex this week, officials said.

title: Too Far on Forfeitures
description: Skipping past recent precedents and ignoring common sense, the Supreme Court went overboard this week in affirming the Government's authority to prosecute narcotics dealers and seize their property. A majority of eight justices were so anxious to avoid tampering with this cornerstone of the Government's anti-drug strategy that they ignored an important fact. Not all civil forfeitures are alike.

title: Louisville Agrees To Stay in League
description: Louisville agreed to stay in Conference USA today after resolving a dispute with the league over football expansion during an eight-hour court-ordered mediation session on Monday.

title: New Grates, Gadgets, Recipes and Repairs for the Grill
description: GRILLING is getting to be like golf, a technique-driven, equipment-laden and time-consuming summer activity that is both solitary and social. A moment of inattention and you have bogeyed the burgers. And yes, there are grilling pros who give lessons.

title: U.S. Curbs Crew's Power Over Local School Boards
description: Responding to new allegations of corruption in New York City's community school boards, state lawmakers pushed through a bill in March intended to make it easier for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to root out wrongdoing.

title: Enigma of the Grill: To Cover or Not
description: THE best grilled food is -- well -- grilled. It is cooked directly over the heat and flame of a live fire. Reach for the cover and you are cooking by another method -- which means you are likely to end up eating food with a flavor that you never expected.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PAYCHEX PLANS TO BUY NATIONAL BUSINESS SOLUTIONS
description: Paychex Inc. said yesterday that it would buy National Business Solutions Inc. for $142.5 million in stock, breaking into the business of administering employee benefits for small and medium-sized companies. Paychex, based in Rochester, plans to issue three million shares to acquire National Business Solutions, based in St. Petersburg, Fla. Closely held National Business administers human resources, employment regulator compliance, workers' compensation coverage, health care and 401(k) programs for 9,000 workers in various businesses. Paychex provides computerized payroll accounting services to more than 230,000 small-to-medium-sized businesses nationwide. Its stock closed at $47.375, down 37.5 cents.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;De La Hoya to Fight Gonzalez
description: OSCAR DE LA HOYA will make the first defense of his World Boxing Council superlightweight title against the No. 1 challenger MIGUEL ANGEL GONZALEZ of Mexico on Sept. 14 in Las Vegas, Nev., promoters said. Gonzalez, who is 41-0, held the lightweight title before moving into the 140-pound division. De La Hoya is 22-0. (AP)

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Lockout Looms as Talks Falter
description: Negotiations between the National Basketball Association and the players union ended abruptly yesterday after a six-and-a-half-hour meeting in Manhattan. Unless dramatic progress is made this week, a lockout could begin on Monday, the day the players without contracts can declare free agency.

title: TV Notes;Back on Tobacco Road
description: Tomorrow night at 10, ABC News tackles America's tobacco companies again, in an hourlong documentary, "Never Say Die: How the Cigarette Companies Keep on Winning."

title: Eating Well;Old Lettuce Masquerades As Mesclun
description: THE dumbing down of mesclun is just about complete. What was once an incredibly delicious mixture of baby lettuces and wild greens -- dense and feathery, bitter and sweet, peppery and buttery -- has in most places become a bland, almost tasteless mixture of cut-up greens. Mesclun is now big business, which means that the once pricey mix has become cheaper and much more widely available.

title: The Honor of Judge Elbert Tuttle
description: Elbert Parr Tuttle, who died Sunday at the age of 98, was a judge who rose grandly to the legal challenge of his time. Appointed to the Federal bench in 1954, a few months after the Supreme Court outlawed segregation in the public schools, he joined the embattled United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, which then covered six Deep South states. As Chief Judge during the turbulent 1960's, he made that court the leading edge in the fight against segregation.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From Prepared Dole Speech on Clinton Foreign Policy
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech that Bob Dole delivered today to the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia.

title: At Times Mirror, What's the Plan?;New Chairman Still Searches for Growth After Big Cuts
description: The question has been posed to Mark H. Willes so often lately that sometimes he just asks it himself.

title: F.A.A. Chief Admits Mistakes on Valujet
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration conceded today that his agency had reacted too slowly to safety problems it had discovered at Valujet Airlines even before the crash on May 11 in the Florida Everglades that killed 110 people.

title: French Block Philip Morris Ad
description: A Paris court has banned an advertising campaign by the Philip Morris Companies that contends that breathing secondhand tobacco smoke poses less of a health risk than eating cookies, a lawyer for French food companies said today.

title: 100 YEARS (1896-1996);A Life of The Times: 4 Shows
description: How the old New-York Times became the modern New York Times is a story that began in 1896 when a publisher from Tennessee, Adolph S. Ochs, bought the newspaper, dropped the hyphen and, without fear or faintheartedness, began a revolution in daily journalism.

title: No Headline
description: It looks probable that he was murdered. Probable, but not certain."
