description: To the Editor:

title: The Files That Kept History Alive ... Not to Mention the FlounderingReporter
description: The name, of course, sounds terrible -- the morgue -- whispering of death and grim finality. Don't be fooled. The morgue of a newspaper offers the blessing of eternal life, a realm where the Vanderbilts are forever sailing to Europe and John T. Scopes is still on trial, where G.I.'s slog across war-torn Europe and an upstart Orson Welles directs a new film called "Citizen Kane."

title: PRO BASKETBALL;A Weighty Decision: All of Draft's Riches Can't Sway Utah's Van Horn
description: He is in his fire-red Nissan pickup truck (101,000 miles on it) when he sees his Lexus in the showroom window (zero miles on it). After he is done drooling, he drops his fiancee at the Italian restaurant where she works, drops his 1-year-old at his future in-laws and drops himself at the weight room.

title: Put Out the Ethnic Flames, Here and in Bosnia;Irrelevance in Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: On Picket Lines in Jamaica, A Solidarity Against Cuts
description: Outside the Jamaica Hospital Medical Center yesterday afternoon, Teresa Sansone and Carol Goodman, red and white strike posters hanging from their necks, refused to believe management's assertion that the hospital was running smoothly.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WORLD AIRWAYS TO END EUROPE CHARTER BUSINESS
description: World Airways Inc. said yesterday that it would withdraw from its money-losing European scheduled charter business to focus on leasing aircraft to international airlines and operating aircraft for the military. World also said it expected to earn about $14.1 million from core businesses in the quarter ending on Sunday, up from $10.8 million last year. Losses from the charter business would reduce earnings by $6.7 million, including a $2.7 million charge for discontinuing the business. World's stock fell 75 cents yesterday, to $6.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Ipperwash Beach Journal;Ontario Indian's Death Is an Issue That Won't Die
description: Dudley always maintained that they wouldn't shoot our people," Sam George said, describing the death of his younger brother, the first Indian in modern Canadian history killed in a dispute with the government over native rights and land.

title: ITT Will Expand 2 Caesars World Casinos
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it would expand its Caesars World casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., in a move that adds new construction to an expansion strategy dominated by acquisitions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;D. & B. SELLING ITS SOFTWARE UNIT TO BAIN CAPITAL
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation signed a letter of intent yesterday to sell its Dun & Bradstreet Software unit to Bain Capital Inc. for $160 million in cash and $50 million in preferred stock. The sale is part of a plan by Dun & Bradstreet, which is based in Wilton, Conn., to split into three publicly traded companies: the Cognizant Corporation, focused on high-growth information markets; the new Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, dedicated to financial information services, and A. C. Nielsen, delivering consumer products market information. Cognizant would retain a minority interest of about 27 percent in Dun & Bradstreet Software. Bain Capital, which is based in Boston, is a private equity investment firm with total investment capital of $1.4 billion.

title: How Senate Voted on Ending Debate
description: Following is the 54-to-46 roll-call by which the Senate voted today on ending a filibuster on campaign finance legislation. Halting the debate requires 60 votes, so the effort failed.

title: Print Edition For Journal On Internet
description: Slate, the Microsoft Corporation's new political and cultural magazine published on the Internet's World Wide Web, has been widely anticipated as an attempt to define a new medium.

title: YACHT RACING;Woman Is Behind America's Cup Secret
description: The secret syndicate for the 1999-2000 America's Cup races came to light yesterday as Dawn Riley, the 31-year-old watch captain from the Mighty Mary team, revealed that she is behind the new campaign.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Landscaper Guilty of Murder
description: A landscaper who had helped publicize the disappearance of his pregnant 17-year-old girlfriend was convicted yesterday of murdering her and burying her in Rochelle Park.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Two Kinds of Saxophone: Sassy Latin and Hazy
description: Saxophones purred and swaggered, scampered and punched out riffs at the Knitting Factory's Heineken "What Is Jazz?" Festival on Monday night. Both headliners, Arthur Blythe and David Sanchez, led groups that were proudly polymorphous, shifting in and out of tonality and mainstream jazz swing, delving into personal obsessions without ignoring the audience.

title: Saga Acquires Stations
description: Saga Communications has acquired four radio stations for $17 million. It bought two stations for $7 million from Ocean Coast Properties. They are WNAX-AM and WNAX-FM in Yankton, S.D. It also bought two stations from Park Communications for $10 million.

title: Nursing Homes And Hospitals Hit by Strike
description: In another sign of financial struggles in New York's health-care industry, 6,000 workers went on strike late Monday against Brooklyn Hospital Center, Jamaica Hospital and 11 other hospitals and nursing homes after rejecting management's demands for cuts in wages and benefits for new workers.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Redeeming A Williams Washout
description: On most people's lists of Tennessee Williams plays least fit for revival, "Kingdom of Earth" ranks close to the top. Composed in a haze of amphetamines, sedatives, alcohol and nasty paranoia, this three-character drama of sexual conflict in the Mississippi Delta reeks of the kind of flashy, grotesque self-parody John Barrymore achieved in his last years as an actor.

title: For Germans, a Kebab Filled With Social Significance
description: FORGET bratwurst, pigs' knuckles, sauerkraut and even pickled sow's stomach. The new German national dish is doner kebab, an overstuffed sandwich that arrived here with Turkish immigrants and has exploded in popularity from the wind-swept Baltic coast to the verdant hills of Bavaria.

title: BALLET REVIEW;An Opulent 'Bayadere' With Nureyev's Hollywood Touch
description: For all its extravagance, or rather because of it, Rudolf Nureyev's 1992 version of "La Bayadere" for the Paris Opera Ballet is not to be missed.

title: Contaminated Anti-Fever Drug Kills at Least 30 Children in Haiti
description: At least 30 children in Haiti have died of acute kidney failure after taking contaminated liquid acetaminophen made by a pharmaceutical company in Haiti, international health officials said last night.

title: White House Got More Files Than Disclosed
description: The White House improperly received confidential F.B.I. files on perhaps several hundred more people than previously acknowledged, computer work records show, including files on prominent members of the Bush Administration foreign policy team.

title: Hong Kong Is Warned By Beijing On Press
description: Long accustomed to their boisterous, muckraking press, Hong Kong's journalists and news organizations are reeling from a series of body punches delivered by a senior Beijing official over the future of press freedom here.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Agencies Expand With Overseas Plans
description: Two agencies are expanding operations overseas.

title: On Juveniles, U.S. Has Treaty Obligation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Coconut Cake Tall Enough For 20
description: A TALL coconut cake showered with shavings of fresh coconut is a moist, sumptuous and irresistible showpiece that could make 20 or so guests happy at a wedding or other summer festivity. The $40 cake is a specialty of the Louisiana Community Bar and Grill, 622 Broadway (near Bleecker Street), and can be ordered in advance to go. For information: (212) 460-9633.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;A Tribute to a Guitarist Bursts With Stringed Chatter
description: There were a few moments when the musicians at a tribute to the guitarist Tal Farlow on Monday night at Merkin Concert Hall overcame their instruments, but not enough of them to stanch the flood of notes. Because it is powered by fingers and not the breath, the guitar can be chattery, and this concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, was dominated by the instrument's language, its little ideas.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on June 18 about the passage of the Olympic torch through the state referred incorrectly to the gold medal won by Robert S. Garrett of Princeton in 1896. While Mr. Garrett was the first Olympic champion in the shot-put and the discus, he was not America's first gold medalist; James Brendan Connolly, who represented the Suffolk Athletic Club of Boston, became the first champion of the 1896 Olympic games by winning the triple jump.

title: Divorce, Manila-Style:Church and Customs Clash : Senator Juan Ponce Enrile was arguing with a priest.
description: MANILA  When love goes out of a marriage, the senator was saying, we should do something about it.

title: Legal Aid Society Sues City Over Its Plan to Shift Cases
description: The Legal Aid Society sued New York City yesterday to block a plan to turn over a portion of the agency's cases to new legal organizations, saying that the Giuliani administration was seeking retribution for a four-day strike by Legal Aid lawyers in 1994.

title: 23 U.S. TROOPS DIE IN TRUCK BOMBING AT BIG SAUDI BASE
description: A truck bomb ripped through an apartment complex housing Air Force pilots and other American military personnel near the eastern Saudi Arabian city of Dhahran today, killing at least 23 Americans, wounding more than 300 people and raising new concern about the stability of the vast Saudi desert kingdom.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;New campaigns by Dunkin' Donuts and Wendy's use familiar faces to build loyalty.
description: TWO familiar advertising figures and a politician turned product peddler are featured in new pitches for consumer brands that epitomize the appeal of continuing characters in marketers' campaigns.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: A Male Nanny Is Charged Again With the Sexual Abuse of a Boy
description: A 24-year-old male nanny on probation for sexual abuse of a 9-year-old boy in Greenwich, Conn., in 1991 is under arrest again, this time on state and Federal charges of sexually abusing an 11-year-old Armonk, N.Y., boy in his care.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fiat Expects Profits To Remain Same In '96
description: The Italian industrial giant Fiat S.p.A. said yesterday that it expected profits for the year to be in line with those from last year. The chairman, Cesare Romiti, said at the annual shareholders' meeting that the output of new car and tractor models would reach capacity this year.

title: Guerrillas Kill 3 Israeli Soldiers
description: Guerrillas who evidently sneaked into the West Bank from Jordan ambushed an Israeli patrol today, killing three soldiers and wounding two others, the army said.

title: Dominion Resources Deal
description: Dominion Resources Inc. said today that it had acquired a 60 percent interest in Empresa de Generacion Electrica NorPeru S.A. of Peru, a subsidiary of the Government-owned ElectroPeru S.A., for $228.2 million. The Peruvian Government will retain the remaining 40 percent stake in the unit.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Chile's entrance into the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur, omitted part of the last sentence in some editions. The sentence should have read, "Mercosur members played an important role in frustrating the coup attempt by threatening to eject Paraguay from the trade group if a renegade general continued to defy civilian rule."

title: 2 Top Executives Dismissed In Astra Harassment Case
description: Astra USA Inc., the American subsidiary of Sweden's biggest publicly traded company, said yesterday that it had dismissed two top executives, including its president and chief executive, and that two others had resigned following an in-house investigation of allegations of sexual harassment and other improprieties.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Voices Ascending In Harmony
description: 'Invisible Cities'

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Picking Kittles Makes Life Easy for Calipari
description: It was John Calipari's housewarming party tonight, a chance for the National Basketball Association's draft host to make the home crowd feel at ease with his first decision as Nets coach.

title: In Health Care's New Era, Catholic Institutions Link Up to Compete
description: More than 30 Catholic hospitals and nursing homes in the New York region are banding together in a new health care network intended to help its members compete in an era of managed care and to strengthen the church's mission of treating the poor.

title: Hearing on Bombing Opens; Defense Names Informant
description: Lawyers for Terry L. Nichols, one of the two defendants in the April 1995 bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, disclosed today that a family member who served as a confidential Government informant was the former wife of his brother, James Nichols.

title: New Jersey Schools Covet Same Name
description: This is a story about a dispute between two institutions of higher learning, both proud of their heritage, both suddenly coveting the same name, though for different reasons.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Mountain Dew's promotion angers children's advocates.
description: A PROMOTION for Mountain Dew that offers young people discounted pagers with advertising messages has angered children's advocates who see it as a new form of manipulation.

title: Greece Gives a Last Sad Farewell to Papandreou
description: As jet fighters flew low overhead, hundreds of thousands of Greeks bid farewell today to Andreas Papandreou, the charismatic former Prime Minister who dominated Greek politics for more than a decade.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti's Chief Executive Resigns Unexpectedly
description: Olivetti S.p.A., Italy's office equipment and telecommunications giant, said yesterday that its chief executive, Corrado Passera, had resigned unexpectedly to lead another, unnamed company. Mr. Passera, 41, will leave his post as the company's top manager within the next few months, Olivetti said. A successor will be chosen in July.

title: Basketball Fans Whoop It Up As the N.B.A. Goes Courting
description: The Continental Arena, home of the New Jersey Nets, was full of the rollicking rock-and-roll fervor that characterizes professional basketball games these days, with exhortatory music pounding through speakers and jazzy game highlights flashing on the scoreboard.

title: BASEBALL;Ochoa's Bat the Spark For Newly Ignited Mets
description: After seeing the strength and accuracy of Alex Ochoa's right arm, Colorado Manager Don Baylor said he was more intrigued with the rookie's ability to throw a baseball than his trying to hit one.

title: Currents;Gardening For the Hardy
description: IT is difficult enough to grow a rose without leaf-curling heat, exhaust fumes and thorn-defiant vandals. But New Yorkers determined to overcome the obstacles and flex their green thumbs now have the ultimate guide, "Ken Druse's New York City Gardener: A How-To and Source Book for Gardening in the Big Apple" (City & Company, $15). Mr. Druse, one of America's leading horticulturists, who has tended plots from SoHo to Brooklyn, offers 221 pages of almost nonstop sound advice.

title: Disney Consolidates Global Operations
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and Walt Disney Television International are consolidating their international operations in a new company called Disney/ABC International Television.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Up on Fear of Loss Of Supplies in Saudi Turmoil
description: Crude oil prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a deadly explosion at an American complex in Saudi Arabia raised concern that political and social tension could disrupt oil output there.

title: Unfilled Jobs Small Worry To Organizers Of Olympics
description: After their last meeting before the start of the Summer Olympics here in 23 days, the planners of the Games said today that short of some remaining concerns about jobs to fill, possible traffic jams and the weather, the city was more than ready to receive an estimated three million spectators and athletes from 197 countries.

title: House Cuts All Spending for Service Program
description: The House of Representatives voted this evening to eliminate all spending on President Clinton's national service program, AmeriCorps, and to use the money for veterans' programs and to help reduce the Federal debt.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HIBERNIA IN $77 MILLION DEAL FOR TEXARKANA BANK
description: The Hibernia Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Texarkana National Bancshares Inc. for $77 million in stock, giving Hibernia its first presence in Texas since 1992. Closely held Texarkana, with $406 million in assets, has nine branches in northeast Texas. It plans to open a 10th branch on July 15. Hibernia, based in New Orleans, has completed two acquisitions this year and has three more pending, including the proposed purchase of Texarkana. Those acquisitions would bring Hibernia to $8.9 billion in assets, with 197 branches in Louisiana and Texas.

title: Victory for Parties
description: The Supreme Court said the Government may not limit how much political parties spend on their candidates unless it proves that party and candidate are working together.

title: Association of Political Handlers Attacks Ruse Polls as Unethical
description: The trade association of political managers today denounced phony "push polls," in which campaigns hire companies to make thousands of calls spreading negative and sometimes false information about an opponent while posing as pollsters.

title: Silicon Valley Whodunit Case Is Effort to End Industry Scams
description: Inspecting a newly purchased $1 million computer for a customer, the technician from Tandem Computers Inc. noticed that the serial numbers had been obliterated. Suspicious, he turned to a hidden set of serial numbers and found that they matched those on a computer that had supposedly been melted down for scrap three months earlier.

title: Essay;Stay Out of Touch
description: The earliest electronic paging devices were distributed to the White House staff in Moscow in 1972. H. R. Haldeman thought it would increase efficiency to have all 20 Nixon summiteers on call at all hours of the day and night while in the adversary's capital.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Finds Less Pollutants
description: New Jersey industries are continuing to emit fewer pollutants, the United States Environmental Protection Agency reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACE SETS RATIO FOR PURCHASE OF TEMPEST REINSURANCE
description: Ace Ltd. said yesterday that it had set the ratio governing the stock swap included its agreement to acquire the Tempest Reinsurance Company. Ace will pay Tempest holders 3.2091 shares for each share of the closely held reinsurance concern, or a total of about 13.3 million shares. The exchange ratio is based on an average closing price of Ace stock of more than $45 a share. Ace shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $47.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tempest agreed to be acquired by Ace last week for $976 million. Ace's offer beat a bid from IPC Holdings Ltd., a reinsurance concern that had offered $943 million. All the companies are based in Bermuda.

title: Police Initiate Campaign For Better Community Ties
description: Tacitly acknowledging that the longstanding problem of verbally abusive and disrespectful officers continues to dog the Police Department, Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday announced a "respect campaign" complete with new training, videos and even sting operations.

title: World News Briefs;Zulu Election Is Ending Vestige of Apartheid
description: Across South Africa's volatile Kwa-Zulu/Natal Province, thousands of people stood outside schools and municipal buildings for hours today waiting to cast their vote in the region's first nonracial local elections. For many, it was only the second time in their lives that they were able to vote at all.

title: Currents;Bamboo Bike May Just Be Recyclable
description: THE superwaif Kate Moss rides one. So does Evi Quaid, wife of the actor Randy. The suddenly chic Bambooclette Country bicycle, made in Vietnam and designed by Quasar Khanh, is largely of bamboo. "It began as a joke and became a challenge," said Mr. Khanh, 62, a French civil engineer who now lives in Ho Chi Minh City. "I told someone maybe I'd make a bamboo bike when I got here, and they called me on it. Luckily, it works. Bamboo is not only incredibly strong and sensual, it's a renewable resource, which makes it environmentally friendly." The featherweight 15-speed vehicles cost $1,000 for both the men's and women's models and have rattan baskets, woven seats and rosewood pedals. Information from Sarah Giles, by fax: (212) 717-4585.

title: Nintendo-Microsoft Deal on Data Delivery
description: In the first partnership between the king of video games and the colossus of software, the Nintendo Company and the Microsoft Corporation said today that they would deliver information and entertainment, mainly from the Internet, to personal computers via satellite broadcasting.

title: East Asia Considers a Policing Agency on Nuclear Power
description: SINGAPORE  East Asian countries, concerned that an undeclared nuclear weapons race between India and Pakistan in South Asia might spread to their own region, are showing increasing interest in forming a regional organization to police nuclear power programs to ensure that they are not used for military purposes.

description: Banco Santander-Chile said yesterday that it had cut 800 positions as a result of its planned $1 billion purchase of a controlling interest in Chile's Banco Osorno y La Union S.A.

title: Orders for Durable Goods In Strong 3.3% Rise in May
description: Strong demand for new commercial aircraft drove up durable goods orders for May at the sharpest rate in nine months, the Commerce Department said today, in the latest sign that American manufacturing was reviving.
