title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ireland to Sell Off Part of Telecom Eireann
description: PTT Telecom Netherlands and Telia of Sweden have teamed up to buy a minority stake in Telecom Eireann, one of Europe's last state-owned telecommunications monopolies, the Irish Government said yesterday. PTT Telecom and Telia will pay 183 million Irish pounds ($289.1 million) for a 20 percent stake.They have been given an option to buy another 15 percent stake for about 200 million Irish pounds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Woman's Publisher Resigns
description: Lori Zelikow Florio, the publisher at New Woman magazine in New York since 1990, has resigned, she said, to devote her full time to raising her family. Ms. Florio, 37, has also worked for New York and Seventeen magazines; all three titles are part of the K-III Media Group unit of the K-III Communications Corporation. In a restructuring at New Woman, Daniel M. Lagani, 32, advertising director, has been promoted to a new post, associate publisher, reporting to Janice Grossman, president for advertising and marketing at the K-III Media Group.

title: Gunmen Slay Irish Reporter Who Wrote on Gangs
description: Veronica Guerin, 33, one of Ireland's most prominent investigative reporters, was shot dead this afternoon after two men intercepted her car on a road in a Dublin suburb.

title: Game of Tense Maneuvers Is Adjourned
description: Anatoly Karpov raked Gata Kamsky over the coals yesterday throughout Game 11 of the world championship match in Elista, Russia, and when play broke off, he was still tormenting him. The adjournment session today will decide whether Karpov can win or Kamsky manage a draw.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Shells Seafood Restaurants Inc., Tampa, Fla., to the West Group, Tampa, to handle advertising for the restaurant chain, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;A Dispute Causes Head of Little, Brown to Resign
description: In a sharp disagreement over management strategy, the president and chief executive of Little, Brown & Company yesterday announced his resignation from the venerable publishing house, which is owned by Time Inc.

title: SOCCER;Germans Defeat English In Shootout
description: England perished in the semifinals of the European soccer championships the same way it had triumphed in the quarterfinals, beaten by Germany's greater mastery of the penalty shootout.

title: TENNIS;With Case of Jitters, Seles Shown the Door
description: Fear was one factor that didn't exist in the ferocious arsenal of shots and sheer gumption that powered Monica Seles to eight Grand Slam singles championships before she was forced off the tour three years ago. Nor was it in evidence this January when she opened her first full season back by capturing the Australian Open, a Slam tournament she has won four times.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: DISCRIMINATION;MILITARY COLLEGE CAN'T BAR WOMEN, HIGH COURT RULES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that under the "skeptical scrutiny" that applies to government action that treats men and women differently, the State of Virginia cannot justify keeping women out of its state-supported military college, the Virginia Military Institute.

title: Now, Bell Atlantic Plans to Buy Nynex, Not Merge With It
description: Seeking to avoid a Congressional vote on their proposed $20.8 billion merger, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Nynex Corporation said yesterday that they would turn the deal into an acquisition of Nynex by Bell Atlantic, rather than making it a "merger of equals," as they had planned.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY MAKES OFFER TO BUY RIVAL
description: Vishay Intertechnology Inc. said yesterday that it was seeking to buy a rival electronic components maker, the Kemet Electronics Corporation, in a transaction that could exceed $1 billion. The companies did not disclose financial terms of the proposal. Vishay, based in Malvern, Pa., said it was ready to buy all of Kemet's shares at a premium above Kemet's current market price. Shares of Kemet, which is based in Simonsonville, S.C., rose $2.125 yesterday, to $19, in Nasdaq trading, while Vishay rose 25 cents, to $21.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The companies compete in the $15-billion-a-year market for capacitors, components used in personal computers and electronic devices.

title: Metro Matters;Stalled Bills On Violence In the Home
description: DEBATE about the law's treatment of domestic violence used to center on the definition of "violence." Now, the debate is about the definition of "domestic."

title: No Time to Run
description: Tuesday's explosion at the military compound at Dhahran was an attack both on the Saudi regime and the United States. This assault, combined with the one in Riyadh last November that killed five American military personnel, has driven home to Washington that the Saudis' vaunted ability to control events within their borders has been exaggerated.

title: A.M.A. Drug Policy Is Still in the Making
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Transfers From Bus to Subway
description: New Yorkers who must take both a subway and a bus to get to work have complained for decades about paying two fares for a single one-way trip. But commuters rejoiced this week when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced a plan to provide free transfers between subways and buses beginning next year. The new system will cost the M.T.A. some revenue, at least initially. But the new policy corrects a longstanding unfairness. It could contribute to lighter traffic and better air quality by getting many New Yorkers out of their cars and onto public transit. It should also broaden use of the electronic fare card, which is cheaper to administer than the token-based system.

title: New Issue At Work: On-Line Sex Sites
description: HUNKERED over computer screens, the six founders of an on-line magazine, five men and a woman, worked in a cramped Manhattan office late into the night to make their start-up business take flight.

title: Occidental And Lloyd's In Accord
description: The Occidental Chemical Corporation, whose corporate predecessor was responsible for polluting the Love Canal in New York State, will receive an undisclosed portion of the estimated $1 billion in cleanup costs under a settlement with Lloyd's of London.

title: Transplant Not Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Plant Closes And Developers See Opportunity;North Tarrytown Focuses On Its Future Instead of the Past
description: After 11 years as an electrician at the old, smoke-stained General Motors plant that rises over the bank of the Hudson River here, Nancy McCague might be expected to be saddened, perhaps even angry, as the plant fades into the history of American manufacturing.

title: Brooklyn 7-Year-Old Is Lured From Playground and Raped
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl was raped by a man who lured her and her 5-year-old brother with a promise of soda pop from their East New York playground on Tuesday to an abandoned apartment building nearby, the police said yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Hearing On Handling of F.B.I. Files
description: Following are excerpts from the hearing today by the House Government and Oversight Committee into the White House's handling of F.B.I. files, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 1 about a dispute over releasing captive dolphins into the wild referred incompletely to the actions of Ric O'Barry, who removed two male dolphins from the Sugarloaf Dolphin Sanctuary in the Florida Keys last month and set them loose in the Gulf of Mexico. Despite critics' concern about "kidnapping," photographs show that the release was carried out with the assistance of Lloyd A. Good 3d, the sanctuary's director.

title: Utilities Gird For Shortage Of Electricity
description: Connecticut is so short of power as the season of peak demand begins that the Navy shipped in portable generators, police departments are preparing to direct traffic if deliberate blackouts darken traffic signals, and the oldest, most polluting plants, which usually run only a few hours at a time, are scheduled to run full out for the summer.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SECURE COMPUTING ANNOUNCES ANOTHER ACQUISITION
description: Continuing its buying spree, the Secure Computing Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Enigma Logic Inc. for stock valued at $71.3 million when the deal was announced. Secure is paying 2.7 million shares for Enigma, which is based in Concord, Calif. After the announcement, Secure shares fell $4.75, to $21.75, in Nasdaq trading. Secure, based in St. Paul, said its network security services would be enhanced by Enigma's client-server identification, authentication and authorization software. In May, Secure Computing agreed to buy Border Network Technologies Inc. of Toronto for stock then valued at $187.5 million. Also last month, it bought Webster Network Strategies for an undisclosed amount.

title: Two Defeats for Democracy
description: This has been a bad week for campaign finance reform. In two days, Congress and the Supreme Court have taken separate actions that undermine the cause of cleaner politics and government.

title: Parents to Be Told H.I.V. Status of Newborns
description: Ending one of the fiercest legislative battles in years, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill today that requires health officials to tell parents the results of the H.I.V. tests that the state routinely performs on all newborns.

title: America and Saudi Arabia
description: The deadly terrorist bombing in Saudi Arabia must not be allowed to undermine one of America's most important yet most vulnerable international partnerships. But in responding to the blast President Clinton should not gloss over the hard issues that make relations with the Saudi monarchy awkward and difficult to manage.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A PUBLIC OFFERING FOR ABERCROMBIE & FITCH IS PLANNED
description: Limited Inc. said yesterday that its board had approved a plan to file a registration statement for an initial public offering of its Abercrombie & Fitch business. Limited, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, spun off its Intimate Brands in an initial public offering in October as part of a plan to reconfigure the company. Abercrombie & Fitch sells casual apparel in 105 United States stores. It had 1995 sales of $236 million. Limited made the announcement after the close of trading. Earlier, its shares fell $1.125, to $19.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TELEVISION;Swanson Named WNBC President
description: DENNIS SWANSON, who resigned last month after a decade as the president of ABC Sports, became the president and general manager of WNBC-TV/Channel 4 yesterday. "The most fun I've had was in the station business," said Swanson, who ran WLS-TV in Chicago and ABC's station group in the early and mid-1980's.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;N.B.A. Negotiations Gain Ground and Will Continue
description: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and the players union met in Manhattan today, and enough progress was made for another meeting to be scheduled for Thursday.

title: INSIDE
description: Power-Hungry Connecticut

title: Holier Than Us?
description: Recently in New Orleans, the 14,000 delegates to the Southern Baptist Convention adopted a resolution calling for a major campaign to convert American Jews to Christianity. The Baptists also appointed a missionary to take charge of the conversion operations, thus supplementing rhetoric with organizational muscle. The resolution is the latest in a centuries-long line of conversion efforts whose history is so distasteful as to make the Baptists' action profoundly offensive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: A Sweetheart Becomes Suspect;Looking Behind Those Kathie Lee Labels
description: Two months ago, a labor activist pulled a thread and Kathie Lee Gifford's storybook life began to unravel.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Go Forward in the First Round
description: For someone 6 feet 8 inches, John Wallace has a soft, baby hook shot that he often lofts up in the lane over smaller defenders. At 6-10, Walter McCarty can knock down the 3-point bomb with aplomb. And Dontae' Jones can simply score from all over the floor.

title: 16 Foreign Law Firms Cleared To Open Offices in China
description: China's Justice Ministry approved the opening of offices by 16 international law firms today, reflecting a brighter climate in Chinese-American business relations now that trade disputes have been put aside.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ad Group Begins New Media Award
description: The Coalition for Advertising Supported Information and Entertainment, a joint venture of the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies focusing on the new media, plans to begin an annual awards competition for effective advertising and marketing on the Internet and the World Wide Web. The Casie Awards will be presented for the best interactive advertising campaign and the best advertiser Web site. The initial awards will be announced during the 1996 annual meeting of the advertiser association, Oct. 4-7 at Amelia Island, Fla.

title: Another Move To Curb Fees At A.T.M.'s
description: With more and more banks charging fees for the use of their automated teller machines, pressure is mounting in Congress for legislation to curb or ban some of these practices.

title: Supporters Of U.N. Chief In Disarray At U.S. Veto
description: Caught off guard by the Clinton Administration's pledge to veto a second term for Boutros Boutros-Ghali as Secretary General, his supporters seem to be in confusion and retreat barely a week after the White House disclosed its decision.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE SECURITY;Officials Say Size of Bomb Caught Military by Surprise
description: The United States had received a wave of threats against Americans and American installations in Saudi Arabia in recent weeks but failed to prepare for a bomb of the power that killed 19 American military personnel on Tuesday near the eastern Saudi city of Dhahran, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Sports of The Times;Point Guards Share Dream Worlds Apart
description: THEY came to Continental Arena having grown up a continent apart, in different worlds. One only had to dream of crossing a bridge. For the other, it involved international borders and a cultural divide.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an exhibition of Adolph S. Ochs's correspondence, at the Pierpont Morgan Library, misquoted a word of his journalistic credo for The Times on his takeover as publisher in 1896. The passage should have read: "He would not depart from the policies that had distinguished The Times as a 'nonpartisan newspaper -- unless it be, if possible, to intensify its devotion to the cause of sound money and tariff reform, opposition to wastefulness and peculation in administering public affairs, and in its advocacy of the lowest tax consistent with good Government, and no more Government than is absolutely necessary.' " (He did not say "speculation.")

title: Head of Carpenters' Union Is Dismissed in an Office Raid
description: In a raid on his office by national union officials and private guards, the head of the carpenters' union in the New York City area was abruptly dismissed yesterday from his $360,000-a-year job on charges of corruption and favoritism to mobsters.

title: COMPANY NEWS;$310 MILLION FOR AMOCO CONTAINER UNIT
description: Moving ahead with a large restructuring, Tenneco Inc., based in Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it would acquire the Amoco Corporation's plastic container division for about $310 million. The acquisition will increase the scope of Tenneco's packaging business, already the company's largest, as the once wide-ranging conglomerate narrows its focus to packaging and auto parts. The Amoco Foam Products unit makes polystyrene cups, plates, carrying trays and other products. It had 1995 sales of $288 million. Tenneco's packaging unit, which had revenue of $2.7 billion last year, makes such brands as Hefty trash bags and Baggies food bags.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Dutchmen Who Add a Touch of Zany
description: Dutch jazz doesn't get the blues. To judge by the Knitting Factory's evening of jazz from the Netherlands, which took place on Tuesday night as part of the Heineken "What Is Jazz?" Festival, Dutch jazz has its heart in slapstick and pointillism, aspiring to be simultaneously wacky and precise.

title: A New Life For a Journal
description: News of the demise of Progressive Architecture last January may have been premature. Like a phoenix, the magazine, which for 75 years positioned itself at the cutting edge of the profession, is scheduled to rise again this fall, as an on-line journal.

title: CLOSE TO HOME;Keeping Alive the Dreams of Love
description: IT had been a long time since I'd met anyone promising in the romantic arena and I'd pretty much retired the dreams I'd carried since childhood about marriage and children. I'd been settling instead for a sprinkling of dates here and there, taking what I could get, almost forgetting that I ever wanted more.

title: Reading & Bates Rig Deal
description: The Reading & Bates Corporation has hired out its deep water semisubmersible drilling rig for 36 months to Elf Aquitaine S.A.'s Elf Exploration Angola in a contract worth about $117 million. Reading & Bates, an offshore drilling services company in Houston, said the rig is expected to arrive in Angola in October.

title: Currents;Whoever Steals This Logo Is in Trouble
description: AT the Decorex U.S.A. design fair in Chicago this month, the most talked about debut was the logo of Anti Copying in Design (ACID), a group of designers dedicated to prosecuting those who knock off their work. Membership information is available from Simon Clark, a lawyer in London (011-44-171-606-8855).

title: Sumitomo Stockholders Create Big Fund to Help Cover Losses
description: Stockholders of the Sumitomo Corporation approved a company plan here today to cover losses in what Sumitomo has described as unauthorized transactions over more than a decade by its chief copper trader.

title: BALLET REVIEW;From Paris, a 'Bayadere' of Purity and Harmony
description: There is more to chew on in the Paris Opera Ballet's grandiose staging of "La Bayadere" at the Metropolitan Opera House than the scenery. There is, above all, the dancing of different casts of principals. And certainly Monique Loudieres and Manuel Legris, who led Rudolf Nureyev's production on Tuesday night, will be among the finest. They repeat their performances tonight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Tyee Ends Alliance With Wunderman
description: The Tyee Group in Portland, Ore., which specializes in infomercials, has ended a strategic alliance with Wunderman Cato Johnson in New York, the direct marketing unit of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Despite U.S. Hope and Help, Ukraine's Star Fades
description: Three summers ago, Ludmilla and Aleksander Kozlov welcomed some foreign visitors into their modest home with wine served in long-stemmed glasses, a table laden with cold meats and salads and plenty of zest for the future.

title: New York City Acts to Tighten Begging Laws
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council reached agreement yesterday on an anti-begging law intended to crack down on insistent or menacing panhandlers and anyone who begs within 10 feet of automatic teller machines.

title: Deputy Chief Is Chosen to Lead Newark Police Dept.
description: A 27-year veteran of the Newark police force with a reputation as a tough, aggressive commander was named yesterday to head the troubled Newark Police Department.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Biotech Seeks $220 Million to Expand
description: In a surprise move that analysts said could depress the market for other British biotechnology stocks, British Biotech P.L.C. said yesterday that it would seek L143.4 million ($220 million) from shareholders. British Biotech, Britain's biggest biotechnology company by market capitalization, said it wanted the money to expand its clinical trial program for two cancer drugs.

title: OLYMPICS;New Face Poised to Get Top Spot on U.S. Team
description: For the last five years, Blaine Wilson has been staring at the well-muscled, well-schooled figure of the top American male gymnast John Roethlisberger and quietly repeating the following to himself: "Catch John. Catch John. Catch John."

title: Bridge
description: Two favored teams were on the sidelines here today in the International Team Trials, which will determine the American Open Teams in the World Championships on the Greek island of Rhodes in October.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: CAMPAIGN CONTRIBUTIONS;Justices Reject Bid to Limit Party Spending
description: The Federal Government may not limit how much political parties spend to help candidates unless it specifically proves that party and candidate are working together, the Supreme Court ruled today in a major case on how far the First Amendment goes to protect political free speech.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: REACTION;For Citadel, Few Options Except Talk
description: In Charleston, S.C., where The Citadel is as antique as the rubble at Fort Sumter and cadets, all male, still march in strut step and hold their rifles high, the end was three years and almost $20 million in the making. But it still came as a shock.

title: ON BASEBALL;Revitalized Bullpen Brings the Mets Back to Life
description: When Dallas Green used to talk about the Mets fragmenting too often in the early going this season, it was easy to envision the gap between those players who were getting the job done and those who weren't as being as wide as the Grand Canyon.

title: New Goal for Police: New York's Politest
description: Tacitly acknowledging that the longstanding problem of verbally abusive and disrespectful officers continues to dog the New York City Police Department, Commissioner Howard Safir announced a "respect campaign" complete with new training, videos and even sting operations. "We will instill respect at all levels of the department," Mr. Safir said.

title: Economic Scene;If the U.S. doesn't follow trade rules, why should others?
description: IF at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Cray Research, the Minneapolis-based maker of supercomputers, seems to have taken that homily to heart. After failing to convince the National Science Foundation that it could build a better machine to simulate global warming than the NEC Corporation of Japan, Cray is attempting to nullify the foundation's decision through the back door. Friends of Cray in Congress have slipped a provision into the foundation's proposed budget that would effectively bar completion of the deal with the Japanese.

title: THE SUPREME COURT;Excerpts From High Court's Ruling Against the Male-Only Policy of V.M.I.
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in United States v. Virginia, holding that the equal protection guarantee of the 14th Amendment requires admission of women to the all-male Virginia Military Institute.

title: Continental to Split Stock
description: The board of Continental Airlines Inc. has approved a 2-for-1 split of the company's class A and B stock, the company said today. After the split, the airline will have 9.2 million class A shares and 46.6 million class B shares, a spokesman for the company said. The class B shares, more frequently traded, closed today at $61.75, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jets Sign Veteran Linebacker
description: The Jets yesterday signed RICK HAMILTON, a veteran middle linebacker who had just completed the World League of American Football season with the Barcelona Dragons. Hamilton, 6 feet 2 inches and 241 pounds, was drafted in the third round in 1993 by the Washington Redskins, and has played for the Redskins and the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Product Liability Ruling Favors Consumer Suits The Supreme Court ruled that consumers injured by faulty medical devices may seek damages, under state law, from the manufacturers even if the devices comply with Federal regulations.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Quaker Says 1996 Profits Will Be Lower
description: The Quaker Oats Company delivered more bad news yesterday about its ailing Snapple beverage business, announcing that the cost of a new promotional campaign to bolstersales of the bottled drinks would result in significant losses for the unit this year.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE OVERVIEW;Saudis, Aided by the F.B.I., Seek Blast Clues
description: Surveying the ruins left by a blast that tore the face from an eight-story apartment building in a military complex here on Tuesday night and killed 19 American servicemen, American and Saudi officials insisted today that the attack would not diminish their close military cooperation.

title: Mississippi G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Responsible Water Use
description: To The Home Section:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Docks Says Takeover Bid 'Hostile and Inadequate'
description: Docks de France S.A., a French supermarket operator, said yesterday that a takeover bid by a rival, Auchan S.A. was "hostile and inadequate" and that the price was too low. On Monday Auchan bid 1,250 francs a share for the 11.8 million shares of Docks de France it did not already own, an offer valued at 16 billion French francs ($3.1 billion). (Bloomberg Business News)

title: When Science Failed to Monitor Its Integrity;Misguided Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: Crafts, Bonsai And a Night Walk
description: Recent Crafts American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;For Keeper Of the Files, A Bad Day
description: Craig Livingstone quit his White House job without ceremony today and soon sat seething before a Congressional hearing as Democrat and Republican alike lambasted him for his handling of hundreds of F.B.I. files at the heart of the capital's latest political controversy.

title: BASEBALL;Lasorda Has Heart Attack
description: Los Angeles Dodgers Manager Tom Lasorda underwent an angioplasty today to unclog a coronary artery, his doctor said at a news conference, while revealing that Lasorda had suffered a heart attack.

title: London Journal;England's Toffs and Yobs: Sports Draws the Line
description: It has come down to this, the yobs against the toffs.

title: Client Sues Bear, Stearns in Trading Losses
description: Bear, Stearns & Company has been sued by a customer who accused the firm of losing more than $300 million through unauthorized currency trading in his brokerage account.

title: Market Place;Stock Funds: Rich but Short on Cash
description: Cash is trash, and should be spent as rapidly as possible.

title: Swedish Firm Cites Sexual-Abuse Charges : Astra Fires Its U.S. Chief
description: NEW YORK  Lars Bildman, longtime chief executive of the U.S. subsidiary of Astra AB, was dismissed Wednesday by the Swedish pharmaceutical giant amid charges of sexual harassment and misappropriating $2 million to pay for vacations and renovating his home.

title: World News Briefs;Afghans Get New Leader During Rebel Assault
description: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, a former rebel leader, was sworn in as Prime Minister today during the deadliest rebel assault on the Afghan capital this year, a relentless barrage that killed at least 30 people.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Science Times on Tuesday about "Scientists and Journalists -- One Story, Two Voices: A Century of Science Reporting in The New York Times," an exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, omitted the identity of the designers. The exhibition was designed by Edwin Schlossberg Inc. in conjunction with the museum's department of exhibition.

title: Military Unprepared For Force of Attack
description: The United States had received a wave of threats against Americans and American installations in Saudi Arabia in recent weeks but failed to prepare adequately for a bomb of the size that killed 19 American military personnel on Tuesday, Clinton Administration officials said.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Hemming And Hawing About TV For Children
description: Another year, another charade involving children's programming and, down to the exact millimeter, the extent to which commercial television can evade responsibility.

title: F.T.C. Sues Ciba-Geigy Over Doan's Pills
description: The Federal Trade Commission is suing the Ciba-Geigy Corporation and one of its subsidiaries over advertising claims that Doan's backache medicine works better than other over-the-counter pain relievers.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Delay Sought on School Bill
description: The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said yesterday that the Legislature would need until Nov. 30 to pass a school financing bill -- even though that is two months beyond the deadline imposed by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Foundation Offers Help to Brewers
description: Trying to secure the future of a "treasured community asset," the Bradley Foundation yesterday offered a $20 million loan toward construction of a new stadium for the Milwaukee Brewers. "We saw time slipping away," said MICHAEL JOYCE, the foundation's president. "We're going to lose major league baseball if we don't move now."

title: Imported Blinds Pose Lead Risk to Children
description: WINDOWS, long a focus of household child-safety concerns, became the object of renewed attention this week, when the Consumer Product Safety Commission determined that imported vinyl mini-blinds can present a lead-poisoning hazard to young children.

title: Victory and Frustration
description: It was a triumphant yet frustrating afternoon for Loick Peyron, the French skipper of the 60-foot trimaran Fujicolor II.

title: At Home With Richard Tyler and Lisa Trafficante;Seduced by a Mythical Past
description: WHEN the fashion designer Richard Tyler was growing up as a dressmaker's son in Australia, he watched newsreels about Hollywood movies and glittering stars like Dolores Del Rio, and he dreamed about one day being a part of it all.

title: How a Sure Summer Hit Missed
description: Sometime in early 1995, Lou Holtz Jr., a prosecutor in the Los Angeles County District Attorney's office, completed his first screenplay, a comedy called "The Cable Guy," and sent it to some friends who are producers. They introduced him to two agents, Tom Strickler and Ari Emanuel, at the fledgling Endeavor Agency.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Puckett Won't Return Before Aug. 1
description: Minnesota Twins outfielder KIRBY PUCKETT, sidelined all season by an eye problem, won't return before Aug. 1. Puckett, plagued by blurred vision, underwent a third round of laser surgery for glaucoma in his right eye on June 17.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF MIRAGE SLIP AFTER REPORTS ON NEW JERSEY PLAN
description: Shares of Mirage Resorts Inc. fell yesterday on fears that the company may be deterred from building a proposed casino in Atlantic City. The Press of Atlantic City and The Philadelphia Inquirer reported yesterday that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey was prepared to approve a road project -- but not a controversial tunnel -- to improve access to the project from the Atlantic City Expressway. Mirage said previously that without some kind of transportation improvements, it would make no sense to build a $750 million hotel casino project in the city's Marina district. Mirage shares fell $2.50, to $50.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED WISCONSIN AGREES TO ACQUIRE A PARTNER
description: United Wisconsin Services Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire American Medical Security Group Inc. for about $156 million, consisting of $67.2 million in cash and 4 million newly issued shares. Shares of United Wisconsin rose 50 cents, to $22.375, on the New York Stock Exchange before the deal was announced. The privately held American Medical is United's partner in a small group health insurance business. United, a managed health care concern based in Milwaukee, owns 12 percent of American Medical.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Luis Sharpe Found Shot in Neck
description: It remained unclear yesterday whether the former National Football League lineman LUIS SHARPE was under the influence of drugs when he was found shot in the neck on a Phoenix street Tuesday night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEDITRUST INC., Needham Heights, Mass., a health care real estate investment trust, agreed to buy a 20 percent stake in Nursing Home Properties P.L.C., a British nursing home company, for $20 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen to Suspend Investment in Saxony
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that it would suspend its investment in the eastern German state of Saxony after the European Commission blocked subsidies of 240.7 million marks ($157.3 million) to two of its plants there.

title: Come, Let's Celebrate 'America's Smithsonian'
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Steelers' Morris Pleads Guilty
description: Pittsburgh Steelers running back BAM MORRIS pleaded guilty yesterday to a charge of marijuana possession in exchange for the prosecutor's recommendation that he not be imprisoned.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Have a Bonus Baby
description: Bryan Berard's base salary with the Islanders will be limited by the rookie salary cap in the new collective bargaining agreement. That means a maximum of $850,000, including a signing bonus, for the first three seasons.

title: State Fair' Closing
description: State Fair," a musical based on the 1945 Rodgers and Hammerstein film, is to close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The evening performance will be the play's 118th; it had eight previews.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Abolishing Hudson Police
description: Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive, has proposed abolishing the Hudson County Police Department to reduce a projected $17 million budget shortfall.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Post Mild Gains
description: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, displaying resiliency in the face of an economic report showing unexpected strength and a disappointing auction of new five-year notes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What am I bid for a British title with no perquisites?

title: Deal for Power Computing
description: The Power Computing Corporation, the first company to license Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system, has been awarded a contract to replace or upgrade 3,000 older Apple computers of Lockheed Martin Astronautics. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: George W. Rothschild, Chicago Judge, 80
description: George W. Rothschild, a Chicago lawyer and Federal official who retired last year as judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County, died on Tuesday at Evanston Hospital. He was 80 and lived in Evanston.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Warring Lovers, Mortal and Otherwise
description: George Balanchine's production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," presented by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, suggests another side to Balanchine than the public image of a man of austere passion and little humor. In the full-evening ballet, created in 1962 and set to several Mendelssohn scores, Balanchine captures all the magic, warmth and comedy of the Shakespeare play.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin Jury Pool Shrinks
description: The pool of potential jurors for the drug trial of Cowboys receiver MICHAEL IRVIN was reduced yesterday as several said they could not be impartial after reading and listening to news accounts of the case.

title: GOLF REPORT
description: The Ike Championship

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Air France Posts Loss Of $580 Million for Year
description: Air France said yesterday that it lost 2.9 billion francs ($580 million) in the year that ended March 31 after recording a huge one-time charge. But it also reported its first operating profit, 413 million francs, since 1989.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Olden Styles Connected To Today's In a Tribute
description: Tuesday night's concert at Carnegie Hall, in which the pianist Chick Corea led an extraordinarily talented group of musicians in a tribute to the bop pianist Bud Powell, was like an archeological dig in the middle of a modern city, where layer after layer of antiquity has been left exposed, surrounded by the bustle of modernity.

title: Dole Campaign Plans an Attack On Clinton's Economic Record
description: Bob Dole's campaign advisers say they are planning a stepped-up attack on President Clinton's economic record, having concluded that despite low unemployment and inflation there is enough anxiety among voters about job security and stagnant incomes to leave the Administration vulnerable.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Conley Is Willing, but His Knees Aren't
description: The former Syracuse linebacker DAN CONLEY says he means it this time: his on-again-off-again football career is over.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TIMOTHY FORBES has never owned a Rolls-Royce, but he's looking forward to seeing a fleet of them roll by Sunday on his family's Timberfield estate in Far Hills, N.J.

title: Executive Changes
description: A. T. KEARNEY EXECUTIVE SEARCH, New York, a division of the A. T. Kearney unit of Electronic Data Systems Corp., named William E. Trautman senior vice president.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;SBC Consolidates Wireless Account
description: SBC Communications Inc. in San Antonio has consolidated the account of its national wireless communications operations at GSD& M in Austin, Tex., and narrowed a review for a new long-distance account.

title: Giuliani Receives Gingrich's Support
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that he would be "saddened" if New York's Republican Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, endorsed President Clinton for re-election. But the Speaker also made clear that he would not criticize such a move.

title: A.M.A. Drug Policy Is Still in the Making;Pain Treatment Lacking
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole Vows To Fill Ticket Ahead of Time
description: Bob Dole said today that he would settle on a running mate before the Republican National Convention in August because he wanted to avoid a distracting floor fight, as occurred when President Gerald R. Ford selected Mr. Dole himself in 1976.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CANADIAN REIT TO BUY MANAGER OF MD REALTY FUND
description: The Canadian Real Estate Investment Trust agreed yesterday to buy MD Management Ltd., the manager of the MD Realty Fund. Financial terms were not disclosed. Canadian REIT owns 23 properties across Canada, primarily in the community shopping center sector. The MD Realty Fund was created in 1982 as a real estate vehicle for members of the Canadian Medical Association and their families. The fund owns 63 properties.

title: Honoring Ochs and the Newspaper He Built
description: Early in a skit by Wendy Wasserstein and Frank Rich that opened and closed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night, a young newspaperman in Chattanooga, Tenn., named Adolph S. Ochs, and his wife, Effie, are describing a telegram just arrived from New York in summer 1896.

title: Lease Plan For Hospital Said to Cover Care for Poor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that a proposed deal to lease Coney Island Hospital to a for-profit company includes guarantees that care for the poor would continue at the public hospital at no cost to the city.

title: Trees to Match the House
description: To The Home Section:

title: CHRONICLE
description: If the reports in London newspapers are correct, the PRINCESS OF WALES won't have to worry about paying for plumbing repairs or anything else, after her divorce from PRINCE CHARLES.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Makes 12 Soft Tosses
description: Back in the Bronx, in an empty Yankee Stadium, David Cone tossed a baseball softly today as he began the process of trying to return to the Yankees this season. Here at the Metrodome today, the timetable for Cone's return indicated that he would not be included on any potential post-season roster.

title: BASEBALL;A Solid Stint by Key Caps Yanks' 6-2 Trip
description: As Chuck Knoblauch's one-out fly ball sailed 300 feet into right field in the ninth inning, the game between the Yankees and the Twins was destined to have a dramatic conclusion. Would Paul O'Neill unleash an accurate throw home to prevent Pat Meares from zooming 90 feet from third and tying the score?

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Power of a Cigarette And the Money Behind It
description: Television's assault on cigarettes continues with "Never Say Die: How the Cigarette Companies Keep On Winning." They do it, tonight's ABC News special reports, with shrewd marketing, sharp lawyering and, most important, big-money lobbying.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Taxes Called Unfair to Poor
description: For poor families, New Jersey's state and local tax systems are among the most unfair in the country, according to a study released yesterday by a tax policy research group.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;So, What Took Them So Long?
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, who retired RED SCHOENDIENST's No. 2 earlier this season, plan to retire two more numbers this year. Outfielder ENOS SLAUGHTER will have his No. 9 jersey retired on Sept. 6, and shortstop OZZIE SMITH's No. 1 will be retired on Sept. 28, the day before the Cardinals' regular-season finale. "I appreciate it very much," the 80-year-old Slaughter said from his home in Roxboro, N.C., on Tuesday. "Better late than never." (AP)

title: THE SUPREME COURT: PRODUCT LIABILITY;State Suits Allowed in Medical-Device Injuries
description: The Supreme Court ruled in an important product-liability case today that consumers injured by faulty medical devices, like cardiac pacemakers, may seek damages under state law against the manufacturers even if the devices comply with Federal regulations.

title: Clinton Aide Testifies on Campaign Deal in 1990
description: An aide to Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor who picked up $22,500 in cash from a bank for the campaign on the eve of the election testified today that she was told that Bruce R. Lindsey, who was then campaign treasurer, was aware that the bank had to make a Federal filing for the cash withdrawal.

title: Investigators Say Arson Was Likely in Venice Opera House Fire
description: Investigators have concluded that arson was the likely cause of a fire in January that left one of Italy's most beloved cultural monuments -- Venice's opera house, La Fenice -- a smoldering ruin.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an Amnesty International report on abuses by the New York City Police Department referred incorrectly to the United Nations' involvement. According to a U.N. spokeswoman, Sylvana Foa, the organization has no plans to investigate allegations against the Police Department; a news release circulated yesterday announcing that the United Nations Human Rights Commission would conduct such an investigation was a hoax, U.N. officials said.

title: James Field Jr., 80, Historian of U.S. Navy
description: Dr. James Alfred Field Jr., a former history professor at Swarthmore College and author on American naval history and foreign relations, died on Monday at his home in Newton Square, Pa. He was 80.

title: No Headline
description: Inherent differences' between men and women, we have come to appreciate, remain cause for celebration, but not for denigration of the members of either sex or for artificial constraints on an individual's opportunity."

title: COMPANY NEWS;SIEMENS AND G.M. EXPLORE A LOCOMOTIVE VENTURE
description: Siemens A.G. said yesterday that it might form a joint venture with the General Motors Corporation to design and build diesel-electric locomotives. Wolfram Martinsen, president of the Siemens transportation systems group, and William Happel, general manager of the General Motors Electro-Motive division, have signed a letter of intent to study the venture, expected to be established in early 1997. The two have already cooperated to introduce heavy-haul freight locomotives in North America and won the world's largest locomotive order, worth $1 billion, in January 1994.

title: Currents;Bored by the Same Old Four Walls?
description: ARCHITECTS build for the ages, so it comes as a surprise to find one whose projects can be tossed into a washing machine. Gisela Stromeyer, 35, a scion of German circus-tent makers, uses stretchable, washable panels of gauze or DuPont Lycra to create a room or transform any space into a personal big top. "Unlike tents, you don't have to deal with external forces like wind or snow loads, so you can really play with shapes in a whole different way," said Ms. Stromeyer, a former modern dancer who calls her sensuous installations "the translation of movement."

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Essays That Hurl Vexing Challenges at the Reader
description: NO PASSION SPENT Essays 1978-1995 By George Steiner 430 pages. Yale University Press. $30.

title: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Democrats Defend Clinton on Immigration in Striking Manner
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the Democratic National Committee began showing nationally yesterday. It responds to a Republican advertisement that started attacking President Clinton's immigration policy last week.

title: Storming the Showroom Citadels
description: WERE Hercules around today, he would have many, many new labors: toxic-waste dumps to clean, monster budget deficits to wrestle, rogue twisters to tame. And if he had recently acquired a sofa, he might be faced with a task that has foiled many a mortal: buying 30 yards of fine fabric without the help of a decorator.

title: Computer Issues In Retreat, With Dow Declining 36.57
description: Stocks fell yesterday as semiconductor and computer issues retreated for a second day on concerns that second-quarter earnings would prove disappointing.

title: Johnson Group in Deal
description: A partnership that includes a development company owned by the basketball star Magic Johnson has agreed to buy a Los Angeles shopping center for $20.1 million. The purchase is among the first by the partnership, California Urban Investment Partners, which was formed in March with $51.5 million to invest in retail properties in California cities. The firm is buying the 184,684-square-foot Ladera shopping center in southwest Los Angeles with Burnham Pacific Properties Inc., a San Diego real estate company.

title: Currents;Movable Feaster
description: NATHALIE HAMBRO, who has five cookbooks to her credit, likes to shop for her lunch on the way to work. So she has designed a sturdy box to hold her street-vendor comestibles. Lunchbox is a satin-finish steel container with an embossed logo and three sassy handle options: perforated metal ($42), studded or stitched black leather ($58) and a shoulder strap ($58). Sold at Peipers & Kojen, 1023 Lexington Avenue (73d Street); Ad Hoc, 410 West Broadway (Spring Street), and through KWM Exclusives, (212) 737-6159.

title: Thomas Howard Wolf, 80, Dies; Made Documentaries for ABC
description: Thomas Howard Wolf, a photo journalist and documentary maker for ABC News and the Smithsonian Institution, died on Monday at a hospital in Annapolis, Md. He was 80 and lived in Annapolis.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Law to Cover Used 'Lemons'
description: Starting next Wednesday, used car buyers in New Jersey will be protected by a "lemon law" modeled after the one that covers new cars. The Used Car Lemon Law, which applies to most cars bought from dealers for $3,000 or more, requires them to guarantee the engine, transmission and other major parts for up to 90 days, the State Consumer Affairs Director, Mark S. Herr, said yesterday. A dealer who cannot fix a problem with a used car after three tries must refund the purchase price.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE WITNESSES;Survivors of Saudi Explosion Knew at Once It Was a Bomb
description: Staff Sgt. Alfredo Guerrero saw it coming, unfolding before him like the nightmare his training courses had etched.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Switching Azaleas

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE SAUDIS;Bombing Attack Raises Questions About Stability of Saudi Government
description: The bombing attack against an American target in Saudi Arabia could not have come at a worse time for the ruling royal family, coinciding with a vacuum in the Saudi leadership and increasing opposition to American influence in the kingdom.

title: When Science Failed to Monitor Its Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Life
description: 'A Healing Modality' in Music

title: Latest Offer For Utility Is $1 Billion
description: A subsidiary of the Southern Company said yesterday that it would offer $1.04 billion in cash for the nonnuclear power plants of the Cajun Electric Power Cooperative, a Louisiana electric utility.

title: World News Briefs;China Drug Crackdown Orders Many Executions
description: Hundreds of drug traffickers were believed to have been executed today as courts marked World Anti-Drugs Day by convicting 1,725 people nationwide and meting out some of their harshest sentences.

title: Murky Pool Hindered Rescue Of Brooklyn Boy, Police Say
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy who drowned in a hotel pool in Philadelphia while on a school trip was left in the pool even as a classmate was being rescued, apparently because the water was so murky that rescuers could not see the bottom, a Philadelphia police detective said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Clinton Imagines in Good Company
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voter Aid Money Is Backed
description: The State Legislative Black and Latino Caucus urged Governor Whitman yesterday to restore $2 million to the state budget that was intended to be used for voter registration under the so-called Motor Voter Law. The Federal act enables people to register at Division of Motor Vehicle offices, but the chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, Robert E. Littell, redirected the funds to be used for restoring the State House dome.

title: Stock Prices Fall in Tokyo
description: Stocks were down slightly here at midday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 50.34 points, two-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,616.46. On Wednesday, the Nikkei was up 69.63 points.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Lyons Talks May Prove Unpleasant For the U.S.
description: When the United States once again failed to send a check this spring to the World Bank fund that provides aid to the world's poorest nations, the other contributors -- chiefly Europe and Japan -- decided to teach a deadbeat a lesson.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE FAMILIES;Back Home, A Time For Tears And Love
description: A member of the Air Force since 1982, Staff Sgt. Kevin J. Johnson had learned how to calm his mother's fears.

title: Race Issue Boils Over In Dallas
description: It is likely that public education in Dallas will survive the secretly recorded racist ramblings of a white school board trustee, the threats by a small group called the New Black Panther Party to come armed to school board meetings, and the spectacle of a young white board president ordering 20 police officers to drag the Panthers out of a meeting when they refused to sit down.

title: A Drive to Defeat Giuliani in 1997
description: The meetings have been held throughout the city for months now, in churches, in offices and in restaurants, and virtually every black elected official in New York City has attended one or more of them. The agenda is always the same: figuring out how to register more than 250,000 new voters in the next 17 months, create a robust "get out the vote" effort and, finally, defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Philips Is Said to Authorize A Polygram Offer for MGM
description: The board of Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics conglomerate that owns 75 percent of Polygram N.V., voted yesterday to allow Polygram to submit a bid for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc., according to several people close to the discussions.

title: Italian Court Blocks Extradition, Citing Death Penalty in Florida
description: Challenging American criminal justice on human rights grounds, Italy's constitutional court today blocked the extradition to the United States of an Italian wanted in Florida on first-degree murder charges because Florida law includes capital punishment among the possible penalties.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany Leaves Key Rates Unchanged
description: The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, left two key interest rates unchanged yesterday at its regular policy-setting meeting. The Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, said the German economy had "bottomed out."

title: Chilean Link to Sumitomo Scandal Denied
description: Juan Pablo Davila, who has been at the center of copper trading scandal at Codelco, a state-owned copper producer, today dismissed speculation that he had done business with a former Sumitomo trader accused of generating $1.8 billion in losses.

title: More Violence Disrupts Rikers Island
description: In the third and most serious outbreak of violence this week in the city jails, four prisoners were shot yesterday in a Rikers Island dormitory by an inmate with a derringer-type gun that had been smuggled in, correction officials said.

title: His Most Powerful Drive Was to Play, With Pride
description: Now don't keep asking me dates," said William Powell, a man who has been so busy making history in his 79 years, he did not have time to write down every last fact. "If I'd known this was going to turn into such a big thing, I'd have made better notes."

title: Critic's Choice/Television;Talking to the Menendezes
description: I'm just a normal kid," says Erik Menendez, wearing pale blue prison clothes and sitting next to his identically dressed brother, Lyle.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE POLICY;Clinton Asks Summit Partners to Join in Battle on Terrorism
description: President Clinton appealed today to the leaders of the world's biggest economic powers to join the United States in a stepped-up international campaign against crime and terrorism in the wake of Tuesday's bombing in Saudi Arabia.

title: A New G-7 Should Reflect Global Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Wilson to Coach United States Team
description: RON WILSON, coach of the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim, was named yesterday to coach the United States team for the first World Cup tournament, which begins in late August. Wilson was selected by LOU LAMORIELLO, the general manager of the Devils, who is in charge of the United States team.

title: Uganda Gets to Vote
description: Ugandans voted today for a Parliament for the first time in 16 years in balloting that barred party affiliations. All 814 candidates ran as individuals; a constitution approved in November set a goal of a new nonparty Parliament.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jet Ski Tests May Be Delayed
description: In a last-minute move, the Legislature approved a bill yesterday that would delay for one year a plan to require jet skiers to pass a safety test. A bill enacted in January requires anyone operating a personal watercraft to take a boating safety course or pass a written test starting July 1. Legislators say they have been swamped with calls from people who say they cannot find a place to take the test or have had to wait in long lines. The measure goes to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who has not stated a position. JOE SHARKEY

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Harsher Penalties Advance
description: The Assembly approved two bills yesterday that would let judges substantially increase penalties for repeat criminal offenders. One measure would allow a judge to classify an adult sentenced for a sex crime as a repeat offender, subject to mandatory prison terms, if the offender had committed a similar crime as a juvenile. Currently, juvenile records cannot be considered in adult sentencing. The second bill would let a judge double the jail time and fines for a crime committed while a person is out on bail for another offense.

title: In the Kremlin, Chickens Still Come Home to Roost
description: In the Kremlin, what goes around comes around, with a vengeance.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Serena's Song to Carry a Big Load
description: D. Wayne Lukas will be back in town today to run another star at Belmont Park: Serena's Song, the champion 3-year-old filly of last year, who will carry high weight and low odds tomorrow in the $200,000 Hempstead Handicap.

title: Keeping Saudi Arabia in Perspective
description: The simplest explanation for Tuesday night's bombing in Saudi Arabia, which killed 19 Americans, may turn out to be the correct one. We should not be surprised if the attack was carried out by people from the same indigenous group of militants responsible for the bombing of a National Guard building in Riyadh last November.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DONNA KARAN INTERNATIONAL INCREASES OFFERING PRICE
description: Donna Karan International Inc. priced its initial public offering yesterday at $24 a share to raise $258 million for the New York fashion design company. The concern sold 10.75 million shares, a 50 percent stake, with about half of the proceeds going to original investors. The company, valued at $513.6 million, raised its price range to $23 to $25 a share from $20 to $23. Some $58 million of the funds raised are expected to go to Ms. Karan, her husband and her children; another $58 million would go to the Takihyo Group, which is the company's second- biggest owner, and an additional $90 million would go to pay debt. The rest will be used for general corporate purposes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Nordic Track Inc., Chaska, Minn., a unit of the CML Group, to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle advertising for the North American retail stores division, previously handled by Market Resource Inc., Hanover, Mass. Billings were estimated at $5 million. Draft Direct Worldwide, Chicago, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., continues to handle direct marketing.

title: On the Trail of 3 Elusive Serial Killers
description: Crime-weary New Yorkers felt a sense of relief this month when the police arrested three men accused of an array of violent crimes, including the Zodiac serial killings, a wave of brutal robberies of elderly people in the suburbs and the vicious beatings of four women, one fatal.

title: Officer Is Held in Plot to Kill Dallas Football Star
description: In a city crazy for news about its Super Bowl champion Cowboys, it was both sensational and disturbing when the Dallas football team's All Pro wide receiver, Michael Irvin, was arrested earlier this year on drug possession charges.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Art in Review
description: Jayce Salloum "There Was and There Was Not" American Fine Arts 22 Wooster Street, near Canal Street SoHo Through July 13

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's a case of yellow type, red face. Right on the cover of the current issue of Ms. magazine, the feminist publication, is a misspelled word, and the word is "feminism." The cover line, in bold yellow type, reads "Mothers and Daughters: Honest Talk About Feminisim & Real Life."

title: Group Destroys Serial Killer's Possessions
description: Belongings of Jeffrey L. Dahmer, including tools he apparently used to torture and kill many of his 17 victims, have been destroyed, a civic group said today.

title: U.S. and Japan Whaling Requests Rebuffed
description: The United States today withdrew a proposal for limited whaling rights for an American Indian tribe, and Japan lost its ninth consecutive bid to be allowed to carry out some whaling despite a worldwide ban.

title: Art in Review
description: Thomas Joshua Cooper Sean Kelly 43 Mercer Street, at Grand Street SoHo Through July 19

title: In America;Blinders On Birth Control
description: To get a sense of why it is so tough for Bob Dole and the Republicans to catch up to Bill Clinton despite the President's daily dose of public humiliation, consider a legislative amendment that is about to be offered by Representative Ernest Istook, a Republican from Oklahoma.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED DOMINION MAKES OFFER FOR COMMERCIAL INTERTECH
description: United Dominion Industries said yesterday that it had made an offer of $27 a share in cash for the Commercial Intertech Corporation, a manufacturing company in Youngstown, Ohio. Shares of Commercial Intertech fell 25 cents, to $19.125, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange before the offer was disclosed. United Dominion, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., said that the total consideration it was offering was about $500 million, including assumption of debt. United Dominion manufactures engineered products for industrial and building markets.

title: Witness Links Top Clinton Aide to Conspiracy
description: The prosecution's main witness in the second Whitewater trial testified today that Bruce R. Lindsey, a top Clinton aide, insisted that large cash withdrawals by the 1990 Clinton campaign for governor be illegally concealed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No one has ever mistaken the Barbie doll for a bona-fide feminist, but Barbie's juggernaut continues to chug along through the decades, no matter what the prevailing attitudes on the image of women.

title: ITT and Planet Hollywood to Develop Casinos
description: The ITT Corporation hastened the convergence between Hollywood and Las Vegas yesterday by announcing that its Caesars Palace gambling unit had agreed to develop several big casinos with the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Prison Law Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE OVERVIEW;U.S. Commanders at Saudi Base Defend Efforts to Avoid Attack
description: As the bodies of the 19 American servicemen killed in a terrorist bombing here on Tuesday were flown home today and F.B.I. investigators sifted forensic evidence at the explosion site, American commanders defended the precautions they had taken to protect the base against terrorism.

title: Cooperstown: Safe at Home
description: THIS may not be your recreational fantasy, but it is mine: You wake up in a small village on a pristine morning, a midnight storm having cleared the air and left it clean and aromatic. You climb on a bicycle and cruise around the corner and down Main Street, around the traffic circle, past the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, and before you know it, you are out of town, on the quiet, gently sloping road heading north along Lake Otsego.

title: Jane Howard, a Biographer Of Margaret Mead, Dies at 61
description: Jane Howard, a writer whose works included a widely praised biography of Margaret Mead and a close look at the dynamics of families, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61.

title: ART REVIEW;Darts and Fusillades From the Sewing Basket
description: Three strong summer group shows of art by women are bound together by some loose connective threads. All three highlight artists of an older generation, and all three include work in which cloth -- woven, embroidered, cut and stitched -- plays a central role.

title: 8 Lives Left, 5 Cats Get New Homes
description: The world can seem an endless story of bad luck and pain, and then, suddenly, something extraordinary happens. A heroine emerges, a young mother named Scarlet.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXCITE AND MCKINLEY TO COMBINE INTERNET DIRECTORIES
description: Excite Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the McKinley Group, the creator of the Magellan Internet guide, in the first consolidation of leading Internet directories. The companies said the deal, valued at $18 million, would position Excite as the second-largest Internet search and directory service, behind Yahoo Inc., which pioneered the concept two years ago. Excite, based in Mountain View, Calif., said that the deal would combine its reviews of 60,000 sites on the World Wide Web with 40,000 on Magellan. Under the preliminary agreement, Excite will trade 1.2 million of its shares for the closely held McKinley, based on its stock price in the last 30 days, and assume an unspecified amount of debt. Shares of Excite fell 25 cents, to $8.25, well below their initial public offering price of $17 a share in April.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel and Banks Agree on a Debt Swap
description: Eurotunnel and its creditor banks have agreed on the principle that part of the English Channel tunnel operator's debt be swapped for shares, Eurotunnel's co-chairman, Patrick Ponsolle, said yesterday. The British-French company and its banks have also agreed that interest due on the rest of the company's debt will then be reduced, he said.

title: Sports of The Times;Gymnastics Buys Time For Stars
description: BELA KAROLYI remembers how Olympic gymnastics teams were chosen in Romania, back when there was an Iron Curtain. The coach would wait until the day the rosters were due and he would point his finger and say: "You. You. You."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Deutsch is Selected By EMI-Capital Music
description: The EMI-Capital Music Group North America unit of Thorn EMI P.L.C. said yesterday that it had named Deutsch Inc. in New York as the first agency to handle national corporate broadcast advertising. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Patrick Quigley, senior vice president for marketing at EMI-Capital in New York, said the decision to select Deutsch came after a three-month informal review; he declined to disclose the other participants.

title: POP REVIEW;Soaring on Passion, Rooted in Gospel
description: Aretha Franklin's voice was in its glory when she sang at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. From sultry low notes to an airborne, carefree soprano, she regularly swooped through a range of more than two octaves. She could land right on the beat with a fervent emphasis, or she could dodge around the beat like a feather in a breeze. And she was the queen of melismas, turning a syllable like "love" into a spiraling cascade of notes, lavish and impassioned. If anyone had forgotten, she proved herself yet again as one of America's greatest vocal improvisers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the formation of a Roman Catholic health-care network in the New York region misstated the number of included hospitals and nursing homes. There are 15 hospitals and 16 nursing homes, not 9 and 22.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Heidi Fleiss: Hollywood Madam 1995. BMG. $92.99. 106 minutes. No rating.

title: Fed Is Not Expected to Lift Rates at Meeting Next Week
description: The Federal Reserve will probably not raise interest rates when its policy-making body meets next week, economists said today, but that call will be an unusually difficult and close one on both economic and political grounds.

title: A Sequel to the Suspense Tale of Shakespeare & Company
description: Two weeks after announcing the imminent demise of their Upper West Side literary haunt, the owners of Shakespeare & Company now say that the neighborhood bookstore may actually survive because of potential cost-cutting measures and an unexpected surge in business.

title: ART REVIEW;Exploring the World's-Fair Mentality
description: Like Barbara Kruger and Jenny Holzer, Dennis Adams has long used the tools of advertising to excavate the public unconscious. His site-specific photo-sculptures, typically called interventionist, consist of big, emotionally charged transparencies, aglow with a literal inner light, placed in such public amenities as bus shelters, kiosks and even pissoirs that are usually designed by the artist.

title: Advertising;Advocacy groups for gay men and lesbians turn the tables and employ mainstream agencies.
description: AS more mainstream marketers hire agencies that specialize in aiming sales pitches at homosexuals, advocacy organizations that address issues of interest and concern to gay men and lesbians are turning to mainstream agencies for campaigns.

title: ART REVIEW;After a Furry Teacup, What Then?
description: After a fur-lined teacup, what do you do for an encore? That was a problem for the German-born artist Meret Oppenheim (1913-1985), who created this famous Surrealist icon in 1936, when she was barely 23. Such whirlwind success -- the Museum of Modern Art almost immediately snapped up and exhibited the teacup -- proved difficult to handle. The sudden burst of fame, it seems, contributed to a major depression that descended on Oppenheim the next year and stayed with her for nearly two decades.

title: Debt Crisis in the Third World
description: President Clinton and the leaders of six other industrialized countries will devote much of their meeting this week in Lyons, France, to the terrorist attack in Saudi Arabia. But Jacques Chirac, the President of France, is rightly insisting that the summit meeting also grapple with the troubling problem of third-world debt. As many as 20 countries have reached debt levels so high that they are shut out of international capital markets and cannot climb out from under repayment burdens. The seven leaders agree debt relief is needed soon, but they disagree over how to provide it.

title: FILM REVIEW;She Wants Him Back, Without the Roommate
description: Who knows why Sonke Wortmann's mildly entertaining sex farce, "Maybe . . . Maybe Not," has become one of the highest-grossing German films in history. Is it because the movie was adapted from a popular late-80's German comic book? Or is its depiction of a group of homosexuals as lecherous gorgons camping it up in clownish drag all it takes to tickle the German funny bone? Or is Til Schweiger, the actor portraying Axel, a young man who becomes the heart's desire of almost every gay man and straight woman to cross his path, the European heartthrob to end all European heartthrobs?

title: No Headline
description: We just wanted something where we wouldn't be humiliated."

title: Ronald P. Lynch, 60, Investor Who Fought Corrupt Practices
description: Ronald P. Lynch, a mutual-fund executive who led a successful industry campaign to curb improper trading practices, died at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn., on Wednesday. He was 60.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Giving X-Ray Eyes And Togas Their Due
description: Although American film has its high-art tradition, a true appreciation of Hollywood movies requires an affection for the many humbler genres that together constitute the core of American film making. Nobody understands and appreciates genre better than Martin Scorsese, a director who is also a collector and restorer. And a new 76-film series, "Scorsese at the Movies: The Martin Scorsese Collection at the Museum of Modern Art," which begins today at the museum and continues through Sept. 12, offers an opportunity to study genre through the eyes of a passionate fan.

title: Legislature Passes New Tax Deduction
description: After two years of cutting income taxes, the New Jersey Legislature approved a new state budget tonight that would allow homeowners to deduct a portion of their property taxes on their income tax bills.

title: Home Video
description: 'Near Video' From Afar

title: 30-Year Mortgage Dips
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.29 percent this week, down from 8.30 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the lowest average since May 30, when rates averaged 8.03 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.98 percent, up from 5.93 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.82 percent this week, up from 7.81 percent a week earlier.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Industrial Output Gains in Japan
description: Japan's industrial production increased a preliminary 2 percent in May from the previous month on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said yesterday. May's output rose a preliminary 2.3 percent from a year earlier on an unadjusted basis, the ministry said. The ministry also said that industrial output was on a gradual rising trend despite high inventory levels, an assessment that was unchanged from the previous month. (Reuters)

title: Diner's Journal
description: Artusi is the first name of the Italian gastronome Pellegrino, who wrote "Science in the Kitchen and the Art of Eating Well" (1909).

title: F.D.A. Approves Gilead's Drug for AIDS Patients
description: Gilead Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company, said today that it had won final approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing a drug for the treatment of an infection that causes blindness in AIDS patients.
