description: In percent

title: City's Largest Trash Hauler Sold to Investor
description: In the latest shake-up in New York City's garbage-disposal industry, an investment firm with no experience in the business yesterday bought the city's largest carter -- V. Ponte & Sons, whose principal owner is under indictment on racketeering charges.

title: Utility Support For Electric Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Boston Edison Corporation said today that they had agreed to develop an infrastructure to support electric vehicles in the Northeast and to market the vehicles to utilities and governments in the region.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Advance in Thin Trading
description: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, helped by end-of-the-quarter buying by portfolio managers.

title: FILM REVIEW;Where Nothing Is What It Appears To Be
description: Vive l'Amour" was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 23, 1995. The film, in Mandarin with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Nine Years in Fatal Crash
description: Donald S. Hinrichs 3d, 23, convicted last month of aggravated manslaughter for crashing into a disabled car while drunk and killing two teen-agers after their high school prom in April 1995, was sentenced in Superior Court yesterday to nine years in prison. At the sentencing, Mr. Hinrichs apologized to relatives of the victims, Joseph Berry, 18, and Tania Mokienko, 17.

title: Prying Open the Japanese Shareholder Meeting
description: Shortly after 10 A.M. today, Tomiichi Akiyama, Sumitomo's president, opened the annual meeting at company headquarters in Osaka with a lively "Good Morning."

title: Co-op of Growers Denies Guilt In Case of Ex-Cabinet Member
description: An agricultural cooperative pleaded not guilty today to bribery in connection with accusations that it plied former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy with gifts to get preferential treatment.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IVAX SEES DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS FOR SECOND QUARTER
description: The Ivax Corporation said yesterday that it expected earnings for the second quarter to fall "significantly short" of recent periods because of price cuts and the sluggish pace of reorders for its generic drugs. Ivax stock plunged $8.625, to $15.25, on volume of more than 11.9 million shares. Ivax said that some customers had established significant inventories of its drugs and that it had cut some prices. As a result, earnings for the Miami company before any special one-time costs would be between 6 cents and 8 cents a share in the quarter ending on Sunday, the company said. In the comparable period of 1995, Ivax earned 24 cents a share.

title: Close, but Still No Budget, Albany Says
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders emerged from a three-hour negotiating session on the long-stalled state budget this evening saying they were making progress but still trying hard to enact a spending plan by July 4.

title: Kamsky Sails Steadfastly To a Draw
description: It took only eight moves yesterday for Gata Kamsky to steer the adjournment session of Game 11 in his world championship match with Anatoly Karpov smoothly to a draw. He thus once again showed what a tough defender he is.

title: BASEBALL;Orioles Refuse to Panic Over Midseason Series
description: The Baltimore Orioles are either blessed or cursed with great patience and a belief in the sanctity of a 162-game season.

title: Critic's Choice/Dance;From Paris, Love Considered Anew
description: The Paris Opera Ballet's season at the Metropolitan Opera House provides a drastic change of pace from "La Bayadere" tonight with the United States premiere of "Le Parc" by the experimental choreographer Angelin Preljocaj.

title: Florida Court Gives Go-Ahead For a Cigarette Liability Suit
description: The Florida Supreme Court today narrowly upheld a state liability law widely viewed as a significant legal threat to the tobacco industry.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Steel Is Cited In Krupp Profit Drop
description: The German steel and engineering company Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp said yesterday that its profit in the first half of 1996 had fallen to around 200 million marks ($131 million) from 223 million ($146 million) a year earlier. The company's chairman, Gerhard Cromme, in a speech prepared for the annual shareholder meeting, said the profit drop was mainly attributable to the company's steel division, which suffered price and volume declines. (Reuters)

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: My Life and Times With Antonin Artaud 1995. Fox Lorber. $89.98. 93 minutes. French with English subtitles. No rating.

title: Campus Fight Leads Reebok To Modify a Shoe Contract
description: Several months ago, Reebok International and the University of Wisconsin at Madison reached tentative agreement on a sports product contract. Similar to arrangements between other universities and manufacturers of athletic shoes and apparel, the contract provided for Reebok to furnish shoes to Wisconsin's intercollegiate teams and to receive in exchange the right to use the university's name and logo on Reebok athletic clothing.

title: Park Ave. Doctor Is Arrested in Sale of Tranquilizer Prescriptions
description: A psychiatrist supposedly known as Dr. Cash to clients who lined up by the dozens outside his Park Avenue office, often drinking beer from cans in paper bags, was arrested on Wednesday afternoon in an undercover operation and charged with selling prescriptions for a controlled substance, the tranquilizer Xanax.

title: Black Officials Unify In Bid to Defeat Mayor
description: The meetings have been held for months, in churches, in offices and in restaurants, and virtually every black elected official in New York City has attended one or more of them. The agenda is always the same: figuring out how to register more than 250,000 voters, create a "get out the vote" effort and, finally, defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Toyoake Journal;Sumo Wrestlers (They're BIG) Facing a Hard Fall
description: When sumo wrestlers hurl their blubbery bodies at each other like fighting buffalos, it is the quicker, the stronger and heftier who is supposed to heave his rival out of the tiny ring.

title: CABARET REVIEW;Making the Final Note Count
description: It was just 30 years ago that Kenny Rankin introduced his seductive fusion of folk, jazz and pop crooning on a beautiful, nearly forgotten album called "Mind Dusters" (Mercury). Building songs by Bob Dylan, Fred Neil and other folk songwriters into trailing musical cloud castles, he seemed to be the gentlest and most romantic of the era's hippie Pied Pipers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police Chases Take a Toll
description: One-quarter of the 1,237 reported police chases of vehicles in New Jersey last year ended in accidents, in which 243 people were injured and eight killed, The Record of Hackensack reported yesterday. Innocent civilians were involved in 145 of the accidents, accounting for 61 of the injuries and 3 deaths, according to statistics for 18 counties released by the State Attorney General's office. Three counties -- Essex, Hunterdon and Mercer -- did not report data. The most recent fatality was a Bergen County teacher, Stephanie Carroll, 39, killed last week when a purse snatching suspect being chased by police through Oradell crashed into her car.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE SAUDIS;West's Uneasy Presence: Infidels or Protectors?
description: Switch on Saudi state television on any Friday and you are sure to see a panoply of preachers -- officially approved and even paid by the Saudi Government -- routinely referring to Christians and Jews as "infidels," "atheists" and "usurpers of Muslims."

title: General Motors Reported to Be Studying Consolidation Of Engineering
description: The General Motors Corporation is quietly preparing a broad shift in how it engineers cars, including the likely development of an immense complex of laboratories and offices to house tens of thousands of engineers now scattered across southern Michigan.

title: Given Tools, They Work the Language
description: I grew up in the southwest Virginia coal fields in a big family of storytellers who, my mother liked to say, would rather "climb a tree to tell a lie than stand on the ground and tell the truth." I spent my childhood hanging around the Buchanan County Courthouse (where my granddaddy was the treasurer) and at my daddy's Ben Franklin dime store right across the street. I heard a lot of stories.

title: ON BASKETBALL;No Longer Trapped by the Stuff Dreams Are Made Of
description: Wes Moore attended his first National Basketball Association draft Wednesday night.

title: Tishman in Brazil Venture
description: Tishman Speyer Properties L.P. said this week that it would enter a joint venture to construct a $175 million, 36-story office building in Sao Paulo, Brazil. The company, based in New York, signed an agreement with Metodo Engenharia S.A., a Sao Paulo construction company. The building would be the tallest in Brazil, Tishman Speyer said. The project will be financed by Funcef, a Brazilian pension fund. Construction is to begin late this year. "Our goal is to leverage our presence in Sao Paulo to build our real estate business, not only in Brazil, but in select markets throughout Latin America," said Jerry I. Speyer, Tishman Speyer's president and chief executive.

title: CBS Adding a Spanish-Language Channel
description: Signaling a long-delayed expansion into cable television, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and its CBS subsidiary announced yesterday the acquisition of Telenoticias, a Spanish-language, 24-hour news channel now distributed in more than 20 million homes in 22 countries.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Fighting Adversity, On Their Own
description: A good solo dance has magical powers that enable one person to work a multitude of wonders onstage. Some of the solo's manifold possibilities were revealed on Tuesday night when the American Repertory Dance Company made its East Coast debut as an attraction of this summer's American Dance Festival.

title: Schools Head Plans to Bar 15 Members On 3 Boards
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will bar 15 school board members -- all of them incumbents re-elected in the May 7 elections -- from returning to their seats on Monday because they were on three boards that had been suspended for charges of misconduct and corruption.

title: Nuclear Test Ban Negotiators to End Talks Without a Treaty
description: An international conference that has been meeting intermittently for 18 months to complete a treaty banning all nuclear testing will end on Friday without an agreement, arms control officials from several countries said today.

title: Candidate Dole and Wife plan a 2-Dayt Coast-to-Coast Book Tour as the Authors Dole
description: Bob Dole is trading in the campaign trail for the book tour.

title: TV WEEKEND;Annals of American Indian Families
description: Television entertainment doesn't pay much attention to the struggling poor. Understandably so. Poverty isn't an uncomplicated diversion. The bright-eyed brain-deads on most sitcoms and just about all commercials are a far easier sell. So an occasional effort to get beyond cookie-cutter bromides tends to get deserved encouragement.

title: Abroad at Home;Mr. Clinton's Victims
description: The American Constitution has endured as long as it has for a reason given by the great Chief Justice John Marshall, in McCulloch v. Maryland in 1819. The Framers, he said, set out only the "great outlines" of the structure they were creating. They did not try to pin down every detail -- a course that would have produced a document with the "prolixity of a legal code," and too rigid to last.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;With the Draft Over, Trading Season Begins
description: Although the National Basketball Association draft has ended, the trading has not.

title: House Panel Rejects California Dam Plan
description: A House panel today rejected a proposal to build a $1 billion dam on California's American River to protect Sacramento from floods and backed a cheaper plan to shore up existing levees.

title: Democrats' New Goal in Congress: Modesty
description: Congressional Democrats are at a critical transition in their struggle to regain control of the House. They have prospered in the polls, so far, with a full-throated attack on the Republican agenda. Now, in a campaign begun this week after months of planning and research, Democrats are trying to redefine their own party and convince the voters that it deserves another chance in power.

title: G.M. to Raise 1997 Vehicle Prices 1.7%
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that prices for its 1997 model vehicles would rise by only 1.7 percent, on average, putting pressure on its rivals to hold down the prices of their cars and trucks.

title: Perot's Party Adds 2 States in Bid for Ballots
description: Ross Perot's Reform Party extended its reach to 20 states yesterday after Arizona granted it a place on the 1996 Presidential ballot and leaders of New York State's Independence Party announced that they had joined forces with Mr. Perot's movement and planned to lend it their top spot on the Nov. 5 ballot.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAB HOLDINGS AND CHESAPEAKE IN BAGEL DEAL
description: BAB Holdings Inc., which operates 131 Big Apple Bagel stores in 26 states, agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Chesapeake Bagel Bakery, which operates 137 units. Terms of the proposed transaction were not disclosed. BAB Holdings, which is based in Chicago, said that Chesapeake Bagel, based in McLean, Va., is the fourth-largest bagel chain in the United States, with units in 26 states and the District of Columbia. Chesapeake Bagel's 1995 revenues were $9.4 million. After the acquisition, BAB Holdings would become the nation's second-largest bagel chain, with 268 units in 31 states. The largest chain is the Bruegger's Corporation, a unit of Quality Dining Inc. Shares of BAB Holdings rose 62.5 cents, to $11.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CLINTON EXPECTED TO SUPPORT PATAKI ON MEDICAID SHIFT
description: The Clinton Administration signaled this week that it is prepared to approve New York's ambitious plan to place nearly three million more poor people into managed care programs, but indicated that it would do so only if the state first satisfied several concerns about the availability and quality of the medical care.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Penguins Re-sign Johnston
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins have signed Coach EDDIE JOHNSTON and General Manager CRAIG PATRICK to new contracts.

title: Not All Aboard: A Big Rail Merger and Its Critics;Sidetracked Since '13, Plan Still Raises Antitrust Fears
description: Talk about your rocky romances. Born as rivals seeking to build the biggest stretch of the first transcontinental railroad in the late 1860's, the Union Pacific and Southern Pacific railroads came close to marriage by the turn of the century only to have their union scotched in 1913 by a disapproving Supreme Court.

title: Company Briefs
description: HARSCO CORP., Camp Hill, Pa., said it would merge its Sherwood brass-fittings division into the Taylor-Wharton Gas Equipment division to cut costs and add marketing channels for both businesses. The merged businesses would have more than $300 million a year in revenue.

title: Space Mission Surveys Moon Near Jupiter
description: The Galileo spacecraft swooped within 524 miles of the solar system's largest moon, Ganymede, early today, training 9 of its 10 instruments on the planet-sized chunk of icy rock.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Wednesday about a decision to allow a coyote hunting season next February misstated the limit imposed by the State Fish and Game Council. Each licensed hunter will be permitted to kill two coyotes a day, not two for the whole season.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Wallace to Attempt Truck Racing
description: RUSTY WALLACE's boss asked him to make a delivery this weekend in Nazareth, Pa., with the company pickup truck, and Wallace will oblige. His boss is ROGER PENSKE, part owner of Wallace's Winston Cup team. The pickup is the Ford that Wallace's brother KENNY usually races in the Nascar Craftsman Truck Series. And what Penske wants Rusty Wallace to deliver is a lot of paying customers when the trucks race at Penske's Nazareth Speedway for the first time on Sunday.

description: Federal Reserve Seen Holding Rates Steady The Federal Reserve will probably not raise interest rates when its policy-making body meets next week, economists said, but that call will be an unusually difficult and close one on both economic and political grounds.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: ONE FAMILY;Dead Pilot's Kin Recollect Earlier Brush With Death
description: Capt. Christopher J. Adams, the Air Force officer who was one of 19 Americans killed in the terrorist bombing in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday, barely escaped another fatal attack there three years ago, his relatives said today.

description: If Jo Lasorda didn't believe in miracles before, she does now. And she can say with a degree of certainty that even though her husband had a heart attack, he'll be "better than ever."

title: U.S. Is Upbeat On Chip Deal With Japan
description: In a private half-hour session here today from which their key aides were excluded, President Clinton and the Japanese Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, appeared to lay the groundwork for a settlement of a highly contentious trade issue: extending one of the largest accords between the two countries, governing trade in computer chips.

title: Michigan Asks U.S. to Approve Work-for-Welfare Plan
description: The State of Michigan asked the Clinton Administration today for permission to undertake a vast welfare overhaul whose central provision would require work in exchange for benefits.

title: House Defeats a Move to End China's Favored Trade Status
description: The House defeated an effort today to revoke China's broad trade privileges with the United States.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BARNES & NOBLE TO BUY STAKE IN CANADIAN CHAIN
description: The bookseller Barnes & Noble Inc. plans to buy a 20 percent stake in Chapters Inc., Canada's largest bookstore chain, its majority shareholder, Canadian General Capital Ltd., said yesterday. Financial details of the deal were unavailable. The deal did not include a management role for Barnes & Noble, which is based in New York and which operates more than 1,000 bookstores. Chapters has 375 stores.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Another Revamping At True North
description: True North Communications Inc., which owns agencies including Foote, Cone & Belding, announced yesterday another revamping of top management that included two executives being stripped of their responsibilities, two promotions and a formation of a committee to focus on resolving a fractious dispute with Publicis S.A. over a joint-venture European agency network.

description: A sports listing on Wednesday for the National Basketball Association draft that night misstated the cable network televising it. It was TNT, not ESPN.

description: The confluence of events made it seem as if New York City were being refurbished from the top down.

description: For Bryan Berard, comparisons to the Rangers' Brian Leetch are inevitable. Both players are offensive-attacking defensemen. Both are from New England. Both wear No. 2 on their jerseys.

title: Restore More Child Welfare Aid
description: Gov. George Pataki's budget, which is still being debated, restores some of the money to child welfare programs that disappeared last year when New York State cut its contribution by 25 percent. But there will still be serious shortfalls, and New York City, which has the state's largest child welfare system, would be hurt more than any other community.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;From Page to Screen, a Frisson
description: CERTAIN words and phrases flow effortlessly between French and English. As a vibrant new film series suggests, scandale and crime passionnel may be the most entrancing of them. Simone Signoret looks as young and beautiful as she ever did in an updated version of Zola's "Therese Raquin." She also has an unusual look of freshness and innocence, at least until she takes a lover and becomes an accomplice in her husband's murder. Jean Gabin, as a railroad engineer, becomes a sympathetic victim of his own uncontrollable lust for murder in another Zola update, Jean Renoir's great "Bete Humaine." And sprinkled among all this dark passion are a delicate wit and sense of l'amour as play. "I feel as young as the Eiffel Tower," says an aging, turn-of-the-century ladies' man, standing before that newfangled monument in a rarely seen version of "Gigi," with dialogue by Colette herself.

title: 9 Are Charged In Cable Scam
description: Nine people in four states have been charged with stealing 16,000 cable-television converter boxes and illegally selling equipment that allows viewers to receive premium cable-TV channels.

title: Gains Seen At L.I. School Taken Over By the State
description: Almost six months after the Roosevelt, L.I., school system became the first in New York history to be taken over by the state, officials are reporting significant academic gains.

title: Judge Blocks Giuliani's Cancellation of Agency's Contracts
description: Saying that the Giuliani administration had abused its authority, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the city could not unilaterally bar from contracts a nonprofit agency that is at the heart of a Federal investigation into the city's contracting process.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WMS INDUSTRIES SHIFTS FOCUS TO ELECTRONIC GAMES
description: WMS Industries said yesterday that it would spin off its casino in Puerto Rico and reduce its pinball machine operations to focus on electronic entertainment games. The company, based in Chicago, also said that it would sell 15 percent of its video games business to the public. WMS said it planned to take a charge for an undisclosed amount that would lead to a loss in its fourth quarter, which ends on Sunday. A year ago, WMS earned $6.2 million, or 26 cents a share. Yesterday, shares of WMS rose $2.125, to $24.125.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Taking Business To the Movies
description: Apple Computer Inc. is going to the movies again with a campaign tied to the 20th Century Fox film "Independence Day," which is being modeled on an Apple campaign last month tied to the Paramount Pictures film "Mission: Impossible." Separately, Mercedes-Benz is joining with MCA/Universal and Amblin Entertainment for worldwide marketing and promotions for the movie "The Lost World," the sequel to "Jurassic Park."

title: GOLF;Norman Shoots a 64 And Shares the Lead
description: Greg Norman staged a late charge and shot a six-under-par 64 today to match Joe Daley for a share of the lead in the first round of the Greater Hartford Open.

description: THE CHOICE By Bob Woodward Illustrated. 462 pages. Simon & Schuster. $26.

title: About Real Estate;Retirement Housing for Affluent Suburb
description: A three-story motel that has been a fixture on Ledge Road here for 30 years will soon be bulldozed to make way for a retirement community for people age 65 and older, a first in this affluent Fairfield County suburb.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Sheffer Eager to Try N.B.A.
description: DORON SHEFFER said yesterday that he was surprised and "very excited" that the Los Angeles Clippers selected him in the National Basketball Association draft and that he hoped to be the first Israeli to play in the league.

description: NBC Sports has agreed to a five-year contract to telecast games of the new women's league created by the National Basketball Association. NBC will not make an upfront rights payment, but will share revenues with the N.B.A.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALUMAX TO SELL MOST OF FABRICATED PRODUCTS OPERATION
description: Alumax Inc. agreed yesterday to sell most of its steel and aluminum fabricated products business for $245 million to Euramax International Ltd., a new British company held by venture capital affiliates of Citicorp. Analysts had expected Alumax to shed assets and focus on its core aluminum processing operations after it had rejected a $2.5 billion takeover bid from the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation. Alumax, which is based in Norcross, Ga., plans to sell 30 plants and service centers in the United States and five plants in Europe. The plants manufacture roofing materials, siding and rain gutters. The businesses to be sold have annual sales of $500 million and employ about 2,100.

title: 25 and Under
description: India has a vast culinary repertory, but you wouldn't know it from the Indian restaurants of New York City. The menus seem to have been duplicated at the same copying store: tandoori, curry, mulligatawny and the rest, most derived from the Mogul cuisine of the north.

title: Families Face A Sad Start In Shelters;Placement Center Life Is Dirty and Fearsome, But the Residents Cope
description: On her 12th day at the temporary homeless shelter, Tanya Capers sat cross-legged on a twin bed in her sweltering room on the third floor, braiding her daughter Erika's hair as the 3-year-old played with a stuffed animal called Dog. With half of Erika's hair woven tightly against her scalp, Ms. Capers walked across the room and peered down into a wooden crib, where her 1-year-old daughter, Tanya, is supposed to sleep.

title: NYC;Strolling The Avenue Of Renaming
description: NOBODY strolling on Worth Street seemed aware of it yesterday, maybe because the signs had yet to be put up. But the stretch of that thoroughfare between Broadway and Centre Street was designated Avenue of the Strongest by the City Council this week.

description: The British retailer Boots Company P.L.C. said yesterday that it would carry out a program to repurchase up to L300 million ($462 million) of its stock.
