title: The Spoken Word
description: SEIZE THE TIME: AN AFTERNOON WITH BOBBY SEALE," Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building, 163 West 125th Street, Harlem. The founder of the Black Panther Party will be interviewed by Flo Kennedy, a lawyer. Tomorrow at 4 P.M. Sponsors include the Museum of African American History and Arts, the Harlem Media Center and the International Agency for Minority Artist Affairs. Free. Information: (212) 749-5298.

title: TENNIS;Era Ends As Edberg Takes His Final Bow
description: There wasn't any sun to set on him, so Stefan Edberg, the last of the genuine touch volleyers, ended his Wimbledon career on a note of doom and gloom with a second-round loss tonight.

title: Consolidated Cigar Offering
description: Mafco Consolidated Group Inc.'s Consolidated Cigar Holdings Inc. unit has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public public offering of about 15 percent of its common shares.

title: Art in Review
description: Albert Chong Throckmorton Fine Art 153 East 61st Street Manhattan Through July 20

title: Spy Agencies Faulted for War Focus
description: American intelligence agencies devote too much time and money to supporting the military, and far too little to understanding the problems of peace, a new and authoritative critique concludes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DUTCH BANK PLANS TO ACQUIRE CNBC BANCORP
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding N.V. said yesterday that it would acquire the Chicago-based CNBC Bancorp, the holding company for Columbia National Bank of Chicago. Terms were not disclosed. Columbia National Bank has $850 million in assets and 280 employees. After the takeover, it would become part of the ABN Amro LaSalle banking group, which has total assets of about $15.6 billion.

title: U.N. Court, for First Time, Defines Rape as War Crime
description: A United Nations tribunal announced today the indictment of eight Bosnian Serb military and police officers in connection with rapes of Muslim women in the Bosnian war, marking the first time sexual assault has been treated separately as a crime of war.

title: Which Japanese Appetite Do Whales Feed?
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 Injured as Shots Ring Out at an Overcrowded Concert in Harlem
description: About 30 people were injured in Harlem last night when gunshots set off a panic in a large crowd that spilled far past the bounds of a plaza where some of the biggest names in popular music were performing free.

title: Trenton State Gets New Name and a Battle
description: Despite bitter protests from many students, faculty members and alumni, the trustees of Trenton State College voted 8 to 0 yesterday to change the school's name to the College of New Jersey.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;N.B.A. Negotiations Continue
description: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and the players union held negotiating sessions yesterday that lasted into the late-night hours. The duration of the talks indicated that progress was being made, and the two sides were expected to meet today in Manhattan.

title: Inside Art
description: Grosvenor House Opens Up

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FIGURE SKATING;A Variant Gene in Fallen Skater
description: The Olympic figure skater Sergei Grinkov had an inherited genetic variation that may explain his death from a heart attack last year at age 28, researchers at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore said yesterday. They proposed calling the variation the "Grinkov risk factor."

title: Pilots' Words Before Crash Show Calm In Emergency
description: A recording released yesterday of the conversation between air traffic controllers and Valujet Flight 592 shows that the pilots and controllers reacted quickly and, given the emergency created by smoke in the cockpit and passenger cabin, relatively calmly.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Donadoni Gets a Breather
description: ROBERTO DONADONI has been granted a vacation in Italy by the MetroStars following a long season with AC Milan in the Italian League and the national team of Italy and three games in Major League Soccer. The star midfielder will miss Sunday's game in Columbus and possibly the next game, in Denver next Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday about fabric showrooms misstated the address of Scalamandre. It is at 942 Third Avenue (56th Street), not 934 Third Avenue.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Church Group Seizes Suspect
description: A minister and two vanloads of churchgoers chased and tackled a man who had just robbed and beaten a woman in Newark's East Ward yesterday afternoon, the police said. A Newark police detective, Ronald Arbuckle, said the vans were leaving the parking lot of a restaurant where they had stopped after a funeral when the parishioners, from a Brooklyn congregation, heard screams. They then saw a man running from a warehouse carrying a cash box, the detective said. Crawling after him was Carolyn Rodrigues, 30, a warehouse employee who the police said was severely beaten while attempting to fight the robber.

title: Doctors Back AIDS Tests for Pregnant Women
description: In a surprising turnaround on an explosive issue, the American Medical Association today endorsed mandatory testing of all pregnant women and newborns for the AIDS virus.

title: INSIDE
description: Accusation on Clinton Funds

title: Easier Passage
description: Several New York City toll bridges now offer drivers the prospect of relief from endless waiting in line. An electronic payment system lets cars slide through toll plazas while a scanner reads the vehicle's identity and deducts the toll from a credit account. Eventually, that will mean no more fishing for "exact change," less waiting time and reduced air pollution.

title: Doctors Discover New Worm, One That's Lethal to Humans
description: Scientists in California said today that they had discovered what they believe is a previously unknown parasitic worm that can be fatal to humans.

title: BASEBALL;Late August Timetable Set by Cone
description: His face flushed, his optimism boundless and his shoulder apparently pain-free, David Cone continued to express confidence yesterday that he could return to pitch for the Yankees later this season. Even as Manager Joe Torre reiterated his belief that Cone might not be ready until mid-September, the rehabilitating pitcher disagreed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;It's a Mystery Why Wallace (No. 18) Wasn't Picked Earlier
description: He has no trouble explaining why he overslept and missed a team flight. He says the reason he did not interview with the Celtics was partly their fault. But falling to No. 18 in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft after two high school seniors? John Wallace had never been this late for anything.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: What the Butler Sang

title: Gaza Dissident Is Freed
description: A prominent human rights advocate in Gaza who has harshly criticized the Palestinian Authority has been released after 18 days of detention, rights groups said today.

title: Genentech Wins Round in Growth Hormone Patent Battle
description: Genentech Inc. won a round today in its long-running patent battle to block rival drug companies from selling competing products similar to its genetically engineered human growth hormones, Protropin and Nutropin, in the United States.

title: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE SECURITY;Saudis Rebuffed U.S. Efforts To Interrogate 1995 Bombers
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Defense Department were refused permission by the Saudi Government last month to interrogate four confessed Saudi terrorists whose information might have helped foil this week's bombing in Saudi Arabia, Administration officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCHE TO BUY P.& G.'S SHARE OF JOINT VENTURE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that Roche Holding of Switzerland would buy its half of the their United States joint pharmaceutical venture. The deal would give Roche worldwide rights to the pain reliever Aleve and to Femstat 3, a vaginal yeast-infection treatment, both of which P.& G. marketed in the joint venture and would continue to sell in the United States for up to a year. While the terms of the sale were not disclosed, P.& G. said it would record an after-tax gain of $120 million from the transaction in the fourth quarter. The company, based in Cincinnati, entered into the joint venture in 1988 with Syntex Laboratories, which Roche bought in 1994. Shares of P.& G. fell $2.25 yesterday, to $91.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TV SPORTS;An Odd, Fictional Clan In ESPN's Newest Ads
description: Meet the happy ESPN family: the sons, Chris Berman, Tom Jackson, Joe Theismann, Chris Mortensen and Sterling Sharpe, the stars of "N.F.L. Countdown." And their dad, Harry Dean Stanton, star of the movie, "Repo Man."

title: Market Place;The Stratosphere in Las Vegas comes down out of the clouds.
description: TRATOSPHERE, eh?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Wickes Reports Chairman's Resignation
description: The British home improvement retailer Wickes P.L.C. said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Henry Sweetbaum, had resigned after the disclosure of inaccuracies in the company's accounting. Wickes also said Stuart Stradling intended to resign as finance director upon completing an investigation into the matter. Mr. Stradling told Bloomberg Business News that the accounting irregularities appeared to have been deliberately hidden.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Big Wonderful Guy With a Thin Inner Devil
description: In "The Nutty Professor," Eddie Murphy makes his overdue comeback -- with a vengeance. Thanks to the mind-boggling morphing and makeup effects that are the film's impressive highlight, Mr. Murphy is able to become Sherman Klump, a shy, gentle 400-pound lonely guy. It's an amazing transformation, and Mr. Murphy handles it with real skill. Instead of merely clowning, he becomes a warm, fully formed character, unrecognizable as the old Eddie Murphy unless you look straight into his eyes.

title: BASEBALL;Rogers Is On Again as Yanks Keep Their Distance
description: Roberto Alomar swung and missed on one of Kenny Rogers's clever fastballs so badly last night that his usually potent black bat slipped out of his hands, slid across the grass and rolled toward the mound. It was a strange sight coming from the leading hitter in the American League, and it was about as close as Baltimore came to seriously denting Rogers on a night when the enigmatic pitcher performed as if he might deserve George Steinbrenner's $20 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;End Nears for Hudson Police
description: The proposal to eliminate the Hudson County Police Department took a big step forward yesterday when the county Board of Freeholders voted 8 to 1 to close the 82-member department to save about $3 million a year. After a required public hearing, the Freeholders are to cast a final vote on July 11.

title: Politics, Passion and Graft at Issue in Rio Slayings
description: When Paulo Cesar Farias, who was the campaign treasurer for the former President, Fernando Collor de Mello, was found shot to death in bed with his girlfriend on Sunday, the police and his family labeled the deaths a crime of passion. But developments since then have raised the idea of a political motive and brought in federal investigators.

title: BASEBALL;Clark Wants Indians To Take Notice
description: Mark Clark has a goal. Actually, it is more like a vendetta.

title: OPERA REVIEW;With Anne Sexton's Help, a Grimmer Shade of Grimm
description: Opera's war with words seems unrelieved even when the words in question are English to begin with. Not even supertitles give us peace; more and more, we find them translating not only from someone else's language to our own but from English into English as well. Britten's stage works are a prime example; so demanding are the subtleties of harmony, orchestration and vocal line that without some help, ordinary listeners lack the necessary room to make full sense of texts.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Coach's Rape Conviction Overturned
description: The Rhode Island Supreme Court yesterday overturned the conviction of a former Brown University track coach sentenced to 15 years in prison after being found guilty of raping one of his athletes.

title: SFX Adds FM Station
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc. has acquired the radio station WROQ-FM in Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C., for $14 million from ABS Greenville Partners L.P. The acquisition gives the broadcaster, based in New York, its third FM station in the Greenville-Spartanburg market, where the company will have 32 percent of listeners.

title: This Suit (a Well-Worn Petite) May Have Been Joan of Arc's
description: Pierre de Souzy, an antiques dealer, bought the suit of armor two and a half years ago from a Parisian collector whose family had owned it for more than 200 years.

title: New Jersey Passes Another Cut in Taxes
description: After two years of cutting income taxes, the New Jersey Legislature approved a new state budget last night that will allow homeowners to deduct property taxes on state tax returns. In the first year, families will save about $73. But when the plan is fully phased in two years from now, some will save far more. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was expected to sign the budget today.

title: FILM REVIEW;What's a Mother to Do?
description: DEMI MOORE arrives in "Striptease" amid a flurry of talk about her haircut, her salary, her naked ambition and her G-string (not necessarily in that order). In light of that attention, Andrew Bergman's "Striptease," which is no "Showgirls" but rather a blithe, easygoing film version of the hilarious novel by Carl Hiaasen, may well leave audiences wondering what all the fuss is about.

title: OLYMPICS;Roethlisberger Back on Top As Compulsories Hurt Others
description: They were the last men's compulsories in the history of the Olympic gymnastics trials, but they were hardly the best in history.

title: Corrections
description: Two picture captions in Business Day on Monday with an article about minority groups in book publishing omitted credits. The photograph of Walter Mosley was by Jill Krementz, and of Terry McMillan by Jonathan Exley.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Greater Bookland store in South Portland, Me., is hoping to avoid a horror story when STEPHEN KING arrives for a book signing on Sunday. The Associated Press reported yesterday that, to insure order, King readers will be charged $50 for a reservation.

title: Veto Threat Follows Vote to Kill Program
description: Republican efforts to scrap Federal financing for President Clinton's Americorps volunteer service program would lead to a certain veto of the $84 billion spending bill that contains it, the White House said today.

title: Jack Reynolds, 62, a Journalist With NBC
description: Jack Reynolds, a broadcast journalist with NBC television for more than 30 years, died on Tuesday at Fairfax Hospital in Fairfax, Va. He was 62 and lived in Great Falls, Va.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Kittles Won't Have to Carry the Load for the Nets
description: There is this side of Kerry Kittles, the part of him that seems as soft and as quiet as cotton. And this is the worrisome part.

title: FILM REVIEW;Sneering on the Outside, Whining on the Inside
description: For someone who has just completed a gilded Ivy League education, the post-graduate descent into the real world can be a humiliating fall from grace. How is an incipient master of the universe supposed to feel when forced to take a low-paying temp job tearing and sorting credit-card slips for a Hollywood accountant?

title: The High Court Rejects Sex Bias
description: The Supreme Court's ruling this week that the Virginia Military Institute could not refuse to admit women and remain a publicly funded institution did not come as much of a surprise, given the cool reception the policy of exclusion received from the justices at a January hearing. What could not be fully anticipated, however, was the powerful eloquence and bold sweep of the majority opinion written by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and signed by five other justices. In what is sure to be remembered as one of this term's high points, Justice Ginsburg methodically rejected the stereotypes about women used by state officials -- and even more inexcusably by appellate-level Federal judges -- to justify denying women an important educational opportunity.

title: Lawmaker Tells of High Cost Of Keeping Secret Data Secret
description: The Federal Government not counting the Central Intelligence Agency -- spent at least $5.6 billion last year keeping secret documents secret, a member of the House intelligence committee reported today.

title: U.S. Discloses A New Method In Birth Control
description: Government scientists today declared that high doses of ordinary birth control pills taken soon after sex were a good way to prevent pregnancy.

title: CHICAGOANS SPLIT ON HOUSING PLAN
description: Dreamers and schemers have been talking and building big in this town for as long as memory. Nelson Algren, the city's poet of the down and out, once dubbed Chicago the "city on the make," a compliment and a curse nearly 50 years old. Now, along comes Mayor Richard M. Daley with a $1 billion whopper of a plan that could help transform public housing or, some fear, destroy it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALCOA OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENT INCENTIVES
description: The Aluminum Company of America has offered early retirement incentives to 3,600 employees, or 5 percent of its work force, in an attempt to cut costs. The incentives offered in letters this week included two weeks of pay for every year of service at the world's largest aluminum producer. Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh and has about 72,000 employees, is trying to cut $300 million from administrative and sales costs, which total $1.2 billion a year. Shares of Alcoa slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $57.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Minntech Advisory Sends Shares Down
description: The Minntech Corporation has advised its customers to stop using its Biocor oxygenator because of unexplained incidents of large pressure drops.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Climbs Near 110 Yen As Japan Rate-Rise Fears Ebb
description: The dollar rose to within a whisker of 110 yen yesterday, reaching its highest level in almost 29 months, as concerns about an increase in Japanese interest rates faded.

title: ROCK REVIEW;Bikinis, A Sign Festival Is Aging
description: One could tell immediately that Lollapalooza had lost its vision at the tour's opening show on Thursday at Longview Lake here, where over 20,000 people attended, several thousand short of a sell-out.

title: Kamsky Again Dodges A Karpov Onslaught
description: Anatoly Karpov tried the hyperaggressive strategy of luring Gata Kamsky on to attack and then eating him up yesterday in Game 12 of their world championship match. But it did not work when he ran up against Kamsky's ingenious stubbornness, and the two grandmasters agreed to a draw in 54 moves.

title: Mollie Beattie, 49; Headed Wildlife Service
description: Mollie H. Beattie, who resigned as director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service on June 6 because of failing health, died on Thursday at Grace Cottage Hospital in Townsend, Vt. She was 49 and lived in Grafton and Alexandria, Va.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about apartment rent increases in New York City mischaracterized a statement by the executive director of the Rent Guidelines Board, Douglas P. Hillstrom, about the findings of the board's staff regarding landlords' costs. While the staff reported that landlord costs had risen 6 percent in the last year, Mr. Hillstrom did not say those findings justified a rent increase; it is up to the board members, not the staff that Mr. Hillstrom heads, to determine what increase is justified.

title: THE SUPREME COURT;Excerpts From the Decision on Regulation of Cable Television
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding part of 1992 law regulating indecency on cable television while striking down two other provisions of that law. The vote in Denver Area Consortium v. Federal Communications Commission, No. 95-124 was one of highly fractured, shifting majorities. Justice Steven G. Breyer wrote a majority opinion. Joining Justice Breyer's opinion in full were Justices John Paul Stevens and David H. Souter. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor voted to uphold the law as it applies to public-access channels.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Envoys Are Skeptical On 4 Saudis' Confessions
description: American officials do not doubt that four Saudis who were beheaded last month were guilty of the fatal car bombing of an American target here last November. The officials do, however, believe that the defendants' public confessions were arranged by Saudi authorities, Western diplomats said today.

title: Chief Whitewater Witness Admits He Lied to Agents
description: Under harsh cross-examination, the prosecution's main witness in the second Whitewater trial acknowledged today that he had first lied to Federal agents when they asked him about whether he was involved in an illegal scheme to conceal large cash withdrawals from the 1990 Clinton campaign for governor.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Charged in Deadly Beating
description: A Plainfield man and two 16-year-olds were charged yesterday with beating a man with a lead pipe and stomping him to death, prosecutors said. Police were searching for three other teen-agers in the slaying of Edwin Ramos, 25, of Plainfield, who died early yesterday at Muhlenberg Hospital, said Edward M. Neafsey, the Acting Prosecutor for Union County.

title: Crew Facing Legal Action For Decision On 3 Boards
description: At a swearing-in ceremony on Thursday for newly elected community school board members from Brooklyn, Agnes Green, who had been re-elected to the District 17 board for her fifth term, heard her name called out by the master of ceremonies. She walked to the front of the meeting room at the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn to join the other winners, held up her right hand and promised to uphold the duties of her office.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Lasorda Expected to Go Home Soon
description: Los Angeles Dodgers Manager TOM LASORDA was resting comfortably yesterday while continuing to recover from a heart attack. Lasorda remained in stable condition at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif. The 68-year-old Lasorda had an angioplasty to unclog an artery on Wednesday, two days after suffering the heart attack.

title: Company Briefs
description: PACIFIC GATEWAY PROPERTIES INC., San Francisco, an office building developer with 3.9 million shares outstanding, received a proposal to be acquired for $5 a share in cash. The name of the bidder was not disclosed.

title: Frustrations Mount With Those for Whom the Tolls Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Soft Light of Summer
description: Horses

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRITON ENERGY TO SELL CRUSADER TO CLYDE PETROLEUM
description: The Triton Energy Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Crusader Ltd. affiliate to Clyde Petroleum P.L.C. for about $69 million, after Clyde increased its offer for Crusader, an Australian oil and gas company. Triton, an oil and gas exploration concern based in Dallas with a 49.9 percent stake in Crusader, said it expected a second-quarter gain of about $1.7 million and a third-quarter gain of about $8.6 million, after taxes, on the sale of 53.2 million Crusader shares. Clyde, a British exploration and production company, increased its offer to buy Crusader shares to $1.32 a share from $1.28, Triton said. Clyde has already bought 10 percent of Crusader's shares outstanding.

title: Wall St. Draws Record Fees in Stock Issues
description: As the stock market set records, Wall Street firms enjoyed their strongest stock-offering business in many years during the second quarter, reaping record underwriting fees of almost $3 billion.

title: A 'Tired' Yeltsin Is Absent Again
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin, whose grueling pace on the campaign trail has left many Russians wondering about his often troubled health, today canceled a public meeting for the third time this week.

title: Summit Meeting Endorses Plan Giving Police Freer Rein to PursueCriminals Abroad
description: The leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies and Russia endorsed a 40-point plan today to combat crime and terrorism that would, if fully carried out, give the police far freer rein to pursue criminals abroad.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Begin a Long Trip By Moving In on .500
description: Having won five of their last six games on a successful homestand, the Mets came to the Astrodome tonight looking to continue the momentum generated over the last week and inch closer to a .500 record. Hence the importance of getting off to a good start against the Houston Astros.

title: First-Quarter Growth Put Lower, at 2.2%
description: The economy grew at a slower pace than previously estimated in the first quarter, reflecting a lull in export demand, Government figures showed today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SMITH CORONA WINS COURT ORDER TO KEEP OFFER SECRET
description: The Smith Corona Corporation won a temporary restraining order yesterday that would bar a group from going public with information about an offer it made to buy the company. The lawyers for Smith Corona, which is based in New Canaan, Conn., argued in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., that Cannon T.& C. Ltd. had violated a confidentiality agreement by issuing public statements this week about its rejected bid. Cannon is a private investment concern that made the bid proposal along with Mara Fund Ltd. of New York and a Smith Corona shareholder, Max Resnick. In court yesterday, a lawyer for Cannon said the group had offered $3 a share for 30 million Smith Corona shares but had not secured funds for its offer. The shares of Smith Corona fell 1.25 cents, to 5 cents, yesterday.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: VICTIMS;Court Backs Statements by Survivors
description: Upholding new rights of crime victims in court, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a murder victim's survivors have a right to tell jurors "that the victim was not a faceless stranger, but was a unique individual human being."

title: No Headline
description: We're going to be playing offense for a change, instead of just defense."

title: Appeal Is Mandatory
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court rejected a request by a convicted murder to be executed, and instead ordered a new lower court review of his case. Exercising an option under New Jersey court rules, the inmate chose last fall not to continue to challenge his death sentence. Article, page 9.

title: The Guru Gap
description: Last week, in the same issue that excerpted Bob Woodward's account of Hillary Rodham Clinton's conversation with the psychologist Jean Houston, Newsweek reported that Dan O'Brien, an Olympic decathlete, had "found redemption" after he failed to make the Barcelona team. The magazine described how he had consulted a sports psychologist who trained him to "free up his mind" in order to focus better.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lonrho Drops Plan To Spin Off Mining
description: Citing tax complications, Lonrho P.L.C. abandoned a spinoff of its mining assets yesterday and said it would instead make a public offer of hotel and other assets worth as much as L1.3 billion ($2 billion). Lonrho has agreed to pay $389 million in cash for the Libyan Government's one-third stake in Metropole Hotels (Holdings) Ltd., a chain of five British hotels, in a deal that simplifies plans to list the hotels as a separate company.

title: In the Soft Light of Summer
description: Stump

title: C.I.A.'s Unsavory Ties
description: The Central Intelligence Agency knowingly hired as paid informers a number of Guatemalan military officers suspected of political assassinations, kidnapping and torture, a Presidential panel reported yesterday. It also found that several Guatemalan officers and officials covered up the military's role in the 1990 killing of an American citizen there.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Rider's Arrest Shakes Timberwolves
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves, riding an enormous boost from the draft-day trade that netted STEPHON MARBURY, suffered an embarrassing setback yesterday when ISAIAH RIDER was charged with possession of marijuana and possession of an illegal cellular telephone, both misdemeanors, after he was arrested Thursday in Oakland, Calif.

title: In the Soft Light of Summer
description: The Human Sacrament

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bridge
description: An upset was in the making when play resumed today at the International Team Trials, which determine the American teams in the world championships in October in Greece.

title: Aetna Delays Dividend
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which already plans to slash its annual dividend as much as 71 percent after it takes over U.S. Healthcare Inc., said today that it would not declare a quarterly dividend until the deal was complete. Aetna Life had paid a quarterly dividend of 69 cents a share, or $2.76 a year. Earlier this month, the company told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it planned to pay an annual dividend of 80 cents to 83 cents a share after it completed its $8.9 billion purchase of U.S. Healthcare. A merger vote is set for July 18.

title: From Tear-Stained Pupil To Exuberance on Toes
description: Nicolas Le Riche dissolved into tears in his first ballet class. Now, nearly two decades later, he is an etoile, a dancer of the highest rank at the Paris Opera Ballet. And tonight he will dance Solor, the hero of "La Bayadere," at the Metropolitan Opera House in a performance that is one of the most eagerly awaited of the company's New York season.

title: Americans in the Desert Now Wonder How Long They Will Stay
description: When the enormous bomb went off on Tuesday at about 10 P.M., killing 19 American servicemen, Ruth Rosser was making dessert for her husband, Tom. He had worked late at the Saudi company that employs him and provides his housing, in a foreigners' compound called Al Rushaid Village No. 3, less than half a mile northeast of the explosion.

title: Frustrations Mount With Those for Whom the Tolls Toll;Who All Is Counting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Circuit Stops Rush-Hour Trains
description: A short circuit on the Williamsburg Bridge yesterday morning left 5,000 people stuck aboard stopped subway trains for about an hour.

title: BASEBALL;Brogna Set for Surgery
description: From the moment that Rico Brogna arrived for spring training last February, ice bags and bandages were his daily companions. Arthroscopic knee surgery in the off season was followed by a sore back, a sprained knee and a sore shoulder.

title: Corrections
description: An excerpt on Thursday from the Supreme Court opinion striking down male-only education at the Virginia Military Institute characterized the institute's per-student endowment incorrectly. V.M.I. has the largest per-student endowment of any public college in the nation, not the largest of any college.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Security Tightened for U.S.-Saudi Game
description: A United States-Saudi Arabia exhibition soccer game is still on for tomorrow in Oneonta, N.Y., despite a terrorist bombing Tuesday that killed 19 Americans in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Officials said that security would be tightened for the game between the two Olympic teams that was scheduled long ago in conjunction with induction ceremonies at the National Soccer Hall of Fame in Oneonta. "We have taken the proper security precautions," said GIL MATTICE, a spokesman for the Hall of Fame. "Let's just say everything has been taken care of." Officials at the Oneonta Police Department and at Hartwick College, where the game will be played, also said that more than the usual precautions would be taken. (AP)

title: Why Concede Florida Seats to Republicans?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Atlantic City Thrives, Whitman May Call a Casino Bluff
description: With two powerful casino heads pulling in opposite directions, the Whitman administration has taken tentative steps this week toward calling the bluff of one of them, Steven A. Wynn, who has threatened to cancel plans for a $2 billion casino and resort unless the state builds a road to his property.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Rushing to Ruin Habeas Corpus
description: The antiterrorism bill passed in April by Congress seemed to present a direct challenge to the Supreme Court's powers of habeas corpus -- specifically, the power to order the release of prisoners it finds to have been unconstitutionally convicted.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3% Rise for Auto Insurance
description: The state Insurance Commissioner, Elizabeth Randall, approved a 3 percent increase yesterday in automobile insurance rates for the 4.37 million drivers in New Jersey. The increase was the minimum allowed under the state's insurance law. The state's 80 auto insurance companies are allowed a rate increase each year based on the rate of inflation. Companies are also permitted to apply for additional increases, and since 1993, the department has granted an average increase of 7.5 percent to nine insurers covering about 21 percent of the state's drivers, said Winnie Comfort, a spokeswoman for the Department of Insurance.

title: OLYMPICS: 20 Days to Atlanta 1996;No Surprise as Phelps and Dawes Lead Trials After the Compulsories
description: There were strobe lights and rock music in the Fleet Center tonight. There were loud screams from the crowd of 16,323, most of whom appeared to be teen-agers, and 14 consecutive renditions of Strauss's Die Fledermaus Overture.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;A One-Day Strike Shuts Air France Subsidiary
description: Air France Europe, a subsidiary of Air France, was hit yesterday by a one-day strike called by unions representing 75 percent of its work force, forcing it to cancel all flights. Eight of the airline's unions called the strike to protest plans to abandon 18 unprofitable routes and other cost-cutting measures. The strike comes two days ahead of the deadline tomorrow that Air France Europe has given the airline's pilots to accept a 15 percent pay cut. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Securities Regulation Bill Is Cleared by the Senate
description: Legislation reducing overlapping state and Federal regulation of the mutual fund and securities industries has cleared the Senate.

title: Unhappy Goodbye for Health Workers
description: Frank Lashley came to work at Metropolitan Hospital Center fresh out of high school and stayed 24 years. When he left, he figured, it would be because he wanted to, and his send-off would be filled with happiness and laughter.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Up and Down a Musical Scale of Personalities
description: Such is the freedom of expression enjoyed by jazz singers nowadays that the only formal impediment facing an ambitious performer is the physical limitations of his or her own voice. If you've got the chops, you can go anywhere and do anything, even change personality as often as you want.

title: Reporter's Notebook;Hungry for Respect, France's 2d City Puts On Its Best for Visitors
description: Lyons doesn't get much respect, either from the snooty Parisians or from foreigners otherwise entranced with France.

title: Judge Finds Hartford Failed In Efforts for Abused Children
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Connecticut is in violation of a 1992 court order to improve services for abused and neglected children and has ordered the state to take 20 corrective actions.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday, about film promotions involving consumer marketers, misidentified the manufacturer of the Z3 Roadster. It is made by BMW, not Mercedes-Benz.

title: Observer;Used to Talk, Now Shrieks
description: It's all about money now. I saw a man standing on the street corner talking into his cellular phone. He was talking about money. What other subject is there nowadays? If I had a cellular phone I, too, would take it out to a street corner and talk about money. I can hear me now:

title: Police Say a Drug Ring Offered Home Delivery
description: When customers call and arrange for delivery of a pie, is it because they crave a pizza?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Gemina Likely to Post 10% More in Losses
description: Gemina S.p.A., an Italian holding company, said yesterday that it was likely to restate its 1995 results to show a 10 percent increase in losses. The company's board convened late yesterday to vote on correcting the balance sheets to show a 694.5 billion lire ($448 million) loss, 63 billion higher than reported in May.

title: Shares of Donna Karan Soar In the First Day of Trading
description: Shares of Donna Karan International Inc. soared as much as 25 percent in their first day of trading as investors sought to cash in on the fashion designer's earnings prospects.

title: Keep Trucks Out of Saratoga Park
description: The mineral springs at Saratoga were first used by the people of the Iroquois Confederacy. Since early colonial days the waters have drawn visitors who came to relax in mineral baths. Today Saratoga Spa State Park includes a grand Georgian hotel, two race tracks, bridle paths, golf courses, a trout stream and a heron rookery. Saratoga is something of a cultural and social icon to New Yorkers. Its environment does not need more stress.

title: EXTREME SPORTS;In Newport, a Grunge Grand Prix
description: It's not easy to pick out the players from their public at the X Games. What about the kid who just jumped off the BMX bike at the gate? Or how about the young girl with the dark shades smacking gum and carrying a gym bag bigger than two third-graders?

title: Artists' Retreat Rejected
description: A deteriorating mansion on a remote barrier island will be leased to the highest bidder after the National Park Service rejected a proposal to turn it into an artists' retreat.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISCOUNT PERFUME RETAILER CONSIDERS GOING PRIVATE
description: Perfumania Inc. said yesterday that a management group had proposed taking the discount perfume retailer and distributor private by buying the shares it does not already control for $6 each. Under the plan, a company controlled by the chairman and chief executive, Simon Falic, and other executives would buy out other holders. In March, Perfumania, which is based in Miami, said it had hired Salomon Brothers Inc. to advise it on growth strategies, including the possibility of selling the company, which operates 197 retail stores in the United States in addition to a wholesale business. Shares of Perfumania gained 12.5 cents yesterday, to $4.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: New York Dominicans Strongly Back Candidates on Island
description: Arturo Ortiz left an assistant in charge of his car parts business on Audubon Avenue in Manhattan. Ramon Infante has taken time off from his job as a furniture salesman in the Bronx. The gypsy cab Demetrio Ortega normally drives is parked in a lot, awaiting his return to Manhattan.

title: Kremlin Machinations
description: It is hard to tell these days whether anyone is minding the Kremlin. Every hour seems to bring word of a new staff upheaval and some outlandish pronouncement by a Government official. In recent days President Boris Yeltsin conducted another of his periodic vanishing acts. With four days to go before the runoff election for president, the chaotic picture is alarming.

title: BASEBALL;Williams Is Relaxed With Son In Town
description: Bernie Williams did not consider last night's game with the Orioles just another evening at Yankee Stadium, and it had nothing to do with the opposition. Williams was excited and he was relaxed because Bernie Jr., his 5-year-old son who had serious surgery earlier this month, watched his father play center field for the first time since his emergency operation.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Albert Broccoli, Film Producer, Dies at 87
description: Albert (Cubby) Broccoli, who was a producer of the James Bond films, one of the most successful movie series of all time, died on Thursday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 87.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Pilobolus Dusts Off First Work
description: Pilobolus Dance Theater, the company named after a fungus, is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, and the dancing fungus is still frisky. That was demonstrated on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater in a program that traced the troupe's wild choreographic adventures over the years and suggested some of the artistic problems it has tried to solve.

title: Special Education 'Nightmare' Is Bureaucratic
description: To the Editor:

title: 15.9 Billion State Budget Signed Into Law by Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a new state budget into law today that lowers taxes for the third year in a row and reduces government programs in almost every state agency, with the Department of Environmental Protection facing the steepest cuts.

title: Lou G.'s Serves Last Meal To Its Saddened Regulars;A Garment Center Institution for 79 Years
description: For 79 years, it has been the Rick's Cafe Americain of the kosher set, a crossroads for garment center business deals, politics, matchmaking and schmoozing in an old-fashioned Jewish restaurant with the refinement of white tablecloths. Among the observant, everyone came to Lou G.'s

title: BASEBALL;Prospect Agrees to Terms
description: A representative for Jackson Melian said last night that the Yankees have agreed to a contract with the 16-year-old phenom from Puerto La Cruz, Venezuela. The contract includes a $1.6 million signing bonus and will be announced on Tuesday, the first day of baseball's international signing period.

title: Fidelity Changes Some Fund Managers
description: The Fidelity Investment Company said today that it had changed the portfolio managers on two of its select funds and created new positions to manage research in specific industries.

title: Giuliani Scolds State Over Harlem Concert
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized New York State officials yesterday for not consulting with the Police Department before allowing a free street concert on Thursday night in Harlem, at which about 30 people were injured. They were hurt when concertgoers fled in panic after shots were fired in the air. No one was hurt by the gunfire.

title: Albany Can't Duck Forever
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, is understandably frustrated by a Justice Department ruling limiting his power to bar corrupt officials from their seats on local school boards. But Federal officials are justified in invoking the Voting Rights Act to safeguard the rights of minority voters. The real culprits are in Albany, where the Governor and the State Legislature have failed to reform a community school board system that tolerates graft and kickbacks.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an appeal by President Clinton for an international campaign against terrorism misidentified Laura Tyson. She is chairman of the National Economic Council; she left the chairmanship of the Council of Economic Advisers last year.

title: CYCLING;Enlivening This Year's Tour Script
description: When Miguel Indurain sets off Saturday in the Tour de France, he will be a heavy favorite to win. What's new about that? He has easily won the world's greatest bicycle race the last five years.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Princeton Fights a Switch
description: Princeton University fired off letters yesterday to the former Trenton State College and the State Attorney General's office warning that it would sue if necessary to protect its original name, a spokesman said. Princeton was known as the College of New Jersey for its first 150 years, but in an effort to burnish Trenton State's image, its board adopted that name on Thursday.

title: Citadel, Bowing to Court, Says It Will Admit Women
description: In a quick response to a Supreme Court ruling earlier this week that the Virginia Military Institute must either admit women or not accept public money, the nation's only other state-supported, all-male military college, The Citadel, said today that it would admit women.

title: John Hanson, 88, Executive Who Built Up Winnebago
description: John K. Hanson, an indefatigable entrepreneur who built Winnebago Industries into a leading mobile home manufacturer, died on Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester, Minn. He was 88 and lived in Forest City, Iowa.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Character Adds Energy, And a Play Picks Up Bite
description: The last time the socialite named Nan Bemiss was spotted, on the stage of the WPA Theater in Manhattan in 1994, she seemed a likable but fundamentally silly creature: a walking photo op for Women's Wear Daily with a wistful, naive soul beneath her sophisticated surface. While the play in which she appeared, Paul Rudnick's "Naked Truth," eventually had her chanting obscenities and shedding clothes, the sense persisted that Nan remained a malleable sort of gal, ready to compromise in ways that befitted a politician's wife.

title: Fund Plans to Lend $50 Million For Jobs, Not Profit, in New York
description: A group of 50 major New York City corporations and business executives, led by Henry R. Kravis, the financier, said yesterday that they had raised $50 million for a new fund intended to make hard-eyed venture capital investments -- not for private gain, but to create jobs and promote economic development.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Surgery Sidelines Jones 3-6 Months
description: Dontae' Jones, the Knicks' third first-round pick in Wednesday's National Basketball Association draft, is expected to be sidelined for three to six months after undergoing surgery yesterday on his left foot.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMMERCIAL INTERTECH SOARS AFTER OFFER OF PURCHASE
description: The stock of the Commercial Intertech Corporation jumped more than 35 percent yesterday, after United Dominion Industries offered to acquire the company for $27 a share, or about $500 million. Shares of Commercial Intertech rose $6.75, to $25.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Commercial Intertech, based in Youngstown, Ohio, manufactures hydraulic systems, building systems and metal products. It operates 35 facilities with 4,500 employees in 10 countries. United Dominion, based in Charlotte, N.C., manufactures engineered products for the industrial and building markets. The company earned $77.3 million last year on sales of about $2 billion.

title: TENNIS;Just a Flick Of the Wrist Ousts Becker
description: When he woke up today in the spacious home he rents just beyond these Wimbledon walls, Boris Becker thought he would be safely through to the round of 16 by the time the predicted drizzle closed things down for good late this afternoon.

title: Police Seeking Motive in Plot To Kill Player In Dallas Case
description: Jealousy over a woman, perhaps even two, emerged today as one possible motive in the bizarre case of a Dallas police officer charged with trying to hire a professional killer to murder Michael Irvin, a marquee player for the Super Bowl-champion Dallas Cowboys.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: INDECENCY;HIGH COURT SPLITS ON INDECENCY LAW COVERING CABLE TV
description: In a splintered decision indicating deep fissures and great uncertainty over how to approach free speech in new media, the Supreme Court ruled today that operators of cable television systems may ban indecent programming from certain commercial channels but not from the community-access channels used by local governments and community groups.

title: This Isn't Brotherhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Faults C.I.A. on Hiring Of Informers in Guatemala
description: The Central Intelligence Agency knowingly hired as paid informers a number of Guatemalan military officers suspected of political assassinations, extrajudicial killings, kidnapping and torture, a Presidential panel reported today.

title: Time to Really Televise New York Legislature
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnam to Retain 3 Aged Leaders, for Now
description: After weeks of backstage wrangling, Vietnam's Communist Party has decided to keep its aged troika of top leaders in place, but to lighten their responsibilities and shorten their terms, a senior Central Committee member said today.

title: About New York;Moon, Spoon And Memories Of All That
description: COUPLES embraced and glided over the marble floor at the Cafe Pierre, the aroma of roses trailing them with each swirl past a huge, flower-packed vase. Over by the narrow, dimly-lighted bar, cigar smoke filled the air, the milky haze lending an ethereal aura to the half-dozen men who leaned back, smiled dreamily and looked absolutely smitten.

title: Divisions on Board Stall Hunt for SUNY Chancellor
description: A search for an interim chancellor for the State University of New York has bogged down over internal political divisions among the trustees, the late withdrawal of a favorite candidate and questions about another candidate whom some trustees had hoped to elect earlier this week.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: FREE SPEECH;Government Contractors Get First Amendment Shield
description: The Supreme Court today extended significant new free-speech protection to independent government contractors, ruling in two separate cases that people who haul trash, tow disabled cars or perform other functions under contract with government agencies have a First Amendment right to speak out on public issues or to back political candidates without reprisal.

title: THE SUPREME COURT;Excerpts From Opinion Upholding the Habeas Law
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's unanimous decision today upholding a section of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 that limits state prisoners' Federal court appeal, on the understanding that inmates can still bring their appeals directly to the Court. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the Court. Justice David H. Souter and Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote concurring opinions.

title: 3 More Charges Are Added To the Federal Unabom Case
description: The Justice Department today named Theodore J. Kaczynski, the reclusive former mathematics professor, in three more attacks in the Unabom case.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Workers to Get Back Pay
description: About 450 former workers at a direct-mail distribution company in Carlstadt will be paid $400,000 owed to them when the company's plant closed abruptly June 14, under an agreement announced yesterday by the State Labor Department. Gene Herman, a spokesman for the department, said the company, Morcom Incorporated, had violated state law by failing to meet its payroll. Workers can pick up their checks at the plant on July 1 and July 2, he said. A Morcom spokesman described the four-year-old company as insolvent.

title: In the Soft Light of Summer
description: Spark

title: Gold Summitry: Dispute Threatens Aid to Poorest
description: LYON  Leaders of the Group of Seven nations clashed Friday over how to provide billions of dollars in debt relief for many of the world's poorest countries, with Germany objecting to a U.S. and British proposal for the IMF to sell off some of its gold reserves to help fund the plan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Is Split On Banning Smut on Cable The Supreme Court ruled that operators of cable television systems may ban indecent programming from certain commercial channels but not from the community-access channels used by local governments and community groups. Shifting majorities on the Court upheld part and struck down other parts of a 1992 Federal law intended to protect children from indecency on cable television.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SPRINGS AT NEW HEIGHTS AFTER NEWS OF PLANT CLOSINGS
description: Springs Industries said yesterday that it would spend $71 million to close three factories in South Carolina while increasing production in other plants. Springs Industries, based in Fort Mill, S.C., a maker of towels, curtains and bedding, said it was consolidating its operations to improve manufacturing efficiency. The company said it would try to find other positions for the 850 people who work in the plants in Kershaw, Columbia and Anderson, which are to be closed by the end of the year. Springs said it has about 22,000 employees and operates 48 factories around the country. Springs stock jumped $3, to $50.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Jobless Rate Rose to 3.5% in May
description: Japan's unemployment rate reached a record high in May as the recovery failed to create enough jobs for people flooding into the labor market. The jobless rate rose to 3.5 percent in May from 3.4 percent in April, data showed yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ITEX SHARES TUMBLE AS S.E.C. CONDUCTS INFORMAL INQUIRY
description: The stock of the Itex Corporation lost more than 21 percent of its value yesterday as the company reported that the Securities and Exchange Commission was conducting an informal inquiry about certain of its accounting policies and business transactions. Itex stock fell $1.25, to $4.625, in Nasdaq trading. Itex, based in Portland, Ore., operates the nation's largest barter exchange, with about 150 independent offices nationwide. The company said it believed the inquiry was a result of litigation with the Business Exchange International Corporation, a trade exchange.

title: Key Witness Asserts His Right to Silence In Inquiry on Files
description: The inquiry into the Clinton Administration's improper gathering of F.B.I. background files intensified today as a key witness invoked his constitutional right of silence and officials disclosed that the independent counsel's office had sealed a White House file vault to protect evidence.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Thomas Howard Wolf, a photojournalist and documentary maker, misstated the date of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, the day Mr. Wolf went to work for ABC. It was Nov. 22, 1963, not 1962.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Argentine Cloud Over I.B.M. Grows Darker
description: Allegations of bribery involving I.B.M. and Argentina's largest bank have escalated into a crisis that threatens to damage I.B.M.'s business and reputation here.

title: Resorting Priorities And Doing It in Bulk;Winners and Losers as Postal Service Changes the Rules for Business Mail
description: D-Day is looming for the Postal Service and its bulk-mail customers.

description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Current Account Deficit Narrows in Britain
description: Britain's current account deficit narrowed to L1.07 billion ($1.6 billion) in the first quarter, less than expected, while the shortfall for 1995 was revised lower, the Office for National Statistics said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Inflation Fear Falls, Sending Long Bond Up
description: Treasury prices surged yesterday as investors increased their bets that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates next week.

title: OLYMPICS;Safety of the Summer Games Still Worrying Organizers
description: Three weeks before the start of the Atlanta Olympics, security remains the biggest concern, Dr. LeRoy T. Walker, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, said today.

title: Juan Diego Lived
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about conditions at the Auburn Assessment Center, a shelter for the homeless in Brooklyn, characterized the medical staff's statements about the prevalence of childhood diseases imprecisely. They said ringworm and diarrhea were common among children generally; they did not suggest that these ailments were particularly widespread at shelters.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: HABEAS CORPUS;Justices Uphold Newly Set Limit On Federal Appeals by Inmates
description: Ruling unanimously and with unusual speed, the Supreme Court today upheld a new law's strict limits on Federal court appeals by state prisoners, on the understanding that the Supreme Court itself retains jurisdiction to hear these cases.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;N.B.A. and Players Union Reach Agreement
description: The National Basketball Association and the players union reached an agreement in principle yesterday to all terms of a six-year collective bargaining agreement. If ratified by the players, the agreement would avoid a second consecutive summer lockout and it would open the richest free-agent market in league history.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Austerity Plan For Workers Is Approved In Germany
description: Parliament approved major parts of an austerity plan today that would reduce workers' sick pay and job security in an effort to increase the competitiveness of the nation's industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SALE OF DASSAULT SYSTEMES SHARES RAISES $179.7 MILLION
description: Dassault Systemes S.A. of France said yesterday that the initial public sale of its American depository shares had raised $179.7 million. Dassault, a maker of software for computer-aided design, manufacturing and engineering, said the 7.8 million shares sold for $23 each, above the expected range of $19 to $21 a share. The shares closed $8 above the offering price, to $31, in Nasdaq trading All the shares were offered by current shareholders, and the company will receive none of the proceeds. Selling shareholders included Dassault Aviation, Dassault Industries and I.B.M.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Krzyzewski Signs 7-Year Pact at Duke
description: MIKE KRZYZEWSKI, who has led Duke to two National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament championships, has signed a seven-year renewable contract, university officials in Durham, N.C., said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Communists in India Cabinet

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAMSUNG TO ACQUIRE ADDITIONAL STAKE IN AST RESEARCH
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, the South Korean chip maker owned by the Samsung Group, said yesterday that it would buy $60 million of newly issued AST Research Inc. stock, raising its stake in the struggling computer maker to 49.9 percent from about 41 percent. AST also named Samsung's vice chairman, president and chief executive, Kwang Ho Kim, as its chairman. He succeeds Safi Qureshey, one of AST's co-founders. AST, based in Irvine, Calif., will use proceeds from the transaction to help pay off a $90 million promissory note held by the Tandy Corporation, based in Fort Worth. The note is related to AST's 1993 acquisition of Tandy's personal-computer-making operations.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel Wins a Late Reprieve
description: After a long struggle, the State Commission on Investigations was given an 11th-hour reprieve yesterday when Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation extending its life until 2002, The Associated Press reported. Critics of the independent agency had sought to put the commission under the control of the Attorney General's office. In the end, however, the measure imposed more modest restrictions. The commission will be required, for example, to submit all its reports to the Attorney General before releasing them publicly.

title: Beliefs
description: What happens when you blend a no-nonsense West Texas newspaperwoman with a devoted Presbyterian church official?

title: 2 Communists, The First Ever, Join Cabinet In New Delhi
description: India's President today inducted the first Communist ministers to serve in the Government since independence nearly 50 years ago.

title: THE SUPREME COURT: DEATH ROW;New Jersey Supreme Court Rejects Convicted Murderer's Request for Execution
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court rejected a request today by a 65-year-old death row inmate to be executed, and instead ordered a new lower court review of his case.

title: House Republicans Offer Campaign Finance Plan
description: Insisting that campaign finance legislation was not dead for the year, House Republicans today proposed a measure that would require candidates to raise the majority of their money in their own districts but would not diminish the role of big contributions by corporations, unions and the rich.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SYNC RESEARCH AGREES TO ACQUIRE TYLINK
description: Sync Research Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Tylink Corporation for 2.78 million shares and $4 million cash. Based on Sync's closing price Thursday of $13.75 on the Nasdaq stock market, the stock portion of the deal is valued at $38.2 million. Sync, based in Irvine, Calif., provides software for I.B.M. networks that link widely dispersed computers. Tylink, based in Norton, Mass., has developed high-speed communications products used for such wide-area networking. The shares of Sync rose 50 cents, to $14.25.

title: Sports of The Times;Wallace Is No Coleman
description: ONE night five years ago, John Wallace, then a high school senior, happened to be walking down Marshall Street in Syracuse with a friend who was a freshman on the Syracuse University basketball team. Wallace, a highly regarded player from Rochester, was on a recruiting trip to the school and taking in the sights. At that moment, there occurred a sight he'd never forget.

title: Gunman, 70, Kills Teen-Agers, Police Say
description: The police arrested a 70-year-old man who they say gunned down a teen-age couple in a crowded park and walked away chuckling.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Acting Chief's Past Queried
description: The Newark City Council is scheduled to vote Tuesday on whether to confirm Joseph J. Santiago as Police Director, but some members say they need more time to decide. On Wednesday, Mayor Sharpe James named Mr. Santiago to fill the job vacated by William R. Celester, who was indicted last week on corruption charges. Mr. Santiago, who is serving as acting chief, was convicted in 1993 of a disorderly-person offense for assaulting a jail guard, and in 1995 of using offensive and threatening language against a subordinate.

title: BASEBALL;Rivera Suddenly Looks Human and Yankees Lose
description: Mariano Rivera has been so reliable, he is almost robotic. Watch him swagger in from the bullpen, pump fastballs by batters while using his fluid motion and prevent the opposition from scoring. Last night, Rivera the robot malfunctioned, so the Yankees short-circuited, too.

title: Serbs' Leader In Bosnia Is Again Told To Step Down
description: As part of an intensifying Western effort to oust the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, the senior civilian official overseeing the peace accord has set a July 1 deadline for his removal from office.

title: Dole Repeats His Doubts That Tobacco Is Addictive
description: Despite the headaches that his previous remarks on tobacco have brought him, Bob Dole continued today to assert that tobacco may not be addictive for some people and the Federal Government should not regulate it. Young people, he said, should "just say no" to cigarettes.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Pistons Acquire Guard for Future Pick
description: The Detroit Pistons acquired RON RILEY, an Arizona State guard, from the Seattle SuperSonics yesterday for a second-round pick in the 1997 National Basketball Association draft. Riley, who was drafted No. 47 over all by Seattle on Wednesday night, is a 6-foot-5-inch, 205-pound shooting guard who has also played at small forward. He is the Sun Devils' career scoring leader with 1,834 points in 116 games. (AP)

description: FRANKFURT  John Schmid of the International Herald Tribune reported from Frankfurt:

title: Dmitrovskoye Journal;Mansions Muscling In On the Humble Dachas
description: It is the season of wildflowers, cabbages and beets in Russia. Each bright, endless day is a gift bestowed on millions seeking shelter in the countryside from the drab, hopeless streets of the city.

title: Justice Dept. Report Details Ruse by Immigration Aides
description: Forty-eight hours before a group of influential House members visited the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Miami operations last June, the top field managers of the agency's local district were panicking.

title: Bridge Rebuilt Despite Troubled Union Waters
description: A year ago, Dave Allan feared that his nonunion construction company had met its Waterloo at the Island Creek Bridge here at the southern end of a highway leading to Jones Beach. Now, he is claiming a hard-won and costly victory.

title: Campaign Financing Bill Deserves Oblivion
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Packers' Favre Leaves Clinic
description: Green Bay Packers quarterback BRETT FAVRE has completed treatment at the clinic where he was getting help for an addiction to painkillers, his agent said yesterday.

title: In a Milestone, Islamic Leader Is Turk Premier
description: Breaking a chain of secular leadership in Turkey since since the founding of the republic in 1923, the leader of the nation's Islamic party became Prime Minister yesterday.

title: Asbestos Fills Con Ed Plant As a Fire Rouses the East Side
description: A fire at a Consolidated Edison Company generating plant on the Upper East Side early yesterday spewed asbestos throughout the plant, sent black smoke through much of the neighborhood and rousted many people from their beds. No one was injured, and officials said tests indicated that no asbestos escaped from the plant.

title: Oklahoma Suspect Is Seeking To Suppress Search Evidence
description: Marife Nichols, wife of Terry L. Nichols, one of the suspects in the Oklahoma City Federal Building bombing, told a Federal court today that she did not understand her legal rights at the time she agreed to let Federal agents search the family's car and home in Herington, Kan.

title: Bratton Pays His Friends For Trips
description: In an effort to end a controversy, former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton sent checks totaling nearly $12,000 yesterday to Henry Kravis and several other wealthy friends who treated him and his wife to weekend trips while he worked for the city.

title: THE BOYS IN THE BAND';A Message With Little Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NATION;It Takes a Nixon . . .
description: THESE are days when, contrary to legend, Bob Woodward seems Richard Nixon's ultimate revenge on the capital city that drove him into exile. Mr. Woodward, the investigative reporter who teamed brilliantly with Carl Bernstein at The Washington Post in detailing the abuses of the Watergate felons, has ever since specialized in megabook writings that hardly arrive in town on little cats' feet.

title: A Question of Conscience
description: THE STATEMENT By Brian Moore. 250 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ Dutton. $22.95. THE German occupation of France and its factious fallout provide the raw material of Brian Moore's powerful new novel. Between 1940 and 1944, more than one in four of the 330,000 Jews living on French territory were deported. The majority were identified, arrested and shipped off by French administrators and the French police, without whose zealous cooperation German forces in France would have been unable to carry out the job. In a time of want, fear and national humiliation, few of the French cared about what happened to the Jews. While many individuals helped them (otherwise three in four would not have survived), many also denounced, pursued and robbed them. The drumbeat of official Vichy propaganda presented Jews as noxious parasites, and the church went along, fearing godless Communists more than godless Nazis. Some bishops -- and, in their wake, some priests -- denounced such injustice, but most Roman Catholics had other priorities. Objectively, the church, like its Vichy allies, shared in the vicious anti-Semitic policies of those dark years.

title: Participation in Pride Parade Marks Greater Acceptance for the Blue  and the Gay
description: Gay and lesbian police officers brushed the lint from their dress uniforms yesterday, polished their buttons and shined their shoes. Today, for the first time, members of the Gay Officers' Action League will be marching in full dress uniform, accompanied by the New York Police Department marching band and representing New York's Finest in the 27th annual Lesbian and Gay Pride March.

title: Harassing Hit Hard In Policy
description: IN the aftermath of two costly lawsuits, the Westchester County Board of Legislators wants the county to adopt a policy that states unequivocally that there will be zero tolerance of discrimination and harassment of county employees by their managers.

And elderly people tend to throw their nighttime sleep off schedule by napping during the day.

title: Foreign Affairs;Will the Center Hold?
description: On March 13, just after four suicide bombers blew themselves up in Israel, an extraordinary summit was held on the Sinai Peninsula, in Sharm el-Sheik. That summit brought together for the first time leaders from most of the Arab world and Israel to reaffirm that they were all in the same trench in fighting terrorism. What made the meeting so extraordinary was not simply the fact that Arab leaders came together to bolster Shimon Peres, but that it indicated a new alignment was forming in the Middle East -- a new moderate center. For the first time Arab states stretching from Morocco to Saudi Arabia were openly aligning with Israel and leaving Iran, Syria, Libya and Iraq on the sidelines.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;American Indians of Flesh, Blood and Hope
description: IN THE POPULAR IMAGINATION, American Indians have usually been defined in the past tense. There's a museum mustiness in the treatment of native peoples in films, an approach that tends toward over-reverent, one-dimensional characterizations, predictable story lines and nostalgia for the good old days of an Eden before European contact. From "F Troop" to the more recent well-intentioned but stultifying TNT cable network movies honoring native people past and present, Hollywood Indians generally lack the vibrancy and immediacy of flesh and blood human beings. They stand for ideas rather than have them on their own.

title: JUNE 23-29;Why Spy?
description: Everyone agrees that the Clinton White House did something wrong at the end of 1993 and the beginning of 1994: more than 900 confidential files, many on prominent Republicans, were improperly obtained from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But last week's public hearings before committees in both the House and the Senate failed to answer why the files were pulled.

title: INVESTING WITH: David L. King;Putnam New Value Fund
description: INVESTORS in pursuit of high returns typically chase after the stocks of the fastest-growing companies. They buy mutual funds that invest in all the usual suspects: fledging technology or health companies that are long on promise and short on history.

title: A Temple to the Present Leans Heavily on the Past
description: THE New Museum of Contemporary Art is a square, firm, well-made frame. The building will disappoint those who think that a contemporary art museum should be housed within an architectural wild child, a structure as provocative as the art it displays. But it should gratify those who revere Chicago as the first city of American architecture.

title: No Smoking' In Translation;South America
description: While smoke-free skies, trains, hotel rooms and restaurants are fast becoming the norm in the United States, tobacco smoke still wafts through much of the rest of the world. Eastern Europeans consider smoking an inalienable right; Parisian restaurateurs shrug as patrons puff away in areas designated no smoking; Italian efforts are focused on establishments that cater to Americans. Restrictions abroad in movie theaters and lobbies, on trains, planes and buses, vary widely. It can be a shock to American travelers to find that in Tokyo restaurants are cloaked in a tobacco haze (but commuter trains and subways are smoke-free) just as foreign travelers may be confounded by no-smoking rules in New York City. In South America and Mexico, smoke is still savored, but in Canada, opponents of smoking are pushing hard to clear the air. What follows are reports on where in the world people smoke, and where they don't.

title: World News Briefs;Ukraine's Parliament Adopts Constitution
description: Ukraine's Parliament has adopted the country's first post-Soviet Constitution after months of resistance from Communist lawmakers. Approval of the measure came in a 315-36 vote that ended a dramatic 23-hour session on Friday. The Communists, who form the largest faction in Parliament, had opposed the proposed constitution, resisting provisions that allowed private ownership of land and factories. They also demanded that the Russian language have equal status with Ukrainian.

In 1911, intrigued by the potential to accommodate multiple uses in a single framework, Theodore Starrett of the Starrett real estate family proposed a 100-story tower to house industry, business, residences and a hotel in a self-contained vertical city. But the idea of living as well as working in lower Manhattan became the exception rather than the rule; the skyscrapers that were built downtown were monolithic "cathedrals of commerce."

These children make up a special population who have been placed at Children's Village specifically for treatment in a controlled residential environment which is safe from conflict so that they may heal . . . any attempts to embroil them in a labor dispute are reprehensible.''

In the park and on Fifth Avenue, two people strutted with antique walking sticks. Two elegant bejeweled Russian wolfhounds took a Sunday afternoon dip in the Bethesda Fountain. Bottom, from left, Caribbean music groups held an impromptu jam at the 72d Street Band Shell. Some caught a breeze at an on-board barbecue at the World Financial Center. The Central Park Summerstage concerts drew a trendy young woman with a dyed yellow modified Mohawk cut and oversize white-framed sunglasses. A different kind of breeze cooled the couple on a Harley-Davidson in stars and stripes from Harley's new boutique on Lexington Avenue at 56th Street. title: DIARY: THE AUTO INDUSTRY;Looking Back, and Ahead, at General Motors
description: General Motors is like a lumbering ocean liner -- it doesn't exactly turn on a dime, or even a $100 gold piece. Still, a changing G.M. was clearly visible last week. It was out with the old, in with the new, and a touch of luxury for dessert. Out went that North Tarrytown, N.Y., plant (above), which had been on the brink of closing, it seemed, for years, and really did so on Friday. It was a plant that nearly spanned a century, making steam-powered cars starting in 1900 and Chevrolets since 1915, and it just turned out its last of those odd late-century creations, mini-vans. Also last week came a peek at the new G.M., as word leaked out about a radical plan to streamline a vast mix of offices and labs, putting engineers under one roof. G.M. wastes billions of dollars designing parts for all its many models, and the goal is to get parts designers working together. Finally, its flight of fancy: G.M., which owns half of Saab, got an option to buy the other half.

An import from soup-smoggy Asian cities, the O2 concept is air's answer to coffee baroque."You need oxygen more than you need spring water or organic food," insists O2 co-founder Lissa Charron, who hopes to sell the idea in New York, "but until now you couldn't get it unless you were flat on your back in an ambulance." Charron has much to say about oxygen's healing power -- for migraines, tired cells -- but doctors are erring on the side of skeptical grumpiness. "In terms of actual biochemistry," says Dr. Mark Greenwald, a Toronto asthma specialist, "it won't do a whole lot."

The sky was just beginning to darken beyond the 24th-floor windows of the Waterside Plaza apartment, but she couldn't see the East River below, or the needles of midtown, still sparkling to the west. She couldn't read the United Nations reports piling up or the legal brief that her husband, Rafael, was studying in preparation for the tenants' meeting. Macular degeneration had reduced the vision in one eye to near uselessness, then last Dec. 20 vision in the other eye disappeared as suddenly as if a shade had been pulled down.

title: Canada
description: While smoke-free skies, trains, hotel rooms and restaurants are fast becoming the norm in the United States, tobacco smoke still wafts through much of the rest of the world. Eastern Europeans consider smoking an inalienable right; Parisian restaurateurs shrug as patrons puff away in areas designated no smoking; Italian efforts are focused on establishments that cater to Americans. Restrictions abroad in movie theaters and lobbies, on trains, planes and buses, vary widely. It can be a shock to American travelers to find that in Tokyo restaurants are cloaked in a tobacco haze (but commuter trains and subways are smoke-free) just as foreign travelers may be confounded by no-smoking rules in New York City. In South America and Mexico, smoke is still savored, but in Canada, opponents of smoking are pushing hard to clear the air. What follows are reports on where in the world people smoke, and where they don't.

The great big-band vocalists -- Helen Forrest, Helen O'Connell, Fran Warren, Jack Leonard, et al. -- were paid to sing the lyrics. They got the words out clearly. Typically, a big-band arrangement featured four segments: full band, vocal refrain, instrumental solo and band again. Tommy Dorsey might begin with his own trombone solo, go on to a vocal by Leonard or Sinatra and an instrumental solo and then end with the full band.

title: Birdwatchers

Listed third with only two brief scenes is Gladys George (as a whining wife), while Sydney Greenstreet, Peter Lorre, Elisha Cook Jr. and Barton MacLane traipse in and out. Mary Astor's plum part almost went to Geraldine Fitzgerald, who woul dhave made a devastating Brigid O'Shawghnessey. The hitch? "A fight with Jack Warner," she said. Look closely at the furtive skipper who staggers in with the wrapped falcon; it's John Huston's actor-father, Walter. And guess who turned down Sam Spade, the role of a lifetime (for Bogart, above): George Raft. No fledging director (Huston) for him.

title: Science Fiction

Heinlein. Publishers who hail a promising new author as "the next Asimov" or "the new Heinlein" seem unabashed by the irony of promoting a fiction that makes its home in the future with blurbs that point to an ever-receding past. Without diminishing their role in shaping the genre, I think perhaps the time has come to acknowledge that modern science fiction is no longer defined by the best of Asimov and Heinlein -- whose most influential stories were published more than a quarter-century ago.
