title: BOOKEND;Way Off Broadway With Pamela
description: I am seated at a small table dead center in the Zany Brainy toy and book shop in a Rockville, Md., mall. In front of me, random 9-year-olds between Saturday soccer engagements, young mothers with babies and a few stray sister alumnae from Mount Holyoke College are assembling. "Meet Wendy Wasserstein, author of 'Pamela's First Musical,' in aisle 1," announces the store loudspeaker. Suddenly I wonder if we might draw a larger crowd if they also offered half-price Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles. When it's obvious that we will not be diverting any more audience from the Silly Putty or Creepy Crawlers section, I begin reading out loud from my new book for children. For a moment I have renewed sympathy for anyone who has ever demonstrated slicing and dicing cole slaw in the middle of a Grand Union. From now on, I will always pay complete attention. By the end of my story of a girl's first trip to a Broadway musical, one baby is crying, two pre-teen-agers are giggling and the four kids in the front row seem either in rapt attention or completely bored.

They had learned the Three R's -- Reduce, Reuse, Recycle -- and discussed how to stop their parents from using paper plates. For Earth Day they had read a Scholastic science publication, "Inside the World of Trash." For homework, they had kept garbage diaries and drawn color-coded charts of their families' trash. title: South America
description: While smoke-free skies, trains, hotel rooms and restaurants are fast becoming the norm in the United States, tobacco smoke still wafts through much of the rest of the world. Eastern Europeans consider smoking an inalienable right; Parisian restaurateurs shrug as patrons puff away in areas designated no smoking; Italian efforts are focused on establishments that cater to Americans. Restrictions abroad in movie theaters and lobbies, on trains, planes and buses, vary widely. It can be a shock to American travelers to find that in Tokyo restaurants are cloaked in a tobacco haze (but commuter trains and subways are smoke-free) just as foreign travelers may be confounded by no-smoking rules in New York City. In South America and Mexico, smoke is still savored, but in Canada, opponents of smoking are pushing hard to clear the air. What follows are reports on where in the world people smoke, and where they don't.

description: Blair Annette Mark, the daughter of Hedy Mark Winick of New York and Sherman Mark of Highland Park, N.J., was married yesterday at her parents' summer house in Ashley Falls, Mass., to Adam Blaisdell Casdin, a son of Sharon and Jeffrey Casdin of New York. Natalie H. Funk, a justice of the peace in Sheffield, Mass., officiated.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;Turkey in the Yard: A Wild Bird Moves Into the Suburbs
description: Linda Konwiser Brown is used to carrying a wide assortment of things on her mail route, which borders the South Mountain Reservation in Millburn. But nowhere in her job description does it say that she must occasionally carry a live wild turkey.

description: The Cable Guy Jim Carrey, Matthew Broderick, Leslie Mann Directed by Ben Stiller PG-13 91 minutes

title: OUTDOORS;A Special Spot for Angling, Undeveloped and Away From It All
description: Straddling the Maine-New Hampshire border in a sparsely populated region, 7,850-acre Lake Umbagog has a mercurial personality, placid one minute and covered with whitecaps a quarter of an hour later.

title: JUNE 23-29;Limitless Campaigning
description: The Senate killed this year's campaign finance legislation last Tuesday, burying a bipartisan proposal to voluntarily limit spending for Senate races and keep corporate and union money out of elections.

title: JUNE 23-29;Starving for Attention
description: WHILE Americans gobble down hamburgers and apple pie this Independence Day, somewhere in the country some patriot is celebrating his independence by going hungry. For reasons that mystify an increasing overweight populace, there has been an upsurge in the number of Americans willing to starve for attention:

title: In Egypt's Schools, Fashion Is Politics
description: JUST 15 years old, Doaa Hatem would be an outlaw in Egypt's public schools because she covers too much of her body with clothing. Other than the bridge of her nose and the flash of her eyelids when she blinks, not a spot of her skin is revealed, she says.

title: World News Briefs;North Korea Denies Holding U.S. Prisoners
description: North Korea denied today that it was holding American Korean War prisoners, calling an internal Pentagon report a "false rumor" that could jeopardize efforts to account for thousands of missing United States servicemen.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on June 16 for the Ramayana Ballet in Jogjakarta, Indonesia, misstated the information telephone number. It is (510) 729-6146.

title: THE NIGHT;Governor Campaigns For Beauty
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN was up to her hips in hip on Tuesday night. And she had no idea who made the red wool suit she was wearing.

title: 100 Teapots, Large and Small, Exuberant and Spare
description: MAKING tea for most means dropping a little bag into a cup of boiling water, producing a lightly colored liquid to be drunk a few moments later.

title: Q. & A.
description: Deducting Business Property

title: NOTICED;Life After Vamp: Look at These Nails
description: LIPS puckered, the model in a Virginia Slims advertisement is painting her nails with a garish shade of blue. "Does this look stupid on me?" the accompanying copy asks and immediately responds: "The correct answer to the question, is 'No.' " The cigarette's new slogan? It's a woman thing.

title: Columbia Trying to Show What a Gem It Is
description: Not long after Emily Lloyd decided to leave New York City government to become a vice president of Columbia University, she began noticing how rarely Columbia seemed to surface on the city's psychic radar screen.

title: Europe
description: While smoke-free skies, trains, hotel rooms and restaurants are fast becoming the norm in the United States, tobacco smoke still wafts through much of the rest of the world. Eastern Europeans consider smoking an inalienable right; Parisian restaurateurs shrug as patrons puff away in areas designated no smoking; Italian efforts are focused on establishments that cater to Americans. Restrictions abroad in movie theaters and lobbies, on trains, planes and buses, vary widely. It can be a shock to American travelers to find that in Tokyo restaurants are cloaked in a tobacco haze (but commuter trains and subways are smoke-free) just as foreign travelers may be confounded by no-smoking rules in New York City. In South America and Mexico, smoke is still savored, but in Canada, opponents of smoking are pushing hard to clear the air. What follows are reports on where in the world people smoke, and where they don't.

title: MUSIC;Grant Backs Free Pops in the Park
description: A MAJOR grant from Citibank has enabled the Westchester Philharmonic to present four outdoor concerts in July, all of them open to the public without charge. "We are happy to have designed Pops in the Park concerts to be responsive to our community's diverse tastes," said the music director, Paul Lustig Dunkel, "and are proud to present them to our county residents right in their own backyards."

title: To Be Young, Indian and Hip
description: JAY DABHI, 20, steps out of the dim red deejay booth, lights a Newport and scans his territory, the main floor of Planet 28 in Chelsea. It is just after midnight on a warm spring Friday, and the discotheque is thick with smoke and attitude. Over to the right, in front of the mirrored wall, an ex-girlfriend of Jay's in a retro halter, puckering her red lips around a red straw, tries not to gaze at herself. On the sidelines, young men sporting carefully pruned goatees stand in crescent-shaped clusters.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Serena's Song Running in 1995 Form
description: Serena's Song gave her first New York performance in eight months yesterday, sweeping the Hempstead Handicap by nearly four lengths and reminding people of how she raced to fame last year as the champion 3-year-old filly.

title: HOCKEY;On Eve of the Free-Agent Bonanza, Whither Gretzky?
description: July 1 is to hockey what Thanksgiving is to Christmas: the beginning of the shopping season. The wheeling and dealing accelerate when the annual crop of National Hockey League free agents comes on the market, and the rush begins at midnight tonight, under a full moon.

title: WEDDINGS;Katrina Abbott, Benjamin Lummis
description: Katrina Schermerhorn Abbott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Abbott Jr. of Manchester, Mass., was married at their house yesterday to Benjamin Rush Lummis, a son of Sheila Lummis of Greenwich, Conn., and John M. Lummis of Philadelphia. The Rev. Joel Baehr, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;Separatism Is In, Except for White Men
description: WHILE Virginia Military Institute hunkers down for the invasion of the Sister Rats, a coalition of women's colleges touts single-sex education in a brochure with the headline, "For Women, Coed Is Second Best."

title: Straight Talk on Accidents From Students
description: ELIMINATING accidents is the aim of 65 young people from 30 towns whose essays appear in a book on accident and injury prevention. The 96-page book -- ''Now I Know Better: Kids Tell Kids About Safety'' -- is published by the Children's Hospital at Yale-New Haven. The stories were submitted by students who were asked to write about an accident that happened to them or to someone they knew.

title: In the Region/Long Island;From Army Base to a Step Toward Home Ownership
description: AN experiment in helping people get off public assistance and into home ownership is under way on a quiet dead-end street of 16 two- and three-bedroom ranches built here in the 50's to house Army personnel.

title: BASEBALL;Person Pounded To End Met Streak
description: Just when the Mets were beginning to think of Robert Person as something more than a temporary fill-in, the rookie right-hander may have earned his return ticket to Class AAA Norfolk.

title: MUSIC;An Opera (and a Tenor) for a Summer Night
description: SUMMER, with its hazy holidays and inducements to relax and melt, is not the time for an opera company to schedule a world premiere or mount a production of "Wozzeck." Standard repertory, please. Listeners want to follow the familiar plot and go home humming.

title: Streetscapes/Prospect Park Boathouse;After a 1971 Restoration Fails, It's Time to Re-Restore
description: AT $1 million, the 1971 restoration of the Prospect Park boathouse was one of New York's first big preservation projects. The 1907 terra cotta facade was removed and replaced, even though glazed terra cotta was long out of regular use.

title: GOLF;Missing Zero on Ball Leads to Norman's Disqualification
description: For lack of one digit, a zero, on the Maxfli golf balls he had used during the first two rounds, Greg Norman disqualified himself today from the Canon Greater Hartford Open. Golf, whose code of honor among its elite players distinguishes it from so many sports today, again came up the winner. Norman announced this morning that he had no choice but to bow out.

title: Evicted Again, and Angry
description: Forty years ago, when the city was clearing houses in Queens to make way for the construction of the Long Island Expressway, Augustine Barry's parents were evicted from their home near what is now the Queens Center Mall. The Barry family settled in remote Hamilton Beach, a morsel of land near Jamaica Bay connected to Howard Beach by the Lenihan Bridge.

title: Dredge We Must. But First . . .
description: PEOPLE call it a ''dredging crisis.'' But while virtually everyone agrees that New York Harbor must be dredged to clear the rising shoals of silt and muck that clog its shipping berths and channels, the real dilemma lies in what to do with the stuff once it is dredged. What the harbor faces is not a dredging crisis but something much more familiar to New Jerseyans: a dumping crisis.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;$100 Mistake Gives Piers A Walkway
description: For Paul Barbara, the operator of the new marina at the Chelsea Piers recreation complex on the Hudson River, paying a $100 filing fee could have saved him the $200,000 he is spending to build a 10-foot-long walkway alongside his project.

title: From Small Beginnings to a Company With Millions in Sales
description: BACK in the 1930's, a pharmacist in Woodside, Queens, began sending product fliers to local doctors to try to increase sales. He knew that he would have to offer lower prices. What Henry Schein did not know, however, was that he had discovered a market that would transform his tiny business into the world's largest direct marketer of health care products and services to office-based practitioners.

title: This Time, a Quasimodo With Charm to Spare
description: Eraser

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about Dizzy Gillespie, with an article about classic photographs from the archives of The New York Times, referred incorrectly to the club in which he was shown playing the trumpet in 1955. Its identity is unknown; the Village Gate did not open until 1958.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: Shower singers of the future won't be singing "Hello, Young Lovers." They will be singing "Satisfaction," "Light My Fire," "California Dreamin,' " "I Heard It Through the Grapevine," "Blowing in the Wind" and hundreds of other standards of the rock era.

title: Keeping Legal Help Reachable to the Poor
description: DESPITE fears of restructuring legal services for poor people, a consensus among lawyers in the field seems to be building that, ''It's not as bad as we feared it would be.''

title: Wrong Approach to Teen-Age Crime
description: The anti-crime mantra of the day is that juvenile offenders are every bit as dangerous as adult criminals, and must be dealt with accordingly. Congressional Republicans propose to prosecute more juveniles as adults and loosen Federal mandates requiring that juvenile and adult prisoners be housed in separate facilities. Meanwhile, at the state level, juveniles who commit serious crimes are increasingly being tried in adult courts and getting stiffer sentences that must be served in adult prisons.

title: IN BRIEF;Bergen Freeholders Start Thinking Regional
description: In much of New Jersey, regionalization may sound like a dirty word. But two weeks ago, the Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders began discussing whether to place a non-binding proposal on the November ballot asking voters if they would favor sharing emergency services, police and local schools.

title: SOCCER;Germany Calls Up a Midfielder for Final
description: Stricken by injuries, Germany was allowed to call up midfielder Jens Todt today for Sunday's European championships final against the Czech Republic.

title: Indian Icons in All Their Fine Clothes
description: IN THE HEAVEN-REACHING temples of South India, bronze images of the deities are treated like next of kin who just happen to be kings and queens. Gently put to bed at night and awakened with music at dawn, they are bathed, dressed in fine silks and rocked in swings by the temple pool.

title: A Fixture at the Empire State
description: When Jack Brod moved into the Empire State Building, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was not yet President and Bob Dole was in the second grade.

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Why Our Pensions Aren't Really Portable
description: MILLIONS of Americans will never get their money's worth from their pensions because, in a very crucial way, the nation's pension system is hopelessly backward.

title: Atlanta and Izzy;No Medals for the Olympic Mascot
description: BOB COSTAS, the NBC sportscaster, has described it as "a genetic experiment gone horribly, ghastly wrong."

title: Boston University and City to Join Hospitals
description: The Boston City Council voted today to merge the city's public hospital with Boston University's private medical center to help keep the public hospital afloat in a time of tight budgets.

title: From Neil Young, Big Guitars, Smaller Statements
description: ON NEIL YOUNG'S NEW album, ''Broken Arrow,'' it's impossible to tell if he wrote the songs in five minutes or five years. They use rudimentary chords and melodies as basic as folk songs; the lyrics can be as simple as these lines from ''Scattered'': ''I'm a little bit wrong, I'm a little bit right/ I hear your name all through the night.'' Only the extra-thick, grungy fuzz tone on the guitars betrays that the album was recorded in the 1990's rather than at any time in the last quarter century.

title: Theater Review;Evoking 'Streetcar' Flavor at Bay Street
description: TO playwrights of another era, Tennessee Williams was an unspoken idol -- intimidating, inspiring, omnipresent, the eternal muse. Nearing the outspoken end of the century, new playwrights, represented in regional theaters countrywide, are no longer laboring under the influence of the master of American lyric theater. They are simply shouting out in tribute, perhaps not knowing that there is a real trend emerging out there.

title: A Gallery's Farewell to This Side of the River
description: AFTER next Sunday, the Trans Hudson Gallery here is closing and moving trans-Hudson, reopening at 416 West 13th Street in the West Village. Hence the present show, by Carl Andre and Melissa Kretschmer, is its last, and this is as much a farewell as a review. The change promises to be momentous for the dealer, Joseph Szoecs, and the handful of New Jersey artists he takes with him, but it will certainly leave New Jersey esthetically impoverished.

description: I was struck less by the lack of violence reported in Adrian Nicole LeBlanc's article, "A Woman Behind Bars Is Not a Dangerous Man" (June 2), than by the lack of even the slightest suggestion of any constructive activity for inmates.

description: Kathleen Dooley Collier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Collier Jr. of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Eric Clemens Benda, a son of Christian Benda and Joan Mooney, both of Portsmouth, N.H. Msgr. Benedict F. Tighe performed the ceremony at St. Leo's Church.

title: POLITICS: THE UNIONS;Citing Abortion Bill Veto, Union Head Rejects Clinton
description: The head of the 100,000-member bricklayers' union has broken ranks with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and rejected its endorsement of President Clinton by announcing that he will not vote for the President because he vetoed a bill that would have banned a type of late-term abortion.

title: Private Gardens Open Gates to Enthusiasts
description: WHY can't we have something like this at home?'' asked a woman from Scarsdale while admiring a rose garden belonging to a retired army major on a visit to Cornwall, England, several years ago.

title: So I'm Shallow'
description: THE BEAUTY OF MEN By Andrew Holleran. 272 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;A Temple to the Present Leans Heavily on the Past
description: THE New Museum of Contemporary Art is a square, firm, well-made frame. The building will disappoint those who think that a contemporary art museum should be housed within an architectural wild child, a structure as provocative as the art it displays. But it should gratify those who revere Chicago as the first city of American architecture.

description: Finding Danish Relatives

title: SOAPBOX;A Tale of Two Harlems
description: I KNOW that the merchants of 125th Street are struggling. I see them every week through the windows of my tour bus. They're battling a two-sided negative public image. First, there's the outsider impression that Harlem is a dangerous place and not a shopper's paradise. Second, there's the residents' view that those store owners who live outside the area are rich, making money off the backs of the poor.

title: On the Ground, A Few Chances to Light Up
description: PERHAPS few changes say as much about the growing intolerance of public smoking in the United States as the fact that the phrase ''whistle stop'' in railroad parlance has been replaced in more modern times by ''smoke stop.''

title: Allan Beigel, 56, Adviser on Mental Health
description: Dr. Allan Beigel, a psychiatrist at the University of Arizona who served as an adviser on mental health in the Carter Administration, died on June 22 at his home in Tucson. He was 56. The cause was a brain tumor, his family said.

title: Fatal Incompetence in Dhahran
description: Defense Secretary William Perry announced yesterday a series of steps to protect American military personnel in Saudi Arabia -- including a wider perimeter around the housing complex that was bombed last week, killing 19 American servicemen. His announcement came at the end of a week in which the Pentagon refused to concede that its security precautions were wholly inadequate and offered one unconvincing and contemptible excuse after another.

title: F.B.I. FINDS CLUES TO THE TRUCK USED IN SAUDI BOMBING
description: F.B.I. agents were reported today to have uncovered the first leads in the investigation of the bombing here that killed 19 Americans, and the Defense Department announced that it would make changes in security at American military installations in Saudi Arabia.

title: Return Engagement For Basketball Camp
description: IT is unusual in Westchester County, known for an opulent life style and expensive homes, for the affluent and the disadvantaged to interact with one another, but beginning next month, youths from well-to-do families will gather with boys and girls who have been forced to cope with illness, tragedy or broken homes. The motivation is a love of basketball.

title: Wilder on 'Life and Death and Things Like That'
description: ONCE, educators theorized about going ''back to basics.'' Some still do. And actors constantly talk of being ''in the moment.'' The theories and the talk have to do with getting rid of the extraneous, with recognizing, capturing and holding onto an essence, a fundamental thing (experience) from which all else (knowledge and enlightenment) springs.

title: The School Bell Tolls for Shop Class
description: IT was the last day of school at Hoboken High, with dismissal scheduled for noon. A side door in Bob Callahan's wood shop class was opened onto the sidewalk and the sun tumbled in, lighting specks of sawdust adrift in the air. The workbenches were tidy now, the machines cleaned and stowed.

title: The Past Faces Off Against the Present
description: THE exhibition is called ''Nude: A Comparison of the Body of the Artist in Video From the 1970's and 1990's,'' but it feels more like a confrontation than a comparison. Even the format of the presentation at the Trans Hudson Gallery here -- two television sets, one showing a tape from the early to mid-70's, the other its recent counterpart, but facing each other rather than side by side -- implies an either-or rather than both-and. In this face-off, unfortunately, its all too easy to pick the past as the winner.

title: Another View Of Children's Village
description: As Executive Director of the Children's Village, I am writing to respond to your June 2 article [16 Teachers Kept on the Sideline] to clarify the issues. The article portrayed a benign group of teaching professionals. In issuing its injunction, here's how the State Supreme Court described the conduct of these teachers: "This court condemns any attempt by (the teachers) to deliberately involve highly vulnerable and emotionally disturbed children in its labor/management disputes. These children make up a special population who have been placed at Children's Village specifically for treatment in a controlled residential environment which is safe from conflict so that they may heal . . . any attempts to embroil them in a labor dispute are reprehensible."

title: BASEBALL;Studying to Be a Star
description: It was Friday night, about two hours before the Mets would play the Astros to open a three-game series in the Astrodome. A member of the Mets' clubhouse crew interrupted Manager Dallas Green's pre-game news conference, seeking a statistical report on the Houston hitters at the request of Todd Hundley.

title: 100 YEARS OF PICTURES
description: I scarcely recognized Eugene Richards from your description of him as a "chronicler of the grisly." Yes, some of his most powerful images depict, for example, drug users and emergency rooms. But to dwell upon these raw topics is to miss other, more celebratory, stories and to neglect the true focus of the photographs: the people within them. Whether he is photographing a new mother seconds after birth or a troubled addict moments before shooting up, he brings to the photograph a compassionate concern for the person before the camera.

title: Intimate Dining, and Roses, in Piermont
description: THIS particular Xaviar's is not for the many. At the Garrison branch, the capacious dining rooms can accommodate all aspiring guests, and Peter Xaviar Kelly, the chef and owner, can be generally welcoming. And on Piermont Avenue, his casual adjoining wine bar announces itself to all passers-by with hospitable open door and lots of glass for peering in. But next door, his premiere restaurant issues no invitation; those seeking something close to perfection in this life will -- by reservation only -- notice the portal discreetly marked ''Entrance.''

title: Asia
description: While smoke-free skies, trains, hotel rooms and restaurants are fast becoming the norm in the United States, tobacco smoke still wafts through much of the rest of the world. Eastern Europeans consider smoking an inalienable right; Parisian restaurateurs shrug as patrons puff away in areas designated no smoking; Italian efforts are focused on establishments that cater to Americans. Restrictions abroad in movie theaters and lobbies, on trains, planes and buses, vary widely. It can be a shock to American travelers to find that in Tokyo restaurants are cloaked in a tobacco haze (but commuter trains and subways are smoke-free) just as foreign travelers may be confounded by no-smoking rules in New York City. In South America and Mexico, smoke is still savored, but in Canada, opponents of smoking are pushing hard to clear the air. What follows are reports on where in the world people smoke, and where they don't.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Things as They Are
description: Dorothea Lange (1895-1965) was a complex woman who excelled at making straightforward images. To show things as they are was the challenge she set herself; to her that meant a simple and direct portrayal of people firmly rooted in their time and place. Lange moved from New York to California in 1918, having picked up her technical training by doing odd jobs in Manhattan studios. She became friends with a circle that included Imogen Cunningham and Ansel Adams, and for a time ran a successful portrait business. During the early years of the Depression, when breadlines and picket lines formed in San Francisco, she began to photograph trouble in the streets. Subsequent work in the 1930's focused on rural poverty and migration, which she documented for studies directed by her husband, the economist Paul Taylor, as well as for the Farm Security Administration. THE PHOTOGRAPHS OF DOROTHEA LANGE (Hallmark Cards/Abrams, $35) includes her famous images, like "Migrant Mother," as well as those from other, less well-known series, like those on the internment of Japanese-Americans in 1942, on war workers in a California shipyard and on a California public defender's office. By her choice of perspective, use of gesture and framing, Lange's photographs convey her empathy and passionate belief in human dignity. The book, with text by Keith F. Davis, who has written extensively on American photography, reflects Lange's taste with its spare presentation of 85 reproductions and accompanying quotations or comments, a device Lange often used herself. Rosemary Ranck

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;The Nanny
description: It is 1970, and a 20-year-old Jewish student of philosophy in Antwerp is reading obsessively, though Nietzsche and Schopenhauer hardly satisfy her. Not surprising, since Chaya is in search of a way of dealing with the horrors of the Holocaust. She blazes through books about Judaism, as well as physics and astronomy, but her most sophisticated readings are of her parents and the Kalmans, the Orthodox family for whom she works as a nanny. Chaya's mother, once "harnessed like a donkey to a cart that she had to pull along the streets of Auschwitz," now dedicates herself to baking and weaving. Chaya's father is absorbed by plans to dig up the suitcases that he buried during the war. In Jeannette K. Ringold's translation from the Dutch of Carl Friedman's novel THE SHOVEL AND THE LOOM (Persea, $20), the author perfectly accomplishes the delicate task of making unspeakable stories at once accessible and shocking. Three-year-old Simcha Kalman takes Chaya by surprise: though his life is governed by laws she mistrusts, she finds herself falling in love with him. Indeed, this devotion presents itself as a vital part of her search for meaning. Yet in the end, the author gives even this small redemption a tragic twist, as if to acknowledge the ultimate inexplicability of life. Katherine Alberg

title: No Smoking' In Translation;Europe
description: While smoke-free skies, trains, hotel rooms and restaurants are fast becoming the norm in the United States, tobacco smoke still wafts through much of the rest of the world. Eastern Europeans consider smoking an inalienable right; Parisian restaurateurs shrug as patrons puff away in areas designated no smoking; Italian efforts are focused on establishments that cater to Americans. Restrictions abroad in movie theaters and lobbies, on trains, planes and buses, vary widely. It can be a shock to American travelers to find that in Tokyo restaurants are cloaked in a tobacco haze (but commuter trains and subways are smoke-free) just as foreign travelers may be confounded by no-smoking rules in New York City. In South America and Mexico, smoke is still savored, but in Canada, opponents of smoking are pushing hard to clear the air. What follows are reports on where in the world people smoke, and where they don't.
